reviews.review: A great way to see street life. We caught the tram from Central back to North Point, which took 20-30 minutes. Along the way you see the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong as people go about their daily activities. We sat up the top at the front seat and took a lot of photos as we travelled along. Will be doing this each time I go to Hong Kong.
Ding Ding. Ding - microwave in HKDing Ding - tram in HKUltra fun and soooooooooooo cheap (HKD 2.3 per ride) - give a go
Nice view for a low cost. It gives a pretty nice view at the evening of the city area. Apart from catching Tramways I would recommend also walking around in the Western district area.
Take a Tram for a cheap fun sightseeing trip. Take a Tram as an excellient fun way of seeing Hong Kong.The Trams are very frequent and very cheap to use.

Another must do in this city.. Really a way of getting to know other people and seeing into other properties. I suppose you are a bit of a voyeur but no-one seems to mind. We rode several while there.
Cute from the outside but .... big deal. The tramways are a good way to get around, but pretty hard to navigate. People are rude and pushy, and you need to watch your purse!

Great way to see the city. If you want to explore the city limits just hop onto this tram and sit back relax and enjoy the slow and steady ride.We simply jumped into a random tram and went all the way till the terminal. Go for this after sunset as things can get hot and humid. Cheapest way to check out the city, just 2.5HKD is charged on your Octopus card irrespective of the destination. Will recommend this.

A very fun way to get around. These trains run up and down the Hong Kong business areas. We hopped on one for a short ride. Very fun for our son who loves trains. They also look cool and are great for tourists. Cheap also.

Scenic ride of Hong Kong on ground level. Excellent way to see Hong Kong on ground level instead of traveling MTR underground all the time. I grew up in Hong Kong and lived there till 1965. It provided nostalgic memories of the days with less population, air and noise pollution.

Unchanged for a hundred years. Many roads had changed over the years, many lanes had merged with others of closed. But this tramline has not. It cost very little. Something like $0.40 cents? One pays as one leaves the tram. Years ago, the upper deck was for rich people, the servants, amahs with their groceries, the delivery men, all took to the lower level as it was half the price of upper deck. Now it is the same price. One can have a great tour of H.K. On the tram from the western tip, to Shaukiwan, the almost end of the tramline. Oh there is Happy Valley tram as well. It travels the almost oval shape of the race course. Fun!

Great way to see the city.. Hop on and off these trams and take in the sights and sounds of Hong Kong. Get a seat up front on top for the best view. Didnt have an oyster card but it was only 2.50HKD each so nothing really. Best way to get around Hong Kong.
Yay for the tram. Hot, sticky, bustling good fun (and an effective mode of transport). The tram was packed full of maids (it was a sunday) but everyone was very nice and made room for me and my baby.

Love the Ding Ding!!!. Whenever I am in HK I always try to ride the Ding Ding! On this last trip I took the MTR out to Kennedy Town and had a walk around the waterfront, and then took the Ding Ding back to Wan Chai. If you can snag a seat on the upper deck the views are better, I love seeing the shops along the way especially in the Western District, and then the hustle and bustle of Central. A word of caution, do not stick your head or hand/arms out the window as the trams pass extremely close to one another.
Easy commuting . A great way to get around all trips $2.30HK(90c AU) a tip to make your life easier is you must have the correct money or a Oyster card.

not to be nissed. If you have any interest in transport history or just fancy a cheap fun activity the trams are great value for money. the are good for short distance travel around the central areas of Hong Kong island but for longer trips the mrt is a much better option unless you are just sightseeing.

Love the ding ding tram. These drivers are champs! They have to fight off crazy drivers and crazy pedestrians while trying to get people to their destination on a fixed route in a timely manner. The trams are so cute and very inexpensive. But if you're trying to get across town in a hurry, just take the metro! If you have time to enjoy the views and soak in the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong, take the ding ding :)
Fun, crowded but worth it. Excellent way to see HK - from a "Ding Ding" Just travel a few stops - but to go the whole length of HK Island can take 1.5 hours

Tram Love. The trams in Hong Kong is one of the oldest, iconic and best ways to see the different districts on HK Island. Just make sure you get to sit so you can really relax and sightsee, if you are standing be prepared to be pushed around a bit as it does get busy during certain hours and the trams are quite small. Get the chairs towards the from as they have the best view especially if you like taking photos. The fare is quite cheap, HK$2.30 to anywhere the tram goes.

Ding Ding to see and experience unique HK. This experience is unique. Strongly recommend to experience this across Hong Kong island. You need to relax and NOT rushing for appointments or meetings. Try seating on the upper deck to view the lights of the city and see people just rushing by.

A Ding Ding Slice of History. My girlfriend really wanted to ride the trams, so innocently we hopped on the oldest looking one we could find, she loves the vintage feel, of things..... We didn't realise that the tram went the wrong way, and ended up in the wrong place... However we jsut got the next one back and transferred ! Great mini adventure.

Local Experience. Excellent experience to travel HK Isaland by tramways You could find the local stuff in detail by this as it runs slowly. It is also convenient and connected few attractions like Victoria Park.

Bang for your bucks here. So cheap to ride on this tramway, assume if you have time, nice day, going to Happy Valley, North Point or Causeway bay..
My fav weekend ride. It remind me of Europe, Melbourne, San Francisco..

Fun, easy way to travel. Cramming into one of the old trams is a fun way to get around town. Probably not so enjoyable if extremely hot! Costs $2.30 HK, jump on back of the buss , pay at the end departing from the front of the bus!
Ride on top!. The tram may be slow, but it is a great way to see the city and is very cheap. I rode on the top in the front seat and got some good photos.

Fun experience . I was taken on the tram by members of my boyfriend's family who live in Hong Kong as they said it was a good experience. There are easier ways to get around such as buses or mtr however it was a fun experience to use the tram! Would recommend as a tourist activity to go somewhere once or twice but wouldn't suggest using trams all the time to get around hong kong
Love love love. Always have to take the tram for as long a trip as possible sitting at the top in the front - what a fabulous cultural artifact and wonderful that it's still functional

Hong Kong Trams - a must do attraction. The tram system in Hong Kong is a must do ride for any visitor who hasn't used it before. It only runs on Hong Kong Island and used to mark out where the harbour front used to be. These days, decades of land reclamation has meant that a lot of the tramways are now many blocks in from the harbour. The trams are great for shorter journeys and you avoid having to go all the way down into the subway and then out again if you were to use the MTR - the stations are deep and huge and it can take some time just to get to an MTR platform. The fare anywhere on a tram is just $2.3 which is just dirt cheap. They are often packed full but run very frequently so you rarely have to wait more than a couple of minutes for the next one to come along. They are generally not air conditioned so are a bit uncomfortable in the summer but still tolerable. Some of the tram cars are very, very old but still functional. But the rolling stock is gradually being upgraded and the newer trams are reasonably comfortable. You just get on at the rear of the car, exit from the front and pay as you leave by cash or Octopus card. No change is given if paying by cash. Even if you only do it once, make sure you take a tram ride on your visit.

Great Way to See the City. We rode the tram all over the city. It provided a great way to see the city from above ground. It is slower than the underground, and does not cover Kowloon. More locals seem to take the tram.

An excellent way to get around on Hong Kong Island. These trams are used by locals and tourists alike. They are double decker trams which run east - west along the island. An excellent way to have a look around the cites and stop at various shopping and market areas. They run every couple of minutes till about 9pm and are kept clean and tidy. Payment method is by Octopus card which by purchased at 7/11 stores

Ok this is the best way to see Hong Kong. It's like US$0.50. You get on and find your way to the upper level. Have a seat and watch the city unfold before you. No annoying tour guides. Can't recommend highly enough. This is the way to experience HK.
A fun ride - although a bit bumpy. The tramways (trolleys/streetcars) of Hong Kong are an institution. Good for a short ride, albeit a bit bumpy. Obviously, the upper deck is best for sightseeing.

Double decker trams.... Had a ball on the east /west tram just cruising gently across Hong Kong...amazing how they build so many high rise buildings in a small area.Gives a great aspect on the the life on HK people...

Ding Ding. A nostalgic way to commute. At times overcrowded (Sunday afternoon), hot (with the windows down) and a little frustrating having to try and squeeze past people to get to the front to pay. A good way to take in some local culture. Also Octopus card friendly

Skip the subway, see the city. Great way to see Hong Kong Island and actually take in the city, as opposed to the subway - which is about 10 times as quick and has airconditioning. But... no airconditioning aside, it was great to sit on the top deck and absorb the beautiful skyline and city views. Enjoyed this very much. Price is about €0,25 per trip.
Great way to get around HK!. Not the fastest firm of transport and won't get you everywhere you want to go but what a great way to see the city! And so cheaply! Must do.
A fun way to get around the city. We had such fun riding the trams. They were easy to use - simply pay our dollar at the end of the trip (honour system!) It was a good way to see parts of the city.
So cute and such fun. Absolute must have experience - riding on the tram - efficient, friendly and just great fun. Mind your head though - not much headroom.

Quaint but interesting . Took this tram along the Hong Kong line sitting downstairs.You enter from the back and find a seat either downstairs or upstairs. If an elderly person needs a sweat then you are obliged to give yours up.Payment is by the front door and we used the octopus card at around HK 2.50 which is great value.Very narrow carriage but seats are ok.A great experience unlike anywhere else

A very economical way to explore HK!. If you are travelling on leisure, and have plenty of time, why not take a tram trip to browse HK? Take the lines towards North Point, happy valley and feel free to hop up n down to explore HK (eg north point vegetable market, wanchai Johnston road, etc) To enjoy your trip, be aware not to travel at peak hours! Enjoy the trip! Don't just look down at your mobile~

A relaxing way to enjoy the city. The fare is really low, only $2.3 for adults. The speed of the tram is always below 50km/h. To be exact, it is around 30-40 km/h all the time (p.s. GOOD NEWS for POKEMON TRAINERS!)

Moving history. A historic sight in Hong Kong. You can see trams or trolleys in museums around the world. You can ride them at amusement parks to go nowhere.But in Hong Kong, they are still being used as a mode of transport!!!Bring your camera and a few Hong Kong dollars and you are in store for a quaint ride taking you back to the early and mid 20th century. Faster than walking, but not in the league of the high speed trains in Japan (ha ha). You will not set any new speed records, but you will be on a living bit of history, so who cares?No aircon, however, so riding in the heat could cause some stress.

Very frequent and quaint. The double decker trams run along the north side of HK Island. Very frequent and very efficient and they mingle with the rest of the traffic. Board at the back and pay as you leave at the front, preferably with your octopus card..

Save your hard earned money and travell in style!. Imgaine spending too little n getting the most out of it and taking fabulous pictures in a slow moving vehicle?Welcome to Hong Kong Tramways!Check out the Tramways and its been operating for 100 years I guess!

Fun to watch . We did not ride these, however they are very cheap and go across the city.They are a little bit of a Marvel and worth at least a look at it if not a ride.They are the oddest looking street cars I have ever seen!

Quaint,interesting ride. The commentary was interesting and with lots of humour thrown in. It gave a good insight of the history and culture of Hong Kong. Had a bit of a problem locating the starting point but the locals were very helpful in giving us directions

Go back in time. A lovely gesture to the old days of Hong Kong. The narrow gauge trams run along the length of the island and for a few pence you can sit in these time capsuals for as far as you want to go and take life in the slow lane for a while.

Catch Pokemon on the Ding Ding. The tram is a good way to see HK island. Gives you a real flavour and smell of the neighborhoods from Sheung Wan to Causeway Bay and beyond. Sit on the top deck for photos. Seems a great place to catch Pokemon too!

Great fun. The trams are very cheap and easy to use. We rode up and down on them from Hong Kong town centre and back for a couple of dollars. Pay the driver on the way off. Try and sit next to a window as they have no glass!
Great experience to take you back in time. Classic tram service and a efficient one at it. Trams look just so beautiful in HongKong! So well maintained as well.

It's a beautiful day in the neighborhood.... Looking to just sit down, relax, have views of the city and people watch...this is the best way! A cheap ticket, I rode the full route of Tramways, both directions, it was so neat, and nice way to be in the city without the hassle. Nice to do late afternoon and early evening as the city lights up. Easy to day dream and fall into the views!

Back in memory land. It's always fascinating to ride the tram in Hong Kong island. I'll always take a ride every time i visit. It always gives me an old Hong Kong feel. Just take the line that travel across causeway bay.

Rickety sure, but fun. I mainly used the different coloured trams whilst in Hong Kong, because the tram stop was practically outside my hotel.They travel from one end of the island to the other. Sure they have hard seats, no air-conditioning, but they have atmosphere. I didn't sit upstairs as I have a wonky knee but still managed to get a seat downstairs and see the sights and get a breath of cool air as we went along the route. Use your Octopus card, as I did, transport fares are cheap in HK. Of course, they do take longer than the MTR.
Kids loved riding these . A slow but inexpensive way to get around Hong Kong. Key benefit is getting to see some of the city, which you miss in a train
Most lovely and cheapest public transport in HK. You can enjoy the views and the breeze in Tram (fare is constant 2.3 HKD) although it's not the best choice in traffic hours

a fastinating way to see Hong Kong. this is a well run service that is busy but fun and a great way to get about. The octopus card makes it easy and its cheap a nice experience to add to the whole Hong Kong adventure.
fun rides !. A little confusing if you haven't been on them before but small change is essential. Riding on the top deck gives you a better view of the city.

Holiday trip. is a very unique experience there as it is one of hong kong culture, the ride cost 2.30hkd for and adult, the good thing is that the price is fixed. the tram move rather slow but it is good to tour around the hong kong island i would strongly suggest people who visit there to have a go

History made modern. The Hong Kong trams are a unique feature of the island. They have a limited coverage but they are a magic way of seeing much of the old city. Get on at the back and have your Octopus card ready when you leave.
convenient way to get around. very cheap and affordable way to get around. You would use the MTR as your first option if it was for speed but for seeing some more of HK, this is great

Slow Ride in HK Island. This is an unique transportation, very inexpensive to sight see some part of the HK island. The routes are limited so be sure to go to their web site to check out the routes and time.
Double decker transpo. Riding in this tramways is easy and fast too. It's near in our hotel and the stop overs are nearby in shopping places and tourist spots.

use the octupus card. Use the octupus card to get onto the tramway
Use the tramway to see where all the shops are and then make a note and come back later to do shopping
cool experience
Possibly the best bargain in HK - wonderful HK Island ride, esp at night. Go on this for over an hour chunking slowly along HK and see the real HK pass you buy. Great views and super cheap.
Great bargain sightseeing . Discovered this little gem on our recent travels. Cheap $2.30hkd trip around Hong Kong Island. Bit bumpy but an easy way around town. Very frequent services.

cheapest way of sightseeing. we went all the way from kennedy town to shau kei wan. i higly recommend anyone try it, although the best sights are from sheung wan to north point. we loved that each tram has its unique color and paint/advertisement (we even spotted one with an arnold schwarzenegger ad!).
To do. It is definitely something to do to ride one of these historical tramways. Also it is very cheap : 2 HKD!

Good to see local life. Very slow compared to metro but cheap at 2.3HKD per trip for an adult and gives the chance to see the busy roads and markets. More of a one off experience than a regular mode of transport for tourists. Very useful for short trips though

A must try experience . Easy to use - just jump on at a stop and scan your octopus card when you get off - it's a flat rate minimal cost. Everybody seems to gradually drift towards the front whether stood up downstairs or upstairs so that they are always ready to hop off.It's a great way to travel and a lovely alternative to the MTR. Get yourself an octopus card to make things easier although cash is accepted by the driver.
Must do experience. Not only is this very easy, cheat and convenient you get to see the island for next to nothing and experience life as a resident
Party Tram. Great way to see the city, a must to do if your travelling Hong Kong.love the idea of sitting back and seeing the sights either in airconditiong or out on the top Deck..

Unique experience to Hong Kong. Maybe I didn't get the full Ding Ding experience in my 3 days visiting Hong Kong, but it was a very good and unique way to move about Central Hong Kong. Definitely a first for me, my tour guide and I used Ding Ding to move about Central. Once again, the Octopus card is so beneficial to moving about public transport in the city. I would revisit Hong Kong and plan a day of getting the most out of Ding Ding, but for this visit it missed the mark when compared to Star Ferry. I hope Hong Kong can hold onto this nostalgic piece of transport history.

Great way to see the city. Although the tram is old fashion, slow and no air conditioner, this is a great way to see the city clearly and it's only cost HK$2.30 (US$0.30). If you have time, just try it....

Best way to feel Hong Kong from one side to the other. either for a party or as a public transportation, you will feel something. Slower than a bus, you can take nice shots of Hong Kong from the upper deck. A must towards any direction.

Best affordable scenic city ride . Retained from the bygone era of Hong Kong, the tramways known affectionately locally as the 'dingding' does offer locals and tourists an alternative yet convenient transportation within the city with a perspective of the sights and sounds of the city as it meanders through.A definite must for travelers to Hong Kong as at HK$2.20, it's probably the cheapest yet most experiential glimpse into the bustling city!

Always the star of HK. The tram ride is always my first choice if time is not of essence. It is cheap and easy to ride toiling daily from the ends of HK island east to west. Brings back the good feel of yesteryears. Taking a seat on the top floor will give you uninterrupted views of your journey and try to do this during off -peak period for the best possible experience you can get. Hope it stays in Hong Kong for as long as possible.

Point A to Point B. You ride the Ding Ding for the experience of saying "...I've ridden a Ding Ding" and as a mode of public transport. The network is quite limited but they are very frequent and they will get you from one side of Hong Kong (city not Island) to the other quickly and cheaply.Ride at night for the best experience.
Short trip. Classic old thin double decker trams.Easy to find and navigate, cheap $2.30 tickets, very crowded, more difficult to get off, but great fun.

Love this tram!. I stayed at Wan Chai. I used to take this tram everyday. If you're in rush, then avoid this because it gets stuck in traffic. However, I found it great.. it's slow so I can enjoy and look around. Its cheap. Make sure to enter from the last door, and exit from the first door. You can use your Octopus card.

Only second to the star ferry. We loved riding the trams, so easy to navigate, work out whether you're going east or west and hop on via the back. Tap out with octopus at the front when you get off. The best way to experience the hustle and bustle through the open windows with our having to walk through it. A strangely peaceful and calm experience. Takes longer than the metro but if you have time for leisurely journey it's just lovely. Sit upstairs near the front it you can. Would have been 5* however the trams travelling east at 6ish we pretty rammed. Still loved it though!

Colourful!. We only did one tram ride from Kennedy Town to Healthy Street East on a weekday. It took about 45mi a and is pretty slow. It's a nice trip through the heart of Hong Kong. It can get a bit stuffy but the views are really good if you're sitting upstairs. We were fascinated at the various colours of the Trams and counted more than 20 colour Trams on our trip!
Cheap cheap cheap. These skinny old donkeys rumble along and are very accessible. They can get hot though as most are not a/c

Interesting and inexpensive. While in Hong Kong I took the Ding Ding from downtown to the terminus in the east one evening, just for the heck of it! I opted for a seat on the upper deck and had an interesting view of the hustle & bustle of the city. It was a cool day, with a light breeze blowing through the open window, but I can imagine how uncomfortable it would be in the heat of the day.Each ride costs HK$2.30, what an inexpensive way to have a city tour.

Most Leisure way to get around in Hong Kong Island. The iconic transport only available in Hong Kong Island.Flat rate trip, two decker, no air conditioning.You can easily burn your afternoon / evening with a ride from Western or Central Hong Kong all the way to the East.Recommend for all kind of traveller, who like to explore more.You can also book a special tour train in advance and provided more history and info about our "Ding-Ding" tram.
inexpensive way to see the city.... We spent several hours just taking the "Ding Ding" and seeing Hong Kong from the streets. You can get on and off very easily...

What you pay is what you get. Cute experience. This tram is nice but slow. The trip fare is really cheap and you can enjoy the view if you want to see the city of hong kong.you cannot be lost in the tram direction and you have several trams along the way.It is best to ride trams in their cold season as it is not air conditioned.

Worth a try. Ding ding, as locals call it, has been in existence for many years. It is liked by the elderly as a means of transportation due to its moderately slow speed. Ding ding only exists in HK side. There are special Ding ding for special occasions such as private parties. If you have time, I would suggest you hop on one and go from the west end of town to the east and vice versa. A very pleasurable ride.
so cool. HK trams are great, they were built during the golden age of the twentieth century when people knew what good proportions were. You must ride, at least once in your life!

Still my favorite way to handle the city.. By far the way to move around Central Causeway Bay and more… Many stops, No rushing crowd and excellent feel of a legendary tram! Also cheaper that the crazy MRT… Just make sure to have coins in your pocket ($2.30 $HK)
undispensable in and out. for a good feeling of Hong Kong life take the trams....comfortable the upper decks...we combined trams with MTR as per our needs without problems.
Tram ride. This is a good way to get around hong kong island very cheap good for spotting side street markets get off and explore seeing the sights
Almost free sightseeing tour. The tram is a nice way to see a large part of the Island from west to east. Not much air-condition and fresh air on the top floor

Slow but good way to see Hong Kong . The ding ding tram is super cheap and the same price no matter what distance you travel (about 23p with an octopus card). It's a nice leisurely way to look out the window and see the real Hong Kong. You can get on and off outside MTR stations if you only want to do part of your journey.I recommend going in off peak times so you get a seat as your feet can get a bit sore standing for a long time!
Ding ding!. A taste of older times, this was a very nice ride through the streets of Hong Kong. You can use your Octopus card and it is ridiculously cheap.

Trams look like Harry Potter Knight Bus. These tall, narrow trams are a great way to travel along Hong Kong Island for only HK2.30 flat fare (exact cash required). Sitting on the top front seats is a perfect way to see the streetscapes and take in all the contrasts of the city. An enjoyable, cheap way to see some of the city and efficiently move from place to place.

Great way to see HK. I did a two way trip , Kennedy Town to Happy Valley. Sit upstairs next to a window and you get a good cool breeze whilst tram is moving. Best way to see the length of HK with the harbour on one side and the peak on the other...great way to orient yourself on first visit...also pretty inexpensive...I enjoyed it greatly and in the end, I got off at Central and was in the middle of everything.

Must do in Hong Kong. Board in to the tram and enjoy the scenes from upper floor. You get a free sightseeing tour (nearly free, I think the cost is $2). Once you leave the tram flash your Octopus card.

Ding Ding is the best transportation on HK side. This is the one transportation you won't get lost in (just don't get on the one that say Happy Valley if that's not your destination). Yes it is slow but you get to see Hong Kong slowly (& no need to walk if u r tired). Best time is riding it during Fall/Winter time when the weather is nice n cool. Just hop off if u see something interesting...is so cheap it will not hurt your pocket even u keep getting on n off. For me I usually turn on my google map n I just get off when my destination is nearby..so much better than climbing up n down from the MTR and having to find the closest exit. It might takes bit longer so leave enough time to enjoy this slow ride on Hong Kong side.
GOOD EXPERIENCE. Cheap and fun ride around town. Tram very frequent and have multiple stop location including some MTR station. Sit on top deck for better viewing of the city

Easy and fun way to see HK. The trams are a great way to transit the main areas of HK island, from Kennedy Town across to Causeway Bay and beyond. If you ride up on the top deck you get a little better view of the passing scene. Hope on and off with your Octopus card.
Old school HK. Definitely worth a ride because1. it's cheap2. you get to see the sights & sounds along city areas such as Causeway Bay3. it's a huge part of HK history!

Best way to see Hong Kong island . The trams have always been a feature of Hong Kong life, for over a century. The modern tram can have air conditioning. It is such a convenient and low cost transportation it is always a bit crowded. Touring For tourists the best way to see Hong Kong is to start from the terminal station in the Western District or the Eastern District, hop on, go up to the top deck and try to get the front row seat. Otherwise, any window seat is great. Then see the various districts as the tram goes from stop to stop. Hop off when you are done and pay when leaving. You can pay with coins or the prepaid Octopus card. I think the entire ride is about US 40 cents. Bring a nice cold beverage and a camera. As practical transpirationIt sure beats going into the Mass Transit Railway (MTR) as there is no need to climb in and out, down and up all the MTR stations. That is, provided you are travelling along the northern shore of Hong Kong Island. The trams do not go elsewhere. It sure beats taxis. Taxis are snooty and hard to flag down. Empty taxis cover their meter and pass you right by. Then when you get one you are stuck in traffic jam. Tram lines are free from motor traffic. And they arrive at stops regularly. So it often is the fastest way to go.

Quaint but Slow. This is an excellent way to travel through Hong Kong Island's Streets. Very cheap KHD2.30 for adults and HKD1.10 for senior ... flat rate for any distance. But be warned, it is slow and non-airconditioned. Can get crowded. But considering its history and unique place in modern travel, it is a must-try for an visitor to Hong Kong.

Cheapest way for sightseeing in Hong Kong island. East bound or West bound only costs HKD2.30 and you can pay by either Octopus card or cash (exact amount) as you exit. Seats on the upper deck allow you to get better view of buildings as the tram moves slowly from one stop to another. But be cautious as you climb down the stairs to exit as it's quite narrow.
Please use. Fantastic system, very efficient and so cheap. This is a must for travelling around hong kong. It goes all the way through the city with many stops and you dont get charged per stop.
Crowded. The trams are fun to look at but are very crowded with low headroom and they are extremely hot. Personally we preferred the local buses which are comfier and have air con.
Fun way to see the city. This tram only costs two HK dollars. You board at the back and pay as you get off. You need the correct money. It is a slow journey but a good way to see the city.

Tour around casually . Great way to see the sites and take it all in. After tripping around you can then go back to the stops get off , shop then jump back on. Top level gives you the best ride and not as crowded as downstairs. Very cheap way to get around, however the tramway is limited to where it goes. Children enjoy the experience.

Good way to explore Hong Kong island. The tramways are Hong Kong's oldest means of public transportation dating back to the British colonization. It takes you along the scenic routes of the island where you can hop in and out at only 2.3HKD per pop.TIP: Take the front row of the second deck to get the best views as the tram chugs along the island.
interesting. Iconic method of transport and very cheap. at least you can get rest of walking amongst the awful crowd and watch from above.

The cheapest way to experience Hong Kong Daily living. Each journey cost only 2 HK$. The tram can take you across Hong Kong island from east to west or from west to Happy Valley where the horse race track is. Avoid the rush hour to make sure you can get a seat on the upper deck. You can see the the Hong Kong streets from above.The whole journey may take over an hour. Best to do it in Autumn season around 9 pm after dinner if you have ample time to spare. It is better to board from the Tram Terminal either at western district or eastern district in order to experience the whole route. Please note the tram is not air-conditioned.

Old world charm. The ding dings are slow but a nice way to travel around central HK. The fare is very less and Octopus cards can be used. U get in from the rear enterance and pay from the front while exiting.

Ride like a local. Not my preferred mode of transportation, but if you have some time hop on the 2nd level to ride around town.
It's super cheap to ride ($2 HKD)

Easy to use. The tram stops have maps with English and tell you what direction it's going. Go upstairs for good views, on top of the next team stops it says the tram stop number so you know where to get off. Pay when you get off, it was $2.30 for an adult

Fun and convenient. Took the tram several times on our recent visit. We could use Octopus card for easy access. Tram stop was convenient to our hotel and also to take to restaurants and other attractions.

The double decker tram . We grabbed this tram one evening when coming back from the harbour to our hotel nit is a really cool way to move around Hong Kong city. You can travel a loop around the city and see some city sights too.

Relax moment. I do take the tram some time when the next station is very close and I'm not in a hurry. It is because it is not airline, but you don't hot, all windows are wide open with natural wind. The tram runs slow, so that you can see the shops around and what Hong Kong really looks like, but if you are in a hurry better take the MTR.

An interesting way to communicate in Hong Kong. We love the trams in Hong Kong.However, why do the new trams have any working air-condition? You can visit the whole Island for a very low price. If You can use a retirement ticket/ Octopus Card it is very reasonable way to travel at a low cost.

Fun way to get to places. The TRAM is quite fun to be in. You will get to see the view all the way, it is great for the occasional picture here and there and is very cheap. It gives the city a more traditional touch and it is very simple to use to get to places.

Iconic!. For the HK$2.3 it is the best deal in town! But beware, the ding ding is very slow, so if you need to get somewhere, take the MTR (also very reasonably priced) or big bus (some as low as HK$3.40). It is a great way to see a lot of Hong Kong and get some great pictures. Many locals use it.
the ding dong experience. no trip to hong kong is complete without having taken the tram. it goes to most areas in the island and it is so cheap , you can take it anytime

take a round trip to see HK island. Yes, if you have time on hand take the Ding Ding to go around the Hk island for $2.30 fare. If you sit upstair in the front seat. you will be able to take great photos of HK.
Cheap and efficient transportation on the Island side.. Definitely worth to take a ride and stroll slowly along the northern side of Hong Kong Island. US$0.30 per trip, can't beat the price.

Don't miss the fun, like going back into the past. Also on your MTR pass and extremely cheap to ride. I like to catch it just to ride across town and see the city from the top floor for a better look. I have even gone both ways because its a different way to see an interesting city.

Scenic Tram Travels. The Tram is an iconic Hong Kong tourist attraction. It is also one of the most affordable ways to go about Hong Kong Island. It is recommended for those who have time on their hand, but it will also give you photo opportunities, and scenic tour. You can go to Happy Valley, Western Market, Kennedy Town, and a lot more places with rich history.

Riding into the past. Have stayed in HK for almost 2 years and the pace of the city just keeps you moving, but if you just want to take a step back and enjoy the beauty of the city , take in the smells of the spice market, lurch away in front of the HSBC bank branch

A good way to see local Hong Kong. A good way to look around Hong Kong with the tram.We took the open air tram and as the weather is hot, we were perspiring during the one hour ride.We boarded from Kennedy Town Terminus and alighted at the Happy Valley Terminus. I enjoyed the whole journey, except the weather.Worth taking a ride

Great, cheap way to exlore Hong Kong Island. The tram, or fondly called the ding ding by the locals, is an excellent way of exploring the HK Island side. A ride costs HKD 2.50, flat rate, and it traverses the city. However, because it has so many stops, it's very slow. If you have the time, ride the ding-ding from one end to the other, and make sure you're on the upper balcony so that you get to see the sights in Hong Kong Island.
From another time. You don't see this in too many cities. From an another era. What a great experience. No rush and so fuss. Must try. Uniquely Hong Kong.
Novelty tram. Lovely for a try however the destinations are just other Hong Kong suburbs. Novelty in not too hot weather as the trams are open air. Unique to Hong Kong so worth doing.
The Hong Kong Classic Experience. will be not complete visiting Hong Kong without take tram, take this ride from causeway bay to ferry terminal. for me is more efficient to use tram instead MTR.
Fun Ride. This is a fun ride to take, the tram is very skinny so you may have to squeeze on, go upstairs if you can it's a good way to see the sights.

Cheap & Cheerful Transport. We jumped on at Causeway Bay and got off near our hotel at Sai Wan. A great way to meander through the neighbourhoods of the island an old style tram and very inexpensive. Try to get a seat upstairs at the front.

Charming double decker trams. Hong Kong is one of probably only two or three cities that still operate double decker trams. The network is limited to a few routes only but these trams have their own charm.
Very efficient. We used the trams quite a lot, and it helped us with getting to grips with our whereabouts. They are very efficient, and of course you can see a lot, particularly from upstairs

Cheap way to travel on the island. Great transportation if you want to travel on the HK Island and see the city at the same time. Cost is very reasonable and also great if you want to catch some pokemon.
Great viewing. Great to see so much for Hong Kong, I would suggest going upstairs to look out over the city and making sure you have an Octopus card. Very handy too if you need to escape the rain!
Great way for quick sight seeing. Very nice and old transport tram for a quick tour ride just to glance and compare the neighbourhoods. Can be a bit packed during peak hours.
Fun fun ..ding ding. Great for viewing the city getting ariund getting upstairs is a tiny stairwell but worth it for views

More than a museum curiosity. A friend once said that great cities are those with tramways, and HK Central has its own along Connaught Road.
Although the excellent MTR train service has superseded the tramways to a large extent, the trams still carry a significant volume of passengers each day, and brighten the streets with their precarious height and colorful advertising.
Cheapest way to go around. . It was fun to ride the tram across the town. It might not be fast but it is a nice way to view the town. We sat in the first seats in the upper deck
Trams are a great way to go up and down the Island. I used the trams a lot on a work trip when I had to travel between Causeway Bay and North Point regularly. Very easy to use and cheap!
A must ride when u visit HK. We took the one hour tram tour from the western bus terminus which takes u thru hong Kong history along with land marks of hong Kong .must ride

Fun. Whilst staying in Hong Kong for 4 weeks, we rode on these trams several times. As well as being a quick and easy way to get around, they are also a relaxing way to spend time and see the sights. A few times we just got on the tram near the Kowloon ferry, sat on the top level, right up the front next to the window, and stayed on until it reached the end. As well as a beautiful breeze on a very hot day, it was a lovely way to spend an afternoon. All for the cost of a tram fare.
Ding Ding!. this tram is the best way to enjoy hongkong island because its cheap! get to the top of the tram and enjoy the view.

Like the Harry Potter bus when it squeezed through traffic. The Ding Dings get the name from the sound they make. There are a few different types and you should definately try to get one with the black wooden plate in front - those are the oldest. Super fun thing to do and great way to travel (but slower than metro of course).You enter in the back and exit in front. You also pay after the trip is done (on your way out). Exactl change only - or Oyster card.

Cheap and convenient ride!. Ding ding is definitely one of the cheapest mode of transport that can be used in HK, it only costs about HKD 2.30, it have an easy route as you may find the station in the middle of the street.If you don't feel like walking, Ding Ding is definitely one of transport that can be used!Each station will provide the information of the route, so don't forget to check it first before you take them. Just in case you're going to the wrong direction.
Worth a try but a warning . This is an easy and cheap way to get around IF you aren't fat or tall. Otherwise, you'll be very uncomfortable.

The most traditional and interesting public transport. The tram is definitely the most traditional, interesting and the cheapest (US$0.3 for a single journey) public transport in HK. It can take you from the east side to the west side of HK Island, passing through the old districts of Sai Ying Pun, North Point and Shau Kei Wan, the CBD in Central as well as the busiest shopping paradise of Causeway Bay. You can even take the tram to the race course in Happy Valley. If you are lucky enough, you may even have the chance to get on the first ever air-conditioned tram in HK!

Good way to save your legs. The MTR is way more convenient for getting around, but taking the tram is a fun way to see more of the city. It's best when combined with Wednesday nights at Happy Valley - the row of trams waiting to take people back to town is a symbol of HK.

Cheap and a great way to see Hong Kong Island. You can take the tram from the east side all the way to the west side of Hong Kong Island for a measly US 50 cents, and get to go through very interesting neighborhoods. I always take friends visiting Hong Kong on the team!

Very nostalgic rude to take this transportation form. Very convenient for a quick ride on the ding ding tram. It cost only HK$2.30 to ride one way . My suggestion is to take the team Westbound from Central station at Pedder Street and take the team all the way to Kennedy town to see the older part of HK . Sit all the way to the end of the line that will take you about 15-20 minutes. Remember to sit in the left at the upper deck so that you can stick your head out of the window. Do not sit on the right as your head may get chopped off with the oncoming ding ding going the opposite direction. If you are not the type who can sit for 15-20 minutes get off earlier and walk back to Central and Fahd fans MTR to other places. Quite a nice experience taking these electric Trams.

Cheapest self tour of Hong Kong island. The tram is always a unique way to discover the area in Hong Kong island at a slow relaxing pace. You can start from Sheung Wan and make your way east to Causeway Bay. You enter from the back and you can choose to be seated at the lower or upper deck, though the front seat on the upper deck is the most exciting in my opinion. As the tram makes it way, look around, down and above at the exciting sights. Try to look out for the Peak Tower.When it is reaching your destination, make your way down to the front and pay using your Octopus card and exit. There are also air conditioned trams that you can take as well. And the fare is ard HKD2!

Handy Tram. Best and the cheapest way to travel Hong Kong just for 2 Honk Kong dollar u can the tram . Only tip give change 2 hkd or use octopus card as u don't get the money back. It is really handy just use google if u don't know what's the right stop .

Not exciting. Good to see Hong Kong from street level without having to exert any effort but it is rather slow and there are lots of stops. Great for teh price though, only $2.30HKD for a single trip!

Best and cheapest means of transport on Hong Kong Island. A tram going slowly without airconditioning can still provide an enjoyable ride along the main streets from the west to the east of Hong Kong Island. Very popular for the locals as well as the tourists.

Fun!. This is great activity in rain or shine. Great way to get up and down Hong Kong Island. Its a scenic route. If you pay for the tour, then you have a free pass for 2 days. It was an awesome deal!

fantastic. everyone visiting should try it, its a lot of fun, very clean and safe, makes all the right noises, also very cheap its 2,3 hkd per adult, jump on when you want aswell as off, hope that the city will always keep them going, do try ......
A must in Hong Kong. It is a must to travel with the tramways. It is cheap and you can reach all important spots in Hong Kong island

Pure innocent fun that costs only pennies. Thank the powers that be in Hong Kong that this transport relic of the colonial era hasn't been trashed to give way to modern progress. The trams in Hong Kong remain one of the most enjoyable rides anywhere in the world. Incredibly, it still only costs pennies.
Back to Colonial Time. Cutie trams travelling within Hong Kong Island business district from East Terminal to West Terminal. There are multiple stops available and trams services are regular
Cheap and a must do. No air conditoning though.. Riding the tram is always a cheap and fun way to get aroung downtown HK. You can rent a tram for a private party too!
Great Fun on these old Trams. The famous Hong Kong Trams is a must when visiting this island ,use your octopus card and enjoy the ride

Fun DingDing For a Pokemon Thrill. It was a great experience , DingDing Driver was friendly & helpful, We alight slightly after the station, knowing that we are in the wrong track at Causeway Bay area. It is really an enjoyable cheap ride. Tap your Optopus Card when alighting only. Highly recommend for tourist only, because the pace in Hongkong is so fast & DingDing is so slow, can play Pokemon. Haha!

A great ride on the Island. Take the tram through the city on Hong Kong Island, from Western District to Causeway Bay and see the dynamics of the city. Sit upstairs for better views. Take the tram at night and enjoy the impressive neon lights, it is an experience.... Old & new, a bit colonial but very worthwhile and very affordable... Not really suitable for tall people though.. ;-)

Simple, cheap, efficient, fun and regular.. The ding dings are undoubtedly the easiest and most entertaining way too get around the city. Make sure you have the right money, no change given. It's simply 2.3 dollars to ride no matter how long the journey. This works out to about £ 0.23p!

Nice way to visit the Island. You can spend over an hour in the ding ding for 2,3 HK$, see the busiest shopping street and the business areas, and if you go outside of the peak hours, the tram is not full at all, si that you have almost all the upper deck for yourself. Not too comfortable, and cool, as windows remain open.

Save your legs - hop on on Tram!. At HK$2.30 a ride (for adults) you can hop on board a Hong Kong tram and enjoy cutting through the traffic with ease. Use an Octopus Card rather than carry exact change. Trams are boarded from the rear and exited from the front. You pay on exit. You will need to be able to use stairs to board. In addition there are stairways to the upper deck. No air conditioning but plenty of open windows. Plan ahead to get off as you need to make your way to the front of the tram or miss your stop. Fun and cheap - enjoy the ding ding ride!

blast from the past. it's often warm & humid, there's no aircon but it's charming the way it trundles along & you watch the world go past you. But there are traffic jams even for trams, especially when one breaks down, then they're all STUCK. Don't forget you can use the Octopus card on this relic too

Cheap and cute mode of transport . Very very cheap compare to other transport modes in Hong Kong. It goes little slow, so please be patient if you want to go little long. But this is very nice way to see the city, specially if you could manage to sit on upper floor first seat.

Great way to cross town. These historic throwbacks are a great way to cross town and see the people sights and sounds of Hong Kong. For around H$4 you can ride the length of the line and it will save your feet on a busy day as well as you clothing on a rainy one. Head upstairs for more air and a better view and just ride till you see something you like. It's your own version of a hop on hop off tour.

Squeezy but fast!. You have to try the Ding Ding tram at least once. It was quite an experience for me. I remember taking the tram around evening period and it was so packed. I was standing on the top deck and boy oh boy, we were grabbing onto all the rails and bars that I could reach, especially when the tram turned. But the ride was fast and we got to pass by many areas around the city area.

As time goes by. Hong Kong is my favorite city and this summer I returned to visit the tramway system. Running up the steps to the second floor, I spend hours discovering the city. it is amazing how wonderful those rides were and reviewing my amateurish films, I cannot wait to return to jump on any of this iconic trams. Miss you so very much

Over 110 years public transport in Hong Kong. I love Hong Kong Tramways very much. The reason I live in Hong Kong Island many years. Moreover, it own the largest double deck trams in the world. Another hand, it provide the cheapest fare to us.One of unique wooden passenger tram No.120 maintain 1950s look make passengers imagine back to 1960s view of Hong Kong Streets and cultures. Nowadays, the first air conditioned tram No.88 in service and provide better service for us.It provide tram hire party service that you can choose different style party trams or passenger trams for wedding, birthday, unique buffet so on.

👍. The first thing that comes into my mind when i hear "Hong Kong" is trams. Funny, fast and frequent, they could serve not only as a mean of bringing you from point A to point B, but be an excellent companion, who will show you the city from various angels. I used tram to familiarize myself with HK, when i came there for the first time.

Ring a ding ding. They may be basic and dirt cheap to use but the Ding Ding trams are a brilliant way of seeing the hustle and bustle of downtown Hong Kong from on high. At Causeway Bay, we caught one that had spare seats on its top deck with a route taking it through the centre towards Kennedy Town. They are so frequent we did not have long to wait. Board from the back and exit through the front using an Octopus Card. A great experience.
Low cost travelling in Hong Kong. If you want to plan low cost and budget transport then prefer it. I love tramways. I like to travel with trams.

Good not only for your Pokemon Go. Tramways has long been a signature of HK - exclusively on HK island, except the exhibit in a museum on Kowloon side. It is old but fully functional, in terms of transportation and for sightseeing.Along the journey, you are able see the various faces of the city, from old to modern; tourists may have heard of Central and Causeway Bay, but it's also fun to see the residential side of the island, at Shau Kei Wan (east end), or walk up to the University of HK (HKU) from Sai Ying Pun (west end).The recent fad of Pokemon Go attracted new tram travellers, as they can still play the game during the journey; (with GPS) and the medium speed of tram is quite favourable for egg incubation. LoL.
A good way to relax and see Hong Kong. Get the tram at the Kennedy Town then sit down in the top deck and just relax as the tram travel eastward!

Second best alternative to MTR and way cheaper too. If you are going short distances and don't want to deal with long walks through the MTR station, the tramway is the next best thing to take and the fare is cheap too.I would just not encourage it for long distance trip because then it is way slower than the MTR.

Amusing for a short trip. It costs virtually nothing and is good fun for a short trip (a few stops). We made the mistake of taking it right out to the far end to visit what we thought wouuld be a picturesque fishing village - not recommended... It's very slow and not very comfortable.
Best way to see Hong Kong and all for HK$2.30. You cannot get lost as the trams go East to West and visa versa. No matter how far you travel you only pay HK$2.30 with exact fare or Octopus card.

Good way to see Hong Kong . Incredibly cheap and you can ride from one side if HK Island West to East in a couple of hours for $2.20. Go to the upper deck and get a window seat and get great photographs as the tram stops frequently. Locals use it all the time. The windows slide down to let in any air and there is one tram with air conditioning. As it costs $220,000 to refit a tram with a/c, that's why more haven't been converted but there are plans to change a few more.
trams. This, is a much slower and cheaper form of travel, but sit on the top deck and watch the streets pass by, excellent way to travel and watch the hustle and bustle of Hong kong
Old days. Suddenly you will feel you are at saint Francisco old day ;)Really noce experience with different colours and prints ;)

Great view of city. . There are lots of restaurants at the top nothing super fancy. You can walk the whole thing but you'll burn your legs out. I'd recommend this if you go to Hong Kong is one of your top three things to do to get the best view of the city. Do it at night it's it's even better and can be good if the fog during the day is too thick

Another HK must do. Sure, it's easier to get around using the MTR or even city buses, but the Ding Dings (like the Star ferries) are classics and pretty much a must do when visiting Hong Kong. The only disappointment was that the operators were on the rude side and wouldn't answer our questions asking what stop we should get off at to visit certain sights.

Is this an attraction?. I'm not really sure. Either way, it's a very affordable way to travel: a single, paid at the front when alighting, only costs HK$2.30 (about 25p in the UK). And it is a relatively sedate, relaxing way to see a fair bit of an otherwise frenetic city. Though not at rush hour.

A Plesent Way to Travel. Get your Octopus Card and get on-board. Great way to get around the city of Victoria Island. There is a special Tram Tour at 10:30 every morning which is very informative and gives you a golden ticket for 2 days free travel. Same price whether you travel 1 or a 100 stops.
Slow but good view of the city. The best way to travel and look at the city. However, it lack of air conditioning car so it's really hot in the hot days. The seats are also very hard as well.

great way to see the HK central area. get upstairs and sit in the front row overlooking where the ding ding is going, best view, ride as much as you want, jump off and on. Suggest you ride till you have seen enough hen jump off, go across the street and ride one back!!

We love the Ding Ding. This is a great, inexpensive way to see Hong Kong Island. The Ding Dings are colourful and quaint. Sit up on top and ride as long as you want, the train route goes all the way horizontally across the island.

Can way to slow down and watch the world go by. Very cheap. Get on at back, pay by Octopus when you get off at the front. Trams go through the CBD and onwards along a single line, so get on and ride the tram and get off, cross the road and go the other way....and watch the world go by.A nice way to slow down in a fast moving Hong Kong.....
seat upper very good place. If you want to have good view of hong kong try at least once , great experience they cross the city and very very cheap

112 Years and still the best way to get a tast of the real Hong Kong. Starting in 1904 the trams are now 112 years old, but we have only been using them since 1985. Slow, uncomfortable and often over-crowded, wouldn't miss them for the world. They are a tourist experience par excellence. Road transports answerer to vintage steam trains , but with a couple of added benefits. Firstly they are actually a practice and low cost, means of transport and secondly a trip from the Kennedy Town terminus to the Shau Kai Wan terminus is a comprehensive history/geography lesson about Hong Kong with the added benefit of enjoying the smells of spices and drying fish (on top of the Tram stop shelters) .Entry is at the rear and exit at the front where payment is made. Payment the same for any trip 2 mins or two hour .. Use cash or swipe your Octopus card.Tip In New Zealand we have a famous rugby football team called the All Blacks. one of the Keys to their World Champion status is their scrumaging ability. They learned this by trying to board Hong Kong trams. You may be first in the queue, but when the tram arrives a hoard of elderly Chinese ladies will push you aside and often Europeans are left bewildered at the stop as the overloaded tram departs. Learn fast, at tram stops, in rush hours, its all in fighting, use your knees , elbows, shopping bags, anything to stop being pushed aside. Did I say I have been to Hong Kong now 34 times and love the place.
take a ride!. just jump in behind and pay with your octopuscard in the front. Just stay on the tram till you are back and enjoy this unique way of public transport.
Historical and Cheap!. This trams are so cheap and sometimes can crowded specially on sundays. Just for HKD 2.30 per ride, you can hop on and off anytime.

The Fastest Transport During Traffic Jam. Do you know why HK people called the tram as "Ding Ding"? "Ding Ding" is the horn sound of the tram. In case of danger, the driver will "Ding Ding" the people nearby. Later on, we called it "Ding Ding" and all of the HK people know it.Almost all the trams are the same but there are 2 trams different with others.The newest one, number 88, air-conditioned. Just released in 2016 and having a trial run for 3 months starting from Jun 2016.The oldest one, number 120, most popular one. It is the 1st generation tram and almost all the visitors are waiting for this tram. I have to reminder you and please keep it in mind that the window in very old style. You have to hold tight the handle to pull up or down. If you release your hand at half open, the window will drop down and hit hardly on the frame. Until now, I do not know the teachnique to hold the window at half open.Why I say it is the fastest transport during traffic jam? There is a tram lane for the trams to go through in most of the area. No cars can drive on it. So, there is private path for the tram only.I would like to give a reminder to the tall people. The room height is about 170cm. So, you'd better get a sit, otherwise you have to enjoy the journey with you head down.If you want to enjoy a slow life and see the HK living style and buildings from old to modern then back to old style, I advise you to take the tram. Get on the tram at Shaukeiwan (the eastern terminal) and get the tram to Kennedy Town (the western station). It costs you $2.30 and you can have over an hour trip.

Ding ding. My favorite transport in Hong Kong , no air conditioning, slow go with style like hundred years ago. Running from east to west.A good way to sight seeing along the north coast trough dazzling district , hop on and off at a good eateries along the line.

See the city. Our granddaughter loved the Trams, they are a nice way to get about and see the city. They have a fixed far so sit back and enjoy the trip. It doesn't matter where they go you can always get back to where you started from. Much better than paying for a tourist bus.

Great experience. Get on at the back, pay when you exit. If you're lucky you'll get a seat and a great view as the trams trundle East/West and West/East. If you're sightseeing, just get the first one you see, they all provide the same experience. One route heads off to Happy Valley, the rest pretty much follow the same route, (with some variations). Costs next to nothing and for a tourist it's a scenic and easy journey from Central to Victoria Park in Causeway Bay and back. Beyond that you're into the more suburban areas, not quite as photogenic, but a highly recommended activity.

Novel fun way to get about. Some of these trams are older than me. Run very regularly and can be a bit of a squash.They seem very high up and shoogle about a bit.Like all things transport in HK , you swipe on and off and it's about 50p a journey. Quaint way to get about . Make sure you look up,the side streets to discover local markets etc

Affordable Hong Kong Island Trip. If you want to have a sight seeing of the Hong Kong island, including Central, Wanchai, Causeway Bay and Tai Koo, etc. The cheapest mean is to take the tram. It just costs you less than 0.4 US Dollar. Very good view and feeling. Day or night is good.
A must. Double-decker trams in vivid colours just call for a ride through the business district of the Hong Kong Island.

Happiness!!. In a fast paced life, it's nice to be in a slow moving, old fashioned tramway. you would certainly enjoy the view of the city's busy streets without paying so much! I will definitely ride on this everytime I visit HK... Love it!
Nothing like them. They each seem to be different. No corporate colours & paint jobs on these as they rattle past.Well worth a visit to Hong Kong Island to see these.

Hong Kong transport traditional styles. The best way to enjoy Hong Kong, enjoying travel around Central and Kowloon the way the locals do. Very reasonable price and regular times make for a great local experience.
cheap and nice way to travel. this is must do activities in Hong Kong Island, the fare is very cheap and affordable among all other transport mode.

Excellent mode of Transport. Loved every bit of ride of this Ding Ding Tram. Run through Hong Kong Island with high frequency. It's better to have a Tramway map in hand before using this service unless one can well versed in local dialect.
An excellent way to experience Hong Kong. Always a fun and exciting way to scout Hong Kong and to feel the lively atmosphere of this city. Make sure to sit on the upper floor though.
A nice way to travel through the city!. It is a great way to know the city from a different perspective! The trams are old but nice. The service is good. It's a cheap way to move through the island!
Riding the rails. If you have time, a good way to see the island city from Kennedy Town to Sau Ke Wan. Gives one a perspective of the life in Hong Kong.

Not to be missed on Hong Kong Island. it is unique that it is only available on HK island and not in Kowloon. It is actually quite inexpensive and convenient for travels across HK island. I recommend going up to the second level to take in the sights and avoid rush hours (such as afternoon after 5 pm!). Google map will list all the stops in English and the station-name sign is located on TOP of the station and you can see it very clearly on the second level of the tram! For boarding, you climb up at the back of the tram, via the turnstile, then you can quickly take the steps to the upper level. There are a second set of stairs to go down to the front of the tram when you are ready to disembark. you can "call" your stop (next stop) with the buttons located on the handrails. My kids think it is so cool and different to take the tram. I highly recommend taking the tramway on HK island at least once!
Great and cheep way to see the business district. We took the Ding Ding from west to east of the city. It took about an hour and it was a great and very very cheep way of seeing the city.
Cheap, simple and safe for short distance traffic. Cheap and easy to use. Top deck give good city view. But relatively slow. Not for those in hurry. Also not air conditioned.

No One Ever Got Lost in 110plus Years. If you have an hour to spend, taking the Ding Ding ride is well worth your time, all the tram are running on the same track in some part of the city, if you not in any hurry, wait for one that have seats available, then get on on the rear of the car, go up to upper deck and find a seat have a good view, watch the Hong Kong world goes by, it move slow, you can take your pictures or video, whatever interest you, when you feel you had enough, get off in the front and pay $2.30 with octopus card or drop coin the box, please note no change is available, walk across street on the opposite side and take another tram, bring you back where you start, the tramway goes from East to West or West to East direction only, you can not get lost, even you want to try, the $2.30 fare cover any distance you travel, one stop or to the end of the line, some have air condition available, don't take it in the mid day afternoon, it can be really hot, best time is in the evening.

An inexpensive way to hop on and hop off the coastline of Hong Kong Island. This ancient transportation means is century old but the trams are pretty well kept and clean. Most cars are not air conditioned but covered. You will get some breeze when the tram moves. I enjoy the street view, hear the noise and feel the smell of the places as the moves along. For $2.3 each journey, you will make no hesitation to hop off when you spot some interesting places, and hop on the tram again.The tram runs on specially built tracks which at times avoid the traffic jam. Many locals use the vehicle for its low fare. It is a good way to explore Hong Kong Island if you have time.

Must sit at upper level. Hop on from the back. And get out from the frontside. It cost the same even if you go short distance or all the way. There are a lot of trams with different destination. Goes to the upper level to enjoy more of the ride
good experience. We have trams in my country so not a big shock to see those ones however is cheaper than other mode of transportation in hong kong and it offers better sightseeing of the city

Hong Kong Trams. Hong Kong Trams are a must do on any trip to Hong Kong, cheap and frequent services. easy to connect to services from Central. The historical trams are an experience not to be missed. Make sure you take some change, 2.20 dollar to anywhere.

Great way to see the city!. The trams are a fun way to get around Hong Kong if you have the time. You will get where you need to be much faster on the subway so don't utilize the tram if you are in a rush. You can pay by octopus card or HKD but be advised that when paying in cash you must have exact change. It was $2.60 for an adult fare at the time I visited. I would suggest getting a seat on the upper level and enjoying the sights as you move through the city! Like the subways, the team can get very, very crowded at peak times.

Convenient and a fun way to get around.. With a tram stop right opposite our hotel, we made full use of the Tram service to get around. It covered many of the places we wanted to go and was reasonably cheap.
A throwback to a bygone age. Essential travel to hop on a tram to reach your destination and take in the delights of Hong Kong and you can use your Octopus card,

A must for locals and tourists alike. If you're not in a hurry this is a great way to travel and see the city.Hop in the back and pay when you exit from the front of the tram. Octopus card or loose change is accepted, and one journey is less than $3 flat rate (even less for concessions).The trams are very frequent and each stop is about a five minute walk away so very convenient to find.The best view is on the upper deck- shove the window down on a good day for a breeze and great photo opportunities!
A 'must-do' experience. Whatever else you do in Hong Kong, find half an hour to have a ride on one of these old trams. For a couple of Honk Kong dollars you can have a unique travel experience.
Fun experience. Quiet tiny especially on the upper level but lots of fun - try it to move from one stop to another one not too far away!
its better from outside. Tramway is really nice from the outside, but it was really crowded the time we used it.i couldnt even breathe! Mtr is a much better way for transportation (to me of course)

Ding Ding is a must!. The tram is so called Ding Ding because it makes such a sound whenever it comes close to the stop. Tram ride on the Hong Kong Island is highly recommended to anyone who wants to know more of the city in a unique and leisure way. The trams go through the skyscrapers in Central to bustling crowds in Causeway Bay, all the way to the residential areas in Sau Kee Wan in the east or, in another direction, to the older part of the island west which is famous for selling dried seafood, salted fish and the like. You get on from the rear door and off from the front with payment. Single ride is HKD2.30 which is also the cheapest means of transportation in Hong Kong. Try to find a seat on the upper deck to get a better view of the city.
Always a good time.. The cheapest form of sightseeing in Hong Kong especially in town. My mom love it a lot. Don't worry where you're heading and hop off whenever you wanted to.
EXCELLENT. I have always wanted to try one and I did. It was wonderful. We had seats in the upper deck and use our Octopus card to pay the fares as you leave the bus.
Beautiful.... looking. This is very smart & sharp internal parallel transport service in hong kong city where we can enjoy Tram and bus both services. Great

The legendary landmark of Hong Kong. Getting on a tram in Hong KOng Island and go around the island from the west to the east is an unique experience for a tourist. First of all, it is dirt cheap, HKD2.30 for the ride no matter how long or short is the trip. It is an open carriage with no air con. So, in a hot summer day, it is not as comfortable but you do get breeze when the tram is moving. The good thing about going on the team as a tourist is that the tram moves very slowly and if you sit on the upper deck, you will have the opportunity to look around things and people on the street and in the building very carefully and leisurely and also to take as many pictures as you like. It is a good and cheap way to appreciate the city.

You know you are in Hong Kong!. The ding ding is lots of fun and its a very old form of transportation. There's nothing like this throughout the rest of the world. Its a slow form of transportation and lots of people are usually on it. The great this is that its very cheap. I'm not sure what the exact price is, but its usually under 5 HKD!! This form of transportation goes many places on the Hong Kong island. Its worth looking at but only go on it if you are not in a rush.

Hong Kong traditional transportation.. The chilling tram is a traditional transportation of HK. If you come to HK please try. Most easy you can take them from Central to Causeway bay (the shopping area in island)

A cheap tour of HK Island. I took a tram from Kennedy Town to Causeway Bay with a stop-off at the Western Market as a cheap sightseeing option. Sat on the top deck and enjoyed the view, and the little bit of breeze coming through the open windows. Definitely a nice way to get about, kill some time, and see some typical HK things. Kids, I think especially, would enjoy this, as would adults with an interest in transport, seeing some less touristy parts of Hong Kong, and for penny pinchers.

When you have time. I always find an occasion to get a Ding Ding ride every time I visit HK. It's not fast, crowded and has no air-conditioning in the summer, but it is a very nice and unique experience. It is the cheapest transportation for you to spend an hour seeing all the stores and people on the street, and feeling the warm (could be polluted) breeze.

The best way to discover HK. I took the tram to visit the city , it s very cheap and reliable 2.3 $HK , you gonna go trough the main avenue , the tram stop every 300 Metres and go slowly , it s give you time to take pictures . i really recommend this activity

Try it... for fun. We got on to this tram from Central to Admiral MTR just to get a taste of what it is like. The tram is very cheap, only around HKD3 and you can ride from one end to the other with the same price. You need not take this tram with a purpose of getting somewhere, just hop on and see where it takes you.
such a good experience. if you visit Hong Kong Island, you have to try the tram, especially sitting in the upper deck. Such a nice experience to enjoy the busy city.
Bad experience. Nothing new and the idea of this bus is so boor you should be near to the big bus station at all-time and then location of it is selected Bad experience

Watch Hong Kong go by. We took tram from causeway bay to whitty street to kill time on our last day. You get to see so much of Hong Kong island, with a great view of the streets from upstairs. $2.3HKD each no matter how long you're travelling.

Hong Kong Trams. My first love in Hong Kong (lol)... I really really love riding trams in Hong Kong... The fare is fixed no matter how long or short point a is to point b. Go up the upper deck to get a fantastic view of Hong Kong. They kept the trams well maintained and clean. Fare is around HKD 2.30 for adults, HKD 1.20 for child and HKD 1.10 for senior citizens. You can also buy a ticket for the tramoramic tour wherein you can hop on the tram and you can get a tour of Hong Kong Island, I think it costs around HKD 90 - 100 per person. When you go to Hong Kong, on top of your of your to do list should be riding on the tram!

The Ding dings.. Just love the trams on Hong Kong island, especially when day is turning to night. All the lights coming on and riding the trams taking in all the bustle on the streets and watching the skyline as well. They are so cheap as well, so don't miss your chance to ride the ding dings.

Such fun!!. I have never been on a tram, it is such a fun way to see the island. I often will get on at a stop and just ride the tram to the end and then catch another back. If I see something along the way that looks interesting, then I hop off and have a look. So cheap and great fun!

Good Slow ride. Its an ancient tram ride on HK Side, slow but steady, Cheap & the Best, relax on the upper floor to enjoy & view HK & its life style. It passes through Main Roads & streets thru, rate is fixed for any destination you may go. You are sure to enjoy it.

Iconic way to see the Island like a local. After catching the Ferry to the Island we decided to take a tram ride to the end of the line just to have a look. We were the only non locals on the tram and had a walk around a wet food market at the end before getting the tram back to the Ferry stop. Great experience.

Cheap and amazing way to see the island!. My wife loves to travel around a city to see what it looks like as a whole before she decides what she wants to do. So usually, this means using the hop on hop off buses on offer in most cities. However the ‘ding ding tram’ in HK is the cheapest way of doing just this. For $2.30 for the both of us, we can literally stay on the tram from one side of HK to the other. My advice is, sit by a window as it gets hot, sit upstairs for the views and if time is an issue, head in the opposite direction to Kennedy Town, as after Admirality there isn’t too much to see

old world charm. upside: very quaint and very cheap fare.downside: no air conditioning.however, that being said, its a great alternative to the MTR if you only have a short distance to cover and plenty of time to do it!

Best view of working hk island!. Take a tram towards Kennedy town. Get on top in cront. Spectacular photo opportunities. Get of tran at depot ..get back on for trip back to where you got on ...best under $6 spent for return trip! If time allows get on tram going to Shaukeiwan ...very different views from earlier to Kennedy Town ... again sit in front on top floor of tram with camera at ready. At depot, need to get off tram and get on again (need to pay again ...(hk$2.60 … pay as you get off tram, not as you get on! Buses in HK pay as you get on) tram will take you to where you got on. Need to allow about an hour for each return trip (assuming you get on in Central HK) get off at front of tram only and pay as you get off!

Fun way to see Hong Kong. We traveled from the Bank of China to Kennedy Town Center and saw Hong Kong change from the modern world to an older more traditional time. Sat upstairs at the front, very tiny seats, not much headroom and cost about 2 HK dollars each person, with discounts for seniors. The tramway only runs on Hong Hong island NOT Kowloon.
Fun way to explore Hk. Good way to get around especially between Mtr stations. Loved the colourful trams too. They add charm to this country too.
Good way to see HKG. Double decker trams is a great way to see Hong kong.It will move at a decent speed and its an new experience.

Charming little thing from the past. These trams are incredibly charming and quaint. They are cheap, and go by a singular fare of about 2-3 HKD for any distance covered. So ride them or just look on as they amble past you.

Great if you don't miss air-con !. If you have time - it is rather slow - and if temperature is not too hot - no air-con - then a great way to travel from Central to Wanchai for example. You must have HKD coins to pay the ride, try to sit on the top floor, front seat to make the best out of it.

Great way to see HK. The old trams are a great way to while away a hot evening in HK, seeing most of the sights of the north side of the island. The double deckers cost only 2.30HKD to ride from end to end and with wide open windows, it's a nice cool way to wind through the main streets, surrounded by the illuminated sky scrapers. When you get to one end, simply disembark and head back!

Interesting. 2.3hkd for all trips(adults). Very affordable. Interesting experience. Board from the rear and exit via front. Pay when you exit. Its double decker for ultimate experience, u should go to second level. Beware of steep stairs. Limited seats both levels. It can get crowded during peak hours. The route map looks a bit confusing but managed to pass through that. A must try!
Loved them!. It was really nice and cheap to travel around Hong Kong with this trams! I really loved them! It took way longer but it was worth the view and to catch the flair of this great city.

Cool unique way to get around. Not the fastest way to get around central, a ride with a Ding Ding is mandatory if you visit Hong Kong. They are fun and give you the opportunity to see Hong Kong easily. And it's nice to support this old-style transportation-system (since it is still being used by the locals, despite the MTR underneath it).
