The slow and steady tram makes it a very interesting way to travel around Hong Kong and after walking it is also the most affordable. I used this to travel across the city and to explore it for 2 whole days. Awesomeness. For the kick of it you may travel across a few stations if you're in a hurry. Avoid these near the market places in the evening times. Trams to get stuck in traffic jams just like the cabs!

Cheapest and fastest way to travel during traffic.. The price is set to HKD2.50 now. The tram goes all the way to Kennedy town from north point , happy valley.
U go in from the back of the tram through a turnstile and u alight in the front where u pay your money in cash ( no change given) or using an octopus card ( value added card)

Cheapest leisurely travel. If you are not in a hurry to get anywhere, a ride on the top floor of the HK tram is really quite pleasant, outside of rush hours. It is leisurely, takes you through local byways, and it is seriously cheap, HK$2.20 for an adult, and HK$1.10 for a senior. That is US$0.20 and 0.15, for a ride from one end of the island to another. Routes are restricted, and traffic jams means timing of arrival is unpredictable. You enter from the end of the tram, and pay as you leave from the front of the tram, no mean feat when the tram is chock-a-block full of people, so be warned. And you have to start maneuvering way beforehand so you have to have a vague idea of where the stops are, or don't mind walking the distance. It is worth the experience.

Double Decker Fun. A good way to see the city and outer areas of Hong Kong if you have some time to fill in. You need to be quick getting off at times and careful if you are coming down from the top floor of the 'Ding Ding'. The drivers don't like to wait for anyone, so be ready either to get on quickly and disembark the same way. A great trip out to Stanley and Repulse bay.
awesome. a very different way to travel, a very enjoyable and fun experience, if you have the time and are ok with the fact that you may get lost it is a lot of fun
Great way to get from one side of the island to the other. The ding-ding is a must-do experience in HK. It is a wonderful way to absorb all of the sights on HK island, and it is so inexpensive!

Old Hong Kong feel. Old and slow form of transport on Hong Kong Island, but the cheapest (one fare no matter the distance/stops). It is very slow so I only saw sporadic of working professionals, mainly older people and students. It was interesting ride with nature breeze and "ding ding" sound as it took me from the east to the west, passing such a different landscape of Hong Kong (more local kind of vibes to cosmopolitan vibes).

Hong Kong Icon. If you have the time, a great way to explore Hong. Your HKD 2 (and half the price if you are a pensioner) will buy you a trip from Sheung Wan Shau Kei Wan. From an elevated upper deck you are able to take in the sights, sound and smells of Hong Kong. Be prepared to be packed in like sardines as this a cheap and popular mode of transport for the locals. A note of warning - the trams are not air conditioned.

A bit of old Hong Hong. The "Ding Ding" Trams still run along Connaught Rd and are the most fun way to transit Hong Kong island.However you need to know where you are going and where is the nearest stop. Take your Transit Map.... You will enter the tram at the back and exit at the front.

Quick and Easy, but count your stops!. Trams are very quick and easy to use, however they do not announce their stops. This means that you have to be careful to watch were you are and make sure that you are getting off at the right place. They are about $2.50 HK which is about 25 pence UK per journey.

traditional and cheap. metro and taxi are not the only way to travel in Hong Kong. tram is one of the most traditional transportation in Hong Kong. it's very relax to take a ride from north point to Wanchai after my busy work in Hong Kong. it's much cheaper than metro. why not give it a try?

Ding ding. If u have time and want some air in your face (which is all i want during the hot season) take ding ding instead of the subway. It's a lot slower though... Need to consider how fast u need to reach your destination.

We love tram rides. We got the tram back to our hotel one night from central to north point, the end of the line we chose, cheap and included on our MTR pass, sat up top and loved every squeaky minute

Tram experience. I went to Central with my sister, a first-time visitor to Hong Kong. After our long sight-seeing walk from Central to Lan Kwai Fong , to SoHo, Man-Mo temple. We took the tram going to Causeway Bay, passing along Central once again, Admiralty, Wan Chai and finally stopping at Causeway Bay. My sister had fun with a Hong Kong Island city tour via the inexpensive tram.
cheap and nostalgic. the trams are well maintained. they are still a efficient way of travel within HK island area. if you are tourist don't go during rush hour, it is jammed packed.

Bring exact change or Octopus card. Interesting to ride if you are on Hong Kong Island. The trolley runs east to west and you can hop on or off as you wish. Sit up top for best city views. Be sure to bring some change as you need exact change or an octopus card to ride. The driver has the fare posted near the fare box when you get on. You pay when you get off.
Tram on a diet. Looked like a seen taken out of a Harry Potter movie. Unbelievable to the eye but enjoyable to ride if you get the chance.

Greatest deal to see one from end of Hong Kong island to the other end. This double deck tram allows you see everything from west to east end of the island. You can always take the other ways around too. Lowest cost to sit on the upper deck in the evening to watch all the night lights and activities on the street. OK, it does not move fast, this will allow you to see what's going on the street. I loved the rides.

Cheap way to see Hong Kong island but can get crowded and hot. The tram cost is the same no matter how far you are travelling. It's $2.30 HKD and you pay at the front when you get off. Be sure to have enough change in coins for your ride because you get no change back. Or you could get an octopus card and never have to worry about it. The tram line goes from the East end of Hong Kong Island all the way to the West end and vice versa. This covers all the notable stops including Central, Causeway Bay, North Point, Wan Chai, Happy Valley. There are many trams running at once, amounting to a wait of less than 3 minutes during off peak times and one almost every minute during peak times. It is certainly the cheapest way to get around Hong Kong Island and effective too.Try to avoid travelling during peak times if at all possible. The trams are crowded and you can get quite hot in the May heat.Pro tip: link up with the star ferry at Wan Chai or Central to cross back over to Tsim Sha Tsui for only $2.50 hkd (or $3.40 on weekends/public holidays). This makes for a very cheap day's outing with transport costs. In a city where the costs are quite high, it pays to save when you can. Plus the trip on the ferry is a must do for your time in HK.

Touring Hong Kong. The trams wends it way from Kennedy Town, the western most part of the island, to Shaukeewan, the eastern most. On its way, you will see the residential areas, the commercial districts, and the shopping area. It is an encapsulated tour of the island. For HK$2! I have not given it 5 stars because some people complain that it is not air conditioned. On the other hand, that is the whole point.

Cheapest tram ride on earth. You just get on any tram at any stop but you must get on from the back andI prefer to move upstairs, find a window seat in the front. Then watch the world ofSusie Wong unfold in front of you. There are basically four sections...one fromKennedy Town to Happy Valley. Second from West Market to North Point. Thirdfrom Shout ki wan to the Central. Fourth runs to the depots from anywhere. Youget on the tram from the middle of the street, it's kind of narrow especially the stairs to second floor but it is dirt cheap and you are at eye level or slightly above but only few feet from everybody...it runs slowly and noisily but you get to see the whole stretch of the island from very west to very east for peanuts. Oh you pay only when you get off the tram, just put two HK dollars (about 25 US cents) in the coin box for one ride. Every ride from one terminal to the last runs about 45 minutes depends on the traffic. It's the most interesting and cheapest way to watch how Hong Kong moves!
Ding Ding. Let's hope they never disappear, my first experience was in 1968, and even though the city looks so very different, the trip is just as enjoyable...well done HK...

Feels like history. The Ding Dings are a fantastic way see a great part of the island. Make sure to board the tramway at a terminus if you want to catch a seat in the front row on the upper deck. We took a tramway from the terminus near Sheung Wan subway station with direction to Causeway Bay. Don't miss the Ding Ding especially if you love trains and/ or tramways (and even if you don't love them).
Love the tram. I like hopping on and off the tram when out and about it's a cheap and easy way to travel along the island with many great places to see along the way.

Popular Must Do in Hong Kong. Ding Ding, the iconic Hong Kong Island Tram really is a must do activity. If possible sit on the upper deck for some very good views of local sites. Like most public transport in a busy city Ding Ding has peak usage periods. There are a few different routes and the peak period doesn't last all day. Remember to enter the tram at the rear and hop off from the front. Paying as you exit, use exact change or an Octopus Card.

You're here, you have to try it !!!. Your trip to Hong Kong won't be complete without a trip on the Ding Ding. They run East to West and are very popular with locals and tourist. Sit up top for the best view. You must have exact change, so use that Octopus card.
I love the Ding Ding.. There is soooo much history about the Tram. I hope HK never gets rid of the ding ding. A must do for visitors. I take it all the time.
Best way to see the island. The ticket is so cheap that you'd want to cry. But it's one of the best way to see most of the northern part of Hong Kong Island.
Make sure to have an Octopus Card. The ride is really fun, you can see the entire city in a local perspective. Make sure to tap your octopus card before alighting.
Superb. It's a superb service that Hong Kong offered. I used this to come to my hotel from airport. Easy to access and really time saving
Take your time and enjoy the ride. A ride through one of the world's greatest cities for the princely sum of $2.30HKD! Sit upstairs, enjoy the view, the breeze and local life.

A rare experience, affordable ride from sheung wan to causeway bay and vice versa.. It runs from morning till night, a relaxing and cheap ride that the tourists can sit back and relax. Easy to take the tram with both english and chinese destination stated. Throughout the journey, you may alight at certain stops to gain direct access to some places of interest.

Precious!. The Ding Dings are great! Someone told us the charges were based on donation basis but it turned out there was a standard charge for it.
Your kids will love them :-)

Nostalgic. The trams are the cheapest mode of transport in HK. Sadly they don't ply everywhere. For 2.35 HKD one can travel through the length and breadth of the tram destination. It reminded me of San Francisco.

Use it outside of rush hour!. I hopped on this and sat on upper deck at around 8am in the morning. By 8:30 the ding dings were crammed full with people going to work. Without aircon, definitely better enjoyed w fewer people! Board in back and pay (I used Octopus card) when you get off in the front.

Great way to see Hong Kong in General. take a Ding Ding it's a must when you in HK, It's Free and you'll able to see HK in every corner. I enjoy my self with a view of HK city, it's really a good way to enjoy HK.

Trip to Hong Kong Business District. Glimpse of Hong Kong Business district. It is a must to ride the Ding Ding or the Tramways when you're near Central Hong Kong. It is cheap and convenient. So, if ever you may see some interesting shops or streets on your way through it, you can just hop off to the next stop.
Great way to travel East and West of Hong Kong. Cheap....can use your Octopus card. Very frequent and easy to use. Go upstairs for great views of the city. Pay on your way out at front of tram.

For streetcar and tram lovers. This attraction or mode of transit is a must for all tram and transit lovers! These trams are the only double decker trams in the world and some on sundays are convertibles or open roof concept on the top! The trams run every 1-2 minutes and has about 6 different lines each running along the main corridor but later either branching off to happy valley or some just dont go as far as others! The line is very long tskes 2-3 hours to do a round trip if not longer! The tram is only located on hong kong island not in kowloon! The cost is only 2$ hk dollar regardless of distance travelled! Thats about 30 cents usd!
Very interesting experience. No visit to HK is complete without a ride on the tramway. Try to ride on off-peak timing so you will be able to secure a seat and ride through HK city. Great experience!

Ding ding!. This sounds ridiculous but these fun little trams were one of my trip highlights! Why? Because they are sort of ludicrous but also very efficient. Tiny and narrow. Low roofs. Two story. Legitimately make the ding ding sound. I'm not sure what more anyone could ask for in a transport option. Note. I only did this for fun - and used the mtr almost exclusively otherwise.

Good ride and can be fun for kids. Get Octopus Card for hassle free ride. For those nee to Hong Kong, take the tram (Ding Ding) and just sit to enjoy the view till the last station and continue to sit to get back from your origin station.
Pay per ride - regardless of which station you stop.

$2.3 for a tour of HK Wan Chai, Causewaybayand more. if you are a tourist you must hop on to this tram and see a part of HK for as low as $2.3
Make sure you sit on the top for a great view and relax for an hour for a street side tour
This will also help you confirm which places are worth getting down and exploring
Charming!. These trams reminded me of the British double decker. They are really charming. The only city in China that offers people such a nice and cheap trip.
The best way to experience HK. The tram is definitely the best possible way to travel in central Hong Kong while experiencing the city, the noise, the smells and the scenery!

Cheap, easy way to get somewhere. You must have the correct fare, $HG 2.30 for your trip for as long as you want to travel. If not you may pay more. Enter at the back and exit from the front and pay. They dont go everywhere and can be crowded but so convenient, cheap and regular. We loved them.

All aboard for a wonderful experience!. It costs just HK2.30 to ride this quintessential Hong Kong transport!It's a great way to see the city on a leisurely pace. You'll never ever go off your intended stop as you have forever to look out for it! It's an experience you have to have when you are in Hong Kong. Like the Star Ferry. Make your way up to the top deck for a panoramic view. It's a real treat!Ps you can pay for your ride using the Octopus card too!

A must in Hong Kong. Similar to Staff Ferry, the double-decker tram walking along the coastline of the Hong Kong Island is a must and cheap experience that should not be missed in Hong Kong. Going along from the western district with dried seafood to the CBD and highrise building in Central CBD to the shopping hotspot in CWB, the tram is a very great trip that to be taken. Recommended to be taken with the Ferry.For those will be vising HK/ in HK soon, there will be free rides for Tram/Star Ferry on 29 May 2016!

Best tourism activity in Hong Kong. I always enjoy the tram rides when I go to Hong Kong. It is the cheapest mode of transportation but the best part is no need to walk all the way down to the train stations. Take the tram during off peak, especially go upstairs and get the front seats. Enjoy a slow ride across the buzzing city from one end to the other for a low cost of HK $2.30 and observe the views through a different angle. You can even get off the tram when you see something you like and just pop back on another tram to continue your journey.

cheapest sightseeing transportation system !!. you want to get an overview of hong kong island AND you want to take great pictures AND you want to use a cheap transportation system?!then the tram is your choice!dont forget to enter at the backdoor and go straight up the stairs.it is worth to wait for the front seats: there you can make the best photosyou can go to any direction [it is only one long line] and then turn aroundsometimes you can stay and go back with the same tram; sometimes you have to change at the final stopbut this doesn't matter re. costs: its only 1.2 hong kong dollar for one whole ride!!you pay when you leave the tram..have a nice trip!!!
If you haven't ding ding'ed, you haven't seen Hong Kong.. The most real, affordable and cherishable way to capture the life and landscape of Hong Kong island's urban stretch.

Fun and Cheap. Easy way to travel around HK, bus and trains are faster but ding ding is more fun and totally a unique experience. Also cheap so if you are in a budget, this is something that you shouldn't miss

DING DING! . Must try from one end of the island to the other end where you can see all of the different parts of each corners from east to west Hong Kong island. Very inexpensive. Try to sit up stairs , more views other than the crowded streets and people. Very interesting journey. I love the tram which I call the ding ding bus

Perfect to enjoy the city without walking . Busy? Tired? Lazy? Recovering from huge parties at LKF?Then just grab a tram and go all the line. Enjoy the view, and the prestige to go slowly in a very fast city!!! A must
Fun. We took a quick ride on the Ding Ding and it was a fun part of our tour and day spent exploring. Easy to hop on for a few stops for the experience.

The most budgeted way to explore HK. With just HKD2.3, you have the chance to go from the eastern part down to the western part of Hong Kong Island. No wonder it is also one of the most popular transportation methods on Island, hence, also a good chance for you to observe the local culture.

Cheap and Leisurely .... I caught the tram from Market Street all the way to Kennedy Town and back to Causeway Bay. It was a fun trip.Definitely recommend at least one tram trip - or maybe several if you have the time.

Enjoy!. I heard about the Tramways in Hong Kong before I visited there, and decided try it. A negative point of the Tram is that it doesn't mention which stop you are, you'll need to be careful, or you just get down on a wrong place. But if you do it for fun, that's easy. All you need to do is to stay on it as long as you wish. Ticket is cheap as well, you could view Hong Kong from a different sight by taking the tram.
Good city drive. If you want to have a cheap ride through the buzzling busy business streets, climb onto the top of these

Unique to Hong Kong. Anybody coming to Hong Kong should ride the tram. Locals call it the "ding ding" and happily commute around their city on really cheap form of public transport.Best route runs across Hong Kong island from East to West, Shau Kei Wan to Kennedy Town.You can jump on at any tram stop and jump off anywhere along the route.You pay on exit - recommend having Octopus card for payment.As mentioned earlier, the tram is really cheap and the locals do use this transport all day. It can get very busy at peak times in the morning and evenings.No a/c so for cooler ride and great views head upstairs and enjoy seeing a very different view of Hong Kong.Enjoy the ride to Happy Valley or out to Kennedy Town.Both places have some great bars and restaurants to enjoy.
An experience. Great to experience these narrow and unique trams in Causeway Bay. Can get crowded, so try to be near the exit when you near your stop, and remember to have exact change.

A lovely form of cheap and efficient transport. What a great way to get from one part of HK island to another. Well utilised by locals. We only had a short trip on the Ding Dings. Next time I would like to go on the whole trip. The trams were very cheap and a great way to get around Hong Kong.
Fun and cheap.. Great way to get from central to causeway bay, wan chai and north point. Busses are probably quicker but twice the price and a quarter of the fun.

Lucky to have been invited for a Tram Party. During a recent re-union in HK of old school mates, I was fortunate to have been able to be one of the lucky ones to have bagged a place on the antique trams that are able to be used for the groups for a tram party. We boarded at the depot, and then proceeded to go to Happy Valley before making our way back toward the Depot again, this is a great way to see the Central District of HK Island, and to enjoy a tram ride at the same time. Even if it had not been a party tram, the trams themselves are a wonderful was to travel, being cheap, often, and reliable with many stops along the way. A piece of nostalgia, well worth the price to go for a long journey, sit back, enjoy the views and atmosphere of this thriving city.

Really cool way to move around . The ding ding is antiquated, crammed, and slow, but it rocks! Best way to feel the pulse of the town and get some sightseeing. It is also cheap and they take the Octopus card.

Saving the legwork!. One must try the ride from end to end..north point to kennedy town. Be sure to check the destination as trams end ad stated in the front. Always enjoy the ride whenever i visit hkg
A quick and efficient means of transport. Its only found on Hong Kong Island and popular with the locals due to the affordable tickets. Do have a try when you come to Hong Kong Island. :)
jennyw. This is a worthwhile activity. Cheap and interesting experienceA good way to get around in Hong Kong

Most charming way to see Hong Kong (Together with Star Ferry). This is a MUST do when in Hong Kong - so nice to sit on the 1st floor - so cheap. The old charming tram plus a trip with Star Ferry is something you HAVE to do when in Hong Kong. The Peak Tram to Victoria Peak is also charming, but nothing compares to the old original charming "Ding Ding"

Cheap historical transportation on the Island. It seems slow, gets quite crowded and hot because no air conditioning during the day!! BUT you should try riding on one at night! I recommend you to do that as late as possible, because when there is no traffic around, it can go quite fast! It goes pass all the interesting places on Hong Kong Island, you actually see all the major architectures historical or modern.

an lovely affordabel way sightseeing HongKong Island. This tramways travel on road like cute antique boxes rolling along the street. You sit on top level, enjoy a slow sightseeing tour along Hong Kong's busies business area. what a lovely experience mixed new and old Hong Kong factors in a budget way.

Highlight Transportation. Hong Kong Tramway is a great way to experience metropolitan Hong Kong. All the trams have historical flavor. Advertising is plastered all over the trams. The newer trams still retain the tram aura on narrow gauge tracks. Seating is along each side and ends of the tram, on 2 levels. Standing is between the rows of seats. A grab-rail is mounted on the ceiling for better stability for those standing. It can be very crowded inside. It's a true experience of what's it like to be a sardine. The trick is if you know where you need to alight, is to squeeze your way to the front (exit is in the front by the driver) by the time you reach your tram stop. Otherwise you may miss it. However that's one of the cheapest, most memorable and unique ways to see Hong Kong.

Something you must do. We did this for the first time and loved it. We went upstairs and rode the 'ding ding' for two and a half hours around Hong Kong Island. It will take you out of your comfort zone to places most tourists never see. Causeway Bay is upmarket shopping but other areas shows how the other half live. Enter from the rear door and exit from the front door where you use your Octopus card.
Do it!. Ride at least once during your stay this transportation option. You are able to pay with the octopus card too!

Ding Ding!. Ride on the top deck out of rush hours and enjoy a unique sightseeing experience from terminus to terminus for the equivalent of around 25 pence (UK) No traffic jams as they run on their own tram tracks. Use your Octopus card.

Cheap & Chilling way to travel - A MUST TRY. This is one of the oldest transportations available in Hong Kong. It's cheap, slow, and chilling. It is the greatest way to feel, look, and hear a city. Note that most of the trams are old and without air-conditioning, it could be hot in summer.You will have to hop on at the backdoor of the tram, and hop off at the front. (Tram fare is paid when you hop off so do prepare a Octopus card)Trams are available in most main streets in Hong Kong IslandA must try as the government is considering abolishing the tram system.

JUST ANCIENT TRAMS STILL HAVE THAT CHARM. Well it's trams ! old yet attractive! though very limited region in hongkong its in service but if you are in hongkong then specially for experience you should get in !
The best. A great way to negotiate the madness of the traffic, I wasn't sure I would fit onto one as they are like toy trams, a great experience

Enjoyable Ride. If you want to enjoy the view of the place, this tram - Ding Ding is the best option for it. You can sit on the upper one and enjoy scenery since it travels slow compared to buses and cars.

Aother way of sightseeing on Hong Kong Island. Tramways is the cheapest transportation in Hong Kong. Ding ding mainly goes from West side of the Island to the East side. You will see different kinds of buildings along the Tram's route. Better view on upper deck. Avoid the peak hours like morning for rushing to work & evening off work. No air conditioning so ride the Ding Ding in a cooler season. Be careful for the pick pocket especially if the Tram is very crowded.

Where On Earth Can You Have a City Tour for a Song !!!. These trams are such a nostalgia for the local older generation using it as the most versatile transport before the subway lines were built in the 1970s. Today it is still patronized by those as transport who would like to save money and for relative convenience due to the short distance between stops, or for tourists to go on a self-guided city tour of the bustling island at a super slow pace.The million $ question: HOW MUCH DOES IT COST ? US30 cents, Wow !!!Furthermore, it is environmentally friendly.Get on the upper deck and grab a front seat, you won't regret.
Interesting Experience. Was taking the ding ding during my first trip to HK. An interesting experience, it is very convenient mode of transport.

Fun ! Fun ! Fun!. Very fun way to travel if you have the time, at A$0.20 (for senior) is a very cheap and fun way to enjoy the true HK way of life, we use them to travel from one end to the other of the HK island, got down as we come across anything interesting.

Trams slow and easy way to have a good look at Hong Kong. Spent a day on the Trams, sitting up top and trundling along was a lovely way to see places, you can hop on and off as you please and they take Octopus card as well

Historical. Nothing beats the Ding Ding or hong Kong Tram . its a must ride for everyone when going to hong Kong side.In a minimum fare you can get the free view of all Hong kong streets and avenues . Try and ride the historical transportation of Hong Kong .
Great and cheap transport. This is the best way to see Hong Kong island if you not in a rush. I do say is a very relax way to travel and just watch how the busy cars pass by you.

Ride It at Night!. I got on the tram on the West end and rode all the way to the end. It was a lot of fun! If you can, ride at night when the downtown area is lit up. On the ride back (east to west) I stopped in a couple of the neighborhoods with traditional Chinese stores.

A working remnant of colonial Hong Kong!. The old skinny trams of HK Island (none in Kowloon) are a must to experience for an authentic unsanitised view of HK life!Absurdly cheap, and supremely uncomfortable, from the upper deck you have a bird's eye view of everyday life from the administrative and business district through to the ramshackle old crowded and bustling residential precincts.My suggestion to see it all is to jump a tram to Happy Valley, and return. Try to get the front seats on the top deck. You will see it all, and you may even deceide to jump off to have a meal at one of the small restaurants you will spy along the way! Don't forget you enter the tram from the back and leave from the front, paying as you get off!The trams are travelling billboards, in a quite charming way.

old school way to the city. a slowly way to see the city plan a half day to go both ways from western district to and fro shau Kei wan (which is east side of HK island) best seats upstairs and bring your camera highly suggest to hop off at one end to get refreshed before you trip backor you can plan your day starting one end and ending the other with surrounding places to see

Fantastic way to get around. Ding dings move along the islands north coast mainly and some go to Happy Valley. Just an enjoyable and very cheap way to experience HK the old way.Just hop on at the back (only!) and take the stairs to 2nd floor and enjoy the slow ride. Get off at the front and pay cash or with Octopus card. Just a few HKD.

Cheapest mode of transport in Hong Kong. Do take a ride even if you do not have any particular place to go. We were told that there is a constant debate over discontinuing the service because it is slow and occupies too much road space. We thought of boarding one just to get the experience. You get a good view of the city from the top deck. The tram accepts Octopus cards.

Very good Ding. The Ding Ding is a cheap way of travelling from one corner of Hong Kong to the other.
Enjoy the trip, and stay close to the windows if you want to see anything of the city.

The "Ewok" bus. It helps if you are actually an "Ewok" because the ceiling is so low.
Use your Octopus card for the fare!

Quaint but slow. The trams are a great way to see the working Hong Kong but don't be in a hurry! A trip from Kennedy Town to North Point is from one end of the system to the other. The distance is only about 8km but the trip takes about an hour and a half. I walk at that speed!Try to get a seat on the top deck toward the front. This provides plenty of opportunities for the photographer as you are above the crowds.One of the interesting places along the way is Des Veoux Street West which is home to literally hundreds of shops selling dried seafood

The Tram should renamed to Cram. Well I'd heard for so many times about this HKG Tramways. As a first timer HKG tourist, I'll have to make it a try. However, just like the HKG average property, it's narrow, packed, squezzy, and crammed. I feel so good after getting out of the Tram.
Fun way to travel. Good fun and cheap way to see the sights and travel along the island. Get a seat upstairs for the best views.

A Must Try -one of the Hong Kong Heritage. If you stay in Hong Kong Island or plan to have a day trip there, Tramway is a must TRY for you to experience the heritage of the business an modern city, great city views with new and old mixed of buildings and suburbs, I enjoyed the relax and classy feeling in it.

It is a fun way to see Hong Kong. This is a fun way to sightseeing the Hong Kong side. Buy an Octopus card once you landed in Hong Kong, save time for digging for the exact change for public transports. You can use the card for shopping in certain shops and kiosks for food and drinks. There are several routes to explore which give you insights of local daily lives, such as vendors, street markets, people watching etc. Neat experience!!!
2016 Trip. Purchased an "octopus card" on this trip and found it easy sight seeing with jumping on and off the ding dings
Not just for tourists. Discovered this by accident but a great way to really see the city with people that really live in the city.

Transport from one end to the other on the Island.. If you have a lot of time to spend. It will only cost you 2 HK dollars to travel on a tram from the west of the Island to the very east end and you will see what the suburban life is Hong Kong.
Lovely. Don't miss that! It's a nice experience. Good to see the city and cross the heart of it. Even if you don't know which direction you should take go anyway.

Excellent way to get around town . Love this old tramway. Still remember riding it when I was a kid and they have made a drastic improvement to the seats since I last took a tram. An excellent way to hop on and off to see Hk island on a tram

rainy day attraction ;). if you find yourself in Hong Kong on a rainy day (and there are a lot of them...) use the opportunity to do a ~1h ride along the coast. very good as panoramic sightseeing of the city
Nice ride. Cheap way to get across city. Nothing exceptional, just a mode of transportation. Can be crowded and dirty

Ding ding tramways only HKD2.30. 🇭🇰 🚎Ding Ding tramways
Hundred year historical for the tramways but manage is very good
But only got in hongkong island
No matter how long distance till end or one station only you take one time only HKD2.30
So i recommend if got time can sit down relax to enjoy the hongkong view in night till the last station
Ride the main street. Narrow, old and full of charm these double deckers travel up and down the main street on the island. You pay HK$2.30 on exit so get the right change before getting on.
interesting ride. took this once in the city. crowded because it was the evening rush hour but an interesting experience

Good way to see HK. We stayed in causeway and the tramway station was just outside our hotel. We decided to take the tramway as we have read that it is a good way to see HK....fare is very cheap,also you have to find a seat at the upper deck to enjoy the view....it runs slow but we really love it as it's our first time in HK and wanted to see HK during the day....it a must try if you are in HK...highly recommend.....

Cute trams. We loved the trams, particularly the way they looked. They were packed with people so it was interesting to watch them as well as the views. Quite a good way to see different parts of the city and very cheap.

good old way of transport. Highly recommended if you have time, best way to explore city. You can just board anywhere , frequency is good. 2.3 hkd is standard charge any distance. You can go from one end to other end of city using tram and explore. Hop on and off anywhere u want.

Definitely a worthwhile experience but slow and not very comfortable. I picked one of the old wooden trams to travel for about 1 hour from Admiralty to the end of the line to visit a museum. By sitting on the top deck at the front you get a good view and aircon however it is very rickety amd the hard wooden seats make you quite sore. Also the journey back on the MTR to about 1/3 of the time so no good if you are in a hurry. Should be done at least once as very cheap - flat rate HKD 2.30.

Love this train system. This is the only way to move about the city even though many of the taxis are Teslas. Travel was very understandable and friendly. The trains and stations were very clean and had a great pedestrian flow. The ride is relatively quiet and I certainly felt safe.
Humorous. Yes. They are in almost every movie with some motives from Hong Kong, so you just have to take a tour. They are still in regular traffic and a good way to get around i Hong Kong.

Take the tram ~ it's a cheap and easy way to cross Hong Kong. We made our journey across from Kowloon using the subway across the bay and into The Admiralty. From there we knew we could catch a tram from across the road. We planned to stay on it until it reached the Terminal junction heading on out past Causeway bay. In total it took us about a hour to do this as the trams travel at their slow easy pace. Up on the top deck and looking out you can see the differences between the commercial heart of Hong Kong to the back streets and markets along the way. We felt this was a great way to see the sites without too much hassle and for a mere couple of Dollars I would say for excellent value. Making our way back we then popped across the Star Ferries ~ again another excellent way to travel.

Ding Ding all the way. Brilliant.. It is a must for any tourist visiting Hong Kong Island. Sit upstairs either at the front or at the back seats for best experience......it will bring back memories...the Hong Kong people were asked if they wanted this form of transport updated, they sensibly said no....so that tells you alot. We travelled to the Hong Kong Happy Valley racecourse which is well worth a viewing on its own. Travelled back early evening with all the lights made it even more atmospheric.....and the best thing of all....it costs about 20p a ride or less than 1HKD if a senior. Go for it.

Always a fun experience with the kids . Always a fun experience with the kids. Although we are locals, we often take it to get cross town from Wanchai or Causeway Bay to the Western district (or the other way) Enjoyable if not to busy. When we have visitors it's always on our to do list.

Cheap, Nice, Must try!. It's sure a fun ride with this tram, with only small amount you can sit as long as you want :) go to top floor and you can enjoy the wind breeze from the open window and might be the cheapest and worthiest sightseeing in Hong Kong. They do offer the tram tour which I don't see why we can't do it ourselves with normal tram as they use the same lane.

In 1980 and today in 2016. If you are not in hurry and do not like walking a lot from an MTR entrance to another MTR exit and be in packed transport and enjoy fresh air, take the tram. See more and spend less. Nostalgia!

Runs along De Vouges Road, for $2.50 you get to see central HK! What more can you ask for. No aircon. Go upstairs and sit at the front for a breeze! Remember to get your Oyster card for quick travel in HK.
Night is the best. I did use this public transport once in the night and i feel awesome. Try to sit at the second floor, prepare your camera, cause the city view is amazing from up here.
Practical and fun. Take a ride on a bit of history as you weave across Hong Kong through the traffic. Hop on and grab an upper level seat. Hop off when you see something interesting.
great and cheap way how to see Hong Kong Island.. Go to the top. Cost per ride is just 2.3 HKD. Enjoy the trip and just see the streets in the evening

Cheap way to see Hong Kong. We enjoyed the experience of travelling on the old trams. Easy to navigate, maps at tram stands. Use Octopus card. Trams come frequently , so if one looks crowded just wait for the next one.

Unique way to see the neighbourhoods . We hopped on a team after a lovely dinner and was treated to a spectacular visual ride. We went to end of the trip stayed on the tram and returned to our destination. Up only paid when up disembarked and therefore only paid a small amount for a wonderful ride

A fun way to see the city! . We hopped on the tram after taking the star ferry to central Hong Kong. We rode it all the way to causeway bay and it was a great way to see a little bit of the city. Sitting on the top level with open windows allowed for a lovely breeze to pass through, and offered great views. Will be sure to hop on again before we carry on with our trip!
Very efficient and cool. We love riding with the tramways in HK. Very nice to have had this experience. I felt like I was in London. The view were great and I would recommend anyone to try it.

Cheap transport if you're not in a rush. Although it's the slowest form of transport compared to bus, MTR or Taxi, it's great value and if you're not in a rush to be somewhere. A good way to save some $$ on your Octopus card.Getting off when the tram is packed can be an interesting challenge though.

Cheapest mode of Transport. At 2.30 HKD（.30 USD) to ride through HK on a tram, what more can you ask for? Double-decker trams have been around HK since the influence of the British. Hop on and view HK island at a cheap cost and from a different perspective! Remember to sit on the upper deck!

Best Sight seeing in HK. The cheapest & the best transportation in Hong Kong Island. You can tour the west side of Hong Kong Island all the way to the other side. It passed through historic area in west, to Banking & Business in Central, to busiest shopping area in Causeway Bay all the way to Shau Kee Wan that has a lot of good traditional & famous fish ball noodles, Michelin Star Curry restaurant & local food like small toasted egg balls - Hong Kong food. Best Value in town for less than 3 HK dollars.
Cheap way to ride round town. Nice change from taxis, MTR and striding around on foot. Cheap and cheerful ride, through the centre of the city. Like a sight seeing tour.
something interesting. randomly hop onto one of these ding ding. full of foreigners but i do enjoy the short ride. that's the old hong kong.

A taste of the old way to travel. My Hong Kong associate convinced to get on this old and woody looking tram after we finished a meeting with one of my client on a sunny afternoon. I often drive to work back in Toronto, Canada and avoid taking the street car (electric tram with one deck only) because it always stuck in the traffic. But in Hong Kong, the tram has its only lane so it never get stuck in traffic. That is a very good thing to attract more passengers. The sad thing is, it travelled very slow just a bit faster than running steady. It would be nice if it had air-conditioning because it was certainly hot inside the tram. I was told it was cheapest ground transportation in Hong Kong. It did give me a taste of the past.

best way to get a feel for HK. All the public transport in HK is fantastic. Especially coming from Sydney ! Here in HK, it's relatively cheap, incredibly frequent and easy to navigate.But my favourite is the tram. Yes it is slower than the MTR and the bus, and can get crowded, and is not great if you are tall, but you can sit up the top and take in the views and smells of HK. Very easy to get around and you are never far from it. As a new arrival to HK, I found it a great way to get oriented. And if you go one stop too far, just walk back, or wait for one coming the other way.

fun way to travel along the lower level on HK island. A very frequent and enjoyable way to travel along the lower lever of HK island. And very cheap too! Only HKD2.3 for any trip length. The only trap is that you only tap-off with your Octopus card. You don't tap on (as you do with the MTR)
Hong Kong Tramways. we did not travel on these but fascinating and lovely to watch - if we had longer in the city we would probably have used this

Fun and cheap. Cheap and fun way to get around the cityDo watch out for trams that terminate their service on one of the stations.(just make sure to check the signboards at the front of the trams)Boarding on one means you have to change trams at their terminus.
Neat transportation. We had fun riding around on the tram cars. Probably the cheapest form of transport besides your own two feet.
great way to see the city. cheap and easy to use, and a great way to look around HK, try for the seat at the window on the upper deck.

Cheapest tour of HK possible!. Spend a couple of dollars, grab a window seat upstairs and soak up the ambience of Hong Kong! The trams are an easy way to meander through different districts and slowly take in the sights!

Charming experience. Top up your tourist Octopus card with some value for easy payment of $2.30 per ride. If not, pay exact amount as the driver doesn't give change. Sit on the upper deck right at the front for the best views.
slow and cheap. this is the oldest transport system in hong kong... very slow at the same time very cheap... its a good way to explore the Central area of the city
Slow trip through the city. Cheap transport, but nothing special, although this is a very historic mode of transport. Cost is HK2.3 per person for the trip.
Enjoyable. Good way to travel to see Hong Kong Island, fare less than $3, can't believe. Of course, if you are in hurry, take the subway will much faster.

Very worthy train. This is older historical train in Hong Kong island. One price you can take a ride the whole Hong Kong island! Make sure take a sit at the top floor! It ride slowly from the head to the end of Hong Kong island! Big window can give you more view! It excellent tourists train .
Fun ride and you must try it if you are a Tourist. Confusing stops but you can always ask from other passengers. Very cheap and you may use Octopus Card.

Cute Way to Travel. If you are like me and you've never been on a skinny double-decker tram you might love this as much as I did! It is quaint and efficient and a lovely way to see some different areas while resting your legs. I recommend going upstairs and sitting right at the front for the best views. Cheap too - it was only 2 or 3 HK dollars.In my opinion, much better value for money than the big double decker buses that transport you to all the glossy 'must-sees' for more than HK$400.The trams basically run in a straight line so you can get off anywhere and if you don't feel confident to just go for a walk using a map you can simply catch the tram heading in the opposite direction to go back to your starting point.

Cheap way to sightsee the northern part of Hong Kong Island. For less than HKD3 you can take the tram from Kennedy Town in the west to Shau Kei Wan in the east, and during the journey of well over an hour, get to see different neighbourhoods along the northern shore of Hong Kong Island.

Double decker!. The tramway in Hong Kong is one of the oldest in the world and the only double decker cars. It is the easiest and cheapest way to get around Hong Kong. Not the fastest way to get around, but if you want to experience what the locals do and enjoy some old world charm, hope on a tram. Make sure you get an Octopus Card before hand,from any MTR station, because there is no ticket dispensing on the tram.

A fun way to get around Hong Kong!. Sit on the upper deck, try to get a front window seat, and enjoy the ride! At the end of the tram line in Central, you will get off right in front of brick building that has some interesting shops, including the 80M toy and model shop, where you can get fantastic large and small scale models of airplanes, buses, trams and ships. Enjoy!

Hong Kong Tramways (Ding Ding). So many simple and basic and very inexpensive extremely enjoyable things to do in this amazing city. Riding the Hong Kong trams ranks right up there with riding the Star Ferries. So? Just DO IT.

Passage to reach peak . Caught the tram station from HongKong central . Had to walk a bit but there were signs showing the correct path . If you have a octopus card you don't need to be in the queue to buy the tickets , otherwise if you need to buy a package offer then you need to be in the queue. The sky tower will cost you extra if don't buy the package offer . The trams are a unique experience but crowded .

So cool!. I am a sucker for all things nostalgiac, and these double-decker street cars do not disappoint! They're handy for traveling short distances, and they're a cheap way to check out the city. I definitely recommend sitting on the top floor, and up front if at all possible.

Jump on and go. Still one of the best (and cheapest) ways to traverse part of Hong Kong. Locals and tourists alike, use it to get across the city- don't be afraid, take your change, throw it in and hitch a ride.
Loved It.. Star ferry and Tram are the unique must have experience while in hong kong. Amazing to see such things in an ultra modern city. Very well maintained and inexpensive.
Fun transport. Not the fastest and limited where you can go, but a fun way for tourists to travel, octopus card doesn't work on these.

Not fast but frequent and interesting. Get on at the rear and exit and pay at the front. Of course you can use your Octopus card which is my recommended form of payment. The trams will have some different destinations on the front and rear but they run east/west and a spur goes off south to Happy Valley. Try to pick up a tram map or access it on your smartphone. Great for taking video and I wish I'd had time to do it at night which would've been extra special.

A great Hong Kong experience. . There were many locals on these teams so as well as a tourist attraction they have some real use as well. Great to jump on and off, and if you've got kids with you they're sure to love them. Low cost as well.
Fun and quaint. Funny, narrow trams that look like big toys! A a lovely reminder of travel in past times but are still well used today.

Had to do experience. Used this tram to go to the Peak, tram so close to our hotel in Fortress Hill, got to sit upstairs, minimal in cost, stops many times but allowed for that, using our easy to get around Otopus card, definitely worth getting.The only issue we had, tram drivers, not a lot speak English, & to try & find where we have to go even though we had our map which was useless, by looking at our map, we felt that there was only 1 line... However this is not the case... trams end & then you have to get off to connect to other trams which there is nothing of a graph on the trams to tell you, where you need to go " as like" when you catch the trains. If it wasn't for continually asking some good folk on the trams that we asked if they speak English, we would havefound this journey to be even more difficult. One lady telling the tram driver for us where we need to get off. Big thanks to her.Other wise loved the tram to look at the visuals around & enjoy the experience.

A "Ding Ding" of a ride through Hong Kong. These little "Ding Ding" trams, whilst not as fast as a bus or MTR service, they are fantastic if you want to see the sites of Hong Kong while you are getting to your destination. Its a bit like a hop-on, hop-off situation as they run almost every 5 minutes in either direction, so if you see a shop, restaurant or point of interest, you just hop-off and hop back on again later. The fares are very cheap, HK$2.5 for adults or HK$1.1 for seniors, (over 65), on current exch rate this is about AU$0.45 or AU$0.20 for a senior. Most off the time the tram operators take a HK$2 or HK$1 coin so its very easy to use this service.Its certainly worth a trip upstairs in a Ding Ding, just make sure that the windows are closed when it rains??The routes that they follow are quite long so you can go from one end of the CBD area at Kennedy Town, thru Central, to Causeway Bay and Happy Valley and return, all for HK$2 or HK$1. If you are in Hong Kong for Four (4) days I would suggest that you buy a Four (4) Day Pass which costs HK$34, (approx AU$6.50) and allows unlimited rides, hopping & on & off as much as you like with this ticket.I would throughly recommend this tram service for getting in and around the main parts of Hong Kong Island. Of course if you want to go to Kowloon or the New Territories, Stanley etc., then the bus or MTR are the options. All in all the "dings Dings are a fantastic experience

Love Trams. I lived in Wanchai and liked taking the trams. But weekday lunch times are alway packed and Sundays are also packed with domestic helpers. Great to take the trams during night time from Sheung Wan to Wan Chai during the weekdays. That’s really enjoyable!
Fun for photos. Great system that is still running. Fun to take for a ride. Watch you head getting in and out as ceilings and doors are very low. But very nostalgic

Oldstyle. Great way to wee the city life and extremely cheap. I went there a sunday evening, when all the housekeepers have their day off. Nice to see them having picknick in the middle of the streets.

Must Try Once. It is very cheap only HK $2. Our family had a great time travelling and photographing along the way. The trams travel relatively slowly and that way you can take in the sights and sounds easily.

Traditional way to travel across HK island. Got to do it as part of your HK trip. You can either do the whole journey, or do the more scenic part nearer to Central area. Wan Chai area could be a little slow. Mind the Happy Valley loop which is not the direct east -west route. I always step on the ding ding foot button when I get on... look for it and have a go... haha!
Tradition. We made several trips , its not fast or comfortable but is very nice because reminds us of old times. A must do.

Lovely way to observe the city. Great way to unwind as you watch the city go by. If you take the tram from one end point into the city, you will see different things - from residential areas to financial districtEasy to navigate and a cheap way to explore the city!My tip would be to get your fare ready when you exit as it can be very crowded. Use the octopus card if you have it!
nostalgic. A very low low cheap transport on hong kong island, i think the best way to see the city from the top of this tram.

Another must do on a visit to Hong Kong. Slow and noisy way of seeing one of the main streets on The Island, very cramped so a few interesting aromas on a humid day but easy to hope off and on to break up a sight seeing journey

Very crampy. Took a tram from Sai Ying Pun to Central (peddler st) at 6.45pm. Not a good idea, as it was crowded and crampy. My previous tram experiences were much better, taken in off peak hours. But it is a must try!!! First of all, it is cheap, 2.3hkd/ride, scan octopus card only when u get off in the front, or pay coins, no change given. It travels at a leisurely pace but not too slow, and you will be able to get a different city sighting experience. Strongly recommended for newbies to HK, and do get upper deck seats, if you know where you will be alighting.

Great fun. Great pace and easy access along the front of central.jump on until the end jump off and jump back on to return.
Great fun thing to do to see the HK world go by
Quaint. Very slow but cheap mode of transport. Good service and easy to access. wouldmthoroughlynrecommend it

hong kong april 2016. A very relaxing ride from Western Market to Causeway bay through Central Hong Kong
easy to get, just hop on at the back and pay when you get off very very cheap, Slow but you can experiece the Hong Kong way of life.
Great way to experience Hong Kong. We have used the trams this past week regularly, and found it a great way to get around, taking in the sites of such a busy city.

Step hack in time. What a cheap and fun way to get around.
These quaint trams are so cheap to use and provide a great way to observe Hong Kong day to day life at a little more than walking pace. Don't miss out on this one of a kind experience!

Amazing tram network. We used all the mode of public transportation in Hongkong, MTR, ferry and tram. Hongkong has an amazing tram network, economical and enjoyable.
We enjoyed a lot while using the tram.
A must ride when in Hongkong
Loving 120. I always find that Tram is always better than MTR if you are not in hurry, the traditional No. 120 is my favourite, so classy.

Something to experience. These cute little trams look like double decker buses that have been squished!We caught one the length of the Island from Causeway Bay to Central Station - not the fastest way, but certainly has character.We were on the top and noticed the windows were open to a degree that wouldn't be allowed in Australia - stick your arm or your head out and it would've been struck by the tram coming in the opposite direction - SO BE VERY CAREFUL WITH CHILDREN SITTING THERE!!!We caught it at a street stop, not the depot, and had no idea where the destinations on each one were- had to ask a local to ascertain that they all go to or past Cemtral Station EXCEPT the ones going to Happy Valley.Very cute and cheap form of transport.
Nice views from the upper deck. For good viewing be sure to go to the upper deck of the tram. It isn't a very fast way to travel but is quite fun.
Good fun!. Got to go on the trams if you are in Hong Kong. Buy an Octopus card for the MTR and use it on the trams too

Double Dekker Trams. Using an OCTUPUS card makes it easy to travel on these tramways. The cost is per ride not the distance. It is delightful to sit on the top and enjoy Hong Kong. There are signs at every stop showing where the tram continues.
An OCTUPUS card costs less for people 65 and older.
Slow but fun!. It is a fun experience to be on Tramways. It is slow, but enjoyed the different feeling being in such a busy city.

Easy and fun!. If you are staying at Hong Kong Central the tram is an easy transportation way for you. It costs only 2.3HKD and you can travel the whole island. It stops everywhere so you can hop on or hop off whenever you want.It is a perfect way of transportation on rainy days, but make sure you close the windows! You will have fun; they look cute and the way they ride is so much fun.

A part of the history of HK !. This is strange to see those old chaps riding in the streets of modern HK. They are tall on a short wheelbase and seems to come from the past. The pawn is a good place to go and eat (terras) and seeing them pass in front of you)

Transport in HK. This my 1st time on ding ding bus after so many years of travelling to HK. Interesting ride from sei yin pun to causeway bay. I can see the many walks of life on the ding ding and at the desinated bus stop u alight from u are able to still do your shopping whether is high end or low end. LIKE.
Amazing -A must do!!. See my longer review under The Peak. This is one of those things you must do. It is great fun & well worth while. Cheaper rates for Seniors as well.
Got to do it. Can't visit Hong Kong without taking the tram ride. At 2 HK$ for whatever journey it's a great way a seeing the sights.

A real experience!. Super pocket friendly and a great way to get about and see Hong Kong island if you have plenty of time.The trams are frequent and always busy.Not any good if you have any kind of disability as it's quite a big step up and down when your journey ends.Cost wise it's tuppence ha'penny as my man used to say - approx 3/4 HKD - equivalent of 30p a trip.There is no air conditioning so if you are looking to cool down then I would recommend the MTR instead.
Great fun. The tram runs from one end of Hong kong to the other, easy to jump on and off, crowded but useful. Also you can use your Octupos card.

Amazing experience-Sit front top. Loves these trains at 3.5HKD regardless of length of journey. Try and sit in the front at the top for best views.Running early in morning til late night these are such good fun. Information and maps at all stops-Swipe Octopus card upon alighing at the front of the tram, or can pay in cash (correct change only) to driver.

Cheap and very cheerful. Once you find out where you are going by asking lots of people you finally get on and for just over $2HK it is worth the ride. Try and sit at the front of the tram on the top floor and get a great view of city life! A must while in HK.
Very very old and small. It is a cheap way of going around HongKong island. I am not impressed though as it is so small and since my husband is tall he can't even stand straight inside.

Leisurely and cheap way to see the real Hong Kong. When in HK I just love using the tramway system. You sense the history of this means of transport, and it provides a great way to observe HK and its people getting on with their lives. Don't expect an express deluxe service as it chunters through the island from its west to east cutting through the commerce heart of HK. It is what it is, a tram that provides regular and basic transport, and most importantly is is very cheap. 20pence (UK) or if like me your in the third phase of your life, 10p. What is not to enjoy about this experience.

Everything in Hong Kong is narrow and tall - even trams. There are many of them, following each other one after another. Try getting into the hot spot at the front of the tram's 2nd deck. Paying at the driver is a need to know.

Sit Back and Enjoy. We use the tramways every time we are in Hong Kong. Your octopus card works on the Tramway also. A great way to see real life is just to get on a tram and go until the end of the line and then just come back again. You see a slice of real HK life.

Our favourite way to travel on Hong Kong Island. This tram system is over 100 years old and a lot of fun. It is also very cheap only HK $2.30. Our family had a great time travelling and photographing along the way. The trams travel relatively slowly and that way you can take in the sights and sounds easily.

I love the Ding Ding. Okay, I still ride the cable cars in San Francisco and I've lived here 12 years. On a rainy day in Hong Kong, I got a seat on the top deck, front seat and rode it from Kennedy Town to North Point. It cost 2.30 HKD. It can be crowded. There are reasons to stop all along the way. A funky market on a side street. A soccer game in the park, a good dim sum place (I got off in front of a church to take pictures of a wedding party). There are both tourists and natives who like to strike up a conversation. The best things about public transportation
Something you have to try!. Used the trams many times whilst in Central. It's cheap and great fun jumping on and off. Watch your footing though.
Slow but sure!. It is a slow way to travel but the upside is you get to see all of HK from above. A good experience for the whole family.
new experience. since we were a small pack family with young kids., the kid is happy to this experience..its easy just like mtr, but not all district in HK have tram..

A great way to see the city. If you are traveling in Hong Kong then you will want to step back in time and hop on one of the Tramways. The system is simple to navigate and use. Having an Octopus card will make traveling on here much easier.

110 years of history!. Taking the ding ding tram is great way to travel around Hong Kong if you have lots of time to spend for sightseeing the street of Hong Kong as this tram travel quite slowly and it keeps stopping at either the tram stop or the traffic light.
if you are rushing for time, take the MTR instead.

Another Hong Kong Classic. The HK tram is famous and like the Star Ferry a wonderful experience on a shoestring budget. You can take the tram all along Hong Kong Island from Quarry Bay to Kennedy Town, use it as a hop-on and hop-off if you want to stop somewhere and you can see a lot of the city by getting a window seat.

It's worth going from one end to the other IF you have time at hand. I wouldnt recommend using the tram if you need to get from one point to another fast. One local said that only old people use the tram because they have time (it is so slow). However, if you havent been to HK before, then I would use it to get a feel for the place, hop on at one end, get a seat on the upper deck, just watch the scenery and get off at the other end. Make sure you accommodate 1.5hrs though.
Bit of a Sore Slog. This is everything the MTR is not; slow and uncomfortable. Only make use of this transport if (a) you are obsessed with trams or (b) stop gap transport to get to the MTR

Must Do!. the tramways are still running from the old days of Hong Kong's past. they are different from other trams, all being double decker and narrow. it's a great way to explore Hong Kong central on a rainy day and very cheap too. Each ride costs about $2-3. you hop on and you can ride as much as you like. then when you get off you deposit the money in the box and hop out. there is no change given. we rode the tram from Sheung Wan to Causeway Bay and back. Highly recommend to everyone.

I guess it's one of those "must do's". Why wouldn’t you not want to ride one of these historic vehicles if in Hong Kong! You should - and do ride upstairs where you will get fabulous views up and down other streets. Very cheap and a good way of getting around town. Have small change with you.
Just for experience. Take it for a short ride just to get the feeling. It will cost about 2 hkd. Pick a second floor seat and enjoy the surroundings.

Still Great. This is a great way to see the city for travelers. I've lived in HK for a long time and still enjoy taking the Ding Ding. Go to the end of the line and wait for a new train to get the front seat, and ride it until the end of the line. I did that with my son when he was younger. He and I loved it. The price - about USD0.30 per ride is about as inexpensive as it comes. One can also hop-on and hop-off to explore the city. Have Fun!

Great ride. . Caught the tram back from a day at the Coastal Museum. Being one of the first on we managed to sit in the front seats of the top deck and great a great view on the way back to Central. The windows were open and we could take pictures and watch the daily life of Hong Kong from our vantage point. We would recommend at least a one way ride by tram.

A must do if visiting Hong Kong !. Edwardian England , still running , a great way to ride from Central to admiralty to Wanchai to Causeway Bay , mite fun than the MTR, your Octopus card works on it, board from the back , exit ( and pay ) at the front , on a crowded tram the trick is to edge forward to stand a chance of getting off at your stop.
Great. I loved the tour with the Tram. Very cheap and fantastic to click pictures of the city. We took it to go from Central to Causeway Bay for around 2 HK dollars.

Good old classic. Felt it had to be done & glad I did Enter one end exit the other, can get very cramped at busy times. Cheap easy way to travel using your octopus card. Some of the older trams you enter through a turnstile.

Enjoy the city! . Really the best transport in HK that allows you to enjoy the city, feel the pace, watch the people and be part of the everyday life of the people living, working here! And it is so cheap that you can take a ride from the eastern to the western across the HK island at only HK$2.3 (~0.3USD) for each ride! Don't miss it!

Ride with the locals. Most of the people on the trams seemed to be local folks getting around town. This is not like the cable cars of San Francisco where the pricing and limited service keeps the locals away. I highly recommend the Octopus card as a convenient way to pay for your trips...which are very inexpensive.I climbed to the top when ever possible to get a better view of the city.This is a throw back to old style city life. Windows that open, folks chatting with others. Frequent stops so it takes a while to cover long distances, but completely charming.

It's big!. I know, just another Buddha right? True, but the fun is getting there and wandering around the surrounding shops, monestaries and landscape at the base. The climb up to the Buddha isn't that bad and the view from the top is great!

Transportation. I like the Tram, especially for short journeys. I can just get off and walk to the target shop or destination without hassel. It is so convenient, and cheap. If I use the subway, I have to walk up and down; and in some stations miles before I can get to my destination. Tram is just an easy and simple way of transportation - a straight line and you will not get loss.
good old days. a comfy ride on a trusty little tram. It's just like a bus, but a bus of the olden days. Trams are cute transport

One of the cheapest and fun self organized tour options in HK. Here is what you do. Take the MTR to Tai Koo and get off an take the tram on Kings Road all the way back to its terminus in Western. It will be a couple of hours, but get the right seat upstairs in the front and just enjoy. Have that camera ready because you are going to go through some "real" parts of HK, especially around Wanchai and Sai Ying Pun (where the waft of dried seafood may force you away from the windows!). Don't get on the Happy Valley tram! Its only half the journey. Whitty Street terminus is good, but exit before the terminus.
A fun ride for the whole family. Taking the tram is fun for everyone. Do try to get a seat upstairs with a better view and just take any route and enjoy the life of Hong Kong.

Not just a tourist attraction. A taste of old Hong Kong. Used regularly by the locals as well as tourists, Interesting difference between the antique feeling inside the tram as compared to the modern, fresh look of the outside of the tram cars which are entirely painted in the color scheme and design of the current day advertisers.
A joy ride!. Just a little over 2 HK dollars you get a good trip around HK district. Convenient and less walking compared to MRT and also much much cheaper with a nice view.

See into first floor life. This is the bargain ride of HK. 2.3$HK. You have to do it. Take it to Shau Kei Wan because you will see a bit of old and new HK. It is slow too. But get upstairs and stare into the shops, workshops, hairdressers and see how locals live.
Great fun. Travellers tip; you pay on exit with the correct money only, make sure you have the (fixed) fare of 2.30 HKD (when we were there)

The perfect tram adventure - see Hong Kong's streets comfortably with lunch or dinner at journey's end. For a relaxed half hour journey with promise of lunch at your destination, wait at the tram stop outside the headquarters of HSBC in Central for a tram marked Kennedy Town which is where the line ends. Make your way upstairs for a good view of people scurrying along the streets going about their daily routines, take in the aromas of dried fish and seafood as you pass through Sheung Wan where dozens of dried seafood shops line the street and see what is being sold in other shops that seem to offer endless assortments of plastic goods and stuffed toys. Your journey will finish at the junction of Catchick and Davis Streets. As you alight, pay your HK$2.30 fare. There are lots of restaurants around - our recent choice for an excellent lunch was an old favourite, Bistro du Vin, every time a winner! Set lunches are excellent value, US$15 for two courses at time of writing, the evening menu is fine dining, there's a great wine selection - a favourite with the growing number of French expats who live nearby. Take a look at the nearby harbour front and return by taxi (there is a rank across the road from Bistro du Vin) or look for signs to Kennedy Town MTR station. Or take the tram!

One of Things in Life You Have to Do... At Least Once!!. Totally inexpensive, slow, crowded, but just great fun! Plus, form the top floor, a great way to take in the sights along the streets of downtown HK Island. And many, many sights there are! Photographers dream really.
ding ding!. cheap, but you can use your octopuss card, a bit of history and is great fun, bit squashed but thats part of the joy
Fun experience a MUST. Very easy go ustairs and drive all the way to the end and then turn around again costs nothing please make sure you have exact amount no Change is give from the tramstaff

Old lazy way to see Hong Kong. We got on the tram at Tai Koo and got off at the Central escalators - a journey that took an hour, although the MTR would have been just 15 minutes! It is a brilliantly lazy way to see Hong Kong, and it's really nice to just see the streets with people going about their every day business.
Very good reliable frequent service. Clean easy to use service, very cheap could teach Brit city's a thing or two about a good transport system

Wonderful experience. A must do to experience transportation in the early days of HK. Most trams have plastic seats which offer a better ride than the wooden ones. There are 6 routes all along Northern HK Island. Take a look at the web site and you will find attractions accessible from the trams.

Nice and efficient. The ding ding as it is called in Hong Kong, is cheap, and doges traffic wonderfully. An old fashioned tram, rickety but lovely...sit on the upper level and enjoy the views. You can ride for a couple of hours and get a very good, overall impression of Hong Kong, or you can use it to go from A to B in a short time. I find it scenic and efficient if you travel on the north side of Hong Kong island
Slow, but fun to ride.. Slow, but fun to ride. Many stops between the MTR stations. Only HKD2.60 per ride. Sit at the upper levels to have a good look of the surrounding
Nice experience. Pretty crowded but people very friendly and accommodating to move around to let others on/off. Nice way to get across town. Lots of locals!

A cheap and easy way to see some parts of Hong Kong you might miss!!. A great way to get around parts of HK - runs the length of the island from Western through Central and on to Saukiewan but also a good and very cheap (about 23p!!) sightseeing tour - head out to Saukiewan (from Wan Chai about 45 minutes) - the end of the line to see where some of the locals live - experience a veg and meat markets - with some things you might not expect to see ;-)

Old Style Travel Through HK Streets. We were walking through the quiet area of Kennedy town on a Sunday & decided to try out the tram since we had the whole day to relax.It is the cheapest mass road transit as compared to taking the bus, cab or MTR and for good reason. Unlike the vehicles running on petrol, the tram running on electric rails are far slower & pick up stops every 2 blocks.Since the speed of travel is much slower, you are able to observe things in the street and notice different characteristics of each area. You have time to study an interaction of people in the sidewalk and see details you would otherwise miss in a bus.I appreciated my tram ride because it was a nice tour around the streets without being rushed.
Nice ride on scary tram. This tram is an old English built tram climbing the mountain towards Big Buddha. Its slow through the bush with extreme slope.

Tramways - A different experience . In Hong Kong, it is the MTR which is preferred to commute. I don't know exactly the routes for which tram is must to take but we were asked to take tram from Causeway Bay to the The Pacific Place to go to the Hong Kong park to take the peak tram.In our tram journey we sat on the top deck and took the front seat (we got it as we boarded the starting point) and the view of the city was amazing.If MTR is the most convenient way to commute, the tram is a must try if you are a visitor.

Nice Transport Across HongKong Island. With a fixed fee, you can take the tram as long as you want, get down wherever you want and experience difference places of HongKong island. Its worth a few trips.

See Central Hong Kong . This is an easy way to see a great part of Hong Kong island. We rode ftom one end to the other. Fun to watch all the people, especially on a rainy Sunday afternoon. Enter at the back and pay at the front as you exit.

Fun Cheap Transportation. The Hong Kong Tramways are a fun cheap way to see the city. You can hop on an off or just stay on for a nice tour. They go sort of slow but that is nice as you can see things rather than whizzing by them. After hours of walking around Central, we we were delighted to get on the tramway for awhile and relax while taking in the sites.

not only for freaks. a must. . well, being a big fan of transportation stuff, it is one of the highlights for me. but also beside that, it is for sure a highlight for everybody. sit upstairs and wait some stops till you can change to your favorite seat.

Try it at least once. Having visited HKG many times - I strongly recommend to try these at least once. The quickest and most convenient way if travelling a short distance. A nice experience at a funny price. Try to climg to the second floor for views and a breeze. Having said all of that a not so pleasnt thing to do in the hot and humid season

A must do. We thoroughly enjoyed the tram ride through the neighbourhoods. It is cheap gives great views and gives your legs a rest. I think this should be on a hong kong must do list. We went upstairs and had the front seats. It is photo friendly as all the windows pull down.

A must do for a new visitor to HK, Iconic experience, and an excellent way of observing the HK street scene. Worth doing, especially if you can get a seat on the top deck, start at the western market stop, which is a very short walk from central MTR and star ferry, I would suggest you travel to Causeway bay, and just sit back and soak up the atmosphere and at HKD 2.30 a bargain !

Do not miss these. We spent a fair time over on the island & utilized the Ding Dings everyday They are an excellent way to get around Hong Kong & very reasonably pricedAn Octopus card is a necessity as it speeds up the process of hopping on & off

Tramendous!. Get on, get off, get on get off, get back on again and then jump off again and you still haven't spent a pound doing one of the best things there is to do on the island! Stand at the back of the tram, just as you get on and in the floor you will see a metal button; use your heal to ding the bell and pretend you are the driver... Ding ding..... What fun being a big kid again and even better fun embarrassing the wife by doing it too often and way to enthusiastically. Get on it, it's a no brainier!

Cheapest way to get around. The tram is the cheapest transportation on the island. Flat fare regardless of the length of travel. Kids got a kick out of sitting upstairs as these trams are double deckers. They get really busy and can cram in lots of pasengers so make sure you get ready to get off from the stop before. You pay as ypu leave and this can be cash or octopus card. Worth a try. I prefer the MTR though but when in hong kong, you need to try everything.

A novel (and very touristy) way to get about. I loved using the trams! It's not the quickest way to get anywhere but it is very cheap and if you're not under any time pressure then it's a fantastic way to see the city. Travelling from Kennedy town in the west of the island to Sai Wan Ho in the east (and back again), the trams are regular and frequent. They offer a great view of the city at a steady pace. I got a fantastic time-lapse video of the experience, shame I can't share it on here. A thoroughly recommended experience.

A Must Ride Tram Whenever you visit Hong Kong. The tram ride was great, after we went to Wing On Dept Store and Sincere Dept. Store from Shung Wan, we did take the tram for Shung Wan all the way to North Point, it was one of a kind of experience, wherein you see all the great sights of Hong Kong, as the tram traveled to your desired destination. Highly recommend to take the Upper Deck Seats to get a fantastic view of Hong Kong.

They sit in traffic like cars! . I thought the trams might have there own tracks, but they sit in traffic with the cars. I'm not really sure how trams usually work, this could be entirely normal! But just something to be aware of.
It was nice to experience, but I wouldn't be rushing to do it again.

Just sit and ride . The double decker ding dings, or trams on Hong Kong island, are a fun way of getting around the island.
