If you are in a hurry you can better use the MTR, but if you have time and want to look around, you can take the tram which takes you through Sheun Wan, admiralty, central, causeway bay etc. Single flat fare of 2.3 HKD which you can pay by octopus or cash when leaving the tram at the frontside.

$2.3 hk! Tourist must do!. This is a fantastic experience, for the price of a newspaper! Make sure you go upstairs and get a window seat. The tram travels along the busy main streets only, so you won't get lost. You can see all the street views and many of the big buildings along the way. Super authentic and old school experience.

slow trolley ride ding ding. As with previous reviews can only add if you want a cheap way to view Hong Kong island $2.3 gets you a front seat on a nostalgic ride as it rumbles along centre of the highway I must for sightseeing or if not in a hurry cheap way to get about You only pay when alighting either coins or use you octopus card Yes old yes dated yes rumble etc etc but nostalgia is magical

Ding Dong A MUST. The double decker tram is a must for tourists!The tram runs from east to west, including Happy Valley, on the island side only. It is normally used for short haul rides for the locals since it is not a fast mean of transportation, and the stops are very frequent and one can get very close to the destination. I believe there is a tourist tram with an open top deck, and I have not tried it since I consider myself local. The tram fare is fixed at just over HK$2 for all rides.One can travel from Saukiwan (east) to Saiyingpun (west) , and be able to view most of the north side of the island. Tourists should get on the tram and go to the upper deck for a better view, and to avoid the crowdedness on the lower deck. Beware of pick-pockets!Enjoy your tram ride in HK!
Hong Kong trams . Hong Kong trams are a great way to travel around Hong Kong. Very affordable . Just need HK $2.30 for a trip on the tram

Ding ding!. Great way to get around the island for very little money. Sit up top and you get a different perspective of the city. Whilst they are quite slow you can actually get to where you are going faster than taking the metro in some cases, depending where you are going. Enter from the back and pay with your octopus at the front when you get off

My 50 cents.... Nothing more fun than to sit on the top level of these screeching trams while whisking by Central's diverse architecture. Don't be shy. Hop on! Most drivers have limited English but will patiently listen and tell you if this is the right tram/direction for you. Afterwards you will regret ever getting on the Big Bus (yes the locals are laughing at you) Unique experience to be had for pennies. I think this beats San Francisco's cable cars (and I am a proud SF resident ;)

Go Slow and Get Home. If you are in a hurry, catch the MTR. If you want a quick trip back in time or only going a few stops then make sure you catch a Ding Ding! They are so small, and most or really old wooden ones in service for decades. If you are above 170cm watch you head, low clearance everywhere. They stop constantly for passengers and traffic signals, but as long as you are not in a rush make for a funny little trip across town.

Good experience but bumpy ride. Out of curiosity, we took the tram ride from Sheung Wan MTR to a station near the peak tram ride. It just costs HK$2.30 and u pay when alighting. The ride was very bumpy and is like the tram constantly bumping on the tracks. The tram looks very old and rusty but anyway we enjoy the bumpy experience.
Cheap way to see the city. Cheap and unique way to tour Hong Kong. Can be busy at times, but nonetheless is a must for anyone visiting the city.
Nice ride. We enjoyed the tram ride through Hong Kong. Very cheap way to enjoy the city at a slow pace. Sit at the top and get a great view.

Go for a ride!. The Ding Ding is amazing, you can just walk in, stay in and see the whole city for almost square nothing! And when your done, you get out, get lost at the place where you are, till you don't want to walk anymore, you find the nearest Ding Ding and hop on again, life can't get better than that! Ont tip: make sure you have enough coins or a octopus-card, otherwise you can't get out

Cheap and convenient. I found this the best way to commute from the west to the east of Hong Kong. The tram travels down the centre of the main street and covers all of the main shopping areas and hotels. A short walk from the tram line and you can fine many other interesting places to see. No card to purchase, only cash is accepted once you leave the tram (coins only - no change given). Very cheap and everyone makes use of it. Trams run every few minutes and stop at tram stations along the way.

Slow, but fun and great for sight seeing.. It's not worth using if you're in a rush, instead take the bus or MTR, but! If you're looking to sightsee I definitely suggest it. Especially during the week at off-peak (working) hours ... But then again, this is Hong Kong and it's always peak hour. It's fun and cheap ($2.3HKD) so go and enjoy!!!

Cheapest transportation in Hong Kong island. Must experience this unique transportation available since decades. Seat on the top floor to enjoy the Hong Kong daily life and the scenes specific to each area of the Island (Sheung Wan, Central, Wanchai, Admiralty, Causeway Bay, etc).As of today, it costs only HK$2.30 per trip and you can stay as long as you wish during the whole trip. Pay when leaving.

Very cheap and got us back from the races. We got the tram back from Happy Valley Racecourse and it was very cheap. It was a fun way to get home - I imagine a morning on it would be a great way to see some of Hong Kong
Cheap way to travel from place to place. Just love to travel on the Ding Ding. Cheap n easy. Though no air cond but it is a local experience. Can be very crowded during peak period.
Convenient, fun (cheap). Easy on, easy off. Better have the octopus card first. Buy at convenience store or subway. It's not only a must-do, it's a pretty good way of getting around.

Super cheap, interesting snapshot of Hong Kong island. On a lark I got on it. Surprised when I got off (using an octopus card) it was barely a North American dollar. Takes you through a variety of districts, showing off the local flavour.Not fat, but an incredible bargain. Well with comparing to San Francisco street cars, especially since ours so very inexpensive!

It doesn't hurt to experience it!. Bit confusing if you haven't tried them before. Ended up asking someone which tram to get to Causeway Bay.
Very small, very crowded, had to go upstairs, but you do get to see somethings along the way. Give it a go for a hoot.
Great way to see Hong Kong. So so cheap and a wee bit of tradition. Sit upstairs on a double decker tram and traveller the length of Hong Kong. It's great fun!

Awesome and affordable. I will not be mistaken is i say that the Ding Ding is the cheapest way of getting around Hong Kong after the free of charge walking of course. It costs only 2,3 HKD, is really fun and authentic experience!

Experience a good variety of Hong Kong from west to east.. Take the route with the longest stretch from west to east or vice versa, one will see some of the dry seafood shops that have been operating for over a century in the west, the CBD in Central and a mix of modern and semi-old residential apartments in the east. A good initial touch of Hong Kong just within an hour. Take it during off peak hours and travel high on the upper deck - economical not just in monetary terms.
Great way to get around!. This is something fun to do to say you've been on it. It's also a great way to get around quick and easy.

Tramway ride. we rode the tram as part of our hello hong kong food tour, a must do if you have kids. Its pretty inexpensive and go to the top floor, as travelers move in and out, you can secure a seat

Sit on the top deck and get a great view of the city.. Best hint of all. You only pay when you leave the tram. It's fabulous to use such an old method of travel to witness the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong. You get to see so many districts. An absolute must.

Hard to navigate!. Google maps recommended taking the tram to get to a particular restaurant we were looking for. Advice : get on the tram at the end and pay at the end of the journey!We got on the tram in the wrong direction and walked to the front and paid! Drivers of both trams we went on didn't speak great english nor were they very helpful.
Ding Ding is a must when you visiting HK!. When you are coming to HK you definitely should take the "Ding Ding" at least one time. It is cheap HK$2.8 and good for sightseeing views.

Lazy way for touring Hong Kong Island. We had an hour or so to spare before getting to the airport so our choice were wandering around the shops or hop on the tram. We glad we choose the latter, Depending on the tram, we rode from Central to Kennedy town one way and there were hardly anyone so we sat on the top at the front seat and had a great view. On the way back however, the whole tram was so packed with what seem to be a tour group plus the local people.Cost $23 Hong Kong Dollars for one way ride and just drop the coins, notes into the box on the way out. There is no fuss if you pay more or less.If you plan to use the tram, have a map printed out so you can plan your trip better as there are no tram way maps that I could find on the trams or at the stops.
Seen while walking.. Love looking at old trams, anywhere. Great to seen them in everyday use. There was a variety of paint jobs which made them seem a bit more commercial than nostalgic.

Nice experience for all. This is probably the most 'adventurous' of all the modes of transport as you are a little more on your own in terms of finding your way to the tram stations and around the system.The tram ride is very cheap, seemingly a fixed price for however far you go on one tram. They are packed to the point of standing the entire length of the aisles but it's great to see the streets through Hong Kong from the upper deck.A real step back in time...

A pleasant experience at minimum cost. If you want to see a bit of old Hong Kong, it is worthwhile taking the tram from Central to Sheung Wan. There is no need to go to the top deck. Any difference is only psychological. It is a comfortable way to sit back and look outside. There is special discount for the elderlies. So, take your passport with you. It is worth the time!

Must try HK icon. Am sure every visitor to HK must have ridden on this cheap, slow paced vehicle. Tram stops are so close to each other you really need not worry even if you miss getting off at your desired stop. This tram service operates only on HK island not on Kowloon or NT side of the country

Cheap and Convenient. Great way to get Around Hong Kong Island. Only 2.30 Hong Kong Dollars and you never have to wait long. Although slow, you do get a chance to see your surroundings as opposed to the hustle of the MTR.

Rainy Day. It was raining heavily so we caught the tram from Causeway Bay to Kennedy Town. I relaxing afternoon in the dry watching the hussle and bustle of Hong Kong and generally see Hong Kong and getting ideas for further exploration. A very cheap way to travel. reminded me of the glasgow trams of late 50's.

Can't get lost and so reasonable. A super way to see a bit more away from the glitz of the shopping malls. Recommend get on and off wherever you like and no fear of getting lost as it only goes east to west and back. Get on at the back, pay on way off (so cheap around 25p) upstairs has great views if you can find a seat at the front.
Part of the HK Experience. Take the time to ride the trams for the few HKDs it costs; see the locals going about their lives. A must do in HK
Cheap and easy way of seeing the city. Cheap and easy way of seeing the city. Make sure you have the right change 2.3o $ . If you can sit up top front seats to watch the city as you travel around.
Must Try When You in HK. Ding Ding only available on HK Island. Thus is make it like an iconic product that a tourist must try when they are in HK.

A simple pleasure. A ride on the ding ding is a cheap and easy way to escape the frenetic pace of Hong Kong and rest before more walking and sightseeing. The trams come past every minute or so, there are no queues and they traverse the main road across the island making it a good way both to orientate yourself and to get, quite slowly, from A to B.

Relex tour. The tram station is just located next to my hotel. Everymorning after 10:00 am when the people are working or in school, I started my tram sightseeing tour. We sit on the upper deck and watch different parts of the city. The tram goes slowly and usually on the main road, that's easy for us to get off in case we find some attractive place or shopping spots. Besides, the fare for the tramonly cost $2.30 each way , we won't get lost because the opposite direction takes you back to the original place.Tram is a traditional , affordable and comfortable transportation in Hong Kong. I enjoy riding on it.

Tramway is heritage. Tramway is convenient to travel and is very cheap. Tramway is only HK$2.30 and only one fare from start to finish. Tramway does not provide changes and you must get the right change. Abit slow but nice to see Hong Kong slowly.
Fab. Nice way to see HK by night , we travelled along a whole route just to soak up the night life and atmosphere

A view of Hong Kong for next to nothing. Take a couple or hours out and jump on a tram and travel nearly the full length of Hong Kong and see the sights and busing streets for next to nothing, have some fresh fish at the turn around station and jump on the next tram back...its fun its cheap and you see lots, if the review was help please tick the help full box, thanks

When antique meets modern. Hong Kong's old trams are a rare gem in this ultra modern and high-tech world. I hope they will be preserved forever. They may not be as efficient and comfortable as modern trams, but add so much character to this city. And cost only 2 HKD (0.2 EUR)!!!!

must do in your hk list. a mandatory item if you are visiting hk the inst time. if you have some time, you should just pop in the tram for only hk 2.30. you will see the different sides of hk from the shopping, offices to the neighbourhoods

Fun ride. We had a fun ride on the tram to Happy Valley. Worth the HK $230! We stopped at Happy Valley and had a drink at a British Pub and then walked most of the way back to central along crazy busy shopping street. It was a fun afternoon.

More cheap Hong Kong Entertainment. At just HK$2.30 for an adult ride this is even cheaper than the Star Ferry. We caught the tram at Central and rode it out all the way to North Point (nearly an hour in total) and the contrast between the high rise office buildings and upmarket shops in Central to the market style shops and crowded low cost apartments as you moved further out of town was an amazing contrast. Prob. best to avoid peak hour travel times and the tram closely follows the Island MTR line to give you the option of a faster trip back to town.
Amazing!. Go back in time for few pennies and enjoy the tram. Also an amazing opportunity to see the city with no rush. Don't miss it.

A cheap and fun way to see the city unfold. Hop on at one end - we got on at Kennedy town - and sit on the top deck with the windows open and watch the different character of each neighbourhood unfold before you. The cheapest and best way to get a taste of Hong Kong

small, fun and cheap. Hong Kong trams system has only 1 line, but it cuts throw middle of the city from one end to the other. Trams run very often, so no need for time tables. Ride costs 2,3 HKD - you can pay cash or Octopus card. And good news is that it does not matter how far you go....you don't pay (scan card) when you enter - only when you exit.So good option for rainy days - take ride from one end of Hong Kong to another on the top floor :-)

The tram is fun! Reminds me of old HK movies. I took it just for the experience. you will def get to see parts of HK that you probably will never visit. I took the tram and got off at various parts of town. Then i went exploring. it was interesting. Then just took the tram back to the city. Worth it for the experience.

Fun thing to do. Riding the Ding Ding is definitely something to do at least once in Hong Kong. It's not that it's all that great -- it's slow and takes a while to get from point a to b -- but it's unique and cheaper than the MTR. Good scenery if you ride it all the way out to Happy Valley or North Point
Must do in HK!. Ding ding! We took it from Kennedy Town back to Causeway bay. What can I say? A must you can't miss when in Hong Kong!

Cheap ride with views. We rode the team from Tai Koo to Tin Hau, and it was a fairly good ride. Basically you can travel almost the length of Hong Kong Island for $2.3 - from Sha Kei Wan to Kennedy Town.It is above ground so you can see the street views and landscape.Downside is that if travelling in peak periods it can get very tight in space to a point where you feel your personal space is been compromised. Also, the tram is subjected to traffic lights so it does take longer than the MTR but it has more stops than the MTR, so you can get off the tram closer to the intended location.

A Super Cheap Way to see Hong Kong. Catch a tram, go to the top deck, slide open the big windows and let the breeze blow through your hair. The trams are modern, but look like they are old and traditional. From the top deck you can get some great photo opportunities of the bustling HK streets.

Fast and Convenient. It was my main mode of transport while in Hong Kong and im really thankful for it. It comes one after another, so you dont even have to wait for more than 5 minutes for the next one to arrive. Everyone goes in the same direction so you dont have to worry about which number you have to get on. As long as your destination is part of the route, you can just take any bus. The fare for one ride for each adult is HKD 2.30. And i just conveniently paid with my octopus card, you just tap when you are alighting.
Fun trip. Rode this with a local, so I'm not quite sure how difficult it would be to navigate solo, but it was a fun experience to ride the famous tram.
Real cheap means of transport. Caught the tram on a Friday night from Central to North Point which allowed us to see a lot more of area than by MTR.Price is $2.30 or $1.10 for 65+.

See Hong Kong the easy way. The Ding Ding Train traveled from east to west along the northern part of the island. The tram were frequent and easy to get on board. it is one of the easiest way to see this part of hong kong.
Ding ding!. This is the cheapest way to explore the island, entry via the rear, sit upstairs to get great views, easy to use stop numbers, don't use if you have children and strollers.
Ding ding is awesome. If u stay in HK Island, u will find it easily. It is the cheap public transportation, clean, and will show up in every 5 mins. It cost HKD 2.3. Worth to try when u visit HK :)

Cheap way to travel. As someone who grew up in Hong Kong, I don't get the same novelty feeling for this mode of transportation. It doesn't follow as tight of a schedule as busses or the MTR, and it can be tricky to try to crowd your way in and out during busy times. The price has not really gone up over the years, so it is definitely VERY cheap to use and is really the only plus. Do note that there is no map available or stop announcements, so you do need to know where you are going (driver will most likely not be multi-lingual).

Fun thing to do if you have time . Had a fun trip on the 'ding ding'. It was an old bone shaker mode of transport but for such a small amount of money, we got from one side of Hong Kong island to the other for less that £2.00! A silly but fun thing to do

plan your stop. nice experience actually, but make sure you know where you are headed and when you had to get off (memorize how many stop/station.) if you try to read the sign at the station,.. well at most cases it is already to late..

HK vintage transportation . Tram aka Ding Ding Che is one of HK oldest transportation and they only have it in HK island and they are very colorful. I love playing Ding Ding Che, it moves slower than other and stop at every station. So you can easily hop on and off wherever you want to go since there's one Ding Ding every 3-5 mins.

sampled it with the top deck front seats :). Not many parts of the world operate double decker trams, especially in densely populated areas with high rises like HK. This one was a nice experience where we took a short ride on the HK Island side. The cost is flat 2.3 HKD and one can get off-on anywhere. If you are in a hurry, this is not your ride though. Enjoy it while it lasts. Do try and get the top deck front seats for the view.
Historical ride!. The trip is not complete with a ride on this historical tram. Slow but you get to enjoy the city view.

A must try in Hong Kong. Tram in Hong Kong is still a daily transport just like bus. It is relatively so cheap and convenient that this is my priority. If you are walking in Central and you have to go Sheung Wan and also Admiralty, this must be your best choice. It is extremely good for the distance between one to two MTR stations. Since it is so cheap and convenient, there are sometimes so crowded. But, people seem not mind because it is so convenient.

Affordable transpo in HK Island. If you're not pressed for time and want to experience old HK commute, you should try riding the tram. It's the slowest among all their transportation mode but you will get to see and appreciate what's on the ground. It's just like riding a hop on- hop off bus. It passes from end to end of HK Island so if you see anything interesting, you can get off and go around with just $2.2 per ride.

We rode on this end to end just because my son loved it. We always go on this everytime we visit Hong Kong. My son just loves it so much. You enter from the back and disembark at the front. You also pay on exit too. $2.30 ( flat fare) for adults with cash or Octopus card. Less for kids and senior citizens. The tram is slow and runs only on the North side of Hong Kong island. The tram system is very old and you get to enjoy a side of old Hong Kong you wouldn't be able to see on a bus or taxi.Sit on the upper deck for better views. Most trams just have Windows that you open for ventilation. You can almost touch trams passing in the opposite directionsWould recommend any tourist to try this out

Brilliant. At $HK2.3 this is incredibly cheap.We used it on our last day to get from Fortress Hill to the Peal Tram. Great experience meandering through Causeway Bay, Wan Chai to get to Central. A cheap way to experience the island. Slow but they you can experience the different areas.

Good mode of transport in Hong Kong. Very easy way to travel in Hong Kong with the Tram. It travels either from west to east and vice versa. But there is a route from the west and east that's terminate midway at Happy Valley so this route does not travel all the way to the other end. Best part is, no matter how far is the distant you travel, it is a standard price of $2.50

Fun and cheap. Worth doing.Costs around 2HKD, which is about 20 and you can travel pretty much anywhere.If you sit on the upper level you get some amazing views of the streets.You get to see some of the real Hong Kong instead of all the tourist areas.

Great Way to Get from Happy Valley to Central. We used the Tram as a very effective and pleasant way of travelling from Happy Valley to Central, having caught a service bus from Aberdeen. It was a great way to see the city as the old tram trundles along between ultra modern skyscrapers. It offers a great viewpoint for a bit of people watching especially when you are stationary at the junctions.

Slow and cramp. Although this is one of the thing that represents HK but I must say that I don't really enjoy my rides on a Ding Ding. The tram was slow and cramp. Since we are tourists we do not know which stop we supposed to stop at and there was no announcement of the stops at all. The driver was not friendly enough to even tell you which stop we supposed to go although we have told him where exactly we wanna go. I don't think I will go on one of these Trams anymore.
The best trip in the world!!!!!!. The best trip in the world,I have never ride this trip.  I want to ride this every day or every week!
Great. The trams are as cheap as chips. Regular. And a great way to see Hong Kong. It's also a trip down memory lane. Sit at the very front or back on the top deck.

Great way to navigate north part of island. The tram is a great way to navigate the northern part of Hong Kong Island. Trams come to stops every minute or two. You pay when you get off either by exact cash or Octopus card. Cost is only 2.30 HK$ for adults and less for seniors and children. Older trams have relatively uncomfortable wood bench seats, but it's a good way to navigate east-west on the island.

Part of the authentic HK experience. It's slow, but great for covering very short distances along the north HK island belt, where it's too long to walk and too short for a bus ride. Be wary as you enter from the rear and exit at the front, the aisle is wide enough for only one person, so getting down at the immediate next stop might be difficult if the tram is crowded. Trams are cheap and have a single flat fare.

Awesome way to see Hong Kong. If you want a laid back and cheap way to see Hong Kong the look no further than the Tram way system.This old but reliable method of transport was once tried to be removed from the city but due to public demand was revived.Try it...You'll love it

a quick way across HongKong. Took this trip on our first full day in HongKong and it takes just one hour to complete. It could provide a lot more info on some of the new spectacular skyscrapers as well as the older sites and buildings. The ticket also gives you two extra days free rides on the main tramway as part of the price although we used the underground
Feel like a local . It was cheap but fun. Take the one with the open rooftop. Amazing experience. It went all around hong kong. I recommend night trips. Only $2 . Worth your money!

So Cheap and Such Fun. These Trams are as Old as The Hills but work Really Well in the busy streets of Hong Kong. They have Very Limited Routes but it is great to Jump on and go to the end of the line and return. Very VERY Cheap and if you can avoid rush hour a perfect way to see Hong Kong Island.

Ding....ding....along!. We were told the Tramways would be a good way to see Hong Kong so we spent a couple of hours riding one. It is very cheap to purchase tickets and we saw a lot of Hong Kong this way. The seats are hard and uncomfortable (but I have a bad back).
Great fun and so cheap!. These are such fun and a must do experience on Hong Kong Island. With an Octopus card, the fare was less than 20p a time - so hop on and hop off at leisure!

Loved it. I did try my best to take tram where ever it went. Loved traveling on it. I would suggest it to every one. I was bit confused with map as I am not good map reader. I would request tram company to promote it more to tourist.

Enjoyable scenic ride in the city on the Ding Ding. This is a must do on the history Ding Ding, and the cheapest mode of travel if it suits where you are going...at HDK 2.30. If you sit on the upper deck, it offers you a view of the city, and it is virtually 'jam free'. It takes a while to get to your destination but considering you don't have to walk a long distance, up or down escalators to the MTRs ....this is actually very convenient in HK island. I took it from near HK station to Causeway Bay. Loved the ride.

Cheap way to see HK. The tram (or otherwise known as ding ding) is a cheap way and convenient way to see HK, even though you'll have to crowd with the locals who take this as part of their daily commute.

A great way to get around the inner city streets in Hong Kong. Traveling on the trams is very low cost and its fun to be able to be in the middle of the busy-ness of Hong Kong without any hurry. Just sit back and take in the local comings and goings without the pressure of looking for specific streets etc. We loved taking our little grand children on the Ding Ding tram when they were toddlers.We still love the stress free ride of the trams years later

Clattering through central Hong Kong . Had to do this whilst here. Had rather a tortuous walk to get to the stop going in the right direction, going up & down footbridges. How they keep these rather elderly trams going is amazing. Glad we did it but the MTR is far more convenient.
Fun and cheap sightseeing. One wonders how come they don't derail. Pay under 3HK$, go to the upper level, sit in front and do the whole stretch. Reminded me of the similar one in Lisbon.

A trip back in time. We love to use the trams in Hong Kong and find them a cheap and excellent way to travel around the city. We always buy an octopus card as this is so easy and convenient when you are paying for things in Hong Kong.

excellent way to explore hk island. jump on the tram in kennedy town and try to secure a seat in the front..then just enjoy the ride all the way to the east..you will see the busy street life and get a good feeling for the different areas on the island..and all that for less than 3 hkd..
Great fun. Takes you on a great journey through some of the interesting shopping spots on Hong Kong. It's cheap and crowded, but not to be missed.

Lets Ding Ding. 香港漫遊及最便宜的交通工具，超過100年歷史的交通工具，主要在港島區；沿途穿梭大小街道，從民居到金融中心，至購物地帶。電車也讓香港人的步伐慢一點。特別適合年長人士及喜歡感受社區的遊客。大概分3-5條線，推薦跑馬地至堅尼地城線，不要忘記後門上車，前門下車的規則，後門上車右邊地下有一個腳踏位，踏下能發出'叮叮'聲，這也是本地對它的稱呼 "叮叮'The cheapest transport to Roaming in Hong Kong Isalnd. More than 100-year history of transport, mainly in Hong Kong Island; You can found from this tramm which shuttle along the streets, from houses to the financial center, to the shopping area. Trams also slow down our Hong Kong people's step . The tram especially for good for the senior tourist to feel the community.It divided 3-5 lines as recommended Happy Valley to Kennedy Town line. The rules to get in from the back door, the front door to get off。 When you get in from the back, try to find a button on the floor in right hand side. When u step on it will make a sound like "Ding Ding". As the local we call the tram "ding ding".'

A must do. We went by tram both ways and spent a couple of hours on them. They are slow bumpy and clatter along the track, possibly not good for commuting but as a tourist it was like a theme park ride. You will get a real flavour of street life in HK, highly recommended.

Happy I've done this! . Took a ride from Wan Chai to Kennedy town - different view of the city which is nice :) returning to wan chai the ding ding was crowded and we could hardly breathe. Kids enjoyed the experience - husband not so much.

Good to get around and see the city. Trams travel along central Hong Kong Island constantly. You hop on and pay HKD 2.30 when you get off. Warning - no change is given if you don't have the exact fare. Visitors will probably just use coins; locals tend to use the MRT public transport 'Oyster' payment system.Best to head for the upper deck, which gives good views and photo-taking opportunities. The trams can get very busy, standing-room-only busy, at commuter times. If all you want is to travel through the main part of Hong Kong Island, you can almost ignore the destination board of individual trams, as they all go along that route. If you intend to travel further afield, take more care in selecting the appropriate tram. Since many tourists are inclined to draw the windows down on the upper deck, to take photographs, that area can get somewhat cold, depending upon the weather, and can also get damp in the rain. If you aren't seeking views or intent on capturing images, you may wish to sit downstairs. Travelling on a tram is an almost must-do if visiting Hong Kong.

Nice way to explore the city. We used the team especially at night as the you don't find a lot of traffic. We went from central area to Wai Chai. The experience was very nice as you can enjoy the view of Hong kong's road and amenities.

Must Try This at least once !!. This is a great way to travel through the main Artery of Hong Kong. Why be underground in the MTR train when you can see the hustle and bustle above ground on these wonderful Trams.
Great fun. I caught the bus from Central to Kennedy and then the tram back from Kennedy to Causeway Bay. Great way to see Hong Kong and great for people watching.

Great. We took the tram when it was market day a huge market we went to see which I think was for the chinese new year the tram was so cheap and a great way to get around Hong Kong very busy and mostly full whenever you catch one but great.
Great way to get around.. If you can cope with the crush at times, you'll love these trams. Such a contrast to the modern city. Only costs around 20p a trip.

Excellent way to see the city. We took the tram from our hotel distribution to through to the centre of Hong Kong and it was such a brilliant way to see the city and its very user friendly. You get on at the back and pay at the front as you get off. It's a fixed fee and no change is given.

Cheap way of seeing city. We used the ding dings regularly in hong kong it works out to be 23p English or 2.3 hkd. Very fun to ride if you go upstairs u get more of a view of the city. For 23p u can go as far as u want on the line.

Best way to see Hong Kong Island. Take from the West end of the island (Kennedy town) to as Far East as the tram takes you, North Point. You will not get lost because you can take the tram back. Sit on the top deck and you will see so all the districts of HK, i.e. Central, Wanchai, Causeway Bay. Get off anywhere you like or stay on to the end of the line. So much more interesting than San Francisco's cable car. It's the best bargain in HK!

Great Way to discover Hong kong. This is an easy and cheap way to get an overview of Hong Kong Island. You can travel by tram from Shau Kei Wan to Kennedy Town. It's a long and slow journey, so I don't recommend doing all of it, but you will get a bird's eye view of the different cultures of Hong Kong. You can look down on local markets, cruise through the designer shops in Central, smell the dried seafood shops in Sai Ying Pun, check out the washing on balconies, and peer down alleyways you thought were too narrow for traffic. You get on at the back of the tram. Be sure to go upstairs to get the best view. You pay when you get off at the front. Each tram ride costs HK$2.30, which is deposited in a box next to the driver, no change is given. It is easier to pay with an octopus card.

A must on your bucket list . Iconic, cheap and easy. The best transport to see the real hong kong slowly pass by. Take your time and get on the so often over crowded trams. But hey, that's the experience!

A simple and inexpensive pleasure. The ding ding cars are the cheapest form of mass transit. They take you by many of the iconic buildings. Unless you give up your seat to an amah, the second level offers you fine views of Hong Kong Island's neighborhoods and iconic buildings. (Please note that they move relatively slow in comparison to the MTR.) Make sure that your tram is going to where you want to go. If you get on the wrong one, not to worry, because they come by every minute or so.

Neat and convenient way to get around HK. Fare coats 2.3 dollars for adults and 1.1 for seniors. Easy to find stations. Only going east or west. Go hop on and take upper floor. You can roll down windows and get some great shots. You cant find many of these running anymore. I loved it.

Brilliant. Cheap and fantastic experience. We used the trams all the time when we were in Hong Kong. They run all the time so you rarely have to wait more than a few minutes, and they're really cool little things. Obviously pretty old, made from wood, and hilariously tiny inside. They can be a bit of a challenge to get into as they get crowded, but aim for a longer trip and get upstairs, seats become available quite quickly. Apart from the novelty they're actually really useful, you just pay a flat rate (with an Octopus card) when you get off (tip you get on at the back, off at the front), and they'll take you the length of the Hong Kong shoreline.
A Must. Take a trip back in time, kind of!! A slow but enjoyable way to get around HK island if you have the time. See the HK world go by.

What a fun way to travel. This is a must do when in HK. It is a cheap, fun and a fast way to travel. A word of warning....the seats are very small, so it can be a tight squeeze! Get a seat on the second floor at the front for the best views and use your octopus card. It's a great way to view the city.
Never fails to delight. Love love love the Tram! Even on a rainy day and packed with passengers with dripping umbrellas, a ride on the tram still brings a smile!

Relaxing. Taking the tramway in Hong Kong was a very relaxing experience as it is quiet and airy. The ride was very good to be able to see the city from a bit higher up. The trams were a bit packed so be prepared for not being able to sit down. Overall, a very nice way to move around the city.

Don’t miss this ride. This is one of the most environmentally friendly ways of travelling in Hong Kong.A tram system has served commuters in Hong Kong for over 100 years and this is one of the fun sight-seeing ways to travel and it is cheap. When you are in HK make sure you try the “Ding Ding”. Go to the upper deck to enjoy the city view. Happy Travelling!

Good slow way to see the city. Good way to see the city from east to west. Use octopus card to pay when exiting. You can use cash but have correct change as the driver won't handle money. Fare is $2.30 so just drop two two dollar coins in the payment box as you exit. Big tipper!The tracks are in the middle of Central, easy to find, just walk towards the harbour and you'll find the track. Follow the overhead cable until you find a station, they are quite close together in Central.My tip is to take the Kennedy Town route first. That goes slowly through some amazing suburbs and ends near the wharf, Kennedy Town.Coming back, take either Happy Valley or North Point and you'll go through a completely different set of suburban activity. Wan Chai is a teaming, high rise jungle with plenty of street side shops as well as huge malls. Get on and off the tram regularly ... it's only $2.30, remember.The low down; seats are hard, the ride is rough and if it rains the roof will leak in places. It is slow ... and that's the beauty of it. Take the upper deck and you'll have fantastic views throughout.Unless you have GPS you will not know what station you have stopped at. No announcements and no signs. Ask someone. The locals are very friendly and eager to assist, even if they don't speak English Go on, give it a go, I'm sure you'll enjoy the trip
Fun. Definitely a good way of going through the inner city, it is less expensive than the MTR and offers a good view into the city. A very good alternative to the commercial bus tours.

Unique - sit at the top for the best views. Unmissable - cheap, unique and great views from the top. Go to the tram stop get on the one you want and pay when you get off by throwing your money into the machine (if you are paying for a single journey - 23HK approx.)
Great way to orientate to that that part of the island and people watch.

A fun way to see the sights!. If you avoid peak periods, these old fashioned, original little trams are a fun and cheap way to see the sights of the north shore of Hong Kong Island. Get on at the back and pay with cash or, better still, an Octopus Travel Card, and try to get a seat on the upper deck. A bit bumpy at times, this is an ideal way of watching the throngs of shoppers, business people and shops and markets. A must for any visiter to HK.

great transportation to move within the island, for short distance. perfect to do some small distance like central to admiralty or up to the next MTR station. the cost of it is fix, 2, 45 dollars, for either one stop, or up to causeway. the frequency is quiet high, you feel like a local. entrance is from the back, exit from the front. get the right amount. as no change.
Great Way to see part of Hong Kong.. Climb on board and find a seat on the upper level. Great view of Hong Kong as it winds through the city.
Must have a go. You really must get on a tram and experience what the real people of HK do rather than the tourist. Make sure you have the right change and if you are Western size, expect a squash.

Always a pleasure to travel on the tram. As my office is close to a tram stop I take every opportunity to take the tram, inexpensive, fun and the fastest way to Central from WanChai when traffic is busy.This is not luxury travel, but it gets you from A to B with a hint of how life was in years gone by!
A Different Treat. a convenient and view-filled way to travel in Central Hong Kong. Cheap as well! I recommend this to first time travelers.

Cheap and fun : Tour the city of Hongkong . Take the tram is the cheapest way to take tour the city of Hongkong. Weekend until 11pm and weekday only till 5pm. It only 2,3 hkd and children 1,5 hkd. You can sightseeing from the tram.

History buffs. For people who like history, this is a good way to sample how old Hong Kong was.Before the subway this was the to way to go around Hong Kong. My first ride was from Kennedy Town to Central. Great way to slow down and just take in in the sights. Make sure to get the seats on the second level and preferably the one in front.The travel is very slow but very cheap. The line travels from West to East with Kennedy town the last station in the West. Cannot remember the name of the last stop though in the East.Make sure to have 2.30 HKG and to put your money near the device near the driver before you go down. There is no change though.
Cheap and Efficient. We are used to trams living in Melbourne but these were still a novelty being double decker, quick, cheap and efficient, great way to get around Hong Kong Island.

A little Sunday fun!. Awesome and ridiculously cheap way to travel around Hong Kong - Takes you all the way around the harbour and central - if you only have a short time here in HK I definitely recommend jumping on board. Ps. You pay when you get off, not on :)
Happy tramming :)

Best way to see Hong Kong. The Hong Kong trams offer an inexpensive way to see Hong Kong day or night. The trams take passengers throughout the busy streets, shopping districts, and great restaurants.

Old world charm. The tram provides a cost effective commute around HK Island. Despite its age, the system is running smoothly with upgraded facility that announces the name of every stop. Although the trams are narrow and squeezy, they run on reasonable frequencies and so the waiting is not too long.

You can walk faster than this tram. These trams look quaint and fun, but in fact are slow and not very comfortable. I would always recommend taking the normal city busses (Google map provides reliable routing info) and get the Oyster card for convenience.

Great way to spy put a resteraunt. Used them to ride up and down kings road to spy out suitable resteraunts. Dirt cheap to ride and slow enough to take in surroundings. Noisy and uncomfortable though so wouldn't recommend for any real distance.
Wonderful... Great nostalgic ride on a 'London Tram' through the streets of bustling HK! wonderful experience, well worth the effort if you have some spare time during a trip to HK
Cute but boring. We made a trip on the tramway on a rainy day, but found it really boring. Good to use if you have a destination to go, but not advised just for sightseeing.

Great way to delve into the city!. This is in my opinion the best way to explore the city! Just hop into one of the countless Ding Ding and try go get a good seat on the upper deck! So relaxing and perfect to take photos while the tramways are making their way through the city jungle. Make sure you have some extra coins to pay,because there is no change:)

Must do in Hong Kong. One of the must do experiences in Hong Kong. An inexpensive way to see and experience the Hong Kong of old. You hop on at the back door and leave and pay via the front door. Try to get a seat upstairs.

Fun way to see Hong Kong. I highly recommend taking a Tramway ride. It is inexpensive way to see the neighborhoods of north Hong Kong Island. Hop on somewhere around the Admiralty MTR station and get off near Victoria Park. Then take another Tramway back. Oh, and you must ride on the second deck. Just sit back and enjoy the view. Get off if you see something interesting.
Brilliant!. What a fantastic way to see Hong Kong island! Literally cost next to nothing and you can stay on as long as you like! Brilliant view of the island!

It brings you back to the days when things were more simpler. I sat in one last year.Everything just suddenly felt right and it was like a time machine that brought me back into the 80's Its a really enjoyable ride to see hk and very well maintained.It still runs smooth and the seats are very retro. I just cant wait to use these trams again on my next visit to hk !10/10

Amazing Bus Tramways!. We witnessed many of these antiquated huge double decker buses in downtown Hong Kong. I was personally quite fascinated with ther size and dynamics as the quickly rolled around the city streets ferrying people to their destinations. some buses also sport some very dramatic painted signages and other cartoon images that make them a real interesting sight to experience here.
An experience . Very good service. Clean and regular with easy way to see the city aboveground. Destination boards on the front means only the illiterate can get lost!

Very authentic. This trams are nice to see in the streetview. A little bit as the dubbeldecker busses in Londen. It gives you a nostalgic feeling. If you want to travel with it, be sure you have enough time. It is not the fastest way. Not good for wheelchairs.

Great Way To See The Real HK . For just a few Hk$ (!!!) you can ride along the north side of Hong Kong island through the CBD, shopping area, past street markets all sorts of life and really see Hong Kong from a comfortable position ideal for taking photos.Do it! Sit upstairs. Take a coffee. Ride from end back to end. You will love it!

Hong Kong ding dings. If your staying on Hong Kong Island you have to try a tram at least once, its a great way to see whats at street level between the MTR stations, its a lot slower, but you see a lot more and its very very cheap.
HK Tramways. One of the last few Tramways left in the world. Great way to visit HK island at very slow pace. It is very inexpensive.

Central city views with a relaxing ride. very cheap ride to see the Hong Kong centre city. We took the upper deck and had a great time. If you are a senior and have MTR Octopus card the ride is only H$1.1.

Slow but fun. It takes you back in time ... and it takes it, too. Nevertheless, it's on street level and if you're only travelling two or three MTR stops, you might just as well take the Ding Ding. Unbeatably cheap and good for a little sightseeing on the top floor.

Small but fun. Another transportation mode from a by gone era. The tramway is just one of those interesting things that you won't see anywhere else. So are packed to the rafters and others can be near empty. So unless you are going to a specific destination let the full one go past and get the next one. They come every few minutes.

Old fashion. These buses are great, wooden and a blast from the past. Cheap to use, easy to use, but can be slow.I think it is a must to do. As it is something from years ago, sit on top floor for great view. Makes a cheap tourists bus

Fun, Inexpensive, and easy to use . For 2.30 HKD, it's the best deal in town. Hop on the only double decker team in the world to explore HK Island in a safe and very convenient ride. Pay as you exit. Remember to bring exact change if you can.
Economical ride . Best way to enjoy the rustic view of hong kong. Tram rides are readily available in certain zone. Be sure to board from the back of the tram and exit from the tram.

Great. What a great way to explore HK island for just a couple of bucks. Especially in the evening.
Just sit and enjoy the ride.
It's a must!. Beautiful ride, get an upper deck seat and take your time to enjoy HK! It's a real bargain, $2,3 HKD for a city tour, it's a a must.

Fab value and must do. Fantastic and cheap way to travel. Yes it's small and not amazingly comfy but for 28p for as many stops as you like who can complain? If you can sit at the top of the bus at the very front you can get a great view of the city. The stops aren't very far apart so if you do what we accidentally did and jump on the tram going in the wrong direction just get off at the next stop and back on again.It's not the fastest way to travel so don't do it if you're in a hurry but if you have nothing else planned it's good fun. Jump on the back through the turnstiles and pay as you get off the front with your octopus card or exact change.

Squeeze, clatter, ding, clatter, ding. With everything new in Hong Kong it's surprising that these old trans survive, but they do and it's cheap and well worth taking a ride to see the street scene whilst everybody else on the tram simply uses it to get around.

Such a fun mode of transport so long as you're not big on personal space . Terrific way to get around HK - above ground so you can see the sights. Cheap and cheerful - you pay on exit. Prepare to fight you way on and stand as seats are few and far between. Great fun
A HK "must do". Great fun and a cheap way of seeing the north part of HK island. Even simpler if you have an Octopus card. The tram itself is a brilliant bit of retro. Better than the MTR!

Slow but fun. We took the ding ding tram from Murray Road to Foo Ming (Causeway bay area). The tram was slow but we enjoyed it, especially children. We got seat at the top, and we had best view from there. We got inside from the back door, and paid in the front before we went down. The fares are 2.30 hkd for adult, 1.20 hkd for children, and 1.10 hkd for seniors.

One of the best things in HK. I love those trams! Okay those are very slow and it is much faster to take train but the atmosphere inside the tram is so nice. You can just relax enjoying the ride and the scene. Totally "have to do list" thing!

Fun trip from quarry bay. Rather crowded on the weekend - head up to the top deck - front seats to see the world pass by. If you're not in a hurry - this is the best way to see crazy Hong Kong in action

Slow the pace. The tram is a great way to travel if you want to view the hustle and bustle from the street. You get a better perspective than you do by riding the MTR underground. But make sure you have plenty of time to travel by tram. Very cheap way to travel.
Love the trams. when in Hong Kong we always use the trams, its over ground, its nostalgic its just a great way to get around.

Fantastic cheap way to travel or see the island. The tram fare is HK $2.30. You can put in more but it will not give you back the change. It's slow but a fantastic way to travel - especially on the above deck. The trams run from one end of the island to the other and I plan to take them end to end the next time I am here. I can't believe that after so many trips here this was the first trip I ever made on it. Fantastic. Anyone 6' or taller cannot stand on the upper floor.

Wonderful way for a first hand view of life in Hong Kong. Th tram known affectionately locally as the 'dingding' because of the sound it makes to alert stops etc is a wonderful way to travel and explore Hong Kong.One can take it from one end of Hong Kong island to the other, east/Chai Wan to west/Kennedy Town or vice versa seeing the hustle and bustle of life in this metropolitan.Another route stops at Happy Valley which is the home of the Jockey Racecourse which is another HK tradition.

I love this traditional "ding ding"!. It is always a pleasant time hoping on one of these. Convenient and fun. I enjoy the breeze too. Try not to take it during rush hour, the traffic could be quite bad and a crowded tram is not so fun either. *take your time and relax*
Average. You feel you can walk faster. Bone crunching ride not comfortable. Look great but not really. Would prefer they keep a rickshaw
Must get on one. We took our children on the trams and they loved it, it costs next to nothing and excellent to have such amazing classic transport in this Morden days.

Joy ride. It was fun to see them on streets of HK and never wanted to miss the opportunity to have a ride. It very affordable and convenient and one of the very few places you can ride in one of those. Make sure you dont miss it.....

Nice trams but not much to see en route. Nice "Blackpool-style" vintage trams but as they travel along through the built up centre of Hong Kong island, there isn't much to see other than lots of the same shops and the ground floors of high-rise buildings. No real views or interesting landmarks, at least in the few miles we travelled. Beware also the racecourse loop when travelling west. The trams go on a southerly diversion and not all go straight through; some stop half way round and you have to change - and pay again - to complete your journey. Also, the tram route is a bit of a yomp if you come like we did from Kowloon. From the central ferry terminal is quite a hike on long overhead walkways to reach the tram road and the places to descend to ground floor level are not well marked and often you have to go into a shopping mall to get down.

Fun way to travel. We caught the tram from central to Happy Valley races. It took quite a while but was so much fun and gives you a good look at this side of the island and all the locals coming and going. Was a lot of fun!

You haven't really experienced the whole of HK if you havent ridden these!. These icons of Hong Kong have been around for a very long time now. It is a popular mass transit system that can take you to most places in Hong Kong, They are slow, they have two floors, and stop at every station. I would not recommend this if you are in a hurry.
A great way to explore Hong Kong Island. This tramways is a must try transportation in Hong Kong. There are two main reasons, first, they are cheap! and second, it's a unique experience

Tram by choice. Getting around on the tram is pleasurable. At peak times they are full and you may need to stand - if you are tall you will stand with your head bowed - the ceiling downstairs and roof upstairs are quite low. The trams do rock-and-roll so if you suffer from motion sickness give it a go from one stop to the next!

One of the more fun experiences in the city!. Not the fastest, and not the most comfortable, but definitely one of the most fun - especially if you get the front seat on the upper deck! Watch people pass in front of you and the city scenery as you make from point A to B to C. TIP: Make sure you have coins with you to pay for the trip!

Iconic!. Travelling on this trams, that have been the same for over 100 years is a wonderful experience. We managed to get a seat upstairs at the front, which was a great vantage point to see the city.You pay as you leave, which is a bit confusing. They accept the magic Octopus Card too.

Tramways of Old Hong Kong. The Hong Kong Tramway System is the earliest public transport system which the British introduced to this British Colony. The trams from the colonial days are still relevant in the 21st century and remain in service today.
A very cheap and nice way to see Hong Kong. The rides cost only HKD 2.50 each trip and offer great views from the upper deck. Goes all the way between the East and West of HK island.
Great- but note you pay before disembarking and not before. Nice experience, and great curiosity. Note as per title you scan your octopus as you get off and not when you board, so can be confusing.

Even if they understand your query the drivers would never answer. The Hong Kong side popular mode of transport that takes you right at the footsteps of your destination. In peak hours this multi level tram will require you to stand in most skimpy place as foreigners or westerners double or triple the bulk size of Hong Kong residents. This is a very cheap way of transport versus the Mtr but the crowd is not really for Expats or tourist. Beware of pickpockets and occasional elbow from locals. The train and the road is not exactly the cleanest or the sanitize mode of travel but if in Hong Kongs Central or Wanchai or Causeway the tram will beat walking in the streets.
Take a trip back in time. When you are on Hong Kong Island make sure you jump on a ding ding to move between the areas. It is old and rickety but has a wonderful nostalgic feel. A must do.

A true Hong Kong experience. The tram or Ding Ding as locally called is a great experience for short distance on Hong Kong Island. The fare is affordable (less than 3 HKD); have the exact fare as no change will be given or use the Octopus card which is the HK transport card that you refill as you need. Avoid the pick hours when locals and the working crowd use it a lot. If you are a 1st time user go upstairs and enjoy the street sights. The tram is not air conditioned but the windows are always opened to have some air flow. This is a great way to experience HK local life.

QUaint and reliable. Travelling around in the CBD on Hong Kong island is easy using this quaint method of transport. Servicing most of the CBD this is a reliable service allowing people to board and alight without the hassle or congestion of the underground system

Moving antique. Since early 1900, tram has been the landmark on Hong Kong Island. They are slow but very affordable. Get upstairs, grab a window seat and watch the scenery along the route. Tram ride on a lazy afternoon is my favorite activity in Hong Kong.

Up the stairs; sit & relax except in the hotter months.. Best way to see the street sights along the busy arterial non- freeway routes around HK. Cheap as chips to travel but can be frustratingly slow & crowded at times. Humour & patience to be exercised like with just about all pursuits in HK.

Experience HK Ding Ding. We are a group of 6 adults and 1 kid travel to HK... A short trip to experience for HK Ding Ding Tram... We are enjoy the sit on Ding Ding although so many peoples on the tram...

Do it!. At the beginning it seems confusing how to get a ticket but what you need to do is to get the right amount and when you get off (front door) you insert it to the box next to the driver. Trams were my 4y old son's favourite way of commuting in Hong Kong. They are very cheap and enjoyable.

Best sightseeing activity in Hong Kong. If you are on a trip and not sure what to do with your sight seeing itinerary, best ride the tram. The rate is fixed (i forgot the exact price but it was between HK$2-4) regardless of your destination. Ride the top deck and just enjoy the sights of the entire busy city.

Nice alternative method of transport . We decided to take the tram back to see a bit more of Hong Kong on our way back to the hotel. Glad we did.
Great value for money, you need to pay with coins though which we wasn't aware of. You pay in your way off the tram.

Great experience.. Study the map, ask questions at the desks, staff very helpful. Enjoyed going on the local trails. Saw lots of ordinary events, e.g. workers out for lunch, people taking a well-deserved break. Busy, busy!!!
Iconic feature of Hong Kong. Provided you can get a seat upstairs, you get some good views. A cheap and cheerful way to get around. Leave plenty time - they are slow!

Turning back the clock. If you are a tourist this is a fun way to travel around Hong Kong on the island part of the city.Cheap to use, just make sure you have an Octupus card and jump on and travel through some amazing street scenes as you pass through both the wealthy and poorer districts of this wonderful city.This is how people travelled around cities before the days of the underground which is boring in comparison.

Must use to preserve it!. There was a plan to remove the tram service, so we decided to use it while we were there. We did and it didn't disappoint, in fact more than that. We found it very handy to transport us from Sai Ying Pun all the way to Causeway Bay. Nice service, feels like going back to go old days. Must take tram if you go to Hong Kong.

Ride across town for the experience!. It takes forever to get across the city on one of these trams, but the feeling is great, especially if you get a seat by an open window or on the open deck model. Go for Dimsum at the Western market and ride this all the way to Happy Valley, you will enjoy all of the people watching and activity of life in Hong Kong all for a pittance. And you will arrive at the Happy Valley Bar and Grill for one of HK's best burgers and a London's Pride right around happy hour!
Ding dong. Fantastic and super cheap experience. You are transported back in time in this tram... no air con, so in the summer be warned! ;)

Ding ding down the history. Most enjoyable ride in Hong Kong island if you are not in a hurry. It's cheap too HK$2.10 for adults. You can also use the Octopus card to pay for the fare. The tram run from the west end of the island Kennedy Town to the east end Chai Wan along the northern side of the island where it passes through the financial district Central , bar and restaurant area of Wan Chai, shopping district Causeway Bay to North Point, Quarry Bay, etc. If you take the team, try go to the upper floor. There is also an open top tourist tram that one can board in Sheung Wan.

You haven't been to Hong Kong if you hadn't ridden a ding ding.... Short inexpensive ride with history! Do it...even if you have no plans to go anywhere! Not the best comfort in the world...go to the upper deck!
Easy & cheap travel. I love the Hong Kong ding dings, they are so cheap 2hkd & 30cent per ride (about 20pence gbp). Quick and convenient.

Must ride while in Hong Kong! $2.30HK - no change. You have to ride these and they provide a cheap tour up and down Hong Kong for those looking to rest their legs and ride above ground. The fair is a paltry $2.30HK but they don't make change so you will likely end up paying a little more if you don't have the exact fare or an Octopus card.

Ding ding. Feb.2016 . If you are in Hongkong , dont miss the Tramways . It is a great experience , it is funny and a cheap Transportation . Go by MTR to Hongkong Island and take a ride with these good old Trams .

Hong Kong Trams. This is a very nostalgic way to travel on Hong Kong Island. The trams move very slowly with many stops! There has been talk over the years of eliminating the trams, this would be very sad. I encourage you to take a tram while we still have them! Very inexpensive mode of travel, if you have the time to take them!
A must in Hong Kong. Definitely a must in Hong Kong, you really should take a ride it's very easy, just go in and pay when you leave the Tram.
Cheap but slow. Fabulous fleet of old trams but we got stuck in traffic heading for Victoria Park around 3pm. ONLY $2.30 so try at a quieter time of day. Great for old nostalgic like me.
Cheapest transportation at hk. Only for $2.3 Hong Kong dollars for a trip.u can take this to travel the whole HK island side and the frequently schedule

Quirky way to get around Hong Kong. Do try one of these trams while you are in Hong Kong . You will see the tram stops throughout the city . They are frequent and extremely cheap (2 $HK a trip. You drop your coins in a box at the front of the tram as you exit) They offer an interesting view of Hong Kong as you go along and are used predominantley by local residents so a trip gives you a snapshot of local lifesyles in Hong Kong too. Do go upstairs when you travel as these trams are quite tall and the view is better.

Ding Ding yourself through HK Island. They are iconic, they are traditional and big fun! The operate in HK Island only connecting the West of HK Island with the East. It is not just very popular with tourists but also many locals use it on a daily basis. The price is very cheap: currently it's just 2.3 HK Dollars, no matter how long you ride the tram. Catch a tram, sit down and enjoy your views, it's better than watching tv.
Try it. Original and cheap transport. Pay with the Octopus card from the MTR. I guess it is around 2.5 HKD per trip. Use it for shopping at Hong Kong Island.

Great way to go around the island. Tired of walking around the various sites? Hop into a tram, get on to the top and find a seat up front for a good view - there are multiple routes (with many common stops, so beware which tram you get into). Tickets are super cheap at HK$2, so well worth if you want to save some walking time as well

A Step back in Time. On our first venture out of our hotel we saw the almost antique looking trams going down the main road. We decided we had to try them, but needed to do a little home-work first to discover how you use them.We found out that you can use the same card that you use on the MTR. You board the tram by the rear exit, and disembark from the front exit, and present your card to the reader as you get off, whereupon the appropriate fee is deducted from the balance on your card.Our hotel was near Tin Hau MTR station, and on several evenings we went into Causeway Bay to find a restaurant for dinner. On the Ding Ding it was three stops, and we found that it was a much easier and quicker method of getting there than the MTR. It also gives you the opportunity to see more of Hong Kong.

An authentic way to view some of Hong Kong Island.. Sit upstairs on the right hand side and experience the closeness of meeting oncoming trams 6 inches away! Fast, uncomfortable but a must in Hong Kong!

Hong Kong Light Rail (Ding Ding). I have so often seen the Hong Kong Tram in books that my interest to ride this piece of history was strong indeed. The Trams run very frequently, and it's a good idea to have a good map or idea of what stop you need to alight from. Enter from the rear only squeeze your way in-literally and try to make your way toward the front to exit as your stop gets closer. Very high patronage, very cozy with fellow passengers, but worth the experience. Cost is $2:30 HK and payment is exact payment with coin or octopus card debit.Happy to have jumped onboard. Worth trying when you visit Hong Kong

The cheapest and fastest way to get around central Hong Kong. I loved taking the old Ding Dings through out the central parts of Hong Kong. It was fast, cheap and easy... plus I could enjoy the sites of the city as the tram made it through the city.

A great way to see Hong Kong on the cheap. If you are visiting Hong Kong for the first time and want a cheap way to see what it's about, a trip along the northern side of Hong Kong Island is a great tourist treat. The trams are not mean for tourists - they are normal economy transport for HK residents - but they give a good glimpse of life in the bustling urban area from a safe distance. Trams run from Kennedy Town in the west to Shaukeiwan in the east, and the full journey takes about an hour and a half, but not all trams go all the way - the destination is on the front. Tip - avoid rush hours, as the trams can be extremely full. If you time your journey for mid-morning or early afternoon, you have a good chance of getting empty front seas upstairs. If the tram is full, simply wait for the next one - they are very frequent. The fare is a mere $2.30 (about US30c) which you put in a slot on exit, or use the very useful octopus card, which is well worth purchasing, as it is very convenient for other forms of transport and even buying goods in supermarkets or convenience stores. Shaukeiwan at the end of the line has an interesting market and is good for seeing the non-tourist side of Hong Kong.
Tricky. This is a great little ride if you are game. Need correct coins and also need to have a final destination in mind as to where to get off as conductors have no English but great fun

Sweet little Trams. What a great service these sweet little trams provide, super easy on and off, very very frequent and travel all the major flat routes, entry via the back door and exit the front, tap your octopus on exit to pay the flat rate fare.

Back to my childhood. Clattering down the middle of one of the maddest roads you will ever see these historical objects are always full. Why? Because the fare is only Hk$2.30 per trip. Take the top deck font for an 'Alton Towers' experience.

what a great mode of transport. just brilliant. Always packed (well normally at least) but still - it's one of the Hongkong Key Features. A must-do. Loving it every time. Worthwhile leaving the MTR a stop early and taking the last view stops on the Tram. Great fun no matter if alone or with kids.

Like in a Hop On Hop Off Bus. You may use Ding Dong almost as a Hop On Hop Off Bus - just seat upstairs and watch a city - we traveled few times in different directions and it was great way to look around. And it is very cheap - you buy tickets in the tram.

Lovely.. I very much like the way those tramways look, they are very cute, and it's convenient to use them as a means of transportation, when you need to get somewhere specific. However, I am not sure it's the best way to do the sightseeing. I took the tram that goes all the way from West to East, from Kennedy Town to Shau Kei Wan, the whole trip takes about an hour, but after the first 15 minutes it gets a bit boring to just sit and look. Honestly, I thought walking would be more fun, because the tram just goes in a straight line through streets with residential buildings. It's fun, but 15 minutes inside is quite enough :) The price is 2.3hkd (for adults)

Brilliant to get from a to b and meanwhile see something of the city. Great to get from a to b in the city. It's not very fast but compared to the subway you actually get to see some of the city whilst going from a to b. Fare is a flat fee and like all forms of public transport in Hong Kong it's incredibly cheap, under $3 flat fare.
Ding Ting 10/10. I love sitting on the 2nd floor of a tramway. Comfortable and a great way to conquer the fear of heights.

Affordable and must try. HK tramway is one of the oldest transportation system in Hongkong. It is very nice experience since you can roam around hongkong just for HK2.30 or around Php14.00 You can enjoy sceneries. Of course, it is best to stay on top to have a better view around. It is fun to ride specially at night. You will not get lost since if you want to go back to your departing place, you can just simply drop at a station and wait for the other tram to the opposite direction.

Mesmerising Experience. The moment you step into this Tram you are taken back to the past , still the combination of travelling in a past mode of transportation along side the state of the art Buildings and Brands has its own experience , a must go place while in Hong Kong , Highly recommended place.

A great and inexpensive way to see Hong Kong. The HK Ding Ding is a great alternative to taking the MTR. It is obviously by far not as fast and effective as the MTR, but it is a nice way to get to see Hong Kong. And the price is extremely cheap. 2.3 HKD, or around 0.3 USD. So skip MTR, and take the Ding Ding for a peaceful trip trough the streets of HK.
Good for seeing the HK island. This tram takes you across the HK island, doesn't cost much although from one end to the other. Although hot weather is not recommended, as this is not air-conditioned.

Love it. The Hong Kong Tramways are really fantastic. A cheap and historical way to travel. Amazing how they still exist and are frequently used by the locals. Just have a ride on them and don't care where they go. You will always be able to get back where you started from and the experience is just great

Thanks for the memory.. I was born in Hong Kong many moons ago. I left HK in 1963 and I have no family in HK now. Every 2 or 3 years, I would make a special trip visiting HK and I ALWAYS went on a tram ride from one end of the island to the other end. All in all, the journey would take between 2 to 3 hours depending what time of the day one travels.The tram travelled through different parts of HK, the Central, business centre, The Causeway Bay, the entertainment and food centre. The west end of the island, one could see the stalls for dried sea products and sometime, one could smell it too. The other end of HK was mainly residential flats or apartments. Of course, there are shops every where. Every time I took a tram ride, there was always something different. It reminded me of my happy childhood growing up in the British colony.One cannot visit HK without sampling its different cuisines. I dare say that HK can offer international dishes if one knows where to look. Due to land/space at the premium, a lot of restaurants were located upstairs and they are always full!As many contributors have already said, get on the tram from the rear and go upstairs. Grab a window seat on one side. What one misses the other side, one can see it on the return journey! Just enjoy the scenery.

Something different. Getting on the tram is a very interesting experience. It is very cheap and you get to see the streets in Causeway Bay. It can get jammed packed during rush hour but if you can avoid it do so. It is one of Hong Kong's traditional way of getting around and a must do if you are visiting.

TRAMendous . A great and cheap way to see the hustle and bustle of downtown Hong Kong island!! Just jump on head up to the top deck towards the front and soak up the atmosphere!!! It's only $2.30 per journey so if your in no hurry to get anywhere it's a cheap alternative to using the metro!!!

Sightseeing. This is a great way to visit Hongkong the fastest way.We explore Hongkong from the city to the New Territory, we are able to see Wan Chai and other old town in Hongkong. I love the experience.

amazing way to get around the city if you have time. Hong kong's tramline is charming- older than many 99% of the buildings it passes it is real relic of old hong kong. get a coffee and hop on the tram (mid morning is best so it's not too crowded) and enjoy the view. not ideal if you are pressed for time or during rush hour....
Cheap and fun way to travel in HK Island. Hop on the trams and experience looking at Hong Kong day to day life! The fare is very cheap. Get on to the front of the tram to enjoy a good view.

Once in a lifetime opportunity to experience this city. We were absolutely amazed at how clean these trains are kept, given the fact that some of them are over hundred years old. As we travelled the island from West to East, we truly experienced Hong Kong through observing how they lead their lives. It's an amazing experience if you got an afternoon and just spend the afternoon sitting in the tram. Truly marvellous!
Cheap and fun way to see Hong Kong Island. Get the top seat at the front of the tram and right during the day or see a different view at night. Less than $2 Hong Kong Dollars.
A must for visitors. Cheap way of getting from one end of the island to the other. Board at back but beware- you leave at the front which can be difficult when the tram is packed!!

Cheap day Out. This isn't in the tour guides but I would recommend to anyone visiting Hong Kong Island and wants to get a realistic 'feel' of the placethen to take the Tram - especially through the Causeway Bay - Wanchai - Central - Sheung Wan districts - and just sit upstairs and watch the world go by out of the window. It costs HK$2.3 (30 cents US) and you pay upon exiting (correct cash necessary if not using pre-paid "Octopus" card). Fixed line goes both ways so when you have gone far enough you can always get off, cross the tracks and get on again to go back to where you started.

Great experience. Easy to use. Great experience. We use it to go a bit far. So we sit upstairs. Great view to the sit and neighborhoods. We have the octopus card so it was easy to pay (you pay when you leave).
Fun!. Oh these are fun! I'm not so sure they beat taxis (or walking) for getting around, but the trams are a lovely historical part of HKG. Glad to see they are still here. Worth experiencing them.

Old fashioned Hong Kong remains. One of the few remaining icons of old Hong Kong is the "Ding, Ding" or tram ride. Travelling up the length of Hong Kong island only for for a few Hong Kong dollars, this is a great ride through Central and the surrounding districts. Don't miss it if you visit Hong Kong. And try to get a seat on the top deck, front row for great camera shots.

A must try. These are not the most convenient and comfortable ways of travelling but certainly one you must try.The on off is a one way, enter the back and leave at the front to pay on exit.. Circa Hk $2? Murder with large bags if you are stuck near the back. They are narrow and have no AC.But they look great

One of three unique modes of transport you should try on a visit to Hong Kong. I do this with friends and family when they visit Hong Kong. You can do it in about 3 hours, if you are already on the island or in Kowloon... This starts on the island and finishes on Kowloon side but can reverse the order and do it just as easily... Start anywhere along the cross island tram route - take the tram toward Central - it's a fun ride - you pay $2.30 when you get OFF. You'll be on Des Veux Road - hop off around Jubilee Street / Central Market. Walk through Central Market toward Queens Road - you'll come to the foot of the Mid Level Escalators. Ride it up the mountain! When you come down - on foot - you'll be headed toward the harbor. It's about a kilometer from the base of the escalator to the Star Ferry Terminal. At the terminus of the escalators turn right on Queens Road and go down a few blocks to Pedder - take a left, join the network of sky bridges, go toward the harbor and the Star Ferry Terminal. Ride the Star Ferry to Kowloon - you can then either grab a taxi or walk the few blocks to the East Tsim Sha Tsui MTR station and head back to where you started. Three great rides in a short time!

Love the old fashioned Hong Kong Tram. Great fun riding along on the trams cheap and cheerful and very authentic Rode along past the Western Market where all the Chinese shops/ supermarkets are and very authentic area then back down to Central and walked back to the Star Ferry to go back over to KowloonTram costs about 30p and it's great fun just riding up and down
Cheap and cheerful . Nice to take a ride even for a few stops. Remove you of uk double decker buses. Get to see a lot of the city on it. Fun ride. Even if just to say you went on it .

Fun and Cheap. The trams run east and west on Hong Kong Island. They are double decker trams. The seat are small. They run very frequently sometimes less than 5 minutes apart. The fare is 2.3 HK$ for adults and Seniors (over 65) 1.1 HG$. You pay on exiting the tram at the front. The driver does not give change. You can get oriented to the city by riding the tram.

A must when you go to HK. It is crowded, it is cheap, it is fun. Just take a ride even a few stops. It wont cost you a lot.
