Best if you can get the front see on the upper deck and you have a nice slow view of your trip. Make sure to get downstairs well in advance before you get off as it can be very crowded.
Useful for hopping on and off to save your soar feet. I have a plan to take the tram from end to end Shau Kei Wan to Kennedy all for 2.3$HK but I've never had the time.

Ding dong the Ding Ding is great!. Must try, fun and inexpensive way to see the width of HK island. Also you can't get lost - one way up one way down it's a breeze. Also really nice to see how differently advertised each one was.
Lovely Experience. I love these trams! Pretty touristy, but worth the while. I took these trams 5 to 6 times in a week and loved it. It is convenient and the sight seeing is unmatched.

British Era life. The small trams which we has seen many years before inn other colonial places, took us by surprise, and at the depot we could not believe the variety of trams that were there at night time. We took a short ride to bring back our childhood and it was worth it.
LOVED THE DING DING. You ride as long as you want for less than $2. It is interesting to try this at least once. You pay as you leave.

You just have to do this!!!!. Using or Oyster Card we travelled around HK, on and off of different trams. Dont ask me where we went but we did end up back where we started withiut too much difficulty and from the top deck had a very cheap but not guided tour of HK. And if you are temptedto take the tour buses then haggle. Friends got 2 days for the price of a one day ticket.

quick easy and fun. did a bit of travel on the trams on hk island. hop on at the back thru the turnstyle, find a seat and hop off thru the front paying - with your octopus card. cheap , convenient and lots of fun.

Cheap and fun way to travel. Used the trams daily from Quarry bay to Admiralty. Regular and cheap 28P for each journey . Not the fastest , but you get to see the real Hong Kong. Remember to use octopus card .
Trams. The old trams on HK island were installed by the British and are running efficiently now as they ever did a great nostalgic way to look around HK island. Cheap as well

Cramped and busy! . Don't get this if you're only going a few stops as it's difficult to get to the front. You get on at the back and pay as you leave which is on the front. However you have to wriggle your way through other people to get off. Saying that it's quick and cheap and a traditional way to travel.

Fun way to get around while looking at the streets of Hong Kong. Always try and get a seat up the top near the front windows. It's a great way to get around and see the streets of Hong Kong. My friend and I did this on our first day there to try and get our bearings. They can get crowded too, especially at the end of the working day. When we were there it was only HK $2.30 per trip, no matter how far you went, so it is always a cheap option for public transport.
super nice train in Hong Kong Island. super nice train in Hong Kong Island. It is a very chip way to see Hong Kong Island and the price is under 3 Hong Kong dollar

A fun, old style way to travel. We used the tram a few times, they are old and quaint and double decker! At only HKD2.30 per ride the trams are cheap to use. Octopus cards are welcome. They are frequent, not heated or air conditioned so expect to be a bit chilly in winter as we were and I'd imagine hot in summer. They're a great way to see the city above ground, allowing you to spot places to visit the next time as you go. The stations are close together so don't require long walks and of course the track limits the tram to go anywhere other than up and down, but through the most popular areas. I noted that this route is serviced by buses and MTR too, but offer some authentic old Hong Kong. They are a lovely way to travel through the city.
Worth a go!. Not just for the historical value, but these trams do work well. It's a comfortable ride all the same.

A cheap and relaxed mode of transport. Cheap and convenient way to travel in Hong Kong Island
Very localised and got a taste of old Hong Kong.

Best mode of travel for short trips along the Island.. The trams are old but efficient and the easiest way to hop on - hop off along Victoria Harbour on Hong Kong Island. From East through Quarry Bay, North Point, Causeway Bay, Wanchai and Admiralty to Central the view from the top deck is of new and old Hong Kong. On a warm day the natural ventilation and shade is ideal for sightseeing. And the cost? Remarkably low ! A Must for all visitors.

Great way to get around Hong Kong Island!. The 'Ding-Ding' tram is a great and fun way of experiencing Hong Kong Island at a nice and leisurely pace. With the ticket only costing $HK 2.30 no matter how far you ride, you can get off any time you like and get back on after exploring any one of the interesting districts on HK Island. It is especially fun for kids when you hear the bell go 'Ding-Ding'.
Old trams add character to HK.. These OLD trams travel right through the main part of Hong Kong Island. A must for new visitors. Get upstairs for the best view.

Must Try. Our three year old daughter was very keen on riding on one of the 'Ding Dings' as they call it and so were we. It is a nice way to see Hong Kong island. Choose a seat on the upper deck, sit back and enjoy the ride. The nice pace of the tram lets you enjoy the city in a very relaxed way. It was a lovely experience!

The fun way to get a ride in Hong Kong. Riding the old trams in Hong Kong is always oh-so-pleasurable. Maybe it is the old Hong Kong feel or the ambiance of a once non-stressfull time in the city's life that attracts me to it. I usually ride at the ground level but it is equally fun to ride atbthe upper level -- as long as it isn't during rush hours. I suggest to go all the way to the Hong Kong Jockey Club to experience the tram fully.

Don't expect a smooth ride, but a great experience.. We love the Hong Kong trams. Over a hundred years old and still going strong. Slower than the busses along the same route and less comfortable, but such fun ! Ding Ding !

Fun way to see sights. I enjoy the trams because I'm a cheapskate and also I love anything old fashioned. These trams are both. They're quaint and interestingly shaped. A fun little way to get around HK island.
a must-way to travel. At $2.30, a no-rush way to travel and the best way to see Hong Kong's street life, slightly away from the actual madness that makes up this wonderful place.

Good view of Hong Kong Streets. Go to the top level of the tram, it has the view of the streets. When we see something we like on the way, we make the stop to see the neighborhood and take the next tram to continue on our way.
Good fun. It's fun cheap and easiest way to explore the islan for lazy days. Try chai wan to Kennedy town route

I enjoyed My Tram Ride in Hong Kong. My frist time at Hong Kong, I was so amazed with the Tram in Hong Kong. Experienced my ride from Shau Kei Wan station to Keneddy Town Station at Hong Kong islands. I'm not sure I pay the right fees or not, but I still remember that I paid HKD2.50 for the ride :)

Quaint and comfortwvel. There is not much to say about these old-timers except that it really quaint and comfortable. Loved them and tried to get one whenever I could. The stops are in the middle of the street and ask anyone where it's going. Sometime sit's just fun getting on and going into the unknown!

These trams are adorable!. The old trams are great, each one has it's own paint job so most are different from one another. Great fun to watch running up and down HK Island. Much, much better to ride on. Don't be scared, jump on the tram, ride as far as you want and put the fare (I think it was about 25 Cents per person) in the collection box next to the driver as you get off! We went down to Causeway Bay and the fab shopping area one day and then up to a great food market near Kennedy Town the next. Ride on the top deck for the best experience!

Best way to see downtown Hong Kong. Take the tramway all its length to see a panoramic view on the city from the inside. Take it both during the day and in the evening and sit on the upper deck. It costs almost nothing, it's better than a tour bus, and you get the feel of the city and its people.

My Favourite Part of Hong Kong. OK, I admit it! I'm a train nerd, I started many Years ago with the Welsh steam railways and everywhere I go try to include a train ride or two.The Ding Ding has something of Victorian England about it, its slow and very old technology but has a wonderful feeling and is a great way to take in the metropolitan part of Hong Kong Island.I see some silly prices for tours here, the cost of any ride for any distance is just over HK$2 (2016 prices), you can just get on and pay when you get off!The locals use the tram as transport so its best to avoid the peak morning, lunchtime and evening rush hours. Outside those times, take a seat at the front upstairs and enjoy the City!

Great for Sightseeing. No trip to HK is complete without rides on the famous Ding Ding Trams. You could literally spend hours watching daily HK life as you roll around through the various neighbourhoods. Easy to find, easy to use & easier still to love! It is one of the most endearing memories of Hong Kong

it's a cheap way of exploring northern side of HK island. there are different routes from east to west (round trip), so pay attention on the station for hopping in or out, great riding experience and feels great to know the history of ding-ding itself.. oh yes, be sure to get to the second level as it offers best experience (pick the head seats or tail seats if you're in a group of minimum 4)..
Night view on upper deck. The tram is comfortable and cheap! Take a seat on the upper deck to enjoy the night view of the city if you have time.Not as fast as MTR but more enjoyable.
Lots of trams on Hong Kong island. Hop on hop off. Make sure to take some change to pay when you leave. Fun for everyone.Just like it used to be.

Cheap tour of HK. If you have time to kill and dont know how to get a glimpse of HK . Hop on the Tram its really cheap and takes a good tour of Hongkong district . Jump to the top deck and if your lucky you will get the front seat

Hong Kong Tramways, just take a ride anyways. Well designed and maintained for the comfort of ride and sight seeing and speed to reach the destination, although its more attracts tourist rather than general commuters.
A fast alternative to go about in Central HK. Very fast and affordable alternative while checking out small places while in central HK. You do not have to walk too far for a station.
Cheap but take time. These things are good but they stop every 100-150 yards. Just do not expect to get from central to causeway in 15. More like 30

Awesome... good alternative to the MTR. Using the Ding Dings for transportation or just for experience is awesome. There are a few things you should know before using a Ding Ding. Make sure you know where you want to go (not in detail but at least the area) because when you re sitting in one of the Ding Dings no one is gonna tell you at wich station you re at or where you generally are. So either know what you should be looking for eg a big building or a special tourist feature what ever. You could also just count the stations where you stop at.You always go in from the back door and go out from the front door where the driver sits. You are going to pay at the end and you are supposed to have either an octopucs card or in cash exactly 2.30 HKD because you re going to put it into a box and you re not gonna get a change. No matter where you exit you always pay 2,30 HKD.You can not use the Ding Ding to get from HK island to mainland but you can have a wonderful long ride to get from west to east or visa versa. I think there have been 6 different paths all marked by colour. The longest ride is around 90 minutes. As for me when I went on I just chose a Bing Bing wich went to the east because my hotel was located at the west. I had a 40 minutes ride wich was absolutely awesome. I did not believe it myself how much I liked the drive. No crowds, no waiting its totally inexpensive and you get a nice tour through the main part of HK island. I had no destination I decided I will just get off where it looks interesting and thats what I did and it was so much fun.So yes try it out if you re in HK its interesting and worth it.

A leisurely and effective way to travel in a turbo-charged city. Trams are probably quite incongruous in a high-speed city like Hong Kong, but along the north shore of the Island, it's a surprisingly good way to travel: not like the MTR underground there's no need to climb flights of stairs, and to figure out where you pop out of the warren, the tram stops are often in the middle of the road next to a pedestrian crossing. Sure it's slow, and at times packed like sardine cans, but you can get to all the good spots on the north shore. Just be careful to jump on the correct one for your destination as there are a couple of detour loops which might not go as far as you wish.

A great and lazy way to see the city. We travelled the length of the Hong Kong island on the top level of one of these trams. It is so cheap. Just two Hong Kong dollars per person. It is a great way to see the different suburbs. It's also a good way to have a rest while still looking about and having fun.

Must experience at least once but once is never enough!. It's cheap and it allows you to travel from one end to the other affording you the local sights at HK island. At the far Western end, the Ding Ding will go past residents' apartments and you'll get to see the local way of life. If you have time, just board it!

An extension of the brilliant transport system. These narrow little tram cars are rather cute. We hopped on and off rather than using the MTR trains one afternoon to travel overland for a change. Clean, efficient.
Good experience. we tried to use tram from sheungwan to times square at night. tried to seat at second level to enjoy the city view. the tram quite comfortable.
A must do. We bought a painting with trams in the picture so decided to actually ride on one. Great experience and you get to see how locals travel
Cheapest Way to move Around. Its one of the cheapest ways to move around the Hong Kong Island. Its flat HKD 2 from one point to another.

Awesome. I love trying different transportation while on travel. The tram was a good try and they have both lower and upper decks. We sat on the upper deck where up can have a better view of the streets. Its a must try when you are in Hong kong

as iconic as the Star Ferry. just like the Star Ferry, no trip to Hong Kong is complete w/o a ride on the "ding - ding", on top of that, its a great way to travers the more central part of the island, cheap and fun, try to get a seat on the upper deck

Must try "Ding Ding". Historic tram in Hong Kong. Fun to take it. I like the contrast between this old tram and the skyscraper. If you are going to Hong Kong, you really must to try this original tram.

Take a Ride. This is only available on Hong Kong Island. If you've ever seen a movie filmed in Hong Kong, then you've certainly seen the tram. It doesn't go to a lot of tourist attractions, but then I think the tram IS a tourist attraction. Have a ride and tell your friends you did it!

Less traffic; efficient. It is efficient and it does not cause traffic. It is unique and it suits everyone's lifestyle. It is very convenient and it stops at different points. It is a unique mode of transportation in Hong Kong,
Cheap transportation. Ding ding is famous in Hong Kong. It is a tram system around the city. It's not fast transport like riding a bus but it is special and unique.
Fun. I like it riding tram. Good that my Chinese friend let me borrow her Octopus. I wish this tram is available in my place. It's fare is not expensive.

Typical HK island landmark. They are a distinctive colouful and clunky landmark of HK island. You can simply watch them and shoot some nice pictures with skyscrapers and luxury boutiques in the background. Or you can ride them to dive into what is actually a mean of transport for locals not a tourist attraction. The cross east west the center so you do not need to look too much for stations. Jusr ride wesf for a while and then jump on rhe next going back. You can't end up very wrong or very far. Along the road you may stop for Soho, the Peak the Escalators etc.

An alternative view of Hong Kong. If you want to see the variety of Hong Kong all in one journey, there is nothing better than taking an upstairs seat on a tram from one end of the tram line to the other, and watching what is going on throughout the journey. From Kennedy Town in the West to Shau Kei Wan in the East, you pass developing areas with construction work racing along, very local areas with traditional trade and local food markets, and the upmarket designer shops of Central and Admiralty. And all this for just over 2 dollars per passenger.
Bargain travel. Use your Octopus card. At the equivalent of 23p to anywhere it's a great way to get around & see more than you would underground!
fun way to sightsee. This was fun but very slow. Sit upstairs for a great view. If using an octopus card, tap when you get off (not when you get on!)
Great views. A good way to see around Hong Kong - elevated view to see some of the local sights.Cheap and efficient - good timetable - easy way to get around.

oldschool. There are several lines of tramways but all of them are going the same way through the Central district of Hong Kong island. Even though it's very unique and oldschool experience especially that many local people use it to travel.

While it's not the MTR. In previous trips I was aware of them as I did not want to get blindsided and they seemed slow. Then I discovered that my tailor was easily accessible by tram from Admiralty. I soon found taking them as fun, like the San Francisco Street Car fun. They are super cheap and I found inserting any set of random coins seemed to work or you can use your MTR card. Connaught Road is the main artery of the Hong Kong side, so if there's time it's worth a tram ride out and back, that will not only take you back to the past but also into the future of Hong Kong. Hint if the weather is nice go upstairs for the views otherwise if you need to go 4 or less stops it's probably best just to walk
Fun. There's something very fun about these weird skinny trams. I'd hate to be in one during a storm! They're not a tourist attraction - they're really used by locals. Very cheap.
A Must Do. Funny, and great sightseeing.. These trams are very narrow but very funny, it's a must do. Go up and you will see the shopping areas from the island.

A must for tram lovers. They rattle along and for us one of the best things in Hong Kong, we would do several day and night trips for 1 to 2 hours per trip every time we visit Hong Kong. It's the best way to see the city on Hong Kong island. The price is fixed $0.18 for 1 stop or $0.18 for 200 stops.
great overview of the city. If you're in a hurry, take the excellent MTR, but if you want to get your bearings the trams are the way to go. Still incredibly good value at HK$2.5 and a fun experience.

A slow but interesting way to get about. Visitors to Hong Kong should travel on a tram at least once during their stay. Trams operate along main routes on Hong Kong Island and are a good way to observe local life and activities. They are slow but, travelling on the top deck provides good views of what's going on outside and provides a good flavor of commercial Hong Kong life.

Interesting experience. You would definitely want to ride these trams. Before you hop on, remember - come in from the rare door and coming out from the front one. And make sure you have more than two stops to ride in - there are so many people, you won't enjoy your ride but instead will be crawling through, like we did. Anyway, it was fun :)

Very convenient and cheap. Very practical,you'll never have to wait long for a tram.Just hop on and pay as you hop off.It's the cheapest way of traveling.I recommend the Octopus card which unables you to pay a variety of travel modes and even in certain designated shops.Cash is also accepted.

The noise is a bit distracting sometimes but I MISS this!. Some people would describe this as the noisiest and slowest mode of transport (which I somehow agree), but I would say that staying in HK would never be complete without this experience (my opionion). The fare's really cheap and you can relax while travelling to your destination.
Easy to ride. The trams are also tourist attractions in Hongkong, and riding one will also be a thrilling feeling, ride one and you wont regret it.
Tramways. The Tramways are an added attaction to Hongkong besides getting you from A to Z, nice to ride it around Hongkong, vwry convenient.

the old way - a must do. this is a great way to navigate the main areas of the island - we were in causeway bay and the tram runs all the way through wan chai, admiralty, central and beyond (we got off at central most days to head up into soho. you need one of their local travel cards (we didnt do this as only there for a couple of days) or you can just drop exact change into the machine when getting off (not when getting on) - i think it is $2.50 HK (about .50c AUS) -so why wouldn't you give this a go a couple of times to experience one of the oldest forms of public transport in this great city. The drivers dont have changed hence the need for exact money. - lots of fun to feel a bit like a local.

From Western Market to King Street. At the Western Market terminal go to the upper deck and you will see the Hong Kong island from the best vantage point. Relax and go! Almost like in London but really better - trams are older than London buses and more authentic.
Must experience. Not recommended if you are 6 feet tall or weight more than 220 lbs... Tramways a bit too small for my taste but interesting way of going through town (surface)...
Well-maintained age-old syhstem. HK trams are quaint and well-maintained. They trundle alog tram tracks in the middle of the road and are extremely frequent.

Enjoyed the Ride across the City. As these trams are among the few surviving trams around the world, I make a point to try them in my visit. It was an enjoyable experience and the tram offer a good view of the Hong Kong Island City. As it was not expensive and easy to use with the Octopus card, I would recommend anyone visiting Hong Kong to make a point to ride the Tram. It was a memorable experience. Tips: - Get onto the Tram from the rear and get off on the front. - You pay when you get off the tram. Fare is HKD 2.30 for adult and HKD 1.20 for kids. - Exact Change only, best to use the octopus card.

Relaxing ride. Cheapest mode of island transport in the city. Catch a ride during non-peak hours and enjoy the breeze and view of the fast-paced city as you ride towards your destination. Unlike buses and the mtr, you pay while getting off rather than when boarding.
Quintessential.. A symbol of Hong Kong for decades. It is a great way to explore the city, and have snapshots of daily street life here.It's fun. Try it.
Cheap tour of town. We took the team from central to causeway bay to eat in din tai fung. They are cheap but crowded. But it is an excellent way of observing the city!
Must do!. Best way to see town is to use this 2 floor trams! Tickets is not expensive, driven often, and everyone can understand infrastructure of stops.
Nice ride. Worth trying. Nice ride, especially on the upper deck. It takes about twice the time to ride the same distance comparing to MTR, but you can see the city and it is great!
Just do it. Ding ding!. Might you be doubting, just do it. This cheapy local tranways is a must-do during your HongKong visit. It's just fun to be in the tram, look outside and absorb the city!

Ride through the streets. Though Metros are available to almost all the parts of the country, tramways are relaxed rides to the corners of the city. In service from a longer time, it runs right in the center of the road and is very frequent.

Cheap but so so busy!. If I'm honest, if it wasn't so cheap, I'd have given one less on the rating. Our experience of the tram wasn't particularly pleasant - we went from Causeway Bay to Pedder Street during a Friday afternoon when we thought it would be quiet enough. It was actually uncomfortably crammed full of people (and that's coming from someone well used to traveling on busy Chinese buses) and only emptied up after Admiralty. A bit disappointing because everyone speaks so highly of taking the tram - I'll take the MTR next time for sure!
Interesting. First time experience. Have to know where the tram goes before boarding. Able to view the streets well. Reminded me of the harry potter scene when onboard.

Just relax. This must be the best and cheapest way to spend up to 90 minutes on a sightseeing tour.The tramway runs along the north side of HK island and is probably about 8 miles in length.There is a flat fare of HK$2.3 (20p) whether you're on it for 5 minutes or hours. Get on at the rear and pay when you get off.It is a great way to chill out and experience the sight, sounds and smells of this great city.HK is a busy place and even on holiday it is all too easy to get caught up in the speed at which everyone dashes around. So, get on the tram, upstairs, at the front if possible and trundle along letting HK life, ancient and modern, unfold in front of you.

Great way to explore the real Hong Kong. Just jump on one of the many trams, head upstairs and enjoy the ride. On the tram you will able to see many more things compare to the MTR or taxi. It's a bit slower but more interesting way to travel.

See Hongkong in difference view. Cheap transportation which provide good experience. Get in from the back door of the tram ( you will see the better view from the upstair of the tram) and get off at the front door (pay when you get off)
A fun way to travel across Hong Kong. These trams are fun to use and makes it easy to get around Hong Kong. Don't miss the opportunity. Well worth the small cost. Ride with the locals!

Easy transportation . Took the tramways to go around the city of Hong Kong. It is more Preffered because u can see the building and architecture rather than taking the MTR and stuck underground. Take the ride and it's convenient

A must when visiting Hong Kong. I love riding on these ding ding. Sit on the upper deck and you can enjoy views of Hong Kong slowly and very relaxing. Just jump on and get off at any random stop and explore the different parts of Hong Kong.
Ding Ding. Nice way to see to town and have a chat with local people. We went one way to out of centrum and came back by taxi.
Cool and small. Cool way to travel instead of waiting for a bus. Depending which way you are heading it can be crowded.
Great way to see HK. Jump on, get a good seat upstairs and marvel the surroundings.. Get off at a random stop, get lost and get back on again... great way to see the city.

Ding Ding Tram. Hong Kong public transport system includes railways, trams, buses, minibuses, taxis etc. Riding the tram is one of the cheapest ways to explore the city. It is a cool ride with the locals and the opportunity to see all walks of life busy on the street.

Hop on. There are many many trams going from east to west and visa versa. No rush? (Almost) no more money? Hop on, and enjoy the island. The best seats are front 2nd floor. Some time 1 tram is waiting for the previous 3. When you get of, do it at the front, where you pay the fixed price of a few hk$.

Cheap, easy and relaxing.. Catching the tram is a great way to see HK. It's super cheap with a set fair. No need to swipe your Octopus card when you get on, just when you get off. Enter from the back, exit from the front.

Get on the tram!. Even better than the bus tours, hop on anywhere and ride to the end with thelocals. Best on a rainy day watching the soggy city go by. Plant yourself ina seat and experience real HK.

A great way to see and sample life on Hong Kong Island. We traveled the length of HK island by tram, even my wife loved them.Simple, cheap to use - go upstairs and watch the areas of HK change before your eyes!Ok slower than the MTR, but hey your on holiday and no better way to see the locals at work/play.
Tram. This is a fun way to see Hong Kong. Recommend sit on the top to get a good view of the city. We took it all the way around and back

Octopus it. You can use an octopus card to pay for all forms of transport in Hong Kong as well as for items in some convenience stores. If you are 65 or over make sure you get an Elder Octopus Card, which costs a minimum $70, including a $50 deposit. The elder card will get you reduced fares except on the Airport Express ($100). The standard card simply provides a convenient way to pay. At the end of your stay the balance on your card, including the deposit, is refundable less a $9 admin. fee. Well worthwhile. On some services you swipe when you get on, eg bus, some when you get off, eg tram and some on and off, eg MTR except Airport Express when you swipe off. The balance is shown at each swipe.The trams themselves are old, rickety, busy and fairly slow but they come at an amazing frequency, at least between Causeway and Central. They are part of the essential flavour of HK

Narrow, slow and bumpy, but you know you still have to do it when in HK. As the title of the review states these are a form of transport from a bygone age but still a must do when in HK. Took a trip from Central up to the racecourse at HappyValley as today was raining so passed some time and see a bit more of the city (even though the tops of the buildings were obscured in the clouds !!).What better way to spend HKD $2.30 on a rainy day.

Great fun way to get around and see Hong Kong. {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252{\fonttbl\f0\fnil\fcharset0 .SFUIText-Regular;}{\colortbl;\red255\green255\blue255;\red0\green0\blue0;}\deftab720\pard\pardeftab720\partightenfactor0\f0\fs34 \cf0 \expnd0\expndtw0\kerning0\outl0\strokewidth0 \strokec2 }

historical, cheap but slow. if you've got the time and inclination take a ride on the old rickety trams on the island. they're the cheapest way to get around but they are slow - two ways to look at this #1 a lovely change of pace in the hustle and bustle of HK and a great view point to see the streets - or - #2 rickety old trams that take an age to get any where!

Cool to experience but super slow. When I go traveling, my fiance and I like to try out all the public transport the place has to offer. So doing a trip on the tram was a must. They're pretty cool and super old but I have to say you're better off getting the MTR as these are really slow. It took us forever to get anywhere - we ended up getting off and getting the MTR in the end.Also a heads up that you need change before getting on. We didn't realise that and only had notes so luckily the driver let us off but it's worth taking note of that...
cheapest way of travelling inHK. We get the tram from central to causeway bay. it was packed! i think its the cheapest way to travel around hk. You can go up to see more of Hongkong.

HK mascot. I think these are the only double deck trams in the world. They run on HK island only, not in Kowloon. Very picturesque, slow and cheap. Have 3 HKD change for a ride or swipe the Octopus card. Go on the upper deck for views.
An excellent way to see the Island. Tranway is the nicest public transportation in HKG. If you are not in rush that is...Go on the upper deck, mix yourself with the locals and enjoy the view.
Hong Kong trams are fun. I always like the tram rides in Hong Kong. The trams are small and usually packed but it is an easy way to cross town and very cheap.

must try. do it night time , as a cheap night bus in town . easy to get to central -- CWB , must better then mtr . just not all have air-con , and get on the tram at the back , get -off & paid near the driver .
Unique Transportation. Well, this tram is unique from the oldway of transportation. Usually always crowded and can be super hot during summer , but for a short distance I guess not too bad.
Let's feel the slower peace of life. I really enjoyed the peaceful feeling sitting on the tram, going by urban roads in the heart of Hong Kong. A little bit nostalgic to mix with modern life.

Just one Ding to your destination!. This double decker tram is uniquely HK mode of public transport. It is cheap, convenient and efficient. Just one Ding to reach your destination is the slogan painted on the tram. Tap your octopus card when exiting and it cost less than HKD 3. But It is always very crowded especially on Sundays when it is jam packed with philipino maids besides tourists. We had a bad encounter as on one occasion the driver was speeding reclessly to change shift that passengers nearly fell off the vehicle while boarding. But it is interesting to spot some beautifully decorated trams that are privately hired for wedding, birthday or special parties. On these open top trams, music is blaring away and food, wine are served on board.
Unusual little trip. Perfect way to first look on Hong Kong - resting in slowly moving tramway, better in second floor.Enjoy a lot!

Excellent sight seeing tour. When you board the tram close to it return-point at Kennedy street - and stay on the tram for the continuation of the return journey - it gets empty so you can move upstairs and into the front row for the best forward view.Make sure you have HKD 3 at hand in cash to put into the pay-box upon exiting the tram.It can be very crowd and people use the stairs too so pre-plan your exit.

Long rides but super fun and different way to view the city. I never used to like the taking the tram. This was before I lived in Hong Kong. It's cheap and it's easy to hop on or off it. If you are not in a rush then I suggest taking the tram. If you are in a big crowd or going solo it's lots of fun. You can drink on it as far as I know. You can take it if you wanting to go to Happy Valley for the horse races or if you central side and want to explore Kennedy town. You will not get lost.

Sometime slow, but otherwise perfect. Need a break from walking ? Want to enjoy the view ? Want to check what is available at street level ? These trams are for you.Tram stop are numbers + E (for Eastward) or W (Westward). Avoid at rush hours if you need to be somewhere quickly.

A Moving Camera for Travellers. The Tram has unchanged perspective from more than a hundred years in the Hong Kong Island. Although the speed cannot compare to the pace of Hong Kong economy, this is the only moving landmark and the only way to enjoy the flourish of the city. Travellers are recommended to visit a portion of tramway from Admiralty to Causeway Bay which takes you around 45 minutes. Train runs every few minutes so wait for next tram if want to occupy the first upper-deck row. Tram service is paid by coins and Octopus Card when alighting .
Tram Away. The Tramways are a must for all visitors to Hong Kong, they are reliable, and easy to access because all directions are both in English and Cantonese

Cheap way to see the city! . For $2.30 you can ride the tram for the length of the island! Theirs no auto guide for tourist, but it's a great way to see the city. You hop on and pay in exact coins at the end.

I love the tram!. It's a fantastic way to see HK life! So long as you're not in a hurry, jump on and let it take you along the top side of HK Island. And for HK$2.3, one of the cheapest ways to see different parts of Hong Kong.

Amazing frequency of trams on Hong Kong island. We took the tram to Kennedy Town and back and thoroughly enjoyed seeing all the sights. There are so many trams you don't need to worry about hopping on or off to have a look at some of the small traders along the way. The cost is amazingly small - 23 HK$ for an adult or 11 for seniors (over 65) ie about 20p or 10p per ride. The only downside is that they don't give change, so be prepared.

Ding Ding, cheap and relaxing, from west to east. Having seen bad reviews for big buses in TA, I decided to take the Ding Ding tramways. Took an MTR until HK University, then proceed to Whitty street, and took a tram to North Point. Since Whitty street is the starting point, it is easy to get the front seat on the second floor. It only cost HKD2 for the whole ride. The ride is passing Wan Chai, Central, Causeway bay, and ended in Java road near a traditional wet market. Thought that kind of market has become extinct in HK. Find at least two Indonesian minimarket selling Indonesian products. They have indomie, biscuits, bimoli until stinky beans (petai). Taking the same tram on the way back, but decided to stop at Tin Hau temple road to see the temple, then return to the city by MTR.
old world aura. Hong Kong Trams will give you an old world aura..its very easy to take the tram and roam about in the Hong Kong city
Fun to explore the city with. You enter from the back door and leave from the front. Quite the opposite. This is to make sure that you pay before you leave the ride!

The oldest transportation in HK!. A must ride if you're in HK!This is historical even to local HK people like me. I have to say this is a slow ride, but you can in another road totally enjoy busy HK street with a slow pace on this tram. Plus very cheap price! Do take a ride if you have sufficient time and you will never regret as it may disappear soon in HK as well...
Step Back in time. Great and fun way of getting around Hong Kong, really cheap and impossible to get lost on. There are loads of trams running long hours.

Nice mode of transport to see parts of Hong Kong Island. I took the tram from one end to the other, it's cheap way to see the city. I had a lot of fun just looking at the city from another perspective as it reaches to parts of the city where you get to see how the locals live and in short, you get to the REAL LOCAL areas.

Best way to travel along the north of HK lsland. you cannot find other mean of transportation in HK that is so environmental friendly, efficient, quiet and comfortable (when it is in non-peak hours of course). you can just take couple stops for a short ride or you can try the west to east / head to tail trip,,, for the same price... reasonably low price... HK$2.2 for one stop or for 100 stops... i am a HK local and i always take this and i highly recommend the trams for all the visitors to HK. we local just love it!!!

Your own (almost !) private tour. We always take the tram a long way, at least once when in Hong Kong. Since its a must as a tourist to get one of the 4 front row seats on the upper deck, I suggest picking it up in the first stop in Causeway Bay (push up front !) and take the Western Market one all the way. If you can't get the front seat wait for the next one or if its busy, walk back to the station before Causeway.

Old Hong Kong at its best!. We were staying at the Upper House in Admiralty and these old trams rattled by our stomping ground so we just had to jump on after visiting Wanchai and take the ride home. Such fun! Hard to get a seat up the front but great to sit with the locals and watch the traffic roar by on its way to Central. Cheap and cheerful- you must take a ride on this HK institution!

Most interesting and cheap way to see Hong Kong Island from the far west to east side of the island.. You only need HK$2.3 to take a tram in HK island, some tram is air conditioned but the old styles are not, so the best time is to travel during the autumn and winter time, not the hot summer. The tram is slow but you can see and enjoy seeing the busy streets, shops and markets along the tram way. It also run through the financial center in Central and Admirtly, the Horse Racing course in Happy Valley, the shopping hobs/ eating places in Causeway Bay........from the west side of the island to the most eastern side or another way round. You can choose to drop off at any station which you find it interesting and then continue your journey heading your destination, but certainly you need to pay again whenever you leave the tram. However, no one would bother about the fare as each time only cost you HK$2.3 (or US$ 0.3)!

Fantastic Means of Transport. We did not know the trams existed until we saw them out of the window from our hotel. Great means of transport to get your bearings in the city. Also a great place to rest when shopping gets the better of you - cheap and you get to see areas you wouldn't get to by foot if you only have a short time in the city.

What a ride!. Despite coming to Hong Kong regularly for 30 years, I had never previously been on the trams - what a revelation! No air con, but fast, frequent and super cheap to get along the main routes. Seldom used by tourists, this is a slice of the real Hong Kong!
Traditional Transport. The rides are quite bumpy, but it's really an experience not to be missed!! Go to the upper deck so it's not too squeesy, and you'll also get a windy ride :D

It's lovely but over crowded.. It is lovely, and quite typical for hk. But unless very late in the evening or very early in the morning, you will have a crowded tram. Specially if there is an exhibition in town. Choose odd times and choose the first stop to the last stop. The. You get a seat gurrantied and for 25 cents you pay, you will almost see every corner of the Hong Kong island !! Good choice.

Tip to tail by tram . Now this is the best site seeing tour going. Hop on and grab a top level front row seat. Live the sites, sounds, and energy that is Honk Kong. I traveled from one end of the island to the other and back again.....with a few stops at markets and parks along the way. Yes the trams are busy and can be noisy.....and not always clean....but you knew they would be ....it is Hong Kong.
Trams great views of the city. Decided to try the trams out great views of the city at night especially over the christmas period. Used by locals as well as tourists. Historical way of travel.

The best way to understand Hong Kong. It is the cheapest way to travel round Hong Kong Island, it runs from the western end to the eastern end. It only costs you HK$2.3 per trip, it is about 100 minutes for the whole trip. I recommend to those who wants to realize the daily life of local people. The tram would pass through Central and Admiralty, where they are the commercial centre of Hong Kong. The terminus at eastern end, where is a residential area, there is a market, a lot of vegetable stalls, fruit stalls and meat stalls. In Western District, there is a lot of old shops where selling salted fish and dry seafood, for an example, dried scallop and shark's fins. If you arrive the Western district in meal time, I suggest you to take your food there, where there is a lot of choice, no matter it is Chinese, Japanese or Western cushines. I suggest to take the trip either at the lunch time or after 7:00 pm to avoid rush hours.
Great way to travel. If you're going somewhere on the tracks or just want to see HK great way to travel and Only 2.30 $ however far you go. Great bargain in.a very expensive city

Excellent way to travel on the island. Really cheap way to travel on the island. You can reach pretty much everywhere without too much walking by using those. I suggest to sit as forward as possible to have the most thrilling ride, especially in the turns!

A great way to tour Hong Kong island. If you are rushing for time, try taking the MTR or even bus instead. No doubt it is slow, but it is a great and fun way to tour the busy streets on Hong Kong island. You can just use your Octopus card to tap when you alight at your stop.

Nostalgic ride, don't miss when in HK !!. Although slow, it takes you to many places along the same street and if you like photography, the best shots are taken from the upper deck.It is also very cheap to use, frequency is also a plus point.

Travelling on Hong Kong Tram. It's the cheapest mode to travel within Hong Kong Island. One rate payment upon boarding and you can ride from one end to another to have a view throught the city on Hong Kong Island. Remember to lookout on the stops number that you would like to exit as their stopping interval on stops are minimal.

Great way to see Hongkong various neighborhoods !!!!. Great for the whole family ,the track goes from East to West of Hongkong ,so a long ride for 2.30 HKD. Good all around viewing ,highly recommend it !! They are a bit hot in the summer and not the fastest !!!!
$2.30 FOR ANY DISTANCE. We spent just over an hour on the tram going across Hong Kong Island. Cheap and easy way to view the city Admittedly, it gets a bit boring once you have left Central.

Transportation or sight-seeing?. This was an interesting ride that is a mix of local transportation and sigh-seeing. It is easy to find and board (enter at the rear and exit with a swipe of Oyster card at the front), but remember it runs on a track so it will only go a very specific route. The view from the upper deck is nice for sights and photos. There are frequent stops, so don't be in a hurry. All-in-all it's fun, relaxed, and an easy way to see some of the city. (Tour bus or Hop-on/Hop-off might be more efficient and flexible.)

Cannot miss. You cannot miss a ride on the tram. You have to be prepared: try it during busy times, early morning time when no one is on it, and at night when you can see the city lights from a different perspective. If you are going to Causeway Bay, try to catch the one going to Happy Valley, there are usually less people on these trams but they are also less frequent. This is still one of the most inexpensive mode of transportation in HK, and the experience will be magnificent. Just note, the locals do use this as their day to day way of transport to get from point A to point B, so it can get busy and crowded. This is a must!
Best city transport. We suggest on arrival visitors to the Island take a tram ride from depot to depot and get your bearings and observe the locals going about their everyday business,

Cheap and Cheerful. This is an excellent and relaxing way to see Hong Kong Island at a slow pace. The beauty of the tram is that it is set price, HK$2 for any length of journey. You could ride the whole length of the island and back for $2. that would be about a 4 four journey.
super cool. hong kong tramways or as they call it ding ding are super cool attraction in hong kong , if you don't want to take a ride with it u can just go to see it.

Heartracing journey. This was a fantastic choice that we decided to use. This was a cool way to travel and see skyscrapers, the locals, different buildings. We boarded in the evening and took lots of pictures. It was safe and cheap. You could travel from uptown to downdown in no time. We visited a market and local areas. Such fun!

oldest and cheapest transport option in HK.. Trams / Ding ding tramways run on the Island side from Kennedy town (west) to Shau kei wan (east). Fixed fare 2.3HKD for an adult. Good way to see HK Local life. Slow but with good sights!A must see( and ride) attraction. Its the way locals travel so gets crowded during peak hours.

Board at North Point Tram Terminal to ensure seats!. The kids love this, and it's cheap so do find time to fit this into the schedule. Try and board the tram at the North Point Terminal to ensure that you have seats for the kids at the upper deck. Directions: Take MTR line to North Point. Exit B2 on King's Road, cross the road and turn left and walk for 5-10mins until you see Terminal on your right along Chun Yeung Street.
Easy to use. We found this to be really easy to use. For HK$3.40, you can travel 2 or 40 stops. Does tend to get very busy between 6.30 and 8.00 in the evening.
To do at night. You should definitely hop on one . Most preferably at night where the view from the upper deck is breathtaking ss you wonder around the city.
Great sight seeing attraction. This is a good way to take a cheap tour of the area, they travel up and down the middle of the main road.

what better way to see the city for HKD3.20. The tram as refer to local as Ding Ding is one of the most distinguish transportation in HK. It goes on and on and only cost $3.20. Plan your route and never ride it during peak hours or hot summer day
Great way to see the city of HK. An alternative to catching the MTR. It is slower but it is great way to see the sights and get a feel for the city.
Lovely to look at.. We were plainning to take a trip, but the monsoon came in and we fled back to the hotel. They are soo pretty. And soooo thin! Keep them going Hong Kong! A great attraction!
Nostalgic experience. Fixed fare, affordable and convenient for travelling between east and west Hong Kong Island. Well-preserved experience - feels the same from years ago.

CHEAP, EFFICIENT WITH VIEWS BUT SLOW!. It is a very good way to travel on Hong Kong Island. The net work is from island west ( Kennedy Town ) to island east ( Shau Kei Wan ) with stops every few hundred metres. One could have very good view of streets if one is riding on the upper level. Best feature: HKD2.3 / journey for adults which is a bargain ( only USD0.30 )!

Wonderful for my young son. MTR is always faster to get around, but we wanted my young son to get a look at Hongkong on his first day in town. Carrying a stroller up to the top level was a slog, but snagged the front seats and for the next hour he didn't blink looking at the sites.After starting in an old neighborhood in Shau Kei Wan (don't miss On Lee's for noodles first !)we travelled towards Central, taking a trip in time as we passed the busier and modernized Causeway Bay, Wan Chai and Central. We would've continued on to the end in Kennedy Town except for "the need to feed" in one of the nice dimsum joints downtown. My son still talks about his trip on the Ding Ding, so I imagine we will be taking it again next year when we visit.
Great view. Good way to start of your sightseeing, travel along the Island whit the tram.Use the oyster card to pay the fare.

Scenic ride. I always enjoy riding on a tiny tram when I am not in a hurry because I find it a best way to explore HK island. The ride itself ia very cheap also compared to other mode of transportation. A must for anyone visiting HK.

Ding Ding in HK is a must!. A cheap and best transportation in central compared to MTR which required more walking. So if you are a lazy shopper but wanna cover more places, may consider this and the price is real cheap.

Hong Kong's original mass transport. These are a very quaint and novel way of getting around HK island itself. If you're not in a hurry, then I would definitely recommend them. They can be a bit uncomfortable and busy at times, but that just adds to their charm.It costs a flat rate of 2HKD or so, regardless of you're travel duration, so the cost is nothing to worry about. So slower than the MTR, but you get to see a lot of things on the journey too.

A ride from one end to the other of HK Island. We took a cheap and leisure ride that cost HK$2.30 per ride by using our Octopus card from Western Market to Shau Kei Wan. Age above 65 pays half of that. Then we took a stop at Wan Chai for some street shopping.

Cheap but fun. Something you must do. For $2 you get a great ride through HK. Watch the world from the window and hop off when you see something interesting. For that price you can take several trips in the day.You pay as you get off not as you get on...a little confusing .
inexpensive fun. Always enjoy the trams, sitting back as you watch the world go by. Hints of yesteryear mixed with the ultra modern

The cheapest way to cross Hong Kong Island.. This is the cheapest tram that I have ever travelled on! As seniors, we both had a green Octopus card which enabled us to travel anywhere on the tram for just 1.1 dollar. We decided to do our own tour of Hong Kong island so we caught a tram at Central and went west as far as the terminus at Kennedy, walked round and the caught another tram right up to Causeway Bay and did the same, before returning on a third tram to central. The three tram rides cost us the grand total of 3.3 dollars - not bad for an afternoons sight seeing!

Ding Ding, clang clang. Soon these trams will be just a memory, so when in Hong Kong its a must see. And its the best priced ride in town only HKD$2.10 per ride what a bargin. This is Hong Kong's SFO cable cars.

A cheap way to see Hong Kong. Hop on a Ding Dingband and travel from one end of Hong Kong Island to the other. The top deck gives the best views. The end of the line at Northpoint (filled with friendly Vietnamese) was a highlight where meals are cheap and the market interesting. If you have an hour to spare or want to rest your feet, don't miss a ride on a Ding Ding which allows you to hop on at leisure. It's so chesp, but don't forget to swipe your Octopus card when disembarking.
Enjoyable ride!. this is a good way to see Hong Kong island on a open top vehicle. it was breezy and cooling and we get to see good views from top deck.

Interesting but too slow. This train can only see on the road in the island and can't find it in the Koloon. It runs slowly on the street and crossing the modern and old market area respectively. I get on the train from Central and get off at Causeway Bay, it takes about 30 minutes as every stop have many people get on it. So, I think this train is very popular in Hong Kong.

Indelible experience to feel the beat of HK. You may experience the life style of Hong Kong people from a most famous slow pace of transportation (Ding Ding) , it is a amazing tour that you will never forget.Take the upper deck of the trams , sit down & relax , enjoy the scenery , places , local shops , markets...

Cheap way to see Hong Kong. For HK$2.30, you can ride the Ding Ding Trams around HK Island. You can sit back and enjoy the Hong Kong sceneries, from modern skylines and traditional wet markets. Lots of photo opportunities. Avoid peak hours as it can be very crowded. Go for upper deck!

Best, cheapest way to get around Hong Kong. We used the "Ding Ding" to get around all over Hong Kong, and it was so convenient and cheap! The kids loved it, as it reminds them of the San Francisco trolley system. It does get a bit crowded during peak hours, but that's just how public transportation works. Love it!
Easy. Hop on and offUsed the tram from wanchai to csuseway bay. Very easy. Has a unique rustic feeling to itEdpecially the ding2 sound

Part of HK's excellent PT system. We were tired of walking, so we just got on one of these at random, and took in the view for a while. Got to the end of the line and rode back.it's real public transportation for real people, so don't expect any sort of tourist experience; it just goes from here to there.

Charming and efficient tranport system.. Ride these charming old rickety, noisy trams for great views of Hong Kong street life. The Octopus card can be used.Routes are colour coded. Listen for the famous "ding ding".

Cheap way to get around town. Cheap, fun way to get around Hong Kong. We took the tram from western district to Happy Valley just to be able to sit back and see the sights of Hong Kong, it was a cheap fun way to do some sight seeing. Also worth using to get to destinations around town if it is close to where you need to be (MTR is faster)
Great way to see Hong Kong Island. This is a cheap way to see Hong Kong. Cheap and easy to use. Great if the weather is not so great , I recommend going up to the second level and enjoy the rides.
Get around in the old fashion way. Ding Dings are very convenient and economical way to get around in HK. It's almost like a hop-on hop-off. It costs $2.6 per ride compared to $13 for underground.

Nostalgic ride in Central , Hong Kong. Not a definite to do thing in Hong Kong, but makes you feel go back in time a little as you ride the whole city with the bell ringing. This is one of several things well preserved in Hong Kong.
Typical, must try !. Typical tramways, easy to take. Slow with stops every 500m, not really fast but very interesting and cheap.

Cheapest way to travel in Hong Kong. It is the cheapest but probably the most crowded way to travel in Hong Kong. So please use it only at off peak hours. Enjoyable ride will take you through the main areas of the Hong Kong island.

Kicking myself for not travelling on Ding Ding on previous visits. Refreshing experience I pulled down window and just reveled in soaking up the street buzz and buildings
Oh Soooooooooo much more comfy than a taxi
For some of us We grow too soon old and too late smart
Ding Ding. Cute and convenient public transportation. Not much else to say about this. Wouldn't put it on the must do list for Hong Kong

"Hop on....:-). I've never witnessed suck an excellent and well maintained tram services. There could be another better ones but so far this one has been my best experience. Easy to access stations, amazing frequency of trams, cleanliness, maintenance, traffic rules following and no hassles of buying the ticket. Loved it.

A great way to see the breath of Hong Kong Island. I, travel from Central to Causeway Bay and also pass the Western Market terminal station. Very exotic way to travel. It is double deck and a bit challenging for old folks to get to and from the upper deck as it wobble. Windows can be opened and you pay, when you exit and it is also indicated at the box slot, so get plenty of loose change, especially coins that is less than a dollar. Seats are OK and the view was fantastic. They have fixed stops and to maximize your pleasure, do know thew end point of the tramway as some route are shorter or goes to specific places.

Hong Kong transport icon. As my son very curious of taking Ding Ding, we just hop on a few stops.All i can say is very antique as i feel interior design and seating place even the entrance seems original design from the beginning era. When we hop on there's 2 line barriers. We can choose want to sit at the upper or lower deck. We choose upper deck. Not like MTR or bus, this tram fare is flat how far we go.Driver was very friendly

Great fun. Got the double decker tram to Kennedy town and back...vey cheat ,I think less than $5 for the return trip....just nostalgic and full of locals....one of the easiest,cheapest HK experiences...you have to pay cash ...on caphange so hold onto your coins they do come in handy
So much fun. If you want to truly experience life as a local, this is the best and most fun way to travel in Hong Kong.

The one and only. Took the more than 100 years old tram from Times Square. It was indeed a nostalgic ride along the oldest tram in the world. The tram although have been refurbished the seats and trams were replicated as it was back then. We sat on the upper deck and had a good view of Hong-Kong. The ride is slow but very enjoyable and it is also very cheap at 2.30 Hk$ per ride.

A cheap experience. You must try its just a trip back in time, for vey little, but cash only, so be prepared. Luckily I had a GPS. so didn't need to ask what stop I needed but it did seem very easy, and I was only one stop out from what I got from there map and where a needed to get off

Take a tram if you have the time. A great way to see Hong Kong, but it does take a while to get from A to B. It is very cheap ($2.30, I think) and you can go as far as you want per trip. You need to pay cash (exact change only), or use your Octopus Card.

Great fun! . I am from a city with an extensive tram network so am very comfortable with these slightly outmoded forms of clattering transportation but the Hong Kong trams are something special. Firstly, they have retained their design essentially from the very old ones still in service through to the not-quite-flash new ones. Very narrow and double decker they hurtle along adorned in their often garish advertising carrying happy commuters from here to there. Here you get on at the back and off at the front. Sit upstairs if you can although it does not really matter and don't forget to tap your Octopus card to pay.It's all fun and very handy and you will see some great streetscapes on the way. Perfect!
Do it at least once!. It's a cheap activity, only a few HKD. You can pay with your Octopus card. You may get a bit lost, but it's worth it!
Something different to the usual transport. Cut double decker buses that drive on specific rails and stop at mini stations. Its cheap and usually on time.

Different way to travel. We took the tram a few times whilst I was here-they are brilliant, so thin and tall-yet they manage to fit a fair few people, they are a cool cheap way of getting around especially as they have their own track so no traffic gets in the way.

Very affordable transport. Flat fare of HK$2.30 only. Plenty of trams that go to various places. Get up from the rear and down at the front where you pay before alighting. Upper deck on a cold Dec day is quite an interesting experience. The tram is narrow and when it gets crowded then movement is a challenge.
Must try experience . We took time to experience tram travel. It's very easy and cheapest travel mode in HKG island area. You need to pay before alighting, only 2.3HKD per travel.

A little bit of history. The trams run from East/West on Hong Kong Island. The trams are working relics of the past and still perform a service to the public. If you have not been on one, you must take a ride, even if only for a couple of stops. You can use your Octopus card to pay the fare.
Must try in HK. This is the best way to have a nice snapshot on the HK side in the tram ride. Unforgettable experience!

You've Got To Try It.. OK there's nothing particularly spectacular about the old trams other than they are double decker trams, ancient and still going strong! Drivers aren't particularly friendly but take a ride so you can say you've done it!

Cheap way to see the city. This may be the cheapest way to see the city. HKD2.30 per person. You can go from one side of the island to another, but be prepared to sit in the tram for a few hours. It stops at stations almost every 30-40 seconds.

Must-try. This is the cheapest and an excellent way to visit the Hong Kong Island. With HKD2.3 (i.e. About 0.3 USD), you would be able to move more or less from one side of the Hong Kong Island to the other. You will see and experience the uniqueness and vibrancy of different neighbourhoods in Hong Kong.With a light breeze gently touching your face, experience Hong Kong in a leisurely way. The upper deck is recommended.

Accessible but can be confusing. After traveling along the MTR for most of our trip, we elected to use the Ding Ding for a little site seeing and travel to Dragons Back. I only give it a 4/5 because figuring out the correct bus to jump on can be a little confusing. Not knowing the exact stopping locations may mean you miss a stop as you do need to hit the stop button near your seat in order for the driver to actually stop at your destination. Otherwise we felt very safe and enjoyed the very cheap option for getting around the city. It is also the cheapest way to tour around Hong Kong.

Small price for fun entertainment.... Hop on and hop off for 2,30 HKdollars, great fun if you get a seat on upper floor. All over central on hk island, this is an option to see the place drom a different perspective.

Cute way to discover the city. Cheap and fun way to discover the city. These double decker trams (the only ones in the world) move quite slowly so you have plenty of time to see the city. Funnily you pay (2.60$) once you leave the tram.

Exp. the HK history. firstly, a much cheaper option than bus and metro. secondly, a great way to explore the urban structure and layout of the HK Island. It gets you close to the local's way of lives, as well as to learn about the collective memory of the city. Try to get a window seat at the upper deck.
Tram !. We asked the people at the stop if this was getting us to Central. But mistakenly were given the wrong direction and got on the wrong Tram . Service is prompt if your familiar .l
Cheap mode of transportation around Hong Kong Island. Love this tramp service. From one end to another, it only cost HKD2.40. It is a good way to relax with view.
Back to old days. I took the tramways from Kennedy Town to Causeway Bay, it took some forty minutes. Cheap but unique. Definitely a try.

Good experience. One of the best transportation experience in Hong Kong. It is only available in Hong Kong Island. I will suggest to enjoy the tram from Causeway Bay to Central. The cost is less than HK$3.
Cheap and convenient. Cheap as chips and really handy to jump on and off to break down the treks between shopping binges! Proper handy ☺

Ding ding joy but a tight squeeze. We've used the trams many times in Hong Kong, for a measly $3 you get to ride up the main streets of Hong Kong. We loved it, just beware that on weekends they can get overwhelming packed!
A different experience. It was amazing to see the trams on HK roads. It takes you back to the old era. Its a nice experience as you dont get to see trams everywhere these days.

Cool but crowded. Eastbound is usually full/crowded. Its okay if you just want to explore the city but not if you are in a hurry. Too much traffic and there's a lot of chance you'll miss your stop. Its cheap tho but only runs in Hong Kong Island

Experience local transport. It is a slow moving and packed means of transport for local people. I joined the crowd to experience the uniqueness of the ride. You climb from the back, and then goes down in front to pay with octopus card.
It was enjoyable ride for my kids, something that we haven't experienced before.

Cheap way to get around. A good, charming and cheap way to get around some of the main spots in Hong Kong. Can be a bit slow during rush hour but it's worth taking once or twice for the experience alone
I love to travel Hong Kong Island via Tramways(Ding Ding). you can pay only hkd 2.30 one way(trip) as far as you can from East to Western suburb of Hong Kong Island . cheaper than the Explore bus...
Historic Fun Ride. took a short trip on a Ding Ding near Causeway Bay and enjoyed it! Looks old from inside. Slow, enjoyable ride that takes you back in time.

Hong Kong Traditional public transport. Tram is one the signature transport in Hong Kong, but also a major tourist attraction and one of the most environmentally friendly ways of travelling in Hong Kong. Furthermore, it is cheapest and convenient public transport and you can enjoy “Ding Ding” with nice city view.
You can check my 360 video of tram in my profile
Awesome tour of downtown. Take the tram end to end and morning and night its such a great way to travel through hong kong……...

A very good trip from the top of the tram. The tram is another cheap transport option in Hong Kong. We caught the tram from Admiralty to Western Market and from the top of the double-decker tram, we had excellent views of the streets and buildings.
Fun sightseeing but slow .. When time left , Nice way to travel on hk Island instead of using THE Mtr . Can be crowdy, very cheap .

Don't get on a lunchtime!!. A real old world experience, still using the original tramlines. DO NOT THINK OF TRAVELLING ON IT BETWEEN 12.45 AND 14.00. At this time all the offices empty down in a made panic, they have exactly 1 hour for lunch! Down in the lift, 10 minutes, get on the tram 10 minutes, 10 minutes to grab a lunch downtown, 10 minutes back on the tram and then 10 minutes up in the lifts to their offices. If you have ever seen a swarm of bees that is the equivalent of the lunch hour in Hong Kong
A Bit Of History. A nostalgic way to travel around Central. Great views from the top deck. Pay upon exiting at front of tram

Cheap way to see the Hong Kong side neighborhoods. After we finished the Peak ( standing in line for the Tram ride ), our feels were tired. Instead sitting around, we took the Tramway from Central to the last stop of Sai Kei Wan. ( almost 1 hour depend on the traffic ). We get to see 5 to 6 different neighborhoods in a very slow pace. The only complaint was there are no air conditioning on all Tramways ( very hot during the summer months ), else the cost is cheap and this is a classic transportation.

cheap form of transport and fun. just knew that I had to try these trams, they are really good and staff very helpful. they run often and go all over Hong Kong. Took me back in time, as they can be old fashioned, however, they are fun, and I enjoyed every minute on the trams
ding ding. as you walk around the city but with ding ding is different, i like it as i walked too much there, thanks for my friends.

Ding Ding goes the trolley. One of the many highlights of Hong Kong are the tramways along Connaught Road (and others) Super thin, these rattle along at a speed when in a bit of open road, which is not that often in HK. Get upstairs and watch the city go by. I never tire of it and make it a journey every time I am in HK.
Too full. Too slow and too full. Not comfort at all. But is worth to try. The back door to enter and front to exit. The city view is nice to see in the evening

Riding history . The cheapest mode of transportation besides your two feet. Get a map or download one onto your phone. You get on the back and exit the front. That's where you pay (cash or Octopus card). They stop at every stop, so get ready to get off a stop ahead (especially if you're in the upper deck). They've been in use forever and most don't have a/c, so in the summer of may not be fun to ride. Note: Hong Kongers call them "ding-ding"

Easy cheap way to travel. At a flat rate you can take the tram through the city. An easy way to get to know the city at the start of the trip would be to go on the team from end to end. You can user the tram to get to the peak as well
Hong Kong Tramways. A classic way to travel on Hong Kong Island, a must do for any tourist. An incredibly cheap and fun way to see the island.

Great way to view hong Kong island. The best way to view Hong Kong Island. No matter where you stop,the price remains at $2.30Hkd. The ding ding goes from the east to the west. It also reach the peak station. Enjoy the view.

Travel like the locals. Forget about the tourist busses and get on to the two story tram.Get a seat upstairs in the front. Lean back and enjoy the views of the busy city. Not too many tourist crawling into the tram

A Must Do!. Take the tram from one end of Hong Kong Island to the other for just HK$2.30 and witness almost everything Hong Kong has to offer. It is not the most comfortable ride in the place but one of the most memorable. Not air conditioned, so best when it is cool. If you get a top deck front seat there are plenty of photo opportunities. Loved it to bits.
Another 2HKD trip. Take a seat at the front in the top floor and enjoy HK. A cheap way to sit and have a rest while experiencing HK island. A target is not needed, just a bit 'walking in a tram'

Ding ding all the way..... We took a joy ride from Chater Road to Chun Yeung market at Northpoint. It was scenic ride with the scenery changes from high rise office buildings to crowded Wan Chai and passing by the well liked Sogo shopping centre at Causewaybay and ended up round a bend into a colourful noisy Chun Yeung wet market. Our tram driver was very patient waiting for a truck (parked at the bend of Chun Yeung) to finish loading before continuing the journey.An slow enjoyable ride and CHEAP !

Great and slow. The trams are such an icon in Hong Kong.They are absolutely nothing special except a great way to watch people and see the town.Do not expect to get anywhere in any time - you have the MTR for that.Sit back and enjoy.

Good Experience, less crowd. This is my favorite way of transportation in Hong Kong (as the rest are so crowded) You can feel the breeze, hear the noise and see the 'life' alongside the Hong Kong Street around you. Yes, it's slower than the MTR as it goes on the same route along the Hong Kong Island coast, but it's better and I recommend you to try at least once (if you are not in a hurry)

My all time favourite way to travel around Hong Kong . A brilliant way to travel. The trams are beautiful and easy to jump on and off. So cheap I can't believe they make money. Use your octopus card to keep it simple. Jump on at the back and off at the front. Pay just as you get off. Go upstairs for the best views. Stops are numbered to make it easy.

The spine of the city. One constant of the city is the ubiquitous trams. Hop on and off with your Octopus card short or long journeys all same low price of 23$HK, someone tell Boris ! You have not experienced a team till you have been in a jam try the rush hour :) enter at the back and out at front to pay on exit with your card or cash

Nice way to see the coty. It is nice to just jump on a tram and see where you end up. It's quite old and slow so if you're in a hurry then get the train. It's a good way to see the city and very relaxing to just sit and watch people!

Must do, the cheapest public transport!. A lot of locals still take the tram and you will need to avoid peek hours otherwise there is too many people on it.Still nice and appreciate it and it gives you a chance to take a look around. If you have time just try it.

Ding ding express..... If you are not in a hurry to go anywhere or do anything you MUST go on a traditional trolley bus or 'ding ding'It costs next to nothing and really is like stepping back in timeAs modern traffic, pedestrians and life goes on around you, sit back on your wooden bench and dream of a time long gone. This rickety form of transport - some of which dates back 100 years - an icon from yesteryear is a wonderfully old fashioned experience Highly recommendedEnjoy:-)

Terrible ride. It was requested by my wife to take a ride on this Tramway upon my visit to HK island. Got up from Tong Lo Wan, and ended at Wan Zai.Terrible ride as it is hot, slow and crowded. Not recommended if you bring kids or senior citizen along.
Old memories. Great value way to see the hustle & bustle below you as you travel from one end of the island to the other.Cheap as chips.

Old but nice to ride. The Ding Dings are a nice transportation. While riding them, you get great views. Good to ride if you just arrived to HK and want a quick tour of the Downtown. Not very practical nor quick, but it's a must do while visiting the city.

Something you have to do when you visit Hong Kong.. Something you have to do when you visit Hong Kong. A little slow but you feel like your are 50 years back in time. HK dollars 2,50 per trip and you pay when you leave the Ding Ding.

Old Skool is Cool. In a city that's so modern and cosmopolitan, the Hong Kong Tramways are a true gem from the olden days, that still function perfectly and are a great way to see the city. Sure they can get a bit busy at times, but head on up any way, try to get a seat on the upper level right at the front and take in the sights of Hong Kong the way it's been done for decades and decades. Not to mention it's one of the more affordable ways to get around Central and just a great way to get lost in Hong Kong.
A relaxing and affordable way to travel . Great trams with time to chill and look around in the city. The fact is that it is part of the city charms and should be taken if not in a rush.
Nice way to experience the HK from island east to west!. Tram is the best way to experience classical local culture from HK island east to west, and of course the cheapest way!

Unique and classic. The oldest public land transport (and still the cheapest) in Hong Kong. Enter from the back through the classic turnstile and go upstairs (for the best view). When you are ready to get off, go downstairs and pay at the front to exit. There's no air conditioning so it's best to avoid the hot days (or pick a less crowded time).

Awesome way to see some of the city.. Jump on, go to the top deck and sit at the front with the window down. Great way to see the sites. You can use your Octopus Card to pay for the journey as you get off, or with the correct change.
Unique.. Travelled on aSunday evening and was absolutely packed.Luckily a kind person advised us where to get off for Times Square.

Great way to see the city. The Tramways are easy to use and really quaint. You jump on the back and then as you jump off (at the front) you pay. You can either pay in coins or using an Octopus Card. It's a flat fare of $2 no matter how far you travel so its great for a quiet and laid back ride through the city. Sit at the front of the upper deck and enjoy the view!

Lots of fun. If you've never been on a cable car, the Ding Ding is a must trip. You can use the Ding Ding for transportation but it is also a good way to see the sights. This year we took the Ding Ding to Kennedy Town and got a great view of how the Hong Kong residents live. When you take this Ding Ding, you have to change to another one to get back down to city center.

Good, slow way to see the city. This cheap mode of transportation primarily runs east to west on Hong Kong Island. The space on these trams can get very tight, but when you have space to breath, it is a nice way to see the city. The tram pace was very slow though. If you are in a hurry or have other things to do, use the MTR. I only recommend using these if you have the time, otherwise you are not missing much.
Great way to get round. Cheap and cheerful and what better way is there of getting around and seeing the city at the same time ! Ding Ding.. hop on board !

ok to look at. These trams look good, wouldn't plan a trip just to see them. They are in Sheung Wan, if your nearby worth taking a look, but wouldn't go out my way to see them, really small inside and confined, not really much to say really

Crowded. We used ding dings on a Sunday afternoon. It was crowded and even thouh people say it is the fastest way to get around, we found this not to be true. We used the convenient octopuss card to pay for the pair.
Interesting Experience.. These trams don't really provide timely transport, but are a most interesting experience for the fun of it.

Great way to see Hong Kong Island. The Hong Kong trams are an icon on Hong Kong Island. Travelling upstairs allows an excellent view of the island business district. They are efficient and run frequently but are often crowded at peak times. The cost is very cheap as you only pay when leaving the tram so a long distance costs the same as a short one. For people who are tall (6 foot or taller), be aware that the ceiling in the tram is relatively low and you need to be aware of the reinforcing structures across the tram. People willingly give up their seats to very tall people or those with small children, the elderly or disabled. It is well worth a trip from Kennedy Town to Happy Valley.
Hidden gem. Maybe its not hidden - had so much fun riding this. Pretty easy to figure out how to board and pay - try to get a seat up front.

Good way to see Northern of Hong Kong Island. Trams take You all around of northern HK island very cheaply. If You are interested in different areas then it's a good way to see them. It is very much slower than MTR but when it's a rainy day then it's more fun than MTR.

Nice way to see the city. After reading on this trams, we decided to give it a try. We managed to get to the front seat in the upper deck and could really enjoy seeing what is going on in the city. The windows were open and so we had some breeze helping us to cool down.A ride cost 2.30 HKD.
