Make sure you have the correct amount or an octopus card.It's really a pleasant journey to do, when you have some time and want to see some parts of the city.
beats the traffic almost any time. easy on and off, when you leave you will go through the front door and pay a flat amount when you leave (do take small coins to move and not block other people)
An enjoyable 1 hour of sightseeing on double tram. Go with a friend, family member, or find a local to enjoy this experience. Pick up the tram anywhere in downtown. or whereever. Get off close to MTR

Cheap and effective way to get through Hong Kong traffic.. A lot of the streets are one way and Hong Kong traffic jams can be quite heavy at peak hours. The trams can go where cars cannot and are really useful . The 2.6 HKD fare is absurdly cheap and I loved the colorful trams. The seats are not always very comfortable , some just plain wooden benches, but it was good enough to get around.

Ding Ding is fun and easy way to get around. Buy a visitor Octopus card ($39HKD/$5US) at any 7-11 and load money on it. You can use the Octopus card to pay at stores, ride the Star Ferry, ride the trains(MTR) and the trams (Ding Ding) without having to worry about exact change and you get a discount on the MTR. Also, download the pdf of the tram routes(east & west) to your phone. The older trams do not announce the next stop and don't have any indication of the upcoming stop. I would suggest that since they come so often wait for a newer tram so you don't miss your stop. The trams say on the front and back where they are going. I got on the Western Market tram because it was going in the correct direction but it makes a u-turn at the market and starts in the other direction. So look at the routes you downloaded because there are a few weird ones. Also, the east and west have different stops sometimes. You get on at the back and don't pay anything till you get off. You are supposed to migrate to the front of the tram as your stop approaches so you are ready to tap your octopus card on scanner as you get off. Your balance will be displayed as you do. It's one price per ride regardless of how many stops you stay on for. It's only $2.30HKD (30 US cents). I rode it for over an hour one day after I arrived to sight see and I recognized a lot of places I researched and wanted to go.

Nice ride!. I had much fun in taking the tram while in Hong Kong! Was an experience sitting in these trams. They are old, but the experience doesn't seem to give that impression at all. Will definitely try it again. It's also cheaper than taking MTR too.

A good way to. The trams are slow and it is a good thing - as you can experience the views much better. Do note that you need to find out where exactly are the stations to board and alight. You board on the rear and exit at the front. You tap your Octopus card as you exit.

Great experience for the kids. its super affordable. If I remember correctly its HKD2.50 for adults and HKD1.00 for kid per trip regardless of distance. enjoyed the slow ride to see the buildings from their neighbourhood area to cbd area.

Great way to get to somewhere or to no where. We decided to just go for a ride on the tramway and all we did was decided that we would catch a tram going to Happy Valley and get off when it looked interesting. We waited to a tram came along which did not look to crowded and we got on and went up stairs and sat down. It was fascinating how narrow the trams are. We saw some great sights on the 20 minute tram ride. As we were going along we saw some markets down a side street so we got off to have a look. It was the Bowrington Street Markets and they were so fascinating and we spent over an hour just walking around with the ordinary people of Hong Kong looking at the peoples markets. There was nearly everything that you would want in this market which ran for probably four streets. Better than the Central Markets. Getting back was the same process waited til a tram came along that we thought we could get on and get a seat upstairs. By the time we went to get off in Central Hong Kong the tram was crowded and it took a bit of effort to get off and down the stairs. It was well worth the ride on the tram. Last time in Hong Kong I was lucky enough to have a ride on an open top one. Did not see them this time. Make sure you have your Octopus Pass as it makes transport so easy.

Hong Kong in nut shell. Should take a ride on this and u can see the life style of HK from all aspects.The views of small busy streets to all the busy banks and the other financial institutions.You can also catch a glimpse of the street food .
Best way accross Central. Ding Ding is such a nice, slow and comfortable way to cross crazy busy Central (except at rush hour when the tram is jam packed!)

Nice, cheap, convenient way through the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong. Hong Kong tram runs back and forth Central and Happy Valley of Hong Kong, through Causeway Bay which is the busiest shopping area. It's a fun and fast way to see the city, especially when there's traffic. Just hop on and off as wished although you need to pay individual trip.

Inexpensive and fun transport in Hong Kong. Very inexpensive transport. Cheapest in Hong Kong. It costs about 25 cents (US) per ride for one stop or the entire run from one end of the island to the other. Its also good for sight seeing. But its almost always packed, so avoid rush hour or lunch hours.

Cheap and fun way of getting around. Cool experience - very cheap and a fun way of getting around.Not as quick as the MTR but very exciting nonetheless.Can get a bit crowded but just gotta deal with it.

A Slow Ride through the City. The Tram is worth a try just to experience another side of Hong Kong life, make sure you have time to spare as it is very slow but worth the experience. You can use your Octopus card on the Tram and there are plenty of stops to get on and off throughout the City

Avoid during Rush Hours. The Ding Ding tram is a popular (and cheap) form of local transportation, so popular that it is best to avoid it during rush hours (7.30am to 9.30am and 5pm to 7pm weekdays). Otherwise be prepared to be squashed like sardines.As the tram station is just outside our hostel, we took the tram many times during our 10-day stay in Hong Kong. One of our best rides started from Happy Valley Terminal to Sheung Wan. Select the tram you wish to take (one goes West, and another goes East), then board at the rear and exit with your Octopus card at the front of the tram. As we boarded at the terminal, we could pick our seats on the upper deck (front seats are the best). I'm not sure if it's just our luck, but we found the tram operators one of the most sullen people I've met in Hong Kong. (Most folks we meet elsewhere were friendly, or at least, professional in handling enquiries.) But try asking the tram operator for assurance that the tram you have boarded is headed to your destination, and you will be greeted with a glare. No answers given.

It's slow. A very convenient way of transportation, from one point to another, on HK island from East to West and vice versa. Save lots of walking compared to the ups and downs in the MTR station.But it is slow, took more than an hour from Central for us to reach Tin Hau. One or two journey on the tram is good enough.
Wonderful and cheap ride. Just enjoy a relaxing ride through hong kong for such low cost that it's just worth while. Takes a lot longer than the mtr but then it costs hardly anything.

Put this on your list of Must Do's. This is one of the must-do's when in Hong Kong. it costs $HK2.20, which translates to $AUDbuggerall, and gives you a slightly elevated view of Hong Kong Island. It runs all the way from Kennedy Town to just past Quarry Bay. The odd thing is, even though it is not air-conditioned, and the seats are uncomfortable, it is still one of the best ways to get around (and still would be so if it was the same price as the MTR). When I lived there I would take it at least once a day when commuting to and from work. Don't ask me why it is so good - it just needs to be experienced, just like you cant explain why chocolate tastes good. It just does.
Great experience. Ding dings are definitely worth one ride for the experience alone. Not exactly speedy but they do have some handy routes on Hong Kong island and it is inexpensive.

Our own private Ding Ding!. Private 2-hour tram ride through the streets of Hong Kong. It is a fun ride, enjoying the sights from the upper deck of the red vintage car. It made one stop at the turnaround point, where we took a few minutes to visit the restroom. No lollygagging, as it holds up other trams behind it!

Fun way to see Hong Kong!!. The Ding Dings are a great way to see Hong Kong Island. I like that they are old and rickety. If I wanted new and smooth, I'd take the bus! Very cheap to use (I used my Oyster card), and it has many routes. I took it from The Central area and got off at Percival Street to visit Times Square!!

Another Must Do activity.. Just because it is a part of Hong Kong history, and who knows how long it will still be there?Clanky and noisy. Cheap, easy and fun. You can see the whole length of Hong Kong island for a flat fare. Get to places you might not otherwise see. Markets, the "real" Hong Kong, not jus the tourist sites.

Great way to see the city. Fantastic way to see the streets of Hong Kong Island. Only $2.30HK no matter how far you go, pay went you disembark. Catch the tram from stations in the middle of the street. Try and get a seat up top for best view.

Economic way to experience HK day/night scene. Tram has it's long history in HK. It runs across the north part of HK Island. Recommend you take a seat on the upper deck to enjoy the sight seeing. Night time view is spectaclar with the LED decor lighting of buildings. It only costs HK$2.3 per adult! If you are interested in group party, consider a tram party for 2 hours or more. It's definitely a unique experience and fun!

Dated, tight for space but full of pleasure. The Hong Kong trams are tiny and busy but they have character and draw in the attention of those on board. I love hopping on and off these shopping trolleys on acid.
a great way to entertain the kids. my little ones had fun riding the tram from one end to the other. It offered a great opportunity to see Hong kong and it's SO affordable!

Nostalgic tram ride if you are not in a hurry. Cheap tram ride through the island. Can take in the sights and sounds along the route. Good for those who are not in a hurry. Several routes available. Entrance at the back and exit from the front. Pay your fares when exiting the tram.
Fun. The trams are a cute and fun way to get around. Just make sure you have exact cash as there is no way of getting change.

A leisurely, cheapest way to see hong kong. I have always loved the tramway as it is one of the cheapest and most enjoyable ride to see Hong Kong. If U sit at the upper deck, there are plenty of opportunities to take great photos.Will never tired of it. To me it is also very environmental friendly.
A cheap way to get around Hong Kong. A great way to get about Hong Kong, it is really cheap i paid around HK$2.3 to use the service. It's a nice experience, a must do during your visit to Hong Kong.

Fun Tour around Hong Kong by Tram/Ding Ding. Taking the Tramway or 'Ding Ding' (as the locals call it) felt like I was on a tour bus as the tram passed by many interesting streets in Hong Kong. Sit on the upper deck in the front few rows of the tram if you can for better views. Costs HK$2.30 per ride and you can use your Octopus card. Board from the back & pay/tap your Octopus card only when you alight in the front near the driver. It's natural fresh air with windows down inside the tram (no air-con). We boarded at the tram stop facing Sogo at Causeway Bay. Took Tram number 7 heading to 'Shek Tong Tsui'. We wanted to go to Central to take the Mid-Levels Escalator. Not too sure which tram we could take so we asked the locals at the tram stop. It was quite a slow ride but we were not in any hurry and happily took in the sights at the upper deck of the Tram. The Ding Ding #7 passed by Causeway Bay, Wan Chai (Wan Chai market), Admiralty and alighted at Central to head to the mid-levels escalator and then to Lan Kwai Fong. It's a fun & inexpensive way to see Hong Kong. Go try it! Note : Take the MTR if you're in a hurry. The tram's speed can be too slow if you're rushing somewhere.

Charming way to travel. The Ding Ding stop was just 5 minutes walk away from the hotel we stayed in Sheung Wan. Prior to hopping onto a Ding Ding, we would ask the driver if it would take us to our destination. They were all helpful and we had no problems at all using the Ding Dings.It's also a way to sight see as the trams move on the roads slowly. Best to get front seats upstairs. Do be careful when you are coming down. The trams may jerk rather strongly, usually when they are stopping.You enter from the back, and alight from the front where the driver is and pay at that point.

Another inexpensive way to tour Hong Kong. Another highly recommended inexpensive way to tour Hong Kong. It costs about HK$2 for a ride. You get to intermingle with the local people, and enjoy the scenic view along the route of the tram. Upper deck has better view if there are seats available. My family and I went to the main station in North Point to start our sightseeing ride. The reason we picked the main station at North Point was that there were plenty of seats available. By the way, the name Ding Ding is derived from the sound of the bell the tram driver uses to warn pedestrian crossing the tram rail.

slow but sure. It'll get you from one end of the main area of HK to the other but note it takes a while but a different way to get where you are going. Ride the upper deck if you have a way to go. It's an interesting perspective of the streets of HK. Try going one end to other if you have the time
Has to be done. Nice experience a most during your visit. Strange is you get in the back and pay when you get off in the front.
Cute & Unique to Hong Kong! . These cute little trams are unique & I loved them. They are smooth & handy. They remind me of Mr Bean- don't know why but they do. Hope on for the fun of it.
Worth going out of your way to figure it out once or twice. Do it. Figure out which way you're going to go and get on the right ding ding.You already have an Octopus card anyways right? So hop on!

Basic but great value for money. We took the tram to Shu Kei Wan, got off an explored a local market used by local Hong Kong people, which was fascinating.We journeyed from Shu Kei Wan along the line as far as the Western Market, which took about an hour, with lots to see on route.The trams were very cheap and you get off at a stop to explore and pick up another tram as they passed regularly. The adult fare is HK$2.30 regardless of distance travelled.I'd suggest an upper deck front row seat for the best view and photo opportunities. Bear in mind the trams are basic but functional.

cheap way to commute in the island. Add thrills to your trip. I prefer ding ding tramways as you get to see more of the city, minus the long walk to the mrt station and train platform, I find mrt station can be a distance from stop to stop... or it is just me... ^^

Great fun ride. Its good, convenient and fast way to cover short distance with good frequency. We just used for very short distance to avoid Walking to go to nearby place from our hotelv after a long tiring day. Its quite cheap too. Do use octopus card for the same. Its so convenient way of travelling. Octopus a superb utility card.

This is a ride in HK's history. Great sight seeing ride if you get a good seat on the upper deck.These trams were saved from 'extinction' and provide good inexpensive transportation.We rode it to the race tracks at Happy Valley.
Great experience. I took the tram ride for fun. Well, it was fun traveling along the busy road of Hong Kong. Good way for people watching and taking some random shots of HK. Sit at the upper deck.

Reliving my Childhood. We traveled to Happy Valley Racecourse on the tram and it was great. Brought back lots of memories of our childhood in Glasgow. No matter how far you travel it is one fare 2$ and yes use the octopus card so much easier.

Love travelling by Tram!. This is my favourite mode of transport, as if you sit on the top deck you can see so much of life on Hong Kong Island. It isn't the quickest mode of transport and it only covers the north coast of the island and Happy Valley, but it is cheap HK$2.3 (for any distance) and great for sightseeing. Worth sitting on and enjoying the journey from 1 end to the other, if you have an hour or so to spare.

A must on any visit to Hong Kong. I always take at least a couple of journeys on the tram. It is very cheap and travels at a speed that let's you see HK in detail. It is the most reliable way to travel into Central above ground given the heavy traffic that prevails during the day. Goes to central from Taikoo Shing, North Point and Wanchai and even Happy Valley -and of course back again. A unique experience in Hong Kong - history and value for money.

Combine it with tram.... Must admit that taxis are cheap and transportation overall in HK is pretty convenient and inexpensive... But really if you combine Trams and MTR you've go the best of all world... even able to enjoy the city from the upper deck...Don't forget your Octopus!
Heritage Transport. Convenient way to travel in northern Hong Kong. Interesting and feel like relaxed traveling. Fare is very less. Allows Octopus Card for payment. To be experienced.
Old School Experience. It is a must to try the ride in the tram. Payable by the Octopus card. Moving slowly in the mids of the busy city, the ride left us with kind of nostalgic feeling.

Cute buses but slow!. If you are visiting Hong Kong for the first time, take the opportunity to hop on one of these cute, narrow trams (ding dings - the sound of the tram bell). If you have public transportation card (Octopus), you pay as you leave the bus (door at the front). They are slow but nice to take in the view especially downtown in the Central shopping district.

Great way to get around, Buy an Octopus Card for the best deal. The Tram was fun and interesting, it was a nice way to travel.We bought an Octopus card which is valid on all forms of MTR transport, including the harbour boats and ferries.It is very cheap and any money left on it will be refunded at the airport.All the transport options we tried were very good and on time!

A cool way to fell the city. They move slower than the busses, but if you get a second floor seat and in the front you get a very good panoramic of the Hong Kong Streets.You can pay with your Octopus card.

Fun way to see Hong Kong. The two level trams, with the different advertisements painted on the exteriors offer great views of the areas that line the north shore of Hong Kong Island. They seem a charming relic of the old Hong Kong. In warm weather, keep in mind that the bus is air conditioned, the trams aren't. Seating may not be that comfortable, and the climb to the second level tricky, butno matter what the drawbacks, the trams are fun. They are boarded along islands in the middle of busy streets, boarded at the rear. Octopus cards are a good idea for fares.Trams do get crowded at times, but they run frequently. Be aware that some terminate at Happy Valley, and don't serve areas east of Causewat Bay. For visitors from the States, keep in mind thatyou may have to think for a second to make sure the tram you're going heads to the direction you want. Traffic keeps to the left here.

Cheap tourist attraction. Even if you don't need to catch one, it's super cheap and they accept the Octopus cards. Get on from the rear and scan to pay as you get off at the front.Use the top deck for a view of Hong Kong island that you will not achieve in a cheaper way.

A journey back in time. In my opinion is an experience not to miss while in Hong Kong. Hop on it from Central and enjoy the ride all the way to Causeway, possibly on the front row of the upper floor. You will enjoy the frenetic city life from a machinery from the last century. A blast!

Unique trams. These trams are great for getting from one end of HK island to the other and we used them twice. Sitting on the top floor you have a good view of all the modern highrises. The cars are lovely to watch as well with their gaudy displays of advertising.

A must when in Hong kong. You really cannot visit the island and not ride the ting ting! At $2.30 it's a bargain! So easy to get from one end of the island to the other and a great change from the mtr
Cheapest way to see some real Hong Kong. The Hong Kong trams are a delightful relic of a past era and worth a ride. Make sure you have change to pay on exit. Charming!

An attraction not to be missed. We took the tram just for experience wise and I must say it was worthwhile. The tram traverse across Hong Kong Island and is a very convenient mode of transport. It definitely beats the jam. The tram is however very small but double deck so best to avoid peak hours. You enter from the back and exit at the front. You only pay when you exit and the fee is fixed no matter where you board and alight.
Ding Ding. I simply love to go on that trams, so old fashioned and relaxing. Could go all day!I hope thy will be working for much longerCheapest sight seeing!
Evening rite by Hong Kong Tram. We toke a few times from the hotel the Hong Kong Dubbeldekker tram, special in the evening when the straat lights are on it is nice to travel different trams.
Voom. Love the ding ding. A bit slow, but outside of rush hour it's a very pleasant trip around town. Cheap as the dickens
Do it once while in HK. Not the fastest way to get around but definitely a historic piece of the city. Very rustic and not many comforts.

DING DING name is enough - add to the charm. Ding Ding add to the charm of Hong Kong . We took Ding Ding in Cause way bay area .. Its actually fun and its not at all expensive.. Must take it , when you are in Hong Kong!

Relaxing. Just hop on the tram and sit back and watch Hong Kong life from the tram.
Go during the day to see the sights and in the evening when all the neon is on.
Must be the best value ride anywhere in the world
A blast from the past. Such a charming way around Hong Kong island, go above ground and get on a trip for a memorable experience.

Cheap and Interesting - but often crowded.. It's a great way to see the city, but it can be very crowded at rush hour, and it's not usually the fastest way of getting places. However, if you value getting the chance to see the neighborhood then it's definitely the way to go!

Cheap and cheerful!. You have to jump on a ding ding and hopefully be able to grab a seat upstairs if only just as a nice quick tour of Hong Kong and to get the breeze on your face for a cool down. It's a cheap way to get around parts of Hong Kong, is heaps of fun and very efficient!

A TRIP BACK IN TIME. One of the best things you can do is ride on a Ding Ding, they are fun cheap and if you ride in the top deck you get a birds eye view of life in Hong Kong, at the crowds of people the traffic and see the constant battle of merchants pushing their little carts dodging cars trucks buses & people
you have to ride the trams. Its the cheapest sightseeing possible. $2.20 to travel the length of the tramways...stop off at Western market for fantastic silks and fabrics.
Good to try. It is a cheap way of transportion. A bit slower but still fun to try. I believe the fare is fixed irrespective of distance.

Easy way to see HK island. Tram is a cheap and cool means of transport here. It goes alongside the island and you can see how diverse Hong Kong is. With open windows seating on the 2nd deck one can enjoy Hong Kong tour nearly free of charge.

Great way to see Hong Kong. This is a Great way to explore Hong Kong. It's cheap and you pay when go get off either with cash or with Octopus card. The coaches has been upgraded during the last years. Jump on and sit upstairs. Notice the difference between the areas in HK. Don't be afraid you won't get lost just ENJOY.

Great way to explore the city!. This is an idea way to see the city. Just jump on and travel as far as you want for $2.30 HKD and you are taken back in time to a part of Hong Kong's past. At least try it once, sure it may be a little packed down near the busy areas but its part of the Hong Kong experience!

Double-decker trams. Very cheap public transport.
Each journey cost 2,3 HKD no matter how far you travel.
Trams operate only on Hong Kong island.

Fun. Unlike taking the underground MTR. Trams are an old fashioned way to travel and you get to see where you're travelling to. Also its easy to get in and hop off when you spot an interesting place to end your ride

HK$2.2 per trip. Cheapest traffic means in Hong Kong and offers you views in the core of Hong Kong Island. You can find from the Hong Kong Tourism Board's web-sites to visit some good and traditional restaurants along the tramways.
a very nice experience. you get to experience the new honk Kong from the look of the tram outside. And toehold HK from the inside of the train. it much cheaper than taking the hoop on hop off bus
Great way to get about.. We took the tram from Happy Valley to Chai Wan on a daily basis to catch the MTR. The trams are very frequent, super cheap and really easy to understand.

The best way to get around HK Island. Yeah the subway is faster, but there are few experiences like riding on the Ding Ding. Try to grab one of the seat on the second level of the car in the front way, and sit back and take in the sights. Only 2-3 HKD to ride, its the cheapest and most unique way to see the city.
Two bucks. If you go to the hong a kong Island make sure you try the Tramway. It is only two HK dollars.myou will experience the 60's of HK transpiration and get to see the island for

Delightful way to travel. A nice experience and very easy to use. Hop on and hop off at your desire. You can use your Octopus card or pay with coins (make sure you have exact change – $2.30 HK I recall). If you don't have exact money, don't bother the driver, just drop what you have into the receptacle, it doesn't matter. Just make sure it is more than what is required.
Overcrowded. Very popular but in my opinion not worth going on unless you get a seat as you can't see where you are going.
Just do t. A really cheap (HKD 2.30) to see Hong Kong at a slow pace. Get yourself to the top deck, at the front and watch this chaotic city move. Keeps you busy for hours.

Good both for tourists and locals. Boarding a 'Ding Ding' tram and touring Hong Kong Island is a must for most visitors. It costs HK$2.30 and is considered the cheapest, and yet the most fascinating, trip in a public traffic in Hong Kong. It runs on a rail with no blockage by other vehicles. I had the experience of boarding instead a bus from the Western District to North Point, and the whole journey including traffic congestion took nearly 2 hours! The next time I switched to this 'ding ding' tram. It took only less than an hour. There is a new type of 'ding ding' tram now, a bit different in the interior with the seats and more fashionable. But they may not be called 'ding ding' tram anymore as they do not give a ding ding sound as a warning for pedestrians or vehicles. They sound like an ordinary car!

Excellent. They may be old and slow but these wonderful trams are a great way to travel across Hong Kong Island. If you can manage to get the front seats upstairs you can see all of the life of this amazing City as the trams trundle along the main road from one end of the island to the other. The are also unbelievably cheap, about 20p ( in English money!) per journey, however far you travel. For short journeys they are a lot more convenient than the MTR. By the time you have gone down to the platforms and back up again along numerous tunnels and escalators, you can be on a tram and at your destination. They are very well used by locals and tourists alike. A must do in Hong Kong.

Great way to see Hong Kong Island. I got the MTR to Kennedy and then got an upstairs front seat and had a couple of hours ride through HK! Amazing to see the sights sounds (and smells) through the open windows. Great photo opportunities everywhere.

GREAT WAY TO EXPERIENCE HONG KONG. Hong Kong's Ding Ding Trams are a cheap and easy way to get around the city. I was amazed at how colourful they were. We were lucky enough to get a front row seat on the top deck, what an experience. You enter from the back of the tram and exit at the front swiping your Octopus Card as you leave.

Discover HK. Two-floor tram is cool, especially for those who haven't yet decided of where to go in HK. With Octopus card you can take any tram and simply enjoy the city with its mix of modern tall buildings and comparably small old ones. On such a trip we noticed some places to visit.
Old fashioned pleasant way to travel . Cheap and fun way to travel around Hong Kong island - a great and efficient way to see the sights with a bit of nostalgia thrown in.

A MUST when in Hong Kong. A ride with the Ding Ding is a MUST when in Hong Kong. Not only is it a very cheap and convenient way to travel "down town" but also a great way to gaze at people and their shopping behavior. Needless to say that you get great views of various monument buildings as well.

Avoid the rush hour, so you can get upper deck seats ;). I would say avoid taking the tram if it is the rush hour, or from busy stops if you wish to get some seats. Queue at the tram stop in an orderly manner and when the tram arrives, you will board from the back. Payment is made before alighting, so don't worry about the octopus card when boarding. If you have an opportunity to take the upper deck seats, you can enjoy the breeze while the tram brings you around HK island. No A/C but I think it would be very cooling during the end Oct-Dec period ;)

Cheap and fun way to get around . These trams offer a great way to see Hong Kong. They run frequently, often back to back. They are included on the Octopus card or you can pay with cash as you exit the tram. At HK$2.3 (about 30 cents US) set price they are a great deal, make sure to have the right money when you get on as no change is given. Used by locals they get very crowded during rush hour but it is easy to get a seat upstairs if you avoid these busy times. If a lot of people get on at your stop just wait for the one behind if you want to sit at the front.

Slow & enjoyable and runs through many districts. Took the westbound train (each tram stop has a sign indicating east or westbound) to the Western Market. Initially wanted to head to Kennedy town but because I was far east, the frequency of the train was 2 trains per hour). There are several routes of the tram, although heading in the same direction, can have different end stops e.g. Race track, Western Market, Kennedy Town etc. Get on from the back and head to the upper deck (front if you are lucky) and enjoy the sights as the tram slowly moves along the road. When you alight from the front, tap with your Octopus. Go during non-peak hours otherwise you will probably have to stand as there are very few seats.

Famous Ding Ding. Able to experience this during Hong Kong trip last month after hearing about Ding Ding in Hong Kong Drama. We travelled from the terminal at Shau Kei Wan to Tin Hau as the stations are conveniently located along Island Line. You could continue the trip to Causeway Bay if you wish.

The busiest Ding Ding. Another must try in HK.
the Ding Ding takes you from one place to another slowly giving you the time to enjoy the view of HK in many ways. Observe the buildings, roads, traffic, peoples, culture of different decades.

first thing we do-nice and slow so you can see the world. always ride to Shau kei wan on our first day in HK just to get the feel back of the city-nothing better sitting up top clattering along- make sure you have an octopus card and mind your head if you are over 6 foot---rush hour can be fun --the question is how many people can you fit on a tram to causeway bay on a sunday afternoon

Very economical way to see Hong Kong island. The tram travels all the way from east end of the Hong Kong Island to the west end with one single fare.You can see the daily activities of the people from your seat on the upper deck.

A leisure way to watch the world go by in Hong Kong Island.. If time is no factor, this is the cheapest (HK$2.20 = US 30 cents; half for seniors) and easiest way to see the city strip and life along the northern side of the island of Hong Kong (plus the horse-racing and sports fields if you take the Happy Valley detour). Try to get a seat on the upper deck (no standing). Alternative is to take the tourist open upper deck tram that runs on the same tracks at a much higher price.
A taste of old HK. A tram ride is definitely a must in HK. Take the seats on the upper deck to catch the view of the city. A taste of the old Hong Kong's transportation.

Inexpensive and leisure way of sightseeing. Considered cheap mode of transport.. unique way of doing sightseeing of the city especially if u sit on upper deck. However seats are limited though it is double decker so do take it during non peak hours for comfort. Non airconditioned hence may be hot if it is sunny. Overall a good experience to hop on the tram.
Easy To Navigate. First timers to Hong Kong we grabbed a map and away we went. Very easy system to use and very cheap.

We love the ding dings!. Very strange looking trams that are awesome. Costs about 2 dollar per journey and you can use octopus card. Great way to see HK. They go pretty much the span of the islands main road at the north.

A wonderful experience from the time of old Hong Kong. The trams run in the lower streets of the Central business district affording one to ride a piece of history dating to the turn of 1900.Here they allow a perfect opportunity for priceless photography appearing in many bright colors and run throughout the day,not to be missed
A must. Not only really handy but great fun to jump on and off. It is so cheap to use and full of locals. Must do
Slow but vintage experience. If you are not in a hurry, it is a must do in HK. Travel from west to east of Hong Kong island. Cheapest way to tour in Hong Kong.

Fun. If you are up for an adventure, get on and off the tram all over the city. My kids loved it and even when you have to be alert at all times because it comes and goes so fast, we had a great experience.

Great trams. We took the trams all over Hong Kong fast and easy way to travel and you can see a lot of daily life as you travel. We alighted at a crazy local market on the east side of the island which was fun with lots of local produce and interesting people to barter with as you tried local foods.

Fun and frivolous way to travel.. Using your Octopus Card jump on and jump off whenever you like. It only costs S$2.30, that's under AUD 50 cents. Sit up stairs, be prepared to be crushed, they are very popular. Rattling along, at about 20kmh blasting the air horn. Good fun.
Simple & quiCk transportation. Simple way to travel along the main road of hong kong.a bit pack n busy during the weekdays but u can still enjoy the ride

Best transport on HK island. With $2.30 per ride, nothing is going to beat this icon on the island. It is the best to take a ride at night to feel the breeze and life in HK. Very easy to catch and you don't have to walk miles underground with MTR.

Only Double Decker Tram In The World. Took the tram from Central to Causeway Bay for the novelty. Very cheap for a tourist attraction filled with tourists and natives alike. It isnt the most speediest of transport in Hong Kong but sometimes it is nice just to get away from the hustle and bustle.
Great transport alternative. Great way to get around to the less inaccessible parts of HK not covered by the metro. Costs HKD2.8 per ride.

A Quintessential Hong Kong Activity. I love taking the tram while in Hong Kong. To me this is just one of those activities that is so uniquely Hong Kong. It is the bustle of the city, up close and personal. A very inexpensive little treat to remind you that you are in a great city.
Do yourself a favor, take a tram ride.

Great way to check out HK ... Cheap Too!. Love the trams in Hong Kong. A great way to orientate yourself when you first get there. Catch the tram that runs east (Chai Wan) & west (Western Markets) ... its a fabulous way to get a feel for whats around. Chai Wan has a fabulous wet market where you can get some great cheap seafood. Its also where you can access the Dragons Back walking trail. All for HK$2.30!!

Enjoy scenery of Hong Kong. Took the tram from West of Hong Kong to Central district. Cost only HKD2.30 for adult and HKD1.20 for child (single trip). You may also use the Octopus card to pay for the fare. Sat on the top of the tram. Cooling and windy in the evening. Great and comfortable ride!

Tram Ride. Being a Melbournian trams are part of our culture so we had to try these. Great old thins that the locals call Ding Dings. good way to see HK Island, cheap and easy to access a step place.Must climb up to the top deck, well worth the view.

Once Threatened To Extinction, The Electronic Murmur of These Trams Is Hong Kong Lifeblood. Just watching these trams go by in the morning, pushing through the throngs of rush hour traffic, is an experience taking you back to 1950s Hong Kong. So important is the use of the tram, and its appearance every day, that Hong Kong people don't call Queen's Road Central or Queen's Road East by those names. They will often call the street, The Tram Street. It seems they have been there that long, and should always be.Lately, though, their existence is in doubt, as a developer and some contractors have recently floated the idea of eliminating them altogether to make traffic and pedestrian egress and ingress easier. It's a crock. Somebody wants to build more buildings, straighten out roads, and take over property. The Trams are special. They move along with an electronic murmur and in your lazier tranquil moments during the hectic Hong Kong day, you can listen to them and take in all the sights by sitting on the top, for just a few pennies! And transport yourself back to a time when "coolies" walked around pulling rickshaws, and British businessmen smoked Chesterfields on the street corner as they read the Standard.
nice experience. good idea if you want to take nice photos of hong kong. Tickets are very cheap and you can use octopus card or cash ( adequate amount of money is required)
fun experience. Ding-ding bus was a two-floor bus with hard wooden seats, no air condition but very cool because all the windows were open.

Nostalgia... . Our visit to hk was very much influenced by the tvb shows we used to watch when we were young in msia. And this provided many memories of yesteryear. Great experience. Only issue was when we didn't know where the team ended it's journey and we're told rather rudely by the driver to depart.
Nice travel system. Used the same to go around places near victoria peak. Octopus Card works on this as well and it provides a nice view. It runs in one of the territories of HK only,
Great!. The Hong Kong Tram is a great way to see the city and to get around easily. It's also perfect for orienting yourself with the area and getting some great photos from the top level!
a must try in HK island. A cheap mode of transport in HK island, only if you are not rushing for time.It can be quite crowded during peak hours

Just a part of the Hong Kong experience. OK, so the tram itself isn't amazing or a must see; but, it's a fun experience, more comfortable than walking on hot days, and a way to experience a classic part of Hong Kong transport.
:-). Name comes from its warning voice(ding ding) :-). Its fast and you enjoy it but its limited and not contents to large line. You dont need tongo somewhere . Just for fun take it.
Some old tradition. Though it move slow, Tram is still a major transportation in HK Island. They have a tram tour for tourist, so that you can get the ride and avoid the crowd.

Historical yet useful. The trams are history on wheels. The trams' interior are old and have a circa 1950s vibe. Not only is it historical gem, it's also a useful form of transportation to traverse Hong Kong Island.
The scenery along the routes are interesting and the ride itself is cheap - a flat fare of HKD 2.60 is charged per journey.

The unique transport in Hong Kong. Ding Ding is the oldest public transport in Hong Kong, it is cheap and convenient to travel within Hong Kong Island.If you start from North Point all the way to Sai Wan, you can have a quick look of the history of Hong Kong. From the old Hong Kong like Sai Wan, to a world business centre like Central, and the local life of Hong Konger in North Point.

Take a place on the roof and enjoy the city. You can jump into the tram and see the big part of the city centre. The old trams are totally diffrent than the other public transport which are quaite new, but those trams are kind of symbolic for HK.
So cool!. Everyone visiting Hong Kong should ride these double-deck trams. For 0,30 USD per ride you can explore the whole coast at Victoria Harbor.

Best way to relax in Hong Kong. When I got on a Ding ding, I went straight to the upper deck where I could enjoy the view of the streets so closely, it was really a nice ride. The tram went very slowly, with the fresh wind blew in from the windows, it's a feeling which you could not find from the other kinds of vehicle in summer in Hong Kong.

Great transport system or just ride for fun. We took a tram across town just for the fun of it - found ourselves in a market for locals at the terminus rather than the usual tourist markets..... Very efficient method of transport!

Ding Ding, Cheap Cheap!. Great experience on the double decker tram (trolley, streetcar). A great way to see real character of various neighbourhoods on Hong Kong island - Causeway Bay, Wan Chai, Central, etc. It costs a flat fee to ride regardless how far you travel $2.30 HKD. Yes, that's right $2.30 HKD! From end to end, it is about 13 km. We rode a good part of the line, from North Point to near Kennedytown. Enter the tram from the back door, best to go up the narrow staircase and try to get a seat on the upper level. When you leave, go down the narrow staircase located at the front of the tram. Swipe your Octopus card or pay cash on your way out. A "must-do" for tourists!

Fun to do with kids. When you visit Hong Kong this is a must do, especially if you have kids.
These small duoble decker trams are cheap and take you all along the Hong Kong Island northern coastline.

oldest transportation in hongkong island. You must try to ride this Trams when you visit to Hongkong.It is fun and fare is very cheap you can ride through along main Road at Hongkong island.You can always hear sound "Ding Ding ,Ding Ding.

Quaint tram ride.. We really enjoyed our ride on the Ding Dings. We got on at Shau Kei Wah, rode to Happy Valley where we alighted and then caught another to Kennedy town. Thus we travelled the whole route and all for $1.10 each per leg (seniors rate). Sitting up the top of these old work horses, you really get a different perspective of the streets and with their frequent stops, have to time to soak up the atmosphere. It will be a shame if they are taken out of service as rumoured. Tip We took our ride on a Monday at lunchtime in November.... no crowds.
The old amidst the new... These tramways have been here for decades but run as efficiently as how you would expect every transport system in Hong Kong to.

Always a Hong Kong experience worth trying!. The (thin) but incredibly frequent trams are a great way to experience Hong Kong for the first-time or infrequent traveller. Get a seat upstairs at or near the front and you have a bird's eye view of everyday HK life and shops. Cheaper even than the MTR, what is there not to like? Perhaps best avoided at peak times unless you are happy to act like a local and become a sardine!!
Fun to do. We used the tram only once as our time was limited.Very cheap and good fun.Can be a bit confusing if you want to get off at a certain stop.Worth doing for the experience.

Convenient. Good way to travel but limited routes. Can hop on and off quite easily and not too much of a wait. Can be fun to ride from one end of Hong Kong to the other and sit on the top level just people watching and sight seeing.

Another must before it goes away.. Best way to see the city by taking the tram from one end to the other on the second level of the double-decker. Many rumors say this is another Hong Kong treasure that will go away soon.

Good experience. Good way to see the real HK besides walking. Best view from top level - but mind the steep steps up and down. Honestly was never on my agenda to get around, but kid enjoyed the experience.

Ding, ding , ding went the trolley. i wanted to experience the Hong Kong Ding Ding....it is a great old fashioned yet modern feeling transportation on Hong Kong Island. I grabbed one at the IFC and took it down to the area of the Western Market. you can use the Hong Kong Octopus card which is used on all the public transport...or I'm sure you can use cash...it was a lot of fun riding down the middle of HK in the central area..do it....great fun

Feel the pace of the city. That tram is an icon, an amazing double-deck tramcar. It is the best (and the cheapest) solution to have a nice first overview of the city. Just hop on the tram, go to the upper deck, open the window and enjoy the show. I really love this tram and kids too!

Hong Kongs Ding Ding Tram. Their is a popular opinion voiced on here and various other travel sites, suggesting that the dng ding tram which operates along the North side of Hong Kong is something is not to missed.In the course of my long life I have endured the sheer misery of sitting on London M25 motorway during Friday eveningrush hour. I have sat quietly fuming in the back of a New York taxi attempting to get from JFK to my hotel on the upper West Side. I have even attempted to pilot a rental car through Romes tortuous streets, made all the more tortuous by the sdriving style of crazy Romans. However, if any country has devised a more uncomfortable way of getting from place A to place B, than the ding ding tram., I have yet to expoerience it. This item of vehicular torture belongs in a Chamber of Horrors.Actually getting on the tram can be a problem. The bording stations are not on the side of the road. They happen to be in the middle of the road, so you may have to cross a couple of lanes of fraffic just to get to board the thingFirst on the list of miseries is that when you get on to the blooming thing, if you are a male you are likely to be whacked in a rather tender place by a turnstile. Quite why the turnstile is there in the first place is a bit odd - so far as i can see all it is there for is to prevent a passenger trying to leave by the rean entrance thereby avoiding the HK$2.30 fare. If that is the case it realkly would be easy for the evader to vault the barrier anyway.So having been dealt a painful blow in the male bits you stagger to a seat, only to find that some elderly chinese lady has deposited her various bags there. She gives you this kind of glare that only a 4ft 5 in seniorChinese woman can give, leaving you with an almighty sense of relief that she does not hold a public executionesr licence (hopefully) So having eventually taken your seat you then discover that the pre-stressed concrete blocks that proviide the support for the Hoover Dam have more give in them than the seat.You may dacided to go for a scenic seat so head on to the upper level. The steps up to the upper level are incredibly steep and the stairway itself is incredibly narrow. So whilst getting up the stairs may provide a challenge, getting down them can be a nightmare.The ride itself is so hard. The tram runs on metal wheels on metal tracks on tarmac roads. So far as suspension is concerned it just does not exist. Every bump in the tracks is tranmitted via the wheels, exacerbated by the seat and eventually arrives in you via your rear end ! One of things that some people seem to think of as being a major plus point is the fact that trams have open windows - great if you enjoy breating in the noxious petrol and diesel fumesSo, sorry to put a downer on anybody who is looking forwrd to riding the ding-ding. If you do so, dont expect any comfort and wear padded pants. Personally I prefer the buses any time - now if I only could purchase a pocket size Solent, whose knowledge of HK busses seems encyclopedic I would be all set!

Fun but Slow. A great was to see the area and gives you the ability to hop off if you see something of interest. Best if you have an Octopus Card so you don't have to worry about having the exact change ($2.30) Don't use if you are in a hurry!!!

Pseudo Theme-Park Ride. Before we boarded my wife said 'no-way' now she is happy to go 'tram-way'. Enjoyable excursions from Sheung Wan to Kennedy Town to the west and only as far as Wan Chai this time. Recommend for visitors, travel during the day outside busy times and weekends (maybe a challenge) and not when raining. We travelled on good weather days and had fun times. Use Octopus Card as well for convenience.

DIng Ding. caught the team on various occasions. amazing experience with open windows and went into food shopping areas where we got a taste of local life. would thoroughly recommend this. very cheap but you must have the exact fare as no change is given. A must when you are in Hong Kong

A Taste of Local Culture. It is worth a try if you would like to taste the local culture and enjoy a low-cost slow HK Island tour (慢旅), just HK$2.3 adult fares/ trip (less than USD0.5). But, be aware that Trams have no air-conditioning. It may be bit hot in summer. Trams attract me most as it witnessed the development of Hong Kong History from British colonial rule to modern Hong Kong. It first run in 1904. Tramcar modernization and routes advancement never make you feel the trams outdated. It is a reliable public transportation. Easy accessible to go to many major places in Hong Kong islands. You may not expect its speed as fast as MTR. Always miss "DING DING" bell sound!

Best way to travel if you have lots of time.. The tram in Hong Kong is the cheapest transportation vehicle there is, it is very slow though as there are many stops.But if you have lots of time, I recommend taking the tram to tour Hong Kong island, as there are no trams in Kowloon.
Crowded. The tings tings were very busy and if you're not sure where you're going it's hard to get off when they are so crowded, especially if you are up the top.

My FIRST Tram Ride and I Love this unique transportation system!!!!. This is the FIRST time took a Tram and I fall in love with this mode of transport. The route is so well-planned in the past and the whole system is well maintained. If you are like me who has never take a Tram ride, this is something you should not miss!
trams. these age old trams just keep running they are clean and run minutes apart sometimes they catch up to each other so no waiting

Worth a ride. The Hong Kong tramways are the cheapest way to transverse the Hong Kong Island. The rates are fixed, so 2 stops or 20 stops the ticket price is same. Just take a long trip to see the HK Skyline.
Travelled both in the morning and in the evenings to get the views. Octopus card comes in handy.
Enjoyed it thorougly

An tourist experience. Every tourist should experience going on the trams,it is an efficient way of travel, easy to use and cheap! No air-conditioning but all the windows are open and you see more than on the train.
Fun, cheap, and great way to see the Island.... At 2 hkd it's the cheapest way to travel from Causeway Bay to Central - except from walking of course - fun for the little ones too...

Old school. The HK tram is in a way old school, another classic way of transportation just like Star Ferry. It is rustic, crowded most often, uncomfortable to sit, low ceiling so when you are tall chances are you bump your head. But it is typical HK and worth a ride. The classic ding dong sound is part of the noisy streets in HK. What would HK be without the tram?

Best way to tour the Island. You don't need a daily bus pass when you have an octopus here in Hong Kong, simply just hop on and off the ding ding whenever you see something that interested you! The tram way goes from the west to the east end of the Island, going pass all the amazing neighborhoods. K-town, Sai Ying Pun, Central, Wan Chai, Causeway Bay, Tin Hau, North point to name a few! It's the best transportation I would say.

Hold onto your hats. A must-do for any tourist, taking a tram ride in Hong Kong is an experience not to be missed. If you can't get a seat make sure you're holding on tight as the sudden braking, lurching and overall swaying makes for an unpredictable ride. The locals are generally friendly and will advise which stop to get off. The acceleration causes a most welcome breeze on a hot and sticky night.

No air conditioning. In comparison, the air conditioned double-decker buses are more comfortable than these humble double-decker streetcars.A one fare rate, the double-decker streetcars seem to cross the entire north side of Hong Kong Island from the east side to the west side. It was raining. There was no air conditioning. The windows were open. So the bare wooden seats were damp. And it was cramped.However, there is a certain charm to these streetcars for these very reasons! Its very presence reminds one that streetcars were at the height of its popularity in many cities throughout the world during the early 1900’s. Here in Hong Kong, the streetcar is active and operational!
Impossible not to notice!. Really stands out among the big buildings. Worth the ride! Near central station and The Peak!! If You havent seen maybe just wait a little longer and they will come...
Ding Dong. If in hong kong you must try these we got on from one end to Kennedy town great for site seeing. Tip pay when you exit.

Being part of the local. Decided to hop on the tram. The lines are pretty hard to understand at first but got the hang of it. A fun ride making us felt like being part of the local. Wish I could take photos while in the tram but it was peak rush hour and the tram was pack with people.
Love the tram. Great but slow way to travel. Used it whenever possible. loved using it at night. Followed the tram party bus one night. It looked great all lit up

A tourist experience, an everyday transport option, and a party experience.. I ride the trams regularly as a cheap (though not quick) transport option. A friend held a birthday party on the trams, which was an enjoyable novelty for many of us.

Victoria Peak Tramway A Must Do, Even If You've Been Here Before. This is an inexpensive must do when in Hong Kong. The views from the tram are excellent and you ride along the ground rather than swing from a cable. Eight minutes is all to take you to the top with shops and the Sky Terrace 428 provides a spectacular view of Hong Kong, Victoria Harbour, and Kowloon. This was a component of an island tour package, which I recommend.
Love it . I use it every day, and it's just the best way to get a feel of the city and the people. It's not to fast and not to slow, just perfect.

Enjoyed thoroughly. The tram is a great way to see a slice of Hong Kong. With open windows and an upper floor window seat you are all set. The slow pace isn't a problem as you see many different neighbourhoods and have time to look down side streets.
double decker trams. the trams are one of its kind in the world I suppose, it is possible to sit on the upper deck and admire the great view, not expensive

Great fun. The tramways are terrific. The trams are slow but a lot of fun for tourists. We took the trip from near Wan Chai to Kennedy Town and thoroughly enjoyed the trip. It is a great way to see life on the streets and is very cheap using the octopus card. Recommended.

Part of Hong Kong. They are talking about closing down the trams. I can see the future and the idea about it, still it's a part of Hong Kong. I enjoy riding these old things, they still get you there in a cheap way. For longer journeys, the subway is the way to go, but still there is something special about the old tram and I hope they will be around for years to come.

Must Try. Great way to move around Hong Kong especially for first timer. Use the stair to the upper deck of the tram to enjoy the view of Hong Kong. One can shop, dine and enjoy the view of Hong Kong - IFC, SOGO to North Point wet market.
solid seats butcheap. The tram system is good and cheap but limited basically East-West HK island. Having recently traveled the world other countries have expanded their tramway systems.
Leisurely travel. Trams are a economical(just HKD 2.3) and offer a slow view of the city, they are slow but that's the charm if you want to explore the city at your pace.

A cute way to sit back and watch the city go by in slow motion. This is the slowest possible form of transportation in the city. Ha! You could almost walk faster. But it is one of the only old-ish things left, so appreciate the antiquity while it lasts! Trams are very popular with the locals, so it is fun to take a long ride down the waterfront and observe the many different people getting on and off. It is also a great way to get a good look at the different neighborhoods - because everything is going by so slowly! Enjoy!

Good Experience. This is inexpensive public transit in Hong Kong Island, the Ding Ding have Upper and Lower level, we like the upper one the view is better. When the driver stop at the station he push the bell - ding ding that's we know it ready to get on. In Hong Kong they have many choices of public transit, the tramways is one of the landmark.

A tram buff's heaven. Whilst in Hong Kong, try and fins time to ride on the old but efficient trams. They are a delight and allows the visitor to see the contrast between old and new, modern and traditional whilst riding on the iconic Hong Kong Trams. You can just go for a few stops or ride the whole system, but DO take in these historic and colourful trams.

Lovely was to see Hong Kong. When we first arrived we only travelled by the MTR, mainly because we thought that the 'ding ding ' would be difficult to navigate. Actually it isn't . If you sit on the top, you can see the name of the stops as you approach. It's a great way to see the city and much cheaper than the MTR ; it's a fixed price, no matter how far you travel.
Travel back in time. A real time travelling great to ride these old trams. Not to be missed but beware no mod considered here, is no air conditioning!

Delightful ride along Hong Kong island. These double decker teams are quite charming and only cost 2.30HKD per person per ride. Ideal when you're tired of walking the streets, or when you just want to soak in Hong Kong...
Great fun for very little money. 19 pence sterling for as far as you can go. You get on at the back and pay on on leaving HK$ 2.30. Great and interesting views of Hong Kong.

comfortable & fast transportation method. its 1 of the recommended transports to use when you wanna move around inside the cities , comfortable & fast to arrive supported with notification monitor to show you the current station & next 1 ,you will enjoy it .
my favorite one. I felt so excited when tried this public transportation. No tram in indonesia. I thought that i will never try it. But lucky me, finally can try in hk

A historical transportation. This transportation has been ran for over 100 years! The tram can bring you to travel the city in a slow motion. It does not have air conditioner, so it is recommended to be taken in the evening with better weather condition and give you a better mood to enjoy the experience. Actually, it is quite romantic to take it with your beloved one! You can get on and off at any tram station and charge you for the same price!
Historical tram to explore. Although is a bit packed in the tram but is worth to experience it. An eco tram I must say.. my boy enjoy it very much..
15KM of track and all for one price. Definitely worth a ride, costs next to nothing and a great way to see more of Hong Kong. They can get quite busy, try to get upstairs if you can you will see more

Historical & Scenic. Very historical and nostalgic tram, still operates in the middle of busy streets in Hong Kong. One of the 'Must Do' when visiting the city. Not only it is cheap, but great for an experience too!

Fun, cheap and interesting. Definitely a nice way to explore that part of the city, fun and cheap. Don't expect speed, and brace yourself for a little wait for he next tram, but for a lazy day of exploring, they are perfect

Great way to get around. This is a double-deck electric tram. It makes for an interesting way to get around and see HK. Slower than the buses but then that allows you to see more. The only negative is head room if you are on the tall side.
Must do. This is a MUST do. Dirt cheap and a great way to get a feel and sense of Hong Kong Island. Not much fun during rush how, but a perfect way to relax after shopping and walking.

A quaint piece of history amidst flashy Ferraris. The tramway is over a century old. The ticket payment system is pretty simple. Sit on the upper deck and enjoy the sights and sounds of Hong Kong. In a frightfully expensive city, this is a cheap, efficient, reliable and clean way of travelling. And yes,you can see the expensive malls, the flashy cars, the fancily dressed folks and so on. On simply a dime from this tram!
Cute and Nostalgic. Inexpensive and fun way to explore the city. We used it during the evening and it was fast and efficient.
A must see part of Hong Kong. A great part of Hong Kong's history. Wooden trams that criss cross the city. I found them efficient, very cheap and a great way to see the city at a leisurely pace.

A must do for all tourists. For a cost of HK$2.30 (21p) you can travel from Western to Shau Kei Wan and view all aspects of Hong Kong life along the route. This is a must do experience, if only to do a short journey, but beware they are not built for comfort.

the best way to travel across the Island!. this is the public transport that I love most! it runs slow, it allows you to have a good city view, and the stops are pretty close to one another, you can decide where you like to stop once you spot the place you want to go from the tram. Most of all, it is the cheapest way to travel around, HKD2.3 per trip.

Good Tool to travel the island. This is the best and cheapest way to travel entire Hong Kong island. It is suggested to start from Victoria Park the finished at central and then proceed to ride star ferry. Relax and ride on the team is very nice.
All aboard. If you're not in a hurry, Ding ding tram gives you a great way to view the city from Central to Causeway Bay. Go to the second deck see the sights and it costs just a few dollars.

cheapest tour of hongkong. Take a tram ride across the island. It is very cheap (at 2.30 HKD / adult / ride) and goes through the island's busy districts.Better have a copy of the route map, downloaded a PDF copy to my phone from their website.
Tram use. Great way to travel across Hong Kong in the old style, again using the Octopus card. The system is easy to navigate and is a great experience with some good views. Highly recommended.

My beloved way to see Hong Kong. These trams have been traversing these routes on the island side for over a century. They are the best way to enjoy the scenery of Hong Kong. It can get hot and crowded at times, but its definitely a great asset to Hong Kong.The trams are also a beloved transportation tool for us office workers who need to hop on and off between Central and Wanchai without going underground using the MTR.There are plenty to see on routes depending on where you get on:Sheung Wan for the Western Market and Dried SeafoodCentral for work, banks and shopping, Admiralty for Pacific Place and more shopping;Wanchai for night life and markets,Happy Valley for horse racing nights and it is a closer route to Times SquareFurther up there is the Central Library, Tin Hau Temple etc...You will be able to find the route and point of interests from the Hong Kong Tram Ways Website.

Ding Ding. Took a 10 minute ride with no destination in mind. The view from the second level was good and the heavy traffic was not too bothersome. Every tram and bus has 2 levels which can accommodate a lot of travelers.

Cheap way to travel and see the sights. The tramway is a cheap way to travel in HK Island, and the fare is very cheap (HK$2.30), swipe your Octopus card when you get off. The fare is a flat rate, regardless of whether you go one stop or to the end of the line. We initially boarded the tram with the intention of going only a few stops, but ended up staying on for considerably longer as we were enjoying the sights and taking a break from walking. Perfect for the budget traveller wanting to see the sights or get around, and way cheaper than a hop on hop off bus. Note that the trams can get quite crowded, sometimes it may be worth waiting for the next tram (5 minutes or less).

Good way of transportation. These Trams are everywhere and are good and really cheap way of transportation in big citt of Hong Kong. I wouldnt say that are too crowdy.Relaxed, clean, cheap. Worth to use
Bargain. $2.30!!! Less than au$0.50c!! Tip - pay attention to side streets or major buildings where you are to get off.
Cheap travel. Travel with the locals, the trams are a cheap way to get about. You can use your Octopus card, you board the tram at the back, then swipe your card as you get off at the front.

Excellent, Cheap Way to See the City. I highly recommend this to visitors. Try to get on the second level to get a good view of the streets, as well as the businesses/life above the streets, AND to minimize exposure to vehicle fumes, which is everywhere on the roadside in HK, specially when it's summertime. This is a great and efficient way to see the city. Highly recommended!

Old Restored Tramcars are a fun way to get around. Used by the public and tourists these are a slow fun way to get along the Shopping and Business districts of Hong Kong Island. $2.30 per trip either Cash or use your oyster card. Train is faster obviously but Ding Ding is more fun

Easy, Cheap and Fun. Tram ride is an excellent way to move from place to place or just watch the city street life. It's super easy to use, just pay with your octopus card when leaving. View from the second floor is great!

It's like flying around Hong Kong. . Had a great time and it's as easy as 1, 2 and 3. #1 get onto the tram and then pay $2.30 HK dollars but you must have correct change because they would give you. Great way to see most of Hong Kong.
Many different colours. It looks like in Melbourne where has so many type of colours. Is a good experience in hong kong. Able to travel from city to another city so that don't have to walk so much

Great Fun. A blast from the past in HK. Routes will be on your tourist map. All journeys are 2.30 HKD regardless of length. Pay when you get off, the correct money is expected as there is no change or use Octopus card. We put in 5 HKD each time (less than 50p UK for two of us!)recommended for sightseeing and taking weight off ya feet!

Love the tram, especially in winter. Many cities have done away with trams, many European cities have installed newer coaches but HK retains the traditional tram and it's one of the best ways to sight-see the HK island. The tram runs east-west almost along the same path as the MTR (underground of course). It's very economical and hence makes a great hop-on hop-off option. The frequency of the trams is very high and you'll rarely have to wait for more than 5 mins for one. However, due to it's low cost and convenience, the trams do get crowded during peak hours.

Ding Ding, and we're off. Super cheap, great way of seeing some of the best part of Hong Kong. We rode the tram from basically one side of the Island to the other (as far as the route allowed of course) and chose seats upstairs where the windows were all open (brilliant on a hot, humid evening). There's no excuse not to jump on the tram, handy to get around and costs next to nothing. Jump on and soak in the sights, sounds and smells of the city, nice one!
You're in HK, you must ride on it!. It's my first time to ride on such a transportation! It's highly recommended especially during night!

Good transport. We rode the Ding Ding while on a food tour. Fortunately our guide knew where to get on, get off, and how to pay. Might be a little bit difficult to navigate completely on your own if you don't have any knowledge of the city. Fun ride - we sat on the top deck.
old school. If you visit HK, u must try this one. Although have not the AC, but in summer time u will not feel so hot here.

Best and Cheapest Ride in Town. Take the tram in Central on Hong Kong Island , upstairs you get the best views in town and an unforgettable experience . Can be busy at times but be patient it is a great ride and only costs the fraction of a taxi.

Traditional transportation in HK!. This is one of the longest history transportation in HK island and it is unbelievable that the ppl is trying to kick this out! A lot of great memories brought to me from the Ding Ding!

Nice way to view Hong Kong. We took it at night after dinner on a friday. It was virtually empty with few people! We are able to choose whatever seats we want. Nice night view of Hong Kong city. And its cheap too!

Great cheap way to travel and see the real Hong Kong. We literally jumped on a tram and went from one side of the island to the other. We sat upstairs at the front of the tram and were fascinated by the streets, buildings and people coming and going on the tram.
A really cheap way to see the sights.

A Must for tourists. Tram is located at Hong Kong Island side, from Kennedy Town to Sau Kei WanIts still an important for local peopleI advise to take a ride at night, which is less crowdy,go upstair and enjoy the breeze and night viewTake some time to view the street in the city, i always like the sheung wan to causeway Bay partDo not advise to go to Happy Valley, its just luxury resident area Its cheap, and not complicatedit you want to go to the other direction just move to the opposite sideyou can go back to MTR station easily

Must try!. Best transportation for a tourist if you ask me. If you're not in a hurry, better try the trams since it brings you from one point to another depending on the destination of the tram that you're in. It's also very cheap around 2HKD. Stops are everywhere in the main street and they have an upper deck which is perfect for tourists. You can sww both the street and the mountain view at some part of the city. They also have party trams which I've seen a couple of times. If you don't mind the sweat, wasting time, and a bit of crowd, then this is perfect.

The cheapest sightseeing transports in Hong Kong. $2.20 from East to West, suggest to sit the front on upper deck to get better view. Because no air-conditioners, not a good idea to do in Summer time! The whole journey will take 1:45 mins.

A must do in Hong Kong!. Great to do if you have a few hours to spare. Take the full tram ride from one end to the other, but beware that it can get quite busy with standing room only. A fun and cheap way to see the city.
Great way to get around. You need a bit of time if you want to use these lots - but if you do its a great way to see local life - I used them every day
Great sightseeing option. The Ding Ding (Hong Kong Tram) is a double deck tram that is very inexpensive and a great way get an overview of the city.
Recommended experience. We rode the ding ding trams several times during our stay. We found it easy to navigate and find stops. The kids especially enjoyed it.

Good Historic Transportation. This is one of the most affordable and historic modes of transportation in the Western District. If you sit in the top level you get great views of the city sidewalks and alley ways. It's also cool on a hot day.

Very convenient. We were staying on Hong Kong Island, so we used the Tram quite a lot. Easy to get on and just go a couple of stops if you are tired. You can use your Octopus Card. We took the tram to the end of the line to the East, which was good, but it did seem a long way back, so manybe catch the train back.If you can get seats at the top in the front you get a good view.
Bag in Time. We had a great time on the Ding Ding. Unfortunately we had to wait a short while but it was a fun experience & was on our Things to do List checked off.

Another Hong Kong Must Do. Simply a nice and easy way to get around Hong Kong Island, but it can get crowded at times so bring your patience. It is been on Hong Kong island for over 100 years so take a seat upstairs and do a bit of people watching as you amble along the island. Great way to get from A to B

Hong Kong Tram experience. Used the tram several times during my stay in Hong Kong week commencin 4 October 2015.Quite an experience! Usually very busy but also very frequent and cheap.If you have the opportunity do try them.

Relaxing way to observe the road along Hong Kong island. Very cheap (less than USD 1.00).Take a trip from one side of the island to another and enjoy people watching as the tram move slowly. Avoid peak hours!Entrance at the back door, exit at front door (pay fare when exiting).

No HK visit complete without a tram ride!. An unmissable Hong Kong experience is a ride on the trams. For a flat rate of $2.4 (adults), no matter the distance you travel, you can watch the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong life from the top of a double-decker tram. You get onto the tram at the rear and exit at the front. Payment, by Octopus or coins (no change given) is on exit. A suggested itinerary would be to travel by tram to Happy Valley (only trams displaying 'Happy Valley' at the front actually go there) and alight at the tram station. Then you could walk back on yourself a little way and up the hill (3 mins walk) to the Tam Kung Temple on Blue Pool Road. From there, you could cut across Happy Valley to Shan Kwong Road and visit the Jewish Cemetary. The gated entrance is between a brightly coloured Buddhist school and a Buddhist monastery. After that, head down the hill, bearing left to Wong Ngai Chung Road. Just past the pink Hindu temple you will find the Parsee Cemetary, which also contains a local plant nursery. Beyond that is the Hong Kong cemetary, followed by the Catholic Cemetary and finally, the Muslim cemetary. Reading the inscriptions on the various headstones, provides a fascinating glimpse of Hong Kong's history. There is a tram stop outside the colonial or HK cemetary (you will need to wave to the tram driver to make sure he sees you and stops) and also in front of the Muslim Cemetary / Cosmopolitan Hotel. Trams from these two stops may go either towards the West and Kennedy Town or towards the East and Shau Kei Wan.

Great to sit and enjoy the ride and sights. We enjoyed the tram ride with our guide. The ride was fun, a new experience for us as well as seeing new sights. Plus the guide told us interesting things about Hong Kong's past along with what we were looking at as we went down.
Got to be done. Wonderful experience travelling around the city with the locals . Loads to see from upper deck and really cheap to use . A definite must .

Unique experience from the Top Deck of a 1950s vintage Double Decker Tram. Dating from the 1900s, the tram is one of the cheapest and environmentally friendly ways to travel along the north coast of Hong Kong Island. The double decker trams are now unique (other British colonies in Asia did away with them) and the current fleet of 150 or so date from the 1950s. Interiors are basic: for airconditioning, slide down the window and firm wooden seats, but what do you expect for HK$2.30, a flat fare however short or long the distance you travel? There is essentially one track that runs from Kennedy Town in the West to Shau Kei Wan in the East, passing through Central, Wan Chai and Causeway Bay, so it's almost impossible to get lost. There is loop that runs from Causeway Bay around the Jockey Club horse racing track in Happy Valley and back again: worth the detour along leafy Wong Nai Chung Road and the views across to the Jockey Club grandstands on the west side. (Don't miss the chance to enjoy it while you can: there are some in Hong Kong who think the tram has no place in the city and want the system closed down and the lines removed.)Tips: You must have the EXACT change (HK$2.30 in coins) or a stored value Octopus card. Get on at the BACK, only pay when you get off at the FRONT. Top deck is best for views, breeze and less traffic fumes. It gets crowded at peak hours and pushing and shoving is part of the deal, so chill out and go with the flow. Keep valuables secure - Hong Kong is one of the world's safest cities but why take a chance. In summer it does get very hot and humid, so those of a sensitive nature should carry a scented hanky for that close-up sweaty experience on board.

Travelling by old but reliable trams.. It's quite an experience to travel around in busy & crowded Hong Kong by trams. It's cheap, airy & slower mode of transportation which offers visitors opportunity to take in the surrounding sceneries.
Best way to experience the city and feel like a local. Despite the traffic, this is a great way to experience the city and check out the views and definately feel like you're part of the city.

A must for first time visitor. Tourist can have a good view of the Hong Kong Island by travelling on the tram . Some interesting places, main shopping and entertainment areas on the island are easily accessible from the tram stops. Frequent stops on the main streets make it a very convenient and cheap transport. Avoid peak hours and hot summer!

Outdate but fan.. The Hong Kong Tramways looks very strange compare to typical European tramways. They are very short and two story high. Riding them - nostalgic fan, but local love it and use it every day. Its not only for tourists.
Love the old metro. The old metro car is a nice experience to see around Hong Kong Island. The fair is around 2 HKD and you can all along the track. Ni

A good transport for you to experience Hong Kong island. Tram has been in Hong Kong island for a century.The pathway of tram is simple. It passes through Sai Wan to Shau Kei Wan. it is slow and provide you a great opportunity to look around in Hong Kong island. It is so cheap. Just around 2 dollars. Enjoy and experience a rare and slow way to travel Hong Kong.

Regular daily scheduled service on Hong Kong Tram with requested festival sponsor's event Musical by season(s). Hong Kong still have the classical Kennedy Town to enjoy the tramway ride. If not on busy hours, the tram ride is the most economical means of transportation to travel in Hong Kong Island only. And yet, artists and musicians must be smart and alert to the posting billboard all the time, or else easy to miss the festival that sponsors invested to let musicians or artists to perform by each count of event.
