The Whitty Street Tram Depot is not that historically classical now. This building has been modified. Only the garage of the trams depot remained the same in olden times of Hong Kong's Kennedy Town of today's Hong Kong SAR after 1997.
Cheap way to get around. Great a must use to get about expect to stand both upstairs and down at busy times but great love the way they are all decorated differently

You must travel on a tram whilst in Hong Kong- a really cheap way to travel. No trip to Hong Kong is complete without a trip on the local trams. We buy an Octopus travel card for use whilst in Hong Kong which is valid on all forms of transport including the Peak tram (the peak tram charges 28HK$ for a one way ride for an adult and 11HK$ for a senior over 65). The local trams charge a flat rate fare of 2.30 HK$ for adults, 1.20HK$ for children and 1.10 HK$ for seniors (aged over 65 - take along proof of age when buying the senior card and keep it with you when you travel in case you are asked to produce it). You can buy the Octopus card in MTR stations at the customer service desk. They charge 50HK$ deposit for the card and you add money to cover the cost of your trips. We put 100HK$ on adult cards and only 20HK$ on senior cards as typical fares for seniors are 1-2 $ per ride (even when the standard adult fare on the bus or train was almost 12HK$). When you are ready to go home, surrender the card and get a refund of the residual top up value as well as 41 HK$ of the card deposit. A ride on the tram is a great way to see something of Hong Kong life on a rainy day. We got on the tram in Central and went all the way to the terminus- a journey of 80 minutes and all for the regular flat rate fare! A real bargain way to travel and lots of fun!

Tram travel is a must.. Couldn`t visit Hong Kong without travelling on a tram. They are built for people smaller than me, and as I`m very tall it was awkward getting up the tight staircase. However it is an experience not to be missed. Have the correct change ready!

Hong Kong trams - A must do while in Hong Kong. Pay one standard fare on exit or use your Octopus Card. The trams run alongside Victoria Harbour on Hong Kong Island. For the best views of local communities, travel on the upper deck. The tram is much slower than buses or the MTR so they are best taken as an attraction rather than for rapid transport
Nice to try one time. If you want something more authentic - try the tram. It is a bit slow and basically stops every 100 meters... But if you need to do a short distance trip go for the tram :)
Local Trams. a novel way of getting about. All the trams were different colours and designs. Very cheap to use and every 2 minutes. Well used by the local community
Sightseeing tram. Quite another way than taking the sightseeing bus. Feels more local and cheap as well l, just 2.30 HKD for an adult.

Old school fun! . They're talking about getting rid of these awesome rigs, but these are a fun way of getting around Hong Kong in addition to the subway system and city bus. Some people recommended to take the street car the whole route up and down through Hong Kong to see the city, but we just used it for transportation to get from one side to another and that seem to be enough as they are wooden benches, take longer, and can at times be a little uncomfortable especially in the heat... No air con.

A charming way to get around and discover the city. With their historical character, the ding-dings are an attraction in themselves, but they also help you get around in a very economical way. The scenery is impressive, especially in the evening when city lights shine.

Leisure trip. I took Ding Ding in the last hours before leaving Hong Kong. It was a leisure for a traveler to sit upstair and see the world slowly pass by your side, soccer playing, shops, people gatherings etc. It was in the morning of a weekend but the tram is not crowd at all.

Great Tram Experience. I went to HK several times, and I always had good tram experience in HK Island. I enjoyed the ride to places where I wanted to go. And the cost isn't expensive too. Good experience.

Great way to see the city.. I just love riding these double decker trolleys just to say, I'm on the ding ding (i.e., the noise it makes). Be sure to ride the top deck and enter from the back. You can't get lost since its on a track.
Cheap. Although the price raised slightly, it's a cheap, fun way to experience your trip from one destination to another.

amazing travel. great value on a relaxing day out we got the tram from near are hotel to murray rd where you get off for the train up to Victoria park it was only 40p each it doesn't matter if you go 1 stop or 10 its all 1 price please have change as they is no ticket person on board and sit up stairs to get great views of the city
Awesome experience. The Double decker trams is fun and cheapest way to enjoy in Hongkong . Kids had fun . Avoid rush hours , we chose to sit upstairs to get good view of the city .

Love it. Old fashioned... moving at a slow pace in the middle of busy roads. BUT WE LOVE IT. Tap ur octopus card only when u alight.Avoid peak hours in the morning.. people goin to work.There r tram stops along the road... eastbound and westbound. Pls check their website n download the route for ur convenience sake.You must do it if you stay in HK island. ;)
Best view and local sights and smells. Slow enough to get photos, fast enough to beat walking, and don't forget about the chance to go end to end on the main road. See it all for HKD2.30 (AUD0.46)

A trip back in time. As a child sixty years ago, I experienced a trip on a tram in Cape Town. The journey took me from the older part of Hong Kong to the modern section of the city. The younger generation were quite helpful for directions and point of alighting the tram to where one wishes to go. A must experience when visiting Hong Kong.

Part of HK history......worth the few 'pence' it costs.. Quirky form of travel on Hong Kong Island that allows you to see a good stretch of the causeway over to Kowloon.Very, very busy at most times as it is a local form of transport in the city for the local. Touristy must do.
Amazing way to see Hong Kong. The most charming way to see Hong Kong. I believe that it would be the cheapest, enjoyable way to see Hong Kong. Lovely experience.
A must do. How fun! And very convinient. Hard to get off at rush hours but worth many trips all day. Sit upstairs for better views.

The trams are a delight. There is so much to do in Hong Kong... The tram rides are a relaxing trip... It's like a London double decker bus on rails. If you staying at the JW Marriott or Conrad, it's a skips do jump to the station.

Good old trams!. Very nostalgic ride on the trams that were introduced by the British. For a fixed fare you can go for as many stops as you want. The tram is narrow and getting up (and down) the stairs can be difficult if you are large size!

Most interesting ride in hong Kong. I lost count how many times I have been to Hong Kong, but the tram ride never fails to impress me. I love taking the tram, although it is much slower than the MTR. It is a very unique mode of transport and no trip to Hong Kong is complete without a ride on the tram. You could take your time to observe Hong Kong as the tram takes you from the busy business district to the crowded residential areas. Hong Kong is a very charming city and the best way to appreciate it is by taking a ride on the tram!

Get around HK like it's 1902. The trams are a great way to get around Hong Kong and it's the oldest form of public transportation. It goes from the west at Kennedy Town all the way to the east at Shau Kei Wan. Ding Ding name comes from the sound of the bells and the sound it makes really brings you back in time. HK is such a fast paced city packed with people. It's good to see that there's a tram slows down the pace and lets you see the city in a different angle. And one more thing that I'd like to mention is this app I discovered recently, Citymapper. It was super helpful in helping me get around hk and it also tracks when the trams would arrive at a stop, simply amazing!
Packed. Crowded, slow. Lots of stops. But quaint and may be convenient depending on destination. Only tried once.

Great value and fun, and easy to use, with window-open AC.. Get on at the back, exit at the front, use your Octopus Card or exact change (no charge given). HK$2.30 adults, over-65 HK$1.10, ride as far and as long as you want. Good way on arriving to orient yourself to the lower part of Hong Kong Island, especially if you sit upstairs. Some cars are museum pieces, 1960s, some are bang up-to-date with digital signage. Navigation is easy by the stop number e.g. 19E (goes east) 51W (goes west). Check front for where tram goes to before boarding - some stop at Western Market, for example, others go all the way west to Kennedy Town. End of the line east gets you to Chun Yeung street market, North Point, a fascinating traditional market.
Great way to get around. No air conditioning but up top is the best way to see the street sights. Lots of choices on destinations constantly arriving at stops, give it a go.

Ding Ding. You will get used to this sound when you are in Hong Kong... Though it is the slowest among other ground transport options, lot of people take this service everyday... Very convenient and easily accessible for travelling to nearby places... Take a ride and get the real feel...

Old tram. By paying 2dolar HK, we can see hongkong islands
But in case we in hurry I not suggest using tram.
We can see hongkong from different angle I think

Good way to see HK. Trams are slow with frequent stopping so easy to hop on and off when you see something of interest. Very inexpensive only
$HK 2.30 per trip no matter how far you travel.
An experience. Slow (but you can see more this way!) but wonderful way to see HK! A must do. No air conditioning but doesn't really bother me.

Great way to see Hong Kong's past mode of transport. These trams still trundle back and forth between Causeway Bay and Victoria Harbour West as well as Happy Valley. Really cheap, they offer a great view from the top deck that is interesting with a cool breeze. You can't get lost, and just pay some cojns as you exit.
Use is before it vanishes..... We took the tram from Kennedy Town to Central and the pier area for our harbor cruise. It was slower than the MTR, and jerkier, but a nice change and entertaining.

Couldn’t hear the ding ding anymore :(. It was a great experience if you have time, and choose a day that’s not too hot and not rainy, it’s cheap! Enter from the back of the tram, better to head upstairs and exit at the front of the tram where you pay by Octopus card.

Hong Kong Tram. This is simply just one of those things you must experience , along with a Ferry ride. This simply beats the hustle and bustle of cities electrifying energy and allows time to stand still. Yes I know Hong Kong does not seem to sleep , this little journey just allows you that little window to re evaluate life.

Fun to do if you have the time. Don't take the tram if you are in town for a day, or if you are in a hurry. The system is slow, compared to the metro or taxis, so this is not the best option for transportation.
That said, it is a fun and cool way to get around the city. Enter from the rear end, sit upstairs.
Old time travel. The tram that we travelled on was rather rickety and tight for space but it certainly reminds one of the time in the past and the fare was very cheap.

A fun way to see the sights. The old trams, although some are not that old, are a wonderful (and cheap) way of experiencing the sights and sounds of the CBD, and beyond, of Hong Kong Island. Climb on board, take the weight off your feet, sit back and enjoy the passing parade.

glimpse of old Hong Kong. I love old, vintage things and felt like I was time-traveling! Must aware that it doesn't have air-conditioner. Not recommendable when carrying baggage or backpack. Octopus card acceptable.

A leisurely tour of Hong Kong. Anyone who wants to simply sit back and enjoy the scenes of Hong Kong must try the tramways. Best to sit on the upper deck at night, feel the cool breeze on your face while taking in the beautiful sights of Hong Kong. My son and I took a ride one night and just headed to no particular destination. It was such a great experience. The ride may be a bit bumpy as it travels through the railways but it's negligible in comparison to the experience.

HK's classic feature. If you did not try the tramway, you would miss the key HK's classic transportation tool. It is slow running and thus you have enough time to see the HK island's main street. From west to east, it will take you an hour. The suggested route is from Kenney Town (western) to Northpoint (don't be misled by this name, it is on the eastern part of the HK island). The fare is unbelievably cheap. Non-rush hours you may easily get the seat. It is better to sit on the upper deck. It will be very relaxing.

Perfect to go around old Hong Kong. We liked it a lot and used it all the time during our stay. It is cheap and the price does not depend on the distance. The stops are short so you can find them easily. And it is so cute!

such a charming way to do sight-seeing. this tram is sooo cute! You pay at the end, and beware - they don't give any change, so prepare the exact fare or get an octopus card in advance - very practical way to get around with all the transport even including taxi if I'm not mistaken and when you leave - you just get the money left on the balance back

Nostalgia-In-Motion. A visit to Hong Kong Island is incomplete without a ride on one of the 161 trams traversing from Kennedy Town in the west, to Shau Kei Wan in the east. These endearing, gentle, bobbing ‘ding-ding’-sounding behemoths are emblematic of Hong Kong’s heritage and are, without doubt, the best way to see and explore the city island at a leisurely, cycling pace, particularly so from the upper deck. Inexpensive (a flat fare of 20p applies) the 110 year-old network now hosts seventh generation trams, some air-conditioned, as >180,000 people daily hop on and off these grand old mahogany panelled rooms on wheels. Efficient, non-polluting, quiet, the trundling journey is of great nostalgic value as well as practical means, and as Hong Kong’s most venerable form of public transport, irreplaceable. Interestingly, more and more cities elsewhere around the globe are following Hong Kong’s example and are either introducing or, in some instances, re-introducing trams to their clean, green transport infrastructure.

Another Cheap Way to see part of Hong Kong Island.. You get on from the back of the Electric Tram (available only on HK Island) and alight at the front after you pay your fares. If you have a tourist travel card you can swipe your card before alighting.
Comfortable and cheep. It is a good way to experience the life style of the city. Taking Ding Ding is comfortable and save the fee as well if you are a traveler who is out of cash...ha

good way to traverse and see HK. Good way to move around the island for cheap. You get to see the surroundings as you travel. Not the fastest way though. It lost its novelty around the third day. Bus is much faster.

You have to ride the tram!. We wanted to experience all modes of transportation while in Hong Kong and this turned out to be great fun. You get to see how people live and parts of Hong Kong that you won't experience from the subway. Try it at least once! You will be hooked.

Of course, why not?. A trip to HK without riding the tram to Victoria Peak is like going to San Francisco and not seeing the Golden Gate Bridge. The view is awesome but getting there from HK to the tramway base might be challenging if you don't know the bus system to get you there. We took a halfway tour years ago that included bus service to access the tram up to Victoria Peak, Aberdeen Bay, etc.
Charming way to see the city. Great way to move-about, and see Hong-Kong above ground. It's super cheap (I think maybe HK$3). Sit upstairs for the best view.

A ride not to be missed. An old and rustic feel. Really amazing. Kind of tight sitting in it though, but was an amazing experience. Really good connection to any location once gotten down from the MTR metro.
An inexpensive way to see HK. This was a good way to put my feet up and see the local life of Hong Kong. It cost nearly nothing and it was a near experience.

Great (and cheap) way to see Hong Kong Island. There are many ways to commute in Hong Kong, but the trams are by far the most charming way. In fact, they are a great and cheap (HKD 2.3 in each direction) way to do some sightseeing. The trams travel along the main parts of Hong Kong Island. Take the tram at any point, sit on the second floor next to a window and see the main part of the city flowing by leisurely. Travel from East to West or vice versa, and then take a tram back and see the other side.

Know that tall the trams don't share a final destination. The trams are all one price payments that you make on your way off the tram. The most confusing problem with the trams is that some go the entire line distance, and others only go one segment of the tram route. The tram can be a great way to see the Hong Kong Island from Kennedy Town to the Happy Valley Raceway -- but make sure you take a tram that goes to these ending destinations, or you'll find yourself having to get off and on different trams along the way. Check the front of the tram, as they post the final destination. Go on the upstairs of the tram for a great view -- they are not known for speed, but do provide an alternative to the subway. There is something charming about them. The "long run" on the tram gives you great view of the different neighborhoods of Hong Kong Island's urban core. They have discounts for senior citizens --

Memorable journey by HK tramways. Hong Kong tramways is a major tourist attraction. It is also an environment friendly mode of transportation in HK. I had the awesome experience of travelling between Victoria Park and Kennedy town.
Unforgettable Experience . One of amazing places in Hong Kong and really is good experience and we spend unforgettable time there while riding the tram

Fund ride with great view of the City. This is one of the icon in Hong Kong and make sure you experience this when you are on the Hong Kong Island. It cost only a couple of dollars and it is a fun ride which take you through the city.

Great fun on the top deck. We travelled out to the tram terminus at Kennedy Town on the mtr and rode the tram to Causeway Bay as a cheap and historic way to see some of the main areas of Hong Kong's Central strip. Great being high above street level in the open air to appreciate the hustle and bustle as you pass through residential, financial and commercial districts.
too hot but a nice way to visit the old wanchai. it is toooooo hot to take the tram in summer, maybe in winter is better. Very cheap and a good way to visit the old wanc

Hong Kong Tramways to stay. I know I have no say, but, please keep the ding ding, It is quite an enjoyable ride. I like the seats on the upper deck, they are breezy. Taking other transportation, they are more crowded. Having said that, I do have the experience of standing on the tram. However, I do believe that it is just once in a while.

Glorious Way To Travel. We travelled by tram from our hotel in Fortress Hill into town and it truly is the most wonderful way to journey through the crazy streets of downtown Hong Kong ... it trundles and ding dings its way along the centre of the street and from the top deck you can savour the breeze and watch the madness beneath you for less than 50p a journey. Unmissable.

great view(eventually). The queue to get on was longer than we expected and the ride to the top was only about 5 mins.when we got to the top we had to go up many escalators to get to the outside viwing point only to find we couldn't see very much at all as the clouds were so thick it was like being in a fog.we decided to get a bit of lunch in one of the restaurants.we all decided what we were having when we looked up and out of the window and all the clouds had lifted to the most spectacular view,considering what we had seen 10 mins earlier.
amazing!. nowhere else in the world where you can travel the same distance covered by the trams in a metropolitan for HKD$2.30! You can also experience the bustling life that is Hong Kong

Very cheap transportation, part of the history of Hong Kong !. Use it as long as you can, very cheap, maybe not too comfortable, but sure part of the history of the city, cannot have been there without using the Ding Ding !

Very Cheap and a very old way to travel. This is a very old kind of transportation in Hong Kong, and it is only in Hong Kong island. The fee is super cheap, it just costs $1.2 Hong Kong dollars to get you to everywhere in Hong Kong side, like Kennedy Town, Happy Valley, Causeway Bay, Wan Chai, Admiralty, and etc.

Interesting and nostalgic journey. Well worth taking on Hong Kong Island. We used it to go to Causeway Bay on a sunday. One thing to remember you pay when you get off the tram at the front. You board at the back.

See a nice streetview from the upperdeck. take one of the lines, does not matter which one and try to sit in the front on the upperdeck. See the Streets and the people, what a busy life in this city on a little surface. In this way of public transport you have time to see around. Notice that you have coins topay at the end of your trip. (fixed price independant from your distance, it is cheap: 2,30 HK$)

Relaxing way to explore Hong Kong Island. Ding Ding is not only a popular transportation means for the locals for short distance commuting on Hong Kong Island but also a must-try for the tourists. Take the tram from North Point to Shek Tong Tsui (or vice versa), go to the upper deck and sit by the side. You can enjoy the very different views of the city, from central business district to residential areas and historical buildings. The day and night views are quite different. It is entirely inexpensive for the relaxing and enjoyable ride, and is highly recommended for those who are not in a hurry.

Ride of fantacy.. My first experience of riding a tram and it will always be close to my heart. It just takes you back in the bygone era. Very efficient and cheap. Exploring Hong Kong using a tram can be a fascinating experience. Just hop on to a tram and take a seat on the upper deck. You will see some of the best parts of the city which are not there in guide books. And all for just 2.3 SGD.

Enjoy the sights of the city. Great way to travel around the city....we went from Whitty Street to North Point & of course the entire ride was only $2.30. If you go eastbound sit on the right hand side to get a great picture of all the skyscraper buildings. Also be aware that if you go from one point to another you must get off at the last stop & find a return bus as you can't ride it full circle.
A good way to see parts of HK. If you are not in a hurry, this is a good way to see some parts of HK. It is very cheap to travel on, and a cross section of the local people use it.
Great way to see the city from the top. We travelled on the tram and were able to sit up the top where we could see the city from a higher perspective.
Great for Sight-seeing. Cheapest way of transportation and great tool fro sight seeing special if you have a lot of time and not in a hurry,

Another tradional way to view Hong Kong District. Ding Ding is one of the transportation you have to try when you travel around Hong Kong. The tram moves in a slow pace (recommend to take the tram from Sheung Wan to North Point), with that you can take picture about Hong Kong island (from east to west or vice versa ;-)The tram will pass HK's Central Business District, there you will see people rushing hectically from one to another point :-P
Great. A fun way to get around in HK. I drove it in the night time, so it was great to see all the lights of the city.

Good to ride. The Tram is one of the symbols of Hong Kong Transportation. It's aged more than 100 years. On board of the tram, you can hear the sound of ding ding for the stop and never has any traffic jam as it runs on the track without any blocking. It is the cheapest transportation in HK and a good ride to seeing the beautiful lighting at evening.

Rattlin' good trip!. A ride on a Ding Ding is a must if you are visiting HK Island. A great way to tour the island and to people watch from the top deck as well. Sometimes crowded, but definately worth riding at least once.. Not quite as simple to navigateas the Star Ferry, but almost as enjoyable, Hong Kong's trams are an institution. The Ding Ding is well worth riding at least once.Get yourself a seat at on the top deck if you can.Tip: Take a ride at night for a totally different perspective!

Shaky, slow, cheap but a great experience!. Tramways are a piece of historical significance. In the land of super fast trains and efficient bus networks, trams are still going strong. Why? For 2 HKD, you can travel from any point A to point B. View from the upper level is fun. Must not miss!

So much fun way of transportation!. I really enjoyed taking the tramways at the island, a great way of transportation thru the city, cheap, clean and efficient. This is a great way to see the city, a great combination of old style transportation with the modernism!

Must try. Decides to try the Ding Ding trams in Hong Kong. It is a really good way to see a bit of Hong Kong. If you see something from the tram you can just get off the next stop look around and get back on. A relaxing way to travel. You can use the octopus cars which makes it easier too,
Trams (Ding Ding). very nice mode of transportation, The tramm has a second floor where you can sit to have a great view of the city while touring.

One of the best way to see HK side!!!. The cheapest transportation by far in HK! Only HK$2 you can ride all you want as long as you don't disembark from the tram:) The best view of the city while touring:)

Great Fun!!. Wherever you get on the view is going to be very interesting. It is ridiculously cheap, crowded and noisy but fantastic. A must do, just do not expect luxury or air conditioning, it is for the adventurous at heart.

Cheap Way to Experience the Sights and Sounds of Hong Kong. One trip cost $2.30, so there's nothing even close to that price point. But I need to keep this real. This transport is used by the masses (why won't they at that price point). It's never meant for tourists only. So you'll enjoy it when you have a front seat soaking up the sights and sounds of Hong Kong in the slow ride. However, you'll end up soaking wet with perspiration when you don't have a seat, packed to the seams with everyone squeezing together and travelling in summer (there's no air-conditioning for this).It's a unique experience after all, but I want to make sure you know the trade-off.

EASY, CLEAN AND EFFICIENT TRAVEL. Trams are a great way to get around in Hong Kong. Fast and efficient, grab an Octopus Card, top up at many locations around the city with easy refund at the airport on departure. Wouldn't leave home without one! Use on trains and the metro as well.

Tiny. These are tiny. If you are over weight or very tall it will be an uncomfortable experience for all. Thankfully we're not but still wacked my head a few times. Only really went on these for nostalgic reasons, and only did short hops. If my wife had let me i'd have quite happily stayed on for the whole line to take in the different elements of the city.
Slow and quiet. I love it. Vintage experience in the busy HK. Takes ages but feels good. And it is the cheapest way to go around HK.
A fun way to explore. A fun way to explore the city. Nice to sit down, but still feel a part of everything. Try to get a good seat up the front.
Must do. Cheap. Hop on and off anywhere you like. Not the fastest way to get around but a good break if you just want to sit and enjoy everything around you without having to walk

If You Have Enough Time. If you have enough time, this is a really good and relaxed way I recommend to spend your time. You get to the higher deck and secure the front seat if possible. You can watch Hong Kong from a different perspective.

nice way to get around in hong kong. We wanted to use different means of travel around on our holiday and after getting the ferry across to north point we jumped on the ding dong tram to travel down to the paek tram stop. Nice sitting up the top of the double decker trams just watching people as you go by. Easy to use with an octopus card, just swipe on. $2.30 for one stop or the whole line. We loved it.

Hong Kong Ding Dong Tram. Wanting to get off our feet for a while, we climbed on board the Ding Dong near Victoria Park and rode all the way to the roundabout at the eastern end and back to where we got on, We were on there for about an hour but we could have stayed on all the wat to the other end and done the complete circuit....all for $2.30 HK...about 50c Au. Seats are like plastic kitchen chairs and it can be crowded at times. But it was fun to see the road from the top level of the double decker tram.
cute. cheap, cute and not crowded. Electronic displays telling you the next stop. have a travel map and you are set to explore downtown Hong Kong

A great and inexpensive way to explore.. Outside rush hour a great way to travel. Go in at the back and out at the front. For convenience use an Octopus card for this and other public transport.Use the upper deck and look down the side streets for markets. A great experience!

All aboard for a quaint and leisurely ride along Hong Kong island. What a lovely way to explore Hong Kong Island. As a newbie to HK, I found the tramway made for a great little excursion, alongside the locals, who make good use of the service. You can ride as far as you like east to west or vice versa and to all points in between for HKD 2.30: use the city's excellent Octopus card (purchased from MTR stations, you can load it with cash at MTR stations, 7-eleven stores, Circle K stores and other outlets. It's valid for buses, trams, the Metro and ferries and makes life a lot easier). Tram stations are in the middle of the street. Enter from the back of the tram and exit front, paying on exit. Sit back and enjoy the ride, taken at a slower pace so that you can soak up the street life all around you. I headed up top (these are two-tier trams with windows open to the fresh air and I would enjoy edging my way to the front and when one was free, bagging a front seat for a great view). The tramway has an interactive map (https://www.hktramways.com/en/interactive-map/) on its web site so that you can scout out attractions such as Hong Kong Park, the Peak Tram and various districts such as Central, Wan Chai, Happy Valley and the Mid-Levels, where you can ride the escalators to Hong Kong's trendier parts. All the stops are numbered for both routes East and West so it's easy to plan a trip. I got the tram from the Quarry Bay area and travelled West towards Admiralty, alighted at 64W, took the escalator from Pacific Plaza next to the stop, alighted at Hong Kong Park, spent time with the exotic plants and birds in the walk-through aviary and conservatory, ambled over to the Peak Tram terminus and caught a vertiginous ride to the top of Victoria Peak with panoramic view across Victoria Harbour. Travelling by tram might not always be so convenient or as quick as the excellent metro (which runs both on Hong Kong Island and on the Kowloon side), but it makes for a quaint, relaxing way to explore. You can also become a bit of a spotter, as I did, and look out for the historic number 120 (all the trams are numbered and come in a variety of cheerful colours and almost artful advertising), the oldest tram on the network. Get on board and have fun. Ding! Ding!

A piece of history. I loved riding on the skinny HK tram! I felt like I was in a little piece of history. Windows open to let in the cooling breeze and upstairs seats offer a great view of the streetscape. Practical too as it is a good means of transport.
Fun and unique way to travel through Hong Kong. A fun way to travel through Hong Kong. Similar to the experience of riding in a double decker bus - Make sure you sit up top.
Must have a ride on the Trams. Mix with the local islanders and ride the tramways Ding Ding very cheap and covers most of the island but not the main land
See the city fron second deck!. Probably the easies way to see Central part of the city. We did realy enjoy it at evening. And it coast almost nothing. Be aware of possible crowed at daytime

Slow and Steady. I caught the tram on a wet morning at the beginning and travelled to the terminus. It rattled along and from the top I could look down on the people going about their daily business. Hong Kong is never still
a must do. it's a must do to ride on the trams . just remember to have the correct change or you will upset the driver
Amazing. Great to travel around HK on the proper old style English trams. Cheap as chips and an amazing authentic local experience.

Ok, if you have nothing else to do.. It's an institution, but it's crowded, hot and sweaty so it's an "experience" that you can miss and that's ok, there's lots of other things to do
To get off follow any elderly Chinese riders, they can be vicious but they clear a path effectively.

The Lady Is Not A Tramp. 5 of us on the Ding Ding. Cheap, effective and charming way to travel. Almost rickety but leisurely. Upper deck travel is more fun. Heard there are plans to shut down this service. Do they have replacement experience better than the Ding Ding?

A better way to sightseeing Hong Kong Island. The tram is cheap. A nice way to roaming around Hong Kong Island and see the city. It is slow and can be too crowded, but once you able to sit, just enjoy the view.

Brilliant way to see parts of Hong Kong Island. Like the Star Ferry this costs 2.50 HK dollars and is worth every penny for a real HK experience
Take out an hour and spend a tiny amount of money for such great fun and a great way to see parts of the island
a unique way to discover Hong Kong island in a cheap way. its a unique experience, especially if sitting at upper deck. Wonderful way to discover Hong Kong Island, and its cheap. Often crowded

Upper deck view. Visited Hong Kong during their tourism promotion. We were given a pair of tram vouchers each. So one wet day during our trip, we decided to do the rides. We took the tram from Wanchai to Kennedy town and to North Point. The rides were very slow with many stops allowing us to literally soak up the atmosphere of this very busy island of Hong Kong. Only thing it didn't have was airconditioning. From the upper deck we had full view all the way. We saw modern shopping malls to financial office buildings to shops selling dried goods, markets and residential buildings. On another day, we rode the tram again and this time to Happy Valley to dine at a one Michelin star restaurant Pang's Kitchen. Apparently the MTR doesn't come this way so riding the tram was the cheapest and most scenic form of transportation here. Each trip cost only HK$2.30. Payment can also be made using the Octopus Card. You can download the maps of the various routes onto your mobile phone to plan your tram sight seeing trips.

You must do this at least once in your life. Out of the dozen or so times I've visited HK, I never miss an opportunity to take the Tram. It is one of the sublime pleasures of the island, and (along with the Star Ferry) a must-do in your lifetime. It's not fast, but it's cheap and allows you to take in the full sights of the skyscrapers along Victoria Harbour.

Cheapest way to view the city. Whenever I go to HK island, I will take tram so that I can view of the city. The fare is also low. During rush hours, the trams are full of crowded. I highly recommend you to experience it.

Old world Charm in a Modern Metropolis.. Along with the famous Star Ferry, the Tramways (Ding Ding) is a very iconic way to get around Hong Kong, very cheaply and in a very cool way. They are very frequent, very good value and just in sharp contrast of old world transport alongside the cleaning office towers they pass by. Amazing!

Feel part of real Hong kong. We took the team to North point - what enormous fun - see the markets of Wan Chai and North point from the top floor vantage of the tram. See all the construction work happening and really feel part of the real Hong Kong

You haven't been to Hong Kong if you have not taken the tram. The tram is very popular among the locals and tourists, it's cheap, it may be crowded (especially during rush hours in the morning and late afternoon when people off work) BUT, it is very special, do take the tram when you are in Hong Kong.

Take the tram for the view. The cheapest way to see Hong Kong Island, and the most fun and relaxed. Using your Octopus card you can sit on the top deck and work out your way around Hong Kong Island, enjoying the sights and working out where you want to visit
Incredible fun. I'm so glad the trams are still there in Hong Kong. It was 2 HKD for a single fare (I think!!) and it's a really fun way to travel along Hong Kong Island.
Airy ride. Take a ride , but be prepared to get squeezed . Durng daytime and rushhours the Trams can be very full.

Ms. Great value and amazing of course if you have enough time to explore then taking the tram is smart and cheap way to see the island from west to east u can just sit back and relax to enjoy the busy local street of course if you would like to get off in between station and explore whatever you see very convience Don't miss!

Reminder of days gone by. A bit shaky and certainly a really fun ride, the tram is a great way to see the city. Sitting in the front seat upstairs gives you a commanding view! This is an experience not to be missed, been around a long time
super. clean ,timely through the city roads an awsome experience for a one time traveller in hong kong.super experience

Best way to have a glance of Admiraly, Central & the western district. The tram ride all the way from western district to eastern part of HK island and i would suggest the visitors to take the part from admiralty to western district as there r lots of iconic building located along the tramways - pacific place, Lippo centre, old & new bank of China tower, Chater Garden, HSBC HQ, Former legislative council BLDG, statue Square, Standard Chartered bank BLDG, Landmark, Alexandra house, Wing On, Central Market, The Center, Western market, Lin Heung Tea House & followed by dried seafood shops etc. you can feel the development of HK in the past 100 yrs.

Verry well maintanined and unique transportation. I took Ding Ding with my family and we enjoyed the ride. The Tram is in good condition and clean. However it is lack of information about Tram's route so we were a little lost in Central Hong Kong and we had to took another transportation to go back.
Go back in time!. No air-conditioning like the buses or underground, but sitting on the top deck watching the world below while travelling at a slow pace is great.
Not so great. Though it might be iconic, I did not feel the experience as great. With no air conditioning inside, it was suffocating inside, hence had to get down just after 2 stops
Historical, beautiful and cheap. Cheap rates. Wonderful for travelling in the central area. Very interesting and historical.I love this so much. Predictable timing as it is not part of the traffic.

Ride the "Dings Dings" for a future Hong Kong Experience. Riding these ageless trams transports you back to the turn of the century. Brightly colored with the famous clang-clang bell - it's Asia's answer to the San Francisco trolleys.

Classic Hong Kong Still Alive . Many times I been to Hong Kong and I prefer to stay in Hong Kong Island and one of the reason behind is I would love to move around with Tram only, cheaper that any transport and frequency is like every minute there's tram... if you want to have some fresh air in the evening and explore the des voux road or wanchai get in sit on upper deck .. it's just 2.30$ for trip until the last stop or just for 1 stop ... DING DING
Fun way to sightsee. we used our Octopus Cards & jumped on board. They are a great fun way to travel. A must do when in Hong Kong.

Ding Ding trams a part of Hongkong history. Pros: 1. Riding the tram gives you a sense of old Hongkong
2. Cheap ( Hk$2.30adult, Hk$1.20 kids )
3. Clean
4. Efficient
5. Fun ( riding on the 2nd floor deck )
Cons: 1. Trams on Hongkongside only

I could ride the trams all day!. Cheap and iconic transport that must be experienced. It's so good that just getting on a tram and going to the end of whatever line you find yourself on is worth it. Shau Kei Wan, Happy Valley, Kennedy Town; they're all fascinating places to see then get back on the tram for a return trip, all for HK$2.30 a trip!

Inexpensive and gives another perspective. Inexpensive way to get around and to see Hong Kong from the top of a tram. However, no air conditioning and difficult to enjoy when the weather is super humid.

Trip back in time. I used the tramway during the HK7s this year to travel the length of HK I to the far end of Wanchai to meet friends. I have been to HKI for 20+ years but not travelled this way since then. Not much has changed and the 'bone shaking' experience is still fun and enjoyable.Make sure to make your way to the front to get off in good time if the tram is very busy....

A must for tourist. nice ride. the antique trams are good for foto. the view from the high upperdeck is nice. cheap fixed fare. suitable for sight seeing. not suitable if you are in a hurry, it runs slow at stops at so many stations..

Ancient ride. The line is only available on the hong kong island and not in Kowloon or any other island. The ticket is fixed 3.20 hkd. The view and ride are both nice. The tram takes combing through the skyscrapers in hong kong island as you witness every building, store and locality pass by you slowly. The streets, lanes and bylanes are all but a slow blurry experience. Tram does not provide ac so you can smell and hear the entire island while you traverse through time reaching your desired destination.
A great way to see the city!. Very shaky and rickety but a lot of fun, they're a great way to go around and see the city, especially if you're upstairs and sitting at the front!
Very cute trams. Not to be missed. Make sure you have the correct change. Very fun experience and great way to enjoy the hussle.
Fun to do and watch the city. Make sure you have some change before you get on.Fun to do sit back and watch the city go by and expereince Hong Kong.its very cheap
Cheap transport. Cheap, Cheap< Cheap a lovely way to get around Hong Kong. There are lots of stops with one coming by every 2 minutes.

A wonderfully old-fashioned way of travelling.. With sleek modern trams in so many cities nowadays these trams are a reminder of the types that were foolishly swept away in the UK (at least). They are a useful service on the routes on which they operate (only in Victoria).One a hot day the ventilation of the open windows is welcome, and the views entertaining.An unusual feature is that of paying on leaving the tram (at the front), which can be done by cash or an Octopus card.

Clunky but fun - definitely not efficient!. We rode the Ding Ding from one end to the other, just to see what was there. It goes so slowly that you get a good feel for the places it visits. Look for Number 120: it is one of the oldest and still has wicker seats, which are also the most comfortable ones. If getting too and from faster and in A/C, take the MTR or one of the many double- decker busses which are a very good deal.

Original. A nice way to see the city. Noy really fast, but makes you think about Hong Kong's old times.So if you have a little time to spend and you are up for a trip to the past, don't miss the ride.

Ding ding tourist.. The Ding or Ding Ding is the most fun you can have for 2.20 HKD. I always allow a day or two to sit for 3 - 4 hours on the ding and take photos, see: http://www.lc-stars.com/hongkong0.html for photos

Nostagia Plus. I love these old trams, they bring back a lot of memories. They are cheap, run quite a long way and they are slow. But that's fine with me. I love the bustle and the throwing in of coins in the box although I understand they now take the HK Oyster travel card

'Must do' when in HK. Quirky way to get around Hong Kong. The trams are slow in rush hours compared to MTR but a convenient way to get around the Island if your starting and end point are around tram stops. The ride is seldom comfortable but that is part of the charm.Payment is either in cash or by octopus and you only pay when you exit. Definitely a fun thing to try when visiting town or simply getting from A to B.

Good way to getting around. One of many British heritage, gives charm and grace to the tours in the city....Its really easy to getting a ride , and many local residents use as a common transportion ; all trams has lots of propagand in their body , making a unique ding ding
Cutest thing ever!. definitely cute and its SO hongkong! its cheap too! less than 4 hk dollars and you can just go anywhere you want! i like calling it dingding car lol.

Quick travel. Quick way to get around the island and still see the view. It's cheap too, each ride is HK $2.30 and you can use your Octopus card here too. Look out for the specific routes at each tram stop.
On the island take the tram. Goes past all the big hotels and shops . Prada Gucci Armani etc . Macdonalds and sogo . Really cheap and cool adverts on the side

Interesting experience in city. Economic and direct transport on hongkong island, romantic touches can show the basic life of hongkonger, safe and cozy maintains attracted customers, a recommended ride for tourists especially at non peak hours.

A must try when u at Hong Kong island!. Love the ride ! best way to explore Hong Kong island !! a must try before you visit any places! http://nanapatricia.blogspot.com/2015/08/magical-hong-kong-free-easy.html
Fast and Cheap... Worlds largest fleet of doubledeck tramcars:-). If your a tourist and wants to go around Hongkong, you should try this:-)

Culture destination. If you're visiting Hong Kong, you must go on a tram ride at least once to experience this unique culture. It's the cheapest transport to go through the island and see all the main attractions!
unforgettable. even if it does not fit to the size of modern people and as no air conditioning, it is a nice mean of transportation in Hong Kong
A must do. Loved these rickety relics of a bygone era, the double decker tram system is over a 100 years old and is inexpensive and efficient. Hop on one, sit upstairs and enjoy the city.

Very Traditional Transportation in this Modern City. You can't imagine there is such traditional transportation still exist in this modern city. They are historical and a great transportation in the Hong Kong Island side. Not to mention the fare of them is quite low too!

Cheap with great fun!. Very traditional transportation in HK Island. Good to ride a trip for sightseeing. Passing through some historical locations and a taste of old Hong Kong as well as a modern city!
Worth a ride. Its fun to travel by Tramway in Hongkong and get the feeler of hustle bustle of the place. Tickets are cheaper.

Slow, noisy, cheap and fun. I think most riders are locals enjoying the $2.30 fares (so if you incorrectly tap the card while getting on instead of off, as I did, it won't break the bank) and putting up with the glacial speeds, lack of aircon and getting stuck in traffic. However, it gives you a great look at the island's streets and you can do the return trip on the MTR.

old but great!!!. the "Ding Ding" is a great ride back into the past of Hong Kong! while it is slow (and lots of times crowded!) its dirt cheap (2.3 HKD anywhere!!!) and if you get a nice window seat on the top you have the time to take lots of pics. the directions are color coded on the front - so as long as you know where you want to go you can traverse west to east plus Happy Valley and see a lot of Hong Kong!
Cheap, easy and amongst it. Although the prices have risen since I first came to HK, the increase was very marginal, making this the chea

Great fun.. Like the Star Ferry, Hong Kong trams are a part of living history. Slow, but cheap, the upper deck gives you a great view of Hong Kong life as it goes by at an average speed not much faster than walking pace. The trams used to follow the waterfront which means everything to the North is reclaimed land. Recently, a city planner has suggested they be scrapped. I hop not!

Best way to go around the island at night.. Yeah, it doesn't have air conditioning, but it's cheap (2.3 HKD), and gets you from one part of the HK island to another. Trams are frequent enough, and come on, where else are you going to see a double-decker tram?

Ride the Ding Ding!. Attention tourists! You definitely need the Ding Ding experience. It is one of Hong Kong's authentic transportation, so get a chance to ride it while they're still easily accessible. (you'll never know when HK decides to modernise everything!)Although it's not at all air-conditioned, it is super cheap and also a great way for sight seeing.

Hilariously memorable ride. My ding-ding experience was truly hilariously memorable. I took the MTR from Mongkok till I reached Kennedy Town and spent some time enjoying the sea view at the boulevard. After some walking, I found the parked ding-ding and took a seat at the second floor. With a map on my lap, I started checking out the scape as the ding-ding moved along. To cut the long story short, I had already completed the entire stretch from Kennedy to the other end without knowing it! I was highly disoriented at that time, expecting the distance from one district to the other to be longer. I didn't notice when th tram turned back and found myself staring at the buildings of central the second time around. Thus, I got off at Wan Chai laughing at my faux pas.

Great, cheap fun!. A fantastic way to get the lay of the land for very little money. Just hop on and ride and watch the city unfold around. You pay when you exit, and it is only HK $2.30. We spent a good amount of time taking time lapse videos and people watching.

Our Tramway Rides 2009 through to 2013. We love the Tramways (Ding Ding) we call them Trolly Buses because they remind us Aussie's of our skinny shopping trolleys lol this is a terrific way to get around the busy streets hop off when and wherever you like very very cheep

A great way to experience the original Hong Kong. These have to be the tiniest trams in the world. The HK developers are trying to do away with them but it would be a crying shame. They are a wonderful remnant of old-world Hong Kong. Just be ready to get squashed!

Add this to the must do list. This has to be the cheapest and one of the most convenient form of transport one can ever find. The Ding Ding can take you from Kennedy Town to places as far as Shaukaiwan in less than $3 dollars. Just check the front to see where it goes before you jump on, there are some that goes to Happy Valley, but generally it's one straight route that takes you through central and Wanchai area, simple!My recommendation is to ride on the top deck, apart from having better view and more fresh air, you can always find a seat easily. I make sure I ride on it every time I am in Hong Kong, it brings back memories! Just miss the baby carriage it used to tow along!

Great way to see Hong Kong. This tram goes a long way for HK $2.30. Got on at Central and proceeded to the top deck. Saw a lot of Hong Hong such as Admiralty, Wan Chai, and Causeway Bay. After an hour and a half, we still have not reached the end of the line. So we got off and took the more expensive MTR back. A nice inexpensive way to see Hong Kong neighborhoods without having to walk around especially on a hot day - no a/c on the tram though.
interesting transport in hong kong. Ding ding is a form of transport in Hong Kong. Saw this on hong kong dramas and always want to take a ride on it when i was there!

Best way to see the Hong Kong city. If you get an opportunity please board the Hong Kong tramway which is popularly known as 'Ding Ding'. It will take you within the city and it is the best way to have a look at this beautiful city of Hong Kong. The fare ja extremely cheap. It's HKD 2.00 and you can travel in it from one end to the other. Yeah its bit crowded during the rush hour and it is slow too. But for a tourist it is must and best thing to do when in HK

A must try experience that cost nothing!. If you've been to San Francisco, you will hop on one of those trams. It's one of their icon.In Hong Kong, it's the same! Only that it travels from quiet residential area to the busiest shopping area in the island and then cut through the heart of a crowded business area (while all traffic are jammed but your tram is the only transportation that moves without being affected on the ground). It's also good for tourist to hop on and off between locations like Tin Hau (Victoria Park) and Causeway Bay (Sogo Department Store) or Causeway Bay to Wanchai (Computer center / Convention Center)However, you have to be smart to avoid some peak hours where you could find yourself like a tin fish in the tram. Avoid weekday 7-8am, 12- 2pm, 5- 7pm, where people get to work, lunch and back home. Avoid Sunday from morning till evening coz most of the domestic helpers in HK will pack each tram and travel from Tin Hau to Central where they meet their friends. Go to the top deck as it usually has more space and as a tourist, you get to see more. Another tip is choosing the right route. If you head west from North Poing / Causeway Bay and want to go to Central district. You can hop on to any of the trams but not Happy Valley. If you want to go to Sheung Wan's Dried Sea Food Street, you should only hop on any trams but not Happy Valley & Western Market. In any chance, you can have a look of their website. (not suggest to buy the 4 day ticket unless you know you travel at least 20 times in 4 days.)Enjoy~~!

Good experience. We almost skipped out on riding the tram just cause we kept procrastinating about it. On the day we were leaving we just decided to hop into one and we were so glad we did! Wonderful experience with open windows in the top deck. It is great that it was so cheap as well. Definitely don't miss out on this experience even if you hop on it just for a while!

Love Ding Ding. You really need to try this one. Strolling around Hong Kong Island slowly and with style. Very cheap fare. Great for tourist. I don't know if they are going to take them down any time, so take tram while it still exists.
Cheapest transportation you can get. When everything is getting more and more expensive in HK, it's good to be able to take the tram for a couple of coins.

A must for any visitor to Hong Kong. This is a great way to see the north side of Hong Kong Island. Only $2-3 for a journey. Just board at the back and take a seat upstairs at the front if you can. Pay at the front of the tram when you get off. It's an experience to match the Star Ferry especially at night, through Admiralty and Central. The only downside is that they are not air conditioned and they can be slow compared to the buses or the MTR.

Ride this till you drop, lol. Yes...you can take ding ding/tram from the first station till the end of station with only one fare. You should try this transportation when you come to hongkong. It is fun. Don't forget to bring your map of hongkong, this transpotation only avail at hongkong island. Traditional way in the modern life of hongkong
Cheap way to get around. These ding ding's were great, we travelled on them a couple of times and went right down past causeway bay, discovered many street markets along the way

An awesome trip. The tram is surely a wonderful transport to travel at Hong Kong Island (for its view). You can surely take many pictures here. But cuz its slowness, is not recommended for a major transport mode travelling, use MTR instead. Also, if you want seaview, maybe is not for you as tram is running in streets behind the harbour too. But for short trips is for you. The fare is just very cheap, it's HKD2.3 or USD0.3 or GBP0.2.

A perfect tour to view the city in Hong Kong Island.. Choose a less crowd tram and find a seat on the upper deck. You will have a good experience in watching the city and the crowd from a relax position. The tram is slow and perfect to watch the details of the messy buildings and business skyrise construction. The ticket is very cheap for such a nice city tour

An icon of HK Island. These can only be found on Hong Kong Island, where I live. They are super cheap: around $2 HK. They are a bit slower than buses and the MTR but it's cheap and fun. It's a classic way to travel. Tip: Board through the back, exit the front. Pay via Octopus as you leave.

Ding, ding. This is a fun way to traverse East to West, cheap and convenient. I'd suggest getting up top and don't try and keep looking right and left, just look out one side going one way and opposite coming back. At nighttime get one of the old units with no windows, during the day get a aircon one.
great way to get about. what a fantastic way to get about especially when its peak rush hour , the trams just wizz along . very cheap way to get about . a must do in Hong Kong

Hong Kong public transport icon. The tram is a good alternative to travel between the neighbouring districts in Hong Kong island. You get to see the face of the neighbourhood up close, which you cannot get if travelling by subway. These are open air trams and it can get pretty warm inside if you're travelling on a hot, muggy summer days. Definitely not recommended if you have tons of luggage as the trams offers very tight space and are ALWAYS crowded!
Cheap n easy transport. Cheap for travel on longer distance as there charge flat rate. Convenient to places far from MTR BUTSometimes can be very pack

These are great. Excellent way to view the city.. These are a great way to view the city.Go for the top deck and view parts of the city you would not see any other way.Stay on as long as you like and pay the fee ($2.30) when you leave.Lots of fun.

trams, lots of fun. Trams were very fun, a little small for taller people, but the family really enjoyed being on trains in the road! I would say that if you have small children make the trams a must do fun activity.

HK Trams :). A trip to Hong Kong will not be complete if the tram is not tried. It is quite cheap and a seat in upper deck will help us enjoy the sights in the entire route. It will be crowded and slow, but you will not be able to find a cheaper transport in HK.

A cheap and easy way to see Hong Kong.. We spent several hours riding the trams. They have two storeys and are ridiculously cheap. This is a great way to see the city! You can stay on the tram as long as you like and there is a discount for the over 65s. There is only one price for the tram, and you pay on disembarking. Have the correct amount, though!
Fun, old-fashioned transport .. Maybe not the quickest mode of transportation but a lot of fun to sit on the upper deck and do some people watching.
find a seat at the upper deck. The good way of a cheap city tour. Find a seat at the upper deck and enjoy the ride between the skyscappers.
Visitor. Good experience but was always packed like sardines. The double decker was good and gave a good view of the streets sights of HK
HK Trams. I love the HK Trams! You can use your Octopus card or just pay HK$2.30 anywhere. This is just an awesone experience... Ding Ding.
Slow and crowded but a must-do.. A must do adventure on a trip to Hong Kong. Very cheap and a chance to travel with the locals. Expect it to be crowded most of the time but worth the experience.
Nostalgic and funny.. Cool! Go to the top, sit right in front and watch the shops and traffic from an elevated point of view. A nice experience for all ages and cheap! Don't miss it.

World's best, most fun way to travel.. My favorite of all! I love these trams so much. They look great, there are plenty of them and they're just so much fun. Sit upstairs, get a great view of the streets, the market alleyways in Wan Chai, make notes of points of interest to return to. Use your Octopus card at the front as you leave the tram. Fantastic!

A great way to see HK. So cheap!Get on and ride to Western and then all the way to the eastern end of the island for one price.See sights you'd otherwise miss on foot, in a taxi or a tour bus.Hot in the summertime but comfortable in the winter.Go upstairs and get the 4 seats at the front. Forget the time and just trundle along soaking up HK.Good for young and old alike.
Old style travel. We rode the trams again for the umpteenth time. We never get sick of this. Rolling through Hong Island in the trams surrounded by the noise never gets old

Crowded and no aircon option for HK transportation. We only tried Ding-ding because of my husband's nostalgic feeling about his childhood. Otherwise I will prefer MTR which is faster and cooler. Ding-ding is very very narrow and no aircon. So with HK heat & crowd, I found it not too appealing to go around with.

HOP ON A TRAM IN HONG KONG. I'm in HK for a few months, and I LOVE the HK Trams. It's my thing to do when I'm in no hurry to get home and have place else to go. Or sometimes I'm just sitting in the tiny flat a bit bored. I'll hop on a tram in any direction on a nice night and watch the city go by or go just to leave my apartment. If I'm in Central I will always take the tram over the MTR on a nice evening to Kennedy Town. I think it's only 30 cents for me to get home. It's just the best way to see HK and if you wanna hop on and off because you see something you want to explore that's cool too because it's so inexpensive. Gotta take the TRAMS. :-)

Cheap and slow way to discover Hongkong. Hong Kong Trams traverse the Northern part of Hong Kong Island on an East-West direction. The trip is very cheap (HKD 2.3) and very unique experience and a sightseeing attraction on its own. Operating Hours are 5.30 am to midnight
Easy way to get around Hong Kong. Love using the trams when we stayed in Hong Kong at Island Pacific Hotel.. A great way to get around, and easy to understand and navigate.

Charming mode of transport. This reminds me of childhood visits before they built their MTR. If you're only going a few MTR stops try the tram instead, you get a nice street view from upstairs and can people watch which is always interesting.At 20p it's worth just going on one with no destination in mind.It stops every 200 metres or so. You can pay using Octopus card.
be ready for a big smile. you will not believe that people fit in this but they sure do and you will leave with a big smile on your face. you must pop up on one even if you go just to the next stop

An interesting way to see Hong Kong. For a very nostalgic way to see Hong Kong, this is good. However bear in mind, it is NON-air-conditioned so if you are there in the summer, it can be hot though the windows are opened.Can get crowded at times but take the upper deck for a bird's eye view. Nonetheless, nothing beats walking along the streets of Hong Kong!

Best way to see Hong Kong ISLAND (north side). If you are not in a hurry! Otherwise MTR would be quicker. And of course taxi is more direct to where you want.Whether it is first time visitor or repeat travelers Ding Ding Tram is actually my preferred method of transport on the Island side (not available in Kowloon, New Territories nor Lantau Island) not because it is the cheapest (currently @HK$2.30, accept Octopus also), but because of it's over 100 years history and most interesting way of seeing HK. A very unique perspective that MTR, taxis do not provide. Buses have similar heights but you cannot open the windows. As many times as I have used the tram I always enjoy the scenery above street levels, you get the feel from older neighborhoods on the western ends (Kennedy Town, Sai Ying Poon etc) as well as the eastern ends (Shau Kei Wan, North Point) and of course the business district of Central and the shopping areas of Wanchai and Causeway Bay. Here's an excellent link from their website:https://www.hktramways.com/There are different lines that have different end stations, many of them with overlapping routes.If you can, find a seat on the upper deck for better view. Though for most westerner beware of your heads if you are standing especially if you are over 6 feet tall. There are currently no Air Conditioning (though there are couple prototypes in the work) so summer or winter or heavy rainstorm can be a little harsh, but that adds to the fun (besides there are windows that one can slide up and down or tilt inward for venting). On a beautiful day when it is not hot, humid nor bone-chilling, with the windows opened and a slight breeze in your face, you just cant help but have a smile on your face.You really cannot get too lost on the tramway even if you overshoot or undershoot your station since they are separated by short distance in between most stops. Hong Kong people are mostly a friendly bunch and you can always ask for help if you get lost.Oh you enter through the back (turnstiles) and exit through the front (where the tram operator stands) and that's when you pay (Octopus or cash).A must try for Hong Kong visit.

Ding Dings are the way to go!. Though I feel bizarre rating a tram system, I can't help but give this 5/5 because the Ding Ding is the heart of Hong Kong Island. At only 2.3HKD a ride, it is a lovely way to wind down on your way from work or to travel short distances as you tour the Island (I.E. from Central to Admiralty or North Point to Causeway Bay). The renovated trams are MUCH nicer and have individual seats and a much cleaner look. The older trams are more traditional albeit a bit drab. Definitely try out a ride on the tram and sit in the front of the second story. It's a great photo opportunity and view.
A retro treat. So cheap and such fun, the tram harks back to another age. It's really easy to just jump on and travel the length of Hong Kong island, pay on exit, fixed price
old school Hong Kong experience. It is comfortable to take the Ding Ding in the evening.With the breeze and the neon light ,you can relax easily in the busy hk life.

ding ding ding. trams are an easy and convenient method to move around albeit a little restrictive as it is confined on the island. however, its cheaper than taking MTR as well as have a better sightseeing view than being in one underground. its a great way to move around from one end to the other. yes, it could be crowded during peak times and difficult to snake your way to the exit at the front if you are stranded in the back end during peak time. nonetheless, for those havent been onboard one, its a good experience.
Hong Kong DING DING. If you go to Hong Kong again this is worth doing . cheap take it to the end and back again only about 30min
must do. you have to ride a tram when you are there. it takes you from Central to Causeway Bay and is a nice alternative to the MTR. It is very cheap, Tip, you have to pay when you get off ...
Dont miss it!. Great experience - nice slow trip through the Hong Kong suburbs. A definite high of the Hong Kong experience.
Sublime!. I wouldn´t miss it. I have travelled all the way a few times and enjoy it each time even if we are in the midst of a heat wave and this tram has no air con...

Great views of Hong Kong city without having to walk! . It was definitely an experience of a lifetime to hop on one of these! I travelled from Fortress Hill to Admiralty. The best spot is on the top level of the tram right up the front.
One of the things you should do in HK. The tram is one of the Hong Kong tradition. Should be if you are there but you can only see them in Hong Kong Island.
Up you go. They take you around the best places and if you go upstairs , the view is unsual and you can see around the streets and the crowd. Do not forget your Octopus Card .

Very Budget Activity for Visting Hong Kong Island Side. It is good for all of you if you want to sit in tram to visit whole hk island.You can just pay only few dollars for taking this long tram Bad: it is not air conditioning tram, so it should be hot for you
Ding Ding. I always like to ride on ding ding and view the whole city arround u. it's not a fast transport, it's more like for tourist enjoy to watchinh the signs along the way.
Great experience although not advance. complicated networking, slow and hot, limited seats and lousy service but great experience to sit in it.

Old school travel for 30 cents. When I'm bored I just hop on a tram and go around the city. It's only 30 cents and you get to go through a lot of different neighborhoods. Great if you want to hop on and off again because it's only 30 cents. Great at night with the city lights too.

Takes you back. Great experience, but they are very small, noisy and the seats are not overly comfortable. Although they have their own tracks they are still subject to traffic (in a bad way). But you have to experience them at least once

A great history lesson for both kids and adults. Our hotel was on Connaught Road so getting this cheapest form of transport was amazing. It is slow compared to buses or the MTR yet my son loved it because he's so into public transport and he noticed that there are newer trams later on in the day. Great observation skills! heheThe popular Octopus card is used on these trams so you are never stuck for small change if you have your Octopus. Unlike the Sydney way of using their similar system of tapping on and tapping off, we only tap off our Octopus card upon getting off the tram. Get a seat upstairs and it's so much cooler for you because their is no air con on these trams plus you get a better view of the bustling life of Hong Kong! Be aware that you get on the tram at the back and get off from the front. The seats are nowhere near comfortable yet well worth the experience of going back in time!

A means of transport for a century. When you have the time and good mood, hop on a tram from Kennedy Town to Shau Kei Wan. The cheapest and most environmentally friendly way to see different districts in Hong Kong.

cheapest mode of transport in HK. cheapest way to travel from one end of HK island to another. Find a spot on the top deck and you would be rewarded with interesting views. Note - It is slower than MTR and buses so plan accordingly

Unofficially the cheapest city tour around. Possibly the cheapest city tour in the world. Hop on a few blocks west of Central, where the trams are likely to be less full. Grab a seat upstairs. The best seats are the ones right up front. Then, sit back and relax as Hong Kong Island unfolds in front of you. When you have had enough, get off at the next stop, cross over to the opposite side and ride back. Be aware that one of the tracks veer off into Happy Valley which is not where you want to be, if you want to get to Central.

not the quickest way to get around.. one of the cheapest ways to get around Hong Kong island although not the quickest way, gives you a chance to see many different areas of the island that you don't get see if travelling on the underground railway system. Trams can get very crowded during the peak times of travel which can make getting off at your stop very difficult as you board from the back of the tram and alight and pay your fare at the front door. whilst riding on the tram i was told the easiest way to get off if you are stuck at the back is to go upstairs and make your way to the front of the car via the top level.

Must do experience. My fiance and I had some free tram tickets to use as part of our big bus tour. It's like stepping back in time, the originally wooden benches and sliding windows very authentic Hong Kong! Suggest a short route as it does take a while, but very cheap to ride.

Reminiscing. This is a traditional and quite convenient way of travel. It is something I think people visiting Hong Kong should definitely experience. It is so different from trams you would see in Europe or other countries and it gives you amazing views along the way.

Colonial transportation system in today's modern context. A rickety tram that moves along the northern shores of Hong Kong island. Seating is cramped but the experience is well worth all the discomfort!
You are set back one century and more; you experience what your great grandfather would have taken to travel from the Eastern to Western side of Hong Kong island!
Definitely worth the time

The Ding Ding Trams a must have experience. It was just on reading some articles online that I got to know of the Ding Ding trams. I was on a bus and when on a whim I just got down and hopped onto a Ding Ding tram and the experience was of having experienced a piece of the Old British transport system. I sat at the top for a good view. The trams are slow, so more opportunities for one to click street photographs. It has a special place in the heart of the people of Hong Kong. However it does not have the comfort of an AC or comfy cushioned seats, but nevertheless a worthwhile experience.
A Must Do. Cheap and easy way to see Hong Kong Island. Used by both locals and tourists alike, this is a great way to see many aspects of the island.

A must do/see when in HK. Like Star Ferries, its like a step back in time, the journey is interesting Many Kodak moments on the route and its dirt cheap. No aircon of course, but its great. A must see/do.
Best way to get from A to B. I felt like a kid every time I jumped on a ding-ding tram and sat at the top front for the view! Affordable fun!

Not recommended to do during summer. We tried the sightseeing route from causeway bay to western market. The scenery was good, its just too hot for us to finish until the end. We were seated at the top level. Maybe next time when the weather is colder, we would give it another try.
Fast, efficient, cool & cheap. Hands down the best way to travel up & down the island. Cool breeze on top deck, cheap as chips & takes Octopus card. Good views too.

A classic pocket change ride into HK's History, HK Tramways. Awesome, one of the World's greatest tramway experiences, these a small, funky historic and absolutely packed and the best way to rumble around on HK Island if you have lots of time and lots of spare SD card space on your camera, as you will keep clicking away. Coins only so make sure you have change in your pockets. Enjoy, again and a again!

Feel like a local while being a total tourist!. Sit up top to check out the changing neighborhoods as you head east or west. Talk to the people sitting up top passing the other direction. Who can't love mass transit with a name like Ding Ding! And remember to take coins to pay on your way out!
A very good way to soak in the sights. Cheap and fun, the kids love it! As it is non-airconditioned, it can get quite hot in summer. But it is an experience not to be missed.
Easy transport. A fun way to get around HK island. Good value and readily accessible - hard to get lost when it only goes in a straight line!

Great way to get a feel for Hong Kong. The tram is a great way to travel up and down the island while at the same time it is a good way to soak up the atmosphere of Hong Kong. It is also very cheap and very efficient. It does get packed at peak times though.If you have time jump on the Shau Hei Wan tram and go all the way to the terminus at Shau Hei Wan. Sit on the upper deck and as people leave make your way to the front of the car. Then simply enjoy the ride. Once you get to Shau Hei Wan go to the Maritime Museum or just come straight back. You will be surprised at how different the trip back seems. A great way to kill a little time while enjoying Hong Kong.

Quaint and nostaglic whilst being effective.. The tram is easy to use and convenient albeit hot. Great way to get from traverse HK E to W and cheap too. You pay as you disembark so have the right change or travel pass.

best view from public transport. This is my absolute favorite way to get around the island. It's a bit more expensive than the MTR per ride, but much cheaper than a taxi. But the real reason to ride the tram is just for the sheer fun of riding a Hong Kong institution, and for the fact that you get a view as you travel, unlike the MTR. Oh, and it 'ding dings' all the time, which adds to the fun. The trams can get a bit crowded, but that's part of the experience. I would not recommend taking large luggage or bags on the tram, as the entrance and exit is pretty narrow and the stairs are a bit steep.

Cheap Transportation to see Hong Kong's Life. I like to go by tram when I am not in a rush! It is a very cheap transportation 2.3HKD per person which basically you can take from start point to end if you want to see how Hong Kong Island looks a like. It is very relaxing and best way to see around. Summer may not be a good choice tho' because of the humidity level if you don't like to get sweat. Tram is usually crowded with local because of its cheap
Comfy and fun. Nice way of traveling and taking in city at a good pace. Try it with kids as they will surely enjoy . The cost isn't much use the oyster card.

Must visit in Hong Kong. Ding Ding is the most cost effective way to explore Hong Kong Island at a very slow pace. Better to go early morning or at night especially when the weather is hot. Take the ride from Western District to North point, and you can see a lot of Hong Kong people everyday life in 2 hours.

Nice way to see Hong Kong . Went on the Tramway because it is an iconic thing to do in hong kong , I was surprised with how slow they moved but as long as you are by a window you get a nice breeze.Would recommended doing this as its a fun way to see Hong Kong.
Hot bus. You have to do it as it is an ICON of Hong Kong. The thing you do not think about until you are on it is there is no air con or breeze and you soon over heat!
Cheap and quick. The Tram is an easy way to move around Hong Kong Island. It also gives you some nice views of the city and all of that for only 2,3HKD!

Cheap N Good. Tis is d cheapest fare public transport in HK . U can enjoyed full view n life on in Hk town. Btw tis tramways very slow got a lot of pit stop station to pickup and also it ll stop when trafficlight turned red. its friendly use to understanding d route n which trams u hv to choose to go ur places. D route just follow d color of which trams u nid to take it. Simple. Im rush backpacker i more prefer MTR bcoz save my times. Btw good experience to have with tis.
Very good. Always a worthwhile trip on the trams. Brings you back to reality.First time we went as far as Kennedy Town with the new Mtr station open, it was worth it.

You just got to do this.. What a way to see the commercial side of Hong Kong Island, cheap, but exiting, if you have the time and happy to have a number bum, take the tram from end to end, it will mean changing trams halway, it is indeed a bum numbing experience but, o so worth it.
worth travelling on and cheap. worth travelling to see the sights cheap as well. the drivers are not really that helpful as English is not really their strong point I found
