Do It. Worth every penny Hop on Hop off great way to get a handle on the city and next day or visit youknow your way around town

Great way to see Hong Kong. A cheap and interesting way to see Hong Kong. Cost is either exact payment of HKD $2.30 or a swipe of your Octopus card upon leaving the tram.Upstairs is best to get a breeze and to view the sights and as it has a roof, some respite from the sun.The trams may not be as fast as other modes of transportation but they certainly have character.This is a great way to get an overview of Hong Kong and recommend it heartily.

The best form of transport in Hong Kong. Cheap and cheerful, these trams wind along the main roads, and are useful tfor those who can't/don't want to walk in the heat. We used them non-stop over a 24 hour period and found them highly reliable and easy to use. Cheap as, but make sure you have correct change for the fares ($2.30 A, $1.20 C)

Ding Ding, anyone?. A definit must try when you are in Hong Kong. Use your Octopus card to get on this inexpensive, slow pace transportation to go from one end of the island to the other end. Get the front seats on the upper deck. Check out the different districts you pass through and make a mental note to come back to those you want to visit again. Do not hesitate to ask the young people questions, they are more than happy to share their city with travellers. The Ding Ding is not for anyone who is in a hurry. If you have a few hours, this is one of the ways to see Hong Kong.

For tourists - not businessmen!. Although not very fast, the tram offers great views of Hong Kong. A 15minute MTR journey took me 45mins, but it was a great way to see HK. Feels like old-fashioned Hong Kong. Get on at the back, and pay the driver at the end.

A quaint way to see the Isaland. A quaint way of travel on the island. Enjoy the view from the top providing the weather is suitable. These don't have air conditioning so a bit hot in summer so do late evening for an experience.
A must. One of those quintessential experiences when visiting Hong Kong. Gives a peak into the past while rushing through the present. Really enjoyed this mode of transport.

Hop in and let it go.... A ding ding trip is an experience worth living before they disappear for good! After dinner, take one, anyone, just let it go until the end of the line and then get back or take another line... Go upstairs and experience the front, side and rear seats with open windows! Enjoy and get a grip when curving :-)

Best way to experience HK. In spite of having other comfortable options of MTR,bus and cab, I have used famous HK Ding Ding for more than 2 years. Yes it is slow, yes it is not conditioned and yes it gets stuck after every bus or car which stops at its path....but nothing can replace the charm of ding ding. One can see all kinds of people using it - from workers to executives, from moms to I'll-do-all-my-makeup-here professionals. If you are a tourist then grab the front most seat and enjoy the HK through the local and lovely mode of transportation. And at HKD2:30 for a ride across the island, it is one the cheapest ways to enjoy this city.
Ding Ding tram is a must for Hong Kong!. These old double deck trams, called Ding Ding are the most interesting and the cheapest way to travel in Hong Kong! This is an worth living experience.

A cool way to travel in Hk. The tramways in HK island is very convinient and something you shouldn't miss riding. It is only HKD 2.3 wherever you get off and you need exact change or better still beep you octopus. The upper decks are better if you want to see the city and life go by. On busy hours it is packed so if you want a seat and want to look around try evenings. The trams are only on the HK side and is a good way to commute and sightsee too.

Must Do At Least One Tram Journey. Cheap, fun, part of HK history - a must do and a great way to see the more western North HK Island part of Hong Kong......bit bizarre that the oldest remaining form of transport (along with the Star Ferry) services some of the most modern parts of the city. Very cheap to do........a one rate fare which allows you to ride for miles along the northern areas of HK Island. Grab a seat at the front next to the open windows and enjoy the ride!
Cheap way for transport around the city by tram. IT is a cheap way to travel, only 2.3 hongkong dollar. Pay with the exact coins, no Exchange possible. From the top level nice view.
Worth to try. It's cheap and it's so Hong Kong. Try it! It's a wonderful experience even though sometimes I got lost somewhere, but just take the opposite way and you're back!

Its the way to get around so cheap. Ok some of the trams are distinctly new and whilst more comfortable do not have the same charm as the old versions they truly are the way to travel along Hong Kong Island. It costs just a matter of pennies to travel regardless of distance and you can pay either by coins or by oyster card as you exit the tram. I stayed on Hong Kong Island so these were my main mode of transport along the harbour front area. They rarely get held up by traffic so travel times are fairly consistent and with open windows they are a great way to see HK and its people. The display as you pay also shows the balance on your card so easy to keep track of your payments.I would recommend early purchase of an oyster card, I got mine at the airport. They are so cheap and you can use them for purchasing food drink as well as transport on the Ding Ding, MTR and ferries.

Fun way to see the City. Used the tram couple of times to go from Central to Wan chai. Took about 45 mins to get from Central to Korn hill. Great way to see Hong Kong as the MTR is mainly under ground. However, the operators aren't sure of stop names or area names! Would recommend checking routes and stop names online. And checking with people sitting on the tram if it goes to that stop!Standard $2.3 per person regardless of distance.

ᖰ　Ding Ding 　ᖱ. It's very Hong Kong.. you see a mix of very Hong Kong people ( local and foreign ) on crowded rides or less crowded rides. It covers Hong Kong Island from East to West or vice versa so one can see the districts change from one character to another. Its convenient and sometimes more so than taxis or mtr subway trains. Its cheap and frequent. If one is lucky enough to catch an old tram, one may see the wooden chairs and stair cases inside the tram which is a piece of our history. Enjoy the ride !

Review of a 13 year old girl. Slow. The trams were slow. Perfect for capturing the scenes of the hectic Hong Kong. I enjoyed sitting on the upper deck as the wind blows on your face and it is very refreshing.

Classic HK experience. Riding a tram is a great HK experience. Get on at the back, and exit and pay at the front. It's cheap. They can get packed out,but part of the fun is trying to get yourself to the front in time for your stop. Starts making your way the front in plenty of time!

What a great, colourful, crazy tramway to be in !!. Here along the main streets on Hong Kong Island, which are parallel with the coast of Victoria Harbour, operate the most incredible designed tramways, I've ever seen in the whole world. They are very popular among the residents and also the tourists, and have gotten the wide spread name, Ding Ding. It is a great fun to take a ride with it, in Financial District, surrounded by the glasses of the skyscrapers and different stores and shops of myriad brands from all over the world. There are the vintage open- top tramcars, in which are held awesome parties, as birthday celebrating, wedding anniversaries, reunions or gatherings. I have taken some ride on it and enjoyed one more time in the views of Hong Kong night life, this time on Island.

Best way to navigate Hong Kong without losing the view. I loved using the trams in HK - SO CHEAP (approx. $A0.50 per ride, no matter how far you go - fare paid on exit of tram) and fairly convenient. They fill up (and empty) fast, so we didn't have any issues boarding the ones we wanted. We were staying on Hennessy Road in Wan Chai so we were able to use the trams to go to Lan Kwai Fong, Causeway Bay, ifc mall and Star Ferry. They are all open air carriages so there is no relief from the heat. However the best thing is that you can SEE everything when you're on the tram, all the while skipping the sometimes horrific traffic. Stops are eastbound and westbound, with maps at every stop to determine where you need to go. Be cautious - sometimes the eastbound and westbound stops are on different sides of the road or spaced out without a crossing in between; do not try and cross against the lights or in traffic.

back to the future. It is vintage tram, and the design is adorable. The coolest thing that was I heard from my hong kong friend, you can rent the tram if you like with fair price.Taking ding din tram it like back to the future.It is old school design which I love it. It is like you travel back to the 80's. If you travel to Hong Kong , do not miss it

Cheap means of transport around hongkong. I bought an octupus card. Everytime i rode the ding ding it cost me 2.30 hongkong dollar. I rode it to go to central, causeway bay, murray road (the peak), victoria park. It was quite slow with many stops but i was not in a hurry. I enjoyed the sights while i rode the ding ding. I stayed at ramada hotel and the dingding stop was in front of the hotel (water street).

A blast from the past. As far as I know, this is the only double-decker tram network still remaining in the world.It is always crowded, slow and noisy. BUT it should be experienced at least once in a lifetime. If you are fit enough to climb to the top deck then you get an unparalleled view of the real Hong Kong.

Highly recommended . A wonderful way to see the different facets of HK. Just hop on at any stop and go straight to the upper deck, find a seat and enjoy the trip. Be prepared with some small change as they don't provide change (HKD$2.30 per ride). We took the tram from central to causeway bay in one of the weekdays afternoon. Although it was packed, we managed to find a place to sit down after a few stops. This was our first tram ride in HK and the view along the way was just awesome. It's like we were watching a live stage play with thousands of actors showcasing the various daily activities of the residents and visitors of this bustling city. Highly recommended.

It's a convenient thing such a 'Ding Ding'. It's quite easy to get in and get off a Ding Ding, because there are plenty of stops within short distance. While sitting on the top deck you may calmly watch the hustle and bustle of the city.

Worst way to get around. The space is very tight, very hot, and I might also have to say it is dirty :(
I would not recommend Ding Ding for a first timer to Hong Kong to take Ding Ding as their transportation options.

WHAT a RIDE. we purchased the Hop On Hop Off Bus Ticket and you get the Tram Ride in the price so worth it amazing. And at the top you have audio to listen to explaining the area etc. Try get up front of tram going up. Come down backwards........

Effortless way to see the city . The morning tram we went on was clean and an enjoyable experience. The evening one was filthy (full of tissues and newspapers and food wrappers) but still a good way to see the buildings and people watch. They are slow but that's part of their charm. Nowhere near as convenient as the MTR so only use if you are dawdling and have plenty of free time and want to see HK island at a leisurely pace!

A great activity and must do for all tourists in HK.. It's an experience to travel up the mountain with the old tram.The only down side is the long ques to get your ticket and onto the tram. Lots of hustling bustling to get a spot on the tram which I felt could have been organized a bit more orderly.

Great way to travel around.. We jumped on the double decker tram at the western market. You can ride it for as long as you like. When you get off you may $2.30...they ask for correct money on several occasions I just put in whatever i had eg $2.50. This is a great way of having a small break and rest but still get a chance to look around. I would recommend this service.
Cheapest transportation in HK. Very cheap fares and easily accessible. A good alternative for short trips within the city. But not very user friendly for foreigners, at least when compared to the MTR
Good way to experience another way of life. Probably the cheapest ride in Hong Kong! it is a great way to experience a large slice of the island from the residential Belchers through central.

Special experience for site seeing. Tramways is quite continence in Hong Kong island. It preformed a different way for experiencing Hong Kong. If your hotel is nearby any tramway station, you should try this and will find out a different perspective of Hong Kong.

hell crowded. Tram experiance is suppose to be good if you get a place to sit and enjoy the ride but their was no control over how many people are getting inside the tram at a time..they should atleast count the people, according to the number of seats and then let them inside...people were pushing each other to get the seat and half of them were standing...even i couldnt got a seat...so i was standing the whole way...and as tram was goin up..peopling were falling on each other...this could lead to some accident in the tram if someone cant hold tight.

check the weather first. If you are visiting on a cool autumn day with not a big crowd then it would have been a very nice scenic way to see Hong Kong especially if you are on the upper deck. But we rode on a hot and humid summer day on a crowded train it is not good... not good at all!! The tram is also a little too narrow... can't pass through the passage freely if carrying a slightly larger bag

Sit on top floor. We only tried this for 5 min, but in our race to do it all in one day, it was a fun experience. It is only running on Hong Kong Island. but it is wonderful to see the busy life around you. It is very narrow and has two levels like a double decker, so sit upstairs. Do it even if you have no specific way to go, this is what we did.
Cheap sightseeing. A good way to see Hong Kong Island, stayed on until the end of the line and took front seats at the top. Fascinating insight to how the locals live. Easy payment with Octopus card.
Rough and ready. You just have to catch a tram because you can. Opt for upstairs. Just jump on any tram catch it anywhere. Its the cheapest city sightseeing anywhere.
Tram HK. Its one of the best part in Hong Kong. Take the upper deck seat to view outside city properly. Its tickets are very cheap. the ride you will surely enjoy.
Nostalgic and easy to use. I use this every time in HK, sometimes to just take a ride and see the sights. Easy to make pit stops along the way and interesting sights even if just riding

See Hong Kong at 10 miles per hour.... When you are in Hong Kong for an extended time, there is nothing like jumping on the tram. Get a front row seat on the upper deck and just watch HK unfold below and around you. Even if your time is limited, just one trip and you will view the city in a whole different way. Same goes for the Star Ferry !

A romantic 'Ding Ding' Tramride. A must try on your visit to Hong Kong. Cost HKD 2.30 per trip (carry exact change, no change given).Take the ride from one end to the other, this gives you time to go upstairs and find a seat right at the front.

The best views of Hong Kong. Travelling by tram has to be done in Hong Kong. The easiest way to do this to purchase an Octopus card (which is similar to the Oyster card in the UK - you can use this on their other transport such as the MTR and buses, as well as in some stores and restaurants). When the trams arrive you enter via the rear of the tram and can either sit downstairs or upstairs and when you depart the tram you pay on exiting which is at the front of the tram. I personally prefer to sit upstairs. The trams are a slower form of transport although you really get to experience the real Hong Kong as you take in the sights and view the hustle and bustle of the streets below. With a flat fare of just $2.30 (approximately 20p) it must the cheapest form of transport around in Hong Kong.

Great way to enjoy Hong Kong if you have a lot of time. I personally love the views you get from riding the Ding Ding. It's just unfortunate that it doesn't have air conditioning. Also, don't expect that this is a fast way to travel around Hong Kong since it isn't. That's why I will only recommend this to travelers who have a lot of time to spare. Otherwise, you are better of riding the MTR.

Entry to the real Hong Kong. Buy yourself an Octopus travel card and jump on the tram (rear door only) find a seat and enjoy a tour with the local from one end of HK to the other, right up the central spine. Had enough, then get off (move to the front and be ready to swipe your card next to the driver) cross the road and go back the same way. The tram is used extensively by locals so it unpretentious and real. The only rule is to stand up for the elderly.A great way to travel and inhale the excitement of HK

Nice way to see local scenes of HK life. One of the few traditional tram rides left around the way. Authentic experience, must try for visitors. There are various routes that you can take. I took the route to Northpoint vicinity and strolled around some street markets.

Great way to travel. Extremely easy to use, cheap and efficient. It goes on the main road so when you get off you dont have to walk far to the final destination in most cases.The only thing is it can get quite packed and it it not air conditioned. But you should definitely ride it at least once for the experience!

Not for summer. Riding ding ding is a unique experience but since there is no air-con, it is quite uncomfortable taking ding ding during summer, especially on the lower level. Otherwise, it's quite good if you are not in a hurry.

Great way to explore the streets. Easy to use, jump on to go one way, get off where you want and pay with your Octopus card as you get off. Look for the stop to go back the other way when you have finished walking around. Get a window seat on the top floor, great sights, not to be missed. The trams look really cool and are great.

Cheap....but no A/C. Costing only $2.3HKD, riding the tram is a very economically way travel when visiting HK. However, unlike the MTR and buses, there is no A/C on board. It was a very long ride from North Point to Central, with the July heat. It was a good experience, and I would definitely recommend it to anyone who can bear the heat (or traveling in the cooler months).

Can try to ride in it if you have time to kill (slow speed). It looks interesting to ride back and forth, but actually it will take a while to go from a stop to another because of its speed and and subject to regular traffic.

retro charme. very nice way of moving in hong kong island, very cheap, just 2,3 Hong Kong Dollar for a single trip no matter if you go one station or up to the final stop. though not recommendable if you are in a hurry

Best & cheapest way to see HK. Hop on and off this tram as you feel like and see HK for what its worth. It mostly not so crowded and the front seats give you a first hand experience of the city. Try this when in HKG

The Ding-Ding Trolly!. "Why don't you take the ding-ding trolly?" said the helpful clerk behind the counter, when I asked if he knew the best way to reach the Central Library. "It goes right by there." These double decker trollies are an historical feature of Hong Kong, so of course I'd seen them, but I had no idea how to ride one - until, that is, the man explained it to me. "Just hop on!" he'd said. And hop on I did. Man, it was so much fun to ride, and got me to where I was headed so quickly, that after that I started riding them all the time. Highly recommended.

Must use in HKG!. I like the Ding Ding in Hong Kong. It's like the red buses in London. Just enter one and go as farenas you like. The same price for all distances and you can pay with the octopus card.

Hop-on hop-off bus alternative. As we were not rushing anywhere, we boarded a tram that was relatively empty so that we could get the front seats on the upper deck. We made 3 trips -- from Wanchai to North Point; from North Point to Kennedy Town; and from Kennedy Town to Happy Valley. The street scenes and the neighborhoods are fascinating. Get on the tram at the back and pay with the Octopus card or the exact fare in cash at the front before getting off.

Best way to visit HK Islands !. If you have time, it's a funny way to see the HK Islands, the tram fare is really cheap ! Be aware, it could be very hot during summer time, and better avoid to take in the peak time, could be very crowded !
Cheapest way to see HK island. Go in for "free" and be ready to pay when you go out. :) nice trams with 2 floors have fix price (few HKD) which is cheapeast way to get tour on HK island.

Fun way to see Hong Kong - if you're not in a hurry. During the less crowded hours this is a charming way to see the streets of Hong Kong. However, in heavy commuter hours - if you have a tendency toward being claustrophobic, avoid this mode of transport.1.2 for children under age of 12 (no matter how far you ride)2.3 for adults (no matter how far you ride)Pay on your way out with exact change or octopus card.

Must try!. Good way to explore the real Hong Kong! It's almost the cheapest historical public transportation in Hong Kong. As its rail is mainly built in the inner part of different districts, so it's very good to take a ride from Central to Causeway Bay or even further so as to see the difference between the commercial areas & the real/old Hong Kong.

Travel in history and see the streets of HK. Travelling by tram is a cheap way to feel like a local, see la good amount of HK and travel on a peice of history. Ow there are a few modern trams so if you want to seek the history watch out for these. They travel pretty much east to west and vice versa with a a few deviations. There is a map on the tram stand and just watch out for the destination on the front of the tram. You enter by the back doors and pay when you depart, and it's the same price regardless of your length of ride. We were the only tourists on one trip and got a seat at the front top, great for pictures and to see the streets and people of HK. Well worth it.

Cheap and Fun Trip. Limited but long route across main areas of Hong Kong Island. Very frequent and cheap. Either buy a multitrip ticket or easily pay as you go - $HK2.30. Make sure you enter at the rear of the tram and pay on exiting at the front.

If you have time in HK take a ride on one, it's fun.. Cheap, fun way to travel if you want a unique HK experience. Try and pick non peak times (steer clear of weekends, especially Sundays if you can) try to get the best seat which is up the top at the front, makes for great video.
Cheap City Tour. Well, with only 2 HKD you can take around the city, it will drive you between all the skyscrapers in Hong Kong.

Slow & Steady. This is the cheapest & easiest way to discover Hong Kong Island. Take 1 day to enjoy the whole network and the interesting places it passes by.
They also have party tram for booking. Checkout their websites!

Great fun for 100+ years and running.... A bit difficult during the hot and humid summer months, but a lot of fun to watch the street scenes as you slowly whisk by in these turn of the century chariots named for their sound.
Oh I wish we have Ding Ding in Singapore. Totally love the ding ding ride. It's a must in HK. Gives you a glimpse in the history while strolling the modern streets
fun way to see HK. Oh man its cheap. two double trecker bus-like trains run by electricity from one end of HK island to the other end. great way to see the city!

relaxing and good for travelers. First it doesn't cost a lot...only few dollars(adultHK$2.3/ kid HK$1.2) you can sit from the beginning til the end. Pay the Fare when you off the tram.....is no change!! Ready your coins!!! No matter how many stops you go you just pay the same fare. It is so convenience........I will suggest you go up level than you can see the street and it is so cool.Why the "Real Hong Konger" called it (Ding Ding) cause the driver will press the bell and the sound is "Ding Ding""""

Easy travel at street level. Well worth giving the Ding Dings a go, because they are there. They can be difficult to get off when the tram is full and busy with people, as there is only the one exit, and if you find yourself stuck up the back and the driver doesn't realise you are trying to get off, you can miss your stop; so be fully aware in advance if your stop is coming up and make your way to the front in plenty of time. Otherwise it is a cute way to travel on the island, and the directions are easy, it is pretty much just a two way system. A good way to get to the other side of the island when you are just casually exploring, just get off where you think it looks like its a bit more lively on the street and you will find yourself in the heart of market alleyways.
Not a Lot To It. Traditional streetcar that is cute and fun to ride when you're downtown. Gets its name from the ding-ding sound of the bell as it traverses the city streets.

Memorial Transport in a Modern City. Hong Kong tramways is an old transport media on Hong Kong Island. It is a cheap, if not the cheapest, but nevertheless cost-effective transport. Unlike to most transport media e.g. Mass Transit Railway which fare will increase proportional to the distance travelled, an adult traveler has only to pay fixed price of HK$2.3 for whatever distance along the tramways. For visitors to Hong Kong, if you are not travelling in a hurry and would like to enjoy sightseeing along Hong Kong Island, Hong Kong tramways is recommended.

It's fun if you are not in a hurry!. I'd like to take the Double Deck Ding Ding in Hong Kong Island. You can see people hustling on the street. They all look really busy. It's fun to ride the Ding Ding if you're not in a hurry.

Cheap Travel but very fun way to get around HK Island. Very fun and cheap way to travel around HK Island. If you have your octopus card its literally cents to travel. It's a fun old style way to see HK Island. Just get on and travel as far as it'll go. Enjoy.

cheap transportation. i like ding ding..cheap and not a long walk transportation. and the plus point is my hotel near one of the stop of this ding ding. just with HKD 2.3 you can explore the north area of Hong Kong Island. so if you have time and no idea what to do, take ding ding is the best choice :)

You gotta do it - but don't expect a seat. If you want A/C, comfy seats and tinted windows, then stay in your SUV back in the mid-west. Ding-dings are convenient and a part of HK culture. Just don't expect to a smooth ride!

Interesting way to see the city. I would recommend top deck, front seat for the best views. The trolleys come frequently so you can wait for one that's not as full. The trolley goes through range of neighborhoods that you might not see otherwise. There's no narration so you are not always sure what you are looking at but it's a very inexpensive way to cover a lot of area.

Cheap travel . Sit at the top deck (off rush hour times ). Relax take your camera and you can travel from one side of the island to the other .from high rise and Gucci to local markets and dry fish. Hop on and off its only $2 a ride

Highly recommended - a great way to see Hong Kong - all the good transport routes. Our entire family enjoyed this tremendously. A nice slow, functional, fun way to see Hong Kong. We also got used to the transport lines and used it to get around to the shops and restaurants. Quite a good range of transport routes and very useful. We will use them every time we go to Hong Kong. Highly recommended!

Transfers in a different kind. These rides traverse along the main city streets. The Vintage like double-decker train that you can find with the city. It is really has a different way of speed, a place where you can find that the elder ones are given priority for seats. Fascinating is the younger cosmopolitan women wearing very high-heeled shoes or boots can stand in the trams for couple of minutes or so.

Romantic, iconic way to see Hong Kong Island. Besides walking around on your own two feet, the trams on Hong Kong island are probably the cheapest and most romantic way to get around and see the sights!They're frequently used by locals to get between popular spots on Hong Kong Island, like North Point, Causeway Bay, Wan Chai, and Central, but if you're an intrepid visitor with some time on your hands, the trams are definitely worth it.I recommend starting in the west at Sheung Wan - you're more likely to get a seat at the front of the tram's upper level. From there, the picturesque scenes of HK unfold before you. The skyscrapers and luxury stores in Central, the busy streets of Wan Chai, the shoppers paradise of Causeway Bay, and the local flavour of North Point's market. There are side spur lines to Happy Valley racecourse and points further east, but those parts get less photogenic, so I suggest only riding up to North Point.It's super cheap and you'll get a great feel of the city from above-ground, one of the few things that the MTR cannot provide.
Travel. A good means of transport to travel in the city of HongKong. Easily available from every corner and the centre of the city.
Ding Ding. For people like me who came from not very developed countries, this might sound stupid, but really I enjoyed every single minute you spend there, try it

Great Public transport. Obtain an Octopus card at the beginning of your stay and enjoy the delights of the HK tramway. Much better than a tour bus as they generally are always on the move. a brilliant way to see the city on a very low budget. Each trip costs about 20p UK/35c US. Upstairs front seats are the best.

Ride Up to Victoria Peak. It was an interesting way to get up to the peak. You are going at a steep incline, so the scenery around you is unusual. It's worth doing it once, but there is no need to every use that method to getting to the top as there are cheaper and I assume faster ways up.

must try. Another unique way to get around HK island, Tram only operate in HK island. slow ride but you got to see HK island in slow motion. Tram is one of the oldest transportation in HK island. Cheap, only less than 3HKD.

Interesting experience. Tram in Hong Kong has a long history. It's very different from other transportation in HK. Highly recommend you all to spend some time to experience a tram ride. But I wouldn't recommend it as a means of "transportation" because it is slow and without air-conditioning, and if you are not familiar with the surroundings, you will miss the stop easily. Yet, it is worthwhile to take the tram at least once in a lifetime to travel along the Hong Kong Island and see the streets.

Picturesque but so dirty. People in the trams tend to be dirtier than MTR (not sure why). There is always used kleenex, food leftovers, etc. I really enjoy the tram rides, but with such level of dirtiness, is better to use mini bus or MTR.

Fun way to see the streets. A fun way to sit back and relax whilst seeing the streets, cheap as well. I had no idea where we were going but it didn't matter as you just cross the street and go back again!
steep ride. A great piece of history and woth the ride but be warned avoid weekends and chinese holidays as the queue gets very long

no report of stop names. we have been to HK several times, but only took once Dingding, and missed the stop. there is no English reminder for the passengers to get off. and if you are not familiar with the surroundings, you will miss the stop without exceptions. so i prefer Taxi or MTR.

Mechincal Rickshaws. This is the best way to view the busy street life of Hong Kong. Start from Happy Valley and all the way to Kennedy Town. It will be a mechanized rickshaw ride at its best. i.e. you do not have to feel guilty about a human transporting you. The best time to ride the Ding-Dings is middle afternoon when there are fewer passengers and no crowding. Skittle up to the top and keep your camera ready. Happy rides.

See HongKong Island. A cheap and easy way to see the HK side of the island as the ding ding traverses the island east to west and the other way. With a sidetrack to the Happy Valley Racecourse. If you have the time and no one in HK does, take the $2 ride during non rush hours and have you camera ready. Entry from the back, go upstairs and exit from the front, where you also pay. Have exact change or buy an Octopus Card. Can't loose. The driver is also the conductor.

Must ride, must ride, bring your Gopro and Camera!!. Tram tour is cheap but yet a premium journey. Why is that? The tram fare is extremely cheap but tram move very slowly that cost you time, which is valuable.Because the tram move so slowly, it enable you to see many things, not within an eye blink. Trams are all double deck, so if you are lucky, jump on upper floor and take the first row. Mount your Gopro and you can create decent time lapse video.I recommend to ride from West to East and if you found any part boring, get off the tram and you will still be in the heart of CBD on this Island.Enjoy :)

See the streetscape!. Great fun although we were a little scared when we got off and quickly caught the next Ding Ding Tram back. Able to use your octopus card and probably best to wait for an empty tram so you can get a seat upstairs.
Out of the way cars, here comes the tram. Fabulous way to travel. Noisy, jerky, but so efficient, cheap and so much fun. Hop on, pay as you leave, just enjoy the experience
Iconic experience. An iconic journey in Hong Kong. Especially in the evening with great colours for photography. In Hong Kong this is well worth the effort
Ding Ding Views. This is a great way to get a feel for Hong Kong Island. You can people watch, ride for very little, and feel the pulse of the surrounding areas.
Good Transport System. Very good means of Transport with Hongkong city . Very Fast & Cheap within the city , well connected to most of MTR Stations .

Just great. Probably the cheapest transportation in Hong Kong. And the most unique. You get on at the back and pay when you leave at the front. Payment with octopus or small change (no change given). The tram isn't fast but steady. Going from east to West on Hong Kong Islands busiest streets. No aircon, but great view. If you can find a seat sit upstairs in front. Can't stand straight anywhere if over 1.75m tall. Tram, Star Ferry and regular ferry to any island are a MUST when visiting Hong Kong.

Absolutely essential. For locals and tourists alike. A vital transport mode full of character and mishap. Just hop on a ride to the terminus, either direction. See the many interesting facets of Hong Kong.
Quick and easy. Stops are announced in Cantonese, English and Mandarin. Cheap, quick, and great views of the city. Grab a seat on the upper deck near the front - and avoid rush hour!

Hop in and hop off tram.. It is very relaxing to sit on the top deck to see the Hong Kong Island. There is no trams in Kowloon. It runs almost in one straight line from one end to the other with around twenty stops. So, you can hop in and hop off when you see a interesting place.

A Piece of history....:). A piece of history that is worth a few rides. Cost is cheap, HK$2, and the Octopus Card is accepted. Tap to go in. The trams cover quite a distance and, if seated in the upper level, offer a good Birdseye view of the area.
Fun way to travel. Inexpensive and a great opportunity for photos. Would recommend using during the day and in the evening (so you can enjoy the lights!).

Easy way to travel. The trams are a lovely way to get around HK. They don't have air con but you don't need it when all the windows are open. These teams are a lovely link to the old Hong Kong. They make a bit of noise and they do wiggle and giggle but this made the ride more memorable. My two young boys really loved every ride we made on the trams
Fun Hong Kong Transport. Fun way to see Hong Kong. Most of the time crowded but worth the ride. Easy to get on and inexpensive.

A 'MUST DO' for any visitor to Hong Kong. These aging historic double-decker trams traverse the entire northern side of Hong Kong Island and are great fun. There are plenty of stops and trams so you don't have to walk far or wait very long to catch one. Hop in at the back and pay exactly $2:30 HK coins into the coin counter next to the driver when you exit - front door only. That fare is per person for as far as you choose to go whether it's the next or last stop. Suggest tourists go straight to the top and enjoy the view, preferably from the front seats, and enjoy the changing views as you travel through financial, commercial and residential areas. I've been to HK many times and I still use them on every visit, I thoroughly enjoy the experience.

A sense of years yonder. While the trams are slow, crowded and rather uncomfortable, it is still a part of the Hong Kong cityscape. They add a good element of how things used to be, and they have a certain charm. The trams are amazingly cheap. So if you don't mind sitting on wooden benches or standing hunched over (if you are tall), then the trams are a good way to get to see Hong Kong, as they travel at a slow pace, letting you view the streets as you travel along.
essential experience. There's no better way to experience Hong Kong Island than trundling along in a tram. Cheap and cheerful!

Very Cheap but Very Hot. These trams are again, a must do thing if you are in the area. Ensure you understand that there are several routes for the trams and the best way to find your stop is to get the stop number from the info board then keep an eye out for your number.The trams we were on were very busy and really hot. They are really cheap to use and you pay as you get off (with exact amount). Board from the rear and exit at the front.
A must for tourist. Along with the Star ferry, this is a must for all tourist. A down side, not pram friendly. An experience of hong kong hertiage.

Best way to see, hear and smell Hong Kong. The tram is your best, not to mention most cost efficient way to explore Hong Kong. Start in Kennedy Town, right by the Merton, so you can head upstairs and grab the front (or back) seats. Don't pay when you get on, and you enter from the back of the tram.Then enjoy Kennedy Town, the scented Sai Ying Pun (are dried goods tied to handrails? placed on the sidewalk?) head past the Macau Ferry Terminal, into Sheung Wan, and now it's Central. The passengers on the tram are changing all the time. Businesspeople, fisherman, children carrying books...this is Hong Kong. Admiralty, Causeway Bay, Happy Valley.... or choose the route that takes you all the way to Shau Kei Wan. Enjoy Hong Kong. At the end of the route, jump off and have some noodles. It's not the swiftest form of transport, but you're not using the tram to get from a to b, you're using it to see and experience HK. All at the bargain price of $2.30 for an adult and $1.20 for a child or senior. Love it.

Tram ride in Hong Kong island. Ride on Hong Kong tram will give you a very local sightseeing experience. You can travel the whole journey from Western district to Shaukeiwan. Western district is famous on chinese preserved food, then central is the banking centre, then causeway bay the shopping area, shaukeiwan, previously the fishing village. You can hop on and off along the whole line. Many locals still use it for short distance, so avoid crowdy time after office hours, ie. 5 pm to 7 pm in week days.
Enjoyable ding-ding ride. Love ding-ding ride way better than mtr and bus...very special and authentic.. Windly and cooling weather is a plus!

Not always 'overcrowded' as some assert. One TA reviewer below asserted that the Hong Kong Island trams are 'always crowded.'This is incorrect, as it depends on the time of day and direction of t5ravel.I used trams most recently on a Saturday afternoon eastbound. There were a few spare seats - 24 on the upper deck plus more downstairs - at all times on my trip.Tourist Octopus cards are not accepted. This could be remedied by talks with MTR and would save tourists looking for small coins.The trams may be an 'archaic British colonial relic to some', but despite their very slow speed (although at peak hours faster than noisy diesel buses whose routes partly parallel the trams) and swaying motion especially over crossovers and points, these Hong Kong trams are a great public transport resource and heavily used by locals and tourists alike.The route frequencies are very good. There are many short workings such as to or from North Point or Whitty Street Depot. The Happy Valley branch is not quite as busy as the main route.Staff cannot mostly communicate with English speakers.The stops are pretty regularly spaced. The trams are unsuitable for those in wheelchairs. The stairs to the upper deck are steep, but the views from it are excellent.Make it a part of your Hong Kong experience. The route passes a number of MTR railway (metro) stations such as North Point.
Very Traditional!. On a rainy day rode it for hours - getting off and on numerous times. It cost less than $1.00 US. Goes through the heart of Hong Kong.

Travel like the locals. This is a very interesting way to travel in Hong Kong. It only cost HKD2.30 for a one way trip!It is really nice to see all the buildings and structures along the way. Since it is a double decker, do go up upper deck and see the view from there

A must do attraction in HK. If you have the time you absolutely should take a ride on the ding ding trams through Hong Kong. They are a great way to see the city. A very cheap way to get somewhere especially if you're not limited on time. One of my favourite ways to get about HK.

Don't get it, but had to do it!. Ok so what's the big deal over the trams? You have to do it, to understand it. We started at the bottom and jumped off once to go in a department store. It takes about 20 minutes to ride to the top. And, as you go up, you figure out where you need to stop in on the way down. There were steps all the way down, so I was thankful we took the trams up, and not down. We stopped in the Soho district on the way back. Really enjoyed the trams and would recommend this, but not at the top of things to do, just do it if you have some free time while visiting Hong Kong.
Can trams be this slender?. Great way to see the city though a bit slow it adds character to the place. Called the ding dings they go from Kennedy town to happy valley.
yes Ding Ding....... they are very convenient,a bit slow as they stop frquently at peak times they are a bit chaotic and you only pay when you get off the tram and it is not expensive

Another iconic mode. Like the star ferry, the ding-dings are iconic HK transport. They trundle along the north shore island streets. Not the fastest way to get around (take the MTR or a taxi if you are in a hurry), but they provide a nice way of seeing the city. Wooden seats and no a/c - but hey this is an old HK experience

Rickety Ride. An archaic legacy of the British Empire on Hong Kong Island, the trams ply from Shaukewan at the eastern end of the island all the way to the up and coming enclave of Kennedy Town at the opposite end. The trams are always overcrowded which add to their charm as motley groups of tourists and Hong Kongers use it as an economical means of commuting. At a flat fare of HKD2.30 per ride for adults (only 30 US cents), it is possibly the world's cheapest DIY bus tour for visitors to Hong Kong.

Slow but funny. This is not the fastest way to move around Hong Kong. But it sure is one of the most intresting ways. Just hop on the tram, sit upstairs and enjoy the views over the city from your moving throne
JUST DI IT. Try for a seat upstairs great view of some out of the way places on Hong Kong island. Get an OCTOPUS card, sure makes life a bit easier. A lot of fun.

Great. This is a fun way to get around , only on Hong Kong Island, I think. Even though they are not made for tall Aussies and certainly didnt try to get up to very narrow staircase to the top deck. Cheap, easy, convenient. Again using the Octopus card which is for all travel sources, it is great.

Easy to Hop On/Off. With the multi-purpose OCTOPUS card, hopping on and off the tram was a fuss-free and fun experience. Just have a good idea which general direction you want to go - the HK tourist map will serve you well in this respect - and let the tram do the moving!

Lots of fun. If you get a seat upstairs you have a wonderful view of the surroundings. The tram goes slowly at a very dignified pace. It is not air conditioned. It is cheap and very classical. I will go again.

Slow but interesting. As a means of transportation the tram is not the best option for long distances as it is a bit slow (in midst of traffic and tram stops). For short rides it's good and allows you to enjoy the view of the city as you ride along. It does have multiple lines though so do check where you need to go and which caters for you.It is also a HK experience and worth a ride for it...

Best and one of the cheapest way to travel in hk island. takes only HKD 2.30 across the whole route to travel on a tram , locals call it ding! ding! If you a group of more than ten or so you can also hire a old vintage style party tram to go around partying in the city. Its 110 years old now.
Cheap Cheap Cheap. Cheaps is the thing i want to say about this. as i am running out of $$$ travelling on tram is only HKD2.3 that is so cheap and affordable when you travel in HK island
No visit is complete without a ride on the tram. It's a throwback to the old times but works efficiently. The cannot beat the price of HKD 2.30 per ride. Great fun.

Fabulous. We enjoyed our ride in the Ding Ding Tram, it is very relaxing and a good way to see Hong Kong Island. It is also very convenient and affordable. If you are in Hong Kong, make sure you ride this classic/vintage transportation especially if you have kids.
Worth one ride. Ride it once; say you have done it. Slow way across town. Hot in the summer. Nice views from upper seating.
Nice view!. This is a great way to see Hong Kong and you should definitely take it if you are a first time visitor...its slow but you will get a feel of the city and is definitely worth it
Double Decker Tram. Pretty cool double decker trams. Went between the Western Market and Causeway bay pretty quick. Just get on and make sure to pay before getting off!

Fun and relaxing way to see Hong Kong. HK public transport is the best in the World, especially the MTR and the bus network. However you won't get to see much going from place to place ... unless ... ... you go rrreeeaaalllyyy ssslllooowwwlllyyy on the tram. The tram is the oldest and the slowest way to get around after walking (yes, you can sprint faster if you're in shape!) but it's also the most convenient for short distances, or for a comprehensive view of the downtown area of HK island from Western District to Causeway Bay and beyond. For a low fixed fare ($2.20) you can literally spend hours following where the old waterfront used to run before decades of reclamation moved the water up to 1/2 mile away in places. Get a drink and a snack, and try to get a seat up stairs at the front, and you can see the kaleidescope of architectural styles that HK has adopted. For those planning a party, you can even hire a private tram, and spend a couple of hours going doing a circuit of the major sights of HK.

City sightseeing. it's a 2 level of tram going to city. the cost is HK$3.20 per way. it is nice to see the city from upper level. However, it doesn't have air condition, would be nice if they do, considering the weather is very humid.

Nice way to see Hong Kong Financial city. I have visited during May 2015. When I was there the trams are free on that day. I took the trams to look around. Hong Kong is always crowed and very warm. If your visiting there, you have to prepare for that
Great views. Great way to view the city and the beautiful views. We took the tramway from victoria peak down to the city..what a fun and exciting way to view the city.
Interesting. If you can, go take the top deck for a better view of the city. Great for first time visitors, especially. Cheap mode of transportation. Slow but fun.

great way to see HK. lovely way to see the city - get onto the top floor, try to sit right at the front or right at the back, enjoy and relax. Remember that money is taken when you EXIT so that they can figure out what you owe.

Quaint, not very comfortable, but efficient!. Used frequently to get around various central parts of Hong Kong Island. Cramped stairway to second level but reminiscent of San Francisco's trolley cars. Best to have the Octupus card to pay as you leave. Indeed, the card is a great way to pay for various things and should be bought at the airport when you arrive.
Fun transport . Alternative mode of transport other than the usual MTR. Love to take pics from the upper deck. It can only be found on HK island. Must try during off peak hours!
Another must in Hong Kong. You have to ride on the tram - prefeerably on the upper deck! And it is not just a tourist attraction, but a useful means of transport.

Exploring HK by Tram. I loved this, I walk the length of HK one way and got a tram back, it was great to see HK from the tram and really take in the local way of life seeing the immaculate high rises in the CBT blend in with local markets and apartment blocks.. The trams are really cheap, a great way to see HK.
Driver was a sea nut. We got off not realizing we had to pay at the end, driver started barking like a dog pointing to the till, I threw $5 in but he took off without giving the change.
cheap as chips. A great way to travel from Kennedy town all the way to North point and shau kei wan. A great thing for tourists to travel the length of hong kong north side.

Best way to see the city!. As recommended by my best friend, the trams are the best way to see the city! They are cheap, very frequent and if you sit at the front or the back, really lend for amazing views of the city. Really cool!

Unique experience. For someone who lives in a country with no trams, this is definitely a unique experience. I love how going in and getting out of the tram is organized. you go in by the back door and go out by the front and swipe your octopus card. :)

Still relevant form of transport. Although a living antique , the Hong Kong Island tram serves a useful ink for places the buses and the MTR cannot reach. The lines along some of the most populous parts of the island serve a community who know no other way of getting from A to B, and visitors wanting to get a feel of the local Chinese daily life.The slowness of travel allows you not to miss things which not obvious on the faster modes of transport.Watch life from the top deck, and use the Octopus prepay card when exiting to avoid embossing fumbles for loose change.
Great fun. Although the Ding Dings are not air conditioned, sitting upstairs we got enough of a breeze to make our journey interesting and enjoyable. Love that you pay on exit. Great fun.

Cheapest way to take it all in!. The tram is a collective memory for many HongKongers. It is a slow-paced, cheap and fun way to get around Hong Kong Island for sure! Trams have their own tracks on normal roads, so you will have the experience of getting around, whilst being surrounded by traffic etc! The tram moves so slowly that you will have the chance to relax and take pictures (without them being blurry), and even just to ponder and enjoy Hong Kong as a city itself! Keeping this in mind, don't take the tram if you are in a rush! The MTR will cut your travel time to your destination by at least half the time!

a lot of charm for these old cars from the 1850!. these tramways are unique, they bring you along the center of HK at a slow pace but with a lot of charm, bringing you back to the 1800! a unique experience for a few HK dollars. Must try.

Transport of Yesteryear. What a contrast. The transport of yesteryear in the worlds most exciting and dynamic city. Take the tram from North Point all the way to Kennedy Town fro next to nothing. It will fill in a morning or afternoon for the whole journey or just on and off anywhere on the route.
Fun!. The trams worked for us since there's a stop by our hotel. It was affordable and very local! But, I would not recommend to ride it on a super hot day thus there's no AC!

Brilliant. A great way to travel whilst on HongKong Island. Once we figured out which tram to take it was great fun. Take a seat upstairs and just enjoy the busy life go past. Very convenient with the Octopus card.
Must try. I saw the Ding Dings pass by and decieded to hop on a ride. They are pretty cheap and very slow but something about the ride was charming. Hop on before you see the last of it.

Quirky and crammed but lots of fun. The tramways wind their way between the other traffic and are tall and narrow, it's rather like being on an ancient form of transport, they are terrific for heading along Hennessy Road towards causeway. A fun highlignt of HK.
Take upper seats. Good place... Worth going once.. Was there with my daughter she loved it..Good option for exploring honking..
great views from the top deck. Much better than taking a tour this is a great way to see Hong Kong and to get your bearings - it's great fun too

Cute Tram Trip. Top deck, front seats, and enjoy rattling along in these old skinny trams. Wan Chai to the City will take you through the streets to see all the massive designer label areas and market/restaurant places to visit later. Finish at Mid Town for the escalators and Peak Tram and you will be well on the way to a great day in HK.

Trams - The main artery for a very special neighbourhood.. Trams are located along north side of Hong Kong Island. Cost is $HK2.30 for one stop or whole journey. Entrance is at back of tram and exit at front along with payment .Use of Octopus card is most convenient way for paying for all transport and everything else in Hong Kong. They are not the fastest form of transport but like all surface forms of transport they share equal problems in busy times. In many sections pedestrians may walk faster. I prefer them to buses, taxis on the same routes in which they operate. Only when needing to make MTR links outside their domain do I find it more practical for time to keep with MTR alone. Trams are works of art and billboard advertising always tasteful and artistic. Most tram lines run eastbound or westbound. They, plus the harbour provide good reference points. At each stop one will find location name plus direction of tram whether eastbound or westbound.Trams deviate from the east-west direction when arriving at Happy Valley. Happy Valley is a north south loop out of Causeway Bay. Useful for going to Happy Valley Racecourse. When one considers shape of north shore HK Island the area of Happy Valley is widest area and whole region is shaped like an eye. Tapering at Kennedy Town and Quarry Bay. The tram exploits this fact.The tram to the east actually rises quite a bit for any tram to get over Quarry Bay area to end at Shau Kei Wan.Another interesting and important tramline is North Point which gives access to North Point Ferry to Kowloon City and Hung Hom. The North Point Tram is very interesting in that it is to my knowledge the only tram that passes along a market street and flanked either side by stalls. A market that tourists have very little knowledge, but which caters to the local community as do other street markets. I have a special liking for the North Point Tram and its market as I discovered it by accident when walking.Another very useful tram stop is around Queensway Plaza also serving the Admiralty MTR and Pacific Place. Why tourists continue to go to Peak by using Central astounds me. Using the tram stop or even Admiralty MTR stop is far more multipurpose than Central. Go to Queensway Plaza by tram. Take footbridge into Pacific Place and at 2 o’clock you will find escalator that will take you into start of Hong Kong Gardens (Conservatory, Tea Museum, Feng Shui appeal and Aviary) and exit western end directly opposite Peak Tram $HK28 one way. Or return to Queensway Plaza and take Bus 15 to the Peak. Definitely and by all means come down from Peak on Bus 15 (front seat, top deck best for ride not surpassed even by Sae King Bus 92,96R) and go to Central and on to Star Ferry and evening in Kowloon. The water in the Park will not however be turned on before 10am on weekdays so check on that and plan to arrive HK Park around then to see water features flowing. Taking trams to ends of lines is both informative and examines all aspects of Hong Kong Island History and Sociology. The fact that HK Island tourist maps finish prematurely at Sheung Wan and Causeway Bay has always disappointed me but should not deter tourists from exploring the beyond to end of tram line. Many tourists go to ends of tram lines and walk back. Go to Shau Kei Wan and see gaps in shopping areas on way as tram rises over and down what is a continuation of the Peak Ridge Line coming down to the harbour. Forming a rise in tramline which I consider significant for line trams operating on the flat. The gaps in shopping areas are a novelty, like dead zones in what is otherwise an unbroken line of shops, lights and Malls punctuated by business, judicial district, sports and social amenities throughout north side Hong Kong Island. The high rise estates of Abbott Point I believe at one time once were part squatter areas, high density housing, where many relocated and boat people once lived. The new estates are themselves mind blowing and they became a characteristic prototype adopted in housing plans elsewhere in Hong Kong. In all aspects of Hong Kong infrastructure there is an incredible amount of research, skill, expense and out of box thinking to achieve goals. Sometimes in face of public opposition projects have a habit of encouraging other aspects of economic development that only Hong Kong can deliver. Invisible opportunities and ingenuity follow many projects. One such current like project is the Hong Kong_Macau_Zhuhai Bridge which attracts critics, is probably ahead of its time, but may grow to become appreciated with time.Trams are well supported and serve an admirable purpose. Hong Kong would be heartbroken without them. You can actually hire a tram and conduct a party on board as it tours Hong Kong. So look into it.Courtesy Wikipedia - HK trams have been around for over 100 years and are only ones in world to be double decked.6 Lines and 120 stops. Proposed in 1881 it took until 1901 to be accepted. First tramline coming into being from Kennedy Town to Causeway Bay in 1903 and later extended to Shau Kei Wan. Initially single decks were progressively changed with first introduction of a double decker in 1912.All single deckers were retired by 1941 with very little tram service during Japanese Occupation. Class distinction was prevalent on trams up until 1972 when one class and one flat fee was adopted.Courtesy Wikipedia - There are six major overlapping routes, Shau Kei Wan to Western Market,Shau Kei Wan to Happy Valley, Shau Kei Wan to Kennedy Town, North Point to Whitty Street, Happy Valley to Kennedy Town, Causeway Bay to Whitty Street and Western Market to Kennedy Town.It is important to understand the above route variations so as not to stop short or end up on way to Happy Valley – a initial common mistake. The North Point spurline through the market is however a well kept secret and tourists do not go there (said deliberately to motivate). The attached map does not show the digression (loop) due to scale. It is only 300m down the street. End of line loops are great places for innovative tram pictures. One can also wait for a tram to Kennedy forever at places along a short part of Hennessey Road in Causeway Bay for a couple of blocks where the Kennedy tram loops into Happy Valley. I talk from experience. So walking up to Tonnochy Road is necessary to reconnect westwards for Kennedy Town coming out of Happy Valley or take Whitty or Western Market and change en route.As I said get on trams at back and if going a long way do not go towards front of tram but hold back and wait for a seat to open up. Going forwards prematurely limits opportunities for getting a seat and you will get squished.

Great way to get orientated. We spent about 4 hours on our first day just jumping on and off the various trams and it was a great way to get orientated. Each tram journey was Just HK$2.49 ie around 20p so couldn't be better value. We were on the top decks and front seats on most journeys and our pictures are amazing !!Once you have your bearings then it's much quicker to go by MTR but I am so glad we did all the tramsfirst.

Tram ride is a must!. Tram ride is easy and convenient. If you have nothing to do, just take a tram ride from one end to the other end, get on the top deck, kick back, relax and let the slow breeze brushes your face while taking in all Hong Kong sights and sounds. All for a cheap a couple of dollars.

Colonial relics. Definitely a tourist service. Locals do use it, but there are better bus and MRT services. The tramcars are authentic and show their age, but for the experience and cheap tickets, it's a must for visitors. Most tourist won't be interested in the destinations at either end, so the ride is the thing.
Easy to use. Jump on the back and get off at the front. You pay when you get off - have the right money. I can't remember if it's 2.5 or 3.5 dollars - very cheap (about 20p a ride).

A bit underwhelming. We did not find this to be as useful as many other reviewers did. It can be found by exiting the Admiralty MTR through exit C1 - the tram line is then right in front of you. The first problem is the destinations showing on the trams- many of them travel only along part of the end to end route so you will have to be aware of where you want to go before you get aboard. The next problem is that many of the trams do not have a commentary so unless you have a map, it will be difficult to know where you are which will then make it difficult for you to know when you have reached your destination if that is before the end of the route.If you get a tram with a commentary, you will be told the name of each approaching street. If you have a map, you can note exactly where you are and plan ahead. So a map is a must.The advantage is that you can get off at any stop and get back on at any stop. This will cost the full fare of $2.30HK every time you travel, but it is a cheap way to move around and explore.

great way to see HK Island. this is a super cheap and fun way to see the hustle and bustle of HK Island, from Kennedy Town through Sheung Wan, Central, Wan Chai, Causeway Bay, Happy Valley and beyond. It's slow, but it's great that this somewhat anachronistic means of transport has survived in the high-tech and high-rise environment of Hong Kong. Same price whether you go one stop or all the way through from end to end.

Ding Ding your way accros Hongkong streets. its a unique must have experience to take ding ding while you in HK. If i may suggest better to take the ride on nights...it have better view with the lights and cool night breeze
Hong Kong Trams. Trams in Hong Kong are very crowded but there is a novelty catching one. Living in Melbourne we are surrounded by Trams. Hong Kong trams are double decker.
Part of Hong Kongs Rich History. These are a must do for everyone they are cheap and you get to see the day to day lives and business of this vibrant non stop city all around you

Best value for money in Hong Kong. What a truly great experience. On a previous trip we used the ding dings for convenience rides, this time we did the full trip from Kennedy to Shau Kei Wan a fantastic and extremely cheap way to view Hong Kong!

Good way to see Island. Good way to experience HK, get good views of the Island from the busy Central area to the far reaches west and east and it is the same low price if you go one stop or all. Go upstairs to get the best view. Note, though if you are in a hurry best take the bus or MTR, since the tramways also get used by cars, etc and the tram can't go anywhere else if it is busy! Take note of the tram's destination since some stop at various depots along the way.

Tram Tour of Hong Kong. Great fun. Brilliant views of the city and we had a private tour for about 22 of us - with food and drink included. Lots of fun and a great way to start the evening with loads of good pics. This really helped to get a good feel of Hong Kong and the whole environment - thoroughly recommended!

At a Glance. As a newbie in HK city, you should try Ding Ding, it is a fantastic view all over the hectic city. IYou should be carefull of the Ding Ding route, because they do not have the same route for round trip. If you are travelled with kids, they will love the view from Ding Ding

Only For experience. Just like bus, if ur location can access by bus pls take bus rather than take Ding Ding because the DingDing car is small and limited space so bus will be better option. Sometimes it really pack and crowded all have to squish into small space.

Love the trams!. Go find yourself a tram and spend an hour being transported around Hong Kong. Great way to rest your legs and observe street life - and the ticket is (I think) HK$2.30, a bargain- just make sure to have exact fare! Get a seat upstairs in front.

Great Way To See Hong Kong. This is a great way to see hong kong and is very inexpensive. Sit on the upper level if you can! You can also take the tramway from the top of Victoria Peak all the way back down... The road is windy and its an exciting ride with spectacular views.

nice experience. Tram stop:The stops are open.. with no shades...so in day time it wud be a bit uncomfyTram experience :it was awesome way of exploring hongkong... very slow ride... but its much better den our seat in coach.tram fare:any where to anywhere 2.5hk $... its truely value for money. tram location:it does not work in the main city. .. offf location. .. but it worth travlling in it

A journey through time. Simple, regular, cheap (About US$1 per person)Imagine how people travelled before the modern rail systemEasy enough to exit the WanChai MTR and head south to catch a tram.Hop off when you had enough and make your way to Admiral or Central MTR to go to your next journey
Incredibly cheap form of transport, and fun!. $2.30 can cover a trip from east to west of the island, so a great way to sightsee and incredible value for money.

Heritage in the bustling city. It is interesting that in such an efficient and cosmopolitan city, the tram still exists. It's slow (well not actually that slow) but it's a very good way to observe the city. If you get on a ride from one terminal to the other (they run on the HK island side but there are different routes, just choose the one from island west to island east), you can observe the differences among the different districts of HK. Quite an experience. You can just hop on and off whenever you see something interesting. It's just HK$2.3 per ride (very cheap!) so won't really cost you a fortune even if you keep hopping on and off. Spare half day to give it a go!
Best way to see HKG island. I could have ridden these all days, great view from the top deck, a really good way to get a feel for HKG.

Seeing Hong kong on the Tram. Can be crowded most days but very cheap. Fixed route so cannot get lost. This is the way most people travelled in the early days of Hong Kong and still is a charming way to see the "real Hong Kong" from the upstairs. Try to get the front seats althou gh all seats have a view out. No aircon but usually windows are open.

cheapest land transport offering excellent street view (upper deck) & colonial feel.. It's a product from the British rule in the last centuries. Apart from the tram carriages have been updated, the route is basically the same for the last 170+ years. And by the way, the tramways on the Hong Kong Island (apart from the Happy Valley line) is actually the original "coastline" of Hong Kong. Everything "north" of the tramways are from land reclamation throughout the years!!

Cheap sightseeing for tourists. They're really slow so it's great for tourists like myself. They often get backed up and come 3 or 4 at a time so just wait for the 3rd or 4th one if you're not in a hurry so you can get a nice seat to enjoy the views. I hopped on and off every few stops and it only cost something like 50 cents per trip. This one is flat rate, unlike the MTR which charge by distance.

Fun Kids loved it. I heard some tourists complaining that it was small and cramped, well that is true, however it is what it is. It is an historical tramway that has been preserved for us to see, and is fun for that reason. To avoid the crowds, go on it between 1030 and 1600. The cars are more empty during that time. The ride is slow and comfortable, and gives you time to relax and people watch in this hectic city.Well worth a ride on the Ding Ding!

If you can, get on one of these!. We took the tram from North Point to Admiralty - wonderful street view from the top, just people watching and enjoying fresh air and sunshine. Not so good if it's raining.

Great time. As long as you aren't in a rush and it's not the height of summer the ding ding is great and well worth the $2.8 (£22p）travel up and down HK Island at your leisure for the one fixed price, suggest you use a octopus as no change is given. My top tip is to go through Times Square (take the tram through causeway bay) at night for the most amazing artificial light show as the shoppers hustle and bustle and make sure you sit at the front on the top for the best view

Best way to travel and cheap too. For virtually nothing its a great way to see Hong Kong. Luckily our hotel was right beside the route so we could go from virtually one end of the route to the other. Go upstairs and try and get to the front near an open window - especially if its hot and humid. It may be old fashioned, bumpy and cramped but such fun and you see far more than using the MTR.
Nice. Excellent Experience !!! The view was beautiful. Tram is built on the hill, so while coming down you can feel the gravitational pull. The experience was totally worth while
Slow & Sunny ride. Day time it is very hot to take the Ding Ding, so please ride it during the night better view and cooler too.

A real old ding. Coming from Melbourne where we have trams galore, I was quite surprise how different and enjoyable, this ding ding ride would be.You enter at the rear and make your way to the front. The ride passes through some of the more densely populated areas of Hong Kong.You get off at any stop and pay as you get off. Remember, use oyster card or have exact cash as driver does give change.A must try for all visitors.
Upstairs for a view. Can get crowed but a great way to see Hong Kong Island. You can use the Octopus. Do not use in rush hour as the trams get overcrowded/

cheap and fun. One of the cheapest things you can do is hop on/off the ding ding. It doesn't go fast and stops about every kilometer so you have enough time to watch shops and people as you go by. It is a bit noisy and a hard ride but you can see HK without getting tired of walking too much.

Great way to take in a little local life. The Ding Ding's didn't really go anywhere we needed to go, but we loved taking them just since they are so unique and a good was to see the street life of HK.
You need to be relatively familiar …. Interesting and only in Hong Kong Island. However, you needs to be familiar with where you are going. Not really tourist friendly.

Cheapest Transport in Hong Kong. Old is gold. This is a historical part of Hong Kong and a tram ride is a must if you are a visitor to Hong Kong. The cheapest and safest transport but only available in Hong Kong Island

Economic way to visit. I really enjoyed taking the ding ding when it was not too hot. It's a very cheap and interesting way to visit the city. If you're not in rush hour, go upstairs, take a seat and let the chauffeur drive you through the crowdy places. I used to go to one extreme side of the city, visit the surroundings and when tired, take the bus or metro back. Even in this rustic bus, you can use your octopus card! I was positively surprised by the very efficient (and cheap) public transportation system there. Wish it's the same here in Canada...

Another great value attraction. This is the cheapest transport in Hong Kong. Catch the tram on a sightseeing trip of the island. Sit upstairs if possible and just take in the sights of all the shops as you pass by. If you see something that appeals to you, you can hop off at the next tram stop.

Distinctly average. We decided to get a tram to get the authentic experience whilst in Hong Kong and have to say that I wish we hadn't bothered. We had a long wait for a tram, mostly because the traffic is so bad that it is queued over the tram tracks meaning that the tram can't move! There was a large queue to get on the tram and the it was absolutely ram packed when it arrived. We managed to squeeze on but the experience was not one I wanted to repeat as far too hot and humid to be squashed against the armpit of a stranger! Trying to get off was a nightmare - you get on at the back and have to push your way to the front to get off where you scan your Octopus card or pay cash. The tram was really slow due to the volume of traffic so it really would have been quicker to get the Mtr or to walk. My guess is that they keep the tram as it is nostalgic and tourists like it. It's good to get a photo of the tram but I would not be rushing to have another journey on one.
Good value. Went from one end of Hong Kong waterfront to the other all for the princely sum of $1.10. journey took over 1.5 hours. Seats a little hard.
Slow and uncomfortable. Tramways is outdate and an old attraction for tourist, it is slow and uncomfortable way to travel around,they should stop using it it is meaningless.

Better than top deck tour. Super cheap, Very efficient. But only in the HK Island. I use it all the time if I am going a few tram stops.
An exceptional experience for tourist where you can see the different areas in HK for just HKD 2.30, the cheapest transport available in HK.

A great way to experience HK. With so many transportation mode available in Hong Kong the far best way to had a good view of the city is by Hong Kong Tramways or we call it as Ding Ding. This is because you can had a great view of each building architecture in a glimpse and without having a sore leg walking around. The tramways had a lot stops/station where you can hop on and off to explore each station. Besides it is dirty cheap if you are in a mode to explore the whole Tramways Line as their fair rate is charge based on per ride. Tips: Hop on to the second level of the tram to get a good view. Have fun!

Fun and cheap :). It's called Ding Ding in locals, it is one of the cheapest way to explore Hongkong island, it's not fast but gives you a fun feel of using it. If you are in Hongkong for holiday, you must try to just sit at the 2nd level and let the tram take you around the city. Bring along your map as well as the tram route map to stop in interesting places the tram passes by. I went to Indo Market, minimarket which sells Indonesian food, spices, drinks using this tram in Causewaybay area.
city view. Good chance to slow down and watch a city closely, fare is cheap and no rush. Due to no air conditioning it is a bit hot and exhaust from other vehicles is strong
Excellent but inexpensive. Excellent but cheap means of transport...... Fun to hear the ding ding sounds......It's gd to sit on the upper deck

Really Busy. I found myself at the tram by accident while exploring and even though it was a very misty day thought I would try it for the experience. The ride up was steep and well worthy the ride even though there were no views at all from the top. A few days later the weather cleared so I headed back to see the views but the queue was insanely long. In the end myself, the guy immediate in front andf the girl behind decided to leave the queue and take a taxi up - it cost just under HK$50 which we split 3 ways. We got to the top in 15 minutes, no wait, saw the view and taxied back down again - so if it is more the view you want and not so much the ride in the tram - take a taxi and save maybe 90 minutes of your life!! - not to mention if you share the cab it's a lot cheaper than the tram anyway

Cheapest way to experience decent chunk of HK. Yes, it takes some time but you are not underground and have the opportunity to experience true HK. Tram ride gives you totally different perspective of HK. And it's only $2.30!It's great to catch the tram between Sheung Wan (West - more fancy and expensive) and North Point (East - local, genuine HK). You can exit whenever you gonna see something interesting as the stops are not very far from each other.
Trams on Hong Kong. There was a tramstop near our hotel. The trams are very regular and very popular they are also crowded. A good way to get from point a to b.

Great way to get around. Cheap and easy way to travel in and around the city. The frequency of the trams is excellent. You need the correct change as otherwise you do not get change given to you. Jump on and pay when you get off.

A slow way of moving in fast pace HK. This is still a very important mode of transport at street level as the routes connect you to several important streets and landmarks that are not necessary meant for tourists. Therefore it is understandable that majority of the passengers are still Hong Kong residents. An important consideration of taking the trams instead of buses and MTR is actually its slowness - that people unfamiliar with locations could take their time making decision to get off. I have in fact been hoping in and off this way, after all the fare is standard and very affordable by HK's standard: $2.30. For tourists it is highly recommended that they should try taking trams from start to end for each of the interesting routes to get to know and explore the downtown area of HK quickly.

Ding Ding !!. Just the sound of it, I tried to take the HK Tramways any chance I get if I'm not presses for time. I've taken it from one end to the other, except I haven't taken the side branch to Happy Valley.
superb experience with Tram. We had used Tram for 6 days during our trip to HK and it was a superb experience. The same Octopus card is valid in this too so it was very convenient.
Old Fashioned Trams. We just went on for a quick journey for the fun element would recommend easy to get about and take the weight off your feet.

Absolutely great!. I had travelled on the ding ding from Kennedy Town to Happy Valley and to Sau Kei Wan. It cost HKD 2.30 regardless of the distance and is a great way to see Hong Kong Island.
