In fact, it is about the cheapest way to travel around on the northern part of Hong Kong Island, and if you are not in Hong Kong for business but for leisure, this is probably the best way to see the northern part of Hong Kong Island.Getting off at various stations along Des Voeux Road would bring you to within walking distance of all the usuall places of interest, such as Hollywood Road, Central, Admiralty, Wan Chai, Happy Valley, Causeway Bay, and for the lion hearted (those who are more adventurous), places less travelled where you can see the local way of life rather than how tourists burn holes in their pockets. LOL!I saved a lot of time and money travelling on the Ding Ding instead of taking the MTR. If you ask me, why time, since the MTR is reputed to be very fast, well, you know, the amount of walking you have to do inside Central or Hong Kong Stations, for example, and climbing in and out of the stations and all that, it's actually faster to just go to a Ding Ding station and continue your journey to your next destination.

Trams. The tramways in Hong Kong are great. When in Hong Kong spend at least 1 day riding the trams, you get to see a lot of Hong Kong that way. My Husband and I saw different places by riding the trams.

Great view of HK. Just 2.30 HKD for a ride, get on it the rear and exit and pay at the front. Try to get the top level in the very front for great views of Hong Kong. Before getting on check the front of the ding ding as it will tell you to which stop it will go to before turning around and going back the opposite direction (map: https://www.hktramways.com/en/interactive-map/).

The best thing in Hong Kong!. Great way to get from one end of the city to the other. Inexpensive, easy to use, and historic! One can just sit and enjoy a great view of city life. They run very often, so great anytime.

Ding Dong. If you are 'doing' HK the Ding Ding has got to be done. If you've an Octopus card for the MTR it's even easier than an easy thing. Personally I'd skip the very busy old trams running up to Victoria Peak which can get very busy. Climb up to the top deck and just soak up the feel. Jump off when you like and when you want to come back there'll be a returning tram at the opposite stop every few minutes

Gotta ride the ding ding trolley. Cheap crowded fun for everyone. Absolutely you have to do a few rides on the trolley for the experience of the city.Pat attention to the maps and signage.
It is low cost and easy and convenient. After all you can't have air conditioning all the time !
Confusing. I still dont get why you enter the back and leave the front but when in HK.... Nice view from the top level
Great Experience!. I like Dingding, a great experience! Special, old but full of memory. Fees are cheap. Hope it would be kept well.

Jump in and enjoy the ride !. "Ding ding" is the sounds that the tram does to signal itself and it's the nickname that locals use to name it.If you are looking for a fast transport, forget about the Ding-ding!If you are looking for a nice ride across the city or a few 100 meters ride, this is the best option. The tram is only on HK Island and there is only one line from Shau Kei Wan to Kennedy Town, with one tram that does a small loop via Happy Valley. Very straight forward and there are stops every 100 or 200 meters. The driver will stop, no need to look for any bells.You pay the tram on the way out. It accepts coins, notes or octopus card (it will not give change back so be ready). Travel TIP: If you stay in HK for more than a day, get an octopus card. You can get them easily in any Subway (called MTR). It's just a card that you will charge with few hundred bucks and that you can use to pay in any shop and transports (except taxis). Very convenient and it avoid having too much change!Be careful, there is another tram (not the ding ding). This tram is from central to the peak. But it's a different tram so do not jump into the ding ding expecting to go to the Peak! The ding-ding is the most popular transport on HK island and so if you want to enjoy a bit of HK life, this is a must. Enjoy!

Old school tram ride. We took a tram from causeway bay to central and enjoyed the experience. A good cheap ride! It also brought back memories of non air conditioned rides where commuters open and shut the windows on their own. Worth the experience as an alternative to the mtr/bus.
A must try transportation. when you visit HK,try this train. It's a must try transportation.enjoy a lot of view while you ride this train.

Enjoyable. I enjoyed riding on the tram because unlike the metro you can enjoy the view as you ride. Octopus card is accepted. It's not very fast. If you are not in a hurry, it is nice to sit on the top deck to watch the chaos and business of Wai Chai or Causeway Bay below.

Fantastic value and great sightseeing.. If you don't have a lot of time in Hong Kong I would recommend a trip on the trams. Slow paced with plenty of time to sightsee and take photos. Jump on and off if you want a closer look at anything along the way. We have been to Hong Kong 4 times and every time we ride the trams at least once. Very impressed.

What an experience. Anyone visiting Hong Kong for the first time, must make this a must do. Really interesting traveling to Victoria Peak and going between the apartments etc. make sure you leave yourself enough time as getting up and back can be really really busy

Hong Kong Ding Ding Trams ride is a Best Value and a must try. When in HK takie a Tram that transverse HK Island in an East -West direction .Its the Best way to see HK as the locals do. Costs only Hk2.30 for the whole journey of 100 stops.Great value. Take to the last terminal stop Shau Kei Wan going East. GET OUT AND TAKE A 2 minutes walk to the open air market selling all kinds of food fruits and vegetables. And they are cheap and plentiful. A sight to behold .Then have a pineapple Ebi burger at the MacDonald located at the terminal with a great birds eye view of the Trams .Watch the locals get on with their lives Well worth the one hour journey from Central. In winter or Spring lovely to sit upstairs first row to catch the cold air blowing through.

Enjoy the ride!. The best seat is infront or at the side at the second floor of the Tram. Tbis is a great way to explore the city. Get yourself a coffee and ride on this transportation. It is cheap but efficient.

World' best value land transport. A few dollars, dozens of possible stops, from the old Hong Kong, to the best malls, or just enjoy the lovely ride. Don't worry , you won't get lost, just follow the rail back if you partied to hard that the service stopped.

An interesting way to see Hong Kong. We went on a Sunday morning.While perhaps it could be an activity in its own right for me it was more of an experience - now I have done it, I see it more as an alternative mode of transport than an outing in its own right.The tram is not the most comfortable way to travel but it does give you a good look at Hong Kong.Remember there are multiple routes, leaving from and going to different places.We took the tram from Shau Kei Wan to the mid-level escalators.Personally the most interesting part of the ride was seeing all the maids congregating in parks, under bridges and in various street locations. It was really something.

Quirky transport you'll never find anywhere. "Oh my God we are going to crash to that other tram" i thought as our tram enter a bend section and skirts another incoming tram by centimeters.Relatively cheap.A cho cho train for adults.Everything is narrow. The tram, the seats, the turnstiles to get inside the tram.

Fun Way to Sightsee. Get a seat on the top deck and sit in front. It's great view and often allows for taking photos. On a nice day you can open the windows and it is really a treat. Then just let yourself create your own "hop on hop off" tour - explore the stops occasionally and get back on!
Awesome!). strange payment method) take some coins! the trip cost 2 HK dollars) take a second floor front seat place (or back seats) to have a nice pictures

A must when visiting HongKong. Have even ever seen a double decker tram? Guess not. Here they are on both the Knowloon side and HongKong island. A great way to travel in Hongkong and for a fair price. They are actually very cheap and make their money on advertising. When you in HK will you understand why. Again, this is a must!
just for fun. a fun tourist option to get around in HK. its nothing out of the ordinary but its fun to just jump on and off especially when travelling with kids.

A wonderful way to see Hong Kong Island. If you have the time to travel the island, take the tram. It is a wonderful way to see Hong Kong. You see the markets and little neighborhoods. It takes about an hour to go from one end to the other and is well worth the time!

Great!. A lovely way to see a bit of the city for just a couple of dollars, especially enjoyed taking a night-time trip. It makes life easy if you have an Octopus card which can be bought at the airport, but don't forget to redeem it when you leave Hong Kong.
Ding ding Team ride. Very good, we started at 1 end and went to the other end then turned around and come back. Get on the top deck and get a seat fared is on your octopus card. Good fun.

Inexpensive way to see Hong Kong island. The Hong Kong Tramways runs along the northern side of Hong Kong island which is the most populated areas of Hong Kong island. The tram is fairly slow but would give you a good view of the streets of Hong Kong. The best vantage point would be the front seats on the upper deck. It takes over an hour to run from one end of the island to the other end, but its worth it. You will be able to see the different districts of Hong Kong with its different characters. However, in the summer it is quite hot. This is the reason why I am not giving it a 5-point.

A must for HK Visit. We went very early in the morning just as it was opening which is essential to avoid very long queue. It was a fabulous visit, great walk with kids. Good place for picnics in cool season.
Nighttime view. Loved sitting on top and ending through Wanchai at night.It's easy to ride this funny little tram. Ding ding your way back to Central, after dinner in Causeway bay!
Great Value. I thought it was great, my partner wasn't over enamoured, as it did get a bit stuffy if busy. Not ideal for a snooze while travelling, but wow what a way of life. 20p or so per trip
A must for your first time there!!. The view on a clear day is amazing!! It is certainly well worth the trip and the restaurant is great too.

Remanence of Old Hong Kong. Anyone visiting HK would definitely get a chance to get on these... one of the major mode of transport for short distances on Hong Kong island, they are efficient, clean, reasonably priced. they cover all the major points on the HK island.Although slower than MTR/Cab/buses etc, they still have their own charm. You can use them to move about shorter distances and.

HK TRAM tip. We rode the tram near the mall in Ice house street. 1.download HK tramways app2. check which line you want to travel. 3. Last destination is written in front of the tram.4. get in the back pay on the front before you go out5. best seat is on top in the front. where you can see other trams going the opposite direction. The fare is 2.30 hk$ to all destinations and you can pay with octopus card or coins but there will be no change.
Spectacular. Freking long que but worth 20min of waiting. Worth every penny, what a view! Best thing....Burger King at the top, yeeeey!

Sweet ride thru city... We hoped on the ding ding purely to experience it, not because we needed to get somewhere so I can't say if it was slow or fast as we were having a joy ride. Sat up top and took it in.. Feels very old school in the middle of the craziness.. Enjoyed it

Nostalgic!. I have used trams in few other cities - Kolkata, San Francisco, Melbourne and now here. There is something old and nostalgic about trams which makes them very enjoyable. Totally had fun going through busy Hong Kong at a leisurely pace.

Ding Ding. The cheapest way around Hong Kong!!! (Okay, walking is cheaper and healthier).If you have time in your hands (or if you have good time planning skills), you can really enjoy the ride.Board at the back and quickly climb to the first floor of the tram for the best views. The cost of the ride is 2.30 HK$ and has to be paid in change (or Octopus Card) while disembarking.

a great way to have an overview of part of Hong Kong. It is slow, but it will give you a great feeling about the pulse of the city and enjoy an immersion in the crowd of Hong Kong inhabitants.The tram goes from East to West, and you pay the driver directly when you climb the bus.

Cheap and fun!. Love the Ding Dings! When passing through some older quarters, it defintely gives the feel of the old Hong Kong. Takes longer time to ride than MRT/Bus but if you need to go anywhere along the northern shore its a great option, or just ride it for fun. Just hop on at the back, try take a seat upstairs for to enjoy the view, when you hop off which you do at the front just pay with Octopus card or put in typically 3 HKD in the machine at the front exit.

A relaxing way to travel. The trams travel quite slowly and give you a chance to view the city slowly amid the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong.Go out on the MTR to Shau Kei Wan which is near the starting point of the tram so you can make sure you get a seat up the top. Then leave plenty of time. It only costs 2.30HKD payable as you leave the tram. No change is given, by the way.
Great way to get around city. these where a great way to get around quickly. Cheap, use the same card as all other means of transport. Get on the top deck for a great view of the city

The tour that cuts through the heart of Hong Kong. The tramway on the Island has been around before the second world war and cuts through the heart of Hong Kong Island, taking you through some of the most iconic areas of Hong Kong.I suggest that you start in Central, maybe after having taken the Tsim Sha Tsui to Central ferry and explored central a little, and take the tram in the east direction towards Shau Kei Wan & Causeway Bay. The first area you will past through is Admiralty with its high rises and posh shopping mall that is Festival Walk, I would get off here and walk through the mall and take the lifts up to Hong Kong Park, its a very nice park with a world class aviary and a really awesome plant exhibit building. The mall itself is so so, with the usual posh brands and everything is on the expensive side. There are some good restaurants in this mall if you have the time.Get back on the tram and the next area is Wanchai, also worth getting off to explore its back streets from Lockhart Rd to Queen's Road East, there is lots of see and explore and the area still retains some of the old Wanchai of the past, with some colonial style buildings here and there.The next area you will past over is Causeway Bay, probably the 3rd mecca for shopping and food in Hong Kong. Trailing behind Mongkok and on par with Tsim Sha Shui in my opinion. I also love visiting Sham Shui Po if you are more interested in Knick Knacks. There a lot of see in Causeway Bay, but it shouldn't take too long as it isn't as big as you think it is.Next few stops on the tram include Tin Hau, North Point, Fortress Hill, Shau Kei Wan, all have merits for the tourist, but if time is pressing you can probably skip them and end the tour at Causeway Bay. You will be missing some of the older areas of Hong Kong with lots of older residential areas with uniquely Hong Kong architecture. I will leave those areas for other reviews in time.The tram is super cheap and is quite quick for short hops, its not for long trips. Recommend that you get the Octopus payment card that is available at the airport (where you buy the airport express train ticket) or you will probably won't have the exact change to get on and off.
BEST VIEW OF HONG KONG LIFE. It is probably the best way to see the real Hong Kong, especially if seated at the front of the tram on the upper deck

So quaint!. It's a quaint way to explore the city - this was one of the things I simply had to do on my recent trip. If you've been on a double decker bus, this isn't that different, except that it's much narrower and older. The tramways are a fun alternative to other modes of public transport like the mini bus and taxis. The locals call it the 'ding ding' because that's the sound the bell makes! Expect it to be crowded as many locals use it. Also, you may have to stand as seats are limited.

一次感受香港发展的独特体验. Ding Ding is a very cheap, environmentally friendly and interesting traffic tool, it also is a flowing landscape. Sitting in the narrow and long Ding car, can visit Hongkong and Hongkong street, feeling that a modern and traditional.

Great way to see the city. This is a great way to see the city. Sit in the front for the best view then just hang out, take pictures and enjoy the ride. Note that there isn't AC on this but the windows are open and at least there is a breeze.

A must do. A lovely 'Local' experience to travel along Hong Kong Island from Admiralty to beyond. I travelled to CauseWay and it was a lovely way to journey - and incredibly cheap - HK$2.50. A lovely experience but if your want speed- take the MTR.

Fun but crowded. Have to try travelling on the Ding Dings if only once. Be warned they get crowded and are not the most comfortable form of transport but they are fun and fairly quick. Hop on back of tram, get off front. When you get on be sure to keep moving through or you will be stuck at back and unable to get through the crowd.

Great way to see city, hop on and off. The fare is so cheap, one can afford to hop on and off depending on what you see along the way, eg you see a shop you like, just hop off, walk around and hop on again

Even better now. After MTR has extended its service to Kennedy Town etc, the number of people taking tram have dropped quite noticeably. This means during peak hour, you may still get a seat on the tram or the wait for a seat won't be long. Best of all, there's less scrambling and squeezing to get on tram. I also love it for its convenience, especially going between North Point to Sheung Wan!

Great cheap way to travel. Hop on and off these old trams on Hong Kong Island is a great ways travel. Cheap and fun. We used these all the time whilst we were staying/ living there. Makes life a bit crazy..but you can get about easily.Fom one end of the island to the other.
very handy. easy jump on jump off . if you want easy access to shopping centres, this is the way, grab an octopus card and put $50 on it

It is a special transport system, world largest double deck tram still existing in HK.. Here is my review on Ding ding Tramways: - Attraction Highlight: Must try!!! It is a special way to enjoy Hong Kong Island using the tramway from Central to Causeway Bay.Attraction Tip: Take the Ding ding tram at Pedder street after the Peak visiting from the Garden Road Peak Tram Lower Terminus by bus no 15c. Then go to the ding ding tram upper deck to enjoy the HK Island scenery. Enter from the tram rear and then exit and pay at the front when reach your destination. The adult ticket is just HK$2.3 for the whole journey.

Ding Ding Tramways. We were delighted to take the Ding Ding ride, as our Singapore payment for bus ride is tap when board the bus and tap out when alighting; theirs only need to tap once which is when you alight the tram.

Great views from the top deck. Cheap and cheerful way to see the city. Pay the correct fare as you get off. So make sure you have some change. We sat at the back and took some great photos as we wound around the city streets.

must try!. each time when I traveled in Hong Kong, I must try to have a ride with ''Ding Ding'' in Hong Kong Island.
you can hop in and out. I always took from the terminal to the end and returned back. this is so relaxing to see the local people life!

Slow but fun!. Well worth doing. Cheap and Octopus card accepted. Sit up top and get above the street and feel an original form of transport. They are quirky and great but plan on spending some time as they are pretty slow getting anywhere. But that's not why you are on them anyway!
Great fun!

Travel like a Local. If you are in HK, you have to travel atleast once. Mainly used by the locals, trams are the most convenient mode of transport for short distances and gives you the local feel. Its cheaper than MTR.
An inexpensive fun ride. I would recommend the ride to the end. Upstairs gives a great view of local life. Everyone was very helpful to direct us as to the route

A true piece of Hong Kong history!. The most scenic and relaxed way to see Hong Kong island for only $2.3 HKD. Sit on the upper level and ride from one end of the island to the other and watch the city's energy shift from area to area.

Slow, rumbling and faboulous. Apart from being a sight in itself and one of the oldest things left in Hong Kong, they are transport and sightseeing packed in one.
1,5 hrs of sights and daily life, if you take it all the way to Shau Kei Wan, which also takes you slightly of the beaten track.

Very fun and cheap way to get a good view from above the street level!. Loved this!! Very fun and reminded me of the double-decker buses in the UK, but with a different shape and one a track! We got on and went upstairs and in just two stops the driver stopped and everyone got out, not sure why... I didn't quite understand what was going on, but we didn't get on the one in front to continue the journey... I would def do this again if I come back to HK. I recommend people getting on at a terminus stop and riding all the way to the other end, that would be more interesting.Anyhow, it was fun while it lasted!
Old and Rickety but worth the ride. Great way to get around the island. Old and Rickety but well worth the ride. Go right around and see the sights first

Slow, but excellent means of transport for looking around HK . There are only in HK island tramlines. These are double decker tramcars, old fashioned style, but very convenient to see Hong Kong Island differently. I tried the tram in an early Sunday hour, where the cuty just started to waiken up and also in a busy Tuesday evening, cca. 6 pm. At that time traffic was a real burden for everybody, the mass of people everywhere and busy car and taxi drivers. All together, Hong Kong tram system has 120 stations, 6 lines and 13 kms lenghts of trail, between Shau Kei Wan, Happy Valley and Kennedy Town. It is possible to use your octopus card. You must enter to the tram in the back and than to go out from the driver side using your card. Take a seat upstairs and just look around..... If you see something interesting, eg. between Sheung wan and wan chai you can discover a lot of small shops, colorful buildings, plazas, street food etc. etc.
Nice way to live the "Old" way!!. Amazing!! My second time in a tram (1st in Calcutta) and it was a good experience... a good way to live the life of our ancestors!!

Fun on the Trams. you must give this a go..Grab an Octopus Card and Hop on...can be crowded, but that is half the fun....go to the teams upper level for a great view. It was a Sunday when we were on the Trams and this is the Philipino Domestic Workers day off so it was crammed...good fun though

Great way to see lots. We jumped o a tram and took pot luck where we'd end up, as it was we got to Shau Kei Wan Markets, we got off there and strolled around, just wished we were staying in a hotel with a kitchen, seeing all that produce I would have love to cooked with. This is a great way to see many places that you would not probably get time to see let alone not knowing that they were there. Best of all it worked out to be about 40 cents one way each, one tip take small denomination coins as they don't give change.

A slow ride but... Excellent way to get around the island if you want to step on and off and see how the locals live their daily lives. One drawback is it has to obey all traffic signals but we love to take the team every time we are in the city. It is inexpensive, sometimes crowded but a really fun way enjoy Hong Kong. A must do!

The old transportation in HK. In fact, the should be the oldest transportation system still in Hong Kong Island nowadays. I love taking this indeed. Since the speed of the tram is very slow and it has no air-conditioner, it is the best way to travel around Hong Kong Island. For example, you can take the tram from Sau Kei Wan and get off at Sai Wan. You can enjoy the fantastic scenery in Hong Kong Island!! I love taking the tram by myself indeed so that I can enjoy the time being and the scenery quietly.
Kitch, but fun. Good for a ride or two while you're in HK. Though it's not the most efficient form of transportation, it's dirt cheap and fun for a photo opportunity.

Fun effiicient way to travel. Easy to use, a bit jerky, but very practical. We sat on top and had a nice view of city as well. Double decker makes for much room. Especially nice at night for overview of city.

must try. ding ding is slow but it is one of the oldest transit in hong kong. it has no air con so it could be hot in the day time. suggest trying it at night, and you will get to see the beautiful lights in hong kong.

Take a ride to see the HK island. Ding Ding (tram) is one of the best way to see the HK island, I always take tram instead of cab or train when I visited HK island. The fare is consider very cheap (around $2.30 per ride, if I not mistaken) and cover most of the important attractions in HK island, so, take a slow rite and enjoy the street view from tram. The tram is very retro feel, the wooden seat and wooden window frame and the special "ding ding" sound will bring a very unique experience.
A must attraction in HK. please dont miss this out while you're hk, is a must, can see all the every days lives in city! Ding Ding!

Best way to see Hong Kong Island!. Authentic and very cheap trams travel across whole Hong Kong Island. These trams are an attraction themselfs. The are neat and clean. If you want to see the true Hong Kong, take the tram instead of a cab.
Must ride :-). Just for fun, it is ok. Nice view from upper desk, ride very slow so it is ok to sightseen, plus U can have better picture than from street level.
H.K. Trams. Very convenient and frequent. Very crowded and basic. A cheap mode of transport once you knew the locations.

Love them. I love these trams. You can sit on them and watch the world go by. Make sure you travel upstairs either the very front or back for the best views.
I love the history of them
Still the best way to see HK. The old fashioned way is still the best - rattle along and soak in the sights as you wind along the main roads.

a fun ride. We used the tram quite a bit on our stopover in Hong Kong. It does get crowded and people are friendly and helpful when asking directions. The ticket price 2.5$HK and displayed outside the cab. A real Hong Kong experience.

Great experience. I loved our 2 trips with the Ding Dings! Simple to use and so frequent, you just wait till you see an empty one and jump on. It costs HKG £2.30 a trip so you can treat it as a hop on-hop off tour and just pop your money in the slot by the driver's door when you leave; it can't be simpler! We sat in the front both times and as it was not too humid, the breeze was great, wonderful views and such fun. Clean trolley cars too.

Just lovely - and takes Octopus cards!!. Ding Ding is just lovely and if you have an Octopus card you can use it on the tram, bus, Star Ferry and MTR. This must be one of the greatest, easiest and cheapest cities for transport in the world.So don't hesitate about getting your Octopus card or going on this tram.
Great experience!. A slow and low cost way to travel on certain routes. Highly recommended. The streetcars are double-deckers with a good view of all the busy life along the route.
Must do. The best $2.30 HK you can spend! On the upper level you get to see so much, ride it from end to end to end. When you see something you like, hop off, look around, then hop back on.

Great Introduction to Hong Kong. Ride this old fashioned, inexpensive tram from Tin Hau on the eastern end past the Western Market to get excellent overview in relative comfort. Then reverse direction and hop off to explore or shop at all the interesting locations you discovered.

Travelling alone. Riding the tram day & night is one of my favorite part of my HK vacay. It is a hop on hop off system & is very cheap, about 2.50HKD each way regardless of the distance. I prefer sitting on the 2nd level front seat to take amazing pix & videos of busy HK life. I love how they kept the actual carriage updated wit the latest movie ad etc. I just wish they also have the tram in Kowloon side. It really is a great way to see & experience the city. Can't wait to go back next Jun 2015

JA JA IN HONG KONG. After losing a lot of money at the racetrack and casinos JAJA needed a cheap way to see the city. Hopped on the tram and took it all the way to the end at Kennedy town. A great way to see the different neighborhoods and watch the people. Head to the upper deck and sit in front. I would love to see a party tram ----open upper deck with drinks and music.

Square Wheels on the Trams, but who cares?. This is a must do activity to see some of Hong Kong from a very unique perspective, and all for $2.50 HKD (45cents AUD).These trams rattle up and down the island side of Hong Kong, and at one point even go through the middle of the North Point Street Market.They are a great way to travel, thus making the journey a part of the destination. Try to sit either at the very front of the top of the tram, or the very back, the views and streetscapes are truly amazing

One of the must-try in Hong Kong!. I live in Hong Kong and I strongly recommend any visitors to take a tram ride! It takes only HK$2.3 and you can travel from one end of Hong Kong Island to the other. You can take a very close look at city life in Hong Kong on the upper deck. Usually the distance between two stations is not long, so you can always get off whenever you see something interesting on the street. Not all trams are air-conditioned but it feels good with all windows open. It is slow but it serves best when you want to go somewhere not close to any MTR station. If you come in a big party, you may consider booking a tram party with catering service. Please note that not all trams travel the longest journey (between Chai Wan in the east and Kennedy Town in the west), so make sure the tram you get on can take you to where you want.

fun way to explore HK. be sure to experience the tram before they are gone! i caught a ride from Central to Causeway Bay. The car is small and cramped. Be sure to enter from the back and make sure you bring exact change of 2.30$ or bring an Octopus card! I recommend you sit at the front of the upperdeck for the best view.

Ding Ding Tram. By far the most value for money attraction in Hong Kong by far....The trams range from new to old but all have character as they shake and rattle along the tram-line, passing the full array of Hong Kong's landmark buildings and shops. Very hot in the summer as no air con and hectic during rush hour. But a tram ride in Hong Kong is NOT TO BE MISSED
Cheap & Fun. Quite a novelty to ride these. The kids loved on as they got to sit up the top at the front.So easy to use, see some nice sights on the way to wherever you are going

So easy and makes so much fun. You just enter the tram but make sure that you have 2.30 HK in cash per person in you poket. You pay when you leave the tram. My recommendation: simply enter a tram without further destination and take a ride as long as it makes fun. Go to the uppder desk and try to get one of the front seat.

See Hong Kong the old fashioned way. Charming and authentic, really cheap way to see the city (HK$2.30/US$.40 per trip), great way to see bits of HK you'd easily miss otherwise.Quite easy also to get on the wrong one but there are only 6 routes and they mostly overlap somewhere so once you get the hang of it it's OK.

Fantastic value. So, so cheap!! We sat on the tram for an hour or so to get an idea of the area before getting off at various points for a wander around. One price 2.8 HK dollars regardless of whether you stay on for one stop or all the way to the end of the line. A great way to see HK and fascinating to watch the local way of life from the top deck of the tram!

Take the tram from the start in Kennedy Town so that you can get a seat upstairs.. A fabulous and incredibly cheap experience either day or night. No air con so may be a bit hot in summer. Take the tram from Kennedy Town to Central or even Causeway Bay if you have time - a wonderful slice of Hong Kong people and places!

A Great Way to See HK Island. The trams run from Shau Kei Wan to Kennedy Town. There is a tram change required at Happy Valley. The total trip lasts around two hours and is very cheap at $4.60HK for the entire trip.
Progress is fast but sedate and stately. From the upper deck you get a great view of Hong Kong

Inexpensive way to see Hong Kong. This is the perfect way to see the city at a cost of only $1.30 HKD (.60 cents CDN). Wait for an uncrowded tram and head up to the second level to enjoy a bird's eye view of the streets below. Enter the tram from the back and pay on the way out in the front. Every stop has a QR code you can scan on your smartphone to find out when the next tram is coming. There are maps at every stop as well. Fun!

Charming way to see the city. The Ding Dings provide a charming and unhurried view of the city. Take this option if you are not pressed for time and would want a relaxed view of the city and it's people.The double decker trams traverse the city and are a very popular and reasonably priced option (HK$ 2.30 per trip) for both tourists and locals alike. I preferred them to the MTR as the latter have maze like stations and you often end up walking miles just to get to the trains. The omnipresent Octopus cards can be used here as well.

good trip. this was an unexpected surprise,knew very little about this attraction but glad we went on it ,allthough busy the wait times were not to bad and the ride was very sedate like stepping back to another era!

Doubledecker tramways. Old, with style and modern efficiency - I love those trams. It is a must for tourist to explore the city on them. Cheap and comfortable transport on ground. If you need fast transport, use the metro but for sightseeing use this. bear in mind that you need to have exact fare prepared as the driver is unable to change. Or use Octopus cards - very convenient.
quick while it lasts. So nice for all of us that remember trams from out childhood.This one a good long route right through the middle of Hong Kong island.

Slow but steady progress and good views from the front. I was a kid, the first double decker bus arrived and I was so excited to try it. The same happened when I saw the double decker trams in HK, 46 years later. The positive far outweigh the negative, it is a steady progress through the north part of the island east-westerly. Fellow passengers are nice and polite except the group of shouting pushing mainland tourists. The fare is low but you must have the exact fare or you pay a bit extra. Front row upper deck gives you a great view of what is happening and how the town changes.

Iconic trans are a fun way to see the island. The Hong Kong Trams are synonymous with the city. The trams are often decorated with advertising but it seems to add to their charm particularly with Hong Kongs reputation as a shopping Mecca. It's a cheap and fun way to travel along the Hong Kong Island through Central.

A great viewpoint and history, too. The tram (ding ding) may not be the most efficient way to get from one end of HK Island to the other, but the hustle and bustle you see from the tram is much different from what you'll see in the MTR (subway). It's true that sitting on the top deck is a better viewing experience--more panoramic, less likely to be blocked by street-level traffic. Lots of vintage trams in a variety of colors, too--great to watch even when you're not riding.

Local Feel and Great Way to Cut Traffic at Peak Hours!. Local traditional transport! Cheap too! If you have time and the weather is nice- try it! Had a simple ride from Kennedy Town to Sheung Wan and this was worth the effort vs the MTR!

Fun way to travel. You have to take a trip or two on the tram. We travelled on it quite a few times and always went upstairs and tried to sit at the front. It's also a really easy way to get to Happy Valley races.

MY RIDE ON THE TRAMWAY. This is my favourite pastime for sightseeing Hong Kong. The fare is cheap for long distance. Normally I will travel from Kennedy Town to Quarry Bay or even to Sau Kei Wan. I will travel to and fro by changing my seat from right to left and this will take me about 2 hours sight seeing. This is a good way to spot interesting places, too. Avoid peak hour. Some warned me about the pick-pocket, but so far never encounter any. Happy travelling!

Quaint, cheap,excellent.. A lovely way to travel on Hong Kong Island. There is a map at each stop with a number at the top so you can figure out how many stops you have to go and what the number of the stop is. Be careful when you get on at the back if you are not a petite person. Lift your handbag over the turnstyle as you go through or you may get stuck!
a must experience. the tram ride was amazing - go before sundown and remember to take a jacket - it was freezing when we were there, take a camera - you will be struck:)

Cheap, quaint and historical. I used to work in Hong Kong and I would take the tram almost every day. It may not be the fastest form of transportation in Hong Kong but it is a great ride. It gives you a great meandering view of the Hong Kong streets and a glimpse into the bustling beauty of the city. I took guests on the tram when they visited and they always enjoyed it.

hong kong trams. another thing to do in hong kong just for the experience but they also go everywhere aswell, i did it just for the experince at first but then were just using them like the busses , you can tell the tourists because they will be the ones fighting for the front seats upstairs, these have got bags of character and are very colourful on the outside, they are cheap to use 30 - 40 pence per trip when i went. they are regular aswell so you wont be kept waiting for ages. they are old ( one of the oldest forms of transport in hong kong) so dont expect luxery but there far more fun than some trams in some cities around the world, the kids will love these aswell.
do it!. this is a quaint, old fashioned way to get from A to B. Not the fastest way to go but certainly an experience worth trying once.

Ding ding, a different view of HK. Great fun, a good way to see HK rather than always using the MTR. Seats are not the most comfortable but it is all part of the experience. Sit upstairs for fresh air and great outlook. Use your Octopus card on exit by swiping it just like you do on the MTR.
Great. Amazing way to see the city, only $2 and you can ride along all day if you like. Pay when you get off. Try and get a seat on the upper floor for better views.

See HongKong like a local. Rule number one ...never take a tram during rush hours!Between 10am and 11 am is a good time,get on one heading from Central to maybe North point...go up stairs if no seats available be patient as most people leave after 3 or 4 stops! Enjoy the ride and view, take pictures,look whats happening in the side streets,if your are getting hungry try and spot a good restaurant(rule of thumb:if its full of local people, then you can't go wrong)be brave get off and head for the place...don't worry in HK most people speak english and restaurants always have menus with pictures.A great meal for about a 5th of the price of a tourist area restaurant !

Excellent way to browse Hong Kong. For just HK$2.30 (US$0.30) each way, this is a very reasonable transportation for browsing Hong Kong from the west end to the east end. It's slow, but it's safe, stable and no rush. Fares for the seniors and kids are even a lot cheaper. Pay when you get off, and make sure you have exact change or an Octopus card because no changes will be made by the tram driver.
Great form of transport. Whatever city I travel to whether its Melbourne (Australia) or Zurich (Switzerland) I always use trams as my main source of transport. Hong Kong is the same.

my favorite part of central :). best way to experience and be a small part of the local lifestyle, the traffic, the people, the hustle and bustle of this very busy city -- all from the upper deck of the double decker tram. i wished we had taken this from one end to the other and probably would have been better if we took it first thing in the morning after the first wave of rush hour.

Sums up Hong Kong perfectly!. Probably the most accurate symbol of Hong Kong, the trams are traditional, quirky and packed full of people! We caught the tram from Fortress Hill to Happy Valley $2.30 HKD. Was amazing traveling past the packed streets, but was also very crowded and pretty hot!

Packed Tram. Its a fun experience with the open concept of the tram, where wind can blow on you. But it will be very packed and you will have difficulty alighting the tram as you'll need to go to the front of the tram.

One of the best way to commute on the island. The tram goes all the way from the western tip to almost the eastern tip of the island - at just HK$2.2. It can get a bit hot in summer (some of them are with air conditioning though) but as long as there is wind it is a pretty good experience to "ding ding" through the island.

a most traditional ride through HongKong on a Tram. On the Hongkong side a most back in time thing yyou can do is to ride the most comfortable and cheap way to get around the major thouroughfare around HK. It should be the most unhurried, relaxed mode of going through the city. They usually arrive every 5 minutes and the seats are ususally sufficient to have everybody a seat. It moves at a leisurely speed and the most attractive bonus you get is that you get to see the major neighborhoods and its distint characteristic. Various types of people take this tram from office workers, regular folks, the elderly, school kids, and even amahs. I would most suggest everyone to try this most comfortable and perhaps the cheapest mode of transport in HK. AT HK$1.30 it has to be the cheapest ride in Hongkong. If you havent ridden this tram then i would saly that you've never been to HK. A great wau to enjoy HK>

real HK transport!. Cheap and cheerful, the tram is a must to experience the old HK along with the new. It is a bit surreal, travelling on the old wooden tram past massive modern buildings through the hustle and bustle of HK Island. Just jump on, pay on exit, very cheap. Great!
whizzing through the city. We loved the tram ! Took a journey from the Marriot hotel to the Hyatt and loved every moment ! Great attraction and will do again on my return for a longer journey.

Very nice. So old-fashioned, but very nice way to travel on those old or old-looking double decker trams, that very often are packed to the roof. Not very fast, nor too comfortable, but absolutely the best way to travel in the city! And very cheap, too :)

Vintage style!. The tram is only available in the Hong Kong Island, frrom Sai Wan Ho to Sheung Wan. You can enjoy the unique "Hong Kong view", coz the tram is quite slow. Moreover, only costs an adult around two dollars.

Easy and cheap transportation. Our guide recommended seeing some of Hong Kong from this bus. Provided a nostalgic ride thru the city. A mix of locals with tourist made it very fun and avoid the congestion of walking in the heat.
Cheap and fast frequency. Ding Ding's waiting time were generally short, we enjoyed taking it as the island is small and well connected. You will be amazed by the fare which cost less than 3HKD

Worth a ride. This is super old heritage of HK. Its not a very long tramway, and runs through the main city area. Its worth a ride to experience. Goes through super busy roads in HK. Very cheap, so as very slow. If you are in a hurry to reach anywhere, i would recommend this :-), but for a tourist, do they take a ride once.
Excellent way to get around. I thought riding the ding dings was a fun experience given that you can only find them in a few cities. Very cheap and does it job. Clean.

Hong Kong's trams - a city icon as old and charming as the Star Ferry!. The electric tramways essentially ply a short distance between the eastern and western sections of Central or Hong Kong Island. At any time, the double-decker in particular, offers interesting views of the bustling city and its smartly dressed people. Inexpensive way to commute in this costly city. Time was in the 90s when gangs of us youngsters would fill a full tram and go up down Kennedy Town and Shau Kei wan, holding Round table meetings on the move. Today, the traffic is too heavy to even think of such fun!Again, the Hong Kong trams are as much city icon as the Star Ferry. As such a ride is recommended for the fun and excitement of traveling in a 100 year old institution.

Like going back in time. Cost almost nothing and what a way to see Hong Kong.You feel like one of the citizens of Hong Kong riding to and from work and shopping. Ding Ding is the sound of the bell from the trolly.Who wouldn't want to experience this nostalgia and wonderful experience in Hong Kong.Bring camera, have memories forever.

Brilliant way to travel, see the real Hong Kong. I have been visiting Hong Kong since 1986 and this was the very first time I took a trip on a tram, well I say trip, I journeyed to both extremities of North and South tram ways.It's a gentle means of travel, but remember they have hard seats!The cost is unbelievable, HK$ 2.3 My advice is travel upstairs, great for photographs but don't lean out of windows!Forget the tours, take a tram.

Inexpensive & quaint. For only HKD2.30 you get a view of the changing HK landscape, the buzz, smells and sounds that one imagines HK to be. Got on at a terminus and travelled to the other terminus and was deposited in a street market - what a way to see HK! Suggest travel off peak otherwise very crowded and sit upstairs in the front or back row for the best views and vistas. To get this right get on at the starting point. Old, creaky and quaint but oh so special.
Easy!. User friendly, inexpensive and convenient to get to several sites or subway stops. Get the Octopus card to make them even easier.

Easy way to get around. We took several Ding Dings - it was a great way to see the city during the day. They took on a completely different context during peak our - be prepared to get cosy with the person next to you. Upstairs at the front gives a great view

A lovely experience. Enjoyed the journey in double deckker tram. The trams run in the center of the road with the help of electricity. A very convenient and comfortable mode of journey, in few areas of Hong Kong. Had an altogether experience of travel.
such fun. Cheap colourful and fast way to get around. Around 2 HK dollars gets you a great experience. Easy to get on and off.
Public transport. Loved the trams saw all city sights and cheap our elderly parents loved it because it saved their legs and the kids loved the double decker because sat at top and saw everything.

Take a nostalgic ride. A great way to get around Hong Kong cheaply, but can be very crowded. Get on at the back and off at the front. Take small change with you to pay as payment goes into a box, with no change given. Or pay with your octopus card if you have one. Not suitable for strollers.

A great journey in Hong Kong. As a tourist first time to visit Hong Kong, tramway from all the way of Hong Kong Island is worth to take. You can experience the magical spacious change of different streets of such a over-crowded environment. The tram even passes through a market which share with the passerby. Nice view and in daytime and nighttime with very different feeling!

ding ding!. There are many modes of transport in Hong Kong but this is a little bit of the old with some novelty that appeals to the young and old alike.My children know the modern motor car very well and this was a new experience with a bit of history thrown in and good value at only HK$25. Ding ding!

Great way to see the city! And SOOO inexpensive. Took the tram from Causeway Bay to the Financial District. It was early evening, so we did let two pass us by to catch the less crowded third, but didn't even wait more than 15 minutes. Really neat way to see the vibrancy of HK.
nice but not much more. it is a nice ride to go across town but it is not very fast, it gets crowded and bring your change with you to pay

frozen in time but not in service. very few attraction around the world have a history and iconic attraction which you can interact with like a hong kong tram. whilst there is new modernised models of the icon tram circulating these days, the same basic characteristics remain - the narrow body, low roof heights, the sounds and smells.its will be rumbling up and down the isle for many more years to come.

The only way around Hong Kong!. The system is so well planned and designed that you really do not need any other mode of transportation. Clean, Modern. I love that you can check your bags in and then take the train to the airport awesome service.

A must - so much fun. A ride on shaky Hong Kong tramway - rather slow as means of communication - is an utter joy, especially if you manage to find one of places on the front. Just look around, at other passing tramways, nice girls :) and have fun. For me a must when you are in Hong Kong.
love it!. very very nostalgic! reminds me of hk many many years back! its in this ding ding that u experience the local people!

Cheap Travel and fast!!!. Riding the tram is very inexpensive and cost 2.3 HKD or 25 cents USD. Dedicated tracks and moves faster than traffic and walking!!!! Suggest always sitting on upper deck to see wheat you normally do not see when walking!!

Just get in for a couple of stops. if you have an Octopus card (which I strongly recommend), you just get in at the back for a few stops and alight in the front (where you can tap the card to pay 2 or 3 HKD). It's a very local transport system and can be pretty quick because you don't have the traffic jams.
you have to!!. one of the oldest forms of transport in HK, use your Octopus card and give it a try. we wanted to experience everything in a few days so we managed to ride a few stops on the top deck.

Ride Is Fun But The Air is Bad. The ride is fun and see lots about Hong Kong commuter daily life. Is a busy city and interesting city for everyone. The city is safe and not as movies fighting every corner in the city. Actual the more this kind of make up violent movies are bad imagine to Hong Kong. Also bad influence to the tourist whether to take this wonderful ride or just pass Hong Kong to Japan or Bangkok. The seat need to be clean to prevent bacteria passing around and the floor need to be clean each time. The road that the ride goes need to level and rectify the bumpy ride ......Check the city weather before go on the ride ......... You know what I mean .......!!
Fun ride. As with all transport in HK the trams are great to use and real fun to experience. Get upstairs to see the world go by.

fun mode of transport. The ding ding is a great way of seeing the city. We had octopus cards which made it easy - jump on at the back and pay as you get off at the front. Boy (6) liked to sit at the front upstairs, from where we had a good view and there's a bit of a breeze through the open windows. It's nice that this bit of history survives.

I love these things!. A great quick way to get around, and see the city while you're at it. Made most of my way around Hong Kong Island using these trams. Much less hassle than a taxi and closer to my hotel then the train station.

Hong Kong's Real Life Fun House. You have tickets included with the Hop off and Hop off Buses and this is the way to get to Vitoria Peak. The slant of the tram is what the British call most improbable....don't miss it if you are going to Hong Kong.

A Moving Piece of HK History!. These things are older than me, cost next to nothing and can take you from one end of HK island to the other! If you have a couple of hours to kill, you should definitely sneak up to the upper level with a beer (or four) and enjoy the tour!

Old fashioned nostalgia!. These old trams are like stepping back in time. We travelled almost the full length of Hong Kong island on one and really enjoyed it. We sat upstairs at the front of the tram and had a great view. Its really cheap and a must do when you come to Hong Kong!

cheapest and slowest way to see HK island. for $2.4 HK, you can ride for almost an hour across HK island from east to west, and get off at the attractions in between. The tram goes just slightly faster than running, maybe 50kmh max?there are a few lines and some trams stop at earlier stops instead of going end to end, so make sure you read the sign... Happy Valley will not get you to Causeway Bay but in that general direction. Try to avoid the rush hours as the tram does get filled up and there's not a lot of room to stand (and no standing in the stairway). if you are visiting HK, it's a MUST-DO (just like the Star Ferry)Just sit back look out the window and take it all in SLOWLY...
Great Fun!!! Good for Sight seeing. Good value travelling on the trams.... Also very cheap!!! Just carry lots of change cause you need the exact money for each ride... Love it!!!!

Anniversary holiday. We travelled all over Hong Kong Island on the trams.Being senior citizens it only cost us 2.20 dollars for both of us to travel any distance.easy to use, very busy, but part of the fun
Glad we did it.. It wasn't the most exciting thing we have ever done, but it was good to say we did it. A novelty, for sure.

Amazing...... I travelled in it just for experience. Fare is one way 2.30 hkd which you have to put in box or octopus card is also accepted. Keep change with you as no one is there to collect the fare. i took it from times square.

Cheap & Cheerful!. The tram is a great way to see Hong Kong. It really does feel like the old Hong Kong meets the new Hong Kong. My teenage son shows very little interest in doing anything "touristy" and he enjoyed the tram ride a lot. We got on at Central around 4pm and travelled to Causeway Bay. We sat on the top deck right at the front and although it was rather windy today we had the windows down. We thought it was great and costing $2.3 I really don't see why anyone would complain!

You must try it once !. The Ding Ding is a must, one must try it at least once.Not in summer (it has no aircon) but a very nice way to travel on surface and to see your surroundings at a slow speed.The top floor is to be preferred for that purpose, but I am afraid that too many people agree with me and therefore it tends to be packed.
Cheap, Fun and a good way to see Hong Kong Island. Hop on the top and ride the tram along Hong Kong island. If you see something you like you can hop off and get back on for $2.3HKD

Still the best way to travel on HK Island. A return visit to Hong Kong after 15 years. As with other cities around the world we expected, on this visit, to make good use of the metro and had downloaded the MTR app in preparation. Arriving at our hotel late afternoon we immediately went to explore, taking the metro to Central as expected. By the end of the evening we realised that the trams were still the best way to travel. With so many stops, its a hop on - hop off service. Every stop has a clear map of the route and each stop is numbered. Once you've mastered alighting at the back and making you way to the front of the tram ready to pay the fee as you disembark, its easy. OK so its a set fee (no change given) regardless of distance, at 23HKD it's less than 25p.

Best tourist deal in HK. Don't miss out on a tram ride in HK - sit on the upper deck and rattle along Des Voeux Road enjoying the streetscape for the cost of a normal transit fare - or use your Octopus card. Good way to have a break from the subway, too - but primarily just use it for some cheap sightseeing.
Hong Kong Tram. Cheap as chips. Best way to get along to Causeway Bay, from the ferry. Great way to see Central, Hong Kong.

why?. I don't understand how this could ever be considered a tourist attraction. I mean it's a tram, packed with people going to work and back, and not scenic at all. Save yourself the hassle, nothing special about this.
Really fun way to get around. The double decker trams are a really fun and cheap way to get around. The only down side is that they are really really noisy.

Spend only $2:00 and experience both the Old and New Hong Kong in 2 hours time Hong Kong. Sit on the upper deck after peak hour, start from any Tram station, travel to the end of the line towards the East or West. Bring a bottle of water. Sit back - weather permitting - not during the raining seasons - take down the window and enjoy.
Only took once..u need to know where yr going.. It runs all over HK proper, but good for short direct distances. HK can get VERY humid. I prefer to take a cheap taxi or the MTR.
Enjoy the Hong Kong lifestyle with a tranditional transport. the fare is cheap and bring along you from west to east, but if you are hurry or rush to some where then it is not suitable

Authentic and kiddie friendly!. So easy to use with the Octopus Card ... Get on at the back, and exit through the front, where you tap your Octopus Card when you get off (I am pretty sure that you can also use cash if you have the exact fare). Definately not pram friendly (but most of HK isn't pram friendly), so we carried our kids on ... And the locals have ALWAYS offered up a seat (also on the trains too) whenever they see us holding our kids ... A true testament to the hospitality and courtesy of the locals. I wish our kids had the patience to let us journey along HK island to take in the sights of the tram, but unfortunately we have only used it to get from A to B.

Unique Experience in Hong Kong. Yes, other cities have trams too, but when you're in Hong Kong you should definitely try riding the trams. You would experience how the trams navigate through the busy streets of Hong Kong and would definitely gave how the locals live in this city.It only costs slightly more than HK2.3 (equivalent to around US 30 cents).

Nothing special. The Ding Ding is just a trolley car. As one who grew up in Brooklyn and rode trolleys as a matter of course, I don't know why this is even listed as an attraction. It doesn't pass through pretty scenery, is crowded and difficult to alight and descend from.

A travelling experience reminiscent of the past. Serves as a reminder of how people travelled through the city in the past. The tram as such feels quite cramped after travelling in the buses that provide comfortable cushions. The trams are quite cheap compared to buses but travel slow and probably to fewer destinations. The cost is constant irrespective of how far you travel, so make the best use of it!

Great way to see the city and so easy/cheap. The trams are so easy and cheap to get around the city. Only $2.30 HK$ each time! I highly recommend getting an octopus card from central station (we got ours at the customer service desk near the airport checkin).

Exotic and Antique. this is a vey colonial method of transporation. try it when it is non-peak hours. better to wander in HK, the best way to get lost (while on track). Very beautiful and photogenic. Per ride is HK2.30 so you should either have octopus card or you should exact change. I think it wuld be very hard to ask for 0.70 change? i used octopus

Go back in time on the ding dings. Brilliant way to travel. Every city should have a tram system. Slow and steady and very cheap. Do not leave HK Island without taking onboard the tram experience. Do not go on without any small change if you do not have a pass.

Great way of seeing HK. If you want to see HK, this is the best and the cheapest way to travel, only 2.30 hkd for a trip.Unfortunately, it only operates in HK Island not Kowloon. It passes through from heartland to business districtIf you see something interesting, you may alight as you wish. You pay for each re-boarding
i love it so much. of course they are very low but it is a part of folklore or Hong Kong.try to get a place on the first deck; nice view. and all the tramways are sponsored by a nice brand

funny, beautiful, bette than in san Francisco. very kind conductor, patient with my not finding coins...those trams are a hit and on a very helpful way to see the core of the city(too noisy and smelly to walk)

cheap. cheap way to travel compared to london transport hk is excellent cheap and easy .
always a ding ding when you need them . taxis change shift aroung 4.30pm every day and hard to find .
ding ding is then the best on hk island

Fun way to explore the island. The ding ding che runs only on the island, and it's slow but a fun way to get around. Many locals still use this to get around so its a lot of fun to experience a ride on this historic tram. Grab the first seat on the top deck with your camera for great views of the city and street scenes.
A great way to get around. The only double decker Trams in use in the world. They are well used, cheap and frequent. Fairly slow but tranquil, A great way to see HK island.

Trams don't 'ding ding' any more. In fact Hong Kong tramways gave up the bell for the horn in the mid 1990s. The tramway runs almost the entire length of Hong Kong Island, from Kennedy Town in the West to Shau Kei Wan in the East, with a branch line to the Happy Valley Racecourse in the middle. It has always been the cheapest mode of transport in Hong Kong, with a fixed price of HK$2.30 (in 2015). It's also the least comfortable as the poor old dears wheeze and jerk their way along the bumpy tracks. 'Modern' trams with plastic moulded seats and air conditioning are beginning to make an appearance, and at weekends 'Party Trams', packed with drunken yobbos, vibrating to duff-duff music, cruise the route. (Don't try to catch one!) If you want to get anywhere quickly, take the MTR, or comfortably take the bus, but if you just want to cruise the streets at first floor level and watch life go by, you can't beat a Hong Kong tram.BTW, if the tram seems too crowded when it arrives, wait for the next one - it is always empty. It's a physics-defyling phenomenon unique to Hong Kong as far as I know.

Some of the trams are from the original lot.. Its like going through a time machine to get off the Metro and get into one of these. The Octopus cards work on the trams and they are the best way to get around the Island. Some of them have the original wooden interior from the initials days of the service. This was my first experience on a tram and if you have not been on one, I would definitely recommend you to try it. It is extremely cheap and a great alternative to walking on the island.

Great fun. The ding ding is amazing. Cheap and efficient, it crosses the entire island and allows you to reach nearly anywhere. Plus it's fun! Sit on the top floor to get great pictures of the city.Perfect for sightseeing.
Interesting ride. Interesting and cheap way to travel in Hong Kong. The ride costs less than HKD2.50. Try to get a seat on the upper deck to enjoy the view of the city.
enjoyable ride. When we got into the tram and when the tram was moving up the hill we felt as if the houses were slanting and it was an awesome feeling.

Trams are a great way to see the island. The tram route is along the old foreshore which gives one an idea of how much reclaiming has gone on since the first tram ran.Still a very cheap form of transport as the first price ( around HK$2.50 ) takes you from one end of the line to the other.The new trams are great, I can now stand up without hitting my head and the seating is much better. The best location is the front seat uptop where you can watch Hong Kong daily life as you cruise along

Still great experience. Took our 3year old daughter to experience the Ding ding while we are on our holiday. We chose off peak hours around 2pm on weekday to avoid the crowds and is fun. We hop on one to do a few stops from central and then hop on another to return for $2.5 is well worth the experience.

Snapshot of the mega polis in one ride!. Great way to have a glimpse of this bustling mega polis in minutes! Get a seat on the upper deck and enjoy the sights and sounds. The trams are quaint and are of the bygone era which adds to the charm :-)

HK Tramway Elevates and Offers Snapshot into Old World Cog Tram. If one is in HK for a day or more, you owe it to yourself to hike to the base of the tramway for a trip up to the peak. The view is worth the wait, providing it's clear, and I felt like I was in a movie or Europe as the tram trundled up the steep rails. The technology is quite remarkable and one can't help but feel a certain sense of relief when the tram nestles into the shed, particularly on the way down.
Tourists must try. even not a fast tool for bringing you been there, but there is a hong kong signatureslow, but very transitional, and window open, you can feel the outside

Perfect way to get around. Stonking value and great fun. Has to be experienced at least once by everyone. Go upstairs and get to the front or back to shoot some great movies. Make sure you have the right change.

Allegedly the only double-decker trams in the world!. OK, so this was just a tram ride, the only different to tram rides in other cities is the fact that you can go upstairs! Drivers don't seem to restrict numbers, so it can get really crammed on there; just make sure you wiggle your way to the exit close to your stop! When I returned to Dublin, I was reliably informed that the old trams here used to be double-deckers too.

Must do for tourists. The tram is an institution in Hong Kong and while the majority of riders use it as part of their daily commuting lives, for a tourist its just a great way to see the bustle of Hong Kong for a little pocket change. But do remember, that its a 'push and shove' experience if you board during peak times, so its best to go mid morning or mid afternoon. Make your way to the top deck and wait for a seat to become available and then watch Hong Kong go by. Its a slow ride, so relax and enjoy. And remember there's no aircon (so avoid in July/Aug), no toilets, little headroom, and a crush of humanity during peak hours. The tram stops are generally spaced every 5 mins or so. Pay on exit with coins or Octopus!

fun way of transportation. Very old school but good way to see a bit of the city. Grab a seat upstairs for a good view. only minus point is that you get stuck in Traffic as the tram tracks are in the normal road. Way to go for the Wednesday horse racing.
A nice novelty but. It is very slow, i can't believe people actually ride theese for longer distances, it's just remotly faster then walking, especially when in the most central places.
Take the time. Grab your camera, sit in the front of the upper level, an d ride from one end of the island to the other. Snap away.

If not rushing. Jump on board of the ding ding in HK great way to see the locals commuting mainly the ones can't afford a metro tkt ding ding tram is very cheap.Slow tho, and if you are in the middle of wet summer might be a not very good idea.
Fun. Fun and ultra cheap. Gets a bit of a squeeze when the workers travel home but wouldn't miss a bit of it. Combined with the double decker buses there shouldn't be a necessity to use taxis.

Best view of Hong Kong. For about $US1 you can travel from Central to Happy Valley and see the bustling heart of Hong Kong. Tourists should avoid peak hours when the trams are uncomfortably packed. During the middle of the day skip up to the top deck.
A blast from the past!. Certainly NOT the quick way to get around but graet for nostolgia and sighseeing. Got to be done! And the cost is so negligable.

An excel;lent way of getting around the Central part of Hong Kong. Despite a low roofline which may be an issue for those who are more than six feet tall the Hong Kong Tramways are a great and cheap way of getting around the centre of Hong Kong island.
Best way to get around. Lovely old wooden framed trams, fairly easy to find your way around if you don't mind getting squished.

Bumpy but fun. If you fancy a change from the bus, why not take the Tram. You can use your octopus card (a must have if touring Hong Kong). Upstairs, you have a great view of this fantastic bustling city. Hold tight please DING DING.

Cheap and efficient. A fun thing to do but a very uncomfortable ride.
But you have to do it at least once while in HK.
Hop on the back, make your way to the front and pay the driver or as we did use your octopus card when you get off. So cheap and easy.

Look at the crazy busy HK at a slow pace. Ding Ding has been with HK residents for many years and it's still the cheapest way to travel on Hong Kong island. If you're not in a hurry, try this slow pace transportation. Ideally, take it from the final stop at Kennedy Town, sit on the top level and enjoy the lovely ride through the old and the new of Hong Kong.
Good Fun. Traveling in tram is good fun. You pay with your plastic card so it's hassle free. Must try to experience the heritage of HK.

Like a Harry Potter ride.. One of my very favorite things to do in Hong Kong. They're turn of the Century Double Decker Electric Trams. So they're extremely heavy bottomed for a low center of gravity. The drivers are real cowboys,and like to speed right up to a stopped tram at full speed,then stop a few inches from it. I always go upto the top,and try to sit in the front seat. I get a great view and fun ride. It is amusing to come flying up to the back of a tram,which has a passenger sitting in the rear seat,and come to a stop, inches from each other's face. Several times I got them to loose their drinks in surprize. Because of the low center of gravity, the drivers speed around the streets,and curves on Central Hong Kong, just like the bus ride in the first Harry Potter movie. Cheap thrills for those tourists who don't have a weak stomach.

Must do while in HK. There are many ways of getting round HK but the tram is by far the best, dirt cheap and, as eveything gets out of their way, sometimes surprising quick. A couple of times I've been in HK and didn't really know what I fancied doing so just jumped on a tram and went to the end of the line and each time we found something good there. You go from the madness of Central out to the old suburbs and see lots of old Hong Kong along the way so don't mess about with tours and open top busses just jump on a tram and hang out with the locals.

"An economical way to explore Hong Kong". This slow ride option brought us down the memory lane as we passed through some old streets with shops selling local groceries and delicacies. A good way to explore non-commercial part of the city.

Inexpensive foolproof way to view Hong Kong life. There are few better ways to view HongKong - and few better ways to photograph the city. Jump on board and travel to the end of the line. Cross the track and head back. Great way to get your bearings. Only on the Island.

Great fun and so cheap. The buses and taxis may be quicker but this is the fun way to travel. The seats are basic and the stairs steep but as long as the line goes where you want this is a good way to get into the centre.
Easy way to get around. If staying in Hong Kong for several days, it's well worth getting an Octopus Card. The trams are easy to use and run regularly.

one of my hong kong favorites. excellent way to see and experience local life. lovely mode of transport even if it gets crowded and hot, especially during summer. iconic moving antiques that get you from A to B without going underground and costing a fortune. i will always find an excuse to ride them when i'm in hong kong.
Worth the trip. We made a trip into Hong Kong on a layover during our trip. It was worth our time and effort to take the airport express in to experience the amazing views of the city.

very good ride in HK island. i think the tram is a great way to move between places in hk island. its very very cheap and the down side is that, it's usually very very packed. but if you're sight seeing, then hop on the tram and climb up the upper deck and enjoy the view.
Fun. Vintage trams amidst the urban jungle, very cool. Obviously time of day makes a difference to how busy, but a fun way to get from one end of the city to the other. Love my Octopus card.

Great way of seeing Hong Life. Great fun riding on the tram system, but always remember to have small change for fare. You pay when you leave the tram, place money into a collection box by driver, no change given. (I think it was HK$2.50 per person for each ride, check!!) The same system for the buses, no change given, small change is aa must

Salvation of the Solo Backpacker. Running East to West across the Tourist-y heart of Hong Kong Island, it is almost inevitable to find yourself depending on this cheap and dependable ride to find your way around. I have learned to associate the tracks with the assurance that yes I will find my way back to the place with the ferries in it.
Fun. Riding the trams is a great way to view different aspects of Hong Kong Island. You can get on and off as you choose. I recommend the upper level in front seat if available

Crowded but fun!!. Just puts you right in the center of everything Hong Kong. Maybe crowded but worth the experience. It doesnt cost much to ride and it can take you from CausewayBay to Central in no time.

Not disabled friendly. Lovely old trams and on all routes in Hong Kong.Entry via a turnstile was awkward for disabled and not very wide so can be a little cosy when busy.... Cheaper than buses though and more to see than MTR.

Great way to see the island. Squeeze in the back amongst the locals.
Travel East or West along the Island.
Push up to the top level and enjoy the view.
Hop on and off when you see something interesting - best use an oyster card - makes paying simple.

Unique experience that can only be found in Hong Kong Island. It is a kind of public transport in hong kong. However， it can only be found in the hong kong island. It is the cheapest way to travel the hong kong island side as you can see the view in the tram. If you want to experience this， the better route would be from central to causeway bay or the other way round. You can enjoy the night view of the busiest part of hong kong.

Experience the old way of travelling. The Hong Kong double decker trams are a typical example how people were travelling through the city in the colonial days. It is a slow way of travelling but it gives you a nice opportunity to view the city at a very low price.

Slow and fun way to see the city!. Such a fun way to see the entire northern part of Central Island - try to take it from one way to the other - Kennedy Town to Shau Kei Wan. The best $2.30 HKD you've ever spent
ding ding. double levels trams are rare in the world but you see them throughout hk islands ! the old ones are so vintage and the sightseeing tram is surly something a tourist should not miss.

Fun Ride Through Hong Kong. Took the Tramway through down town Hong Kong to get a good overview of what the city looked like. Found a seat on the top level in the front and kicked back and rested my feet. Great way to cover a lot of the city and get a great view of the buildings, shops and people. The cost was minimal, I believe 2.5 HK$ so like $.33 US.

Chic & Chill. Please scroll down for English language
รถรางดีกว่าที่คิดนะ หลายคนไปฮ่องกงมักคิดว่าต้องนอนใกล้ MTR จริงๆ แล้วรถรางสะดวกกว่ามาก เดินใกล้กว่า เห็นวิธีชีวิตของคนฮ่องกงชัดเจน ลงรถปุีบเดินเข้าห้างได้เลย ไม่ต้องเดินลากยาวจากชานชลา ขึ้นบันไดแล้วเข้าห้างแบบ MTR รักที่สุด Ting Ting !!!
Many People though The MRT are greatest but not at all. The Tram will bring you back to the old days. slow life and enjoy every minute with Tram...Ting Ting+++
Great experience. Very enjoyable trip and an experience not to be missed when in Hong Kong. Be prepared for the view and expect to queue unless with an organised tour

Slow, sedate, fun - a trip back in time.. I love Hong Kong's trams. Full stop - no argument.I beleive that they first saw service in Blackpool in England on the promenade areas, and were brought over to Hong Kong in the 1890s (yes, they are that old!!). Of course, there have been some newer vehicles introduced since then, but many of the original trams are still in service.Another amazing fact is that the tram lines are still in their original locations, but that it's fascinating to learn that the northernmost sections (from Western Market all the way through to near the end of the line at Shau Kei Wan) ran along the seafront. In some places reclamation means that they are now close to a mile from the sea!!Although it's a very slow way to see Hong Kong, there is no more relaxing (apart from the crowds of passengers!!) way of seeing the contrasts of Hong Kong. From the gleaming skyscrapers of Lippo Centre, Bank of China, and so on, to the bamboo poles of washing hanging out to dry, it's a colourful chaotic trip. My favourite route has always been to take the MTR to Shau Kei Wan, then jump on a tram to Western Market - must be around 10 miles or so (about an hour in duration), and all for a flat fare of HK$2.30 (about 28 pence or 40 US cents) - bargain!!On HK race days, these rickety quaint old trams are a favourite way to get to the racetrack at Happy Valley - there's a branch line that stops very close by the main grandstand. So if you find yourself at a loss on a Wednesday evening, you could combine two of HK's iconic attractions and go racing by tram!! I did!
Just a funny way to get around HK. A fun and inexpensive way to get around downtown Hong Kong and pretty fast too, there are so many different designs

A Hong Kong equivalent of hop-on-hop-off buses. Certainly not the fastest way of getting around the island but without any doubt the most authentic. For a little over 2 hkd you can ride across half ot the island and see some of the hallmarks of the city without doing a single step.

My old friend, the Ding Ding. When I was a kid in Hong Kong back in the 1960s, my ama (cross between a nanny and a domestic aide) would take me to school and our mode of transportation by choice was the tram or ding ding as we endearingly called it. The upper deck then was called first class and at the price of 30 cents per person, where else could you go first class? The tram, as I remember, was not everybody's favorite, some lamented that it was too slow while other complained of the blood sucking fleas that lived in between the rattan seating. But for myself then as it is now, the ding ding is more than a mode of transportation.
