Before I left Hong Kong, I could not think of a less expensive or better way to while away a muggy summer evening by sitting in the front row of the upper deck with the windows rolled then and allowed the gentle nocturnal breeze to caress my face and sooth my soul while feasting my eyes on the gradual transformation of a busy city that was about to call it a day as the ding ding slowly made its way from North Point to Kennedy Town.Several decades later, while I am no longer a little boy and my ama was long gone, I still make it a point to at least ride the ding ding once or twice every time I visited Hong Kong. In this world of uncertainties, it is nice to know that something has remained constant. Try it, you cannot go wrong.

Cheap and convenient!. So glad I discovered the trams! Best way to get around HK island, and with a good view and site seeing! Easy to read signages and alerts at all stops! Be sure to enter by the back and tap out in front. Best views are from the top of the double decker!

Double-Decker Tramway experience. Taking the double-decker tramway from Western Market in Sheung Wan as recommended by my guidebook. I appreciated the fact of seeing buildings, streets on Hong Kong Island. If I took the MTR then I'd miss the views. I also enjoyed seeing the different ads on the trams. Met a nice Filipino lady and she showed me how to get to the Times Square when I got off at Causeway Bay stop. Thanks to my Chinese New Year tourist promo "envelope" received at upon arriving at the HK Airport, I had a free voucher for a tram ride. You should definitely take the tram to see the city!
So lala. Nothing special to see. There are so many more interesting things to discover around the world. Just a simple tram if i must say truth. Sorry...

cheap, and good for sightseeing!. The tram is always a fun way to get around hk island. Little slow, but good for seeing the city. If you're going 3 or less metro stops, then it could actually be faster than the train.

Redefines the meaning of trams. Hong Kong trams certainly redefined the meaning of trams as we had come to believe in India, in Kolkata. Ding Ding at HK actually made me believe that trams can prove to be a great people-mover instead of just being a mark of tradition and the perennially cause of traffic snarls. Trams in Hong Kong are fast, frequent, double-decked and also cheap. They run from 6Am till half past 12 in the night. They provide the best vantage point to admire the innumerable and glitzy malls & hotels dotting both the sides of the entire strength of road from Keneddy Town in the west to Shau Kei Wan in the East. We used the tram a lot in our 4 days trip of HK city and enjoyed every bit. It very simple to use as they run almost straight in East-West direction on the Hong Kong island. So even if you have a slight notion of which direction to go in general, you can just hop onto the tram, besides detailed maps are displayed on all tram stops and on their website. My wife was especially excited to see the cheetah-print tram racing across the town!!
What a ride. It was great to take a ride on an old tram.The views were outstanding.It brings you back a hundred years.One can not visit HK without doing it.

So fun. My hotel was easiest to access via the tramline, so I used it a lot for several days. But the first time I used it, I used it just to get the lay of the land and took it practically from one end of HK to the other and it was fabulous for that (especially when it was raining). Sit upstairs. You'll swipe your Octopus card when you get off (oh, and it's dirt cheap too!).
Get a seat upstairs. Who would come to Hong Kong & not ride a tram?There's not many places left to ride trams like this. Great fun.
slow life on tram. HK MTR, TRAIN, BUS, TAXI are very fast..However we cant see the view clearly...As tram is very slow in HK Island, It's very good to enjoy slow HK life :)

Breathtaking view, fantastic tram ride. To me, your trip here isn't complete without a trip here. Although I enjoy the views a lot, but it was a bit too crowded for my like. However the tram trip is fun. Beware of buying anything electronics here though. They will sell you something that's broken. I have heard this before but cannot believe that it actually happened to me!
Clang on a tram. Tried a ride on ancient tram , very enjoyable .got a great feel for the city . A must do trip for very low price .

Ding Dong Ding. My wife and I took the Ding Ding one afternoon while in HK. Although it was mid day, our car was quite crowded. If you're “stuck” in the back and want to alight, just keep yelling as you make your way forward. If the driver can hear you, he'll wait for you. Fellow passengers were very helpful. Also, I downloaded the DD app to my 'phone and was able to track our journey, just to ensure that we got off at our desired stop.In truth, I traveled on the Myrtle Avenue trolley in Brooklyn many times in my misspent youth. Although that was about 65 years ago, I did not find the DD to be anything exceptional. If you're there, it's worth a shot. Use the app.
Top ride. You have got to ride the Tram while in Hong Kong. Sit up the top for some wonderful views of the city. The $2.30HKD is so cheap.
Favorite way to cross the islan. It's my favorite way to cross the island, the only thing: you must not be in a hurry!Elegant, cheap and a bit sightseeing.

Great to see the city slowly. It is a pleasure to go across this busy city and enjoy the views from this old trams. It will only cost you a few cents...And remember, you pay at the end of the ride!
Only if you have time because...they are slow

Must go . Im From hong Kong. I do recommend all travellers To take this to thé Peak. It is must do Activity in hong Kong.
You CAN See thé amazing Night view Of hong Kong At thé Peak.

Very Reliable. These were fun to ride since they are very different from the other public transport that I have taken and they are very reliable. This was my main form of transportation to get around and it was lovely. Must try at least once.
My favor in Hong Kong. A cheap and easy way to look around the island, it go through the city center of the island and is recommended to ride it in non rush evening.

you have to try it. this thin, high, funny trains are ikons of Hong Kong Central, easy to use, great experience and sightseeing, you have to try them! Especially useful if you go from Central towards Admiralty or Causawaybay.

Excellent way to see the city. These trams are fantastic, a reminder of the old days of British rule. They are noisy, sometimes crowded but this is what the real Hong Kong is about. Be sure to get yourself an Octopus Card as this makes it cheap and easy to get on and off wherever you like.

What a Fabulous Way to Explore the Surroundings!. Unbelievably good value! For approx. 36 pence (Uk Sterling) you can ride the tram from one end to the other.
Its a super way of finding your bearings and exploring the area.
We got on and did a full circle before getting off again.
Sit on the top at the front if you can for the best view.

a cheap way to tour. When we got up the first day, it was too early for shopping, and we didn't know where we wanted to go, so, we jumped aboard one and took an extended trip on one of the routes. Go upstairs, and work your way to the front. From there we just lowered the window for fresh air, and enjoyed the ride. Super cheap.

Something Different. Now I have been on trams before, but never where you can get on and go the whole length of the line for 25pence. It's pretty slow which for me was great, taking in the local areas. I will however catch cab to the office!!!!
Take a short trip when it's not too hot. Recommend to take a ride from Central to Wan Chai. Just about 10 to 15 minutes and it's a great way to see downtown.

The BEST travel experience in HK. Flat fare 2.30...takes the octopus card...close up views of everything...nothing not to love. Only warning, do not go if you are in a hurry to get somewhere or meet someone because the traffic jams affect the trams as much as the cars and buses and it's a frustrating feeling. For short journeys along the coastal strip of HK island it is actually easier than the MTR because you end up walking so much in the stations. Also great to spot places to see or visit.

travelling slowly in the hustle and bustle, dreamy. The tram is like the slowest form of transportation in the central business district in Hong Kong and we totally loved it. it feels like we were on a kinda ride that takes us to the old good time. The feeling is actually quite surreal since everything, everyone around the tram is super fast and busy. me and my girlfriend totally enjoyed the ride. Even if we were sure of where to get off actually, we still find it a very good experience to aimlessly wander around the Central district as it is really beautiful.

A glimpse of the past. Taking a ride on the tram makes me think of how people used to travel in the past. The tram is the most used public transport when it was built in 1904 and i believe it continues to be the case even till today due to how economical it is - just a flat HK$2.3 for an entire ride which can run for an hour if you fancyWhile i took the tram during cooler weather and enjoyed it thoroughly, i can imagine how uncomfortable it can get in summer, with the heat and crowd all bundled in a 2 storey vehicle.

Great if you are a tram lover. I understand the enthusiasm of other reviewers, but for me, the trams are a bit of a chore. I can't stand up straight in the trams because of the low ceilings and the seats are hideously uncomfortable. Yes, they're cheap and an Interesting aside during a visit, but if you are looking for efficiency and comfort, probably not so much.

fun!!. Went on the trams a few times when in HK and they really are great simple fun. It's much better than walking as the streets are so busy. Also its a good way to see things as you trundle along. Tip:-) try to get a seat on the top deck.

A different sightseeing way. It's slow and funny. Seat down, relax and let it take you from one side to the other of HK island and enjoy the view. It may be used either for short distances within downtown and for discovering popular, not touristic areas (why not) of the city. If you are in a group of friends you can even rent one in the evening, bring your music, chose the drinks and have a private party on an open top coach.Many trams are original old ones kept functioning by using new and safe components.

Cheap and fun. I lived in Hong Kong for 11 wonderful years and never more than a stone's throw from the tram line. It still gives me a thrill to hear the rattle and get back on one of the old trams whenever I visit.Top tip: You can often hop on an empty tram and secure your favourite seat by waiting at a terminal. There are a number of terminals along the line. For example wait by the Regal Hotel for a tram departing west from Causeway Bay.
MUST. If you go to Hong Kong and haven't ride on a tram then just like never been to Eiffel tower in Paris.

Great way to get around. Loved the trams and so cheap, what a great way to see the city, just jump on the back and throw your money in the front when you get off . Fixed fee wherever you go, 5 hkd for us, not even 50p !

Cheap and easy. Once you figure out the system...it's cheap and easy to use! It goes either east or west, depending on which side of the road you're on, and it runs along the main road of Hong Kong island's tourist areas.

I love tram tour. The tram has been operating in Hong Kong for a century, still reliable, the path from the west to the east on the Hong Kong Island less than one hours only $2.40, only $2.40 (not sure, we we electronic fare collection card now) ,but very slow , not a speedy boat , However, the height of the cabin not very tall. at 5'10" only.. tall guys have to be humble (bend down the head). Sorry not suitable for wheelchair, very narrow gate for people walk in/out.

Good way to have a look at the city. I took the tram from the Sheung Wan Station (West part of Hong Kong) to Chai Wan Station (East part of Hong Kong). The cons are that if you are in a hurry, this is not the quickest way to travel and sometimes the tram is packed of people so one has to wait for a long time before being able to take a seat. The pros are that this is a great way to have a look at the various sightseeing spot throughout Hong Kong, one can take many photos, it is also particular and that this way of travel is very cheap compared to the others(one has to pay when he/she gets off and I paid something less than 5 HKD for the whole ride).

Rattle Rattle Bang Bang. Traveling on these wonderful trams takes me back to my child hood days in Sheffield, we had these sort of trams and I had forgotten how uncomfortable and very narrow they are, rattle, rattle bang, bang they go but it is a pleasure to ride on them and they are brilliant British history. But today no conductors just place your Octopus card on the spot and you have paid, no more "Any more fares please" but its like that back in Blighty" The seats are wooden no soft cushions but they are very uncomfortable, take a ride and see how your granddad and granny used to travel.

Ding Dings. Want to see Hong Kong at its most Authentic then take a ride on the trams (ding dings).They are incredibly crowded loud and uncomfortable but you get a great view of the areas and they are frequent and above all very cheap particularly if you purchase an Octopus card.If you are looking to get off before the terminus then plan your exit 2/3 stops beforehand as it may take you that long to get through the crowd to get off

Value for Money Ride. It could be the most cheapest but best for sight seeing experiencing of riding an unique transportation means in Hong Kong. My suggestion is to ride the double deck tram from Sai Wan terminus (West part of Hong Kong Island) all the way to Sau Kei Wan Terminus (Est part of Hong Kong). You should choose to go for the ride during weekdays non-rush hours and sit at the upper level. Then, please sit down and relax to enjoy the scenery of remaining old buildings at West part of Hong Kong, passing through the Central (financial district), Admiralty (business district), Wanchai (some old buildings along the tram line), Causeway Bay (Victoria Park), North Point, Taikoo, Sai Wan Ho... Approaching Sau Kei Wan area, there are many old buildings still around. You may realize the cultures and daily life of Hong Kong people by observing from the upper deck of the tram. It is a much better experience than paying more to ride the Big Bus Company tours. Tell me your own experience after.
Explore the city. Recommended.Cheap and fun way to experience the city.Get on second floor and enjoy the view of Hong Kong :)

Cheap and efficient - a great way to tour the island. The tramway along the North coast of Hong Kong Island is an excellent way to see this bustling city in all its glory. These double-decker trams are unique in the World. I recommend starting your journey in Kennedy Town (at the start of the line) to guarantee a good seat - you can get there by MTR underground train.

cheap and comfortable. It is a comfortable transportation if you are not in a hurry. The fare is low. However, sometimes it would be very crowd. maybe it is better to take it at night. If I can choose, I would prefer the tram without air con.

A Bygone Era. I'm a Hong Kong expat having lived here for over 20 years. I thoroughly recomend taking the 'Star Ferry' cruise in the evenings for the best vistas of the iconic Hong Kong skyline. The experience and views obtainable from the open sided ferry are excellent. A Hong Kong Trams are iconic in themselves providing reasonable quick and VERY cheap transport to the Hong Kong general public since WAY before our fantastic underground Train system ( MTR). Its impossible to get lost as they only go along the North side of Hong Kong Island. Take a trip back in time and board one of our Hong Kong Trams. A must whilst in Hong Kong. (Just watch your head. the ceilings are VERY low!!). I hope you enjoy your stay.

No more ding ding. It's known as ding ding 'coz it used to have the ding ding sound when there're requests for the next stop. You have the pull the string and the bell rings at the stop. We were excited to get a ride on it again after years with my boys (who were born aboard). I agree that it's still an economic way to see the city, however, we're disappointed that the ding ding sound was gone.It's good to travel around the city if you have time. Otherwise, you'll be stuck in local traffic with the cars for a while. If you're in a rush, MTR is still the #1 choice.

economical transport option. the double-decker tram is a great way to see the city as well as to commute from one point to another. you can easily spot the brightly-colored trams or as locally called 'ding ding'. we took a little while to understand how it runs and its end points but once we had, we went for a merry ride, seated in the upper deck and looking at the sights the city has to offer. if you are using money, please have exact change as the tram driver is not going to return change to you. we got off at one of the midway stations and it was extremely crowded. but by the time we reached one end, the tram was empty. my husband was truly fascinated with it!

Classic, Excellent Way to See Hong Kong. This historic double decker team service is one of the best ways to see diverse Hong Kong neighborhoods and street scenes. Get on in Western or Quarry Bay and ride the line through Central, Wan Chai, Causeway Bay and Quarry Bay on the Upper Deck at a leisurely pace with great photographic angles. An excellent way to maximize your Hong Kong experience. Pay with your Octopus card on exit.

Must try: Easy, cheap and historic way to see HK Island city side. The trams go mainly between West and East side of HK Island. It operates very frequent (every 5 minutes until midnight).The price is only 2.3 HKD (children 1.2) no matter how far you travel. Take the double decker and enjoy the view of the buzzling city, buildings and people. It is a tourist attraction, but it is also easy to use as a main transportation if you stay in HK Island side. It is hard to get lost on the tram as long as it operates between West and East. Remember that the driver doesn't change if you pay in cash. Alternatively you can use an Octopus card. Remember also that you pay when you leave the tram (in front by the driver). Entering the tram is on the back/rearside and the driver will not let you enter in front. In rush hour it is very crowded. Try to avoid this if you only want to try and experience the Ding Ding as tourist. Strollers on the trams are also difficult/impossible in rush hour. We only carried our 5 months daughter.

Fun!. Trams are not only a fun experience in Hong Kong but also one of the most effective and convinient ways to explore the island. HKD 2.3 flat for a ride and you can get on and off any at point. Plenty of tram stops along the island so its as good as a HOHO. It runs only on HK island though, so you have to go back to the bus, ferry or MTR to get off the island
Back in time. The trams are great but the wooden seats are not good for the back. Take a tram from and to Happy Valley race course. One of the best rides in the World.

Five star experience. As a frequent traveler to Hong Kong, I always admired the tramways from the outside but avoided to use them because I considered them too slow to be efficient. This time I decided to give them a try and I am extremely happy for doing so. They are indeed slow but they offer a different vision of Hong Kong island. Highly recommended!

A True Hong Kong Experience. Many Hong Kong residents use the Tram's every day. If you ride one of these, it is a real Hong Kong experience. Probably the cheapest possible tour you can do perhaps with the exception of the Star Ferry. Mostly the Tram's just go east to west or west to east with the exception of Happy Valley Tram's which deviate south halfway along. The price is currently 2.3HK$ which is a bit of a fiddly price, most locals have an Octopus Near Field cash payment card, worth getting if you are visiting for mire than a couple of days. they can be used in many places including McDonalds, 7-11 etc. You pay when you get off the Tram and it does not matter what distance you go the charge is the same. when you pay the driver will usually feign interest in your payment and ignore you when you say that your Husband or wife paid the fair who is in front of you. The Trams can be VERY crowded in rush hour and Sundays. Be prepared to have to fight your way towards the front when your stop is approaching. When I first arrived here, I found Navigating very difficult due to the overwhelming amount of sights. Combine that with the fact that a large amount of the signs are in Chinese, I found navigating hard. I therefore suggest that if possible you count the number of stops you need to go before getting off
Must do. I planned a HK transportation day and tried buses, MTR, taxis, ferry and the Ding Ding. Great experience regardless of which one you take. Preferable on a not so humid/hot day.
TRAVEL DOWN THE MEMORY LANE. A must for any first timer. Take a short trip (if time permitting a longer one) in one of the trams and you will remember that forever.
Fun ride. Definitely a good way to see the city without the walk. You can get off any stop along the way. It is a cheap way to see the city.
trams. neat and well maintained trams with courteous staff to welcome you on board.The service duration is is fair enough.During peak hours it is an added treat to the commuters.

Manage your expectations and your time and you will enjoy it.. I live here so I have found that taking the tram at off peak times and getting on at the terminals is the best way to improve your odds of getting a seat. Standing up is really rough especially if you are tall. The main thing to remember is that even though the tram is a very popular tourist attraction, it is very cheap and so it is really a crowded public transportation mode. If you go during peak hours you will get on at the back, and will be very unlikely to even stand still, let alone sit down, as people tend to move forward to get closer to the front to get off. This is true upper and lower deck. If you are traveling with a group or your family, try to go non rush hour and start at the terminal. They may even be empty and you might have to wait as bit for it to move, but you will see it fills up. It really does move slowly. But at $2.xx dollars, you can see the real HK and save a few bucks. Don't expect to see anything particularly interesting. It can be very pleasant and relaxed if a little frenetic at times. Your kids might get bored... Make sure you know where you want to get off, the signs of the stations are on top of the station shelters and near the front and you can only see them from the left side. The old ones don't have announcement signs inside but the new ones have them. And if you miss your stop its usually only a few blocks between stops. As with anywhere in HK, being pushed and shoved may happen to you, but it can feel worse in a crowded tram car so if you want to enjoy it most, go non peak and find the terminal! Hope this helps.

Lost in Translation. Cheapest way to travel when you are in the main island as the Ding Ding traverses Sheung Wan, Central, Wan Chai, Causeway, North Point and Happy Valley. We were never accustomed to riding the Ding Ding as tourists eversince I visited HK many times but only recently when I am now travelling with my son. Every visit, it has been a must for us to ride HK's variety of transport, Ding Ding included. It was fun and cheap. One thing though..make sure you ride the right coach as the drivers do not understand English when you ask for the exact stop or route, would not even bother to reply even if you converse in acceptable Putonghua. Also, make sure once you enter, better go to the deck as it would be much easier for one to move out on your stop.
Trams are great. easy to use and saves a lot of walking !, HK being very Hilly the trams make getting around easier, the trams are an icon relating to HK and are a must when visiting

The best way to take a closer look of Hong Kong Island. This is obviously the best way to take a closer look of Hong Kong Island and the best months are from mid October to end of February when the city is cool and dry because there is no air-con onboard. It runs from the far eastern corner to the western corner of the northern coastline of Hong Kong island and less than 30 US cents for a ride wherever you get off. Since it is so in-expensive, you can hop-off when you see something interesting from the upper-deck of the tram, explored and hop-on again to continue. I suggest this is an "must" experience for every visitor to Hong Kong.

Cheap, convenient and busy. Tram is a wonderful way to get across HK Island north. Cheap. Great way to discover new stores encounter. Can be packed inside so choose time of travel carefully. Avoid peak traffic hours. Air pollution can be an issue.

Best way to see the local communities and it is cheap. Pop in one of the tram in the Hong Kong Island for only US$0.25. One fee for the whole route no matter it is one stop or the whole route. It passes by the financial districts and old area like western dried seafood streets, North Point wet market etc. it is a ver popular transportation, don't do it during rush hours. Do go to the upper deck to have a better view.

Slow but steady.... After living in Hong Kong for nearly a year, I finally took the Ding Ding this past weekend. It's a nice way to see the city if you aren't into dodging lots of sidewalk traffic and aren't in a hurry. Also, I suggest winter months as the windows were open and there was a lovely refreshing breeze blowing through. If you have plenty of time and want a relaxing way to see the sights, wait for a seat to open on the upper deck and enjoy the ride! Also, the price can't be beat! You simply climb on board at any stop and pay on your way out (exact cash or Octopus card).

Don't miss to take a tram ride when you are in Hong Kong!. If you are tourist, you have to take tram for sightseeing. Even though I am not tourist, I would try to grab a chance to jump on the tram for a short ride.

A very cheap way to view Hong Kong. For HK$2.30 you can travel from the western part of Hong Kong (Witty Street) to the east (North Point). Go to the upper deck, get a window seat and relax. It'll probably take more than an hour depending on the traffic. You're going through the heart of Hong Kong. From the traditional western part, the financial center in Central, Wanchai, shopping area Causeway Bay to the residential area in North Point. You will see the face change at different areas. This is like an overview and if you like you can go back to the area you are interested. Of course you can get on and off any stop you want. But the tram can get very congested at certain area and you may not be able to get a seat.

Travel back in Time. This old fashioned way of traveling across the island is perhaps the best way, slow and bumpy but gives you plenty of time to soak in the past and the present life of Hong kong. A must for Tourist

Great if you need to travel a short distance or you want to kill time. It's convenient to take tram because it's on the ground and there're many stops along the lines! It's very very cheap at $2.3 for adult no matter how many stops away! You'd better go upstair to have a better view. As tram runs very slow, it's a great way to visit Hong Kong island. I recommend you to take from Kennedy Town to Shaukeiwan, the longest route!
Quaint. Just a lovely way to sit back and look down on all of the street activity from the top deck.it travels through interesting little streets and you can get off when you see something you like.
Tram to Happy Valley. Took the tram from Central to Happy Valley racecourse, great way to see downtown Hong Kong. Cheap and cheerful, lots of character.

the way to go. Head west!1 on the ding dong tram. a terrific way to take in the sights. Old world charm and views of the city that acnt be beaten especially on price. we stayed in wan chai so if you head west in to central you pass all the important stops, stay on it and continue out through to quieter streets to the aptly named dry fish street. This area is well worth a visit, a thriving selection of fish stores with huge selection of dried fish on display, and also with loads of side street markets to explore. The Trams make for an enjoyable and very affordable way of seeing Hong kong up close

When you're stuck with your suitcase. We jumped on the tram on our last day as a way of doing a bit of sightseeing while lugging our cases around (we booked somewhere through Airbnb and couldn't leave them behind!!).The tram is really cheap and the same price irrespective of the distance, so we just went the whole length of it over a few hours, and jumped out at the second last stop to go to a Veggie restaurant we spotted.Saw a few nice parks, lots of shopping, and a couple of other interesting things but nothing particularly amazing.Worth doing for an hour though.

Still reasonably-priced. Still captivating.. Every visitor to HK needs to experience the HK trams. My recent experience was a lot of fun. They are still as reasonably-priced and captivating as in days gone by. It is the ultimate slow tour from the Western district to the Eastern areas along the North Shore of HK island. It's a reminder of more gracious days without the frenzied rush of other forms of transport. We must join in with friends who are planning to rent a tram for a night excursion cum party soon.

EPIC Ride. One of the memorable moments of the visit the tram ride, so I stayed at the North Point, harbor plaza which has a tram stop right infront of the hotel. So I got on and went over to the north point MTR which is around 3 stops and the best part about the ride is no matter how much you ride u need to the pay the one amount 2.3HKD I did it thrice during my stay and felt quite happy doing a tram ride, it is a double decker ride and quite spacious and the frequecy is very good, about one tram every 5-6mins

A must do in Hong Kong. When you first get to Hong Kong go and buy an Octopus card at MRT or where ever you can buy one. This is the first step to freedom of travel in Hong Kong. You can get on and off the tramway anywhere along the route and you can see the areas you may want to stop on the way back. Upper deck is best to see from. Start early in morning when it isn't as busy and you will beat the crowds

What can you do with HK$2.30? Take a ride to experience Hong Kong. Board at the back. Go upstairs. Find a seat by the window. Enjoy the ride. Pay when you get off. The longest ride from Kennedy Town to Shau kei wan. Experience HK. If you sit in front row seat, get your camera ready. What a ride!!!!

110 years and still strong. Introduced in 1904 the tramway system is still a very convenient and inexpensive way to explore parts of Hong Kong Island and do it on every trip I had made to Hong Kong, watching street life from the upper floor of the double-decker.
Best way to slowly cross Hong Kong. Ride upstairs for great views as you traverse the city. For about 25 cents (US) easy to get on an off.

best way to see city and causeway bay. just the bustle and ground level stuff for all hong kong workers.
So cheap and jump on and offable. took some pics and a video in the finance centre, really atmospheric
cheap and safe. it cheaps for city sight in Hong Kong. it flat rate every where route around city . many station to get on and out.
Good, cheap, easy ride!. Quick, fun ride; standing room only! That's to be expected in a busy, bustling city like Hong Kong! Be sure you know that you pay upon exiting the ding ding.
Ding Ding. A cheap and good way to go around and exploring Hong Kong island. I was used to the system back in SG but this one is different. You pay or tap during exit.
Cheap transport. Take a Ding Ding tram and get lost...you can always get a taxi back if you don't know where you are. This is the best way to see the real Hong Kong.

They still go. Thats the amazing thing ..steamy , old ,hot and ugly . Good to get around or just for the novelty . They operate in the main roads of the city , so try them just once to say you have . Not recommended for comfortable travel.

Handy trams. It was a bit of fun catching the tram in Hennessey Rd down to Causeway Bay but they are all very busy and jam packed. We did, however, also catch a tram from near Central to Happey Valley to attend the races and that made an easy way to get to the track.

Quintessential hong kong. I dont think any visit to Hong Kong is complete without a ride on ferry in Victoria Harbor or a ride on the tramway through the town. They are safe, cheap, and a good way to see the city sights.
Historical trip. This is a great way to see Hong Kong Island from east to west. The seats are wooden and hard, but you see a cross section of thie island.

Fun!!. Funny experience on the local trams! They call them Ding Dong because of the noise they make... It is definitely worth trying it when in HK... They are super cheap and you can either pay with the octopus card or with coins when you exit.

A must to understand Hong Kong. The best enjoyable way to vist Hong Kong Island. On the upper decj let them take you anywhere: just watch and breath the Kong Kong atmosphere. Stop in Happy Valley and enjoy the best food around.

Worth a try. A slower and cheaper alternative to the MTR on Hong Kong Island. You can pay by octopus card. The old wooden carriage is interesting enough, and it's an ok way to go through the city if you want to see what you're going through and don't want to walk.

cheap and easy. What a great way to see HK.. get on and see HK above ground.
very easy to navigate and your 'oyster' card works on these too :)
Just be warned they are absolutley packed during rush hour

The Only 'other' way to get about. when travelling in Hong Kong, forget taxis! The tramway and MTR rail system is just fantastic. Firstly go to an MTR station and buy an Octopus card, similar to our Oyster cards, But much cheaper. Then, the whole of Hong Kong, the Star Ferry is open to you. Great system.
You just got to do it. A slow ride through the HK streets is the way to go on this inexpensive public transport. A delightfull way to see the street life of HK

Must see. This is the no.1 attraction here in my opinion. Going to the highest inhabited point (I think) in the city and seeing the entire city from that vantage point was breath taking, especially if you go at night. Only problem was, it was too crowded. I am not sure what time of day will be better. It is an experience worth having regardless.

Wonderfull sunday. After 15 years back in Hongkong i took the Sunday to ride to tourist bus. I am not such a fan and i would like a little more comfort. But its really a very good way to see Hongkong fast. I stoped at the market and had a nice lunch.
just nice ,relaxing ride..... ... nice views if you sit in the front with you're Camera.-Best travel time after 11am - 3 pm-best ride from causeway bay to the market

Ding Ding. A ride with the Ding Ding costs one 2,3HK. There is no change, so make sure you have coins.
It is a fun experience to hop on the tram and take the whole route. Locals do use the trams a lot, and they become very busy in the early morning, noon and after 16h till 19h.
Exciting. It feels like a piece of history. I love trams, but have never gone on a double decker. It was raining and we decided to go for a ride. It took us from SOgo to Central. Quick and easy.

A ride to real Hong Kong. We rode on Ding Ding tramps from Admiralty to Causeway Bay and back. It was a late evening on a Friday. I should say it is the best way to see the real Hong Kong. As the tram moves slowly along the middle of the road towards Causeway Bay you will see how the landscape change, modern sky scrapers to thousand of small businesses with flashing neon lights and thousands of people on the road...that's the real Hong Kong.Because the tram runs on middle of the road and goes very slowly, it is the best way to see around. Windows can be open, so kids had a very good time looking around (be careful tramps pass each other very closely!).Travelling on Ding Dings are quite easy, just get in from the rear door and scan the Octopus when exiting from the front. Price is fixed for the route no matter how many stops you travel. It is very cheap, we paid only HKD 2.50/adult. Tramps are very clean and very well maintained and still looks the old passion they used to be.If you are in Hong Kong Island, this is a must do and is the best way to see the real Hong Kong.

Love these skinny trams!. The trams in Hong Kong are cheap, impossible to get lost on, frequent and wonderfully slow so you can take in the sights. $2.30 gets you from one end of the island to the other, or one stop. People are friendly on the tram and give you advice if you look lost. Slower than a taxi, but well worth, especially late at night.
a good ride. Trams are a great and very economic way to see somehof Hong Kong. Sometimes its a bit too crowded tho!
The best way to see Hong Kong.. Get the upper deck and enjoy the ride. The fare is affordable. Board the tram until the end. Great way to see the city life.

Almost a Rollercoaster. Interesting experience! The trams are very narrow and the tracks run close to each other - quite thrilling for little kids. They can get you around the city, although it takes a while. Most interesting is that the city goes from looking very urban with crammed, somewhat older buildings to grand, shiny structures (at Bank Street) to cramped again - get a feel for all of Hong Kong. You pay a fee when you get off, the same price regardless of distance.

cheap, cheerful and great way to see the city. The trams on hong Kong island are excellent value for money! You can ride the entire line for just 2hk dollars (either cash or using octopus card)! Sit up top so that you can see the lights and architecture. Get on the trams from the back, and you continue to move forward based on where your stop is. If you are getting on an older tram, be prepared for the windows to be left open, and it can get a little chilly.

Brilliant way to see HK, for a very cheap fare. We made the mistake of not looking into getting an octopus card in HK, considering the amount of transport we packed into our few days. So, first, you need the correct chand, $2.30, about 20 odd pence. You pay into the pot by the driver when you leave the team, something we had to figure out.That aside, these are great for seeing Hong Kong and all the sights. They are double-decker, so raced upstairs each time and headed for the front to take in the views. You could happily spend a day pottering on these, but we took a few routes, watched the world go by, as people have done so on these teams for over a century- a definite activity in HK.

Most fun way to get around!. The Hong Kong trams are a must-do experience. They may be a little slower than other options, but it's great fun to head up to the top level and get a more birds eye view of the streets and suburbs below. They are convenient and very cheap.
Cheap transportation. At only $2.50, you get a great ride in central. Just make sure you carry change because none is given back.

A great Asian Tram. Took the most interesting tram ride on the H.ng Kong side. The Ding Ding Trams. Very cheap just a few cents and they travel the main street thru the island. Double decked so top side viewing is possible. Much better and cheaper alternative to the expensive bus tours. You can almost touch the different neighborhoods that are teaming with activity. Good for a couple of houhs and you have seen the broad fabric of Hong Kong society. Runs parallel with the subway so it is easy to get to and from.
Fun and inexpensive. Fun way to view the streets. It's a nice slow way to look around Hong Kong. Also inexpensive compared to other options.

Great fun. These come by so often one wonders how on earth they can be profitable. But I hope they never decide to get rid of them, they are on the very last vestiges of what old Hong Kong must have been like.

Cheap way to look at the Main Street. For first time arrivals to HK island on the early morning flight.Leave bags etc at hotel storage(2pm checkin.) catch a tram to Kennedytown or Shaukiwan and back, then go the other end and back. Grab a window seat on top, and look at the street scene as you travel. Great way to find,see some shops, department stores etc, and Hong Kong !A couple Hours one way, and the other, it is time to checkin, cheap too! You won't get lost if you grab a hotel card, show the card to anyone, they will point you in the right direction.

Tram to Victoria Peak. Long lines that move well. The ride is very impressive rising quickly up the steep grade with great views as you ascend. At the top is a tacky shopping mall, but the views are worth it. A must do part of the trip.

Must do as tourist! But only if you have lots of time. Some of the lines weren't clearly marked - had to get off earlier than expected. No free transfer means we have to pay to connect. But it was cheap nonetheless and allows you to use your Octopus card which was convenient.
Sit and watch. It is very slow, but very cheap and is a good way to see a part of Hong Kong. I recommend to take this tram, specially the old ones and sit on the top of it, to have a better view.

Another icon. When you are in Hong Kong you also need to try the Hong Kong Tramways as it is a return to another age in seconds. There is nothing better than just sit back in your seat and just enjoy the ride

Worth a ride.. Worth getting the tram to give your feet a rest and for the experience of riding the tram. They are not very comfortable to sit on and are very crowded at times. They are cheap though and well worth it for the experience.

Hong Kong Tramways. Excellent cheap way to tour Hong Kong Island. Best to get a seat on the top level at the front. Good views of shopping areas and other attractions to which you might want to return.

Essential Hong Kong experience. The tram is a quintessential HK experience that hasn't changed for decades. They are narrow, slow and always crowded with residents who are patient with the tourists who want to try them. They are lovely and ricketty, much more fun than a smooth modern tram and you get to see so much of Hong Kong along the way. If you keep a map on you and watch the street names in Central, it is easy to work out where to get off but it is no hardship to stay on for a longer journey and just come back on yourself. I have to have a tram fix every time I go to HK. I hope they never get rid of them.

Best Way (and Cheapest, too) to Tour Hong Kong Island. It costs only HK$2.30 per ride for adult, HK$1.2 for children under 12, and HK$1.10 for senior 65 and above. It runs between east and west on the northern side of the Hong Kong Island. It used to be my favourite way to enjoy a relaxed ride on the upper deck of its double-decker tram with windows wide open during not so warm weather. Yes, it is slow moving and without air-conditioning. But it is also relaxed, moving gracefully on the busy roads of Hong Kong island. It is also interesting to watch the shops and people on the way. My favourite districts are Wanchai, Sheung Wan, Western District, Causeway Bay, and Central, in that order.Do allow yourself at least 60 to 90 minutes. Don't rush. Payment of fare (upon exit in the front by the side of the driver) can be by coin (which has to be exact) or against stored value card like called Octopus (similar to Oyster card) card available from most convenient stores.Relax and enjoy.

Cheapest mode of transport in the city. The trams, although busy and slow, are the cheapest mode of transport in the city. If you have time to get from A to B, then jump on the back, hop upstairs and stare out the window for twenty minutes at the incredible streets of Hong Kong. When you arrive, get off at the front and pay the driver your 2 HKD (that's something like 17p). For simple journeys, for example between Wan Chai and Central, they probably take just as long as the MTR as you can simply hop on and off quite quickly. I definitely recommend riding them at least once, if just for the experience!A word of warning - they don't announce the stop name, so you have to count how many stops you've travelled or recognise the area to know where to get off.

Hop on. Hop on and see the central strip sights at a slow rattle pace. Not touristy really as these are still a mainstay of local transport. Correct change and flat rate fare or Octopus Card as you get off by driver. Easy.

What amazing old trams and only HK $2.40 a ride!. We caught the trams on Hong Kong Island as we headed up to the giant escalator and this was an unexpected blast from the past. What beautiful old trams.  It is the only tram system in the world operated exclusively with double-decker trams, and is one of only three non-heritage tram systems in the world that use double-deck cars (OK - I admit it, this is a paste from Wikipedia...BUT it is true. Be sure to take a ride if you're in HK.
Can even bunk them!. They are a great way to travel, you get a nice breeze and a brilliant way to see the city and its many exciting sights.
Ding Ding is crowded. It was so crowded. We started from somewhere near Wanzai riding to Central, and we have no clue where is the stop at Central. Great experience, though.

love at first sight. oh, got, i am getting nostalgic, i really miss these tramways. I used to live at johnston road, didnt enjoy the noise every morning but still it was a great means of transport and give great flair to the city!

Fun Transport. A great and cheap way of seeing some of HongKong Island. For $2.30 you can travel from nearly one end of HK island to the other. We made it out to North Point and then to Shakue Wan and then bussed it back to Causeway Bay. Seats are small and hard and a wee bit tricky to make it upstairs, but the sights are worth it. We were lucky to get on trams with not many passengers, if too many it wouldn't have been as enjoyable. A great way to see sights above ground instead of MTR.
Great way to see the city. Cheap as chips and getting on at Kennedy town travelling the line through Central, admiralty to the end you can see the various districts.

My son loved it and so did I. I made a special trip to take my 3 year old on the trams. And I loved it too. Its a nice way to see Hong Kong Island.
I wish every city had a tram.
Hard to figure out. Tram was cheap. Only problem is trying to figure out where to get off. Couldn't find any signs in English

Very crowded. Was crowded and had to wait for about 10 trams to go through before we would for in one. Was not a pleasant experience for us as we had to stand very cramped and really didn't get too see anything.

Fun way to get around. Seeing these cute boxes moving on tracks, we had to try it out. Riding through the city, we had a good view of daily life. We learned that the MTR card doesn't work here, and it is best to have an Octopus card or exact small change.

Great Experience. The experience of the tram ride in the city was great. It is commendable how they have managed to keep the trams in such great condition in HK. A not to be missed experience while in HK.

Easy,cheap,efficient system. A great way to move around Hong Kong, Get upstairs, keep you arms in and admire the views as you pass through the various districts and shopping areas, great for people watching and being able to see more of Hong Kong in a novel way whilst resting your feet. Very cheap and if you have the octopus card you can use this to pay the fare, very convenient.
nice. Take an early morning trip to avoid long queues. The view from the top is very nice although we experienced some fog which hindered our view.

Great experience & it's unbelievable cheap!!. A must ride if you're in Hong Kong! It is also unbelievable cheap at $2.3 only per ride. In addition, there are trams approaching the station so frequently but just have to make sure you get on the right tram! Good way to explore Hong Kong as it gives you an opportunity to look shops located at the street, people etc. Remember getting in from the back, pay and exit at the front.There are times whereby the tram can get very very crowded! I remember it was a weekday during lunch hour, I did not enjoy the tram ride at all as I was having difficulties inside the tram to look for sign of the station I wanna hop off! This is worse if you are the lower deck. There was a newer tram I took which is equipped with LED indicating each stop, I guess it's just more convenient for the tourists though.
Iconic Stuff. What a brilliant way of getting around, great fun, really quite efficient and incredibly cheap. Everyone is very helpful and ready to help as far as their language will allow!

a must. Fantastic - get on at kennedy town, a great new up and coming area where you'll find great independent shops and restaurants. By getting on at kennedy town you're guaranteed a front top of tram seat. Only costs about 40p and worth the trip along to other end of line. Great!

A cheap and novel sightseeing option. Some may wish to ride a tram for the experience alone. Others may use it as a convenient transport method. Whatever your reason, HK 2.30 per ride is not going to eat into many peoples travel budgets so I'd encourage everyone to hop on and take a trip!After disembarking the Star Ferry at Central, the closest stop for visitors to Hong Kong Island is Pedder Street. Board the tram from the rear then go upstairs to try and get a seat at the front. Then it's just a matter of deciding whether to ride to the depot before boarding another tram for the return journey or hopping off and exploring a new neighbourhood. Pay on the way out the front door with an Octopus Card or with the exact change. Be aware that some lines are longer than others, so it may be wise to get a copy of the eastbound and westbound routes from an Information Centre or a PDF version online. Each tram displays the name of the depot it's travelling to and each stop is announced, English included.

The narrow trams in HK. Hopped on and off the ding ding trams while sight seeing in HK. This narrow tram is another way to explore HK either Kowloon or HK island. We particularly enjoyed our ride at the top deck eventhough some time the ding ding trams can get particularly crowded at peak hours. The tram system is very efficient and regular, really good way to get around at street level. Highly recommend this experience. Very cost effective too !
Great way to get around. Fantastic and affordable way to travel. You can see so much and have time to take in the hustle and bustle

OK but everything stopped at Happy Valley. Because of the Umbrella Protesters all trams came to a halt just after we got on them and nobody explained why until we came across an Umbrella Protest Camp.Great experience and very cheap.When I return I may try to use to travel from my apartment in Quarry Bay to my office near Admiralty

Dingding-tastic!. Fare is a flat rate of 2.30. You ride and pay as you exit (you can use your 'Octopus' prepaid card to pay so no worries about fiddling around for small change). Riding on the Top deck gives you a great view and plenty of photo opportunities. Don't just ride the DingDing. Alight and explore. We did and were greatly rewarded with the local markets. Hong Kong, despite its modernity still offers plenty of places where time moves slower.

Fun way to see Hong Kong. These funny little trams are quite cute and a novel way to see HK but is you want to get somewhere faster then use the MTR. A good experience though. Very easy to use and with the one transport ticket travel in HK is simple.
extraordinary experience. unbelievable.this hundreds years tram is still running and working fine.ticket fee is flatprice at HKD2.30 per ride.

Fun and cheap. A must do when on Hong Kong Island. It is a flat $2.30 Hong kong dollars which is super cheap. We went in the evening and sat on the top deck which was a great way to see the lights and happenings at a sedate pace.

Ding Ding - Not to be missed. This is my first time taking the tram ( Ding Ding ) after many trips to Hong Kong, and I must say that I trully enjoyed the newly found experience. The sight on ther upper level is superb but only if you're medium built as I found that the tram could be too crampy on the upper level. Same goes to the narrow steps upwards and downwards the tram. It's so convenient to take the tram and it's cheaper too. Agreed with other reviewers as this is the best way to see Hong Kong. Just hop on, look out the window, see something interest you, get down and explore! So easy. And the tram stops at every tram stops and you will definately won't miss any spot.Also the tram travel the same route except to check out the last point you want to go. Direction and route map is clearly pasted on evey tram stops. Best nostalgic experience!!

Great for sightseeing!. When I woke up earlier than my husband on our first day of Hong Kong, I didn't know what I should do, but I didn't want to stay in the hotel! I had read that this was a great way to see the city so I hopped on (you pay with Octopus on the way OFF - not on) and sat at the front of the top level and just watch as the city passed by. When I got to an interesting neighborhood, I got off and walked around and had a quick bite to eat. Then my husband texted and I headed back the same way. They come once every minute or two so there is very little waiting.
tram views. The trams are crowded but fun. Best view is from 2nd floor of course with steep stairs and pushing a bit required at peak times.

DO NOT MISS IT!. As a train lover, I loved the "ding ding"! We stayed in Northpoint and the tram station was right in front of our street, and provided a cheap yet wonderful way of "seeing" Hong Kong. The real grandeur of Hong kong city center, with its impressive skyscrapers and buzzing shopping areas can be completely experienced only from the top of a tram! I frequently used the tram to get to Central, thus avoiding the faster but no-chance-of-sightseeing metro and the costlier taxi options. Wherever you stay, just go to the nearest tram station, travel to the end of the line and then come all the way back (or alight where you want!). P.S.: Keep in mind that you should have the exact change (it was $2.30 during my stay) and you get into the tram from the rear end, but exit via the front and only while exiting you have to pay the driver (you put the change into a small box next to him)
It's like Harry Potter's Nightbus. Whenever I ride the dingding, always think I'm in Harry Potter's night bus. It's such a fun ride. I always go for the top deck and take pictures along the way.
so convenient although crowded. stops are very convenient and fare is reasonable. don't understand why you need at least 50 characters. let's say what we want.

Interesting. Different experiences from ones in San Francisco!! These 2 layer buses are cool. They come really close with cars or people. They have interesting decoration or interesting advertisement on it. It is about 0.3 USD per trip, yet cheap and fast!!
Nostalgia. Dont like urbanisation takes this Ding Ding tramways away.It makes HKG unique. It brings the old world charm in ultra modern HKG. It also reminds people of the World of Suzie Wong movie!

Scenic ride across the Hongkong Island. We hopped on one of these from the Western Market to Causeway Bay. I think it could go as far as Kennedy Town on the West and Chai Wan on the East. It stops frequently and runs slowly. But for the price of 2.30 HKD per ride it's really worth it especially if you don't have them in your country

A fun way to slowly see a fast moving city. I love the ding ding in Hong Kong! It's the cheapest form of transportation aside from walking and you can see a large part of the island from a slow moving double decker. In a fast paced city, it's lovely to be able to move relatively slowly while sitting and absorbing the sights, sounds, and smells of Hong Kong. A must do!!!
Ding, ding went the trolley.... A cheap and fun way of taking in the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong! Enter at the back, sit on upper deck and pay (exact fare, $2,10) as you leave at the front.
Even better at night!. Sit in the upper deck, start in Causeway Bay and head toward Central. HK just COMES ALIVE even more at night, when it's a bit lower temp anyway. Best way to soak in the city.

Hong Kong Tramways. We travelled twice on the trams and. The journeys were really interesting. You see so much more from the top deck and the tram routes take you at a relatively slow pace so you get chance to see all the sights and the Hong Kong people's.

Our favorite mode of transportation here. We moved here in July and to date this is our absolute favorite thing to do. It can get hot in the summer time, but if you only take it a short ride it's not bad. It is a bit slower of course than the MTR, but it's a fun way to see the city, get where you're going, and get a nice breeze. AND you can't beat the price :)

Awesome way to see Hong Kong. These are really neat. A great way to see Hong Kong, hop on and enjoy the view. Remember to enter via the back door and exit via the front door. You can use you Octopus Card on exit.

A must if in Hong Kong and so cheap!. I was initially a bit nervous about the trams however they ended up being our main mode of transport as we were staying in Causeway Bay. The trams go along the top of Hong Kong Island and journeys can end up taking a bit of time if the traffic is bad, however it's such an experience and a great way to see more of the city rather than going underground on the MTR!At our time of visiting the fare is only 2.30 hong kong dollars - amazing value! You get on at the back of the tram then leave by the front after depositing change of swiping your Octopus card. At popular times the trams can get really full but it's all part of the fun and there is always another along in a couple of minutes if one is too crammed! My husband did struggle to stand up properly in some as the ceilings are quite low (he's 6'1) but it wasn't too bad.

Loved them!. Really fun way to ride around Hong Kong island and make sure you see everything (unlike on the MTR). Payment is also easy, just bip your octopus on the way out, $2.3 however far you wish to go.
Most convenient and economical form of transport!. Enjoy the great city view, save the walking through the MTR tunnels, good for short trips between Causway Bay, Central and Wan Chai!
Great way to see local neighbourhoods. I really enjoyed the tram experience. It's cheap and great if you have time to spare. I enjoyed seeing the diverse shops and neighbourhoods.
Get on find a seat and sit back and relax!. Went over to Hong Kong Island and decided to try the trams. Very inexpensive and a nice way of getting about the main waterfront area.

A wonderful & cheap way to explore HK island. It's cheap, it's not affected by traffics jam, it offer good view if you are on the front of upper deck, it's convenient. My young daughter loves it, & was one of the few that she remembers fondly from this trip.
Pleasant and entertaining for a short while. Very nice to try and feels closer to the environment than in the underground or busses - try it at least once.

give it a try. finally got to ride on the Ding Ding. It is a historical form of transportation and something you must try. They are crowded but get upstairs and you will eventually get a seat to sit down and enjoy the upper deck view.
Great for a real feel of Hong Kong. Highly recommend using a tram, only 230HKD. Just jump on and see the sights, they cover a wide area. Sit upstairs and watch the city go by.

Fun and easy!. These trams are a fun and easy way to get around! The tram stops are everywhere so it's super convenient! It's a great way to view the streets of HK if you've spent the day walking around everywhere and need to rest your feet.
Highly recommend a ride on one of these iconic trams.
A Hong Kong classic. The tramway has been around for decades and little is changed. It is slow and not air-conditioned. Take it if the weather is nice and you're not in a hurry.

my all time favourite. Trams are my favourite transportation in HK. You can find them on the Hong Kong Island. I study in the University of Hong Kong and I take the tram every day to and from the MTR station. With the opening of the new HK Island MTR line, extending to Sai Ying Pun, HKU and Kennedy Town, I am not sure if the tram can still survive... If you have a chance, give it a try, they are the cheapest, slow, traditional transportation in Hong Kong, witnessing the development of Hong Kong during the past decades.

Back in Time. One of the Tram stops was just outside of our hotel. We used our MTR card to ride it from our hotel to the Causeway Shopping area. Historical and a fun and worthwhile experience. It gets a little crowded but it is a great way to see a little more of the Hong Kong from a different perspective. It is best to ride upstairs if you can. You need to do it at least once if you are in Hong Kong.
Funky! . The trams look cool, they're cheap, comfortable, and an easy way to get around and see parts of the city too. You will find a tram every few minutes, just make sure it's the right direction!
so much fun. these trams are just so cheap and so much fun, even when they a jammed packed with commuters. They are an experience all on their own and a a MUST for all who come to h.k.

Get your directions right. There are a lot of posts on the experience and I cannot deny that it is an enjoyable one, especially with the cool weather.However, for those who are not used to taking trains, you need to get your bearings right. You cannot simply just hop on to any tram you see. Although the trams do go along the same lines, we noted that certain trams only stop to a certain area. In our case, we got on one tram, came to a terminus and had to pay and get off the tram to get on to another tram to get to the place we want to go. If you have some spare time, to stop and go up and down the trams, it is ok. We had a toddler and an infant so getting on and off was a bit tiresome.At each stop, there is a map, to tell you where are you and which tram will stop at which stop. All you need to do is look at the location you want to go (Eastbound or Westbound) and then see where you want to go. Then look at the tram's color line, which will tell you the first and last stop of the tram. When that tram comes on by, just hop on. Since it goes on a single entry basis, it doesn't matter which stop you go. We didn't use any travel cards so we had to make sure we gave enough coins. A lot of the residents plus some travelers used the travel cards which does make commuting easier.

Giving you a glimpse of everyday HK street life. It’s clunky and slow, but definitely an unique experience and bargain deals (at only HK$2.30 per ride!) to experience the everyday HK life and get around the busy Hong Kong island area. It’s often crowded too and you will squeeze on with the locals.
Relaxed way to get around. If you have the time and don't mind the crush, this is a great way to get around Hong Kong. It allows a great opportunity to pick up the sights and sounds of the area.

One of the cheapest thrills in Hong Kong. I've always loved the feel and look of the Trams in Hong Kong. It reminds me of the old Hong Kong that I used to grow up in. Rides in it are fairly quick, just don't ride on it during peak hours or super hot days because they don't have AC. Best to ride on top and with your camera ready.
Old but functional.. Simply an experience. Go upstairs to get the best views. Stay on for a few stops and retrace your steps if you can. Of course, the routes are limited, but the route is historic.

An Experience to be Packed like Sardines. You cannot say you have been to Hong Kong if you haven't sat the Hong Kong Tramways. However, if you hop on the tram in Central, it is always packed with people. We had to climb to the upper deck as there were no place to stand at the lower deck. We had to rush down when we arrived at our station and it is not an easy feat. If you just want to have a feel of it, choose a station with lesser crowd.

Fun way to travel. What a great way to get around and cheap (don't forget - you have to have the right amount of coins - there is no change offered). These trams are so skinny and small but everyone is so accommodating as you squeeze on with the locals. Even if you don't need to use them to get somewhere, just take a ride for the heck of it.

Hong Kong Trams. These tams traverse the north of Hong Kong Island from west to east. They travel on dedicated tracks and are therefore mostly unaffected by traffic jams. The upper deck offers an unbeatable view of the hussle and bustle of Hong Kong life. They are often crowded, but people tend to get on and off often so, chances of getting a seat are quite high after a little time.Trams, although moving quite slowly, often are the fastest form of transport as you don't have to go up and down to the subway for the MTR. They are frequent; the next one usually comes in under 5 minutes.Tram fare is unbelievably cheap - HK$2.30 for as far as you want to go. That's less than US30 cents
A nostalgic ride into the past. It is amazing the "Ding Ding" is still around. For a very low price per ride it was a fond ride down memory lane to the HK of my childhood.

Slow rides, great attraction and a heritage to be maintained. With the fast pace life these days, and especially in Hong Kong, some time one have to slow down.How? This is the best way. One cannot hurry. Everything is preset in terms of speed. You cannot hurry the driver. if you want to travel and tour around Hong Kong Island, and not liking a duckling type of tour, take this and you will not regret. Take your time as the trams is on a fix speed. So, their time is your time.Even if you do not want to take a ride, seeing them is fascinating enough, as it is a mobile heritage.Ding Ding!!... love the bell ringing and slow pace. Here we come... slow down Hong Kong

Love the double decker 'skinny' trams.. The trams look fantastic, winding their way along the streets. Very narrow, double decker trams. We had the Octopus card so could add money to this which covered the trams, buses. You can even use your Octopus card at local shops and restaurants.

Very convenient and cheap mode of transportation. The hotel that we stayed was at Shueng Wan and there was a Ding Ding station less than 5 mins away. It costed only a flat fee of HK$2.30, a really cheap way to travel. The tram can get really crowded but you can alway wait for another one if you can't get on as the next one will come really quick.

A different way to see the city. If you are tired to walk along the almost endless streets on Hong Kong island, taking the tram is a great alternative to get from one point to the other! Especially as you pass trough the main roads of the central district, admiralty, wan chai, causeway bay and the happy valley. It's not the fastest way to get trough the city but for sure one of the most interesting one!
A Real Piece of Old Hong Kong. the fee is only 2.3 for one personThe best and cheapest wayto explore Hong Kong Island from the east end to west end and return.

HK trams - vintage mode - must try. Hong Kong tramsA unique, novel and slow way to see this city from point A to B –  East to West. One of the best mode of sightseeing for the Tourist, these tram cars have remain unchanged since ages, and areStill as they were around 40-years back. A Vintage mode to take before They are re-placed with modern and aircon. The ones now in use areNon-A.C, with wooden seats though they are now being replaced withPlastic chairs at the sides. Modernization is on the way, but how long itWould take, the operating company only know? For now let us enjoy ourRide on the cheapest mode of travel you can find in any place.(US$0.30)Hong Kong is divided into 2-parts, seperated by Ocean -Kowloon Peninsula and the Hong Kong Island. The trams are on the HK Island.And there is no direct route from A to point B. You need to make a change.Make your change point at Central Landmark (well know CBD Mall)  your 2-final points areIn the East – Shaukeiwan – and West …. Kennedy Town.Start your journey from Landmark and head towards Shaukeiwan –It would take anywhere between 90 to 120-mintues, head up totop section and take your seat on the front to get the bestViews and be ready with your camera. This route would take you Thru old and new places including the famous shopping area of Causeway Bay Upon reaching Shaukeiwan, You need to deboard, walk around the place, see the sights which are now Just starting to change, though you will still be able to see some old Hongkong.For your return get onboard another tram – destination to be Western Market.Deboard at Landmark and re-take another one this time the Destination to be Kennedy Town.Repeat the process and on return take a tram showing destination either Happy Valley or North Point - reach back your starting point Landmark,& continue enjoy rest of your stay in this city. Please allot total about 4hrs+  depending on the traffic conditions.If you staying on the Kowloon side, depending on the exact location,Fastest way to reach Central – Landmark is by MTR = UndergroundScenic route Taxi to Star Ferry piers (public transport /Buses also available)From the Pier take Ferry across the Harbour to Hong Kong Island (10-mins ride) Use the elevated walk-way upon reaching and you would shortly be seeing these trams andAlso your change point – Landmark. – this section of the road is known asDes Voeux Road Central.Have a nice time and enjoy your trip.

Ding-Ding. Riding the tramways always makes me giddy with excitement. Although it is time-consuming, it gives you the opportunity to go around the city with a cheap fare. The trams give a vintage feel and they make me think I'm in Chicago. You should try riding them at least even once. The stop points are helpful as well in going to certain tourist spots in the city.

Its a cool HK experience. There aren't many places in the world that you can ride an old tram for the equivalent of 20p and enjoy stunning views of HK streets. The trams get crowded but its very friendly and good natured pay as you leave either with your octopus card or 2.30 HK $.Enjoy the noise, the company and the streets and just ride the trams

Best way to explore Hong Kong Island from east to west. The best and cheapest way (HK$2.30 one way) to explore Hong Kong Island from the east end to west end and return. The trams run slowly so give you lots of time to enjoy the street scenes on both sides. Get to the upper deck and you can see more. Try to avoid rush hours cause you will never be able to get on one. I will recommend early early morning and late evening to take a ride.
Very fun way to see the city. This is a very fun way to see Hong Kong island. It is very easy to understand the route. Plus it's very cheap to travel on it. The best seats are the front seats.

Cheap way of travelling. Good for cheap travelling. Speed is rather slow and not much sightseeing between Hongkong station and Western Street. Beyond Causeway Bay, it is not functioning due to protest area. Usually very packed in the morning between 8-10am. Can hardly board it.
Loop to Happy Valley. Fun to do in an evening when the neon lights are all on. Only costs HKD 2.20 per person. Worth the 30mins ride round.
Hop on a Tram. Probably the easiest and best way to see Hong Kong. Very frequent, clean and simply great fun. Inexpensive.

Easy way to survey HK and people. Cheap, simple, double-deck tram ride with dedicated traffic lane and tracks, allows you to survey the some highlights of HK Island from Central, via Causway Bay (epic high-end shopping), pass Victoria Park, TaiKooShing (big local shopping mall) all the way to the old-school residential district of ShauKeiWan. Sit up-stair by the window is an effortless way to see and experience local scenes and people. The whole ride, 1 way is about 45 min. Hop on and off at any station (pay each ride, all 1 price).

A Real Piece of Old Hong Kong. Ding Ding is loved by the people of Hong Hong Kong. An original Tram system, that slowly trundles through some of Hong Kongs oldest areas ringing is bell "ding ding". Its noisy, cheap and nostalgic. Its not designed for tourists - its an integral part of Hong Kong's transport system, but it is a 'must do' for any visitor to HK

great experience before it disappear. we took the tram without any purpose or destination. we enjoyed sitting on the trams, seeing ppl walking on the street and try to imagine how HK looks like during those days. Definitely worth a try!

Should try when you are in Hong Kong. The tram is slow, but, you can enjoy very nice view while you are in the tram. However, recent demonstration in Hong Kong affect part of the tramway, which might causing some delay or traffic jam near causeway bay.

What an absolute bargain. For just HKD $2.30 (use your Octopus card!) you get the most fantastic sample of Hong Kong life, looking both outside and inside the tram. It's definitely worth picking up the tram from it's starting station to ensure you get the seat at the front and then just enjoy the ride as Hong Kong daily life goes by. Just don't think about how on earth the tram stays on the tracks, it's not exactly the smoothest mode of transportation. We travelled from Shau Kei wan down to Causeway Bay, which took 45 minutes or so, was probably enough, given the section thru Central is more modern office blocks, less apartments.

Cheapest way to see Hong Kong . This tram is a fantastic way to see Hong Kong and it's the best value for money trip you will find here . Get on at one end and ride it till you have had enough or ride till the other end . I would try travel outside of peak times as the teams can get very full . You can get some great photos from the upstairs section of the tram and I found sitting at the back better than the front . Take the time to ride the tram , it's a great experience

Love them!. The trams are just brilliant in Hong Kong. They are fast, efficient, dirt cheap and above all, fun. They are a fantastic way to get around and provide a great way to see the area. Try them!

what could you get for that little money. In Hong Kong island this is a must try for visitors. Fare is HKD2.30 for adult on any line. The longest line from island east (Sau Kei Wan to Kennedy Town) to west takes almost 1 1/2 hours. You can have a very good feel about the old and new places in HK.If you are in a rush you could try the happy valley line which last only 15 minutes having a view of the horse race course.

I love this ride. This is a great experience not to be missed while visiting Central Hong Kong. Try to get a seat in front on the upper deck. You could reach out and touch a passing tram, but don't. It's a good way to get back and forth in central Hong kong and a great way to see the hustle and bustle, traffic, people, buildings along the way. Every trip to Hong Kong, I like to ride it from end to end. The cost is about $2.30HKD (about $0.30US).

Inexpensive Transport in Hong Kong. Get to the upper deck and you would have a great street view of Hong Kong. Cost of the ride is "pennies": less than US0.30 and US0.15 for seniors. Try the ride running from the west end of the island to the very east end, and the one going through Happy Vally Race Course. One might find it crowded, however, do not forget you are in Hong Kong.

Can be a fast way or discovery journey. Can be really a fast and cheap alternative. can be crowded like hell, careful in rush hours. As tourist a way to discover hong kong as you seldom see it, you should try.
I try to use it every week. The Trams and quaint and historic but still a useful feeder for the MTR. Great views and you can't get lost on the tram or ding ding

A century long vehicle carrying you through Today's town. I would prefer traveling in chilly season Instead of hot summer, for no air-conditioning on tram. The best recommended route is western part of the Island and eastern tip of the route, where older faces of the city could be found to match with the slow moving tram. Upper deck is more preferred if you could find a window seat, the farthest front or end

All aboard.... Getting around Hong Kong is quite easy w/ MTR (metro), bus, mini-bus networks that will pretty much get you anywhere you want to go with high-efficiency and very reasonable cost... for a more leisurely experience (for even less - HK$2.3) hop on a tram and cruise from Sheung Wan to North Point and beyond... suggest grabbing a seat on the top deck at the front for view of the hustle and bustle below along Johnston Road in Wanchai... so not an "attraction" per say, just a fun way to spend an hour or two cruising through town as it was done since 1904...

HK Tramways. As I life in Hong Kong I just can recommend for a ride in the tram.Best is you start in 'Kennedy Town' and go to 'Happy Valley' or verse visa.When you enter the tam (old once) go upstairs for a better view and if you have any chance (not rush hours) you maybe lucky and get the ‘front seat’. It’s the best to get a view what’s happen on HK streets. When you leave you must pay the exact fair or use the ‘Octopus Card’ as you don’t get any change money back!http://www.hktramways.com/en/tramservice/schedulefare.html
Still a Great Bargain. No other form of transportation in Hong Kong allows you to sightsee the main parts of Hong Kong Island for less than 50 cents U.S.

Cheap way to see HK Island. I took a tram from one end of the island to the other. It is one price, no matter how long the trip is. I think it was about HK$2.80. Get a seat on the top deck and the views can be amazing and scary. You get so close to the other trams, so keep your hands inside! Greta value.

A great way to get your Hong Kong bearings & it's cheap.. The "Ding Ding" Tram is the best way to gather your compass bearings in Hong Kong. The tram is a tourist guide in it's own accord, it weaves it's way through the bustling streets of Hong Kong Island giving you a chance to get to know the landmarks & shopping hotspots.My wife & I stayed in Kowloon but for an adventure we got the Hung Hom Ferry to North Point, walked a little way (no more than 400m) to the North Point Tram Terminus. By doing this you get first crack at an empty tram, so choice of seats is easy. Grab 2 upstairs near the front, you'll get an elevated tram drivers perspective, "watch that pedestrian, look at that dare-devil push bike rider, how'd we miss that bloke, did you see that car push in, what's that busy area there, geez that motor cyclist must have no fear". These are just a few of the words that you'll exchange with your partner whilst riding the "Ding Ding".Certainly a cheap way to entertain yourself at $2.30 HKD a trip. Who says "There's no value these days?"
Great experience. I love the tram, i always take it to go back and forth to Central, its pleasant , and you can do a sight seeing to at the same time. So cheap, 2.30 hk dollars.
