The routes were disrupted due to protest. We thought of traveling in the tram just to get a feel of the city as it passes right through the middle of all the important places. We started from North Point, but the trams were stopped at the Victoria Park Stop. The ride was slow but cheap. It's good for the leisurely traveler, but if you need to reach places - it's better to use the MTR.

Slow and Easy Ride for HK island sightseeing. Probably the cheapest form of public transport in Hong Kong at HK$2.30 per ride, Double decked Ding Ding is often the most convenient way to get around. The only thing is that it is pretty slow and has to fight with all other traffic including public buses, trucks and private cars for the same road that Ding Ding travels on.Depending on where you would be visiting, one of the more enjoyable rides include the tram ride to and/or from Happy Valley and stop over for some lovely oysters at the oyster bars over there. But do bear in mind that being cheap, Ding Ding is often crowded and sometimes over crowded.Particularly, if you enjoy seeing all walks of life of Hong Kong, it is an eye opener. Gentle reminder though for tourists, there is no room for luggage in a tram and it is also difficult to bring a pram on board. Cheers!

Another Hong Kong heritage. If you visit Hong Kong island, many transportation available there, but only one unique transportation, old tramways that already exist many years a go. Still like an old bus, like the one you see on Kungfu Hustle Movie, you can sit on the top, with fresh air .....

cheap way to see Hong Kong island. board the tram in central, take the route to Happy Valley, then change route to go to the eastern suburb, change route again to go back to central, you may continue to go to the western suburb as well if you have time, the whole trip cost you about 10 HKD
A lens of reality.. Avoid the daytime. Catch this ride at dusk, stand on the lower deck's back area. You'll see, smell and feel the city.

Must do. Surprisingly fast on the busy main streets. Difficult to get a seat, but cheap. Hot in Summer since no air-con. HK Tramways also run 'Party Trams' - you can charter a tram (open top if you prefer) for your party to run from Kennedy Town to just past Causeway Bay and back, bring your own food and drink and music onboard and enjoy the sights, sounds and smells of the streets. Toilet stop included. :)

Historical Public Transport. Well maintained historical public transport in Hong Kong which is still in good operation.Hong Kong Tramways serving Hong Kong peoples more than 100 years ago and still going strong.Hong Kong Tramways surviving the pressure of the crowds in peak hours and still reflecting the traditional life style of the old Hong Kong.

"Ding Ding" - Long time no see. Last time I took the tram, i think is 5 years ago.This time, when I get on the tram again, I felt so relax (make sure you got enough time to take).It drove me from the Sheung Wan (old street) to Causeway Bay (shopping area), I found out there is lots of changes within these 5 years.Moreover, it was so interesting when i sat next to the driver, it seems the tram is so easy to control (just few button).High recommend to all traveler - Cheap and traditional public transport in Hong Kong.

Explore Hong Kong in one ride. Hong Kong tramways ran on Hong Kong Island only. It was not operated anywhere else in Hong Kong. It ran from the far eastern side of Hong Kong Island to the far western. Full trip took about 3 hours. No matter how long you travel, it costed HK$2.3 per trip.Started from the eastern side, tram passed the residential area. Lots of local shops, wet markets and experience local life. Further on tram passed by City Plaza which is one of the biggest shopping mall for middle-class. And then it passed thru Quarry Bay (newly developed commercail area), North Point (another residential area) and later on Causeway Bay which is the traditional busy area of Hong Kong, Sogo, Times Square etc... Further on is Admiralty and Central which is the heart of Hong Kong economy. I suggested to plan a trip to Central on week days lunch time so that you can experience how busy this area is. Then you will enter the west side starting with the "Dry Sea Food" old district. Most shops and buildings are over 100 years old. Further on is another residential area for oridinary people.Except industrial area, tramway allowed me to experience most of the Hong Kong living in a short trip.

Ding ding ding went the trolley. My husband. And I took our very first tran ride this week, after being in Hong Kong for two years we decided it was time!Much to our delight this tram is so central to everything! Shops, train staitions, main roads and not to mention some great little alleyway markets along the route.Double decker tram that is so skinny..it's surreal but, charming.Enter from the back of the Tram and disembark from the front of the Tram..where you pay as you leave.

The old fashioned way to see Hong Kong Island. This is an excellent (and very economical) way to see Hong Kong. Try to take the front seats on the upper deck for a scenic ride. For groups, you can hire a open-top tram for 2 hours and party on. You can even bring food and have a party on board. If you do this, suggest to do it in the evening. The tram lights up and offers very pretty photo opportunities.

Relax and interesting. I like taking trams in Hong Kong. It's clean and cheap. I feel comfortable and relaxed. You can take them from Kennedy Town to Saukeiwan. Although it moves slowly, you can enjoy the scenery and see what happens on the streets.

Cheap and easy. Booked our hotel away from mrt station, tram were the main transportation we had to go central station. It has quick turnover and it own lane in busy hk street. Nice surprise of how convinenet and cheap. Octpass card is a must tho.
Fun. Everyone should jump on a Ding Dong and travel around with the locals. Very cheap, one price for any length of journey. Locals love to chat to you .

Good value trip with lots of nostalgia. I was surprised that this was quite a good value journey - and easy with the Octopus card - only use this on exit. The motors must have been brought up to date - they were smooth with a fast progressive pick up of speed. The corners have to be taken quite slowly and are quite jerky. Will make a point of using these more on our next visit.

You think slow but quite fast. You think with all busy traffic that taking these trams is slow but actually it is quite quick. And cheap! It saves you a lot of walking under the ground if you take these. Try to sit on top level in the front and see the city passing by. I loved it. You can pay 2.30$hkk cash or with your octopus card if you leave them. Anywhere you go. Same price

Easy to catch & cheap. Staying near Happy Valley we were frequent users of the trams to get to various MTR stations inc. Central and Hong Kong as well as attractions. Always easy to use and although a bit slow at times, they do have dedicated lanes for the tracks along much of the routes.

If you have extra time in HK... must ride. Ride the tram and get a great view of the north side of Hong Kong Island. Relax, take seat and enjoy the views. Also a great thing to do at night, grab some drinks from 7-11 and make your way from North Point wet market to Central for a party atmosphere. Cheap and fun :)

Get your MTR card ready and get on quick. Get on through the rear, you don't need to beep until you reached your stop. Make sure you know where your going ahead of time, the drivers are understandably impatient, but can be nice at times. Get to see the native streets of Hong Kong as you travel around

So much fun but very slow. The tram was a lot of fun, especially if you can snag the front seats on the upper level. It is also so cheap!!! The ride is very crowded and so, so slow but you can get a cheap tour of Hong Kong and if you can get a seat, it is worth the time.

slow but fast transport. The Hongkong tram is the only public transport with no air-conditioning. It is the cheapest land transport. Its routing extends from Shaukeewan(Eastern) to Kennedy Town(western) and Happy Valley to Whitty Street and Shaukeewan.It runs at very low speed when comparing to motor vehicles. However,during rush hours ,when the road are jammed with motorcars(especially in Central District),It is a fast transport. Please take a ride around 5:30pm during weekdays.Edward CHAN in Hongkong

slow but fast transport. The Hongkong trams are the cheapest public vehicle.This is the only public tansport without air-conditioning.Its running speed is very slow when comparing to motor-car.However, during peak hours,when the road is crowded with motor-cars(especially in Central district),tram is the faster transport.Please try. Edward CHAN in Hongkong

A piece of history and a cheap and fun way to see the real Hong Kong.. I lived in Hong Kong for 18 months back in 2007/2008 and have used the trams to commute and also as a fun tourist activity with family and friends. during a recent trip to Hong Kong on business (Dec 2014) I used the tram to get from my hotel in Johnston Road to Pacific Place in Admiralty and it reminded me how great they are and prompted me to write a review here on Trip Advisor.They have been running for 110 years and are the cheapest and most environmentally friendly way (other than walking) to explore Hong Kong. At just HK$2.30 (about GB£0.20) per ride for an adult and HK$1.20 for a child aged 12 years and under, it's amazing and no wonder that the trams with their 6 lines and 120 stops have about 220,000 riders every day! You get on the trams at the rear and exit at the front, paying as you exit with cash deposited in the trams farebox or by tapping an Octopus card on the fare processor machine. All the trams are double-deckers and it's great sitting up top and watching the bustle of Hong Kong as the driver 'Ding Dings' his way through the busy streets. If taking a 'tourist ride' I strongly suggest taking the tram right from it's start to end, so get on in Shau Kei Wan and ride all the way to Kennedy Town... It really is something you'll never forget or regret doing. This journey will take about 80 minutes and for the HK$2.30 Fare that is exceptional value for money!!! Note that due to their age and restricted space inside they are not suitable for wheelchair users or for baby buggies.
Must do. Charming, cheap and very cheerful transport from Happy Valley down to Central. Head upstairs, grab a seat and watch the hustle and bustle of Hong Kong roll by. A must do.

A journey in the past. I ride the trams every time I visit Hong Kong. You get to ride in historical relics from a bygone age that still function as public transit. Now be ready for standing room only in peak hours and remember that there is no air-conditioning! Sit at the front for your photos. Did I mention the ride is cheap?
vintage transport. extremely cheap but reliable, comfortable transport. Great for touring certain areas of HK Island. Front seats on top level make good viewing
great......... .....near central it can be very slow because of trafic. easy to use with octopus card.in happy vally you have to change the tram and you get a roundtripp.i hope they Keep it!
Love it love it!!!!. I just loved these trams. The best way to travel around Hong Kong!! You get to see so much, and so cheap!!!!

Cheap and a good way to explore HK island.. If you have time, take a rid on the tram. It's slow, you can take pictures and admire the city. It's the cheapest transportation mode in HK. Go upstairs for a better view!

Well worth the experience. Cheap and interesting public transportation, easy to figure out ( well sign posted) . Enter in the back, sit upstairs, pay on your way out. Purchase an Octopus card when you arrive at the airport and use it for all public transportation.

Typical Transportation. It moves very slow, the fare is only Hkd 2.3 then you can travel the whole Hong Kong Island. Hong Kong people call it 'din din' as it will make a sound like "din din". Take a ride and enjoy the view of Hong Kong Island if you are not in hurry.
cool!. funny way to travel around... You can enter, and travel as long as you like. As soon as you leave the Ding Ding you have to pay a small fee.

Nice to see a piece of old in all of the modern world.. I enjoyed seeing these trams still around. Although it isn't authentic culture, it is still a part of Hong Kong's culture. Rode it once just up the street but it was nice you could use your octopus card and hop right on. Nice things to do at least once.

A legend. What is a trip to Hong Kong without going on the Ding Ding. The best way to get through the traffic on the Island and so cheap, especially if using the Octopus card. Always crowded, but that is part of the magic.
Fun..... If you want to have some fun while in HK, definitely try the tramways. This was lots of fun and I enjoyed every minute of it. You can easily hop on and off of these things when need to.

Slow. We hopped on this after a night out just to say we had. It’s a slow way to get about and not particularly worth a special effort but it’s a ‘tick box thing’ that doesn’t take much time or money to do.

Do Ride the Tram. Our group of 12 took the tram from Central to Happy Valley races on the Wednesday night. The tram took us all back to the days of trams here in Australia, most are now gone. These double decker trams have manual air con - just pull down the windows. Only negative comment was that we travelled at peak hour and it was so crushed and we had to wait for a seat. My suggestion is leave for the races early !!! And No, we didn't win!
Ding ding all the way. Make sure you go to top deck. It is something you don't want to miss. It is very loud and slower than subway but well worth the time.
Hong kong transportable. Easy to arrive all of hong. Kong island,from shaukeiwan The free is ony 2.3 for one personGood choice ~
charming. nice nostalgic feeling. modern from outside but classic from the inside. the rides are not so smooth though but we didn't mind since it's just a short trip.

A good ride around part of the town. We went on the tram ride as part of a cruise excursion and was happy with the organisation and the ride itself. Gives a nice little overview of the north west bit of Hong Kong. Not sure if they do other parts as well. It gives you a good look around and then you can decide if you want to go back to any of the bits.

The best transport and observation deck in HK. We stayed at the end of Connaught road and were a stroll away from a tram stop. Actually, we used it straight away on arrival, when out of Central. The best is to buy an Octopuss card (at the airport) and refill it when it's going to be empty. You can do it at any grocery store (7eleven for example). It is an easy way to go through that part of HK island and cost peanuts! If too crowded, just wait for the next one. Then, go upstairs and enjoy the life passing by.

Charming. The ding dings are something I didn't know even existed in Hong Kong before I came and wow now they are my fave part. Its just brill to brisk through the downtown metropolis for basically 0£. More cities shud do the same!
Bit of fun. Bit slow and crowded during peak hour but still a cheap and fun way to get around. Easy to get on and off.

Essential HK Experience. Not to be missed by railway enthusiasts and the public in general. For just a couple of HK dollars these iconic trams provide an unforgettable experience of the sights and sounds along both main and side streets in the north of Hong Kong Island. Make sure to go upstairs to get the best view.
Great mode of transport!. This tram was clean and efficient and we really had no complaints. It was packed a lot of the time though.

A fun way to get around but can be crowded. A really nice and convenient to get around ( cheap too! ) but can be hard to get off when its busy! Best used in the evening when its quiet. Get on at the back and pay with your Octopus card at the front when you get off.

Must give it a go. This is transport for the masses from a bygone era. It's cheap and cheerful and is to be tried at least once on your visit. Although I have used it many times. It can be quite crowded at times and the only air conditioning is an open window but it's the equivalent of £0.20 per journey.
Tram Rides. Fun experience for children on the double decker trams. Fast, efficient and an easy way to get around.
Don't Miss It!. The quintessential Hong Kong and greatest travel bargain in the world. We use it often every time were are in the city. Seniors ride for 1.10 HK$ which is about 15¢ US.

Great to travel on. We bought an octopus pass which we could use on trams, buses, MTR, ferries. But I have to say that the double decker trams are such fun. We travelled often on them in our week in Hong Kong.

A bit of fun. We rode on the top deck. Can pay by octopus card or money. Enter at the back of tram, exit from front past the driver.
I liked it as a novelty.

World's Largest Double-deck Tram Fleet (over 100 years). Since 1904, trams have been running from East to West of Hong Kong Island. This is the cheapest transportation in Hong Kong. There are 6 tram routes (totally 30km) providing tram service between Shau Kei Wan, Happy Valley and Kennedy Town. It costs you less than US$0.4 !!!There are 120 tram stops from Shau Kei Wan to Kennedy Town. The tram stops are located at an interval of around 250 metres on average. Compare with MTR (underground), Tram is slow and hot (in summer), But you can enjoy the view of the main street on Hong Kong Island. I suggest traveler to spend one hour on the tram (from one end to another) to take a look at the real life of Hong Kong!!!

Fun Way To Take a Quick Tour. Definitely a great way to spend HK$2.30 per person to rest those tired feet and take a quick a quick tour through one of the main shopping areas of Wan Chai and Causeway Bay and up around the Happy Valley Racecourse. Take a seat on the top level for the best views.
Trams at its Best. found only in the hong kong island, and one of the most preferred way of transport with a very minimal charge. A good view of the nearby skylines during the way.
What fun. Took the tram one day for fun. Nostalgia! Not a quick ride, but when you have nothing to do on a saturday morning and things are not crowded it was like stepping back in time.
Tramway Review. An inexpensive transport method, but also very busy, sometimes uncomfortable and quite slow, especially during peak travel times.

Fun and convenient. I took these several times. Easy to use- just pay as you get off- you do need exact change 2.30. Apparently they have raised the price and so it wasn't crowded at all. Tall and skinny- they were fun to ride.

Terrific Trams. They might look quaint and old fashioned. And they might seem to be a slow means of travel. But they are terrific - no traffic hold ups, cheap as chips, and great for getting around if you are on Hong Kong Island.They get crowded but it's all part of the fun& atmosphere of being in Hong Kong. Plus unlike the MTR, one gets some great moments - the sights and sounds of Hong Kong first hand, especially from the upper deck.A must when in HK.

An interesting experience. Inexpensive way to see the Islands North Side. Travelling out of rush hour is great. Seats can be a little un comfortable, but the experience outweighs that. Using an Octopus card is the way to go. As no hassle with finding the correct fair, as no change is given.

Fantastic, exciting and cheap. This is a fab way to get round and do it like the locals do. Either buy an Octopus card (similar to our Oyster card in London) or pay as you go as long as you have the right change to drop into the box on your way out. It's exciting watching all the scenery go by if you sit on the top deck.

Cheap and colorful. What best way to visit Hong Kong than by taking a tram through the various districts and sitting on the upper deck (it is quite slow, but all the better to look around)? This time around, due to the protests in various parts of HK I had to change a few times, but got a free ride the 2nd time (same direction) to alleviate the disruption...

Ride the Ding Ding tram. Riding the trams is a very cheap but fun way to see Hong Kong. Trams are old with traditional wooden seats. Sit upstairs at either the back or front for the best views. You board trams from the back and get off at the front, paying as you leave. Journeys are all priced the same, and can be paid either by Octopus Card or cash.

Ding Dong.. The Ding Ding Tram is something that you must experience at least once.In my case I travelled from Central station to Kennedy Town and back again, The Tramcar was slow and crowded and on the way back even more crowded, I had to stand upstairs.There is a nice view across the Water from Kennedy Town Waterfront and also some nice Restaurants in the area.

fun way to travel until you get stuck in a traffic jam :)). until you get stuck in a huge traffic jam :)) absolutely fun and cheap way to travel. It is not the fastest way to get somewhere due to the traffic but do get on it.

The last Hong Kong history transport left. We enjoyed the Ding Ding, it is as old as Hong Kong history, you can sit there to enjoy the slow movement at the very busy city. very good experience for traveller.

nice way to look around. First get to one of the terminal stops (we went to ´Shau Kai Wan´-metro station) because there You can be sure to get a nice front-seat on the upper floor. The ride takes some time, but there are a lot of impressions and HK really passes by ...

Wonderful part of Hong Kong's heritage. I have used the Hong Kong Trams numerous times, and love it everytime. It is really cheap to use at $2.30 HKD per ride, regardless of the length of your journey. I particularly love the old original trams that's made of wood (I don't like the new modern aluminium ones!), there is something charming about being on the trams. If you go on a longer journey, it's worth trying to get a seat on the top deck as it's a great way to see Hong Kong's streets and neon signs. You always spot something different from up there, that you wouldn't from just walking at street level. There are Albert and Victoria, Hong Kong's oldest two trams. Albert is green and is lit up with pretty lights, and Victoria is dark red also lit up. They are a joy to see.

Must Do in HK. It's the cheapest transport in Hong Kong. For HK$2.3 you can travel from Kennedy Town to Sau Kei Wan (distance ~ 14 Km.) It goes at a leisurely pace along the North side of the island, taking you through HK old and new. I would recommend taking the tram once during daytime and another in the evening. Since it goes so slowly and the stops are frequent, one can easily hop off at places of interest. The trams are mostly non-airconditioned and can be something to consider if you visit during the summer months. However, if you visit between November ~ January the ride is very pleasant. Actually, it's the best time to visit HK. The weather is usually fine and not too hot.
A must to do !!. Going up to the top of the island in the tramway is an invigorating experience you will be able to see Hong Kong on its plenitude and beauty...Must do...Luis Fernandez-Maldonado

Ding Ding your way. Being from Melbourne, I have a thing for trams. Hong Kong street trams are really quirky, boxy, smaller than I thought and a really interesting transportation method in Hong Kong island. The trip itself cost $2.3 per trip regardless of distance. Sometimes, trams can get really packed, but don't be afraid to go up to the upper deck for a better view. There are two stairways, one at the front and one at the back. So you should be able to get off easily when it's time to do so. Also take notice of the interesting "branding" of these trams. Each one of them normally carries advertisement of one certain product or company.

Great trip. The ding ding is a cheap and pleasant way to see downtown Hong Kong. Not many locals use it, except the elderly and parents with small children, due to its slow speed, but this just makes it perfect for taking pictures from.

A must every visit. Great fun just to trundle along on one of these. Can get very busy but they are very cheap and worth the wait.We will often just do the full route of a tram to see HK slowly pass by.

A must do in Hong Kong!. I LOVE travelling on the Hong Kong trams! Best if you can get a seat upstairs up the front! It's cheap and a great way to people watch and look at all the buildings! A definite must if you are visiting!
great trip. great trip for very little money or credit of your Octopus card. historic looking but some are quite recently rebodied. normally very busy even on a sunday a "must do" in hong kong

Old but true. Wonderful means of transport in HGK! Small trams run every 5-8 minutes and can take you to metro stations or center or vice-versa. Cheaper than buses - it was 2.3 HGK dollars per ride when you do not have a pass

What better way to travel. We use the ding ding most of the time when we are in Hong Kong and love them. It's convenient, cheap, and above all, fun. It is also usually packed, sometimes slow, and can be draughty upstairs. It is possible to travel practically all the way along the Island - and it is a great way to see it. Okay the buses are air conditioned and swift [traffic permitting] - but when you're on a tram you know you're in Hong Kong!!

Not just a tourist attraction. Riding the tram is even better now they take the Octopus (stored value) card.... Hop on at the back entrance ... When you want to get off make your way to the front and tap your Octopus card before disembarking. Upstairs is nice and breezy.... You can go up the back stairs when you get on the tram.... When you want to get off, make your way to the front set of stairs. I mention this because you might not expect to see two sets of stairs in a vehicle this size! If you have time to kill you can hop on the tram and just stay on to see where it takes you! Many HK-ers (not just tourists) use the tram as the flat fare is lower than the bus so more economical for a short ride. To be fair it is not overly comfortable and as you can see from the outside the trams are pretty narrow so the seats are small

Fun night drinking in tram. My friends and I rented two trams for my friends birthday. We were suppose to have it from 10 pm to midnight. We didn't leave until 10:30 because most of us for last. None of the taxis knew where to take us. Just for the record, tell them Connaught Street and water Street and you should be fine. The tram departs from Sheung Wan and travels to Happy Valley and back to Sheung Wan. We got two trams. One was the red one and the other was green. At Happy Valley we switched trams. The red was a lot better. It had twice the outdoor space. We had 50 people. 25 in each tram. It was bring your own alcohol. It was a fun night. We did have some issues with the staff. They wouldn't let us switch trams at first when we got to Happy Valley. And then they wanted to charge us extra for going after midnight. Minor things that could have been avoided. Still had a fun night though
Tram. HK tram services may be slow at times but they are the lifeline . One must carry the exact currency coins while traveling on it .

A British touch... A lot of fun to go through te HK streets you would never visit without them . hot in the summer, i suggest you take the air conditioning busses around everywhere.But in the evening if you are not in a hurry, they are very interesting..If you are handicap or have problems standing, then i do not suggest the dubble decks trams.Otherwize, yes !!, take the tram in HK . It is fun.

Great to do at least once. These Tramways are an extremely cheap (2 HKD) to travel as short or as long of a distance as you would like to go. They start in Kennedy Town on the West to Shau Kei Wan in the East with over 100 stops in between the 13 kilometer stretch. The Top is the best place to see Hong Kong and to check out all the different neighborhoods.

Great experience. The queues were quite long but they handle it very well. Use your Octopus card if you have one to avoid the ticket queue wait. Make every attempt to get a seat rather then stand as it is a very steep ride

Seeing Hong Kong on a slow pace. Though it gets crowded and hot in summer, the tram has always been one of my favorite transportation in Hong Kong. Its low price takes you from the Island's one end to another.Take it on a cozy day in autumn, you would never regret. Under the slow pace you will get to see another side of Hong Kong. And if you're lucky enough, there's a tram model 120 which is the oldest movable version of tram, where you can find a seat under the staircase, and seats made of bamboo on the upper deck.Enjoy!

You "gotta" take the ding-ding!. We live in Hong Kong and always take out-of-towners on the ding-ding. It's an inexpensive and authentically Hong Kong way to see a lot of the city without walking. It goes very slow, so you can take great photos from the street level. And, it's only filled with locals, so you'll experience an old and lovely mode of transport with folks that are using it to get around. (A break from the relentless tourists everywhere else.)
My boy like it. My boy was very happy when we finally take ding ding tram to victoria peak. Pros : unique vehicle Cons : a little confuse to understand the route

Tram journey in Hong Kong. I always enjoy Tram ride in Hong Kong provided the temperature in below 27 degree Celsius. Avoid rush hours in morning and evening. The upper deck is the observatory deck for curious tourists. You can take multiple journey 's for fare is $2.2 per ride. The stops are convenient just follow the tram track or railway. It is suitable for family or solo travel.

Ding Ding and CheepCheep. A lovely means of travel along the north side of Hong Kong Island.Although the price is not "hop-on-hop off" inclusive it is cheap enough for most people not to have to worry about the cost.
Tram. Vibrant and bustling and packed! Tremendous value and a good view of the local sights from the top deck

the best value sightseeing transportation in hong kong. cannot imagine this form of transport in this highly dense populated city. but a flat rate of 2.5$, must be deal of the century nowadays! can literally spend a morning or afternoon going from one end to the other , and see this amazing city- from financial centre to residential district- and back- especially in the beautiful autumn weather! try during the weekend to avoid the crowd

Legendary Ding Ding is HK's Icon. The iconic trams made their debut in 1904 in Hong Kong where a large number of residents lived and had a growing demand for cheap and convenient transportation on the island. The HK Tramways launched their seventh-generation tram in 2011, which is a combination of modern interior design with traditional exterior tram outlook. The face-lift allows the tram’s iconic image to be maintained but the interior is a lot more comfy now than how it was decades back. HK people fondly refer our famous trams as 'ding ding' because of the tinkling sound it gives out as it trundles daily, weaving through major streets stretching from the East to the West of HK island. If you are pressed for time, Ding-Ding is perhaps not for you cos it is confined to run on assigned tracks at a restricted speed. However, if you have time to spare, I strongly recommend anyone, esp tourists to take a ride on these very comfy, airy, and clean public transport, to get a glimpse of real HK where east meets west, with routes leisurely taking you from our newest, most cosmo districts in Central to our older, more conventional and historical areas like Sheung Wan at a fare you cannot resist and nothing can beat----hop on and ride the entire routing for just , look----adults HK$2.30, kids HK$1.20( 3-12 years old), and senior citizens HK$1.10. People can hire the trams for tram parties and it is getting more and more popular with product launching or weddings or graduations.The tram windows open wide to bring in the draughts in cooler days and breeze in the hot summer. This is unique to HK and no tourirts can claim they have visited vibrant Hong Kong without a ride on our beloved 'ding-ding'.

Tram party!. This is one party we do not have in the Philippines, and having to use the tram for everyday commute is like a therapy. You enjoy the culture. You have to be relaxed becuase it is a very slow commute.

Best Value Attraction and Transport in Hong Kong. If you have time to take the tram to the end of the line in Kennedy Town and sit upstairs you get away from the tourist mobbed Central area and its combat style shopping and see Hong Kong as it had been some time for the rest of the population

Nice way to get around and see the city. If you're not in a rush, try hop on to one of the tram car. It's not as fast as the subway, but it's an interesting way to see the city. A lot of local people also use the tramways. The fare is a lot cheaper than the subway.Tip: get an Octopus card upon your arrival in the airport, it can be used on all the transportation and many stores (convenience store, cafes, bakeries, Watson's...etc.). I don't like getting a lot of coins back, so I usually just deposit money into my Octopus card, it's very convenient. And the card can be returned and the balance can be refunded before you leave Hong Kong.

Value for money. This is one mode of transport that i do not think you get to see anywhere else in the world at such a price, 2.3HKD as of october 2014! Truly amazing ride and you get to see how locals use this as a common mode of transport but i can imagine how uncomfortable it will get during hot summer... Tip: Ride this when the weather is cool!

Fun Time. I have been traveling to Hong Kong since I was 4 years old with my parents and they took me on the tram and now I have taking my own kids. Slow ride, you get to see the people and shoppes. Great way to see Hong Kong

Surely the cheapest way (apart from foot) to explore Hong Kong. We used the tram to help decide where we would like to explore later in the day. Try to get a seat on the top deck as it gives you an entirely different perspective from the street level. We travelled from near Admiralty MTR to Happy Valley racecourse, and simply stayed on board while it returned, disembarking at an interesting street market in Wan Chai. The amazing thing was the cost of the trip HKD2.30! I have seen it written elsewhere that it was important to have exact change; however I simply paid HKD5 upon disembarking (there were two of us) and it wasn't a problem.

Good experience. Travelled it only the once - it was very crowded and got stuck in traffic. As we had to get back in time for another event, we got off and walked instead. You pay when you get off, exact money needed (about HK$ 2.50) so have the correct coins. The trams are iconic for Hong Kong, as are the double decker buses.

Still the best way to see the city!. For not very much, you can go from the west side of the island, all the way to the east. The locals use this means of transportation still because it's very convenient and not very pricey - AT ALL (right now at about US$0.40 for adults). If you can, get a seat upstairs on this double-decker and sit in the front or back if you want to have a true 360 view of all the hustle and bustle of the city. There is no air-conditioning so in the summer time it may get hot, and in the winter might be chilly, but we went during November when the weather was perfect :)You've GOT to take at least two ding ding trips during your stay if you can in Hong Kong!

Great Way to Travel Hong Kong Streets.. Fabulous way to travel the streets of Hong Kong. It stops all the time, which makes it perfect for navigating the often times confusing streets of Hong Kong. Worth taking advantage of, but lay out the route you are choosing to take for your stops.

You must try this experience. If you have time and you are up to a new experience, you must try the tram in Hong Kong island. There are different lines and you pay directly on the tram so make sure you have some coins with you. Make sure you get a place on the upper level and settle in for a journey that can be up to one hour or even more, if there is high traffic. The trams are also used by locals so if one is too crowded, just wait for the next one. As far as I know there is the possibility to rent a tram for the while night for a private party and you can decide your route around Hong Kong island.

Duck. Stops all the time but that's what it does. Interesting way to observe life as you travel through Hong Kong streets. The important thing if you are tall is duck because it wasn't built for tall people. and you will bang your head on the ceiling. Worth takeing a ride and its cheap!

Best way to see HK and for short distance travel. What can you get for HK$2.30 in HK these days? not even a packet of chewing gum which is double that, so the tram's fare is a steal!There are a few types of trams. The really old wooden ones which ooze with character, the slightly more modern ones where you still have to make sure you don't bang your head on the ceiling if you are relatively tall, and then the modern ones which have lost much of the character of the old trams and hopefully don't entirely replace the old wooden ones.The trams are very colourful on the outside, having become the biggest advertising billboards around. They're quite fun to watch, and many tourists and locals alike take photos of different designs.The trams are not air-conditioned, so that's a slight issue in the summer, especially if you take this during rush hour. Generally a tram is ok for the same distance as 2 or 3 MTR stops, otherwise for convenience the MTR is better. However if you are visiting HK and want to have a good view, go upstairs and enjoy the gentle pace of the tram. Kids love it, get a seat upstairs at the front and they're happy to go along.On weekends, the trams tend to be overrun by the helpers who have a day off, since this is the cheapest way to get around.Enjoy the ride!

One of the best way to see Hong Kong island. Executive summaryPros - cheap scenic ride across town, view from the top deckCons - Traffic is usually bad during peak hours, may take a while to finish, trams are fairly oldTop tip - Go early or late for a more pleasant experience. Also note the occupy movement means traffic is worst than usual in Causeway Bay, so best to get off beforehand to avoid long waits.Best to take the MTR instead, if in a hurry...Highly recommend trying the trams.

Great way to see the city!. The Ding Dings are a must if you visit Hong Kong. They are incredibly cheap and very enjoyable on a nice warm afternoon. The open-air top level is fantastic to sit back and watch the city go by. Every city should have cool ding dings like HK!

Very slow means of transport.. I love trams, but sadly in HK they have no priority over other traffic or at lights which means dring busy times progress is painfully slow particularly around Causeway bay and Wan Chai areas, possibly quicker to walk! Whilst it is very cheap at $2.30/ride, I am not sure if I would be bothered with them next time. Nice to watch go by and photo. If coming to see trams suggest you stay in Western end of town, where you can see and hear them move at a more reasonable speed!
Not to be missed.. Cities with trams are always a plus. An interesting and relaxed way to view this beautiful city. Climb the upper-deck and enjoy!

Nice ride to see Hong Kong side.. We took the tram and had a nice few hours taking it from central to north point and saw many changes in the area. It is very cheap and isn't fast due to traffic but otherwise nice ride.

Interesting way to see Hong Kong. It is very convenient to travel through the Island Corridor from Eastern to Western end. It passes through all the main districts on the Hong Kong side. It is a bit slow, but maybe faster than a cab during many of the traffic bottle necks. An it cost HK$ 2.30 (30 cents US).

Good attraction for the kids. Again we had to queue...howeveer not for long, we got a nice place upstairs at the end of the tram, it was nice kids really enjoyed it and it is a cheap and nice way to travel withiN Hong Kong. You pay when you hop off (saae price whatever the distance) an dyou can of course use your Octopus card!

Good fun ride.... A must as a tourist to have a ride of the tramways. It amazing how so many modes of transport work in sync with each other in such a small country. Tramways though has its old charm as is riding an open Double decker. Do not miss either of them.

Tram Disruptions. Unable to use the trams due to the demonstrators This was a shame for first time visitors.It did not spoil our holiday as we have been many times before.Just had to use the MTR which is very quick,but always packed like sardines and a lot of extra walking involved.

The Ding Dings are a local treasure!. The Ding Dings are a cherished part of Hong Kong's present and past that can be easily enjoyed by visitors who spend time on Hong Kong Island. These slow moving tramcars have been plying their way along the streets of Hong Kong Island since 1904 with the same look and feel that passengers would have experienced a 100 years ago. For the cheap fare of HK$2.30 per adult and HK$1.2 per child, you can catch one of the Ding Ding trams going west and east from Kennedy Town all the way to Chai Wan, passing many historic districts and neighbourhoods, the massive skyscrapers in the Central Business District, the shopping mecca in Causeway Bay and Victoria Park. There are many tram stops and quite a few Ding-Dings on the street so you never have to wait long to find one that you can board. If one passes by and is full, just wait a few minutes for the next Ding-Ding. If there is room on the top deck, we suggest going there as the views are much better. Upstair seats provide you with much better views of the interesting street scenes along the tram line. This is especially true after dark, when you want to have high vantage position to see the neon and bright street signs you will pass during your journey. In the end, Ding Ding trams are not just a important link to Hong Kong's past, they are a heritage treasure and something that we regularly enjoy using during our own leisure time. If visitors have time we highly recommend adding this to your bucket-list of things to see when in Hong Kong.
Great experience. You can use the Ding Ding as á sight seeing vehicle and enjoy hong Kong central. Take a ride for 2.3 hkd it is about worth 20 eurocent per Person.

Go early!. Done this before... It was So beautiful, but did not feel like waiting in line for hours. Go up when they open. Shops/ coffee choices not much then, but the air is cool and the view spectacular. Ride so you can look downhill if you can.
Best deal in town. Great ride down the island that moves much faster than traffic, for sure. No air conditioning though,

Crowded but fun. The tram system was disorganized because of the protests, but took them anyway. They were convenient and fun to get to ride in the upper deck. Easy to use -- pay as you exit and you can use the Oyster card on them.

A Breather. Travelling by tram in HonG Kong is cheap and gives a great view of the streets and buildings but it's not fast. And that's a good thing in a city that moves at lightning speed 24/7. So give your feet a rest and catch a tram from one end to the other and sit back and relax.

Fun and Unique... my first time in a tram.. quite unique for a city tour.. but a little bit hard for tourists to find a way back to the first place after a ride to another point.. but it is cheap.. $2.3 for adults/ride.. but overall, it is fun.. love it..
Easy way to get around Hong kong island. Cheap and great way to see the city, jump on and off when you like and its a nice way to see the island at a slow pace.

A good way to see the Hong Kong Island. Tram is one of the oldest transportation in Hong Kong. It takes you from the west to the east of Hong Kong Island. It's cheap, HKD2.30 (Adult) HKD1.20 (Child). It runs at moderate speed so good for sight seeing. I'd recommend every visitor must experience it as one of the must do thing when travelling HK.BTW, it is the one and only public transportation without air conditioning in HK.

fun and practical. it is more another mean of transportation rather than an attraction. it has one route which goes around HK island and covers major touristic attraction ( but not the Victoria Peak). you should know in advance how many stations you need to ride as going the whole way is a waste of time.having that said, it is fun and practical as the ride on dedicated tracks and thus bypass the heavy traffic. mos enjoyable to ride at the top deck.
I love tram!. old transportation,cheap, but we have to know the maps of tram before we take the tram,very busy in the morning!
Fantastic and cheap way to see the city.. Fantastic and cheap way to see the city. Fares are HKD $2.30. Runs most the length of the north side of Hong Kong Island

Best way to see Hong Kong. This is the best way to see Hong Kong without being jostled by the crowds. Ride the tram from one end of the island to the other for peanuts. Just climb the stairs to the upper level and enjoy the ride - it's slow but it means you'll be able to take pictures.
Excellent. So many other cities could learn so much from this. Its cheap, clean, on time and personnel are always on hand to guide you if you look even a little lost. A great experience
Great way to see life outside Central in HK. A great way to see parts of the city you normally would not visit. Head out on the tram and catch the MTR back. Absolute bargain price.

fun way to see the city. I think it a must try to ride in one of these at least once while visiting hong kong and view the city from its upper deck. Try to get a seat on the front upper deck part to get a good view of the streets. We rode this by walking a few blocks from the tram station going to Victoria Peak then going to causeway bay. Load your octopus card to pay for your ride.

fun. It's just a fun experience, crowded, no idea where they are headed, hop on and hop off and save yourself a couple of miles walking. Since the uprising of the student protests in HK it's a little slow, traffic is affected, but it was nice to go like the locals go.
Reminder of Sentimental journey of the past. I love the ding ding - if all traffic in HK on the Island is in gridlock, the ding ding gets you safely to where you want to be or at least near!

Good fun, and a unique experience.. Easy to use tram system on Hong Kong Island side only. All double decker, so we got a good view of the streets from the top deck.We had octopus swipe cards, so it was very convenient. In trams you swipe the card (or pay by exact change) at the end of your trip.You go into the teams from the back and exit from the front.

Great way to see the city. It runs slowly, but its a great way to see the city from the second level of the ding ding. It's also extremely cheap to ride which is a bonus. You can see the different areas of the city and it is breezy on the second level which is nice. It is also usually uncrowded which is nice!

One of the must do's. Due to the protests the trams were not running our side of the Island but we did see them from Central to Hennessy. At 2.3HK dollars for a flat fare its a bargain. Note you pay when exiting the tram with exact change (or in reality more likely to be 2.5HKD). Fare is about 20 UK Pence. Try to sit upstairs for the view and great pics of the thin and only double decker trams in the world. Looking like they've they are cousins of the night bus from Harry Potter.
Party tram. Despite the protests the party tram took a shorter route through western. A great way to travel and party with friends.

HK Tramways. It is the best way to see HK in a slow pace but try to avoid the peak hours. You can travel from east to west vice versa on a budget. HK$2.50 each way, make use you have the change or get yourself a octopus card.

A must when in Hong Kong. The trams are great. They provide a great view from the top deck and are cheap and frequent. No a/c but that's all part of the charm. If you are in a hurry take the MTR. It's quite odd paying as you get off at the front (you get on at the back).

Uniquely Hong Kong. Used Ding Ding a lot during my Hong Kong trip this time round as I was staying in Hong Kong Island. It is a good way of transport to enjoy the street views and I enjoyed all my Ding Ding trips!

old memories. ding ding is good to take in the winter, do not take the ding ding in summer it is without air con. I like to go up stairs to the first floor and sit in the single seats, watching the shops along Hennessy road is the best tour of Hong Kong for HK$2.2 cheapest transport and tour in the world. The ding ding is clean and the good thing we cannot get lost in the ding ding because we travel along the fixed path

Ding Ding. Don't loose possibility to explore the city the traditional way and have a great view from the upper deck! It is not the fastest mean of transport in Hong Kong, but the views are great and you may feel the atmosphere of old Hong Kong. It is very cheap and special. I travelled by tram a few times, the best views are at the front of the upper desk and you can cool off in the summer by a gust of wind through the open window.
Cheap but crowded. Good in terms of price and gives you a view of the city around, but it is extremely crowded and you are left waiting a while during peak times

A bit of fun and chance to see Hong Kong. While the trams are not as quick as the MTR or buses, you do get to take in more sights of Hong Kong from the top deck at the slower pace.
We used the tram a few times instead of the MTR just to see the sights. Worth a trip.
Tramway. A must do when you are in Hong Kong! Explore the city the traditional way and have a great view from the upper deck. It might not be the fastest travel solution but worth doing it!
Take the tram for authentic HK . Fabulous value! We love the ding ding and use it where we can. Great way to see Hong Kong and get around cheaply and efficiently.

Smart travel. Ride in a tram is very interesting.
They are best way to travel in crowded areas of hongkong. Very safe and cheap.

Relaxing. My wife and I spent a couple of hours going west to east to west simply watching the world go past. Hopped on at Chun Yeoung Street after taking the ferry from Hung Hom. We couldn't go far Westward due to HK student protests in the city during our HK stay.Anyone staying at Grand Harbour Hotel, Kowloon, head to Hung Hom Ferry just by the river, get off at North Point and up Shu Kuk Street to Kings Road. Look for the tram stop in the middle of the road.

cheap with good views. A brilliant way to travel from east to west on Hong Kong Island. Very cheap, you pay when you leave, and a fixed rate. You could sit all day going from east to west to east again
Must do. This is an excellent way to see Hong Kong and to get to your destination on Hong Kong Island. I loved the trams. The trip is only about AU$1.20 each way. Excellent value.
great for orientation. the trams are very slow but that makes them a great vehicle to see surroundings and get oriented. the windows are all open in the summer so thereis a nice warm breeze...

Unique. We used the tram just to experience it...they are many that run one after the other..they are a double decker, all in different colours, open windows..,its cheap and its a great way to get around that part of HongKong..when you are there you must experience it!

Slow but chariming. These little Tramways are the advertising boards for all sorts of luxurious things, but they have their charm. We do not actually know how old are they but they look old. Very slow. Very cheap. But because of it pace you can see a lot when you travel on them. Make sure you read the stop name, as nothing is announced. Old meets new...

Fun way to travel through Hong Kong Central. My first ride on the trams was at age 5. I recall my fascination looking out at the city passing outside. My most recent ride is about 45 years later. I am still fascinated by the passing city. Do go up the steps to the second level for better views.
fun. Very inexpensive and its a great way to get around. It was a lot of fun exploring Hong Kong in this fashion
Nice view. Little scary but when you reach up you can see all the beautiful Island,go for it,there is shops up there and a museum,a statue of Bruce Lee!!

Trying the tram. We enjoyed the tram ride. We were with friends from Hong Kong who said that that the queue was very short, I wouldn't like to go on a busy day! It was however hugely enjoyable, although being on the top of the double decker bus on the journey down was pretty exciting too!
Fun way. Really enjoyed this historic mode of transportation. Fun way to explore Hong Kong and its sightseeing attractions.

You can't get lost!. Running West to East the 'Ding Ding' is a pleasure to hop on hop off and feel the pulse of the city! There is really just three things you need to know (1) get a prepaid travel card so you just debit your ride on the scanner each time (and remember to get hand it back on your last day to get the deposit refund) (2) you get on the back and pay as you leave (3) all trams run East to West but there is one that goes to Happy Valley so make sure you don't take that one - sorry I can't remember the number! People are very friendly and helpful - just smile and ask!

relax and enjoy the ride. you got some time to waste ? than don't waste it, go to a tramway station and take a long ride in the city. Sit in front upstairs and enjoy the Views ! why ? 1. it's cheap 2. you can see different parts of the city 3. it's really relaxing 4. you can take great pictures. so why not ?
Great way to see the sights. They are fun and easy - not air conditioned tho, so take your fans !! Get off and on along the way as you see so many different things as you pass along the streets
Nice experience. it a nice experience if you did not had it and u can escape from the traffic on this> it allow u to see more than a MTR of HK
Give them a go. Took me back to my childhood in the UK. Easy to get on and off, very reasonable rate for Elders (We used our Aussie Senior cards to buy Octopus passes for transport)

Fabulous value, but you'll get a numb bum!. At just HKD $2.50 for a ride that can take you from Kennedy Town to Shaukeiwan this is the best bargain you'll get in Hong Kong, but bear in mind if you do go from Kennedy Town all the way along, you're going to be pretty numb by the time you get to the end (and there's not much to see at the end). Heading from Central to Kennedy Town is probably a better way to go, there are a few bars and restaurants at the terminus, where you might want to enjoy happy hour before heading back.Make sure you head up to the top deck and nab one of the four front or back seats for the best view and the best chance of some air.Enter via the back of the tram and you exit via the front, where you swipe your Octopus card or pay your money (exact change).

good ride. We took the tram from Wan Chai to Causeway, the ride is enjoyable, able to view the HK street slowly. The ride is cheap, only one price, HKD 2.30 per ride, you can pay with the Octopus Card(like the EZlink card used in Singapore). Most cities have take this form of transport out but HK still keep it. It is one thing you have to experience when you are in HK
must do. what a view even for a little smog, we could see our ship that was miles away, good shopping in the building too
Cheap way of getting around. Very cheap way of getting from my hotel to Central...sit on top deck at front for a great view of the city.
Another ''Must Do".. Cheap enertainment and a fun way to cover some territory. You can usually get off pretty close to an MRT station to return, if you are in a hurry.
Old feel and exciting. Kids loved the trams. Good way to keep them entertained! We spent a good deal of time exploring and discovering Hong Kong this way. Well worth the time and money!

Shuffle Time. A fun way to get around HK, cheap and interesting. Take a night tram to view the lights and stores all lit up in the evening. Sometimes very packed with people and can be difficult to get off at your stop so make a move in advance.

A cute trip. I have used up almost every type of transportation in Hong Kong. Ding Ding is a good experience and good thing is, you do not need to experience traffic jam by using ding ding as there is a special track. Pay after the ride, it costs around HKD 2 no matter how far is your distance. Love how they preserve Ding Ding in this busy city. Even HK people love to use it.
Great experience. Don't be scared to do this. The maps in the stations have English names on them and are easy to read. Very cheap to get around and very efficient.
Very Busy. This is a must for tourist but be aware it is very busy during week days. Would recommend getting on at the start so that you can get a seat upstairs and enjoy the ride
Trams. They were brilliant. Cheap travel with the Octopus card. Great way to see the sights. Went on them again just for the fun of it.

Cheap way to get across the island. This is a fun way to travel to get across the island for very cheap but it is very slow. But if you don't want to make the trek down to the MTR station this can be a quick way to travel for short distances.

Where else can you get a city tour for .35 cents (US). I LOVE this! The tram can get quite crowded...so it might be an idea to go to where it starts a line (or finishes) and get on early....head straight upstairs...grab a window seat and watch the city go by!
Shoot the Ding Ding!. Very cheap transportation though little bit time taking in compare with MTR or BUS. It's also great for street photography.

HK Tram - a cheap way to explore. Using the Hong Kong Tram, also called Ding Ding, is a very cheap way to get around on Hong Kong Island and explore this area. It's one of the few double decker trams so make sure you sit ob the top floor to get a good sight!

these are fun. just hop on and go to the end of the line a great way to explore - we did and ended up at a market although small it was great to see how locals live and we were able to buy a few small items

yep. only place in the world that has these trams still running so just grab your occy card and just do it.
remember enter from the back and exit from the front.
we went for a short ride but stayed on for two hours .
worth the effort.

inexpensive way to orient yourself with the city. Hong Kong has the most efficient public transport systems and the "ding dings" are a must do in the city. The cheapest way to do sight seeing while orienting yourself with the city.

Easy transit, nice and orderly.. Before we hop on the tram, we saw very long queue, we were wondering what's the line for until the tram arrived. We spent only $HKG 2.70 for the ride from one end of the old island to the other, basically you can go back and forth all day if you wanted. Great way to see the mix of old and new HKG.

Rattling good fun. Catch the tram to any where ,WHY! because it has to be done ,this is Hong Kong iconic way to travel,all for 0.23 hk dollars thats about 19 uk pence ,thats not per mile that's per TRIP,go for a ride one end to the other approx 1hr 30 min all for 0.23hk must be the cheapest sightseeing trip in the world.If you can , get yourself up stairs and sit at the front,but rush hours ,its stand and mimic a sardine in a can.No A/c here just open the window.Its not only the sights its the smells as you pass different areas.These trams only sit on 4 fixed wheels and are the only tram's with upstairs,they do rattle about but thats half the appeal .Get yourself a Octopus card at a MTR station load it with 100HK (£9) dollars and see how far you can travel on it, its taken everywhere all modes of HK transport, you can keep topping it up or hand it back and you get your deposit (50HKD)back minus 0.90 handling charge.

Cheap!. it only cost 2.3 HKD for circling Central HK.
you can just sit and wait until the foremost corner of the stations and it will go back their route is in a circle. You should check what Tram you ride because they have several tracks.
Trams. Brilliant way to travel with the locals - a real experience - a must do. It's easy to pay (and. cheap) you can pay cash or use the octopus card

the iconic hong kong tram!. charming, old-fashioned, picturesque, nostalgic remembrance of bygone times!great views and great for snapping pictures along hong kong island.an east-west trip takes around an hour and is well worth the ridiculous hkd 2.3 charged.get back in time with the hong kong tram and snap away!evenings offer better views.trams can also be hired for parties at very reasonable prices!

Excellent. As a Tramtragic I found HK tramways inspirational. I was allowed to drive the tram around the Happy Valley loop but when I got to Tin Toc lane it was terrifying, every manner of bus and car was on the narrow road with the sething plethora of HK all wanting to jump under the car.... Back in the old days upstairs was first class and cost more.... A pleasant way to see the city, get off at Central and take the Number 6 bust to Stanley for good fish and chips!

Cheap and fun.. This is a great way to see Hong Kong without getting out to walk. Jump on the tram, walk to the top floor, and get that first seat right up front. Simply sit back and let the visual bombardment commence.

Both a transport and an attraction. We find the tram the best way to move around the city centre. It's at street level, which saves you the long walk in and out of the underground MTR station and allows you to avoid the crowd. Even if you have no where to go, just hop in, go up to the upper level, sit back and enjoy the city goes pass you. And it's so affordable. Fare is HKD2.30 for adults and HKD1.10 for children. You enter from the back of the tram, travel as far as you like, then pay the flat fare on your way out through the front doors with your Octopus card or cash (but only accept exact change).A great experience not to be missed.

So cute!. Love this tramways very much! It so cute. Not too fast.. and its so cheap! You can enjoy the view if u sit upper level. Good for traveler so they can record a video or take any pictures of the city. Easy to use as long as u have an octopus card. ;)

Rub elbows with the locals. The Hong Kong trams are a great way to explore and sitesee Hong Kong. The relatively slow pace of the tram allows you to appreciate the beauty of the city. Plus, you also get a chance to interact with the locals.
HIstorical. Slowing down in a hectic city - a great break to watch the world go by while heading somewhere . If you are in a hurry to get anywhere, give this a miss and take the MTR.

A lovely way to commute and so affordable too!. Taking the tram is such a lovely way to avoid the busy traffic. Simply hop on, grab a seat (on the top level for more of a view) and enjoy the ride. The affordable fee is paid as you disembark.
Party trams!. Went on this for a party tram at night, great way to see most of the city, its BYO and takes you back to the city centre for more partying.
try it!. So inexpensive and a great way to see the city, not to mention avoid the awful traffic that you can sit in while paying for a taxi! Excellent people watching too

Sit back - as best you can - and enjoy the view.. Hong Kong is such an 'in your face' kind of city that these trams were just exactly the right mode of travel along the island that I needed. When I was in Singapore last year there were times when I could just about forget that I was in Asia - not so Hong Kong! My son and I went from our hotel near Tin Hau MRT to the eastern tram terminus at Shau Kei Wan and took a tram all the way to the other end at Kennedy Town. In the two and a bit hours it took to make the journey there was not an inch of unused space on either side of the street. Whether it was an eighty storey bank headquarters or the half mile of dried fish & seaweed shops towards the west end it was just amazing. It was the best HK$2:30 that I spent in my entire stay.

Hong Kong on a budget.. During my stay in Hong Kong I used the tramway system on about 5 or 6 occasions. What I learned very promptly was that I should get an 'Octopus' card. These are freely available and inexpensive.Before I bought my card I was charged in a haphazard manner. I don't think the drivers had any idea of the appropriate fare.The card covers travel on trams, buses, ferries, and trains.The card can be topped up almost anywhere, and a refund of the unused portion is available.The trams that I used were quaint little vehicles with very narrow aisles and hard narrow seats. However, it was a pleasant experience and I found the Chinese to be polite, offering their seats to the elderly.I only used the network on Hong Kong Island but found it extensive and efficient.
Great way to get around. Very frequent service, but during the weekday commute gets very very crowded. It still was fun to experience it
great. its the most old line in hk.nothing change 100 years.its very nice and easy to get it.better to try it in the night as it not have air condition.
Good joy ride.. The trams are beautiful. Hop on and get some nice views of the downtown. I could not sit on one but saw them very closely.
Go back to older days. These run along the north side of Hong Kong Island. They are quaint and give a view of how things used to be. Very narrow passages and stairs. Pay as you get off.

The Best and Cheapest Way to see Hong Kong Island. If you have not be on a Ding Ding, you have notexperienced Hong Kong in full. Always get to the top deck and try to get the front seats. Watch out for pick pocket and thieves. But it's safe enough upstairs. Good spots for photography along the tramway. You willnot regret.
Excellent for sight-seeing. It's very cheap, but very handy. We've enjoyed it daily for sight-seeing and for moving around the island. Excellent way of exploring Hong Kong.
Slow, but awesome!. Take the ding ding from Sheung Wan to Causeway Bay for a great slice of HK life. Try it get the front seat on the upper deck
Fun!. Except for the fact that getting in with a stroller can be a challenge. The overall experience was quite good!
Great way to see HK. Cheap and cheerful rickety and fun. Bring your camera and correct change 2.30 HK or use octopus card? They go East to west and back again .
An alternative to MTR. Good alternative to MTR, particularly on the top level to enjoy the sights. Sit near a window and be prepared to get unclose with fellow passengers when it's hot and busy.
Above the crowd. A great nostalgic trip along the main street on Hong Kong Island sitting upstairs above all the chaos of cars and people. Cheap too!
An experience for visitors. All visitors should experience these double-decker trams at least once.Cost is minimal with a variety of sights along the way.

Best traditional transport. This is one of the most traditional things in Hong Kong. Although this transportation is no longer popular among the teenagers, it was one of the most used transportation in the past. And it is still very popular among the elders.The tram goes along HK island. It goes past popular places like Causeway Bay and Central. And it is also extremely cheap (HK$2.5 per adult). Here you can enjoy the scenery in Hong Kong while transporting. And I would definitely recommend going on the upper deck as it is cooler and a better position to enjoy the view.Overall, it is very easy to use. The fee is the same wherever you go. And you pay at the end of your journey. One thing to bare in mind is *pickpockets*. It is often very crowded inside the tram and it is easy for pickpockets to take action.

A trip back in time. Ding ding is my favorite transport in Hong Kong. Many locals agrees with me when it is not rush hour, but I do think being in a traffic jam is way less annoying if you're in a Ding Ding. Recently there are more and more a/c equipped Ding Ding going around, making a trip easier for young kids and elders. However, I do miss the warm/hot breeze coming from the window on the upper deck of the old trams.
Old style transportation =). I like this frequent very cheap transport in Hong Kong that is available at Hong Kong Island.Nothing to dislike about =)
So easy to use. The trams are fabulous and it is like stepping back in time. There are regular stops along the major tourist routes, take time out and grab one for the experience.

Must see: Tram to Victoria Peak. Amazing ride up and back. Very busy, but very well organized. The views are incredible with all the buildings appearing to be on an angle. On the descent you ride backwards, but the angle is so steep that if you were facing downhill, you would slide off your seat.

HK Tram. This is certainly a part of Hong Kong Island not to be missed. If for no other reason than to check it off your HK Bucket list. During the hot months (which is 70% of the year) it gets a big sweaty. No aircon, only open windows and slow movements. The best part is that these are normally decorated in very interesting advertising schemes!

The best way for seing the streets of Hong Kong. I would recommend tourists to try this mode of transportation because it represents the character of Hong Kong Unassuming, Efficient, Humble, Traditional and Diverse. Similar to what Jennifer Lopez sang "My love dont cost a thing" this transport will cost you a flat rate of HKD$2.3, pls note that you have to prepare small change, HK trams does not provide change for banknotes better yet purchase an "Octopus card" upon arrival this card can be used in most transports bus, tram, kcr and mtr except taxis. Hop on and enjoy the ride my Pang yau. :)

Ding Ding. One of the least expensive and fun things to do in Hong Kong. Sit up top for a better view and grab a window seat. There is no AC but the windows are always open. You get a great view of the street life and the massive crowds in Causeway Bay. It's best to be above the crowds not in them.
Great views of entire city. Great and almost free way to see the city. A good way to gauge the nightlife and get a feel for the different vibes in different suburbs.

Brilliant: authentic, colourful & inexpensive. It is a cheap way (HK $2.30) to get to see a wonderful (photo opertunity) part of Hong Kong from the upper deck - great with children as well. The trams have been running every few minutes apart since 1904, and they stilltransport 200.000 people every day.Keep an eye on your belongings - I have seen pickpockets operating in the overcrowded lower deck.

Busy and Bustling!. A ride on the Hong Kong tramways is an absolute must! Hong Kong is bursting at the seams with shoppers, people on business, students, tourists!Blend in with the hustle and bustle and absorb all that amazing atmosphere on a tram! We loved it!
lovely. I love the tram but I don't use it if I am busy - it takes a lot longer than MTR but it is such as cozy and cheap ride - unless it is too packed which definitely happens!
Steep one. WOw factor when u stand just behind the driver and get to see the views. Form the top , the view is excellent, nice restaurants, excellent weather, nice food, loved it the evolution.
Great ride up the mountains. Take a trip up and enjoy the views of the city and on hot days, maybe a respite from the heat. Great way to see the city.

For $2.30 HK you get up close to old and real HK. From Kennedy Town through the city and on to Happy Valley, its a great tram trip - can be slow going during peak times. Sit up to either at the front or back, to help with getting some really good photos. You have to enter via the back door, and leave via the door at the front, which is when you pay your fare. Either exact change in the box near the door - or Octopus card.
Part of Hong Kong's history. Authentic, quick and cheap way to get around Hong Kong. Must try when you travel on Hong Kong Island and try for the upper deck!

Different way. Took this Ding Ding. It's very convenient as it was in the heart of Hong Kong, Don't have to worried about the traffic jam. It's a must try when you're in Hong Kong and it's relatively cheap.

Fun, characterful and dirt cheap way to get around.. These guys are really fun. They look strange at first, tall (double deckers) and narrow but they're iconic. Whilst riding along you get a great chance to get a feel for HK life and a the layout of the place. Kids totally loved them.Get and Octopus card (like London's Oyster card) and each journey is only HK$4 (less than GBP0.50) much less for kids.I couldn't correlate their colours which didn't match the colour of the 'lines' and I got confused until I ignored all reference to colour and just looked at the destination on the front of the tram. Then it all made sense.

A travel back in time. Tried the tramways in Hong Kong on recommendation of guide books. It's interesting that in such a hustle and bustle place like Hong Kong, this relatively slow mode of transport still has a role to play. It's actually a very good way of touring around HK. It runs from the western end of the island towards the eastern. So to complete a tram ride means you can manage to see the different parts of HK in just one ride. Suggestion is to get a seat on the upper floor as it can get quite crowded (still a very popular mode of transport for the locals!). It's cheap too, the fare was just HK$2.3 (get an octopus card - the local travel card - so you don't have to find 30 cents) for the whole journey, amazing!

Take it in the morning. Since there is no air conditioning, I'd advise taking it in the morning. We boarded at the beginning of one of the tram lines, so our large group could all board a single tram.

Cheap fun!. Just get on and ride. You don't need a destination to have fun. Every time I visit Hong Kong I get on the Ding Ding and just ride the circuit for a couple hours. Fantastic photo ops from the upper level.

No aircon but who cares?. Love things like this. Old style HK, out in the open, mixing with the hustle and bustle of the city, taking in all the sights. Who cares that it doesn't have aircon? I would use this instead of the MTR anyday :)

Must ride the ding ding. Don't come to HK and miss a trip on the tram. It only costs $2:30, which is an absolute bargain for the frequent and fast service. You get great views of the city straight through the centre of the island. Look out for no 120 which has original livery and fittings.

Great way to get around. We used the tram several times each day to get around whilst staying in Hong Kong. Slow and noisy at times, that is part of the attraction. They were easy to use and it was obvious where you were so selecting to right place to get off was never a problem. The best place to sit, if possible, is on the front seats as it gives an unusual perspective of Hong Kong. Cheap and effective transport around one of the world's great cities.

One falls in love with the "Ding". This is by far the easiest way to get from point A to point B and the most cost effective. The drawdown, it is sloooow and in the summer there is NO aircon.To say the Ding is not everyone's favorite means to be mobile is disingenuous. It is.You hop on and hop off for all of Hong Kong dollar $2.30 (about , 30 cents US).This would be the only time expats and tourists get to rub shoulders with the locals, other knowledgeable expats and get a sense of the island.Go on, get on the Ding.

Nice way of traveling. There was a tramway station just next my hotel, and I used this instead of the metro. It was the good choice ! Travelling in a tramway is so much fun, and you can admire the city from the second deck. It is also cheaper than metro, and you have stops regularly. If you need to go somewhere, and there is a tramway stop next to it, do not hesitate !

Be careful with this mode of transport. A nostalgic ride. It can be a bumpy ride and one of my friends fell down the stairs because the driver had not waited for her to be settled upstairs before driving off.

A more relaxing way to travel. Although limited in destinations, the trams are a great way to traverse the island. Not as crowded as the MTR, and with lots more to see, they are a cheap way to travel between Central and the eastern end of the island, stopping at most major places in between. A must if you're not in a hurry.
Great way to see the city. Visited last May. These trams are great to just watch. It is the cheapest way to travel and no traffic jams. Recommended.

Still going. Having lived in Hong Kong for a while in the 70s, it was an absolute pleasure to see the old trams still plying their trade. They are still as slow as ever but a wonderful experience if you aren't in a hurry. Upstairs is best and with the windows always open, you can get some great photo angles from up there. The price is just ridiculously low (HK$2.30, about US$0.30!!!). Go the trams.

A cheap- and fun way to travel across Hong Kong Island. Every time my wife and I visit Hong Kong,we always make sure to find time for a trip on one of the Hong Kong Tramways.Please note that,if you come from North America and ask for directions to the streetcars you will only get blank stares.It's TRAMWAYS,not streetcars! The Tramways,also called Ding Dings,are double deckers.Try to get a seat on the upper floor,right up front,where you can enjoy a panoramic view of the passing street life below,while the Tramway clanks and sways along.There seems to be no regular schedule,but Tramways come along every few minutes, sometimes 2-3 behind each other.Depending on the time of the day,the Ding Dings can be packed.If you are on the upper floor,leave plenty of time before your departure,because you will have to squeeze down a very tight spiral staircase,and then push to the front,where the pay station is located,right next to the driver.Only exact cash ($HK 2.30=$US 0.25) or the Octopus Card are being accepted.Not all Tramways travel from end station to end station.The final stop before the turnaround is displayed at the front of the Ding Ding.Consult your street map,before getting on.We found the most interesting stretch of Tramways travel from "Central" to the "Western Market",because you will get a glimpse at the "Old Hong Kong" with colorful shop signs (or neon signs),some deliveries of goods still by hand-pushed dollies,old fashioned shops,all in a somewhat chaotic atmosphere.We usually get off at the "Western Market",where we can enjoy a light lunch or a piece of cake with cappuccino at the German Bakery/Cafe' "Das Gute".A trip on one of these Tramways is even more colorful at night.

Double-decker trams evoke past history. Myself and a friend got on at Central Station and stayed on until we reached the end of the line. Pros:-Good for people watching. I eventually got a seat at the front (upper deck), so could take forward photos out of the window. -Trams travel down centre of street. -Trams are moving advertising hoardings. Cons:-Limited headroom when standing. -No air-con, although the windows can be pulled down. Notes: Adults HK$2.30 - pay exact fare on leaving tram.
Ding ding, here we go. One of the best and cheapest sightseeing opportunities in HK. So cheap, and so enjoyable, enjoy your ride it's a rare opportunity.
Cheap travel. Great way to get around the city and do some sightseeing as well, great thing is you don't sit in traffic !

Great way to get across the Island - and still cheap.
