The trams are part of the iconic atmosphere of Central and eastern districts of the Island and a great way to get your bearings if you are new to HK is just to get on a tram in Central or in the western Sheung Wan area, sit near the window on the top deck, at the front if you can get a seat, and just watch the city go by. All for a really cheap flat fare. Great!

I would pay to just look at them. These trams are fabulous to look at, all different colours and such a fantastic shape! Don't worry about exact change, you can give the driver more and maybe you may end up then paying 30p instead of the 20p flat fare. That's how cheap they are. For a lovely trip as far as you want to go. Top deck, beside the open windows, instead of air con. An easy way to explore when you are on your own, and the tram route provides a way to find your way home even when you are on foot too. You could go by tram to Hong Kong park and sit in the aviary there. Then back by tram to Time Square for scary modern shopping centre. Nice contrasts for a 50p outlay if your just have a couple of hours free time.

Never miss this!. If you go to Hong Kong, this should be the first thing you do to take the pulse of the city. The old trams cut through the heart of Hong Kong Island and take in all the beauty and chaos of this amazing city. You get a brilliant tour for much less than a cup of tea. Take the Happy Valley line too, if you have time

Don't miss this!. I've been a fan of the Ding Ding since my first trip to Hong Kong as a child. The experience of riding on it hasn't changed much. Bring exact change or use the Octopus card. They DO NOT give change.

Relaxing Way to see Hong Kong. Trams have a long history in Hong Kong transportation system. It is still the cheapest way to get around, if you don't mind spending more time.There are several routes for the trams. When I visited Hong Kong for the last two times, I lived in Happy Valley so I took the advantage of riding it from the terminal there. The best way is to get on at any terminal because you can have seats you want and I prefer the upper deck. It is more airy with less passengers standing around you. Avoid the rush hours: your trip will be more enjoyable. Taking the tram at night is another alternative to see the night view of Hong Kong from a different angle.The whole trip just cost around 40 cents US!
enjoyable. Step back in time and take a ride on these tramways. Easy to use so take in the views of central Hong Kong

Fun & Cheap. If you want nostalgia and travel with locals than this is it. Top deck seats face forward and downstairs are side facing. They travel either east or westbound so you cant get lost and are cheap way to get along the main areas of HK island. Not quick but a great delight to ride on at least once

The tram. In the UK, you would have to go to a museum to see trams like this, and here they are, part of the transport system. Great fun, very cheap - worth riding the whole line to see bits of HK off the tourist route. A bit hot in the summer with no aircon

It's the ding ding. The ding ding is the cheapest form of transportation on the island costly a mere $2.30HKD or $.25 USD. If you want to take in the city whether during the day or night then take the ding ding, it is slow but it allows you to absorb all the things hk island has to offer. The best thing about the ding ding is there are tons of stops between north point and Kennedy town so you can get on and off where ever you would like to. The is no a/c just windows so avoid if it is hot and humid but at night it makes for a super fun ride. This is a must for all tourists to hk!
A great way to see HK. If you're in HK, you must take a 'ding ding' at least once. Its a great way to see the sights and its cheap as chips

Cheap, convenient, well worth using!. The stop was straight outside our hotel door and could take us all over HK island. For HK$2.30 a trip (about 23p) they made life so much convenient. Several routes, jump on the back door and then use octopus card or exact fare on exit. They arrive every couple of minutes ... So simple!

What a way to see the city!. This is really a wonderful way to both get around the city, and to see it, especially by night. These antiquated trams are so like dodgem cars that it is really fun to be on them. For HK$2.30 you really get a ride!

Hkd 2.40 all around. HK ding ding tram is one of the cheapest ways to see Hong Kong Island. A journey costs only HKD 2.40 and you just need to pay as you leave the tram. You can pay with coins or just tap on your octopus card.

Great in the evening. The tram only operates in the Hong Kong Island, no service in Kowloon penisula and New Terrritories. Most HK people rely on it during the morning and evening working hours so it is rather packed. There is no air conditioner but with the big windows wildly open, it is like a tram-cruise to get a general view of HK. Travel after 8pm could usually secure a seat upstairs. If it happens the tram is full, just wait another few mins for another tram. No matter how long you travel, the fixed rate is £0.20. For a tourist, get on the tram from Sheung Wan going eastbound, drop off in Fortress Hill and then take the tram westbound back to the original place, or take the much faster Subway back.

Amazing way of winding through Hong Kong island. Cheap too.. It costs just HK$2.30 no matter where you go – from East to West one way or back, and we found this an really good way of discovering different areas on Hong Kong. Some of the areas are posh and modern (like around Pacific Place and Central) and some that are westwards are crowded and busy, but the Ding Ding tram is the way to go. If you want to see the real Hong Kong, forget the underground MTR (quicker) and take the slow lane of the tram.We downloaded the PDF maps (East and West bound maps have stop numbers and accurately show you where you are) from http://www.hktramways.com/en/index.html. Some of the tram cars are really old, while others are pretty new, but the experience – specially if you sit upstairs (with your camera of course) is just unforgettable. We took the ding ding tram several times across Hong Kong island.Use your Octopus card – that is the best and only reasonable way to travel across Hong King, and the fare is automatically deducted as you swipe when you exit through the front. Some of the stops are pretty close to each other, so make sure you are ready to exit through the front before your stop arrives. Keeping those two pdf maps on your phone is a good way to use the tramways. Each tram has a number – but you should look for where the last stop is (says so on the front of the car) rather than the number of the tramcar. New tramcars are made of alumnum, and the older ones are wooden. Trams come along frequently, although sometimes they get delayed in traffic. When they do arrive often we let the first couple of them pass (crowded) and we boarded a near empty one (usually the third one along). Tram stops are marked clearly and they sit in the middle of the streets (both way stops usually face each other and are shaded). Each stop has a map. Whatever you do in Hong Kong, you absolutely must get on the tram, and ding ding through. It's an item that should be on everyone's bucket list.

This is how I get to work every day.. For HKD $2.30 this is the cheapest and dare I say the most fun of travel here on Hong Kong Island. Forget the MTR, if you want a real experience of HK, get on the tram and head up to the second deck. Granted it may not have air conditioning which does make it slightly uncomfortable during summer, the view and the experience of HK's hustle and bustle more than make up for it! Just get on and hold on tight, standing on the second storey of a bumpy, moving tram can be slightly exciting for the uninitiated!

What an experience!. Such a cheap way to get around Hong Kong. You get on at the back of the tram and make sure you go straight upstairs to get a birdseye view as you wind your way around HK streets. Easier to also spot your stop from upstairs. You pay (exact fare only) on exiting the tram at the front. Good luck!

Great Inexpensive way to see Hong Kong. The tram system in Hong Kong is fondly known locally as the "ding ding". It's a very easy system to use and when you use it once you will be hooked. Simply Get on at the back door and when you are getting off pay down at the front. Only $HK 2.30 per person per trip which is about €0.24 or £0.18 - great value. Great city view from up top.

A must do at least once. Very, very cheap & a nice way to get about if you are not in a hurry. Pick your time as they can get very crowded. Unfortunately they are refurbishing the fleet & the No 1 tram - the oldest - was included in the refurbishment which is a great shame. They are still an exciting way to get around though

A must try HK experience. These trams are so cute and are one of the few things in HK that seem to reflect history or something antique-like. Check out the different routes and some go right across the city, so it's a cheap way to sight-see if you want to give your feet a rest. I would advise you use them when the heat and humidity are not at their peak in HK as these don't have air conditioning. Usually, the speed at which they travel does provide a breeze, and you'll see elderly people sitting beside you barely breaking a sweat (guess I haven't acclimatized yet). One more thing that's worth noting for first-timers, you enter the tram at the back door and exit at the front, which is also when you pay. I didn't know this my first time and was a bit confused. Happy travels!

Travel on the Tramway - A best cheap way to see Hong Kong. It's convenient as there are stops almost every few hundred meters along the track. It's also very cheap, costs you less than $3 HKD. If you have time to spare, its a very enjoyable ride during the fall / winter (It maybe a bit too hot during day times in Summer) to see Hong Kong Island in a 1 hour ride or so from Central all the way to Shau Kei Wan. You can jump off the tram to visit any place you see interesting and hop back up to the next available tram, usually within 5 mins waiting time. You must give it a try!

Great way to tour Hk island city life. Great way to see Hong kong island from east to west. This tram is slow moving without air-con but is unique that it provides a good tour of Hk island on the northern coastline where most people work and live. Is cheap and there is only one fare regardless where you board or alight.

Best way to travel!. This is my favourite way to travel around HK! Don't listen to the address, I'm sure you have a tram stop somewhere around you ahahah it's a lot better when theres wind so it doesn't get too hot!

Rent a tram and see the sights of Hong Kong!. I rented a tram for my birthday and it was great fun!! 20 friends and a few hours of traveling around HK Island. Two routes are available for a very reasonable price. You must supply your own food, beverages, and music (and speakers)...but it's a blast!!!
You have to try it. For a couple of dollars it is a convenient way of moving around HK island. You get the double benefit of being right in the middle of local culture.
A cheap classic ride. Make sure you have spare coins and take a ride on the iconic Ding - Dings. The transport options in Hong kong are vast and all are a cost effective way to get around

A good way to view west part of the Island. We took the train from the Central area to West around Bonham Strand. Took us to lots of "local" shops and restaurants. Inexpensive way to see this part of the Island.
So Cheap.. Hop on board, it's a very cheap way to see Hong Kong Island, you can hop on/off and explore, a great way to spend a few hours exploring.

Historic trams - experience you must have. If you're in Hong Kong, I recommend experiencing this at least once in your life time! The trams are very old, so the best time to visit is in the cooler months of Hong Kong Dec - Feb. Remember there is no air-conditioning just old open windows.For more information you can visit http://www.discoverhongkong.com/eng/plan-your-trip/practicalities/transport/getting-around/trams.jsp

Worst sightseeing idea ever!. I visit HK often for work and am always looking for something new to do. Having done various hikes (Dragon Back, Lamma Island, Lion Rock, Lantau Island) and sightseeing (Big Budda, Nunnery, Peak, History Museum, 10,000 Buddahs, etc.) I thought this would be good for a leisurely event on a hot day based upon other reviews. There are many fantastic things to do in HK but this is NOT one of them. The buses move at a glacial pace and even sitting in the front seat on the upper deck you can't see much above about 5 floors of a building. The only thing going for these buses is that it only costs 2.5 HK$ (33 cents US) to ride the damn things.

Well worth a ride -- "ding ding!". What a classic!! They remind you of the olden days on Hong Kong Island! They are so tall and narrow that they look as if they will fall over, but I'm assured they don't! Great view from the top level, cheap and no doubt where they will go, they're a must!! (I even bought a model one at the Airport as a souvenir !)

Ding Ding along HK Island. It was very easy to get on and off, it's a cool way to see the city of HK Island. You will find there are new and old trams. Older one you will not have Screen announcement on the next stop, I miss my stop. However it is so easy to get to opposite site and get on another tram to go back where you want to be. Both side give different names/code no for their stops, beware.

A classic must do. After a lot of walking sometimes all you want to do is sit down, well the trams are definitely worth a trip, old and original, but certainly an easy way to travel. You get to see the lights and the upstairs of many of the older buildings. We loved seeing the laundry hanging above the streets, which you seem to miss when walking around. For a couple of dollars the tram should be a must do.

A fun easy way to see lots of Hong Kong without moving a muscle!. The ding ding is a fun easy way to ride through Hong Kong island and see the sights. I would ride it in both directions so you don't miss a thing. Frequent and inexpensive you can't go wrong if you like to see city life and people watch.

A piece of Hong Kong history. These tramways are part of Hong Kong's history so riding one was absolutely on my to-do list. Hong Kong is the only Asian city to have a double decker tram and the ride is fun. The ticket is very cheap and you can pay by using the Octopus Card. If you don't have this card, remember to carry small bills because you won't receive any change!

Go for a ride. Loved this almost as much as the Star Ferry! They travel east-west through the city, providing such an easy way to transport. Fun, cheap, clean and historic--all rolled into one easy ride. Felt like riding the old-time cable car in SF, but no lines or touristy crowds. You just hop on and pay when you get off!Use the Octo card for ultra convenience.

Fun Ride. This is a very cheap form of public transportation and it is a great way to experience the city. It moves slowly so one can soak in the vibrant atmosphere of Hong Kong while still traveling efficiently. Also, being one of the oldest forms of public transport in the city, it is a good way to experience some history. There was no A/C on board so it was a bit hot but that did not keep us from enjoying our time.

Interesting Experience!. This is a nice try for me to take tramway to go sightseeing. you could find Ding Ding in the Central, and tramways have lots of stations, you should pay HKD less than 3 and you could get on this special bus.

I love the 'ting ting' bell sound!!! :-). It was the first time i travelled in a tram.. Though i travelled for a short distance, i thoroughly enjoyed it.. But was worried to have missed the peak tram.. :-(

Very hot...and take a long time to get anywhere..but a unique view of HK!. Get upstairs and wait for a seat...right at the front is a great spot for pics - there are some sights both outside and inside the trams!! At 2.20 a ride, I can't think of a cheaper way to get across the north of the island. You pay (the exact money) when you get off at the front by the driver. Beware in the height of summer that they have no air con....
Kids loved it. All our kids wanted to do the entire time we were in Hong Kong was to ride the ding ding! Great for getting around and entertaining for the kids!

Fun anticated way to see Hong Kong. When we were visiting as part of the local authority anniversary celebrations, the trams were free for one day. Hoy are we glad we took up the offer too, as it was a great way to see the Real Hong Kong, watching neighbourhoods melt into each other, a far more open view than the MTR allows. Try to get upstairs and to the front for the best views as you speed the way through the Hong Kong bustle. watch in awe as thousands of people cross the road and tramway in Causeway Bay! The cramped conditions hark back to older times but it's a very fun, cute and hot way to see the city. So good we went back on it even when the MTR was working and free travel wasn't available, for such a cheap cost it's a cool way to see the city. A MUST do!

Hong Kong style. The high lite in HK. Everybody must take a ride on it upper floor especially when it is roofless is something you can try once in your life but you will remember forever. HK is a crowdie city foul of details. So what can be better than a ride with 360 degrees visibility and 3 meters height.

Great legacy of HK. A must try flavor when in HK as this transport has been used in HK for umpteen years till today.It does not move fast so it gives you a very good view of HK busy roads, especially at nightWell, its not aircon, so better take be prepared to sweat if you visit HK in the summer.
Convenient and frequent. Trams are an easy way to get around on Hong Kong Island and you never have wait too long. Best thing is they only cost HK$2 for a single ride.

See the sights from a direct angle. The ding ding tram is a must do when in Hong Kong. For $2 you can travel the length of the line and see the city in a new light. Yes it is hot but sit upstairs near a window to catch the breeze and enjoy the bustling city from a more relaxed pace. There is always something to see whether it is on the street level or on the floors above which house hidden restaurants, shops , clinics and residences which unless you are aware of are hidden from tourists on the street. Kids would love it and it won't break the bank. You can use the octopus card.

Cheap thrill. I think of the HK tramways as the HK equivalent of San Francisco's cable cars. OK they don't go up and down steep hills (for that you have to take the tramway to The Peak) but they're a quaint part of local culture, not to mention a practical way to get around. And there's no better way to see the sights than from a window seat on the upper deck. And cheap -- the equivalent of 32 U.S. cents. What's not to like?
Historic public transit. Cheap way HK$2 to travel across the island of Hong Kong from East to West and vice versa. Go upstairs and seat in the front to get the best of the street views.
people watching. Cheap way to travel in HK island , and stay at upper floor over the window seat if you can .Nice way of watching local come n go ,nice way to spend a lazy mid morning !

thin and fun. Good way to see HK for a cheap price and it's a bit of living history. You can hop on and off to see anything that takes your fancy. Do try to sit upstairs and in the front for good views and to catch a breeze to cool you in the oppressive heat of summer.

Don't Miss it. It is an old tram but it is worth going. you will love to be part an ancient ride. cheap (2. HKD) and best but really hot as not closed.
Worth Try!!

Tram tour of HK. The tram may not be the most efficient way of getting around Hong Kong but it is certainly one of the cheapest! Agreeing with other reviewers, it is a great way to get an idea of the city & some of the main sights. Catch it from any point and stay on as far as you can ensuring that you try to get the front seat at the top- excellent photographic position. The first time we rode the tram, we alighted at North Point & found ourselves in a colourful, vibrant local fruit market where huge pomelos & oranges were piled high. A definite 'must' for all visitors.
Frequent and convenient. A good chance to see the city and daily life(upper seats).. There are many Ding Ding Cars so we always had seats to enjoy the view. No traffic jam for Ding Ding. Very clean.

A trip on the Hong Kong trams. For people " of a certain age " who can remember the double deck trams in UK cities, this is an absolute "must". Jump onto any tram, go upstairs, and at the first opportunity grab a seat at the front. I must have gone on at least 6 trams, and enjoyed every one of them. It is certainly the way to see Hong Kong, whilst bringing back memories.

Ding Ding fun ride. We decided to go on the tram just for the experience.We had no idea where to go so we boarded the tram & just went for the ride. It was very interesting seeing the sights of Hong Kong Island from the top deck. We just stayed on board & then returned back to our original point of boarding. We have trams in Melbourne Australia where I live but they are only one level & not as much fun & of course not such an interesting view. Highly recommended .

Enjoy the ride, like a setting from HK triad movie. It’s a “must-do” for me whenever I drop by HK, as I grew up watching their movies! Plus if you come by during cold season, it’s so refreshing with the breeze on face.

Worth a try when you are in Hong Kong. The tram is a good alternative to other public transports that you have taken.Gets pretty cramped up and crowded, but cheap and worth the try.We took the dingding to Causeway Bay and it was a pretty smooth ride!

Only worth it because it's so cheap. This was highly ranked on this website, so I made sure to get on a ding ding. My wife and I got on at about 10 am, but already it was warm and sunny. No A/C.We got seats on the very front of the upper level. Very slow ride, and after about 10 minutes, the novelty wears off and it feels like you're just sitting in traffic. Not something I want to do on vacation.Glad I did it, but not something I'd do again, even for $2 and change.
Great experience. Great way to tour. This is a nice experience to see parts of Hong Kong but not the only way. Kitsch and cute but not amazing for me. Worth to use if a lot of time.

A great (and cheap) way to get a sense of Hong Kong Island. Taking the tram from Sheung Wan or Central to Wan Chai or Discovery Bay is a great way to have a quick look at the most important urban areas in the island and will give you a clear idea of how the city looks like and how it's organised. Even if it's quaint and fun to ride, it's not exactly a tourist destination, so you will share the ride with mostly local people.Getting one of the seats at the front or back of the upper deck will get you tons of great photo opportunities too.
Hot Sunday trip. Good way to see the sights of the bustling city, we did a Sunday trip which was interesting. Be wary it can be quite hot on the trams

Best way to tour Hkg Island. Credit to the folks who kept this traditional tramway running after all this years. Despite the fact that it took up a big portion of the main road, it's maintenance and effort to upkeep it from operating. And its only Hkg$2.30 to have unlimited journey ride. Kudos!
Must do. If you need to travel in Hong Kong, this is the best option. It is cheap, fast and unforgetable, if you travel at the upper deck.
Slow but cheap. $1.30 a trip amazingly cheap. Very slow though. No aircon. Packed if travelling peak time. Most enjoyable scenic route. Highly recommended.

back to old time with the tram. its classic tram just remind us the oldest public transportation in some country, very original and still works very good. The good things is we just need to pay $ 2.3 for adult.

Ding Ding (Tramways) in Hong Kong. It was really an exceptional experience especially for city folks like us. Partial of the tram is wood, my kids have never seen anything like that before (so are we as adults). Its stops are all conveniently located at places that you want to visit (eg. Peak). Is cheap, clean and efficient. If you miss a stop, the next stop is also not too far apart. Fret not. Is a must try for free and easy travelers. It offers you the authentic flavour of Hong Kong.
Transportation. It is a historic transport still available in Hong Kong. Good that they still preserved it. There are many Ting Ting going to different area in Hong Kong Island.

Let the tram get through the jam!. The tram system is well worth a ride! It's only 2 and a bit Hong Kong dollars no matter how far you go (or you can use your octopus card). Just get on and go for a ride and see what you see - it's fairly basic but good fun.
Tram Bus. Loved the tram. Easy and cheap to use and you get a good view of the city. Can do the entire route and get off and then go back the same way.

Highly recommend to get around Hong Kong Island. You can use your Octopus card on the Ding Dings! These are a great way to get across Hong Kong Island, even if just to sit down and people watch for a while!

So-so ride on the tramway. Took the tram from Central back to my hotel in Causeway Bay. That day, they were waiving the fee for the tramways also (aside from the ferry). Had to wait for several trams to pass by as I wasn't so sure anymore which one to take. The stairways going up to the top level are a bit narrow and challenging now for me to take. Good thing I was able to find a seat. IT was hot and humid inside the tram but got to see a section of Hongkong which I haven't seen in a while from my elevated perch. Not too advisable for people with physical disabilities or seniors. All in all, a pleasant enough trip but would opt for the speedier mode of public transport.

Rattle Rattle. Anyone visiting Hong Kong must ride these trams which are now over a hundred years old it only costs Hk$2.30 for as far as you like. You enter by the back door turnstile and pay when leaving via the front door.
A good way to see Hong Kong. A really cheap and easy way to see Hong Kong. We went to the Terminal and then came back. About 1/2hr trip but worth it.

Easy and cheap way to see the city. Hong kong trams offers a great option for travellers to travel around the hustle bustle city of hong kong with a very minimal fee. Go for the second floor seat to have opportunity to take pictures and from my personal experience it is more breezy on the second floor. The tram stops at all the traim stop along its route and if you have only little time to spare , you may want to just take a trip for a few stops rather than the whole route as it takes quite a while from one end to the other.

Fun, but not essential. A fun ride, cheap, if you have time. It is generally crowded and cramped and there is not much of a view. Take a bus for a scenic ride instead, or the subway for quick transportation.
Slow trip to Causeway Bay. It had been years since I last caught a tram in Hing Kong, so I did when there in May 2014.Sorry to say I found the experience slow and tedious

Don't miss a ride on the trams. Check the route map at a tram stop, then hop on. You enter at the rear of the tram and pay when you exit at the front. Use an Octopus card or carry change - the fare is less than HK$3. Try to ride upstairs for a nice view. Riding the trams is a HK experience not to be missed.

Nostalgic Experience. The trams are the cheapest way of travelling on the Hong Kong Island. Admittedly, it can become quite crowded at times. Just choose your time to avoid the rush hours. The best time is to travel during the early hours.For the equivalent of 30 US cents, you can travel from the eastern end of the island to the western end - a trip that will take closer to 2 hours. The trams are clean and the newer version have stop announcements and displays. I always prefer to travel on the upper decks to catch the sight and fresh air.I have always wanted to check out if someone knows that the trams still uses sand to assist turning. Will appreciate an update.

Cheap Thrills. We rode the tram from one end to the other and back to Central one late afternoon during peak hour.....hot, muggy and fun at the top front where the windows are open on all sides. Loved the stops and starts, the glimpses of backstreets and mountains. We were too slow to get our change out and one driver hurried us away without paying; that was unintentional. We told one driver we were riding for fun and let us know in facial gestures that he thought we were nuts. Tram is good for those who need to read the street signs or see the landmark because the stops are not far from each other so if you miss one, it is not far to walk back.
Nice way to get around on HK Island. Enjoyable way to travel while on Hong kong Island. Covers most of the Island for one set fare, just make sure you have the correct change.

City tour on board a tram for HKD 2.20. Imagine taking the tram from end to end on Hong Kong isalnd at the incredible low cost not to mention a bird's eye view if you are seated upstairs. The tram runs very slowly so you can take in the sights, take photos & absorb the happenings on the street as you are driven through Hog Kong island.Getting a seat is difficult at rush hours so go off peak. It is not air-conditioned so do this only in cooler months unless you want a sauna during summer season.Best deal in HK

Reccomended to get your Bearings. Very very cheap, and a great way to see the city, especially from the 2nd floor, would not recommend it to travel long distances. Just watch it when it rains as the windows often do not get put up. Get on at the back of the bus and use your Octopus Card (2.5HKD for each trip, regardless of length) when you exit the tram at the drivers door.

Cheap way to see the city. If you're already too tired to walk but still wanted to see the city, I suggest taking the tram and take the longest route (Kennedy Town>Shau Kei Wan). For just HK$2.3/ride, you can have the view of the city -- just make sure that you sit at the top deck for undisruptive view and remember that you'll be asked to pay as you hop-off the tram and that means, you hop-on at the back and hop-off at the front.

Ding Ding!. Ok, it's just a tram but it's a cheap (HKD 2.3 - less than 20 pence) and fun way to see a small part of Hong Kong (only goes along the north part of HK Island with a handful of routes from west to east such as Kennedy Town, through Sheung Wan, Central, Wan Chai, Causeway Bay, Happy Valley as well as to North Point and various stops to the north east of the island.On a nice day and sitting on the top deck, it's a great way to while away some time. Note of caution, it doesn't have air conditioning so when it stops (and there are many stops), it can become very hot.Btw, very cramped so not a good idea if you have a push chair or large luggage as you have to pass a very narrow turnstile to board.

Super Cool 2 Floor Tram. Only 2.30 per adult (Bring exact change). More than the transportation itself, it is the experience of riding a very old Wood Tram.... Just beautiful... Use it either for a longer trip or just a couple of blocks to have the experience.

Excellent for those not too keen to walk. It is open so you can take pictures. Adult is HKD 2.30 only at any stops. I was very tired from walking in the city in the june heat so hopping on the tram to go to causeway bay was nice. Great way to see the city.

All aboard !!!. The trams are a great and cheap way to get about, but are obviously limited due to being on tracks, but try them they are great.buy an OCTOPUS card, for travel on ALL forms of transport in Hong Kong, AND if you have any credit left when it's time to leave, they give you a refund for your outstanding balance, what more could you ask !!! Ding Ding and off we go !!!
Funky. Pretty cool way to get around HK. Being from Melbourne we have trams here but they are different in HK. Mostly double-decker trams and allows commuters to navigate the city with ease

Convenient with view. This is a very convenient way of transport for HKD2.30 per trip. You can see the shops along the route & get on & off the route. It also stops at all the MTR Stns along the route. We just love it despite the fatc that the trams are not air-conditioned, but it's cool & breezy even on the hot days in June.

Don't miss a wonderful ride. It is a wonderful ride in Hong Kong Island only (perhaps not too much city has it now) if you take the tram for HK$2.3 (adult and 12-year child as well as senior citizen for $1) by spending one more hour on the upper stair. The eastbound route starts from (1) Kennedy Town to North Point and (2) Western Market to Shau Ki Wan; for the westbound one is from North Point to Whitty Street. If you do not want to go to Catholic graveyard and horse racing course, just skip your way to Happy Valley.The whole journey takes you from Sheung Wan (dried seafood products, Cat Street), Central (Hong Kong Bank head office, Lan Kwai Fong, Mandarin Hotel, Statue Square, Old Supreme Court, Star Ferry etc), Admiralty (New Legco chamber, Tai Koo Plaza shopping malls), Wanchai (Central Plaza, ferry to Tsim Sha Tsui), Causeway Bay (Sogo Department Store, Victoria Park) , North Point (Chun Yeung Street market, tram depot), Quarry Bay (Tai Koo Shing), and finally the last stop at Shaukiwan.If you follow the tram track, you won't get lost, just like from Tsim Sha Tsui to Mongkok by walking along Nathan Road in Kowloon.Bear in mind to buy an Octopus card ($100 basic fare with $50 for deposit, you can get it at any MTR station), I think there is no need for you to buy a tourist card unless you want to keep it as a souvenir. Either paying tender fare (on tram, bus, ferry, peak tram and even train etc) or buying quick food (MacDoanald) as well as buying snacks at 7-Eleven, Circle K, Vingo etc., this value-added card not only save your time, but also it is extremely easy for you to get your refund back at any MTR station before your departure.

the Peak. Wonderful experience. Go early to avoid the queue.Take a taxi up the Peak, catch the tram back...an easy walk ( about an hour) around the Peak, excellent view of the harbour etc on a good weather day....Visit the Botanical Garden at the foot of the Peak, you wouldn't have thought Hong Kong can be that green...a good playground for the kids too....l

Slow but fun and cheap. These run the length of the island and are only 3.5 HKD for an adult for the whole journey, the windows are always wide open when its not raining so its a great way of photographing HK from the upper deck and getting a good look at HK.

they have a FREE RIDE DAY. lovely way to experience the old times! though in the day it can be hard to bear the NON-AC trams over the ACon'd MTR. Our 6 years old son enjoyed alot, the views at evening market and SOGO area in causeway were overwhelming. And Yes what a lovely gesture, we also saw a Free Ride Day, which means hop-on/off anytime on any Tram for free... no charges for that day

Cheap and a must try!. I used the tram a lot to get around from Wan Chai. It is much cheaper than the metro and you can use your Oyster card on it. All caution is that it takes time and most of the drivers do not speak English so it's good if you know where you are going.

Cheap & Fun. It's a wonderfully cheap way of travelling around Hong Kong Island from West to East and vice versa, while seeing most of Hong Kong. $2.30hk/ ~$0.3cdn (regardless of the distance you travel) And as soon as you see something that catches your eye, you can just hop off the electric tram/ "ding ding". The tram maps at the tram stations are incredibly easy to comprehend since they're all colour coded. Just make sure you check whether the tram is headed East/ West. It's a fun mode of transportation for sight seeing in the afternoon. However, the night view on the tram(mostly on the West side) is also quite nice with the various neon lights. The only time I wouldn't really want to be on a tram is when it's raining and during rush hours.

A must adventure. Buy an Oyster card on arrival at the MTR station and you can use this for all forms of transport. You enter the trams from the back door and pay when you exit via the front door. Head upstairs for the best view. The stations are all numbered so easier to remember. We got on at Causeway Bay and headed to the end of the line East and were delighted to be dropped in old town with an amazing local market. This is a real eye opener on how meat shopping is done here. The area was a world apart from the glitz and glam of the business district. It's clean and safe a the mandatory McDonlads at the end of the line for your toilet stop should you require one. One of my favourite travel tips is to take a photo of the timetable with your smart phone and that way you always have a copy to carry around. We then head edge East went as to the end of that line and back to the middle level escalators which are a must.

Low cost and enjoyable. The HK trams rattle along now as they have done for so many years. Some of the newer or refurbished ones have plastic seats, but there are still some original wooden seat trams. Sit upstairs and enjoy the slow clanking trip across the the north of HK Island.Just be aware that you pay when you get off the trams. You can use the MTR (underground) stored value Oyster cards, but if you don't have these, then you will ned to have enough change in coins to pay on exit.

A great way to view the city. We reached HK early in the morning and therefore decided to take the Tram to a stop near the bottom of the peak. It was very cheap (HKD 2.60) but very crowded. We managed to get a seat, which is a must if you want to enjoy the scenery of the Hong Kong streets. I even took some pictures when the Tram stopped at the stops. It was an enjoyable moment not to be missed.

Retro. This was a really fun and unique way to travel along Hong Kong Island to experience the bustling and fascinating streets. Really cheap (you need correct change or pay over) and avoids traffic. Retro both inside and out. A gem on my visit to HK. For travelling further afield I recommend the subway, which is very efficient, clean and signs/announcements in English also.

Great way to see the city. A great way to see the city at bargain prices. Pay on leaving the tram with either cash (no change) or with an Octopus card which can be purchased at any MTR station. Not only a reliable form of transport but also a real slice of history.

On time everytime. What a wonderful way to travel It can get a little cramped at peak times but thats the fun but you will never be late these guys (as like all public transport in HK) is spot on time. We used it a couple of time to go to the races and we were never held up and was a very short walk to the track. and cheap! bonus! Give it a shot if you like Melbourne trams you have to jump on a Ding Ding

Frequent but crowded. These trams run frequently and are an excellent alternative if you want to view the streets, but be aware, they become very crowded. You can use your Octopus card and swipe off at the end. It is very cheap at HK$2.30
CHEAP WAY TO GET AROUND. The ding dings are are fantastic way to get around the island and to avoid the heat! Simply hop on and then ;ay as you leave- you need coins

Great way to see Hong Kong Island. It's really one of the easiest and laziest ways to travel along HK Island while being able to see outside. There are no windows, so be prepared for weather/temperature.

Cheapest way to get around on Hong Kong island. We are surprised that this tramway is still operating in excellent condition. Take the top level to enjoy the view of busy roads and traffic of Hong Kong. Using the Cash Card is very convenient. Although the section around Central can be crowded, however Hong Kong is a busy city and this is a great way to experience it.
Worth Doing. Always worth experiencing! We managed to hitch a ride on what was a free fare day. Not the most comfortable ride but a great experience.

Fantastic way to tour Hong Kong. We chose to use the Ding Ding tramways on a rainy day. We sat on the top floor at the back having great views while the tramway was passing through different part of the city. We climed ont a random one and ended up going through a market selling meats, vegies and lots of other colourful items. We also had great views of hyndres of umbrellas below our viewing spot. Fantastic value for money.

Antique + Modern City. Busy roads across the very modernized Hong Kong Islands. Ding Ding, a double decker tram just fits in well among them and the skyscrapers. Subway is everywhere and ding ding is pretty slow but what is special about the tram itself is the riding experience. Give it a try when you are in HK and feel like a time traveler.

A little piece of history. A brilliant way to get around Hong Kong Island. Not as speedy as the MTR however the charm that comes with riding these double decker trams that first ran in 1912 far outweighs the modern alternative. Do yourself a favour and spend the HK$2 to take a ride on the ding ding!

good old charm with a spectacular view. Tram will take you to an almost vertical route to the peak for a spectacular view of the harbour and the city. Tram is always a old charm. well maintained. It will take you to madam tussaid museum and the souvenir shop.

One of the best ways to know about my hometown!. This is probably one of the best ways to know about my hometown!
As a local Hong Konger, I really love sitting on the tram, wandering around the northern part of Hong Kong Island.

Brilliant trip back in time. Regular service, busy with locals and easy too use if you purchase an octopus card, (travel card) you can use on all transport and in 7/11 stores too buy coke ,water etc, we travelled from soho too kennedy town price for about 85p .bargain and a great experience

Nice ride to take in city. The Hong Kong tramways on Hong Kong island are nice for a one time ride along the busting part of the island. Certainly breeze, sitting on the top deck offer a nice views of city streets as you scoot along. The trams are certainly not a smooth ride, and jerk about quite a bit on the tracks and stop frequently. We rode from North Point down to Sogo department store and it took about 20-30 minutes. Fare is cheap at HKD2.3 no matter where you ride.

An interesting way to see Hong Kong Island. Firstly, don't use this if you actually want to get somewhere. It stops very often and is an incredibly slow method of transport. Get the MTR if you want to get around and visit places. That said, this is a good way to see Hong Kong city. From a seat on the top deck you get a good vantage point into the hustle and bustle of this busy city. It may be slow but the atmosphere and insight are well worth the small fee. We got an Octopus card. $50 deposit and $100 credit, the deposit and unused credit are refunded when you hand it back in. Using the card has two benefits, slightly reduced fares and instant payments. It can be used for the tram, MTR, peak tram, Star Ferry and in many small convenience shops and cafes. Very handy!

Ding-ding Trams. The Hong Kong tram lines run east-west-east on the northern corridor of Hong Kong Island and there are presently163 fully-operational double-decker trams serving the 13-km track with numerous stops in between. The tram system here is recognized as the largest in the world with the biggest fleet of double-decker trams and is owned by Hong Kong Tramways Limited. The tram is an environment-friendly, convenient and the cheapest mode of transport in Hong Kong.Many people use the tram (known as “Ding-ding” to the locals) and one arrives every couple of minutes at every stop and this would ensure people movement is not disrupted for long periods. The trams come in different ages and looks, some older ones and some newer ones which are brightly-painted and carrying advertisements to boost revenue. To get a better view choose a window seat on the upper deck. No matter how far you travel the fare is the same at HKD2.30 per adult and unique to this tram service, you only pay into the box or touch the device with your Octopus pass when exiting the tram.For the experience, it is a must-do when visiting Hong Kong Island.

Classic favorite. Cheap way to see the bright lights of HK. Cost the same whether it's one stop or 10 stops. If have time, just hop on to one and go all the way to the end of the station. That's how I ended up finding some nice neighbourhood wf good food where I normally might not have visited.
Interesting and economical way to tour. We took the ding ding early in the morning. Interesting that this is still the way folks travel around Hong Kong island.

Special experience. We tried Ding Ding by June 2014. I had been to Hong Kong few times but never get the chance to take Ding Ding. This was our first time experience. We took a short journey by Ding Ding car to Kwan Kee clay pot rice. Ding Ding get different color and decoration. This is a refreshing experience to me.

The cheapest transport on Central Island. Only 2,30 HKD for any ride on the trams. Lines run along the whole Central Island crossing it horizontally. Loved the double deck and the paying method (just board the tram, pay at the exit!)

Great way to get around above ground. With an Octopus card, this is a great way to get around. They pass regularly but you do need to know which one goes where. Arm yourself with a map and don't be afraid to ask.

Great way to get around this busy city. The tram and bus service in HK is so easy and convenient. Get and Octopus card from any MRT station. It works for trams, buses, trains and ferries. Buses & trams don't give change, so a card will save you lots.
Great fun. The Ding ding in Hong Kong is a great fun way to travel in certain areas of the city. The fare is very reasonable and they travel along the track constantly so there is never a long wait.

Best if you want to see real life of HK yourself!. Trams are traditional HK transport, signifying the colonial life style in HK. Though it obviously does not fit the horrifying pace of HK, it exists with people's tolerance. The trams travel from east to west of the HK Island (not in New Territories nor Kowloon) along the main roads. So you can see the old parts of HK in Sheung Wan, the business and financial areas like Central or Admiralty, the more residential areas like North Point, the shopping paradise like Causeway Bay. Mind you do travel by tram in winter or autumn, i.e. from October to March. You will melt if you take this non-air-conditioned means of transport in summer time.

The best transportation!. Although it's quite hot and there's no aircon, it's just HK$2 and you can go a long way with this tram. It's so far the best transportation (the cheapest) I've came across. If you haven't tried it, don't say you've been to HK.

One of the best ways to travel in Hongkong. We were lucky to be present in Hongkong when there was 'Ride the Tram' promotion going on with Free Rides. Even if its not a free ride, in Hongkong, trams are one of the best, cheap and eco- friendly way to travel in Hongkong.

Good way to enjoy HK Island with valuable price. The tram works on the HK Island only. It covers almost the whole northern part of the island, from CBD to old district.It is slow but this makes it becomes the best way to feel the HK mood and culture.

Worth a ride. We rode this old but still very appealing tramcar for almost 45 minutes and loved everybit of the ride.You pass through the major artery in the heart of Hongkong and enjoy the wonderful views of buildings and luxurybrand stores all along the way.Try to occupy front seats on upper floor to have better views.A different way to see more in less time.

Bargain tour. I still enjoy riding the trams after 15 years of being in Hong Kong. Spent an hour riding one of the trams to the end of the line and then catch the same car back. Work your way to the front of the car as people get off. Great way to see some of Hong Kong and very very.

These are a really fun way to get around. these tram run all round the island you can hop on and off as you require you pay as you leave so no tickets are needed they do get busy at peak times but they come really quickly so if one is packed just wait and another will soon come along. i highly recommend using these to get round or just to see the area.

Charming Tram Rides Bring Hong Kong Alive.... With a rich history of over a 100 years, the existing tram line used to align with Hong Kong's waterfront. You are left imagining just how much land has since been reclaimed! For HK$ 2.30 (US$0.40) it's an inexpensive way to explore the old and the new in Hong Kong. A 20/30 minute ride from Central/Wanchai to Kennedy Town will provide you with unrivalled sights taking you from a bustling citadel of capitalism, past a hectic dried seafood street market and finally becalmed in a quaint terminus at a local residential district which overlooks Victoria harbour. Exit and grab a quick bite at a local cafe or cha-tan-teng. Of course, if you're still exhorting for more, just take the next ride back out...towards Saukeiwan or Happy Valley.
Ding Dong. Can be quite hot, no air con just the windows that open and then it rains! Great service...remember to get on the back and off at the front

Best HKD2.3 you will ever spend. This is a great way to experience the busy central parts of Hong Kong. You can spend an hour travelling slowly making your way along some of the busiest parts of Hong Kong, without having to worry about traffic, pedentrians and the like. Start at Central and do a round trip past Happy Valley, or start from Central and continue all the way past North Point. Take the MTR back if you want to return faster.

Best way to really see Hong Kong. A nice slow ride on the top of a tram is a great way to see real Hong Kong life. Get a seat in the front so you can get a nice breeze through the windows, and even on a hot day they can be fun. Get an octopus card! Even if you're only staying for a while, it will make life MUCH more convenient and makes for a good souvenir. With that, each tram trip is about 2.3HKD, so you can get on and off all you like without feeling the pinch. Always go for the top floor, the views and the air are much better up there, and don't be in a hurry as the tram is NOT a speedy mode of travel!Once you get where you're going, the tram roughly follows the island line of the MTR, so you can get a ride back on the subway.

Great way to get your bearings. I've been to Hong Kong for business and pleasure more than I can count so I know the city pretty well. I traveled with a friend visiting for the first time so I wanted him to see the different facets of this city that I love so much. We hopped on the tram from Central and took it all the way to both ends. Perfect way to catch up on the gossip and periodically marvel at the site that we see along the way. It took us over an hour and by then we are fully updated with each others lives and have seen the high contrast of HK that most tourist don't get to see. It's also cheaper than a Starbucks coffee. HK is not short on things that will marvel you. Nightife, shopping and just soaking up the vibe in SOHO/LKF you'd feel the earth really move in HK. But there's other parts of HK that's almost idyllic and we felt that like saw that by taking the tram.If you have time to spare and want something away from the usual trifecta of eating, drinking and shopping - take the tram. have a cup of cuppa on random stops. watch the world go super fast and relatively slow just a few stations away from Central. On another occasion - we have taken the tram to party. Literally booked the entire carriage and partied all night long. So whatever you fancy - take the tram!!!
noisy & bumpy. A must do! being shaken at every turn, climbing up the high-angle stairs, hearing the bell ring! what a ride!

Ding Ding, you can't get it from any parts of the world. I stayed in Hong Kong for a long time. Ding Ding is always HongKongese's favour transportation. Cheap and easy to access. Get the tram and stay upper deck, preferablily in the front seat. Prepare your camera and watch how interesting of Hong Kong. Cheap and cheerful tour activities. Absoule 6 Stars tour.

slow down. when i studied in the university, my friends and i rent an apartment near the campus. the building is situated near the tram road and every morning, i was either waken up by my roommate's alarm clock or the 'ding ding' sound from the tram. at late night when i was studying, i could hear the sound from the tram. it became part of my u-life, very familiar to it. i loved to take the tram to campus from Sheung Wan, when i was not in hurry. not only because of its price, but also the pace. i could look at the daily life of the shop keepers and people around, going to work, getting home or shopping along the streets. one time i took the tram from Central to Shau Kei Wan at night time. it was really nice to look at the buildings along the tram road, the traffic and people. if going with friends, it will give you a very good atmosphere to chat and relax. there are commerical buildings in Central, big shopping malls in Causeway Bays and some old buildings in Wan Chai and farther away, some older buildings in Shau Kei Wan. compare the life and pace of people in Central and the community in Shau kei wan, big contrast and very interesting. i started to know more about it only when i studied in university and up to today, i still like it very much.

Great experience. First time ride the Ding Ding it is so excited. I took it at night and along the way you can see the colorful of the lights from the shops at both sides. It is fun when you hear ding ding sounds at the stops.It is fast to go anywhere cause you do not need to walk so far to reach the destination compare to MTR. It is a must try transport when you at Hong Kong.

Increasingly out of sync. It is charming, antiquated and lumbering. It winds through some of Hong Kong's oldest districts. It is uncomfortable and sweltering during summer. But it is like a zoo; it does not fit into its transformed surroundings, like caged animals. There are echos from the past along the way but for the most part, it is out of place in 21st century Hong Kong. It has little of the charms of the trams of Lisbon, for example.
Trams. Great to travel on. Only cost 2.30 HK$ Must have exact change. Best to know the stops you want to get off at. Best way to navigate Central HK.

must visit. must see in hongkong attractions
it is better to buy the combo ticket and u can avail extra 10% discount when u buy other attractions like ocean park

A great step back in time.... The trams can be found in the most crowded areas of Hong Kong. Their dinging sounds and constant bumps as it rumbles along its track all play host to a slow and captivating tram ride across Hong Kong. They are cheap and hardly any traffic. Definitely worth trying out!

Superb way to sightsee and move around. At 2.30HKD (pay on exit flat fee) the ride is the perfect, relaxed way of getting around HK. Sitting up top you get great views. Often it is quicker then the MTR and without detracting fwm the MTR experience it has something extra to it.

A must for any tourist!. A ride along the tramways is a must for anyone visiting Hong Kong. Get yourself a seat upstairs, either right in the front or at the back. Ideally join the tram somewhere like Western Market and sit on it all the way to Causeway Bay and Times Square. You get a great view of all the high-rise buildings along the way, and a fantastic view of life on the streets below. Also a great way to take photos of the surrounding scenery. And at around HK$2 for the whole ride - it is a true bargain!

Real Sightseeing. Absolutely the best way to sightsee Hong Kong Island for pennies. Just jump on one of these historical trams day or night and enjoy the journey to the end of the line; then simply catch one back again. You can't get lost and all of human life is there outside the window.
Part of the experience of HK. You haven't been to Hong Kong if you haven't taken a tram. A cheap and fun way to travel. Get on the top deck and view the city scape.

Don't Miss!. From Central or Admiralty areas, catch the North Point tram heading east and enjoy a great view of the wet market at North Point when the tram detours from the main line to head through the market street. Hop off at the next stop and stroll through the market, stopping at the stalls that caught your attention from the tram. Use your spare HK coins for the HK$2.30 fare or use the handy Octopus card.

Must try transportation when having tour in Hong Kong. Really a must try transportation when touring around Hong Kong, if time permits try the route from Causeway Bay - Kennedy Town which you can get through from shopping district - Causeway Bay, Business Areas - Central then do Western Market...

Great way to get around the city. The tramway provide very reliable mode of traffic-free transportation while allowing you to view the city. This will allow you to have a feel of the past while exploring the modern surrounding. The seat was not extremely comfortable especially the one at the bottom. But I still enjoyed riding in the tram.
great ride. well worth a trip on tram very cheap and colourful.tram travels quite slow giving you loads of time to take in the sights.

Good way to see the streets. The tram is a good way to see the island. Get a front seat on the top deck and you get a great view and easy unobstructed photos. It’s quite easy to get one of the two front seats. Wait for a relatively empty tram and go straight there, or work your way to them. It takes about two hours to travel from end to the other. At the west end of the track, you may find yourself on a tram that terminates on the street in which case cross the road and get another one back. Or you may, if you’re not careful, find yourself on an empty tram and in the depot with driver shouting upstairs telling you to get off, as happened to me once. There’s not a huge amount of interest to see at the far west end so you won’t miss much by not going all the way. The east end is easy, as the trams terminate on a small loop. There’s a McDonalds there for some refreshment, and a small street market to look round. The fare from end to end is the same as for any short journey – maybe $2HK – it’s such a small amount I never actually took notice.
Cheap way to see sights. Costs a few dollars to see the sights. Travelled from Admiralty to Kennedy terminus and back, Hoped off and had a stroll around the area

Nice way to tour the city without tiring yourself. The trams do not travel very fast giving you a chance to absorb all the sights and sounds of the bustling city area. Do not that they are non air-conditioned. Best of all, all trips are only HK$2.30 regardless of distance so you got a cheap and tireless way to explore Hong Kong.

Ding Dong Ding. When in Hong Kong for a vist, you have to have a trip on the old Trams. Admittedly not very comfortable on those that do not have much padding on the rear end ! But we spent 1 hour from Lei Yue Mun Fort ( Coastal Defence Museum ) to Central . What great fun it was, you see so much more than in a taxi or bus. Just for once try it out and have a laugh.

Ding-Ding . . . Rattle-Rattle . . .. Any adult reminisces of railway sets and similar while travelling this antiquated cheap means of viewing Hong Kong at street level amongst the hustle & bustle with the locals, rather than the sterile bubble of a tour coach operator. Some may travel awhile for the experience, others may travel from end-to-end, and back again to appease the inner child in all of us.

Fun and fun. Its not the most comfortable travel but you must use the trams to experience the past in the present. There is a few minute wait between trams and its very cheap to travel with. Sit upstairs be best views.

Take your time. First a caution - board a tram when you are not in a hurry to experience this, else you will only be looking at your watch.One of the ways to experience this is to go end to end on a Hong Kong Tram ways & also experience the transition in people & experience as to move from Central to Causeway and beyond. Moving from the busy business district into where most of the expats live to where the locals reside. The transition at times is distinct.Board the upper deck & try to grab the first seat if you can to get uninterrupted views of things that lie ahead.Avoid the rains or the journey could last forever because of the slow pace & the traffic.

Great experience. The tram are in their "juice", made of wood, victorian style. A great way to visit Hong Kong and enjoy the multiple places. At night it is even more impressive has you can get a view of all those signs and lights that embrase the sky of HK.

Okay for short rides, but slow. These are okay if you want to go a short distance and are cheap at HK$2.30. But they are slow with regular stops and traffic jams. Also they aren't air conditioned so on hot days it is better taking the subway if you want to go a few stops.

MUST try in Hong Kong. In this crowded and noisy city, you have to try this slow motion transportation means in Hong Kong island. It runs from western side to eastern end of Hong Kong Island but just cost HKD2.3 for one way! Suggest go to upper floor and open the window. and sit down Then enjoy the street view of this beautiful and unique city. Definitely a wonderful experience.

Great way to view the suburbs of Hong Kong Island. Enjoyed our trips on the trams during our week long holiday staying in Wan Chai - good views from the upper level & very cheap - reminded us of our past when there were trams in most capital cities here in Australia.
Old fashioned trams. The tram travels through the heart of Hong Kong Central giving you a view of the main streets. They are used by locals and tourists and are inexpensive to use.
The Trams. So cheap - about 20p for the full ride. Go from one end to the other and just watch the world pass you by. You pay when you get off, have some coins on you.

Gets The Job Done. Public transportation in HK is amazing. So many options, much history. Amaze. I didn't hear these trams ding-ding, but this was located a block from my hotel so was my go-to for everything. Riding at the top is an adventure. It's hot, but the windows open. And they park about an inch away from each other - I was trying to go for the high-five, but the other trains parties were not having it.
New experience. Just several cities in the world have tram in the city. So new experience for my whole family to feel it. We also can enjoy the city tour with this cheap fare transport

Cheap and cheerful. A fun way to travel on the Island. Great opportunity to see the significant buildings along this route. Not a squick as the mtr, but a fun way to rattle along. And very cheap, as long as your not too tall.

Morning tram ride. This is a great way to spend a morning, It costs $2 Hong Kong to ride the tram for as long as you like. Jump on and off to visit the local markets, buy some bargains, which are usually cheaper then any of the well known ones and you can find some fantastic street food there too.

Great Ride. Its a great experience watching the tram move at its pace from the first floor deck. The best place to take a tram is near the central station and move east. It would cross at its pace the major landmark buildings of Hong Kong like the Bank of China Tower, The HSBC head office and many more!

A cheap form of transport. If you want to get around on the island then a Ding Ding is the way to go. Get on an older tram and stand at the back. Look for the indentation on the floor and 'accidently' step on it... "ding ding" You get the idea. This form of transport is cheaper than the trains and gives you an above ground view. Most are spartan without airconditioning, so be warned. It's worth a try though. For best results avoid Saturdays and Sundays (the maids day off) because they all love this mode of transport, especially in the mornings and in the evenings.

Worth a little ride for the novelty. You don't find double decker trams anywhere else (as far as I am aware) and we found it quite fun to sit on the top deck and ride the ram from one end of the line to the other and just take in the architecture around us.

Great trams. I love going up there, although it is a bit slow.
Quite an experience! If possible take a tram up the Peak to get a spectacular view of the city.
Do not be turned off by the slowness of the tram. It moves along the busiest part of the city.
Back to the past. One of the best thing in HK - funny adventure, antique added to the modernity of the city. You should go to 1'st floor to watch people above. Enjoy the low fee :)

Good fun. Fast & efficient, crowded & busy. Get on at the back, pay with the octopus card at the front as you get off. You'll need to make it clear you want to get off & be determined to get on, there seems to be no maximum load!
Fun and cheap. A fun and faster way of getting along the front of central. I believe these were shipped over from London years ago. Worth trying though.

Fun way to see the city. I have always loved trams whether in Europe or Hong Kong, except in Hong Kong they are double decker, which only enhances the enjoyment. It is a great way to see the city especially sitting upstairs and in the front. They generally criss cross the island side of Hong Kong, and you can get on and off as you would a local bus route. Get on in the back of the tram, and leave by the front where you also pay for your fare. If you have an octopus card. Just swipe it over the device and exit. Cost for a full length ride is about 2.30 HK$. They get priority on the road, but must also stop at signals but the slow movement allows for picture taking or maybe even a video. No visit to Hong Kong would be complete without a ride on the double decker trams.
Easy to use. I wanted to try the Honk Kong tramways which was easy to use and very good value for the money. I sat in front and it is bit slow but nice way to see the city.

wonderful view. We went there around sunset and the line was fine it took us 5 mins to get the ticket and 10 mins wait to ride the tram. Upon arrival you can either go straight up to the overview of HK city. The view was unbelievable.

Inexpensive way to see the city. As others have said this is an inexpensive, yet interesting way to get a feel for the city. The front seats are great. It is slow moving, but not a waste of time if you have an hour or so to kill. Charming is a good word to use. Younger kids might be bored.
Such an experience. Riding on the trams was just another of the fantastic transport methods available in Hong KongThe trams are always crowded, but we always managed to find a seat
cool man. reminded me a little of SF... so much to see if you have a little extra time for your journey... super cheap at only 2.3 hkd..

Sight seeing for sore feet. The Hong Kong tramways are an easy way to see Hong Kong city and get your bearings. The trams arrive at regular intervals, go up the stairs and find a seat on the top deck. Locals use the trams too so even if you start off standing it won't be long before you can get a seat. The trams trundle slowly along the main streets, allowing plenty of time to gawp at the tall buildings that surround you on all sides. You can see the locals haggling for fish with much shouting and amusement, or pushing their wooden cart across the road in front of buses, cars, trucks, bicycles and people. It is cheap, I think you just pay when you get off, but HKD2.50 or so. The driver doesn't take much notice but I made up for my short-payment by overpaying another time, honestly. I was so busy looking around I didn't see the fare notice, or perhaps it is not displayed on every tram? Seriously recommended as a way of getting to grips with the scale of downtown HK, where things are, how much distance you can reasonably cover. Much less frightening than trying to cross the main road.

A unique Charm to a former colony. @ 3.20 to where ever you wanna go, the tram system is a fantastic way to get to know Hong Kong island and will take you the places where the Chinese people live and give you a whole new look on the city.Its a charm to experience this mode of transport.

Grab The Front Seats!!. As many have said, this is a cheap, fun way to see many parts of HK you probably wouldn't otherwise. The fare is $3.20 (about 25p) and you bet fabulous value for money.The front seats upstairs allow you great views and it's very interesting to watch life unfold around you. You do need the right change but we bought an Octopus card to use and got a refund for the underspend later.You can pull the windows down and enjoy the sun too, weather permitting. Good fun!!

Fun way to see HK island.. Quirky cable cars, very frequent. Observing streets and sights along the way allows you to choose when to get off en route back. Old style, slow moving. Very cheap. Get on at back, pay at front when disembarking. No change given. Great experience.

Character ride through city. Riding this tram crowded as it is, is a must for visitors. Working your way through the tram to exit the doorway is a feat in itself. A bargain ride for just over 2 dollars HK
Incredible way to move.... What a smart public transportation system, and a great way to advertisement too.I think is very unique and "vintage" at the same time and part of the charm of the city.

Make sure have correct change!. When our Octopus cards didn't work, the driver grunted and grumpily pointed to the coin dispenser, we were the last two off so not holding anyone up.The fare is HK$2.30 and once you put it in the slot, that's it.The route we travelled looked quite uninspiring but on a rainy day, it filled in plenty of time.
nice way to get around. take the upper deck if you can. beware that the stairs are a little tight and steep. enjoy the interesting transportation at a low cost
get on one. a slow bumpy ride around town but a must if your here, mega cheap but not if your in a rush to get some place.

cheapest transport in town (and good for a look around). at only 2.30 HKG per person (exact change only) this was by far the cheapest (and likely the slowest) way to get around. the first time we used it to do a small tour of hong kong island and for that, from the top deck, it was quite good and helped us to find our bearings a bit.then, after this, we used it a couple times to get from place to place when it was logistically convenient.you should give it a try at least once. just hop on in the back and get out (and pay) in the front.

My favorite means of transporation on Hong Kong island. For only $2.30 HKD, you can circle around most part of HK island at a leisurely pace. With the newer trams, they now have display showing you the route and next few stops - which would be handy if you know the street you are looking to get off.Since the Tram has its own rail section on the road, there are times when you can get to places faster than getting on a bus during traffic jam. If you have an hour or two, you would get a close up and personal view of Hong Kong for next to nothing! If you are in Hong Kong, I would definitely recommend getting on the Tram.Tips: The top offers great views, however, for those that are taller than say 5'10" watch out for hitting your head on the ceiling. It isn't build for very tall people if you happen to be standing. :)
Great. What a lovely trip, overlooking the beautiful Hong Kong buildings while going up. Scenery just amazing!

Fun Ride!. For a flat fare of HK$2.30 the double decker tram that runs on Hong Kong Island is great fun. We sat up the top and enjoyed the view of the bustling city. The best way to pay is using the Octopus Travel Card. Pay at the end of your journey. A must do!
Must do!!!!!. I love Ding Ding a lot. Its 2.8HK(if im not wrong) per way, and you can see a lot of thing about Hong Kong. The car is so tiny so cute, i just love it so much.

Must ride the top level at least once!. Cheap and a great way to see Hong Kong Island (east to west) from a different angle. Inside can be very crowded, narrow and slow but it is some good old fashioned fun and the best photo opportunity. Best to have an octopus card though

As per my son's request, ride the "Ding Ding". I have taken the Ding Ding numerous time, yet it is always an enjoyable journey each time I take it. This time, my son insisted on the "Ding Ding" and as he embarked he immediatlely went upstairs and loved the tour. It is a great way to discover "Hong Kong" from Central to North point and more if you want. Not to be missed when travelling to that great and exciting city.
See HK in action. Take the tram and experience a bit of the local life they travel slow enough to see places you may want to explore further and they are delightful double deckers!

Best way to see Hong Kong.. These are a step back in time. Sure there are air conditioned busses and trains to get you around but the ding dings offer a journey back in time - they transport you back to another era in Hong Kong. The elevated view gives you a look at life above street level in all of it's gritty reality. The ride is authentically rattley and firm, the seats pretty hard but it is an intoxicating mix along with the sights, sounds and smells of the journey.We loved our ding ding experience - amazingly cheap and great fun.
Great Way to travel on Hong Kong Island. Good way to take a quick tour up the Main Street of. Hong Kong island good photo opportunity , not many old trams left in the world that work these day
Great way to see Downtown HK. Yes, original mode of public transport for so many years. Slows you down to watch hectic HK life from above.

Authenticity. It's of course not the most comfortable ride, and the standing room or sitting room is very limited and there's no AC and the ride is noisy, but this is one of the oldest and cheapest form of traveling in HK, and you gotta try it and sightsee while on route.

Fun!!. It's so much fun just crossing the hustle and bustle of town in these old trams. HK loves new and shiny, but happily they leave these trams as they are. Running every two minutes and very cheap.

Octopus card makes this easy. Cheap mode of transportation and probably runs at the perfect speed for tourists who just want to sit at the upper level and take in Hong Kong. With an Octopus card you also don't have to worry about having change or paying in cash. Be warned that the trams can get very crowded with limited seating so if you're insistent on finding a seat or enjoying the sites of HK you may have a go awhile on the tram until someone vacates his/her seat.

HK tramway. this tramway experience is always one of a kind. I took double-deck bus in London, in Brussel and in NYC, but only here in HK, you would be reminded of the old days still haunting this modern and prosperous city.

Not much ding, but a buzz nevertheless. We caught the tram on Easter Monday, which was perfect because there was no traffic & few people so we felt quite alone. We wanted lots of ding dinging, but on the trip to Kennedy Town there was no dinging at all. However we had the best seat, which is at the front of the tram on the top level, from where we took some great photos of true Hong Kong. Every tourist should take a trip on this tram, just to experience the sights sounds & smells of this wonderful city.

Great experience!. We loved riding around on the trams for next to nothing though they do fill up quickly! It. Sounds obvious but try to get a seat as once it's crowded you won't see much if standing!

Double decker trams! Can't believe.. Oh! They are so cute to watch gliding down the middle of the street in elegance and style. No, they are not air-conditioned but who cares, the journey is so comfortable. It is a must-ride for all tourists visiting HK. Just board one from Central that goes to Happy Valley race course and enjoy the ride through the city. One can take a round trip back to the starting point or stop at any MTR station to find your way back. It is advisable to sit on the top floor as I found mostly elderly people sitting at the lower floor. Entry is from the rear end while you alight at the pilot end paying with your octopus card. Same fare for any length of the journey. Please don't use tram if you are in a hurry. It makes frequent stops both at the designated stops and the traffic crossings.

one of the best ways to see Hong Kong. I had ridden the trams in HK before and did not hesitate to do it again. Upstairs at the front, make yourself comfy and let the city pass by before you for a next to nothing fare. Wonderful views and as the lines pass through different areas just take it all in. !!!!

A great way to travel and enjoy HK. I love the trams in HK! Dirt cheap (HKD 2.5) and gets you from place to place easily. It's a must try when you are travelling around HK.Enjoy the sights and sounds when you're travelling. Just be careful and not to get too excited and stick your head out while travelling. It may cause an accident.

Fun way to see HK and to travel if you've got time. If you're not in a rush, take a tram to your destination. These are really cheap and quite an experience. You can ride the whole line for $2.3 and soak up the city.

You got to ride the Ding Ding. The trams are definitely showing their age, narrow stair case to go up the moving tram may be a challenge, but you got to try it. It is the best way to see HK by paying just $0.30 US. Try the Northpoint to Central route, you can see most of the Island in slow mode, you must seat upstair to get the best view.
Worth to try. One of the best way to enjoy Hong Kong, you should try to take the tram on upstairs. The tram runs slowly, it felt like a cheap city tour.
You just have to. They just shuttle up and down the road continuously and they cover quite a bit of ground and they're so cheap, you just have to get on one Try get the front seats up top.
fun. a good way of getting across town without the walking. if you're tall, stick to the downstairs. good value.

A cheap way to do sightseeing in HK Island. As a HK resident, if I am not in a rush to go from lets say Central to Causeway Bay or vice versa, I will most definitely taking the tram because a) is the best to beat the traffics and b) it is so cheap (HK$2.30 for adult one way, short or long journey. Children may be 1/2 the price. Sorry don't really know for the children fare). The journey from Central to Causeway Bay it's more or less 1/2 hour, the driver will stop at every stopping point. I like to seat upstairs just to see what's going on around the area because there is always a new building coming up or the old one being torn down due to a new development. All in all, taking a tram ride in HK is fun and full of surprises just be ready with the weather situation it can be nice & windy or hot & humid but overall it's pleasant!

cheap way to go around HK island. If you have enough time and want to have an inside look of HK island, it is recommended to take the tram and go around most part of the HK island. The fare is only HK$2.3 for each journey. I recommend to go upstairs of the tram and sit by the window side.
