Best way to get oriented to HK Island. There is no better (or cheaper) way to see the entire length of northern HK Island. Find a time off-peak hours, go to the top deck, sit in front (or in back), and watch the neighbourhoods go by. At this price, if you see something you want to explore, hop off and get back on later. Note that North Point and Happy Valley lines divert themselves from the main track; best to use Shaukeiwan (in one direction) and Kennedy Town (in the other direction). Pay as you exit, with coins or Octopus card. You can more or less see if you will need to stand, before you get on, so if you have time, just wait for the next tram to come along.

Hong Kong Tram journey. When you come to Hong Kong, you should really take the tram journey. Some people found it slow and polluted with the open air but this is the best way to observe the busiest streets in Hong Kong island.

Tram Tuesdays. I have lived in Hong Kong for more then a decade... I hop on the tram to get around the island cause its the best and cheapest way to go... yeah the air is bad, pollution and rain lately horrible but its great for seeing the city evolve!!

To do, but keep an eye on your map. If you go to Hong Kong. It's a must to travel once (or twice) with the famous 'ding ding'. The fact that Hong Kongers drive on the left side of the road is one visible remnant of the English colonization. And the 'ding ding' is a second one. But keep an eye on the map while you travel with it, as it's not easy to find your way.

Another experience at Hong Kong. What I can said this public transportation is most slowly in Hong Kong. But it give u the other side of the Hong Kong living style ( slow and steady). It much fun compare to take the other public transport especially MRT is much faster. I love to take this to travel around .

if you do not rush anywhere, they're ok. Hong Kong is a very busy city, so going by tram can be very painful if you are eager to get to a certain place. it's quite slow and you get to see from above the crowded streets of HK.
Plus: very cheap
Minus: if you do not get a front upper deck seat, it's not worth it.

Do not Miss this!. To me two of the iconic symbols of Hong Kong are the Star Ferry and the Hong Kong Trams. For just over HK$2 you can ride the whole tram line from end to end. Go for an upper deck seat and take in the many vistas of Hong Kong, from the up market shopping malls in Central and Causeway Bay, to the open air fish, meat and fruit markets at North Point.

A wonderful perspective of Hong Kong!!. The 1st occasion I used them was purely out of convenience as my hotel was on the outskirts but it was a wonderful 1st ride I sat at the top and drank in the atmosphere!! I then used the ding dings at least twice a day and at only $2.30 it was amazing!!
Part of Hong Kong's history. Love the tram it is part of Hong Kong's history.It is so cheap! If it is raining as it was last week (April 2014) take something to dry the seats.

Cheap and convinient. Runs right through the heart of Hong Kong Island. Fixed cost of HKD 2.3 per person no matter where you get on or off. Pay exact change only when you get off. Also a good and cheap way to tour the island by riding on it for the entire trip.

Cheap and pleasant. The ding ding is a cheap and pleadant way to see downtown hong kong. Not many locals use it, except the elderly and parents with small children, due to its slow speed, but this just makes it perfect for taking pictures from.

Best way to see the city. My mother and I took a short trip to Hong Kong and felt the trams were the best way to see the city. for only HK$2.40 each ride, we got to see entire swaths of the city that the main tourist buses miss. The refreshing wind blowing on our faces and our great views from perched on the second floor was exactly what we needed to feel like we belonged in this metropolis of 7M. No need for us to pay the $25 of other tour buses when we have our own guidebook--and lots of helpful tourists who gave us their top tips on where to go and what to buy. Definitely ride this when you're in Hong Kong!
OKB trip to H.K. Island -. Another MUST when visiting H.K. Island. From the Ding Ding you can see much of the Island center in a very casual way ... and very cheap!!
Wonderful old world throwback. The tramways are a must see in Hong Kong. They are inexpensive and fun to watch the many varied sights of Hong Kong CBD at an old world pace.

Keeping the old age still. It is one of the main attraction by keeping the old age beauty still ON and most economical and convenient way to reach the top.
You can really enjoy the view during travel.

Definitely tram across the island - unique HK experience!. Highly recommend hopping onto the trams that run across HK island, it's a fun and definitely unique ride through the hubbub of HK and unbelievably economical (HKD$2.30 no matter how far you go!). Board the tram from the rear and alight from the front (you pay on alighting the tram). Grab a seat upstairs and watch HK life roll by - my favourite spot is tramming through the middle of a wet market in North Point! I am often in HK and will always make the time for a tram trip on HK island, no matter how short or long the trip!

Great view at night. We did a couple of trips during the day on the ferry from Kowloon to Hong Kong Island but a trip on a boat around Victoria Harbour at night is spectacular!! the lights on the buildings are just sensational
Must do!. The iconic ding ding trams are cheap, offering an easy way to get around the harbour side of Hong Kong Island.

Great transport. this is our go to transport preference. so cheap 60cAU for 2 of us. We travelled up n down the tram lines when we first got to HK, so we could suss out where we wanted to go. Its slow, but hey, who cares youre on holiday. most of the trams were clean, we loved them....this is what we need in Perth, W Australia....cheap transport
Cheapest transport!. Cheap and great way to get around HK island! Only concern is it's a tight space in the tram especially during peak hours.

A casual way to see some of Hong Kong. You can't beat the Ding Ding for value for money, unless you count the local ferries. Crowded? - yes. Comfortable? not particularly. View from the upper deck - almonst unbeatable. You have to do this on your visit to HK.
cheap & novel way to travel. if a tram stops near where you are staying, take it! It is really cheap and the ride is a good way to see another side of Hong Kong.

a traditional part of old hong kong. If you go to Hong Kong island you cannot miss seeing the trams. In fact although they are vintage they still represent a great way to get around and at just $2.3 per journey they are cheap as chips. A not be missed Hong Kong experience.
Unique Experience. It was interesting to travel in a 'narrow' double-decker tram in the midst of the city. The buildings and signage seem within reach.
Excellent. These guys get you wherever you want to go for $2.30HKD. How good is that ? And, the drivers are very helpful
A great way to see the city. For 23pence you can see a lot of the city. Ensure you have 2.3 dollars in change, as no change given. A great and cheap way to see the city.

Great way to see the city. Settled on the Kowloon side of the city the ding dings as we call them are a great way to get around cheaply while seeing the city.
Go at late eve to avoid the crowds and enjoy the night lights.

Where in the world can you travel on a tram for peanuts?. So glad they are keeping the trams: part of the rich heritage of Hong Kong, but also a fun way to see this amazing place, so go upstairs and snuggle up to your partner on the seats which were made before bottoms started to increase in size! You can pretty well go from one end of Hong Kong island to the other and the rest of the traffic gets out of your way!

It's a streetcar. Not sure I share the same level of excitement as my fellow reviewers. You drive along a busy shopping street in a street car. Yes, it is cheap and it connects you faster in some instances than the MTR. But it is not a particular scenic sightseeing trip. Perhaps it is fun if you have never been in a street car before?
So cheap yet so much fun!. For the UK equivalent of about 25p you are able to step back to yesteryear and travel for miles aboard these beautful and clean old trams

Love it!. Great way to travel around Hong Kong Island on the cheap and get to really see the real HK. Less time wasted walking around subway compared to MTR and much cheaper at 2.3 HKD for any trip. I have been on all of them and definitely recommend it,
Ding Ding. A easy way to get around Hong Kong once you learnt the proper way to get on and off. A bit low for tall people but lots of fun and very cheap.
Trams. Nice way to travel,, saves your legs yet gives you time to see what shops there are. Very very cheap,way to travel in Hong Kong
Top of Hong Kong. Only way to go - and cheapest and fastest - in Hong Kong.One experience you must not deny yourself.

Drunk People... Very nice and efficient. If the tram is full, there is always another one coming.
However on two occasions, there are drunk people boarding. One almost picked a fight with me, while the other guy is singing, dancing and shouting as thought the tram is his stage.
Both guys are not local!
Awesome. Never experience this kind of transport, good to have a try and its cheap either, just cost HKD2.30 on way.

Great Way to see Hong Kong. If you have the time, this is a great way to experience a good swath of Hong Kong island and soak up some local flavor. Try for the top level. If you are staying in Central, take the tram to Causeway Bay where you will find much more of old Hong Kong than in the modern financial district. Go for some street food and check out "Times Square".

A great way to travel on the Island. Buy an MTR pass at the information office in any MTR station, these can be used on buses, the MTR subways, Star ferries and the Trams, it makes travel both in Kowloon and on the Island very cheap, even longer bus rides to Aberdeen and Stanley are just cents.The trams can get crowded, get on at the back at off at the front, you need to have an idea where to get off and make your way to the front stairs. Swipe your 'pass' by the driver or put $2.40 in the money 'bin' ( more is ok but no change given) and hop off the tram. A map of the MTR and tram stops is freely available.The front seats on the top deck are great as the windows slide down and you can take photos easily.A 'must' for down to earth travelling in Hong Kong!
A Tourist must sit. A very old traditional mode of transport must sit/ take if possible! bring you around in hongkong! very hongkong feel!
Really cheap!. Sometimes crowded but run regularly and are soo cheap. Hop on and off where you want and a great way to get your bearings when you first arrive. You just have to do it!

Must try experience. It is one of the oldest public transport in Hong Kong and is still a major mode of transport for the locals. It is incredibly cheap and so accessible to every major centre on Hong Kong island. It is a must try experience for anyone. (But avoid peak hours which could be sardines packed busy!)
nice ride if u hv the time. great ride to while the time and people watch.. got from sheung wan (wing lok st famed for dried foodstuff) to causeway bay via this traditional transport.

Best way to see the Hong Kong Island north shore. This is, like the Star Ferry, a must for all first-timer Hong Kong tourists. The tram travels all the way from Kennedy Town in the West to Shaukiwan in the East, covering almost the entire northern shore of Hong Kong Island. With fare at HK$2.3 for an adult per trip, which usually covers more than an hour if you stay on from terminal to terminal, you cannot beat it for value with any other means of transportation. The tram which starts at Kennedy Town travels through Sheung Wan, Central District, Admiralty, Wanchai, Causeway Bay and normally terminates at Happy Valley which is mainly a residential area with few touirts attractions, unless, of course, you want to see the race course. But you can get off at Causeway Bay, the busy shoping district, and catch another one which bounds for Shaukiwan to continue your journey eastward (with fresh fare payable). After Causeway Bay, the tram will pass by Victoria park, Tin Hau, North Point, Quarry Bay until it finally terminates in Shaukiwan. Actually, with fare at HK$2.3, you can always hop off to see things or places which you want to explore further along the way, and then hop back on and continue your journey after each such stop over. The upper deck, of course, offers better view than the one down below. It is also a good idea to do the tram ride in the morning, and again at night. It is quite a different scene, sight and sound when the lights are lit and the crowd has dissipated. Bear also in mind that there is no air-conditioning on the tram. So you have to brave the heat if you come in summer.One more piece of info - you can actually hire your own private carriage and have a tram party. It costs just a few thousand Hk dollars but you can have the whole tram which can hold more than 30 people for about two hours. You can design your own intineray too. The other good point is that you can bring your own food and drink onboard at no charge for the enjoyment by your own party. But please book early if you want to try this unique experience. Finally, a word of caution. Because it is cheap, the trams are always busy and crowded. Hence, pickpockets of different nationalities ply their trade on them. But just stay alert and be careful as in in many other busy tourist spots all over world, then you should be okay.

1900s in 21st century. Great to experience the tramride, a transport system that goes way back from 1900s.A good opportunity to savour a taste of an everyday HKer life, with lots of sights and sounds to take in.

Cheap transportation. Very nice way to get to see the city, the trams are super cheap 2.5 HK dollars, and you can get to travel in a very traditional way. We were planing to get a tourist bus, but then we realized how much better it can be travelling with the locals and see a more genuine side of HK.

Tried and True. Simple to use and takes you either to, or very close to, the major attractions on Hong Kong Island. There is a good map online of the routes, the start/end destinations, and the times the begin and end running. Also, a great way to see the city from a different perspective for very little money. The destination is stated on the front of the tram, which can be used to determine on the map where it will go and what time it will stop running. Enter through the back and exit through the front doors. YOU PAY WHEN YOU EXIT. We used our Octopus card and just kept it in our wallet and pressed our wallet to the reader and it registered. Quick and easy. It will tell you how much is left on the card every time it is swiped somewhere. I strongly suggest buying an OCTOPUS CARD at any MTR station. They are 150 HKD, 50 HKD is a deposit you get back when you turn it back in and 100 HKD is to use. IF you don't use all 100 you get back what remains on the card when you return the card at an MTR station. We refilled in an MTR station at an ATM looking machine, just by inserting the card and then inserting the amount we wanted in bills, and then take the card out. So easy. It works in MTRs, Trams, and 7/11s. I'm sure it works more places but that is all I personally have experience with.

Old Tram But Still Working Well Today. Funny, nostalgic and cheap way to move from place A to place B in Hong Kong Island.You enter to tram from behind the cart and get off in front. And you pay exact amount to driver when you leave. The payment is HKD 2,30 / adult and the price is the same no matter where you get on and where get off.You can pay also with an octopus card.This is something you have to experience when you're in HK!

Tram to Shaukeiwan. We took the tram from Central to Shaukeiwan, about a 45 minute ride. A very nice way to see this part of Hong Kong, though a little slow. Shaukeiwan was more prominent as a fishing village in the old days. Now its a trendy little area quite different from busy central Hong Kong. Some nice restaurants, a market, and a few temples.

A Hong Kong icon and a great way to see Hong Kong Island. "Ding, Ding", the Hong Kong tram is an icon and a must do when you are in Hong Kong. The tram gets its name, Ding Ding, from the sound of the its bell. You can use an "Octopus" card to pay for you ride making it easy and you don't have to fumble around with unfamiliar coins, there is no change given if you pay in cash you just drop the money in a box. One very important tip when riding Ding Ding is that you enter from the rear door and exit from the front. once on board make your way up the small staircase to the upper deck and take a seat for some great views of the city.
Quaint. Great and a travel back in time for most of us. Only one route so easy to use. Best to have the Octopus card which you use when leaving
Ding Ding. The best way to get around Hong Kong (if you aren't in a rush).You may find it crowded but you gradually work your way towards the front, the fare is fixed for one stop or 20 stops

Priceless tour from Kennedy Town to Happy Valley. The Hong Kon Tram runs from Kennedy Town in the West to Happy Valley. At leass the $US 0.30c it has got to be the best value for money travel in the world (unless you are in a hurry). It travels along busy streets, but is a great way to get from where were staying at the Courtyard, up to Sheung Wan, Central or Pacific Place at Admiralty.
Classy ride. It is like a hop on and hop off service we tried in Hongkong. For you to see a better view of the city make sure you sit at the 2nd deck.

Travel with the locals - one low fare takes you everywhere. When you get on you may find it crowded but you gradually work your way towards the front, the fare is 2.30 HK or you can use your Octopus card. It is a great way of seeing things and observing the local people. The route used to be along the harbour front but now you can't even see the harbour because of all the reclamation work, just shows how much H has changed in the last 50 years.
One great ride. A great experience to ride the tram! It's affordable and a best form of sightseeing in Hong Kong. It connects you to many stations that makes it hassle-free.
Great value transport. I always use the trams on the Island. They are great fun and very convenient. There are frequent stops so you can get just about anywhere on the lower level.

The best value. Whenever I'm in Hong Kong, I always tried to take one of the tram routes at least once. The routes remain the same all these years. Take the tram from terminal to terminal. It's the best form of sightseeing to allow the traveller to see different parts of the city. For example, take the Kennedy Town to Happy Valley. The trams travels through so many diverse areas of Hong Kong - from the dried food and wholesales districts in Kennedy Town to the mostly residential area in Happy Valley, not to mention a view of the Race Course. It's well worth the time spent. Do avoid rush hours!!

See the real Hong Kong. For just about a dime, you can spend an hour or so and experience life in Hong Kong. Get a seat on the front or side of the upper deck and experience the real busy daily life of Hong Kong, everything is so close that you can almost touch and feel them.

GREAT FUN - AND A GREAT VIEWING PLATFORM TOO!. Just hop on and be prepared to pay tiny amounts when you get off. Avoid the very busy periods when everyone seems to want ot ride the trams on their way home. There are very few lines and it's easy to navigate.

Cheap, fun, exciting. The tram is quite cheap, a fixed rate if I remember correctly. Although several route does exist, but most of the trams will be passing Admiralty-Central, so for fun instead of taking the MTR it is way more fun and exciting to experience HK in a different way. Highly recommended!

The best 20p ride on the planet. At 2.30 HK dollars (approx. 20p), the tram has to be the cheapest and most entertaining way to see many aspects of Hong Kong life. Over our time in HK, we travelled over the whole system viewing both the splendour of the central area and the residential areas with very local shops and markets towards the termini. A must for any visit to HK.

Took a test ride - Chinese is mandatory :(. I was fascinated looking at the tram and so decided to step in. Apparently the driver didnt guide us at all on where to get off or anything and most of the Co-passengers didn't speak English. I had expected more since this was in the business district of HK. But I still rate it average as the ride itself was very pleasant, we almost had a city tour through the windows. The vintage look of the trams is appealing.
so fun. was really neat to ride on always would see it in the movies and have wanted to try it out a bit packed but that's HK

Best way to experience Hongkong. This 100 year old mode of transportation is the cheapest and most enjoyable way to get around the city. Always crowded with all communities of the local population, it's a great way to get a sense of local life as well. Because it travels slowly and cheaply, hopping on and off whenever you want is totally viable. Do not miss!

Ding Ding!. A trip to Hong Kong wouldn't be complete without a ride on these lovely old double decker trams that trundle along the north shore of HK Island. Good views of both old and new Hong Kong can be had for just HKD2.20.
Blast from the past. Loved riding on these quaint little trams, cheap way to get from one side of the island to the other.

Have a ride!. Definitely worth a ride on these old trams. So cheap and fun.
If you don't know where they go to, just take a return trip to any destination.
Fantastic. Very good view of the city while going up by tram. View from the top is awesome. Romantic place to visit. Good restaurants and shopping arcade.
HOP ON - HOP OFF , THAT EASY !!!. NO trip to HONG KONG is complete without a tram ride across town . These heavy old rattlers are FUN ,CHEAP , and worth a snap shot for the album ,,
bestway to explore hong kong island. very cheap just for 2,20 hkg $ and coming every 3-5 minutes drive along the south side of hongkong island,
Do not miss. They are so retro and take you to areas you would never go otherwise. Hongkong is a moving city..it just spreads out and out. Take these vintage trams. Fun and cheap

Cheap, efficient, cultural.. I LOVE HK TRAMWAYS! You can travel from one side of HK to the opposite side for only HK$2.30 Super cheap. There are always trams going past you on HK island and you can catch one from just about anywhere and hop on-hop off. Trams have been part of HK's history for a long time so they are also a very cultural influence.
great way to get around.. clean, efficient, cheap as chips, almost like going back in time.special note larger people use turnstile on left hand side.
Cheap and fun. For HKD2.5, you get to go around HK island and people watch and feel like a local. A trip to HK without a tram ride is incomplete.

Good for Young Children. We took our young boys on a Ting Ting tram ride to Happy Valley (Eastbound) and back to Central and they had a blast. We were seated at the top, front row and it was a great way to see this side of the city. Board from the back and exit from the front after tapping your Octopus Cards. If the first one is full, wait for the next. The tram line has its own dedicated tracks, and it seldoms get caught in the city jams. Locals use this mode to get around the city, and unlike the MTR where one would have to do abit of walking and climbing, the tram is on the surface and has numerous stops.

Signature Ride. Trams in Hong Kong I must say is a signature ride tourists should not miss. It is a slow and cheap ride that can bring one from as far as Shau Kei Wan to Sheung Wan. With a fare of HKD2.30, one will be able to see the many places and points of interests in Hong Kong. The feeling one gets on a daytime and night tine ride is different, try riding it on the upper deck at night to have a feel of how festive Hong Kong is once the sun sets. A morning ride will allow one to witness the busy side of Hong Kong. Explore Hong Kong by taking the tram!
Brief but Fun!. A must do... but go early and try to avoid the long lines. Take to ride up to the Peak and a taxi or bus ride back down.

Slow scenic ride. The Hong Kong Tram way is an old fashioned, slow moving double decker streetcar, but it is good to ride it when it is not yet hot (there is no air-conditioning) as it glides through city streets with a view better than what you can see on a Rolls-Royce. Choose the last row (back) window seat for best photo opportunity and the best (also longest) ride at the same cheap fare is from Happy Valley to Saukiwan. Avoid peak hours of course. It will be quite an experience for first-time riders.
Fun cheap transportation. The old trams are a fun cheap way to get across town. Sometimes crowded, but not bad. Try to go upstairs for a better view if you are going a distance.
Excellent way to get around. Great way to get around on the cheap! Wait for one of the "old" ones that has an outdoor area on the 2nd floor. They also do tram parties!
Great way to see the town. Might be slower but if you want to just get the feeling for Hong Kong it is a great way to go. It can get a bit over crowded. Check it out. I would do it again.

scenic route of HK island. yes it may be quicker to catch the MTR but underground you cant see anything and your missing out on seeing the streets of HK. plus the tram is sooo cheap only 2.30HKD. got to do it at least once.

An Economical Scenery Tour. Hopped onto one after my dim sum breakfast. Just great that i managed to find the front seat overlooking the top of the bus. I travelled from Sheung Wan to Causeway Bay. great for photo taking! Tip that I may leave behind, don't be over-enthusiastic in taking photos (e.g. standing up etc). Keep it simple, discreet and quiet. I think the locals will appreciate that. Before going to HK, i was wondering when i should tap the Octopus card for the ding ding tram/bus. Because, where i come from in Singapore, we tap when we get on and off. For the Ding Ding bus/tram, you get on from the back of the bus, just push the barrier and get on. Tap the card when you get off only.
Best way to get around town. Very easy system to use. Avoid the early morning work crowds or you will find out what a canned sardine feels like.
Great way to see Hong Kong. This is a cheap and fun way to see Hong Kong. Jump on any tram and grab the seat up stairs at the front.
Great fun on the ding ding. It is slow, very slow ....... but something you should do at least once when you visit Hong Kong. Watch you head too for everyone over 5ft in height.

top floor!!. get one across HK Island...top floor is a must.
there's so many of them, and they cost nothing (almost!)
definitely worth a ride

Another of the must be experienced .... .... though a little bit complicated to get to a stop because of HKs
policy to prevent crossing streets because of its heavy traffic.
Try to get on the Upper Deck, of course !

A way to see the city.. This is a different perspective to see the city from the tramways. They go to many places out of the city and run a very frequent service. It was a fun way to get around and quite cheap too.

always on time. Only dislike in always long walk in and out of the station.On the good side,burning off calories.Buy their pass,not tickets.The pass
can be use on subway,bus and tram.
cheap and quirky. you use your octopus card and there is a set price. probably not great if you are very tall. The best way to travel and see some sights and a good alternative to mtr

Pleasant City Scene. I stayed at Wanchai area for 4 days and this was my main mode of transportation. Since I've got plenty of time, the tram's the way to go as it offers you a unique experience from the subs. Going at rather slow speeds, I'd people-watch and see what the locals are up to whether in the morning or at night. Once I took the tram and traveled the entire line ending at Shau Kei Wan. Very fun! I'd surely go back again for such a cheap and meaningful way to travel Hong Kong Island!

All the travel we needed for HK$30. Loved travelling on the tram. Each trip is $2.30, so if you go from one end of the island to the other it's still only 2.30 as long as you don't get off. Easiest way to pay is by Octopus card, we had one from our last visit and just topped it up at a 7/11. The trams are very clean. Get on at the back and off at the front where you either swipe your Octopus card or pay the driver - correct fare only, no change given. Octopus is a great way to pay for most things bus, tram, star ferry and even McDonalds!

Very easy and very old. it is the easiest and cheapest way to travel in Hong Kong, it has a fixed price for any trip for just 2.3HK$. You should try this very old tram at least once when visiting Hong Kong.
A fun way to see Hong Kong. A ride on the tram at HK$2 is a real bargain, and an opportunity to mix with locals and see the city. Take any tram and sit upstairs.
the best way to see Hong Kong. Get on the TRAM , on the upper deck and just watch the city , you can go from one end to the other end - you would love the tram
Great way to discover Hong Kong Island. Great way to discover Hong Kong Island from the Western Market and Shai Kei Wan and go back in time... Best at night-time...

The cheapest and easiest way to see HK. The whole family really loved this mode of transportation, stop at the station and get aboard the back of the tram and away you are off. The best way to go and get lost in Kong Kong.

immers yourself.... great way to see the city. inexpensive and therefore your biggest bang for the buck. sit on the second level and enjoy the unique perspective. you can hub from one to the other especially when you realizing that you are heading in the wrong direction. all easy and so much fun.

The cheapest means!. It's certainly the cheapest means to explore Hong Kong Island with only HKD 2.30. With the tram service, you can just go from one end to the other. Just embark at the back door of the tram and you are only required to pay when you are getting down. Do prepare the exact fare if you are not using the Octopus Card.
great service and on time to the second. this was a joy to flavour,service was exceptional to the second,cheap as noodles and narrated in english for each stop,cheap way to commute in HK

Best I have sen. they are timely reliable and very organised. I thought sydney Trains were very good until I saw the Tramways in Honkong. The way it runs even with that high population density is just fantastic.
exquisitely slow :). just the right ride for a whole lot of city viewing and picture taking. it's slow but you'll surely love especially the fare is amazingly low---> only HK$2.30 :)

Do You seem price of Hong Kong taxi to expensive?. So You should not miss get double decker tramways - but be carefully - all cars, buses and tramways too drive on the left and boarding islands are very narrow!

Great experience, and very cheap - but can be a tight squeeze. The trams are a great way of travelling east-west (or vice versa) in the central areas of Hong Kong. They're very frequent, and very cheap; but they get incredibly crowded. Definitely avoid at peak times, if you're carrying any luggage (which is actually banned beyond a certain size) or if you're large or tall.If you manage to avoid all of the above, then travelling by tram is a great experience, most easily enjoyed with an Oyster card (2.30 HKD per trip, payable on exit).
A Little Bit of History. A cheap and historic way of travelling across Hong Kong island. You enter at the back through the turnstiles and pay once you get off at the front.

great ride for little money. The trams run through the heart of Hong Kong Island, very frequently. If you sit on the top floor you have a great view of the hustle and bustle in the city. absolutely recommend this ride. Just watch your head coming down the stairs :-)
Cutest trains in the world!. Those double-deckers are excellent choice to explore and just watch live on the streets of Hong Kong.Great for snapping shots and relax and enjoy the ride.

For 5'5" and under. This is a great form of transportation for East/West travel on Central island as long as you are 5'5" and under. If you're any taller, it's worth it to wait for the newer version of Tram (less frequent). Of course, we didn't realize there was a "newer" and taller version until our next to last day there. So, with a sore noggin', take a warning from those that went before.
very efficient mode of transport. cheap form of transportation. very frequent running. good for sight seeing. travel from one end of HK to another.

Takes you back 60 years or more. Fantastic ride on these trams thank god they kept them and Im sure they will remain there for ever. The trams are open windowed so with the extreme heat that is a god send

Maximize your return of investment by taking the tram. If you are in Hong Kong Island and not in a hurry, taking the tram is the way to go. For HK$2.30 each time (regardless the stops), I consider it the best deal to explore HK Island. I took all their routes from end-to-end just to see different neighborhood. The best seat for tourist will be the upper front roll seat. You can take a lot of photos with the windows down (sunny day only).

Cheapest transport along HK island. The trams make just as fast progress as the buses and only cost 2.5 HK$ per journey, pay on exit or use your Octopus card on exit. Ideal if you want a straightforward journey down to Causeway from Sheung Wan
Enjoyed the ride. It is very convenient. Make sure you get the Octopus card.its easy to get around from Hongkong Island to Kowloon side.

Brilliant - and cheap - way to travel. Get yourself an Octopus card and enjoy the trams for very little cost. Try to avoid rush hour if you want a seat - we found the evenings were best. And from the top deck you get a great view of Hong Kong's streets.
Easy, cheap and efficient.. Best way to get around Hong Kong. Extremely easy to navigate, inexpensive and quick. Don't be afraid to do it.

Good way of transport for short journey. Unlike the trams in Melbourne, at some points, the trams and cars share the same path, resulting in trams journey interrupted with cars on and off. The result is a slow tram. It is not advisable for a long journey, as it will take a long time. The tram experience itself is nice. You can go to upper deck to enjoy the view

Ding Ding. The iconic tramway system on Hong Kong Island is something you cannot tire of. For a mere 2.3 HKD (17 pence UK - $29 US - 0.21 Euros) is a cheap reliable and frequent service anywhere on the north side of the Island. OK, it is bumpy and not that comfortable but considering this service has been in operation since 1904 not that much has changed. Just love "Ding Ding."
Excellent cheap way to travel. Loved the authenticity. Still a really cheap was to travel to and from the main areas. Very regular.
a travel must. easy to use and very regular trams, stops in good places, very economical and chance to see lots of things you would miss otherwise.
easy transport. just jump to the tram and this is the easy way to take a mass transport in Hong Kong island, just ony for HKD2 or with your Octopus Card.

Fantastic and cheap way to get around. When on HK island a ride (or 10) on the trams is a must. Be sure to pick a tram where the front of the top is not occupied and then go up there and take in the atmosphere.It price is $2.30 which is paid on exit with either an octopus card or cash (no change given). All in all, its a must for the full HK experience

Hard to see. Since this is used by the locals as a method of transportation, it is very hard to get a seat, let alone a window seat. We had read that this was a cheap way to see the city, and I would say that one gets to span multiple areas of the city. It was nice to get out of the ritsy financial center and see areas where most of the people can probably afford to live. But, it was hard to get a seat. I think the suggestion was to start at the end, which we didn't do, and this very much may help you start off with a window seat. The seats at the front have the best view and the entire front of the tram is glass. One thing though, is this tram moves extremely slow. So, going anywhere takes forever.
Ace!. Once you`ve looked at a transport map so you know what destination to look for on the front then just hop on and off, very cheap.

A great way to see Hong Kong. On your first trip to Hong Kong, ride the double deckers. Great value and a wonderful way to get your bearings. Hard to beat the 2.3 HK$ fare and it runs the length of the island. Sit upstairs and enjoy the sights.

Wow.. the Travel was very slow, good.. The most surprising in HK, is to see the tram ways. Right at the heart of the HK, the entire tramways to Happy Valley, Western Market etc was very good. we get good view of the HK skyscrapers which is consistent across the Kings Road..take the front seat at the top of the tram and you get good view. Chilly air these days and that's more interesting
Long Lost Tram. Not many cities got trams anymore. Only seen in Hong Kong and last seen in Australia back in the 90s. For something different, maybe you can take a ride. More fun than bus.

Interesting Leftover from earlier days. Fun but slow travel along main route in Hong Kong Island. Enter the tram and the back and pay HK$2.30 on exit - can use Octopus card or have correct change. Make sure you are not upstairs near your stop or you may miss it - can get very busy. Also - the stops indicate Eastbound or Westbound on the top of the tram shelter.

cheap easy way to get around. HK$2.30 or about 20p per journey = bargainwe used from right outside Cosmopolitan Hotel to get to Wan Chai, Central, Lan Kwai Fong etc. Seems slowish in traffic but compared to how far you actually walk in the MTR stations to get to the exit you want I think it's quicker and you get a great view aswell. Run till late too
Good view. It is nice Tramming Hong Kong island. We sat on top and had a great view, nice pictures taken. It's relaxing when yout tired of walking and a great way for sightseeing the area.

Enjoy the air pollution!. Although it is dirt cheap, this is a extremely slow way to get around the north side of HK Island. It can be painstakingly slow especially during rush hour traffic. I've been to HK quite a few times, and there are way more efficient ways to get around this part of the city. The trams are very busy and are often crammed full of passengers like canned sardines- something that you may want to avoid during your vacation unless you prefer rubbing other people's elbows or smelling sweaty people's body odours. There is no air conditioning so the windows must stay open (and hence you'll be breathing in all the wonderfully polluted air from the road - exhaust and fumes from other vehicles and A/C from surrounding buildings, etc. - not good for your health especially if you were to be stuck there for an hour or two). For just a slightly higher costs (which is still very affordable compared to other parts of the world), you can get the same city views from a double-decker bus; it has much more comfortable seating with A/C and, more importantly, it saves you valuable time.
Good value, easy transport, packed like sardines. $2.30 for adults. Worth a try just for the experience. Very regular and reliable and routes are straightforward

Feel Like a Local. We absolutely loved getting around Hong Kong Island on the trams as it gave a different perspective to sightseeing. It felt like stepping back in time a little bit to be transported on the quirky trams and venture on the tram from one end of the route to the other. Sometimes we would just hop on one for a relaxing way to observe what the locals were up to while we took a breather!
Nice view at the top. The easiest way to get to the top, walk up will take more than an hour. The waiting time on Sunday about 45 min.

A must for all visitors. Everyone has to take a ride on the Hong Kong trams at least once during their visit. These tall, narrow trams have a toy-like appearance as they trundle through the main streets of Hong Kong island. all bearing large and colourful advertisements.But apart from their looks, the system is both cheap and efficient, with trams running regularly during the day and evenings. Be sure to sit upstairs for the best views.But a warning, if you are travelling in winter always have warm clothes, the trams are not heated and it is not unusual for other passengers to have the windows open to get air.

A lot of fun. Take one of the tram lines from one end to the other. Take a seat on top at the front and drive for example all the way to the east to discover some very authentic areas. Prices are very low.

Cheapest Tour. The trams are the best way to get a good feel of Hong Kong Island city. Just hop on & off as you please for only $2.30HKD. Best seats are up top at the front or back & you can snap away at all the sights. This is a really fun way to travel in this city.
Dont miss the experience. Really cheap, just a few dollars and quite good fun. just hop on at the tram stop and see where you end up. Nowhere is too far away.

Good transportation. One of the best way to see Hong Kong Island....It is cheap only $2.30HKD when you get off .... From one end to the other side.It is slow but get you there and sight seeing all the way.

M & M Trip 2013. I recommend you buy an Octopus card, you just swipe the card as you get off the Tram. Its a really good way to get around. The card can be used on the buses, ferries and the train. The card can be purchased at any underground station ticket desk.
Nice ride. Cheap ride in modern Hong Kong in an old Hong Kong tramCASH ONLY / you can do all the tram ride on top talking photos and it is ok :)
Fun way to see HK. Love the trams so narrow and a great way to see HK. Take the back seat up top and put the window down.
Ding Ding Trams. Best value trip in HK. Go on the MTR Island Line to North Point at about 1030. Ride the length of the Island on the open top tram for 2 dollars. Great people watching at a slow pace.

fun way to travel. You can't go to Hong Kong and not go on a tram ride. It doesn't matter where you go. It's cheap and a fun way to see the city. Sit up top at the front if you can and just enjoy the ride
Ding dings are tops. Cheap ($2.30HKD), fun double decker trams running frequently east-west on the island, slower than the bus but much more fun. Makes me miss the Melbourne trams!

Northpoint to Western Market. (NORTH POINT TO WESTERN MARKET)A tram ride is an exciting way for visitors to experience the colour and atmosphere of Hong Kong's vibrant street life and this suggested trip enables the opportunity to take an upstairs front-seat "grandstand" ride through some of Hong Kong's most interesting districts;Take the MTR Island Line to North Point. Exit the station via Exit B2 to emerge on King’s Road. Cross King’s Road and follow it to the left for about 200 yards until reaching a junction in the tram tracks where trams emerging from the short loop to North Point Tram Terminus along Chun Yeung Street rejoin the main line. The terminus is on the left and here visitors can join an empty tram and occupy the upper deck front seats for excellent views. Alight at the Western Market stop as there's not much to see after that.

Best value for money. The Hong Kong Tramways are the best thing about being a tourist there - they cover a vast part of the harbour and central shopping districts, they are cheap and they are always there.At two dollars and thirty cents a trip - regardless of how far - this is something you have to do. The trams are old and and old-fashioned, and run on their special tracks, hooked to the overhead supply and affording you a top deck view of Hong Kong. If you consider that the open-top tour bus will cost you a hundred times that for a day trip, the trams have to be considered the best value for money.There is a route that willt ake you to Happy Valley of you want to watch the rachorses, or to the various ferry berths. You'll pass the big business districts and the side alley markets, and along the way you'll see the daily life of Hong Kong. Allow a day and hop on and off as you fancy.

Am a boy at Heart!!!. I just had do do the tram ,i picked it up in the financial district for a few stops at night ,it was a great buzz the last time I stood on a tram like that was in Glasgow 1963 and I was ten years old .What else can I say I was ten again !! Hong Kong has it all!!

A good way of Seing downtown Hongkong Island. Try it, you will never forget it. A good way of seing downtown area of Hongkong Island. By a subway fare ticket for tourists, the easiest way of etting on & off the tram!

a quick & cheap way to get to mid-level escalators. we found the HK transit system to be excellent, including the trams. Great way to people watch too. From Metro, to star ferries, to double-deckers, to trams, to cabs all were good and very reasonable.
good to take this ride if you want the viewalongthe way. it is ideal for sightseeing. You can enjoy the beauty of Hongkong while you travel to your destination
Great way to spend time to watch the crowds. We took the tram all the way to Kennedy Town from Central. Spent some time in windswept waterfront & cam back. Its really nice in the night

A Real Experience. Any trip to Hong Kong Island is not complete with traveling on the trams which take you back in time. Very cheap way to cross the island from Happy Valley to the Western part of the Island.

Great value and convenient. If you're on HK island, it's quite likely you will be able to get around by tram, or "ding ding"as known colloquially.The tram runs up and down hk island, west to east, rides are $2.3 hk dollars (no change given), pay when you get off using either cash or your octopus card.You may want to avoid it in summer though, no aircon!
Just plain fun. Make sure you go upstairs and try to get in the front for a wonderful view. Do not rush this. Plan to spend a couple hours just riding and viewing. Get on and get off often.
Efficient and cheap. Efficiency way of getting around, no jam and cheap. a must do! You can drop off anytime when you see something interesting.
Different. Good experience and great way to see the city. Take the tram up to Victoria Peak. Lots to do there and the ride up is one of a kind.

Love these trolleys!. In some cases it is faster to take these rolling antiques for a few stops than to hike down the MTR or hail a taxi. They offer convenient stops and a great view for people watching from the top deck. They are also a great cheap option as it is a flat rate regardless of trip length or destination. A great way to get out and see the city!
You have to experience it!. You can use the "Octopus" card too. It's a great experience. I do take the Trams as a means of transport sometimes. I nickname them "ding dings."
Good for sightseeing. Great to see the sights. This bit added because TA requires 50 characters minimum for these reviews!

A unique ride. There are no tramways where I come from, thus my friends and I were intrigued when we saw a few thin tall looking double decked bus linked to a line pass by us at the long narrow bus/tram stops located in the middle of the road.Hence we decided to hop on to a random tram and took it for a few stops just for fun. It was a refreshing experience, the interior of the tram was of a unique antique mechanical design. And it's pretty fast and affordable too!

Tram your way to Causeway Bay. As a visitor from a country where there's no tram system, you'd surely love riding it if you try it in any of your sightseeing in Hong Kong. A tram ride is very cheap at HK2.3 regardless of distance covered. You can have a smooth ride from Central to Causeway Bay passing along the picturesque streets of HK amidst beautiful skyscrapers.This system is only available in Hong Kong island, not anywhere else. The entire system has 9 routes with the westernmost terminus at Kennedy Town and easternmmost terminus located at Shau Kei Wan. Since majority of HongKongers rely on their excellent transport system to move around, you would never see traffic gridlock anywhere. You'd be amazed how HK run so smoothly despite its being a huge city. No chaotic vehicular traffic on the major thoroughfares. Not too many people crossing the intersections even in major shopping and tourist areas. Why is that? Because of its extensive networks of elevated footbridges or subways.

Easy transport system. Take plenty of change. Easy, frequent and very cheap transport system. Trams are a great way to get around Hong Kong island. Take plenty of change, jump on and off as you like. However, just note these are very very crowded at most of the times.

Love the Ding Dings. Great name isnt it! But we love them, they are a must see if you go to HK. And with the Octopus card you just hop on and hop off. The whole length of the line takes about 60-90 mins depending on traffic but I love to just sit and take in all the sights. Sit on top tho but start to make your way downstairs a bit before you actually need to alight as the stairs are very steep. And the stops and routes are marked on the poles at the stops while you are waiting for a tram so take a minute to see where you want to go and then just enjoy.

Beautiful & very well organized..!!. I am super impressed with Hong Kong transport in general and so many means to travel here,the teams are beautiful and amazing advertisements on them and good way to see city,as most run too slow during most part of day.The Octopus card would work on all transport means here including ferry. Hong Kong Island has great escalator and walkways network and amazed how they maintain a double Decker tram/buses running up/down the slopes.

Glimpses of daily Hong Kong slowed down in good old fashion. Taking the tram is really an unique experience that everyone should try if they're in Hong Kong. I took the tram from the Western Market Terminus (3 min walk away from Sheung Wan MTR) and alighted at Shau Kei Wan, the east terminus of this route before hopping on again and alighting somewhere in Causeway Bay. The tram offers great glimpses into daily Hong Kong hustle and bustle, and the cheap fare was well worth it. I recommend people who are into simply enjoying city views and interested in seeing the infrastructure of surburban areas as well to take the tram from the West to the East terminus or vice versa. The tram was able to bring me to certain streets and places along the way that I wouldn't have been able to get to directly with the MTR or bus. Remember to board the tram by the rear entrance and pay using your Octopus card or coins while disembarking by the front entrance when you alight. Amidst the modern modes of transport, the ding ding tram certainly stood out with its old school charm that reminded me of colonial Hong Kong and pleasant childhood memories.

Avoid Friday evenings. After a day seeking out various foods around Dental and seeing some live fish for the chopping board, I ended up at Western Market. Decided to catch a tram as I hadn't been on one yet. Caught the first one along that was going to North Point. Entered through the turnstiles at the back into a packed tram. People were standing upstairs so I just stood at the back. The tram then proceeded to stop everywhere and even though it was akin to a can of sardines in there, that didn't see deter up to a dozen people getting on at every stop. Some couldn't even get through the turnstiles so just stood in them.Then the fun part, getting off. You pay at the front and trying to get there when there's no way of getting through is challenge. Eventually managed it a few stops after where I had wanted to get off by gradually pushing forward.So avoid Friday evening as they are packed. Buses seemed fine.To cap it, went to Admiralty MTR to get to Kowloon and it took a good 10 trains, one arriving every minute, to get on board as the crowds must have been a good 50 deep and just surged forward every time.
Old style but very effective. Calm down and enjoy the view on Hongkong streets! Get to your destination on Hongkong Island in an old but effective way.

Quick and incredibly inexpensive. We travelled from Central to Wan Chai, and then back to Causeway Bay by tram today. The journeys were $2.30 HK each, and we discovered further half price discounts for senior citizens.Enter the tram by the back door, and leave and pay by the front. No need to ask the drivers to stop, they stop at all stops anyway. Trams every few minutes. Double decker and amazing!

Evening time is best. Very cheap and I believe a must do. It is only $HK2 or 3 and if yoiu get on at Western and stay on to Causeway Bay you see all of HK. The modern part, Wanchai, and off course shopping at Causeway Bay. Try to sit at the front on the top deck. Great value.

Front seat on the upper level. Basically just took a tram ride for the experience and to sightsee. Went on a weekend so was very crowded. Managed to get seats in the front on the upper deck which provided brilliant view. Also very reasonably priced at HKD 2.30 which we used our Octopus cards to pay for. Definitely recommended - great experience:)
Excellent transportation. A really excellent way to see the city, just loved it, very frequent service, and feels like living in old days, and very cheap as well.

Happy tram fan. Good old double decker trams crammed to the rafters with uostairs standing no problem. Cheap and fun for a tourist! And there are so many, you are not waiting long. Tram map at every stop is very helpful and was not battling against other traffic.

An expedient way to travel around Hong Kong Island. Hong Kong trams represent a very convenient, economical and efficient mode of transport. Just make sure you take the one going in the correct direction.

An expedient way to travel around Hong Kong Island. Hong Kong trams represent a very convenient, economical and efficient mode of transport. Just make sure you take the one going in the correct direction.

A novelty. It was quite novel to take an electric tramway. The only thing is that you have to be very sharp as to where you want to alight because it can get very very crowded and getting off can be a hassle.
Nice experience. It's nice to take the tram although it's long queue during our visit. Nevertheless, it's worth to experience it.

Easy way to get around Hong Kong Island. We liked that there was always a tram around the corner, but sometimes they were quite crowded. If you catch them with an attitude of acceptance of the crowding, you will have a bit of fun.

Very Convenient and Efficient. Love this tram service. It runs up till 12am everyday. Very convenient and efficient. Only cost HK$2.30 per adult, doesn't matter where you decide to drop off at. If you missed the first tram, the next one comes in less than 3 minutes or so, you don't have to wait long. Though it might be very crowded in the tram during peak hours, but it's bearable and good experience, it's part of what Hong Kong is anyway. I used the tram to get around places and especially from my hotel to Central Station. You can use the Octopus card for this tram service.

Double decker trams. Such fun and a super efficient way to travel. Travellers MUST purchase an Octopus card as it allows easy travel on all tranport except taxis. This includes trams, peak access, ferries, rail and buses.
The best transport for sightseeing. This lovely old tram in hong kong is very good for sightseeing, my most favourite transportation in hong kong! But it only cover a little area of hong kong.

Get a seat on the top deck. To get here, we had travelled via MTR to Central Station. The trams are on Des Voeux Road. Enter the tram from the rear and you don't need to tap your Octopus card until when you get off the tram (beside the driver). We wanted to go to the terminus on the east. In order to do this you do not climb on the buses that say Whitty Street, Western Market, Causeway Bay, Shek Tong Tsoi, North Point or Happy Valley. They do not go to the eastern terminus station. At the terminus is a great market where you can spend a lot of time to browse, buy some fruits and cooked foods and snacks. We had a great lunch here (goose). We asked for them to chop it up in bite sizes. Make sure you bring tissues with you. You can return via MTR which is quicker but we decided to take the tram back to Central to see the other side of the street. You have such a good vantage point on deck too. Good people watching activity (folks on the street and on the tram). The air is not clean when all the windows are open on deck two because of all the fumes from the vehicles so if you are sensitive, stay on deck one.

Not a show stopper. We hopped on this after a night out just to say we had. It’s a slow way to get about and not particularly worth a special effort but it’s a ‘tick box thing’ that doesn’t take much time or money to do.

Slow but enjoyable. The fee for the tramway is very low, rather say it is symbolic, you never take this transportation when you are in a hurry, it is very very slow, a bit faster than a runner, you must enjoy every view of every street and shop out of the tram, must be aware that there is no air-condition!
LIke San Francisco CA. Good transportation option but that's about it. Similar to the folklore of San Francisco's cable cars.

Taking in the sights of HK. If you have a lot of time, and want to take in the city in its full hustle bustle, get on a tram and take a ride. Make sure you sit on the upper deck though and enjoy the view !

Old-World HK Experience. Riding the trams was an entertaining, old-world Hong Kong experience. Fun to ride and fun to watch! I loved seeing all the colorful advertisements on the outside of the trams.
Caution: If you are tall, watch your head when entering the upper level.

Great way to explore Hong kong island. This is a great and cheap way to see hong kong. For only HKG$2.50, this is way cheaper that taking the MTR. It runs through hong kong island. We did sit on the second level of the tram which gave us a better views. Its the same as taking a sight seeing bus. The trams could be very crowded and very slow because of the traffic during rush hours but if you are not in a hurry, this is a perfect way to move around in hong kong.

Its Fun even you dont have Fund. In this expensive city of Hong Kong, The tramways is the most cost effective service, commodity and transport whatever you say..! It feels so relaxed on the Tram even you don't need to know any address just step on the Tram and the Tramway itself will create the destination. Me and my colleagues just loved it..!

See Hong Kong in real fashion and it costs just peanuts. For HK$2.30 (about 30c) you can climb aboard the ding ding, go upstairs and see Hong Kong island from an absolutely ideal perspective. Watch the busy street life as you slowly travel from Central to Happy Valley, or hop on and off wherever you want. The open windows and minimalistic decor of the tram make you feel more like you're actually gliding through the streets and being part of it all. An absolute steal, you'd be crazy to miss it. Just bring plenty of coins.

Memory lane comes alive. What value for money! Just a little over 2 HK Dollars and you can rumble along the tracks on Hong Kong island. The changing scenery is amazing and life with all its variations is there right in front of your eyes.Sit on the top deck and your view will be even better. If you have time try to take the whole trip from end to end. Not all trams cover the entire route but even if you only go part of the way it is so much fun.When most transport is soul less and faceless the trams in Hong Kong exude charm and character. A real working time machine that still forms a really useful, not to metion cheap mode of travel for locals and vistiors alike.Do not miss this one!
Great, cheap way to see the city. It was so easy to hop on a tram and go wherever you wanted for such a small amount of money. A good way to see many parts of the city.

Simply Amazing. The trams have a long history in this city. They're simply an amazing way to get around the city.(mostly available and running on the HK Side area) Great way to get some awesome pictures if your into city photography, and romantic at night if your with your special someone.

cheap and efficient. the one thing i love about the tram is how efficient it is to get past a traffic congestion. At just HK$2.30, you literally skip past any traffic conjestion as the trams run on their own dedicated pathway

The best tourist value in town. Take this tram for a sightseeing visit of the real Hong Kong. We travelled from the City Hall area to the North Terminus where we then spent half an hour in the local market. We were the only Caucasians in the market and enjoyed a break from the big brand shopping experience of the tourist areas of the city. The wares offered in the market included live fish of all types, hardware, t-shirts, baked goods, fruits and vegetables. Prices were low and quality was high. The tram service is very good and a best buy way to see a part of Hong Kong that is off the beaten track. Bring lots of pocket change - exact fares are required.

Must Do!. this is how i like my vacation to be. not wandering into tourist spots..but do it like the locals.. this is one way you can enjoy Hongkong..in " slowmotion" and just enjoy the scennery.take a short trip or long trip...and stop at the nearest MTR. Or just go back with another tram.easy, cheap, and memorable. enter front the rear door and exit from the front door. sit on the upper deck.use you octopus!LOVE IT!

cheap way to see the city. cheap and nice way to see hong kong island. got on from central station, then took a tram to happy valley terminal. dropped off halfway at causeway bay MTR station for shopping. Try to take it during off peak hours, else u will have to squeeze with the locals. i took it during 2-3pm and it was ok. There's plenty of tourist taking the trams. great and cheap experience. U do not have to pay when u board (boarding is via rear entrance of tram only). U only pay when u alight. i think it's a flat fare regardless of distance. U pay via cash/octopus at the front of the tram when u alight.

Brilliant way to see Hong Kong without pounding the streets!. We absolutely loved travelling on the trams. They are a bit different and feel auhpthentic and cost very little (a fixed fee per trip of around 2HKD! So you can hop on and off as much as you want to explore a bit more on foot. If you sit upstairs you get a great view and you can absorb all the hustle and bustle on the street without wearing out your feet. Great way to people watch too!

A fun ride. We took the tram to and from Causeway Bay - our first time on the tram. It was very crowded and we we're impressed by the politeness of our fellow passengers, not only giving up their seats for us but their courtesy to one another.

Best way to experience Hong-Kong. This is an amazing way to experience this vast metropolis. It is also very cheap and convenient and it’s the best way to identify places that you want to see the next day. We had a front sit which made it perfect for us to take some great pictures. The trams are amazing and they are among few surviving from colonial past and so far I think it’s the best way to go across the Island of Hong-Kong. This experience will show you Hong-Kong as you’ll never see it again. Definitely recommend it.
Yesteryear. Very authentic, real time-period trams. From a time before air-conditioning, so open all the windows :-) This is on the Island Side and what a great way to explore from the top deck.

Tip. Weekends and the national holidays are the time when the tram is very crowded. Avoid this time to travel. It took us almost 3 hours to catch the tram to the Peak and almost 2 hrs to catch the bus to come back to central.

A great way to experience downtown hong kong island. taking the tramways allowed me to see most parts of downtown hong kong island. it stretches from east to the west part of the island. a caution is that it is not the fastest transportation, but it is the cheapest. i guess you pay for what you get. it does get crowded at peak hours in the morning, lunch and evenings. not for those who are carrying lots of things. its worth the experience.take the upper deck.
A step back in time. It's fun and exciting, and thee Chinese help you with the proceedures and stops, fares, etc., don't miss this.

Another way to get around, cheap and something different. Worth a trip as it's so easy to get on and off. You can also use your Octopus card to pay for the fare. They are just a nice different way to get around on these still somewhat vintage trams. Can get crowded at times, but just all part of the experience.
Thrill. Short ride but surreal as you come down the steep mountain it feels like the buildings are falling over. Good idea is to walk up and take the tram down.

Still Fun, Cheap and a way to see the REAL Hong Kong. For a second time we took the slow, rattling tram along Hennessy Road (on Hong Kong Island) to Shek Kai Wan. Get a front seat upstairs and you'll see so much to take in and talk about.Cost is just $HK 2.3- about 30centsUSD - walk in the back, grab your seat and drop the money into the box as you exit from the front. Ride it to the terminus, wander about the fascinating Shek Kai Wan village for a while and the head back on the much speedier MTR to wherever you are staying.Guarantee you'll love it !!!!

So cheap and so muchfun. This is an institution in HK.You HAVE to tide a tram and its only HKD 2.30 for you trip no matter how short or long.I remember trams in the UK from my youth so this was gret fn
Interesting and very cheap. The regularity of service. The sights, especially at night. The low price. The convenience.Dislike that it's not on Kowloon side....

Perhaps once. Never having experienced the tram, I thought it a good way to get from Wanchai to Central. It is, possibly. If you are tall and on the upper deck, much crouching is needed to see where you are going. Furthermore, the trams can get packed and, therefore, any one concerned about SARS or other diseases might want to think twice. Personally, I think it's worth doing once.

Always fun. It isn't a trip to HK without visiting the mountaintop! This time there was no fog and the view was fantastic. It was crowded but manageable. I think we waited for two trams, but we had seats. Be careful when you are buying your tickets though. The 428 viewing thing is a bit of a scam. You don't need to pay extra unless you want to go to a bit higher of a view. If you just want to make it to the top, buy the cheaper ticket.

when in HK, try this. My friends tried this when we went to Hong Kong. It is slow but a great way to see the city especially at night when the it is all lit up. For only HK$2.3, you can have a tour at the city. Have a seat on the top deck for better views. Do remember though that it may get crowded during rush hours. You don't need a map, and don't be afraid to get lost, just ride on the tram and get off wherever tram stop you want, there's always an MTR station nearby. You can choose to go from the east to west or the other way around.

Original, Historic and a Must Do. The Hong Kong Trams are iconic and have been trundling through the city for over 100 years. There are various routes but they mainly follow each other backwards and forwards bisecting the centre of Hong Kong Island. They provide mobile grandstands to the hustle and bustle of the City and travel slowly enough to enable great pictures to be taken from the airy top deck. The system is to join the tram from one of the special stops throughout the route initially get on at the back of the tram. When you reach your destination leave from the front (there are two staircases). The fare is 2.30 HKD which is placed in the container by the exit. No change is given. A great bargain.

the cheapest way..... to see Hong Kong. Take the tram to east and west and enjoyon the upper deck the life of Hong Kong. You see and smell the real Hong Kong. Make sure you have your Octopus Card fortram, subway and ferry, even for shops and McDonald.
Tram rides were great. If you have the time, ride one of the trams for the fun of it. During Sundays and rush hour, it can get crowded, but hop on and enjoy the ride.

Mass Transit all the way. Ride at least once. The best way to travel as a tourist. Top deck. You can sight see while moving through this modern city at a good rate. I used if for the majority of my travel in HK.

Fun but slow way to see the island. Hop on one to see the island. It's not fast, at times I think walking might have been faster but it's fun and cheap, in October 2013, it was 2.30 for each ride in cash or with the octopus card. Go to the top and watch the world go by, Hong Kong style.
Cheap and good. Tram rides were great. The rides were really cheap so i took them around HongKong island. Saved me lots of time and energy! View from the tram was a pretty good too.

Nice if not crowded. This is a great and inexpensive way to check out the city of Hong Kong, but only if it isn't crowded. On some, we were able to sight see, and just relax. On others, we were packed in. It can be a hit or miss, but worth a shot.

Our experience. Was crowded and had to wait for about 10 trams to go through before we would for in one. Was not a pleasant experience for us as we had to stand very cramped and really didn't get too see anything.

Vital transport link. Staying in an apartment in Kennedy Town, the tram became my main means of transport on this last stay.Excellent way of seeing local life (sit upstairs) and a cheap and relatively quick way of moving through lower levels from West to East. The line goes close to most tourist/hotel/shopping areas on HK Island. A standard HK$2.30 per trip (pay getting off) use an Octopus card for convenience.Only downside is spotting your stop coming up, especially if downstairs at the back in a crowded tram!
Just to say we did.. We rode the tram to save a bit of walking and just to say we did. Fun,cheap and easy to use. Great way to see a bit of the city.

Great and cheap way to see HK. Although the trams can be very crowded, and therefore best avoided during rush hour, as well as impossibly slow for a city like Hong Kong, a ride on the tram is a great way to see the city, and has the added benefits of being inexpensive, and you can hop on and off at your leisure.

superb experience. it's been an unforgettable experience riding in tramways,we went there from sheung wan station, after quick sightseeing at Western Market,all the way down to causewaybay (around timessquare).The view is nice, especially near Bank of China tower, the speed is just right for taking picture,Up level is recommended,it's just the weather which minus, It'll be perfect if we go there in winter,cheerrsss

Different !. Thin, rattly and crowded, you feel like you have stepped back in time when you board one of these trams, however, they are a must as part of the Hong Kong experience. Very cheap - you pay as you get off.
A great way to view Hongkong. I love these trams and a ride on them (up the top of course) is a great way to view hongkong. Just 30 mins can give you a different perspective

Kids Loved the Trams!. This is an inexpensive way to sample the streets of Hong Kong. Jump on and try and make your way up the narrow staircase to the top deck. Pay on the way out, try and have the correct change but throw whatever you have in and driver doesn't seem too worried. I could have gazed out the windows at street life all day and kids were glued to the windows too. A must do!
Trams. What a wonderful tourist attraction, as well as a means of getting around the CBD of Hong Kong. Dirt cheap too, HK$2.30 or about 30 cents USD or Aussie .

Cheap and cheerful way of getting across town. When travelling from Central to Causeway Bay we always get the 'ding ding' trams.They cost just over $2 and you pay when you leave. It's a slightly longer route than the MTR due to the traffic and the constant stops but you get to see things you don't see when journeying underground. Well worth it if you are not in a hurry.
Cheap and Easy way to see Hong Kong Island. Cheap and Easy way to see Hong Kong Island. Took it from Central to Causeway Bay. Easy to commute during rush hour. It is a must do.
Nice way to tour the city. It is little slow and stops almost every 200 meter but nice, clean and goes all around the city. It is very cheap 2.5HK$ for a ride.

A FUN ride. We were staying in the New Territories and took the bus into the city. Got off the bus, walked a bit, then hopped the 'ding ding' to take a 'riding tour' of the city. It was fun and due to traffic, not fast, so you could really look around and take pictures as you traversed the city. Jumped off to find the Harley Davidson store to get a shot glass.
Awesome travel mode to the Peak. Must travel by the tram to the peak its really awesome the way the authenticity is maintained. It is on a bit expensive side but its totally value for money.

No visit without a ride. You can't visit Hong Kong without a ride on the famous Tram way on the Island, catch it from one end to the other but try to get the front seats up stairs, its great fun, cheap but watch your head if you are tall, they run from early to late and are a better way to see things than the MTR, do it

Do take the Ding Ding. Always try out the tram which runs along the north side of Hong Kong island outside of the office rush hours. What I love about HK is that is very much a walking city. Few people except politicians and Tai Tais (ladies who lunch), drive in Central so the best way to get short distances is by tram. Enter via the back platform and make your way upstairs, grabbing the handle bars as you go. The tramlines turn and you find yourself being suddenly jostled hard. The best view I think is not at the front but the back = cool cruising, superb photo ops of the many hanging neon signs at night. You only pay as you get off downstairs at the front.10/10 for value and atmosphere. Not recommended for the infirm and those with strollers, too hard to get through the entry turnstiles. Don't wear stilettos either, easy to get caught in the wooden floors. Take also crossing the roads to board the trams as the platforms are in the centre of multi-lane roads shared with double decker buses, mini buses, taxi, rick shaws and bikes!"Where is the tram = Ding ding hai bin doh?"
Great to get from East to West. Make sure you have exact change and move up to the front of the tram before your stop so that you can get off easily as they're pretty crowded.
A Trip Back In Time.. A wonderful idea to have vintage double decker trams running through the City.Whilst it is fully functional it gives one a feeling of travelling back in time.

For those who seek a different way to ride HK. I have taken many times the "Tram" in HK. Practical and easily accessible, convenient when in Central. It can get very overcrowded but it is also part of the charm. Try the big tour, it will give you a good feel of the city.
Unbelievable angles.. Taking the tram to the Peak is a must on any trip to Hong Kong. You will not believe the steepness of the climb to the top. Beautiful views at the top both by day and night.

Sight seeing on the ding , ding. A cheap and convenient way to see the sights and go from one end of H-K island to the other.Ride at night for a romantic feeling and catch the colorful night life. A cheap must do , Ding - ding

Best for city tour . Don't want to get into crowd and walk too long. Sitting in an old slow tram is the best option to see the city. It's cheap and just sit down and enjoy the view but during off peak hours. If you're not going to view the city and going certain place, just take normal transport as trams are slower and it's open Windows. Full stars for it as sitting in an old tram services with city view and at a very cheap costs.

Cheap and Convenient. The locals nickname the trams 'ding-ding'. They are the most convenient and cheapest mode of transport on congested HK Island. Although they are very packed like sardines during the day, they make a romantic ride at night, catching breeze from the windows and watching the colourful illuminated HK streets.

Enjoyable way to see main part HK island. A simple and fun way to see the main commercial area of Hong King Island. Riding on the top level at the front gives a good view. Only thing to watch -- they are very narrow so keep your shopping or carry bags to a minimum!
Must do. Our children enoyed the tram too much, they wanted to ride them all the time. It's a fun thing to do, possibly when seated. Try the ferry to Kowloon too, old timer.
great night trip. Great ride at night from one end of the island to the other. A very efficient way to get around, octopus card friendly.

fun ride. like - fare is cheap for long distance ride
dislike - breathing bad air and bumper ride
this is my 3rd time taking a ride on a tram and the seat is limited but the frequency is very close. so no worries if you missed one :)

Lots of fun for just $2.3 (HKD). The trams are both useful and fun to use. They are cheaper than the MTR, busses, and taxi's but provide a better feeling of the city. Just hop-on a tram (you need to pay near the driver before getting off), go to the top floor, listen to the fun ding-ding sound and enjoy everything you use.

Enjoyable and fun ride. This trip, we decided to visit the less touristy bits of Hong Kong and we found the trams a great way to travel around to areas like North Point and Fortress Hill. The MTR might be faster but it travels below ground and you will miss seeing locals going about their business, as well as the different vibes and nature of the various neighborhoods that the trams pass through, from Chai Wan to Sheung Wan, via Central and Causeway Bay etc. Stops are relatively close together and you can hop on and off at your convenience. Each ride costs $2.40 and you pay upon exiting the tram at the front. Do note that the tram is a leisurely ride, so make sure you have a relatively flexible schedule.

Rattle, clatter, shake...great fun!. I can see why the locals hate these things, they are slow, hot and often crowded. But from a travellers perspective Hong Kong's trams are a must do. The first thing that you notice is how physically small they are, the modern double decker buses in HK dwarf the old trams. The ride is often comically slow and corners are often taken with an alarming grating and clattering noise. All of which in my opinion adds to the experience! You can probably jog faster than the trams in some places, so its not a transport option when in a hurry...We used the trams daily over a ten day stay and really got to appreciate the details of street life that you can see from the open windows of the top deck Practical tips: Board at the rear doors, avoid early mornings when they seem to be stupidly busy, pay on leaving by dropping the fare into the box at the front door, its HK$2.30 per adult and HK$1.20 per child.

Sight Seeing? Time Travel? Or just for Transport!. The Hong Kong Tramways are really cheap, actually too cheap!
