Best Value in Hong Kong. The only way to enjoy travel within Hong Kong, irrespective of the route one , as someone over 65 can travel for 10 pence ( $1.20 H Kng) travel with the locals , most can speak english and will gladly help out if you seem lost.
Great!. They are old, slow and crowded - and great fun! We travelled by tram to the Happy Valley race course. Go upstairs and watch the crowds on the streets.
They never change. These wonderful old trams just keep on going and a great way to see the island and get to out of the way places like Northpoint

Rattling along. At $2.30 per ride (cheaper with an Octopus card), and sitting up on the second deck, its the only way to see Hong Kong Island. It's slow, noisy, you can't stick your body parts out the window, and its hard to walk up with narrow steps to the second level,but what a view! Don't miss this ride.
Old style. No other way to see Hong Kong except on a 'ding ding'...as the natives call them...plus at HK$2 for a ride as long as you want it's a steal

Best Way to see the city. The best way to get around (for a short distance) and to see the city and people watch. The route is simple and basically goes from the west end(Kennedy town where their are a lot of new French bistro and bakery) to the east end (Shaukeiwan where you can find the tastiest Chinese restaurants); then of course in the middle of the route is Central District where you can find EVERYTHING. Go for the whole route or just hop on for a section. Cost is close to nothing and you can see EVERYTHING. Upstair is of course the best view and if you do not go at peak hours (8-10 in the morning and 5-7 in the evening) you can almost always get a seat. Don't miss this!
Do it!. It's the cheapest way to see the north side of Hong Kong island and gives you the full experience of living in Hong Kong.

Taking in the sights at a slower pace. Taking the ding-ding is a great way to experience Hong Kong Island from end-to-end at a relaxing pace. What's more, it is quite cheap compared to going the same route by other modes of public transport. However, due to the lack of air-conditioning and the fact that it can be quite crowded, it is probably best to experience this during a cooler season and not during the peak hours. It can also be a bit difficult for people with lots of baggage, shopping bags or prams to go up and down the ding-ding since it's a bit small compared to the usual double-decker bus.

Journey in time. The best way to see HK Island, and almost free (2,30 HKD no matter how far you travel). But mind your head - the cieling is low. In rtush hours it is quicker than the buses and much nicer than the MTR. Buy an Octopus electronic card for 150 HKD - gives you 100 to travel for and a deposit of 50, whereof 41 wikll be returned when you leave. With this card you can also pay for smaller purchaes (7-11) or fast food.
Fun way to explore. Fun way to explore HK Island and see the various neighborhoods. Definitely slower than bus or MTR but less expensive and a good way to spend some time before meeting friends.

Rise to the top. I really wanted some breath taking pictures so My wife and Itook a taxi from Admirilaty Station to the base of the mountainwhere the tram began.I wanted some pictures with the sun still up,we arrived there at 4.30 still light stood in a 400m queue, by the time I got to the topit was dark.We paid an extra 30HK$ for the special skyview.When we got to the top we took 10 sets of escalators to the top just to find I was facing people about 10 thick, I litraly had to fight my way for about an hour to the edge and as I tried to take picsI was bumped and pushed by other people wanting the same thing.The view is breathtaking but the rest sucks.

Ding Ding is a fun experience. but don't go on it if you don't like being squashed as they always seem to be full. A different way to get from Central to Causeway Bay and much more interesting than the MTR

Almost magical experience. From my experience the best way to feel the city is to get to this old-fashioned double-decker and enjoy the ride from the one side of the city to another. Get yourself a sit on the second level by the window and enjoy watching people, traffic, buildings and dynamic of the city. Good opportunity to take photos of urban life. Get on from the back door and get off from the front paying 2 HK dollars regardless of teh length of your journey. The weather was pleasant in March an I fully enjoyed the ride. But I guess it might be pretty hot during summer (there are no ACs in trams).

If you use the tram a lot - aware of the availability a 4 days unlimited ride pass. We recently spent over six days in Hong Kong and stayed at one of the hotels in the Western district. The Western district has no MTR coverage - tram is the cheapest way to get to a MTR station.We ordered a 4 days unlimited tram ride pass before our arrivals in Hong Kong. This turns out to be a real money saver for us since we use the tram everyday. A single ride on the tram costs HK $2.30 for adult. A 4 days tram pass costs HK $34.Also, the tram terminates at different point - if you want to continue the ride beyond the termination point, the passenger needs to pay the tram at the termination point and pay again when getting off the transferred tram. We saved quite a bit because of the ride pass.We ordered the 4 days ride pass directly from the Hong Kong Tramways website. Many people we met in Hong Kong did not know such a product is available. Tram travels real slow - so if you are in rush, skip the tram and get a cab to the closest MTR station. But if you want a slow close up look at Hong Kong, ride on the upper deck of the tram and you get a very different perspective of Hong Kong Island.
An excellent way to see the city. pick up a travel card from an MTR station and use it on the trams to tour round the city. If possible, get on one of the older ones for an authentic experience

Not the fastest way of transportation. They are cheap and from the upper deck there is a nice view over the streets. This makes it worth taking the trams a few times. However, the metro is normally a much faster way of transportation so it should be used when time matters.

Great for travelling on Hong Kong Island. These are cheap transport in which you enter the back of the tram and go out the front. Use your Octopus card.
Gives you an experience of using transport in the streets of Hong Kong and you can see the shops and streets. You dont have to go up and down stairs, lifts etc.

Hong Kong Tramways . We used the trams all over the city also all the other city transport the different colours of the trams going all through the centre of H.K. we were staying for 6 days so bought a travel card which proved very good value
very busy. there are many people in the tramway and smeling not enough aircondition in the tramway.but for short destination it is good.
Excellent cheap way to see HK. Easy to use and navigate, get a seat on the top at the front if you can! Worth the 20p cost for any trip

The best way to see the city. Amazing value and the opportunity to ride in the 'ancient' trolly busses. A great way to see the city of to hop from place to place. Sample everyday life and watch the sights go by...
very good. great way to get about lets you see more than on underground just put 2.30 in box next to driver when getting off

Just love the quaint trams. Perfect mode of cheap travel in central HK. Well connected. Some of the coaches are from ancient times ( made of wood etc) and that really makes them shine. Double Decker buses although small are fun and cheap way of travel.
Slow pace is compensated by the frequency.
Go ahead take a ride!!
Trams. Loved getting around HK on these trams, they are cheap and you get awesome views of the cities. Friends thought this was a lot of fun for seeing HK.

Nice ride. It was a nice ride and you get a fine overlook over Hong Kong.
The old tram cars are really nice.
It is really crowded, so we had to wait about an hour.

Awesome way to see the city and get places. Price was nominal. Get an octopus card for all the transportations in HK. We were there for 4 days and between 9 Metro, 2 trams, 3 busses, the star ferry 2x, and taxis, we only spent about $35 USD. Taxis are cheap but the Trams is cooler and the view better. Another HK must

A ride into memory lane. The HK Tramways ride has to be one of the best deals in Hong Kong in terms of going back down memory lane. The trams remain basically unchanged since the beginning of time and the fares also remain somewhere in the past. If you have the time take the tram from one end of the island to the other end and you will see some of the best street scenes of Hong Kong. It will take time but be patient and enjoy the ride.

ride the ding ding!. The tram system on Hong Kong island is a great way to travel around the island as it gives you a flavour of the history of Hong Kong and its unbelievably cheap at 2.3 HKDs (about 0.2 GBP or 20p) The system is simple, you hope on at the back of the tram and to you move to the front to get off. You pay upon getting off byt depositing the correct fare in the money machine or by using the Octopus system (which is much more simple).The trams are double decked and its a great and cheap way to explore Hong Kong. Hope on at Central in the West and travel all the way to the East (Shau Kei Wan) or vice versa. Enjoying stunning views of Hong Kong, it travels at a fairly steady pace which is good for taking photos and soaking up the different atmospheres each part of Hong Kong has to offer. The tram does not stop at every stop along the line. It only stops if someone is waiting to board or if you stand near the front (exit doors) so allow time to get to the front doors if you intend to get off at the next stop - especially when the tram is packed.The tram is not air conditioned so its best in the cooler seasons, in the summer you might prefer the MTR for the air conditioning. The locals refer to the trams as "ding ding" owing to the sound that it makes.It is by far one of my favourite ways to get around Hong Kong island.

Best view in town.. It runs from the western to eastern part on Hongkong. HKD2.3 per trip no matter where you alight. Board the tram at the back and exit from the driver door. Very cool especially thru Central and Wanchai. Is a very good experience riding the tram.

Ride the Iconic Hong Kong Trams with a Century of History. The iconic Hong Kong double-decker tram celebrates its 100th year on the tracks in 2012.As one of the oldest member of Hong Kong’s world renowned public transport system, it is the cheapest ride at HK$2.3 (< 30 US cents) that takes you from one end of the Hong Kong Island to the on other. Trams runs on their own tracks that guarantee a consistent and reliable travel time, relatively unaffected by traffic condition.Single-decker trams were first introduced to Hong Kong in 1904, follwed by open-air double-decker trams in 1912, and finally the closed double-decker trams we know today arrived in 1925.163 double-decker trams are in service today, making them the largest tram fleet in the world. They run the 85-minute 13km along the north side of Hong Kong Island from Kennedy Town at the western end to Shau Kei Wan on the east side with a 3km single-track “loop” running through Happy Valley, where Jockey Club's race-course is located. Tram Number 50 was withdrawn from service in 1991 and can now be seen on display in the its original 1950s condition in the Hong Kong Museum of History. In 2010, a new generation of trams was introduced replacing the wood-frame tram bodies with aluminium ones. Tram 168 was the prototype.As Hong Kong tramways celebrates its century of the double decker tram services, visitors and locals look forwards to continue enjoying the inexpensive and reliable journeys.

British Engineering. It's hard to imagine that 100 years ago this tramway went round the very edge of the island, land reclamation now finds it about 2 miles inland at least. Tiny electric trams, barely big enough for Westerners, but a great view of everything on the outskirts of the island up to Happy Valley racecourse. The standard low fare is payable by depositing coins, make sure you have them first, then you can stay on as long as you like, upstairs is best.A "must do" in Hong Kong, great picture opportunities

Hong Kong Trams. These are bags of fun to ride on, clattering and humming along they epitomise the difference between old and new HKG. Most trams are several decades old but there are also some new additions, compare this somewhat "primitive" mode of transport to the state of the art integrated transport systems now populating this country. For a couple of dollars HKG you could stay on a tram all day if you wanted to. From Western Market to Kennedy Town or Happy Valley these delightful vehicles ply their trade all day and nearly all nght. Get a front seat upstairs if you can for the views, but be prepared for a stop every few meters and having to fight your way off down the steep stairway thru the "saloon" type doors. You can use your Octopus card, this is a totally invaluable travel pass, buy it at any MTR station and top up at same when needed. What's more you get the balance left on it back when you finally surrender it, less a mandatory deposit. A Must Do ride. Try "tram spotting" to see how many different sponsor logos you can find, I filmed one advertising Yorkshire!! (UK)
Too small. Good fun ride but way too many people allowed on the tram, not my cup of tea but cheap way to get around

old style but good way of transport in Hong Kong. It looks very old fashion but actually it is a very cheap and good way to travel around Hong Kong. The fare is only $2.3 for adult and $1.2 for children and you can tour around Hong Kong from the Eastern part to the Western part of Hong Kong Island. If you are travelling off peak hours, you can enjoy the wind breeze sitting on the upper deck. One can sit on the tram for hours without getting off to enjoy the sight of Hong Kong views.

Excellent sightseeing for the small budget. The Hong Kong tram is a nice way to see the sights for just a few HKD. Easiest for all of Hong Kong transport is to buy an Octopus Card and you'll just hold it against the machine when exiting the tram.Just hop on at a station, take a seat upstairs and enjoy the ride. And keepy our camera ready! If you're done, just go back in the opposite direction.

One of the best ways to get around the Island.. These tough double-decker trams are the way to get around the flatter areas of the Island. And so cheap. As pensioners we paid HK$1.10 (Aust 14c) per trip, popping the exact coins into a slot then scrambling up the stairs to get the front seats for the cheapest trip on the Island! Go to the end of the line and be fascinated (and educated!)
Cheap, cheap, cheap!. Slow but atmospheric and gives you time to look around as you go. Top deck for better views.Sit back and enjoy.

A great way to see the bustle life of Hong Kong. The tramway has been serving HK since 1904. It is still being used as a main form of transportation today. It travels across the Hong Kong island. It is slow moving. So, this is actually a good choice for visitors who want to see the daily bustle life of Hong Kong. By the way, the Tramways also offer "party tram." You can rent a tram for party.

Great Way to See The Core Parts of Hong Island. If you have time and want a relaxing way - and cheap way to see the core parts to HK Island - this is for you.. travels along the Vic Harbour part of the island, covering key areas like Central, Wan Chai, Happy Valley .. and so cheap.. just plan as not all services will continue and require a tram change.

A bumpy, noisey, sparky ride through time. Want to relive the old days of Hong Kong when Bruce Lee could be seen busting heads in the dingy, crowded alleyways of the city? A trip on one of Hong Kongs old trams could be just the ticket. The trams run along the northern waterfront of Hong Kong Island. They are hard to miss due to the wires, rail track and the incredible racket they make. There is no mistaking the noise of an approaching trolley. They run very frequently so they are also a good way to get around, although the buses may be faster except at rush hour.Whether or not the bus is faster, it doesn't even come close to the experience of actually riding in one of these spam cans on wheels. If fortune is smiling upon you, you may just be lucky enough to snag one of the wooden seats, the vibration of which is enough to rearrange your skeleton into a modern art piece. Otherwise, find something (or someone) to hang on to while the trolley rolls along through the concrete jungle of Central and Wan Chai. Breathing is considered a luxury when the trams are full. Final thought: Leave your claustrophobic friend at the hotel, grab your octopus card and hop on!
a total thrill. best way get a first glance of this exciting city, inexpensive, requires no knowledge of the place, and lots of fun

The local tramways.. A very cheap way to get about the main city area which the locals use. Sit on the top deck and enjoy watching the hustle and bustle of the city. At $2.30 per person per trip its a bargain.

Old & historical transport - must try to view Hong Kong. The tram, old & historical transport, is only available in Hong Kong Island (no service in Kowloon or New Territories). It travels from western to eastern part of Hong Kong Island and vice versa (about 1 hour for single trip from the east to west). In between, you may stop by Central (the commercial area, Lan Kwai Fong for dinner or drink at night time), Admiralty (with grand shopping mall like Pacific Place), Causeway Bay (a very busy spot crowded of people with lots of shopping areas, dining places. The big and famous shopping mall is Times Square). You may also take the tram to Happy Valley, a living area with lots of dining places as well as Happy Valley Racecourse. The fare is the cheapest (HK$2.3 for adult & $1.2 for children under 12) among all other transports. If you have time, you must have a try, better on upper deck where you can have a relaxing trip, view all the old and new buildings, shops, rushing people. You are highly recommended to buy an Octopus card (available at all train stations) which could basically be used for all transports in Hong Kong such as tram, bus, MTR train (except taxi) and even for shopping at supermarkets. I recommend this to all tourists coming to Hong Kong.
Experience in an experience. Nothing like travelling back in time. Very cheap, very entertaining to some, others may find it not as entertaining, but there is plenty to see and do.

One of the last remnants of Old Hong Kong. For any traveler to Hong Kong the old Tramways are well worth the trip. One of the last remnants of Old Hong Kong they are old but move along surprising fast!You can go from one side of the island to the other so you get to take in the wonders of Hong Kong, from the older markets and streets to the more modern areas!One trick from childhood was to place a coin on the tram tracks and watch and wait until a tram rolls over it - then you have a very flat coin! They can be hot when picking them up so give it a minute and make sure another tram is not on the way :)

Cold and not very efficient.. I was sat downstairs by the window initially as it was a nice day, but every single window was open and it got very cold. Although the driver was very fast (alarmingly so at times) the stops are so frequent that it seems to take forever to get anywhere.Great if you're going a short distance, but if you're going anywhere that takes more than 10 minutes I would advise you to use the MTR or walk if you have the time.

A real treat. Running across the width of the island, you can travel end to end for a tiny fare. From the top deck you can enjoy the bustle and the sights and experience the old fashioned roll of the double deck trams bringing back memories of how it used to be in the Uk. A very frequent service with trams almost queing one behind the other. Pay as you exit, same fare for any length of journey but you must have the correct small change. On our first visit having just arrived we only had banknotes. The driver was no help and were rescued by a friendly local who paid our modest fare. An octopus card is better. We have been to HK 3 times and on each occasion have enjoyed a ride. Don't miss it.
A great way to see Hong Kong. Sit up top and get to see the city, just don't be in a rush, tram takes a long time. Very inexpensive HK $2.90
Cheap Transport. The trams are a cheap and easy way to get aroud, running every few minutes its a must way to travel. Get an octopus card to save fumbling for change each trip,

Cheap and cheerful. Great transport to travel around the key destinations on HK island. Not ideal if you are in a rush and travel at peak hour. Great weekend ride as it is relaxing and get to see the real HK.

Cool touristy thing to do. You should definitely ride it for the experience that it is. It is cheap and you get a chance to see the streets of HK in several different areas. It is a bit slow if you're actually trying to get somewhere. I was in HK for 5 weeks, so for practicality, I preferred the subway.

Fabulous!. We loved the trams! Make sure you have the right money. Coins only ... 2.30 HKD per person. Hop on at the back and pay as you get off! You can get a great feel for Hong Kong as you travel down the streets. The trams come all the time and you just hop on and off as you like.

Cheapest and most useful of HK attractions. Take tram somewhere not very close to Central, then you have almost a guarantee to have seat on head of upper deck. Since then, just look around :) And it is not attraction with sightseeing only. It is really useful transport, which allow you to cross all (at least interesting) areas of HK island for cheapest price.

The best way to enjoy Central!. I prefer travel by Tram on the Central side as it is certain that you can enjoy the surrounding view of Hong Kong, in just 1.20 HKD per trip.No car traffic in Hong Kong!Your Octopus works here.
Great fun. Get an octopus card and travel on the trams that have been there forever. Can be crowded during rush hour and you wonder if you will be able to get off at your stop but you always can.
Great way to see the hustle and bustle. Take the tram instead of the MTR and see more of this very busy city! Take a seat on the top deck. And it's cheap too.

Classically slow. Riding on the tram was ok itself coz u feel like your in Old Hongkong...but when the tram gets stuck in traffic jam specially in busy streets and intersections and there's nothing much to see around...i wish i took the MTR instead!

A bit of History today. When on the north of Hong Kong Island you must use the trams, for people of my age it brings back memories, albeit vague ones, of the Glasgow trams so that is a bonus. However, the main attraction is that you can travel east to west across a lot the north of the North of the island and identify places that you may wish to visit later. It is also a great way to people watch and see locals about their normal activities. The fare is standard 2.3 HK dollars and is deposited in a cash collector on leaving the tram. It is important to note that the trams get very busy at rush hour and lunch times and can be busy most of the time at the weekend but then this also applies to the MRT and you cannot see much from it. Great to get to Happy Valley, Times Square and in and around Central and Hong Kong station where many of the attractions and much of the night life is centred

A cheap thrill. Want to have a view of bustling Hong Kong? You can hardly do better than taking a Hong Kong tram through Hong Kong Island on the second deck. You'll pass markets, skyscrapers, and busy people. All for a pittance.

Ding Ding Tour. We took the Ding Ding Tram from Kennedy Town without any plan were to drop off. It is the best way to tour around and get to know the Hong Kong Island. The tram is quite slow but on the other side you will have more time to observe and see how the locals live their life. It is also the best way to see the Island into different angle and perspective..
Awesome!. the best way to get around central and wanchai. It's cheap and clean though it may be bit slow so enjoy the ride and View of Hong Kong!

Cheap travel, street level views. Buy an octopus card, which will allow you to use the ding dings. Not as quick as the MTR but if you want to see Hong Kong at street level, this is a good way to do it!

best way for sight seeing and people watching. It is slow moving, but it is definitely the best way to see the city on Hong Kong Island. Find a seat on the double deck and enjoy the scene. It travels through the City, Central, Happy Valley and many other scenic spot. It is fun to people watch, you can really notice the difference between neighborhoods. Highly recommended.

historical city tour. you can take the historical tramways in Hongkong and can go to Causewaybay area (financial district) ,It takes almost 1 hour depends on traffic, it is so cheap (4H$) but be careful, you have to pay exactly 4 otherwise they do not give you the change back.

This place reminded me of Melbourne Australia. Similar Trams to Melbourne Australia when I visted Melbourned many years ago. The fare is not as good value as Melbourne but the route is good and many attractions on the way to see
watch the world go by. in the hustle and bustle of the streets, getting on a tram and watching the world go by is a bit of relaxation. every district is different so best to stay on it all the way.

Just take a photo. Too crowded to enjoy. These trams are a cheap form of public transport rather than a tourist attraction. You will have a more enjoyable ride on the top deck of a double decker bus. Also check before boarding to see how far it goes.

San francisco.... Really cool, you pay at the end of your trip???
Really clean and civilised way to travel in this charming city...
and It doesn't cost much...

Cheap fare, & awesome views!. I loved the trams in Hong Kong, it is so old school, but so awesome! I took the tram in the evening and sat upstairs at the back and watched the streets and bright lights of Central go by.I would recommend it if you fancy a different means of transport! I think the fare was only like 2 or 3 HKD! :)
Easy. Travelling around the city by subway, tram or bus was simple and cheap. We found it amazing that a city of 7 million people could move around the city so easily
Fun. The double decker trams cover limited distance & are quite slow, but provide a novel change from the metro & buses.

too crowded for sight seeing. cheap transportation but very slow. Good to see the streets if it is not crowded as it moves at a very slow speed. However, most of the time, the tram is packed with people. Hard to move from one end to the other end to get off the tram.
Great fun. Travelling along the tramways is good, cheap fun! We caught the star ferry across and then travelled on the trams down to Times Square.

DING DING !! in Hong Kong.. A fun way to see parts of the city. Very cheap only 30 cents ( USD ) each way. You get to see daily life in this active city without having to drive or go on a tour. Sit upstairs for the best view.

Great little slice of history. Make sure you have some loose change to pay and take a ride just for the fun of it. I rode from Central to Kennedy Town just for the ride. The trams are narrow, tiny and convivial - several people entered into conversation with me. Sit at the top front for a good view, but downstairs for a more 'local' experience.

Kids Love the Tram. Like other reviews, this is by far the easiest and cheapest way to see Hong Kong. How do you beat this kind of price; HK$2.3 per journey for adults, HK$1.2 child (3-11) and HK$1.1 seniors (65 and over) and you can just sit and ride from one end to another and it's still $2.3. My children would be all excited sitting on the second deck looking and commenting at different sites and views. Then they'd get all sleepy due to jet lag and would take a nap, when they woke up, we're still on the tram as us parents also appreciated the view and some down time. If you'd like to go to the Bank of China by famed architect IM Pei, it will drop you off right out side and all you need is cross the street. To get to the top, which is free, be sure to bring your passport along.

Enjoyed it- fun ride. Very convenient and fun to ride specially seating on top part of double Decker. Very well maintained and very cheap to ride. I would strongly recommend for families with kids to ride from one end to other end of city. its same price. Route maps are posted on each station.

Front seat, upstairs on a Hong Kong tram - travellers' delight. Aim for the front seat upstairs on a Hong tram to Kennedy town or Causeway Bay, or .... and watch Hong Kong unfold. It is a brilliant way to see the sights while sitting down, and find new places to explore on foot - and all for HK$2.30!!
Fun and easy way to see some of HK island. Liked - good view of the action, traffic, and people; avoiding the heat; cheap; well-signed.Disliked - busy (but just wait for a seat).

Nothing special. We went there in the afternoon, the queue was unbelievable long. It took over 1 hour. And the same when we came back, we have to wait about 1 hour. Wasting our time. We rather seeing other places.
Must try once. The trams are frequent but slow and crowded. However, it offers passenger a different view of Hong Kong Island. Go to the second level for better view and more space.

Best Value in Town. For HK$2.20 you get a slice of history, a tour right through the heart of Hong Kong island if you stay on the tram, and get to observe the local people busy at their daily lives. Definitely not a tourist sight but a fully functioning part of HK, you get a real sense of the vibe of HK - the good, the bad, the hot (although now some of them are air conditioned) and often times local smell!

Cheap thrill. Cheap thrill at HK$2.30 only. Pick whatever routes you like as there are many to choose from. I like the one from Central to Happy Valley. It is less crowded and you have a better chance of getting a front seat on the upper deck which gives the best view. If money for value is what you want, look for one with the longest route and start from the terminal so as to get a good seat. At HK$2.30, what more can you ask.
Cheap and frequent. The fare is cheap-hkd2.3 and frequent, however it's a bit slow as it stop every time along many many tram stops.

fun ride and great city view. highly recommend for those who never try on tram! it is a must with just $2 HKG, pretty cheap to buy this great experience. you will have a chance to see Hong Kong city view on the street, recommend route is between central to causeway bay.

Take the tram. A must do for anyone visiting Hong Kong. They run every couple of minutes and you can go either one stop or the full journey (probably close to two hours!). It's unhurried observing of Hong Kong at its best.

A Cheap and Cheerful Way to Travel. During the years we lived in HK the tram was considered an easy if not quick way to go short diistances. If you have time duirng a visit please consider taking the tram from Kennedy Town to North Point. or vice versa .This could take up most of the morning but is the best way to get an overview of the city while sitting down. If your time is limited then get off in Central. You could then do one of the walks suggested in the Tourist pamphlets or go up The Peak. Whatever you decide, you should get on at a terminus so you get the best seats which are upstairs at the front.The tram ride begins in Kennedy Town ( Catchick Street ) which is the far western point of the harbour. For a short distance the line runs along part of the original route close to the harbour. Board the tram and go straight upstairs to the front seats (you pay by Octopus on alighting). From there you can sit comfortably and watch life in the bustling streets. The tram route was once on the waterfront but the harbour is getting narrower as the years go by. Getting to Kennedy Town is easy if you know the city but could otherwise be a hassle. You could get a tram going west outside the HCBC main branch in Queen’s Road Central . The destination should say Kennedy Town. Stay on until the terminus then pay, get off then straight back on again. If you do not want to do a longer trip at least try and use the tram at least once while in HK. It is a unique experience.

An old fashioned form of transport in a modern city.. Still an everyday way to get around Hong Kong island for many local people, it's a great, (and very cheap) way to transit the island. Loads of atmoshere from a bygone time.

Must do--slight long wait at entrance--but relaxing and get a glance of all f Hong Kong. Walk around the peak--good ex. Great vista of Island and great walk at top of Peak. Advise to have food at Soho at end of trip--short walk with galleries at Hollywood and wine bars at Soho.
Don't Miss. One should not miss. Should be in the things to do list. Just for few dollars you will be able to see the Hong Kong city.

Love these trams - excellent value and great frequency and views.. Just HKD 2.30 (or HKD 1.10 for age 65 and over) means the best value transport in town - going East / West across Hong Kong Island.Sometimes very crowded (especially 8/10 am and evening peak time) but the view from on top is great and the trams come along every minute. The steps are narrow and steep but the atmosphere is great. We loved the trams and used them in preference to the MTR and buses whenever possible. If you are in a hurry or have to go across to Kowloon, though, use the MTR.

The ONLY way to travel in HK Island. I will never get sick of riding these trams. It's the one place you could relax and have a seat while going from point A to point B in Hong Kong Island. You get to see all the districts from end to end unlike when you're in the MTR, you see nothing and everyone's in a rush. The tram is the best thing for laid back commuting travelers looking for an escape from all the HK busy-ness.

A view from above if you aren't in a hurry.. If you aren't rushed for time then a trip or two on the Ding Ding trams is a fun way to see some of Hong Kong Island. The view from the upstairs level gives you an aspect that you wouldn't get walking the streets. Gets you out of the crowd. Cheap (and easy using octopus card) and an interesting way to fill an hour.
felt like we were in SanFransisco. Very fun and fast. Great way to see the amazing architecture. Hop on and off was very easy. Only a few lines, very clean and efficient

For the taste of Old Hong Kong. If you're on vacation, I don't think you have too tight a schedule. For a simple $2.30HKD at least ride the ding ding once, in place of your regular trip on the island line MTR. The tram is slow-paced enough to cover more ground than by foot, but helps to take in the bustling street scenes.
Time Warp Of Travel. Still an effective method of travel.. A fixed, very low, fee per trip. the size and height of the trams shows how small people used to be. A must do experience.

Free city tour. A great start to a visit to Hong Kong. Sit up top and cross the city noting places you would like to come back to an explore. Super cheap and a great opportunity to mix with the locals.

After a week of treking spend a day on the tram. Trams are great in hk. Getting you everywhere cheaply and quickly.we always take a day ridding the tram from end to end of the island its a great way to see from above street level whats going on and if you see something you fancy just hop off and hop back on. Its a grest way of seeing hk without getting lost

I'm not a fan of hights. This was great. After awhile, I forgot that ships were sailing under us as we crossed the water. The tram is an engineering marval. It was really spell binding. When we got to the top, there is a small village. The perfict spot for a local beer or three
Quaint. A great way to get around and only HK$1 flat rate. A bit rickety though if you suffer from motion sickness

Must try! Cheap and interesting!. We took the tramp almost everyday since we were staying in Western Market. The ride is cheap and interesting but extremely slow. Try it if you have time to spare. It's worth every penny!

Great way of getting around HK and cheap!. The HK trams are a classic sight on the island city and provide a great alternative to getting around rather than using the MTR, buses or even walking. What makes them particularly easy to use, is that for the most part, they all follow one main line right through the heart of HK island, going through all the major areas (Sheung Wan, Central, Admiralty, Wan Chain, Causeway Bay etc), so even if you're not geographically familiar with the city, you can't really go wrong by hoping on one of them - just make sure you're heading in the right direction. During peak hours, they can get quite tight however, but for the most part they are fun to ride on. NOTE FOR TOURISTS - always board from the back of the tram, and when you get off you leave from the front door near the driver and this is also when you pay - either the flat fare or with your Octopus card.
Splendid experience. Very narrow and can be fully packed but comfortable way to get from one point to another. Paid at exit. Octopus cards accepted. Sit on upper deck because of the view of the city.

Tram ride a great treat. Worth the effort just board a tram at Causeway or close by and travel to the end of the line have a wander and return later trundling down the road on the old trams is gr eat and cheap.

squeezy ride. for only HK$2.3, one can travel on the hk island from east to west and vice versa with a good view of how people travel to work everyday and their respective culture (yes, shoving of people in the tram included unfortunately...)

A great and inexpensive way to see everyday Hong Kong. Hong Kong's options for transportation alone make it a city worth visiting!Like the Peak tram, and the Start ferry rides, the HK trams give passengers a unique ride and experience. It's been around for more than 100 years too.Sit on the upper deck for great views of the city roads. You can just look at the people and the shops from afar. And only for HK$2 a trip! (Pay on your way out, next to the driver)Suggestion for short trip (15 minutes): Central to Causeway Bay (Will pass Admiralty and Wan Chai)Suggestion for long trips (50 minutes to 1 hour): Causeway Bay to Shau Kei Wan(You can always take the MTR on the way back if you want to save time).

romantic and accessible ride. it is one of the rare treasures in Hong Kong. It is so accessible yet very romantic (as long as it is not too cramped with people). it is the cheapest ride in Hong Kong too.

Need to have little more information in the tram. Its nice to ride especialy on the upper deck. Coming from a city of trams i loved it. But since the driver speaks no English there should be some notice somewhere saying that people should pay exact change. Or else you lose your money. Not so easy for visitors to move around in it unless you have the map with you.
Ding Ding. This is such a great way to see the city in all its glory; hop on and off, very very cheap, and pay when you get off.

Great ride. Experience alot of the city and these old trams!We went on these a few times, mostly to get around but once to take in the views as well.Can be quite full and squished in, but thats part of it all!

Wonderful. This is a wonderful way to tour HKG Island.Can't get lost because there is pretty much only two directions.Bring your camera and sit at the front of the top deck. Tram is slow and stops a lot. Perfect for touring and photography.Oh it is also dirt cheap so you can afford to hop on and off.

Take the bus to Stanley. It is a great ride and you get a sense of the structure and detail of this city. Try sitting upstairs for the great views (and you wont really notice the traffic). It is one of the best vale for money experiences on offer.

great leisurely right through hkg island.. i take them from central to causeway bay and vice versa when I've got 10 minutes extra here or there and don't want to do the hong kong hussle through the busy subway.

Hong Kong looks different from the top of a tram. I took the tram one evening principally to avoid the hell that is Causeway Bay MTR station at rush hour, what a plesant surprise I had. The tram is small, narrow and has a very tight staircase to get on the top deck, it goes really slow and stops all the time but as you sit there watching the manic hong kong street life drift by on all sides slowly the clattering tram takes on the role of a calming oasis, when we finally reached Central I really didn't want to get off, loved the tram.

One of a kind transport!. This is the best of our trip. Where on earth do we get on an electric bus. It is a good way to sightsee the busy hong kong city. We went in the evening when the roads were getting busy. So to be able to squeeze our way up to the second deck and just sit and enjoy the ride. It moves slowly so we get to see the locals roaming about their daily lives. The neon lights, many signboards, loud voices, etc....just a very dramatic ride. Feel that we are in a hong kong movie.;)It costs $2.30 Hong Kong dollars. You must have exact change. It moves in designated area according to the rail track.When in Hong Kong, you must try this. However, it is a very small transport, narrow so may not be comfortable for certain passengers.We did not find Hong Kongers particularly friendly during the past week. Kind of strange....???

Good attraction if you visit. This tramway is one of the 2 ones to have 2 floors. Its design is old-fashioned and it is really nice. You only have tramways on Hong Kong Islands and it is sometimes very convenient to use it. When you are seated on the first floor, you have a nice view of the streets. You pay with your Octopus card so it's very fast but you can also pay with money if you have the exact payment of 2.3HKD (20cts euros!). However, a big part of the lines are mixed with the Hong Kong cars traffic jam and during peak hours it can take a lot of time to go from one place to another.

Efficient. The trams are narrow with 2 decks. At peak times they get very busy. The trams are on HK island and are very regular and cheap. One journey is $2.30 pp. Make sure you have the correct fare. We stayed in Wan Chai so travelled to Causeway Bay and Central a few times. A great way to travel is you're too tired to walk.
Nice at night.... This is one of those things that you should do once. It is very inexpensive but I wouldn't ride it in the summer!

The Best Deal in Hong Kong. If you're going to Hong Kong Island as a tourist, a ride on the Tram is a must. It's cheap - about US$0.35 for any distance, short or long. Take a seat on the upper level and enjoy watching Hong Kong clatter by.
Cheap & cheerful. This delightful old trams are a great, cheap way to get around. You can use your octopus MTR card or cash. Enter via back & exit via front, paying on the way out.

Great way to explore. We found the trams were a great way to explore Hong Kong Island. Just jump on one, go upstairs and look out for little side street markets or other points of interest. Jump off (pay on exit) and explore for a while then head back to the tram to move on. It was 2.3 HKD per ride so it is so cheap! The trams are very tight for room and you cannot guarantee yourself a seat so I wouldn't advise them for anyone who is less mobile for any reason.

Cheap way to get around the city side of the Island. Avoid rush hour in the morning and evening because all transport is over packed, but mid morning or late evening in Summer or mid afternoon in Winter is a great time to get the trams. Real atmosphere of the city as its used by the locals.There is no air-con it is air cooled in summer so avoid if its very humid and you don't like to get hot. Likewise in the winter evenings it can be very cold on the trams as the windows are opened.

Colonial quirkiness. In such a modern city, the Hong Kong trams offer one of the few remaining historic elements to the city. They are mostly old and very few have air conditioning, however they also have a charm that makes them a great leisurely way to see the busiest parts of Hong Kong Island. Regardless how long or short your trip on a tram, the price is the same and it is ridiculously cheap - you can use coins or an Octopus card to pay. As the trams travel relatively slowly they offer a fantastic opportunity to pull out your camera and take some action shots of Hong Kong streets and buildings (best to sit on the top deck to get those). For tourists, I would recommend taking the tram from Central to Happy Valley, Causeway Bay or North Point (or vice versa). You will go through the High rise areas of Central and Admiralty and the bustling hub of Wan Chai where craziness abounds out the windows as people race about their various activities. You will see wet markets and if you travel at night the rapidly disappearing neon lights that once made the city famous. During peak hour the trams are PACKED like sardines, so best to avoid those times if you can. My kids love to ride the trams and watch Hong Kong pass by. They are a great attraction for both young and old alike.
Fun experience. Old style tram ride. A fun experience and a good way to get from A to B if you are going a short distance. Trams are pretty regular too.

Skinny Trams!. Old and new versions. the old ones have all the old wood and hardware. Go upstairs and enjoy the street views below. Cheap also and a great way to grab a rest and sigh tsee above the traffic!
I'm hooked. I know i know, it super slow. Takes forever. BUt it's so cute. I take it to work everyday. it's just special. gotta try it. plus its so cheap!

For kids age 2-5 it tends to beat Ocean Park/Disney for a little over HK$1. My son will travel Kennedy town to Shau Kei Wan enthralled the entire journey. It costs less than half a US$ end to end, the best budget attraction in HK and over a 100 year old. There are party trams you can book which will take you on a circular trip from Kennedy Town to Happy Valley and Back. Bring booze, food etc and make an inexpensive evening of it.
Ding Ding ride. Love this cheap mode of transport but the stairs leading to the upper deck is a little steep. alittle hard for people who are carrying infants and little children.

Slow-motion Rides in the Busy Metropolitan. Ding Ding trams can be dated back to 1902 and you can see them only on Hong Kong Island (i.e. none on the Kowloon side). Trams are an inexpensive way ($2.3 for adult) to travel between places while you can enjoy the view of the busy life of HK people, enjoying a breeze. The tram is a must-ride during your visit in HK as it gives you a chance to slow down and appreciate your surroundings.
Love it. I love riding trams, so this was pretty cool thing to do in HK. Very cheap way to get around and the wiew from the double decker was awesome. Dont miss this one!

cheap and different atmosphere of hongkong. Yes, by tram we can see the different atmosphere of Hongkong. I used tram in Hongkong because easy and cheap. for short distance, tram is really efective. Beside that I can see all of people in Hongkong. Just use HKD 2.3 and you can around hongkong, wanchai, central. Since indonesia have a film with the tittle 'sunday morning in victoria park', so we visited this park. Not really busy in the weekday. But we just walk 2 minutes from tram stop station. Easy and simple. So don't forget to try tram if you want to know hongkong deeply..
Different way to see the city. Instead of going underground, why not travel the city with cheaper fare, spectacular view and talk to the locals?

Great fun and a great view!. Everybody must ride the trams at least once in their visit to Hong Kong. Cheap, fantastic atmosphere and you can watch almost the entire city passing by you. If you're tall, watch out for the wooden ceiling planks that you *will* hit your head on.
A cheap way to view the Island. Hop on any place and head straight upstairs. Then spend the next 3 hours touring from one end of the Island to the other. All for 30 cents AUD...

A slice of HK Heritage. Ding Ding Tram, an iconic sight - and sound of HK on the HK island side. One thing that simply impresses me about public transportation in Hk is the sheer integration of it. On one hand you have a piece of heritage idily rolling down the tram tracks while a few seconds later, a zooming air-conditioned modern double-deckered bus zooms past it. There seems to be a healthy respect given and accorded to these rustic looking trams as the modern buses always seem to give way to them. That being said, it is a good photo-op as they are indeed an iconic sight. Riding on one is cheap to the point of disbelief and if you are like me, with time to spare, taking a round trip around HK island on one of these trams is a good way to see HK Island for what it is. Besure to take the upper deck as it affords a more spacious sitting environment and provides better air circulation as the trams are not air-conditioned. It is simply great that the HK transport govt has not eschewed these old rustic models for more snazzy modern ones. It will simply kill it if they replace these trams with the modern alteration which will most certainly kill the rustic flavour and heritage of this unique mode of public transportation. A must do when in HK Island. Try it you will find the experience pretty interesting!

Cheap interesting way to see Hong Kong. From the top level you get to see the vibrate city that is Hong Kong. You see all walks of life (the rich in the expensive cars to the not so rich dragging trolleys of paper boxes and paper to the depot to exchange for money). The clean to the not so clean (Central to the wet markets). Choose non peak hours to get teh full spectrum of Hong Kong life from a distance.

A great way to see Hong Kong Island. If you haven't try Hong Kong Tramways you don't know what you are missing out on. Sure the MTR gets you around Hong Kong Island quickly but it doesn't give you the views of Hong Kong Island. This is where catching a tram comes in. It's a great way to see how residents of Hong Kong live, work and play. For $2.30 HKD per ride, you can go just about anywhere on Hong Kong Island. The trams have livery advertisement, it's well maintained and clean. It has it's draw back been small, non-air conditioned and can get crowded during busy times. The Trams are quite full between Central & Causeway Bay. If you can get to the top of the trams, it provides the best view of Hong Kong island. The tram isn't fast or slow, but moves at a good pace. The windows on the tram can be lowered and allows you to take nice pictures of Hong Kong island as the tram moves along. I highly recommended if you want to are adventurous...
Great fun. Definitely take a trip on the trams when you are in Hong Kong. Small and dinky, with some hilarious designs and you get a great view from the top deck.

Bring your kids for this interesting ride!. Like the Star Ferry, the Ding Ding Tram is an activity that I recommend to all visitors. It's a fun experience for kids, especially for those who seldom take public transport. Parents can explain to the kids about the evolution of public transport in HK. I recommend stopping near IFC for a meal at Yung Kee. That will wrap up the ding ding journey pretty nicely.

Worth a ride !. Took the tram @ Sheung Wan area towards Kennedy town. Nice Tram. Old fashioned. Old School. Excellent ride with views of the older buildings. Makes you think u are back in the 70s (at least). Cheaper way to travel, able to pay by octupus card. If u are tourist. worth a ride!

enjoyable ride but not if you are in a hurry. took the tram from northpoint to sheung wan on a Friday morning, around 10am. it's an enjoyable experience, especially when you travel through the transition of the older streets of Northpoint, then to the modernised buildings of Central. the journey took a good 40min+, so if you are in a hurry, don't take the tram.
very packed but value for money - HKD2.5!!. Had fun on the ride but was very packed. It was the christmas weekend thus can't complain and great value!

Great way to travel. It was cheap, that's for sure. It was a great way to travel HK, you can actually travel HK in one day using this and you can a lot of nice places. The tramways was not that fast and not that slow, it was just right, you will pay when you go down. Inside you can opt to be on the second floor which has a good view, It was fun considering the amount you pay, you just have to take note of where you are going because the voice over is not that clear, but you can always ask if your lost hehe.

Amazing Transportation. Really amazing. Only with HKD 2.3 we will going around hongkong city. Based on my experience, I around hongkong city by tram in one day. And we can get all of view in hongkong. People, habits and also activity of hongkong. Remember that we must take in tram in the behind door then take out from front door while paying the ticket. When i tried tram, all people help us to give information about nice place in Hongkong. They really helpfull. Before, we think that tram is dirty and hot. But the fact is not. Tram is really warm. Because no pollution, there is not hot and very clean. Lastly, we must try this tram if you have a spare time in Hongkong.

Great way to explore HK. We used the trams several time while in HK, you can use the Octopus card (similar to OysterCard) on all HK transport including the trams, we visited several markets on the tram and enjoyed using them, each one is painted in a different livery and they are good photographic material

Cheap, fun way to travel!. As other reviewers have stated, this is one of the cheapest and most interesting ways to travel in HK.HK$ 2.30 for a single journey (much less for senior citizens), take a ride on the top deck and see the sights!Take a photo of the map at the stop when you get on and note the stop name. The stops in the opposite direction are numbered differently, so take a photo of that map too. Each stop is numbered and the tram will generally stop at all stops.

A fun way to see central Hong Kong. The trams are a Hong Kong tradition and probably the cheapest way to travel out To Causeway Bay and east. Avoiding the traffic chaos and slow enough to see the sights, to smell the aromas, and see the real HK.

The cheapest ride ever. It's simply the best and cheapest way to do sight seeing on HK Island. Good for all ages and anytime. This is how you experience real Hong Kong. Take your time, try to catch a seat upstairs, preferably front row, or work your way there. Enjoy the views, smells and the ride. Listen to some Cantonese conversations and just go until you reach the terminal station. From there take the next tram back to where you came from. My favorite is Happy Valley terminus and would personally prefer to take this tram near Western Market.
A view into the past. Cheap way to get around on the island, frequent and on-time, enjoyed the experience. Just beware that you don't stick your head out when you're in it

Very vintage. Not much cities in Asia has this tram ways anymore, while Hong Kong maintains the use of this type of transport, it best for you to try it, feel the heritage of Hong Kong with British invasion

Fun way to get to know HK island. It's cheap and convenient. Costs a flat fare of HK2.30 and you can use your Octopus to hop on and off stations along the HK island. Though it is slow, it is not affected by the traffic jam. It can get really crowded during peak hours as it is still well used by the locals, including office workers.

Great way to travel. If you are not in a rush, the Tram is a cheap and fun way to travel around HK island. The tram travel across the length of HK island and you can hop on and off with your Octopus Card which makes it so convenient.
awesome racing day. lots of tourists, beer garden, horse racing, gambling, and everyone's friendly. A must go. Don't go to Sha Tin day racing it is depressing.

Good if it's not overly crowded.. We went on a Sunday and it was very crowded from Central going towards Causeway Bay. We had to stand elbow to elbow hence wasn't such a pleasant sightseeing experience.

Give it a try. It is a flat fare of HKG$2.40. I reckon it is fantastic way to explore HongKong. Was told that a complete journey takes about 2 to 2-1/2 hours. At hkg$2.40, one can simply hop off when a place interest you ; wander around that area then catch the next tram.
I will do this on my next visit.

Another Must do when in 'town'. Travel from one end of HK to the other for 2.3hk$ (about 25p) not quick like the MTR - takes quite a time (about 1hr) but you get to see all of the real day to day activities along the route. Very busy because of the cheapness but a definate experience you must take advantage of especially from the top floor front seats.

I love MTR Hong Kong. Everyone can use it, even a person who is travelling alone to an overseas country almost completely alone for the first time. Everything is so convenient and straight forward that it's almost laughable! However, keep in mind that the lines to Mongkok and Central are often extremely busy. If you're not one for Claustraphobia, if you're on the red Tsuen Wan line to Mongkok, get off at Admirality and change lines. It's better instead of suffering one stop to Mongkok. This is just my opinion.
excellent. riding on tram turns back the clock and will remind you how lifebefore was so simple.You will enjoy a lot of sight seeing while ride the tram from one point to another

Best way to cross Central of Honk-Kong.. Great to use. All the locals jumps in and out, the view from the 2nd floor is just great. Costing 3 HK$/pers. - Give you the time to make it from the beginning till the end...

Nostalgic rides that doesn't cost the earth. Some things don't change for a hundred years, and this it one of them. Except for the convenient Octopus fare-deduction machines next to the tram operator's seat. The sights are dynamic but smells and sounds have been the same. Plus, it's the best, cheapest way of getting around the city, if you have time to spare.

Fun way of getting around. It is a very peculiar experience. Hot, sometimes very crowded, slow and the traffic outside could be crazy. All these seem to be pretty unpleasant. But just couldn't tell why, even a HongKonger like me, fall in love so much with the tram. Just couldn't tell why...I encourage everyone to give it a try to see if you like it!

Very crowded but not to be missed!!. The trams are very crowded but it is an experience not to be missed. They run frequently and are very cheap. The only drawback is that they are extremely well used so they can be very hot; sitting by a window is the best place to sit. But don’t miss this experience as it is so Hong Kong!

Excellent way to see HK.. Taking a tram trip from one end of the tramway to the other passing places like Wanchai, Central, North Point, Western etc is a relaxing and CHEAP way to see street life along the route.

A great way to re-live old Hong Kong. Do go up this tram. It is so fun. Get up at the back and alight at the front. We sit at both the top and the bottom deck. Go up the top deck if you want to have a good view of the Hong Kong street scenary.

Good way to relax from life. This is a very famous transport in Hong Kong, even in the group of Hong Kong people, we would take this with friends, as the tram's speed is slow, we can chat for a long time and relax from our busy life and enjoy the scenery of urban area in Hong Kong. It's fare is cheap, so you must try this transport if you came to Hong Kong.
Fun & Cheap Way to get around. NOthing to dislike-I would not want to stand and I think this might happen at busy times. Otherwise, the tram is a novel replacement for a bus.

Must try! Good if you have more time. Recommended to try the stretch between Sheung Wan to Causeway Bay. It's a good way to see the busy streets of Hong Kong. It is slow, so it's good if you have time. It's also cheap!
Great experience. Was a bit dirty, but the best way to view the city if you are tired of walking. I would really recommend doing this just to observe the area.
Lively trip. Took a trip on the tram from Central to beyond Times Square - packed to capacity with local people and nice to experience something of the 'real' Hong Kong

Love the Ding Dings. Great way to get around as the line runs across the island-just need to know where to get off.Get on at the back -Fare is 2.30 HK$ and you pay as you leave from the front.Mind the ceiling height if you are tall!!
Hop On Board. In downtown HK? Have an Octopus card? Take a ride. They give a good feel for the down town area. And like all public transport is incredibly cheap

Fun ride! Felt like I was in a Harry Potter Movie :). It took a while before we figured out how to get to the station. We rode one near Causeway Bay and got off at the station near Worldwide House for a quick walk to Hollywood Road. Nice experience. :)
A good way to see Hong Kong Island. Cheap and cost only HKD2.30. Level with Road so can see as the tram move. If I had more time, I would take more rides.
trmaways. trilling for me that is ...and its a wonderful experience to see hong kong from the tram as it looks so beautiful with lights surrounding the city....and the tram is so beautiful

An easy way to see and explore Hong Kong. The trams are a throwback to a bygone era, and while their route is not all-inclusive, if you have the time it is well worth using them to explore the city and then to go back to interesting places you find en-route. They run along the whole of the north shore, and they couldn't be easier to use. Hop on, and pay HKD$2.30 (that is about US$0.35) per adult when you get off. Flat Fee. Correct change only (and you'll be glad of somewhere to get rid of it!)Tremendous value, lots of fun spotting stuff out of the windows from the top floor.A tip, though. If there looks to be two or three trams coming at once, pick the last one as it is liable to have more seating!

great fun. The upper deck of the ding ding was a great way to see the buzz of HK. The tram is narrow and the stairs to the upper deck are steep but once there, the ride is fun. It's a good way to see the crowds of people out and about from a different angle. The trams are timber and the windows open and close, they are crowded and the atmosphere is brilliant.

Nice, but almost useless. These old trams are funny and it's cheap to ride on them, but their routes don't cover many of interesting sites of the city, and they are pretty crowded by people who need just ride.
Good ride. Nostalgic ride for us - always bring back good memories - it only cost HKD2.30 a ride - no matter how far you go!

Simply the cheapest and best way to enjoy the HK Island's north coastline. No one can offer a better trip along the island than the trams. Easy to board, cheap to ride and slow enough to provide great opportunities for sightseeing.

Must experience. If you don't like crowds or being pushed up against, this is not for you. Otherwise it was a good experience. Just don't take Happy Valley. It goes out of the way. You can take the ding ding to Admiralty to see Hong Kong Park or continue to walk to the tram for The Peak - that too is a must do.

Fun way to have a look at the city. These querky trams that look like the wheels are too small are a great way to pass a few hours. Even on a rainy day, get a seat at the top and watch the city go by. We jumped on and watched the world go by until the end of the line and then came back again. Get on at the back and pay when you get off at the front, not like we did and jumped on the front and tried to pay straight away. Only $2.50 (have the exact change). They take Octopus card.

Nostalgia.Adventure.Fun!. I brought the kids on the upper deck at Central, and we stayed on board for 1 hour!You can see the trams, bus, vehicles and pedestrains criss-crossing at every junction.Looks chaotic, but there is a systematic flow.First timers might struggle to climb up the narrow stairway. We find it interesting to board from the rear.Once the tram moves, you can hear the wheel grinding on the track, and we come so close to the bus/tram in the opposite lanes! (Kids must not stretch their hand outside the windows !).We view Central's impressive skyline along the route.So much fun, for only HKD 2.30 !I suspect there might be limited space for your strollers, but please try the Tram whenever you are in HK.

Cheap and a great experience. It's really cheap at HKD2.30 for adults and it gets you to places without having to walk too much. Passes through really vibrant parts of Hong Kong island and is a great experience.

Classics!. They rattle and sing and ding ding ding. Sit up on top and watch Hong Kong Island go by. The locals who use the trams will not mind you enjoying them. I wish I could go to work on one of these every day instead of the #2 train!!!

A slow and nice ride. A cheap and nice experience to see Hong Kong day and night if you have time to spare. The taxi driver dropped us in Sheung Wan(I think), about 10 minutes drive from our hotel. The tram moves very slowly and it took us an hour to Causeway Bay. It would take another hour to finish the second route so we didn't continue. It is a cheap way to see Hong Kong as it is only HK2.30 all the way. But we got a bit confused and took the wrong tram when coming back from Causeway Bay. Luckily we came down and asked around. So make sure you ask the people if you are not sure which line to take as going and coming back is a bit different.
Fun and easy to use. A great way to see Hong Kong. Stops along the major stops. Make sure you have change because the driver doesn't. Fare was $2.30.
Good local experience. Fun way to travel easy to navigate but packed and better for shorter people . At 5 feet 10 ins I was challenged but thankfully got a seat. Cheap and feels authentic
Must see... great way to travel. The tram offers tourists and locals an iconic journey with great views as you meander around Hong Kong's bustling streets... don't miss it!
Crowed and uncomfortable but still a must do experience. Even if you go a few stops it is fun but constantly crowded, in peak times faster than a bus.You pay as you exit via the front door only.
Terrific way to get around. Inexpensive, reliable, punctial and fun. A terrific way to get around HK. Love these old trams and the characters who travel on them.

Worth doing.. We went on the Peak tram in the afternoon when it was busy, but it was efficent and we didn't have a big wait. Its a lovely ride up and back. Up the top is a typical shopping area. Unfortunately it was a misty foggy afternoon and we couldn't see much, but on a clear day it would be fabulous. If you post a postcard from the post office at the Peak, the stamp is franked with a special commerative stamp.
In-Expensive. Very cheap leisure ride to see part of Hong Kong Island. We took from Central to Causeway Bay in the late evening. Children felt it's like a roller coaster ride!

Try a piece of Hong Kong history while you can. It is not the quickest way to get around Hong Kong, but for HK$ 2.30 (around (£0.20), the tram takes you from one end of the Hong Kong Island to the other. It is the oldest transportation system still being used in the otherwise rapidly changing island. So try it when you still can.

Take the Old Tram to Shau Kei Wan. We've been to HK many times but this time decided to escaoe from the touristy areas and explore some slices of 'old' Hong Kong.We'd been advised to take the MTR to Shaukei Wan - on the island line past Causeway Bay. We did this and came tio the surface to find a fascinating and 'real' part of HK that few tourists get to see or visit. If you like the feel of street markets, shops, HK people going about their business, some temples and other local sights then heade for this area.A huge surprsie fgor us was to find that the old island tram that runs through Central and Wanchai terminates at Shaukeiwan. We took it back to Central (cost $HK2.30) on our Octopus card, and really enjoyed the sights as the old tram trundles back (heading for Kennedy Town) get a frront upper deck seat if you can. You can get off at Waanchai, or Central opposite the Star Ferry terminal so it's very convenient, and slow !A trip to Shaukeiwan will show you that HK is much more than the Star Ferry, tailors and annoying touts. Allocate a morning that you won't regret

Lovely Way to Get a Feel of the City. These are double decker trams that run on sunken rails in the middle of the roads. It is best to get a seat on the upper deck from where you can take in the sights and sounds of the city through the open windows (don't put your head/hands out as there is very little space between two trams in opposing directions) as the tram ambles along at a liesurely pace. It is not very crowded like the metro/bus as it is slow and it has fewer stops compared to the bus. You can use the "octopus" card on the tram otherwise remember to take exact change (HK 2.00). The Octopus card is like an e wallent and can be used on the metro, bus, tram, etc. and even some shops accept payment through it.

An atmospheric but slow way to see HK. The trams are a charming way to see the city especially from the upper deck. Be aware that they only take exact change or Octopus card and they are slow since they seem to catch every traffic light. There are several routes so take care you don't catch the Happy Valley tram by accident like we did.

Cheaper than the open top bus tour. There is a day that I can't think of what to do, so decided to take the tram, from the West to the East. Started at Western Market and got down at Shau Kei Wan. It was a great way to see how the locals live, and since I took it in the early morning, you can see the city beginning to wake. Gradually, you will leave the bustling metropolis and will arrive at a quaint little town. The food is abundant, and cheap. Tasty too! The famous Big Bus tour does not go this way. Highly recommended. And it only cost HKD 2.30 for adult.
Trams fun to ride. The Trams are fun to ride, easy to catch and can take you right from one side of the Island to the other.
Hong Kong Tramways. the best ever , you pay when you get of , and you go as far as you want for a few penny's , well worth the money

Fast easy way to get around. Buy the card and use HKs incredible people mover system...trams, busses, ferries subways. Don't hide in the hotel or taxis during the day, have trip time and see the place above ground.

Can get very busy. We travelled on the trams to get a taste of Hong Kong life. However the queues can be long and the trams dont seem to run to a timetable! You have to pay exact money on exit , so make sure you have change. I loved it though!
Great Experience. It was fun and a one of a kind experience. The nostalgic feel cannot be described by words alone.Just remember to try to avoid office worker's knock off timings.
Best value. This is still the best way to see and get around Central to either Causeway, North Point or Sheung Wan.

Cute & cheap way to travel and see Hong Kong. I love these trams, they are like dinky toy cars! Very, very cheap as well, costing only 2.30HKD for each journey. From these trams you get great street views.
different way to see hong kong. it is just simply a different way to see the city. its slow and even slower in the traffic. easy to use with the octopuss card.

What is PAST is PAST !!. This reminds me of my childhood days spent in Calcutta , India. As a child I used to hop in and hop out of the Calcutta Tramways that was built by the British during the Colonial Era.It was like living the past once again .. but in modern times .. The amazing trip to Victoria Peak is something I would not forget ever. A MUST for all HK Tourists ...

Great way to see the city.. Really cheap and convenient method of travel.go to the top and sit in the front and take in the sights of Hong Kong as you cruze through Causeway Bay over into different parts of the city. Besides the double-decker buses, this is a great way to take in a view of the city and take in the sights.
Fun way to travel. Cheap & easy way to get around Hong Kong Island. And its fun. Its easy to get on and off where ever along the way you want.
Fun way to see Hong Kong Island. Cheap and easy way to get around on Hong Kong Island. And its fun. Hop off and on along the route. You pay as you exit the tram. But dont do this at peak hour.

Soooooo cute!!! Must try!!!. They just wow:) Especially the once with open tops:) Very clean, nicely decorated, comfortable and the most important thing they are unusual!They go to different directions too!Must try while in HK!!!
Always a favorite. Whenever I am in HK, I take the ding ding tram. It's an inexpensive way to sightsee and beat the traffic.

so convenient. well we stayed in Causeway Bay and it was ultra convenient and cheap to get around from the hotel to the MTR (Metro) stationsAlthough the trams are mostly old but it is still a good experience

I love the trams. This is a great way to trundle around the city. very cheap and you can always wait for the next to get a seat on the top deck. Its slow too so you can take pictures or see a favourite store and leap off.
Ding Ding Tram Hong Kong. Fun way to travel!! Easy to find them all round the city. Great way to do a bit of sight seeing!!! We used them to find the Happy Valley Racecourse.

Love it!. I love taking the trams whenever I visit Hong Kong. It's cheap and efficient because will not get caught in traffic jam (well, at least I hadn't so far...). Can also look at the life of the Hongkongers as I travel to my destination. My children enjoyed the ride too.
Loved them. Simply at atmospheric way to get around. Perfect for the aerial view of the comings and goings of the city.
Easy and simple transport. Besides the novelty of riding the old trams we found it very easy to travel into the shopping district

The best way to see Hong Kong and so so cheap!. Take the Tram from Kennedy town all the way to Central. Sit on the top deck, take your camera and be astounded by the sights, sounds and regretfully smells of this city.

Watch your head. Cheap, great way to get around HK and really get to see the city. Jump off, get back on. Sometimes it feels like you need to duck your head, other times you feel like the whole thing is going to tip over. No worries - that hasn't happened in about a 100 years. Since on the second floor in the front seat if you are not easily put off your lunch.

Not just for the enthusiast. A step back in history, for tourist and resident alike. Top-deck position essential to view the hurley-burly of H-K life. Forget air conditioning, simply pull the windows down for cooler air, and enhanced sights, smell and sounds. Needs a degree of bravery as instructions not crystal clear, but locals will help. Remember to pay on exit.
Cheapest form of transport. Go to the top floor - and try to get a seat at either end of the tram - best view that way. Would not recommend if you are trying to get somewhere in a hurry though!

Safe way to get around Hong Kong. Best system I have seen. The tram system is safe, cheap, clean and efficient. I suggest try to avoid morning commute crowds because trains can get very crowded. Also suggest checking out airport to city train to the intercity
great cheep way to see the city. seat upstairs in the front of any line and enjoy a slow ride in a very busy city day and night. you will pay few cents for the whole thing

$2 ride worth every penny!. I got on the tram in Central after passing through the pedestrian subway filled with many many people sitting on cardboards on the floor sharing food, talking and enjoying each other's company. Then I realized that it was Sunday. This is what they do on their day off. The culture of the live in maids in Hong Kong. Anyways, back to topic. Before you get on the tram, make sure to read the sign on the top as to where the tram goes. I thought they all made the same route until my mom and dad pointed it out to me. HA! We wanted to get on and go to the end stop in Shau Kei Wan to have a bowl of fish ball noodle. Paid only $2 and on the tram for like 1 1/2 hour from one end to the other was kind of cool. The seat were a little hard, all made of wood but it just has that nostalgic feel to it. Well worth the money you pay. Not to miss!
jump on, jump off!. the best way to see Hong Kong Island. Cheap, convenient. we are avid, avid walkers, but this was much more pleasant than walking down a crowded and dirty Hennessy.

A glimpse of Hong kong life. These moving elevated walkways offer myriad glimpses into the life of everyday people. they only go in one direction at a time: down from 6:00 am to 10:00am and up from 10:00 to midnight. Take them up, getting off and on whenever you see something that catches your fancy.

Charming!. Ding Ding Tram is called this because the bell they have that makes the sound “ding ding”.It is a traditional transport, very charming and very cheap, still used nowadays by locals. It is not only for tourists. Choose your destination or go without one. As this is not for tourist it will go from one point to other and if you want to come to the starting point you need to take another tram. Drivers usually don’t speak English.As it is an old way of transport, seats are not comfortable, it’ s wood benches, it doesn’t have air con and might be a little too hot, depending on that day weather.The ride cost is only HK2.30 and is better to have coins or the Octopus card, a prepaid card that can be used on the MTR also as well as on the bus, and even some shops.You get on the tram through the back door and get out through the front door, and you pay just before you get out.I love to take the tram and my kids also like, they like to go to the top deck (trams have two decks) and if you seat in front you can take some nice photos and enjoy the ride.

Enjoy the ride!. I love the trams. It is a nice, easy, cheap way to get around in Hong Kong and with a view!I started to use the trams because some years ago we choose a hotel away from the MTR that had a tram stop in front and we decided to try to use it as it was much cheaper than getting a taxi.It is incredibly cheap at HK2.30; make sure you have coins or an Octopus card that you can use also on the MTR and buses as well as for shopping in 7/11 and some other places. There are a lot of trams, just check your destination or go without destination.It gets quite busy during peak hours as the locals get out of work and go home.

Old meets new. These old rickety trams runs through the busy areas on the Hong Kong island side. They joins all the main areas. If you want to experience what it was like to travel around HK 50 years ago then get on an a tram. There is a flat charge of 2.3HKD regardless of how far you tarvel.....that around 20p. Its probably the chaepest entertainment on the island. The old trams run right through the ultra modern business districts and old really does meet new. Definately worth an hour of your time.

Really fun and convenient. We took the Tram one night on our way from dinner and found it fun and convenient. For the most part it follows the MTR line so we were able to jump off and walk to the MTR to get back to Kowloon. Plus it's dirt cheap! Definitely a must-do!
