Great fun. Travel the tram is a great experience for very little cash, just look around at all that goes on, then ride back!
walk and catch. slow and steady .. v v cheaply priced and give ur soul and rest as compared to the hurry hurry ..now now ..asap life of h kong
Beautiful.... HK tramway are very good and I like it. You can also take a tramway for PEAK from where you can see beautiful HK from the Top and also you can go to Madame Tassaude Wax Museum

Fun. Lots of fun and as cheap as chips. A must do on HKG islans, these double decker trams ply up and down the main thoroughdares. Costing almost nothing, it's a must do, the locals use them all the time and for a first time tourist get on the top deck and see the local sights from on high!!!

Not exactly the best way to see the city. We took a Ding Ding Tram on our first day. It hardly made any ground and stopped every 5 minutes. The tram was also packed with locals and we found it very difficult to enjoy the view and we didn't see much.I would recommend taking another mode of transportation if you want to get the lay of the land.However, if you've got time to spare, go for it.

Antique trams. This trams are really old and weared, but it is good they are still allowed to ride. It is for tourist and those who don't want to walk short distance. It is hot (no airco), very slow but cheap, and you enjoy an historical experience.

Loved these Trams. These trams are an amazing and efficient way to get round. They are not new, are noisy with hard seats and often crowded but such fun and very cheap. So much better than the buses, just remember to get an Octopus card or have some change - $HK2.3 anywhere.
Oh what an joy to go with these. old fashion stylish tram system, even slow they are so cheap, and do remember to get Octopus card, you can use that so many places, and dont need money to pay.

Good for daily commute in the island, fun for visitors. If you are only visiting Hong Kong, do try to take the tram once or twice. Tram only runs in the main island, so tourist locations are not necessarily part of the tram route. But it is inexpensive - just HKD 2.30, irrespective of the distance. It can be a fun experience. If you have kids, try to go to the upper deck. You can pay through your Octopus card, or drop the fare in the box next to the driver. Make sure you put the exact amount, as there is no arrangement for getting the change back. If you are limited by time, this is not some thing that is a must do. Do it for the experience once, but if you miss it, you aren't really missing much.
Cheap and easy transportation!!. We loved these trams! They got us where-ever we wanted to go and it was pretty cheap. Nice and clean inside but you can't always get a seat on them

Lovely. The Ding Ding Tram is a quaint transportation around Hong Kong city. Do make sure that you have a pre-loaded Octopus card or a lot of change with you because they don't give change when you pay more than the required amount.

See the real Hong Kong. jumped on the tram in the east of the city, and took it all the way, sitting on the top deck. I like the way it allows you to see the real heart of the city, running right through the centre of Hong Kong, seeing the streets, shops and people going about their daily lives. The tram itself is an attraction, but the real beauty is in truly experiencing the city. The time spent is well worth the minimal fee for riding the tram.

Old HK crawling. An amazing way to see HK slowly. There are many lines and they take you to diff parts of HK. Seat on upper dec to get better views and try diff trams at night time. Cost nothing to travel on the trams. you can spend a few hours on diff trams to admire the quick paced HK gently. Love it.

Tramtastic. Cheap, noisy, packed and not for the larger or claustrophobic person - but at about 20p for any trip the Ding Dings are wonderful. After getting on at the back, we always go on the top deck and work along as the exit is to the front. Octopus cards are a must unless you like juggling small change.

Great way to see the town and almost for free. Just hop on and travel along al long you enjoy it. Then get off (do not forget to the 2,3 HKD in the metal bucket next to the driver) and ride the same way back or take a line that goes around the race track.
inexpensive, slow moving way to see Hong Kong. View from the second level. Get a a window seat if you can. Lots of stops to get on and off with ease. Pay when you exit.

Fun way to get around Hong Kong. I really like the Ding Ding Tran. Its not something to take if you are in a rush but it is a really good way to see the city. It is compariable to the trams in San Fran.
You enter at the back of the tram and pay on your way out at the front.

neat way to see the city. These are a great way to see the city but are not air conditioned so can get quite hot during the summer months. They are also quite crowded at the wrong times of the day so keep in mind. If you have time, a ride from Kennedy town all the way to North Point would give you a bunch of different views of the city (and you can get off anytime).
Excellent way to travel on the island!. A real blast from the past these trams. Tiny and very regular and straight through east to west on the island. Great fun and a great way to get about

Price. Price increased from HKD2 to HKD 2.30. Overall still affordable to take the Ding Ding Tram to travel around HK Island. Suggest you prepare some info before you board the Ding Ding Tram as the drivers are not so willing to tell you the exact directions.

Hong Kong October 2012. The trams are a 1 minute walk from the hotel. They are very regular. The cost is unbelievable. $2.30 which is about 21p and can travel all over the place. Next time I will travel on them more.

Cheap way to travel on Hong Kong Island. What a great way to travel on Hong Kong Island. The tram is really good value. Go up to the top deck and you'll get to see Hong Kong through the back streets. Really good way to get around.
Must do. Really enjoyed the trip up the rock face on a bit of history. View from the top worth the effort. Don't bother with the skydeck
The kids love them!!. You must do this if you go to Hong Kong. They are cheap and a great way to see the city. The boys really thought they were cool.
Tram ride. BEWARE!..... the tram ride is from Shueng Wan to the other side of the Hong Kong Island, and does not come to the starting point as we expected.

Cheap convenient with an Octopus card. Cheap, convenient with an Octopus card. You walk less than taking a subway, get a nice view and more breeze on the 2nd level, slowly easing forward as people get off. Be careful to read the final destination as the train might take you to Happy Valley instead of your destination.

Original & fun. The trams are ancient, cheap and great for snapping photos as you crawl your way through the busy streets. Try to sit on the top deck at the front or back and try to buy and Octopus (transport) card from the MTR station first as this makes the whole thing a lot easier

Dic Dic. You have to go on one of these. You will weave in and out of Hong Kongs busy high street. You have to go on one of these before they get rid of them. Sit up stairs to get the best view for only a couple of pence best transport in Hong Kong

Take the Bus. Best to take Double Decker bus as its sometimes cheaper for short trips than the MTR. Not to mention you can view the sights from the top. From Hamphong long Nathan Road to Airport will cost you HK$33 and about an hour drive.
Fun Ride and yet Cheap. Fun ride to see the sights at a cheap price. For only about HK$3.00 take the Tram from back World Wide Shopping Mall (near MTR Central) and go Wanchai. Enjoy the ride.

Better from the outside than inside. Hot, crowded, sweaty, smelly, uncomfortable. Nice to look at from outside, but IMHO don't bother taking one. Stick to taxis or the MTR. Yes, I know that's not the romantic approach, but the trams look better from the outside so why not take the view and actually go places in comfort ?
The Trams. Brilliant for getting about, make sure you have small change as they are very cheap, lots of locals use them, very friendly and a great way to travel from road to road

how to discover the city for almost nothing. The ding ding trams are a very good way to discover Hong Kong at a very cheap fare. It allows you the opportunity to very well see the details of the city because they are higher than usual trams and they do not run too fast.
Ding Ding Ding Ding. love the ride, cheap fare, great without aircon....excellent way to see HK...check out its website for the route map, it will be useful

get around the old way. very frequent very cheap, take a full route and just look around without a tour guide. The trolley bus is very old and worth a look at a bit of transport history, still operating normally

A little tricky to start, but after that you're home free (and cheaply). Our biggest problem is figuring which way we need to go. That's because we're Americans, and this whole driving on the other side not only makes us a danger for getting run over when we cross the street, but REALLY screws up whether we want to go west or east and which way that really means on the tram. Tip - let one or even two go by so you can see their destination on the front of the tram and compare it to the tram line map at each stop. Because if you get confused to begin with, heading the wrong way on the tram will sort of imprint that confusion for the duration of your stay. If you drive on the other side of the road, ignore this tip as you are doing just fine.
Great way to travel. Travelling with the locals - make sure you have an octopus card which allows you to travel on most of the buses, trams and mtr. Makes it much easier than scrabbling for money.

Another way in exploring Hong Kong. Another way in exploring Hong Kong especially after 3 days of long hour shopping, my legs really can go any more further. Sitting at the top level, with the just nice pace, enjoying the great view along the tram way in Hong Kong city. However, please watch out to avoid peak hours so that it is less crowded on the tram. Also, the tram is open-air while Hong Kong air quality is really not that good, using a mask will be better.

HIGH FREQUENCY. GOOD INSTALLATIONS. It is worth to take a tramway and spend a couple of hours travelling across the boroughs that go all along Queen's St to North Point. It is cheap and easy to use, though is not the fastest way to travel for sure.Try to get a seat in the top deck, at the front, and get your camera ready.If we talk about metro, Island line, orange line (to Lantau) and red line ( to Kowloon) are the most used if you stay in Hong Kong Island. i have only seen a better organized, cleaner and apparently safer tube than Hong Kong's, that is Tokyio's. But when we talk about frequencies, Hong Kong is 'the most'. In none of its stations I spent more than two minutes (literally two) for the next train. Price is cheap, but varys depending on the number of stations you pass. I recommend to take an Octopues card, that is suitable for almost every transport: tramways, mtr, peak tram and ferry. I only missed a couple of mtr stations more.

Easy, cheap, but beware of rush hour.. The tram runs down the middle of tge city so gets you anywhere hkg-side. For next to nothing (2.30HK$). But, take the tram during rush hour only if youve brought a good book. Still worth it mind.

Awesome experience. It can get slightly crowded but it is definitely an awesome experience. Enter from the back, exit from the front 2.30HKD for the ride for an adult. (but easiest in all Hong Kong is to get an Octopus card)

Love the trams; see the city for a song.. Cheap, fast, reliable, and local. Skip the traffic and enjoy the trams. They work just like buses everywhere else (check the destination on the front and the routemap on the boarding post). Pay attention as they board from the rear and pay the fare on exiting!

Tram along Causeway Bay. For a few dollars you can go sit upstairs on a double decker tram as it winds it's way through the hectic Hong Kong traffic. Routes run from Kennedy and Happy Valley along Causeway bay. A step back in time experience as most of these trams are vintage models.A great experience that allows you to see Hong Kong on a budget.

Great way to see Hong Kong. The tram ride is fun and when you get to the top, the views are stunning. It's a good way to see the whole city and figure out where everything is. Of course, you only want to do it on a clear day. There are places to eat at the top. We had excellent lattes and muffins with a view to die for.

Cheaper, more direct and more scenic than the MTR. Only $2.30, and if you go upstairs you get a good view. It can get really crowded though, as you might expect in HK. A good but slower alternative to the MTR, though it might take you closer to your destination as the stops are quite close together.
taking public transport. when did we last board a tram - very civilised, no need for elbows, even though crowded, stops marked clearly enough even for us

icon of hong kong. if you haven't take the tram, you haven't been to hongkong.
very simple form of transport yet you will see how everyday people travel to work.
the only thing is get ready for some pushes and shuffles as it is really jammed most of the time

Great way to see the city if you're not in a hurry. Instructions:1. Use the interactive map here: http://www.hktramways.com/en/tramservice/routemapeastbound.html to figure out where you're going. Or, what the hell, just get on one and go!2. Find a tram stop. They're quite frequent along the tram line, which is great, because they're convenient, but makes things slow because they stop so frequently.3. Enter FROM THE BACK DOOR. Do NOT attempt to get on via the front door. 4. Try to find a seat on the upper level. best seat: upper level, front row. Excellent visibility. Probably won't happen if it's rush hour.5. When it's time to get off, go downstairs and exit via the front door. This is where you pay the (miniscule) fare. Ideally with an Oyster card.

A fun ride. Most of tourists in Hong Kong would opt in touring Hong Kong by subway. Ok ok yes, its fast, modern and convenient. But the Hong Kong Tramways are more fun too. You get to ride a slow , traditional form of transportation that gets you to see the city along the streets which you cant see if you take the subway. Its a fun ride experience. Try it! it costs you HK$2.30 per ride!!

Fun, inexpensive way to experience Hong Kong. We road the tram between our hotel in the Happy Valley area and Victoria Park. There are two floors, and sitting at the top floor up front gives you an excellent front row seats to see the city. The tram only costs 2.5 HKD (about 0.32 USD) per single ride, regardless of the destination. Can get very crowded during rush hour. The only downside is that the tram is not handicap accessible. Going witha stroller would also be a bit challenging, because the cars are fairly narrow, and the seats small.

On and off, often on. For about 20p you can not miss this experience. The trams will get you out to the race track in Happy Valley on a Wednesday night for just a few pence and indeed are the cheapest way to get around. The tram stops are obvious and frequently spaced around every couple of hundred yards or so i believe. Queueing etiquette is a little less obvious, you just have to go with the flow. They can be incredibly crowded at rush hour but that's all part of the fun. I recommend using your Octopus card because of the sheer speed of payment when you get off at the front end and also because cash can be a pain because you must have the correct fare as no change is given. Seats are hard, basically a bench of flat wood so not ideal for longer journeys if anyone has comfort problems. If you have small children, they should love it, I know the big kids do!
A good experience!!. Another great way to see Hong Kong Island. You can hop on and off as you like. Great experience for the kids!!
Good experience with lots to see. I think you can see a lot when you use the trams in HK. You can see and feel the culture of HK people.

Nice but only if you have the time. It was a leisurely way to see HK but after a while, the snail pace got to me. And it didn't help that the ride became stuffy after the rain stopped. So, I don't regret trying. I just won't do it again.

Pragmatic and fun. Not many cities run trams anymore. The ones they do, its mostly to mantain cultural continuity or as tourist attractions. Not here in HK though. Tramways are a means of everyday transportation and are a corporate enterprise. Cheap by any means and extremely reliable. I try to take the trams whenever feasible. A must if you want to see some HK life.

Great way to travel like a local. Used the tram to travel above ground and short distances within HK. It is very inexpensive and easy to use. Be careful during warmer seasons as they do not have air conditioning and can get very overwhelming. Try to avoid rush hour as the tram gets very packed. Definitely recommend if you want to travel like a local.

A great way to see Hong Kong Central and other Districts. The "Ding Ding" Tram is the cheapest and the best way to see the coastal strip of Hong Kong Island. For a few pence you can stay on board for the entire trip, or just hop off when you feel like it to explore whatever takes your fancy. We take the Tram every time we go to Hong Kong, it is fun, cheap and gives a great view of the main commercial areas. Try to get one of the older Trams and look at the signs on the walls!

A must do. Recently rode the trams for the first time and was able to share this experience with my wife and young family. The children loved it as well. It is a must do. They are small and quaint but by far are the best transport to ride in my view. Sitting up top with the windows open it feels as if they silently stroll through the streets and it gives you time to sit back relax and watch HKK go by. Cheap easy and definately a must do.
Great fun. Sit upstars at the front, beware of traffic fumes though. Make sure you pay on exit downstairs by the driver - who speak no english. Avoid rush hour if possible

Authentic. Though the "Ding Dong" is no longer used on the trams they are an experience to be savoured as you sit amongst the locals on a Hong Kong institution. Try and get a seat at the front if you can.
A Hong Kong Institution. You are really in with the locals on this trip. It's cheap and an experience not to be missed. Best used with the Octopus card as you need the correct change otherwise.
great value.. These are value for money.... do stay on the bus and go to the outer areas where you wil find great scenery and beaches.

Worth the $2.30!. Cheap and a good way to see the city in an old fashion transport system. You enter through the back doors and pay on the way out (in the front). You can go a fair distance for $2.30! Sit at the top if you want better views! =)
cheap and frequent. Just love the tram - great way to watch the hurley burley of the city and crowds. And, so efficient and cheap.
Night Ciy tour: amazing~. We took the Double Deckers with the open second floor: amazing to feel the breeze in your face and experience the view of buildings and their lights.
Great on top deck. Cheap and serves purpose to get from a to b if you aren't in a hurry! Do it for the experience, you see a lot from the top deck, future shopping possibilities!
Nice. Nice experience but the drivers are sometimes rude. Hong Kong people should really work on the way that they are treating people.
it was cheap and comfortabel. i like it because you can see every where and it has lots of station.and one of the station was opposite of my hotel.

Ding ding a must ride. Thought the tram line would have one or two teams on it adtake forever. Wrong. Trams every minute or two go for front seat ontop floor for a great view and very cheap at hkd 2.30 for one trip of any length. You pay as you get off with your octopus card or exact money. Loved it and dd it both day and night

Try it!. My family and in-laws were visiting HK for the first time, and we had to take the Ding Ding. They loved it. A nostalgic way of visiting HK and seeing the area. Mind you, there is no air conditioning on the tram, so riding during a hot day isn't too pleasant. Fare was inexpensive and we would do again!

Ding Ding Tram - great fun and practical.. The real Hong Kong travel experience is to be found on a 'tram ride' - but only on the island.These wonderful old work horses are a living reminder of times gone by and that remarkably can still be enjoyed today. There is quite an extensive network - so you can explore very easily.Unfortunately, I am unable to get up to the upper deck now - getting up the rather narrow stairway favours the young and athletic! But if you can manage it make the effort as the views are really worth it - plus it's cooler on the top deck on a hot day.Cheap to ride - Octopus card accepted - what more could you want for a pleasant hour or so.

Part of Hong Kong culture. These trams are slow, but in our opinion a better means of transport than the MTR (underground). They enable leisurely sightseeing and give a good taste of Hong Kong bustle and people. Cheap too!
Very easy to use. Very easy to use, print the routes off the website, use your octopus card, Its one price no matter how long you travel.
Must try!. Cheapest way to go around Hong Kong island for only 2.30HKD! Make sure to sit on the upper deck for a full view of the surroundings! Must try for tourists!

a fun way to get around. These old trams appear like from a theme park, but they are the real deal and have been in service for ages. For next to nothing you can go all the way from east to west in Hongkong. You'll have plenty of time to take it all in as they stop at almost every corner. A fun way to explore the city!

The old colonial red double deckers reminiscent of London. The British were responsible for introducing these buses to Hong Kong and even after "they left" these beauties still ply up and down the streets of Hong Kong. Used mostly by the locals it is worth a single trip up Nathan Road to get a feel of the pulse of the city from the upper deck.

Excellent way of transportation to discover the island. Excellent way of transportation to discover the island, but not during business time and not with too much luggages as it is quite narrow inside. Very cheap too.

old fashion. Love old HK trams, each having their own character with different companies using the space on the vehicle to put their advertisement on. Get on one from the back door and remember you pay with coins or use your octopus transport card when exiting through the front door. Don't get lost in tram! :)

Ding Ding Hong Kong Tramways. A great way to see Hong Kong is taking the "Ding Ding" dubble decker tram from one end station to the other going from the fine and expensive buildings and shops to end up in the more modest part of the city. The end station was in a very interesting little market where they sold everything from fruit and fish to shoes and shirts.

An opportunity to sit and watch. A great ride through Hong Kong Island. The trams were easy and took the Octopus Card. We have been only using public transportation so this was really a low budget sightseers delight.

An fab way to travel and see Hong Kong. What can i say aboout the Ding Ding Tram other than it is a really good way to see some sights, it not expensive, one price no matter how long you ride, we used our oyster card. We downloaded the two route maps from the website and used them a lot during our short holiday in Hong Kong. Its worth getting on if you have time and doing the whole journey start to finish.

Excellent value.. Only air con is when the tram is moving so can be a bit hot stuck in traffic. Buy an oyster card or have the right money no change given 2.30 HKD however far you travel and a fun way to ride.

Sit on the second floor. It doesn't matter if you miss your stop or if you prefer to walk. Just try it! Go and sit on the second floor: excellent photos guaranteed and from a higher perspective!Just take the exact change with you (2.30 HK$, as already mentioned), because you drop the coins before you step down.Funny and cheap way to visit the Island.

Some tips to take the tram. To me, the best time to take the tram will be Saturday (if time allows) morning. Then, you don't have to undergo busy time with the locals especially during peak hours. Don't start too early (after 10:00 a.m.) as most of the shops along may not yet open. Go to the upper deck and try to sit in front. Prepare exact coins to pay when you leave (unless you have bought the pass) as there is no change available. Despite having 3 routes in general, all the trams run the most busy areas - Causewaybay, Wanchai and Central District. If you want to explore more, you can go to local residential areas like Happy Valley, North Point or Western District. Don't worry you will get lost because so long as you see the trams, they will bring you back to the busy areas!
Old style. Got the experience is totally valuable especially when you choose to sit at the second floor. Passing the Kowloon shopping center, you may see the hustle bustle of Hong Kong.

Must try for first time visit to Hong Kong. If you are on your first visit to Hong Kong and have the time to spare, you should not miss this nostalgic way of transport in Hong Kong Island. Fares are really cheap at only 2.3 HKD for one trip, and you really get to see more parts of Hong Kong when compared to the faster and more comfortable MTR. It is open air and not air-conditioned though, so it can get a little warm sometimes. The deck can also get rather crowded at times as there's not too many many seats on board compared to a normal bus. But still, all things considered, I feel it is really definitely worth the trip.
Much better than the metro. Takes longer time than the metro but this is a great experience where you get a nice view at the same time. Pay with equal amount of cash or go with the octupus card.
it helps!. It helps to sent me closer to my hotel where located 20mins walking distance from the closest MTR station!Really different feeling when stepped on this historical transport..

Be the old hongkongers.. The tram runs rather noisily, but it is a good experience to become the old hongkongers. You just get on and find a sit, enjoy your riding. When arriving your stop, line up at front, pay the fare and get off. The fare is only 2.3 HKD per aldult.

If u have too many bags, take the mtr.. The ding ding was one of the cheapest transport they have. It cost 2.3 HKG for one trip. U are able to travel the tourist area more on those tram. However, do note that entrance and exit have a turnstile. So if u have a bit of shopping bags, please use the mtr instead .

wao, satin tram. we are cramp into a satin tram on sunday! So many people ride the tram! All the country maids come into the cities during sunday...dont ride the tram in sunday, u hvae no place to sit, no eye to see..Also why no more ding ding sounds?

Definitely must try!!. Though there's the convenient and really fast mrt, but this is a totally different experience. If you have the luxury of time, try the entire route of the tram. This is one way of exploring the HK Island. But do this when the weather is neither too hot nor raining and hopefully when there is not too much passengers. The tram is not air conditioned and there's not too much seats. Not very recommended for families with little kids. The tram could get really crowded. The entrance is at the back of the tram and the exit is at the front. It'll be a little hard to take care of your kids when people are trying to squeeze their way to the front. And little kids couldn't see the view if they couldn't grab a seat. One more thing, the fare is very cheap!!!
Return to the old days and nights of Hong Kong Island. Easy leisure transport-- go to upper deck! Ood, cheap, reliable mode of transport, plus sightseeing right within modern city.

HOT BUT WORTH IT. Worth the try if you want a ride along Hong Kong island for a price of HKD2.30 per adult. You may continue to sit on the tram to get back to your original destination. Not air-conditioned and may get messy and hot if it rains.

Great way to see a good cross section on the cheap. Road these things a couple of times just to watch the scene along the route. Just jumped off when I got hungry and found a great Malaysian restaurant by chance. Definitely sit upstairs for the best view.

It's only in HK island...... Taking this tram is not on my list. But seeing this kind of transport around Hongkong Island, do makes me want to try this. So after my visit to Causeway Bay area, I decided to take this tram to the harbor, having no idea the number is…just find the nearest tram stop, there’s listing for the tram number and the direction as well. Even you hop off in the wrong place (just like I did), just enjoy it, you still in Hongkong anyway, you won’t get lost and no need to worry. Most of the bus looks quite old.

Pick your time carefully!. Well, it was cheap and different to the metro. We took a tram late morning to get to a computer store on Hennesy Road. The tram was packed like the proverbial sardine can. Too hard to get to the top deck so our views were limited. It wasn't easy to work out where to get off because the stops don't display names (at least, I couldn't see them). There was no glass in the windows so looking out meant being blasted with dust from the streets. If you want to try the tram, I'd go in the early afternoon when it won't be as busy and don't use it to go somewhere specific, just for a ride.
Experience. Great way to get about even though you dont know where your going, They feel like they may topple over but they dont, Ding Ding get aboard. Fun times.

Ding Ding Tram, Aug 2012. Another good and cheap way to see the HK Island besides the bus is to take the tram. One flat fee of HK$2.30 (u.s.$0.30) (some bus routes are HK$2.5) can take you from Central to Causeway Bay or North Point. You can get off at any station, walk around and bound to find a mtr(subway) station to take you to your next destination. Btw, Causeway Bay is a shopping and dining area you should not missed.

A Must take transport in HK. This is one of the culture of HK. If you never taken this tram ride, you can't say you have been to HK. Sit at the upper deck and enjoy the breeze while from sheung wan to causeway bay. There are several routes for you to choose from too. With the destination displayed clearly on the tram it's not difficult to take the tram at all.

Cheap and easy to access. Brilliant, novel way to travel across Hong Kong. You really feel part of the hustle and bustle and best if you sit upstairs for the view. Plenty of stops and frequent service. VERY cheap.

Nostalgic. Maybe the cheapest (2 HKD fare) and most impressive way to travel on HK island and have a nice sight seeing tour through the streets of HK and get the impression of the locals hopping in and out!

Great Mode of Transportation...if You Know Where You're Going. I love the Ding Ding and it really is the cheapest way to travel around Hong Kong Island. The catch is, they don't make stop announcements and the signage at the station can be iffy. If you're not trying to go anywhere in particular, this is a fast and convenient way to explore. However, if you have a specfic destination in mind, things can get tricky. I recommend taking the MTR, taxi, or bus to your destination the first time and using the Ding Ding on the return, until you're familiar with the way your stop looks.Also, prepare to exit the Ding Ding at least one stop before your destination, trying to scurry from the top deck to the exit in a hurry can be a challenge.

Don't miss a trip on the tram. Very easy to use - just check on one of the tourist maps where the stops are and wait for one to come along. You can go a long way for one standard fare and you pay as you get off.

Excellent way to get from Central to Causeway Bay during rush hour traffic. Sure beats sitting in traffic in a bus or taxi, and being crammed in the MTR with everyone else during rush hour. It's accessible and easy to get on and off. HKD $2.30 HKD is less than USD $0.50.Another favorite method of travel in HK is the Star Ferry to get across the harbor. Perhaps its because I hate crowds in HK. Like the ding ding, the ferry offers interesting views of the city.

Travel the Island. What a great way to travel, if you have the time take a tram from one end to the other, get a seat upstairs, they can be crowded, but we found that if the first one is full the next one was sometimes empty, just get off if you see something of interest along the way, explore and shop, then get back on another one, The are cheap and with an Octopus card get on at the back and when exiting from the front just scan your card.The stops are not that far apart so if you miss your stop or pass something of interest just get off the next stop and walk back.

great experience. we enjoy the scenery alongside and the Ding Ding sounds. Interesting, and kids like to experience the difference feel from the bus we used to take in Taiwan. love to take once again.

Great way to travel around. Just get into the tram and goes along all the way in Hong Kong side. You could see the commercial area and also the residential area with market and people all around! It is one of the great experience in Hong Kong, only don't do it in Summer time!!

Best value way to see Hong Kong. At just HK$ 2 flat rate, its the best value for money way to travel and sightsee Hong Kong CBD. Trams come every few minutes. Climb up to the 2nd level for a better view (& fresher air). Pay the fare at the exit before leaving.
Duck your head. Head for the top deck and remember to duck your head. The trams of Hong Kong Island are as iconic as the Star Ferry. Sit back and enjoy a clunky ride through Hong Kong.
A taste of old victorian England on the other side of the world!!!. Easy to jump on and off. Cheap form of travel. Lovely and cool in the humidity of Hong Kong (94% one day)

Hong Kong Tramways. This is a repeat of my review under Hong Kong Tramways.During our last trip to Hong Kong we completed our exploration of Hong Kong Tramways by taking the Tram from Western Market to the end of the line in Kennedy Town, so we have now travelled from one end of the line to the other. Travelling by tram is a fascinating way of experiencing the busy city and residential areas of Hong Kong from the western point of the island right across the city to the east side a journey of 13km in total. The trams are nicknamed 'Ding Ding' after the bell used to warn pedestrians and other traffic of their approach.The tram system is one of the earliest forms of public transport in Hong Kong as they have been in existence for over one hundred years. Owned and operated by Veolia Transport, the tramway runs on Hong Kong Island between Shau Kei Wan and Kennedy Town, with a branch circulating Happy Valley. The trams which are an environmentally friendly mass transit system are not surprisingly a major tourist attraction. There is lots more information available on the internet about the tramway and in my opinion one of the most interesting and comprehensive articles is to be found at Hong Kong Extras. I have also posted about this on my Travel Tales Blog with photos.

Ride the Tramway. During our last trip to Hong Kong we completed our exploration of Hong Kong Tramways by taking the Tram from Western Market to the end of the line in Kennedy Town, so we have now travelled from one end of the line to the other. Travelling by tram is a fascinating way of experiencing the busy city and residential areas of Hong Kong from the western point of the island right across the city to the east side a journey of 13km in total. The trams are nicknamed 'Ding Ding' after the bell used to warn pedestrians and other traffic of their approach.The tram system is one of the earliest forms of public transport in Hong Kong as they have been in existence for over one hundred years. Owned and operated by Veolia Transport, the tramway runs on Hong Kong Island between Shau Kei Wan and Kennedy Town, with a branch circulating Happy Valley. The trams which are an environmentally friendly mass transit system are not surprisingly a major tourist attraction. There is lots more information available on the internet about the tramway and in my opinion one of the most interesting and comprehensive articles is to be found at Hong Kong Extras. I have also posted this information with photos on my Travel Tales Blog.
Something unique. It is a unique experience and still a mehtod of transport on Hong Kong Island. Not only for tourists ! - A sightseeing tour for cheap money.
Try it - lots of fun. The ding ding tram is on Hongkong Island. It is great to hop on it and take in the sights and sounds of Central. Go up to the upper deck and enjoy the ride. Great experience
Ding Ding Tram. Cheap way of getting around. Unless you know where you are going and where you need to get off, can be a bit of a guessing game. Fun certainly worth doing at least once.

An essential part of HK heritage. Each time I go to HK island, I love to take the tramway. It's highly inefficient, slow and generally packed with people, but it has a special atmosphere that makes you immediately feel like you're in HK. You should at least try it once, like in San Francisco.
Experience hong kong in the old days. If you like heritage transportation, this is not to be skipped. Take on the upper deck and enjoy some of the street scenes of hong kong.

So cheap and best mode of transport in HK. I am of the view if you wish to know a city you must know its public transport..When i found my itinerary useless provided by my tour operator Freedom Travels in Hongkong...i bid them good bye in between..I got down in wanchai ..had dinner...till the time was quite clueless what to do...the hotel guy suggested to visit time square in the vicinity...mall is something i hate to visit in an alien land..malls will remain mall wherever you go...totally undecided what to do...sat whole family on the footpath...finished our soft drink...one interesting thing which happened while we were sitting on the footpath needs a mention here....One lady of Indian origin came and asked whether we need some help...as the way we were sitting made her thought that we were perhaps in problem...I salute the unknown lady whose willingness to help other in trouble was quite remarkable...anyway..quite undecided where to go we got in the tram...it was going to some...residential area i forgot the name...enroute i found a chinese lady teacher who guided me to go to central and then to take a ferry to harbour....One caution to new visitor who wish to take tram....keep exact change with you to pay your fare.....no matter whatever money you pay...tram driver will not return you change....my chinese bus mate paid for me when she saw me paying 100 HKD...it was a good gesture...in tern i gave her my e-mail id and invitation to come to India...Coming back to tram...it was slow and best way to see the city .....off course the cheapest mode ..but best too...
way to travel. I never used to MTR on Hong Kong Island I found the trams to be great value ($2.30) and very convenient. Get a seat up stairs and watch the world go by!!

Notice to Passengers...:d. Hong Kong Tramways is the cheapest mode of transportation in HK, only HK $ 2 ...: dWhen you will use the tram, there are some things to remind. First, passengers should board or alight through specified doors. When you board, please come ini from back door. Second, please tender the exact fare or pay by Octopus Cards. No change will be provided. Passengers may not collect tram fares from other passengers inside the tram.Finally, do not place any parts of the body out of the windows...:p

Hong Kong Ding Ding - Fantastic (cheap) experience on Hong Kong Island. The Hong Kong Tramway is more better known as the 'Ding Ding'. See the TA listing under this name for a collection of reviews for this attraction, which is regularly rated in the top twenty for Hong Kong. Personally, we both love riding the 'Ding Ding' when its not too crowded or hot outside. For just HK$2.30 (adult) and HK$1.20 (children) per ride, you really can't go wrong with this quick, easy and child-friendly attraction. The Ding Ding slowly plies its way along Hennessy Road and is best taken between Sheung Wan and Causeway Bay. We enjoy it best at nighttime when you can see the endless building lights, especially as you approach Causeway Bay. You can find a nice map on the Hong Kong Tramway website and a nice travel guide for the Ding Ding on the Discover Hong Kong Website, both are worth taking a look at if you intend to use the Ding Ding while on Hong Kong Island.
Fun times. For two dollars you get a tour of hong kong island, get on in Wan Chi and get off at Western Market. Great fun

Price & frequency has increase. It cost HKD 2.3 to travel per trip. Frequency has increase also, so you can constantly adjust your camera's mode etc to get the perfect shot without wasting too much time waiting for the next tram to come
Welcome to my world!. This is my favourite relaxing way to get around town. You can see Hong Kong from street level and watch ordinary life.

Cheap. Convenient & cheap.
To avoid after office hr as it is very pack! Only HKD 2.30 no matter how far u travel.

Nostalgic means to explore Hong Kong Island. A ride on ding ding tram is a nostalgic and economical way to explore Hong Kong Island (if you are not in a hurry). With only HK$2.3 (almost US$0.3, half for kids under 12) you can travel from the western end to the eastern end of the island on one of Hong Kong's oldest transportation system which has over 100 years' of history. You can either pay in cash or via an Octopus card. Slow in motion but not short of efficiency, the tram will give you a good idea of all walks of people in Hong Kong and if you've been here before, the changes that took place in recent years. My friend from USA remarked that, compared to what she saw 5 years ago, the tram ride displayed an array of high rise properties in Hong Kong which reflected the outcome of the property boom, but short of character - fading away of the Old Hong Kong in which you will find old low rise buildings or communities with it's own unique style.Some factual information for those who want to ride on the ding ding tram: the western end is 'Kennedy Town' and the Eastern end is 'Shaukeiwan'. Remember to take a seat upstairs as the views are much better and the space less crowded. Highlights includes: West bound: Sai Ying Pun - Des Voeux Road West (nicked named 'Salty Fish Street' where over 30 shops display the preserved/dried seafood such as squids, fishes and shark's fin etc outside), East and West bound: All trams - Des Voeux Road Central and Queensway (the financial & commercial hubs of Hong Kong), Hennessy Road (busy for shopping), East bound: North Point, Quarry Bay, Shaukeiwan - King's Road (the longest road on Hong Kong Island which stretches from North Point to Quarry Bay). The whole journey will take about 1.5 to 2 hours depending on the traffic conditions. Get off whenever you want. Avoid the peak hours (0800-0930 or 0430-0630) as the locals rush back to office/home, or occasionally, Sunday afternoon - when there are parades and demonstrations, which will virtually affect the mobility of every single vehicle, including the tram, from Causeway Bay to Western District.

Great way to get around. Atmospheric. Cheap. Frequent.. You can either pay a cash fare as you get off the tram, or (and I recommend this - because it offers cheap travel round all of HK) pay by swiping your Octopus card as you leave. (Octopus is like the London Oyster card). It is cheap, trams are frequent. And the trip is atmospheric. You need to double check the routes - the trams are all signed and maps show you the tram lines - or you could end up somewhere you didn't intend to go. But these trams are a great way to get around. Leads you to think it's a shame we ever got rid of them in London!
Bring back some good old memory. Slow but why such a hurry. it let you enjoy the view and people. Avoid taking the tram during busiest hour, you can even get off teh tram.
Fun. This is the only mode of transport that is slow enough for tourist's sightseeing. But the routes can be a little confusing.
Cheap, fun, easy way to get around. $2.30 Hong Kong dollars, drop the change in the tray as you exit the front. I wish the stops were more clearly marked.

Fun!. This is a cool thing to do specially with kids. It is best if you can grab a seat on the 2nd deck and be on the front seats. I read a hint that a good place to be able to grab this is at the stop on Kings Rd. by North Point station (north east corner of Kings Rd. and Tong Shui Rd right by the pedestrian bridge) and this actually worked! This is also a good starting point for the ride to see Hong Kong island.

Feel the local, be local. Ding Ding is the cheapest transport in HK Island, sometimes you get whole day free rides too during some special occasion.It cost you HKD2.30 per ride, no matter which station you get up/down.

Don't miss. This is a ride you have to have even if you don't have a particular destination! Sit at the front and travel east to west or west to east. Observe the crowded footpaths as you rattle along the middle of the road. It's these sort of interesting features that Singapore could introduce to liven it up a bit.Public transport is very cheap in HK. Also take the double decker to Stanley from Central or en route and enjoy the scenery in air conditioned comfort.

Best, cheapest and most fun way to see HK.. Sit upstairs and see HK life. You can ride from one end to the other (Kennedy Town to Shau Kei Wan) and see sooooo much. No air conditioning but normally a good breeze. You are so close to things on the 2nd floor that you feel like you are a part of the 2nd floor. If you go late afternoon, you will see one world in the daytime and a new world when the lights come on in the city. This has been around and operational for over 100 years. Sit back relax and see HK.

An unforgettable way to see a fabulous city. Get to the upper deck of the tram, go to the front and stick your head out of the window. You'll have the best seats on the tram and feel like you're flying through the streets of Hong Kong. The city floats by in the tram but it's slow enough that you could still take it in. The best part is the ride is just a few cents, a bargain for the wonderful ride and excellent experience of an amazing city.

Slow but lovely. Only on the island of Hong Kong, but a lovely way to travel. Very cheap, very slow so sitting in the top you have the opportunity to look around while being transported. It's very slow so not recommendable if you're in a hurry. BUt lovely when you're on a holiday. Drivers do not speak English so find out your self where to get out.

Double decker tram - you cannot miss~. The double decker tram that you can only found in Hong Kong Island, it has been running for over a century, you cannot miss it if you got a chance here in HK. And, usually no traffic jam during the tram ride :-)

Loved it the first time but if you use this daily the stopping and starting gets annoying. If this is a once off experience it was fun.Our hotel link was by the ding dings and it got quite annoying as they are not air conditioned and get very crowded and stop every 2 seconds. They are a bargain and in peak hour were the only way back to the hotel - every bus will pass you but on the plus you get to watch life below as it happens.

A Step Back In Time. What did I like about the Ding Dong Tram? Everything. All visitors have to go on the Tram and you may have to plan to get on and off near a Metro station or Taxi Rank but do it. The fare is awkward at HK$2.30 for any length of ride and you need exact money. Not sure if they accept Octopus card.

Ride the Ding Dings!. The double-decker tram cars, or ding-dings, are a great way to see Central Hong Kong. And they're cheap. They take Octopus cards (like a debit card for all forms of public transit). It's about $1 U.S. to ride almost anywhere. Go to the top deck, sit in the front, and enjoy the view. Get off wherever you like, explore a bit, then get back on. A great (and cheap) way to spend the day in Hong Kong, much better value than a packaged tour bus.

Nostalgic Transport. We stayed at a hotel with MRT, buses and trams all equally accessible and found that we used the trams more than anything else. They're fun (and smaller than I remembered) and you can actually see things, unlike on the MRT. They're also the cheapest form of transport. We did have one hiccup when a tram was trying to turn into a congested street and we were stuck for over twenty minutes until it was able to clear the track in front of us.

travel back in time, in style. I like riding the tram from end to end and see a big part of Hong Kong island. From old houses and shops to the new and modern buildings. It's like traveling in time in the old but reliable tram. Best of all, it's cheap.
those good old days. cheapdin din all the timeenvironmental friendlylovelypeople watching besteasy to ridetry to avoid peak hours

Cheapest trip ever!. for around $1-2 US the four of us took a trip along central district on a tram. great to just sit back and enjoy the journey and the tram it's self. Gets very busy travelling east to west side. lke Rayners comment if your'e in a hurry the MTR is much quicker.
"Affordable and fun". Make sure that you have your fare in coins, no change is given back. This the best and fun way to explore main Island. We loved it.

Longest Double Decker Tramline in the World. Ding Ding Trams - the cheapest way to explore this city. By paying US$0.30, you can hop onto a tram that takes you tour around Hong Kong Island for hours. It is a good recommendation for the first time visitors, and for those who like to watch the street scenes in an easy way. It is NOT good for visitors who like to have something exciting. There are not many double-decker trams in the world and our tramline is the longest!There is just one long tramline along the northern part of HK Island (east-west direction) plus a little loop into Happy Valley where the horse-racing course is located. In case you see something interesting, you can always get off, find out what interests you then hop on another tram (have to pay another US$0.30 of course). If you have enough, just take the trams in the opposite direction and it will bring you back to your starting point. There is no tram running in opposite direction in the loop.When you wish to add this program into your itinerary, here are some advices: (1) AVOID the busy hours when there are a lot of people using the trams, (2) AVOID the HOT DAYS as trams have no air-conditioning, (3) be sure you have an octopus card as you probably do not have so many coins! For the above reasons, I only give it 4 stars instead of 5. :(Bring your camera or video recorder along. If you can find a seat in the front on the upper deck (always go onto the upper deck for better views), you can take some beautiful pictures/video of the street scenes of Hong Kong. In my opinion, the section in Wanchai is the most interesting where you can see a lot of interesting things going on beside the tramway. I recommend you to get off there and visit the side-streets too.
Cheap ride. We used our Octopus card, very cheap ride, lots of stops but quite slow in the busy traffic. Get on the back but pay at the front when you get off
Ding Ding Tram. What an exprience will never forget. Great view how the people live and work on HK island. if you are in a hurry don't use as it is quite slow

Effective mode of transportation. Use this on daily basis during our stay. Relatively cheap, simple and clear route, frequent (around 3-5 minutes interval), runs until midnight and near to our apartment (we stayed at Hongkong Island, Connaught Road West). Minus point: no AC, expect to get wet when it's raining.

Ri-ding a “DingDing”. The much loved Hong Kong tram is called the "DingDing" by the citizens of Hong Kong, in a reference to the double bell trams use to warn pedestrians of their arrival. We are convinced there really is no better way of taking in the sights and sounds of Hong Kong Island than by riding a “Ding Ding” tram. Hong Kong’s trams have borne witness to the development of the city and served the Island extremely well as an efficient, environment friendly and economical mode of transport. Some noteworthy features:- Hong Kong Tramways have served the Island for over a hundred years starting 1904…which means that the service is now almost one hundred and ten years old!- Starting with 26 single deck tramcars over a hundred years ago, today a fleet of 163 tramcars is in operation, carrying a daily average 230000 commuters.- Hong Kong has the world's largest fleet of double-deck tramcars, running on seven different routes. Hong Kong Tramways is fully owned by Veolia Transport China Limited.The tram line runs 13kms – from Kennedy Town at the western end to Shau Kei Wan on the east with a 3km track running through Happy Valley. A new route introduced in late 2010 from Shau Kei Wan to Kennedy Town made it possible to travel the full route without changing trams – in the normal course, changing trams is a must with Western Market being the most common interchange station. Hong Kong trams operate from 6am through midnight and the flat fare for adults is HK$ 2.30 (for children 3-12 years the flat fare is HK$ 1.20). Fare can be paid by Octopus card or in exact change.Trams can be boarded at tram stops which are an average of a quarter of a kilometer apart. Standing in trams is allowed on both upper and lower decks – which is practical, since trams can and do get extremely crowded during rush hour. Many trams look bright and colorful since they sport whole body advertisements for various products.Some interesting asides:- the inspired, path breaking decision to knock off multiple fare classes and replace it with a flat fare was taken forty years ago in 1972- apparently in 1984, Hong Kong Tramways conducted customer surveys to decide on the future plan for the tram system – the wise people of Hong Kong voted overwhelmingly in favour of keeping the trams going- In 2000, when Hong Kong Tramways replaced the trams’ bells with a beeper, the Hong Kongers were up in arms at this sacrilege which led to the “ding-ding” bells coming back!HINTS:1. If you have only limited time to spare, try and time your tram ride around 12 noon which is when they seem to be least crowded. During rush hour, even standing room is hard to get. Standing in a crowded tram is not an experience to be recommended since the journey is quite obnoxiously odorous and suffocating.2. This is sort of obvious – nonetheless, do try and get a seat on the tram’s upper deck and ideally right at the front. From this vantage point, you get to see more and can also take photographs of the action on both sides of the tram as also all that’s happening directly in front of it.3. If you are not carrying an Octopus card, then make sure to have exact change with you since there is no system on the tram to get change back in return.4. If you are on a leisurely visit to Hong Kong, we strongly recommend your spending a full day on the trams starting early morning through late at night. The trams offer you simply the best and most economical way of experiencing the heritage and cuisine of Hong Kong Island. We suggest the route starting from Kennedy Town through Sheung Wan, Central, Admiralty, Wan Chai up until Causeway Bay. In particular, the variety of culinary options available on this route are simply scintillating – for example: a cup of tea in an authentic tea house, hand made breads, signature cakes and desserts, cookies, egg rolls and egg tarts, buns, puffs, pies, ice creams, meringues, congee with accompaniments, a mind boggling choice of soups, glutinous rice balls, dumplings, noodles, satay, duck, chicken, pork, beef, eel, squid, crab. If like us, you are a foodie, please do read the ‘Ding Ding’ Hong Kong Tram Guide for more information (http://www.discoverhongkong.com/tramguide/eng/) – it is an amazing resource that tells you how much you can do riding Hong Kong’s trams.
Another must do. We loved this ride, slow but let us take in the lives of many in HK. It is still used as public transport, not really touristy at all. Go to the upper deck, it offers better viewing.

A World Away. It is worth the very inexpensive fare. Buy an Octopus card when in Hong Kong as this makes transport much easier. We went from one end of the tram line to the other getting off all over the plave and it was a very rewarding experience.

the icon of hong kong!. been to other asian countries this time and none other has the tram as such an iconic public transport. very impressed with how the tram is still maintained despite that many years versus other transport methods like trains, taxis etc.

Slow transportation with out AC. It's cute and fun but going on during the summer season is definitely not recommended or during busy hours. It's a shocker to experience and image using this type of transportation.

Must exprience the ding ding. I love the trams and prefer travelling on them than taking other modes of transport, although they do take longer than other modes of transport. It’s so nice to watch the busy city life from the ding ding. There’s no air conditioning however the windows are open, and there’s often a lovely breeze flowing through.The cost is HKD2.30; a set rate no matter where you travel (nb: the cost is per trip). Take the exact money as there is no change given or use an octopus card. Entrance is at the back of the tram and pay upon disembarking. As per everything in HK, try and miss peak periods.

Not to be missed!. Great to be on such a tram grinding its way along.... You get on at the rear and pay when you get off at the front - it's a standard charge for any length of journey. And as the trams are designed for HK residents the ceiling height is not so high :) Enjoy!

Best Value in HKG. I used to live in HKG and I always took visitors on the Ding Ding. It's especially good early in the morning to ride on the top deck and check out HKG "life" as it wakes. A one-hour ride costs about US$0.50 and is the best value trip in HKG.
Travel on a piece of history.. After seeing the trams I had to take a ride as they took me back to Scottish towns and cities in the 1950's. Ah, memories, memories.

Use it as the locals do!. The ding ding is fantastic for getting around the island. Just hop on and get off where you want, all for hkd2.30, and worth every cent.Go upstairs for the best view, and definitely recommend off peak times as gets pretty crowded.Oddly you get on at the rear and only pay when you exit via the front.

Classic. One of the oldest mode of public transport still in operation. Take it in Hong Kong Central (Zhong Wan) and you will see the paradox of this classic tram running right through the concrete jungle of shopping malls with luxury brands and modern skyscrapers that you have a hard time seeing their summits however hard you bend your neck backwards.

make it part of your hong kong experience. The Ding Ding is only available in HK island and links east to west and dips south alittle into happy valley.Regardless of the distance each time you hop off you pay hkd2.3 via coins or octopus card. Having never had trams like this in my country I find it really interesting. there's lots of stops and they are easy to spot. I read online before hand that the ding ding in the past was along the coast with a seaview; current position showed how much land had been reclaimed and built upon.Due to the speed of the ding ding you have the time to enjoy the sight and score the streets. just make sure you take the upper deck on a good day and a less sunny/hot hour. we did it for a short distance from admiralty to wanchai; one of the stop was near to an eatery famous for their noodles and 'tong sui' .. yummy red bean soup.ps: ding ding is popular and convenient for the locals and hence like their mtr, can be crowded at times. so take it on a non-peak hour on a working day.

Brilliant - if often crowded. The HK trams - that run basically west to east and east to west are very economical and easy to use. Have the correct change ready and pay on exit at the front. Entrance is at the rear. Have a look on the maps provided at each stop and you'll soon get the hang of where to board for which route.
fun!. My family and I enjoy this ride alot! sit on top if possible to enjoy it more
A great way to see life in Hong Kong's main thoroughways. Unleash the kid inside you and take a ride on these double-decker trams, even if you don't have to.
Great. Just a nice way to see Hong Kong Island from the inside. Just hop on one and stay there for a while and enjoy al the buildings around you.

Never get caught in traffic jam. Tram is the best travel mode to get from one end of HongKong to the other end. No delays, efficient to reach nearly all tourist spots.Most importantly, hugh savings as it costs HK$2-30 flat to anypart on the island. Trams are clean but crowded during peak office hours. Use this mode to visit tourist attractions on your owntime instead of strict schedule with tour operators.

Worth a go to experience old Hong Kong. I enjoyed my trip on the tram but do agree with a previous review, it isn't a white knuckle ride but is worth doing. The routes are clearly marked at the stops, so work out whether you want to go east or west, check the number of the stop you want to get off at, and jump on the back of the next tram that comes. I headed for the top deck and took photos from the back - it was hot in summer and you only get a breeze when tram's actually moving. It's similar to any double decker bus, so if you've 6ft like I am, be prepared to duck. The trams do get busy towards Central so be prepared to work your way through people to get off at the front, where you pay HK$2.30, no matter how far you've gone - worth doing to experience it and also helpful to get rid of some loose change too!
Cheap but really boring. Well its cheap 2.3hkd pay when you get off. Its slow and found it boring. Good views. Would i go on it again... No! But 2.3hkd its very cheap ride but nothing exciting

Must try!. Tram ride is certainly a must try unique HK experience! The fare is only HKD2.3 regardless of distance, which probably the most economical mode of transport to explore HK city areas. You will experience different tastes of HK, from metro feel at Central or Causeway Bay, to local flavor at Sheung Wan. In short, don't miss it!

Fun way to get around. Cute to look at (so narrow and so tall!) and fun to ride. Upstairs front window is a great spot for the view and also for the fun of being close to the next cable car at stops and looking in. Any place upstairs would have a good view though. Payment is as you get off the cable car (only form of transportation in Hong Kong where I noticed this), and you can use the Octopus card.
Interesting experience. It was an interesting experience getting onto the cable car. Not for people in a hurry though!

Low cost and great way to soak in HK Island at a digestable pace. To get a good feel of Hong Kong we recommend doing the double decker bus ride experience. You can catch it from the West side of Hong Kong Island and head to the east. It is an experience in itself and will allow you to soak in more of Hong Kong at a digestible pace. Once you have done the tram you will get around faster on the metro or cab. Tip: go on the 2nd level in the front seat for the best seat in the houseMore videos of the experience and more info and photos of Hong Kong athttp://chicvoyagetravel.com/featured-experience/hong-kong/hong-kong-guangzhou-experience/
up up and away... nice cable rite.. but if you want to scare yourself then you better take crystal cable car where you can see things down below.

Great way to travel across the city. We travelled from the Central District to the Causeway. Another great, cheap way of travelling about the city. HKD2.30 per trip, pay as you exit. As everybody else mentioned make sure you sit or stand upstairs to experience the views. Each stop is numbered. Easy to use, just check the map at the tram stop before getting on the keep your eye out for your stop. They are very crowded but A Must!

Nicer views than the Metro!. The tram is one of those classic must do attractions in Hong Kong.It is cheap too just swipe your Octopus card or use loose change on exit. We found it a bit hard to know when to hop off, so plan your journey if you have to get somewhere particular.Tip: If you want the best views for Photography sit upstairs at the rear or the front.

Only one in the World. Another example of public transit that is both convenient and fun. Make sure you go on the top deck and try to get the seat at the front. It is a great way to travel and a good way to see part of Hong Kong. Located in Hong Kong - we use it to go to the Happy Valley racecourse. Another help hint is to get an Octopus card - they are cards that carry cash on them and can be replenished is hundreds of locations. They work perfectly on all the public transit so you do not need to worry about having the correct change. They also work for purchasing other items such as drinking, food, etc. Wish we had these in Canada!

A unique Hong Kong experience. It's rumbling, it's open, it's crowded - it has to be the Hong Kong Cable Car. Typical for this metropolis, it connects all the important spots of Hong Kong Island. It's eather west- or eastbound and costs 2.30 HKD per ride. You have to pay cash, no Octopus card possible. Enter at the back of the tram and pay when you leave. For the best views, go upstairs and grab a seat in the front.
bus ride. We always take the double decker to Stanley markets,sit on top at the front FUN.

View from the top. We rode around on the car for a bit, but found it hard to tell (from street signs) where we were going. Very cheap, but not really useful for first timer's to HK Isle. Would have been better if we rode from one end of the rail tracks to the other. We planned to do this, but decided to walk instead to allow for more throughout sightseeing and exploration. You jump on and pay only when you exit. You must have exact change, $2.20 HKD.

Not so easy to navigate. Hard to tell where it stops and when it runs, often very crowded, if you are over 6' watch your head. Better the subway, but then and again you do not get the view if you take the subway.

You have to ride on the trams!. This is another iconic thing to do in HK (just like the Star Ferry, Ladies' Market, Victoria Harbour, Stanley....)It is inexpensive (use an Octopus or loose change) & so convenient (hop on and hop off). Sit upstairs for a better view. Avoid rush hours or if crowded just wait for the next one (they are frequent). Travel from one end of Hk Island (Sheung Wan) to the other end (Shau Kei Wan). Even in hot weather it can be pleasant due to the breeze through the open windows.Highly recommended!!!

One of the cheapest and best value things to do in HK. Take a tram from Central to Causeway Bay. It costs just $2.00. If you want to void the crowds, travel mid morning, but if you are not claustrophobic, go in the evening.
travel with the locals. easy on, easy off, easy to find, inexpensive way to get around.

Ting Ting Car. Hong Kis call this mode of transportation "ting ting cher" and I've always wanted to ride in one since young. So, when I was in Hong Kong on 19.05.2012, I took a ride in this tram. It is slow but it is enjoyable. We will pass many of the iconic big advertisements billboards that Hong Kong is well known for. The ride is smooth and the fare is the cheapest among all other mode of transportation in Hong Kong.Save your money and go for this ride rather than paying big bucks for the big city tour bus.

JoH883. This is such a fun thing to do! For a very small fee (using the Octopus Card) you can ride all along the HK foreshore and get a great view from the top deck. But don't carry much because the staircases are narrow and you need both hands to hold on.
Cheap and fun. A bit less convienent with a baby and especially a stroller, but it's always worth it to see the city from the tram !
Sight-seeing in comfort. A great way to see the city. Ride the second level, sit up front and enjoy the view.
Cheap entertainment.. Nice way to see Hong Kong. I enjoyed seeing different people getting on and off the cable car. Like I said, cheap entertainment.

Cheapest transport. With less than $3 u can go from one end of HK island to the other end. It takes hours though. At certain times the tram is packed. But if u can get seat at the upper deck, it is one of the best way for a city tour
Slowly but surely. If you have time, take the double decked cable car. Cheap but slow. A slow way to look at the city.

Real local pleasure. — An easy way to get around the city — that is holy true. — Very good method of sight seeing in Hong Kong — that is holy true too.— Super cheap — true again.Instruction — get in the tram, go on the top, sit, look at the window and enjoy. Recap — it's a real local pleasure. Recommend to spent couple of hours.
Very local. An easy way to get around the city, but don't bring bags and be a little patient. Can be a little crowded, hot and dusty.

A very good way of viewing Hong Kong island's main roads. This is a very good method of sight seeing in Hong Kong. If you have a lot of time to spend for the day, take a trip on this cable car. It is also the cheapest mode of transport in Hong Kong island.

Gotta do it!. Super cheap $2.30 HK pp. Get on in the back and pay/leave from the from the front. Sit up top, it's bit cooler :) Can be a bit confusing which tram to get on, but there is a map at all the stops.

Fun ride. Don't leave HK without getting on the cable car. Buy an octopus card and ride around the island. Sit at the front and enjoy the ride. Get in from the back and move your way to the top, front of the car. Pay by swiping your card as you exit from the front-too easy.

A must do. My first time visit to Hong Kong was made easier by printing off the maps of Double Deck Tram stops available via http://www.hktramways.com/en/index.html.
Tip - have an Octopus Card for travel and enter the tram from the back and leave the tram at the front

Not sure what the big deal is. I know that the trams in HK are historically significant (and cheap) but riding one is just a very awkward way to get around, on the back, stand up all the way, fight your way off the front. Underwhelming.
Best transport. Cheap (2.30!), good, just that it gets very very veyr packed at times. Locals tend to push. Not a fun thing to ride when it's raining heavily though.
Must do the Ding...Ding!!. Unbelievably cheap, but very cramped, worth just riding it in both directions to see of HK Central.

Maybe the World's cheapest ride. For HK$ 2.30 (about US30c) you can ride this genuine working century-old tram-line the length of Hong Kong Island, watching the hustle-bustle of HK below you. prepare to be hot, humid, and sometimes gassed by the far-to-many double-decker buses congesting the city. Amazing to think that the tram-line used to snake along the waterfront, there are blocks of land reclamation between the tram and harbour these days.
Small but nice. It's a rare sight to see these cars in the small Hong Kong. It's quite cheap and they ride till night.
Quaint trams. These trams take you back in time, not modern at all, very nostalgic

TRAM Car. It’s a pity the heading for the reviews for this wonderful old transport system refers to it as a “Cable Car.” They are in fact Tram Cars, driven by their own electric motors. They are loved by natives and visitors alike, and are affectionately known as the “Ding Ding” - In both Chinese and English :-) Cable Cars are hauled along by a cable under the street - as in San Francisco!Please moderator, tell me if I am being too picky, but I do think we should get it right,
Awesome nostalgic ride/convenient and cheap, too. Easy to take throughout Hong Kong Island. Cheap and convenient schedule. Get a seat upstairs for a leisurely afternoon's sightseeing journey!

Sit Up Top and Enjoy the Sights. We loved this tramline, both as a way to travel across Hong Kong and a way to relax and see the sights. Using the Octopus card made it very easy. We hopped off if we wanted to see something, then got back on later. There are lots of trams, all painted up in bold colors as advertisements. If you want to speed along, use another type of transport.

A great & cheap way to see Hong Kong. For HKD 2.30, U can discover what HK can offer tourists. My first ride was from Causeway Bay to Kennedy Town. It is a slow ride but nevertheless the sceneries are just fantastic.

Terrific to ride a slice of history-- if you have the time!. HK Island's ding ding trams are a delight, if you have the time! They are decidedly slower than other modes of transport, and seem to stop ever so often, but it's a delight to ride a real slice of history! Don't miss it if you are on HK Island.The ride is not always smooth though, and the cars do jerk at times, some appear to be fitted with powerful air horns as well, though there are mercifully hardly used, the ding ding bell being the warning system of choice. The wooden seats are more cramped that the seats we are used to on modern public transport, but what the hell! And mercifully, the trams appear to be well patronized, they get packed at times. But it's a thoroughly enjoyable experience.

The cheapest way to explore Hong Kong. Trams - the cheapest way to explore this city. By paying US$0.30, you can hop onto a tram that takes you tour around Hong Kong Island for hours. That is my recommendation for the first time visitors, before they have some idea of what they want to do in the city. It is cheap, safe and EASY. There are not many double-decker trams in the world and our network is the biggest!There is just one long tramline along the northern part of HK Island (east-west direction) plus a little loop into Happy Valley where the horse-racing course is located. In case you see something interesting, you can always gett off, find out what interests you then hop on another tram (have to pay another US$0.30 of course). If you have enough, just take the trams in the opposite direction and it will bring you back to your starting point. There is no tram running in opposite direction in the loop, of course it is unnecessary.When you wish to add this program into your itinerary, here are some advices: (1) avoid the busy hours when there are a lot of people using the trams, (2) avoid the hot days as trams have no air-conditioning, (3) be sure you have an octopus card as you probably do not have so many coins! For the above reasons, I only give it 4 stars instead of 5. :(Bring your camera or video recorder along. If you can find a seat in the front on the upper deck (always go onto the upper deck for better views), you can take some beautiful pictures/video of the street scenes of Hong Kong. In my opinion, the section in Wanchai is the most interesting where you can see a lot of interesting things going on beside the tramway. I recommend you to get off there and visit the side-streets too.
Cheap and relaxing. It goes slow, so it's a perfect way to relax and rest your feet and observe Hong Kong island at the same time. And it's cheap!

A great way to see Hong Kong. I love the ding ding tram! I was staying all the way out in Chai Wan; woke up early the first morning because of jet lag, took the MTR to Shau Kei Wan, and then rode the tram the entire length of the line. It was a marvelous experience to sit up front at the top with the cool air blowing in, watching the city wake up and people begin to go about their day-to-day lives. Another night I took the tram most of the way back, which is another unique experience - you get a close-up view and feel part of the lights and bustle without the exhaustion of wading through the crowds.
(Practically) free sightseeing!. Easy and fun, and extremely cheap way to see Hong Kong Island

Fun, cheap way to move around. We took this because it's the clearest way to Happy Valley, but when we got to the racetracks, there was no race that night. Good thing the tram ride was super enjoyable. It's a unique way to experience the city. It's slow so it's perfect for sight-seeing. You can easily get on or off if you see something interesting.

It's almost a must. The cheapest way to see most of Hong Kong. Use your Octopus card and go for a ride. Try to get a seat in the front row on the upper level and have your camera ready. If you see something interesting just leave at the next station. You can always continue your ride, it's sooo inexpensive.
Ding Ding! A cheap historic ride. The Ding Ding’s are a great way to see HK; cheap too! Watch your head though!

Too crowded. Great experience to hop on to this heritage transport. But it was very crowded until I could hardly move when it was reaching the alighting station. I am not sure if there is certain time of the day it's less crowded and could have some sightseeing?

Just fun. Just for fun, take the tram and sit on top. Gives you a good view of the city. A bit jarring and definately not fast but for $2.50 HKD, it is very inexpensive. You will need exact change unless you use your Octopus card (recommended).

Fun experience. I used the tram from Tonnochy Road in Wanchai to Cotton Tree Drive. It was an awesome experience for me and my parents even though the tram is quite small and slow.The price for the ticket is also cheap. We used the Octopus Card to pay the fee as it is easier. If I am not mistaken, the HKian call this cable car as Ding Ding.
cheap and fun. Why not? Is a bit slow, but something different. I wouldn't put this at the top of my list but if you could use it to get where you want to go, and are not in a hurry you should do it.
2,30 HKD per trip = great sightseeing. It's not the quickest way to get around, but it's dirt cheap and will allow you to really view the city! Don't think about it, just do it!
Fun for a while. Should def take it for a few stops but it gets too hot in the summer. But def fun!

Take it from one end to the other.. This is a fun way to see Hong Kong Island. Take it from start to finish for a really great view of the busiest part of Hong Kong. You board at the back and get off and pay as you leave from the front. Go upstairs for the best view. The cost is just a few Hong Kong Dollars so it is a great value. You will need exact change or an Octopus card.

nice and comfortable. briliant views upto the peak, well worth the price and the trip, truly amazing. busy but always the que moves fast too, dont be disapointed if que is long its worth the wait , every 10 mins for next tram

Tour the sights of Hong Kong. Fantastic, takes you all around Hong Kong with the availability to get on and off at interesting areas. Night tour was great with all the lights etc. Costs was very reasonable. A must when in Hong kong.
Very cool!. It's got to be done...and is such a cheap way to get around. Just have your change ready as you exit, otherwise the driver may get cross with you!
