perfect for a city tour by yourself. In case your friends have to work or just dont want, take the big bus tour and catch a bit of the different faces of Hong kong. I personally suggest to take the south tour were you will also go to Stanley and Aberdeen as you will see enough from HK island but not only city but also the lovely beach side..
A fantastic way to see the sights. A real old Hong Kong experience, it is best if you can make the top deck.
Great fun for kids. This was one of my kids favourite things we did. They loved sitting at the top front of the tram and waving to the passengers in the oncoming trams - a bargain too!
The English Have Left Their Mark On Hong Kong. Not for tall people. The views on top were great! An inexpensive way to see Hong Kong and get around.

A good and inexpensive way to see the city.. For as little at $2.5 HKD you can ride the double decker tram and see the city sites. The cost is the same no matter where you get on or off. Sit on the top for the best views and experience, it is encloses with windows that can be opened for air and to take pictures.

Loved it!. A cheap way to see the real Hong Kong along the way. REALLY inexpensive, we hopped on and went to the end and got off and just hopped right back on to go back to Central a couple of times. the ride is fun and sit at the front or the back for a nice view.
Bit of a squash!!!. they are really busy but great fun!! and easy to work out which one you need to get to your destination

Way to see HK island slowly. Upper deck is a must. Suggest get on at Causeway Bay to Kenndy Town / Shek Tong Tsui. Free to return at terminal... or get off anytime while you see any thing interesting, just HK$2.3 one time.
A Hong Kong Tradition. It was fun being on these double decker buses and cable cars. I have ridden on the ones in London but I think I enjoyed these more.

Prehistoric. This things look like they've been around for centuries but a real part of Hong Kong. Just jump on board and cruise the steets. They are built like tanks and very cheap way to see the downtown areas

The Local, Economical and Best Way to See Hong Kong. For $2.30 HK you can get the best tour of Hong Kong on these charming double decked trams. We boarded at the Pedder stop just after disembarking the ferry at "Central" from Tsim Sha Tsui and rode to the last station in the east Shau Kei Wan. Once there, we walked around the open-air food market, ate in a local snack bar, visited one of the temples where you can photograph inside without a flash and without a tripod. We then hopped back on and went to the western-most stop - Kennedy Town. A bit run-down looking and later, I found out this used to be the red-light district. In any event, it is not the destinations that are important, but the journey itself. Try to get a seat up top and in the front for the best views and photos. From the centre of the city, each ride (centre to east and centre to west) takes about an hour.
Double Decker Tram. Actually, not a cable car but a tram or trollery. Best value for sightseeing. Hop on, go on top and go the front. Get your camera ready and enjoy the views.
It's fantastic!. Riding this double deck car in Hong Kong is quite fantastic. Try this when you're in Hong Kong. Nice!

Great Way to Appreciate HK. If you're looking for a different - and less tiring - way to see some of the key sites on Hong Kong Island, you can't beat the tram.Make sure you sit upstairs for the best view!

Great !. Frequent, inexpensive, connect with MTR on Honk Kong island...Well,convenient way to travel around central in an unsual and way.Get in at the rear, pay when you leave the cable car (octupus card accepted otherwise you need to have some small change).Try to get a seat upstairs and enjoy the street view.Really must Do!
cable car. nice way to get around the crowded city. on the second deck , you get a nice view of the city as you ride around.

The tram, maybe?. The old HK double decker trams are a fun ride through the main business/shopping/commercial streets of HK. It's like a thrill ride in slow motion. Don't take your luggage - space is pretty tight!!!
Great wy to see HK. It was a great incite into real hong kong ie not a touristy thing to do

Best way to see Hong Kong Island on a TRAM. 1. Price for a tram ride HKD2.30 (hiked up as of late 2011)2. Needs time. Great way to view Hong Kong Island at a slow paced and pleasant manner.3. Good idea to sit on the upper deck. Great view, and also great for photos - try and get a seat right in front or at the end. I love the trams. I live in Hong Kong and just can't get enough of them! Lovely especially since the city is lightening paced in every other way. A ride on a tram makes me feel relaxed. :)

Some clarifications. Just wish to clarify an earlier comment I read - I am a HK local:The stored value cash card for the various modes of transportation, only allows one person to pay per time, so you cannot pay for multiple persons using one card - you'd need one card per person. And the card is called the Octopus Card, not Oyster Card. :-)

Good and cheap way to see Hong Kong. This is a good way to see Hong Kong, especially on Hong Kong Island, where the tram travels from Central to Happy Valley and Causeway Bay etc. These quaint rides have been around for over 100 years and are popular with both locals and tourists. They are so narrow that you can almost touch each side of the tram with your arms!
must try. You can take this tram as sight seeing around the island and can access to all city centre such as causeway bay or central

Best way to see Hong Kong. This is public transportation on Hong Kong Island in the form of double deck street cars (trams) of considerable vintage. Go on the top deck and you get a unique view as it travels through Central District, Wanchai and Happy Valley. There are different routes, but that doesn't matter - get on one, go to the end, then come back! If you want to get somewhere in a hurry use the MTR, which parallels the route. Best seats are at the very front on the top deck.Pay when you get off. Exact change or use your Octopus card. Can get very crowded.
A different riding experience!. It was such a fun experience to ride the bus (Bus 639) going to Ocean Park...Cool and so clean.

Cheap and interesting. This would be one of the cheapest way to travel around, costing only about HKD 2.30 per trip regardless of where you hop off. If you get the front seats at the upper deck, you will get to enjoy great views of the city and the tram moves slow enough for you to get some nice pictures. The only downpoint is that there is no announcement of the upcoming stops so you would need to have a little sense of direction by yourselves to determine the right time to hop off.

One of the best in Hong Kong. Great way to see Hong Kong in a slow manner. Very unusual. But you will meet a lot of local people who are always ready to help.My kids loved it!But never use if you are in a hurry!

Get oyster card if you are traveling a few times. The ding dings (local name for tram) are great. They are easy to use, nostalgic, fun.Get a HK$150 oyster card from metro. More than one person can use per travel. Ding Di g costs HK$2.30 per travel or 30c AUD.

Historic Must-do. This is a must if you're in Hong Kong. It's incredibly inexpensive and a great way to see the area as it moves quite slowly, but that's a definite plus for anyone there on holiday. If I had one tiny criticism, it would be that it's not super clean; although, it is public transport, and I was on it on a Friday night, so that's not unforgivable.

Best value ride in town.. Okay, the price has gone up by 30cts in the past 5 years but at $2.3 per trip this still remains the best way to see HK island from end to end. Glad to see that the private owners of the trams seem to be better placed to survive than the no-longer-so-impressive Star Ferry ride across the harbour. If only the ferry could be given as much respect and leeway by the Govt that the trams seem to get.

Fun cheap and quick. The tram service covers the south part of the island - Kennedy town to the north point, with several stops in between. Try to get to the upper deck, you will see better view of the streets especially at night. You pay when you leave - either with octopus or exact change. HKD 2.30 for a trip regardless of the distance. Great way to go to Causeway Bay (Time Sq, Sogo), Happy Valley (look for the final destination at the front of the tram), some may go directly to North Point instead.

A bit of nostalgia still running on the streets of Hong Kong. Cheap and a new way to see/get around the city.. There is one flat fare for the trolley (1.5 HKD?), no matter where you get off. We were intending on riding til it looped around but it lost its novelty after about 20 minutes. The great thing about this is that the stops are spaced close together, so if you see someplace that looks interesting, you can just hop off. We took it to an MTR stop then took the metro to our next destination.

If this is what we think it is...... This is a regular, cheap tram service on Hong Kong Island. You have to know how to use it though. We used it to get to Times Square. Hop on through the turnstyle at the rear of the tram. It can be very crowded. Don't worry. Gentlly move down the tram as people exit at the front of the tram. People will move to let you off at your stop. We also found lots of friendly and helpful chinese on the trams eager to help with directions. Have the exact change, which is tossed in a metal box at the front of the tram. In February 2012 the fare for seniors was 1 HK dollar. Everyone else pays 2.30. This transport is not suitable for people with disabilities. If you want a bit of excitement, this is the way to travel.

A great way to see city life. A very slow form of transport that takes you through the city streets, allowing you to have a good look at whats going on. Caught one from North Point into Central. Took a hour but good fun

Don't mix up peak tram (cable car) & city tram in Hong Kong. First of all, they are two different mode of transport in Hong Kong. The cable car (we usually call it Peak Tram) is single deck (red in colour) that runs up the Peak from Mid-Level (Garden Road). They are operated by two trams linked up by a cable one running down hill with the other one running up-hill on a single track but split into two somewhere in the middle. From the Peak Tram station up the hill, you can see a large part of the Victoria Habour; just like the typical post card you can see about Hong Kong. There is also a shopping centre with restaurants next to it. Bus station is just at the basement. The Peak is definitely a place that is worthwhile (highly recommended to tourists) to go if you have never visit Hong Kong before or leaving for long time. What you can do is to take the Peak Tram uphill but take Route No. 15 bus downhill. When riding on thedouble deck bus down the hill, you can have a view on the famous horse racing course - Happy Valley from the top. Leave the bus in Causeway Bay or Wanchai where you can visit another shopping area in Hong Kong Island.
Great. So much fun and really cool, also really inexpensive.

Another HK must. As were ambling around the Causeway Bay area on the Island, you couldnt help but notice these buses. It is an experience, the bus may be crowded but the cost is incredibly cheap. They may be slower but you do get to see the sights.

The ding dings are a must!. I realize that many of you are tourists and want to ride the ding ding for an "experience" --- we did so 25 years ago as tourists. But living here, the ding dings (onomatopoeia at its best) are just a cheap and easy way to get around if you are reasonably close by. Enter in the back and either go up stairs or start making your way to the front. No need to push past people, just move forward with the crowd. of course you might get a seat!Tourists will want to go out upstairs for a view. Some newly remodeled ones have lost that old feel a bit but have more standing room. Did you know you can rent these out and have a private party? http://www.hktramways.com/en/tramhire/index.html That's kind of a fun couple of hours and they will provide food and beverages or you can provide. Load up on Paisano's pizzas and your favorite beverages and take a couple dozen fiends up and down the Island!From Central through Causeway Bay I hardly even pay attention to which one I am on as long as it is headed in the right direction. Just avoid happy Valley and Racecourse as they turn off....Remember you exit the front and either swipe your Octopus card or pay cash. It isn't much, so have your small change.
Scary. Be prepared as you go up the steepest hill in HK. It is truley amazing and the view at the top is breath taking

Lots of fun and a mour first trip to Hong Kongust do on y. Travelling around on the bustling through back to a bygone age is lots of fun. Make sure you are upstairs as the views are better and if possible get the seats at the front.

A tram... not a cable car.. This is not a cable car (powered by attaching to an underground cable, and managed by a Gripman) - it is an electric tram car (powered via the pantograph on the roof linking to the overhead line, and managed by a Driver). It's a totally different experience and slice of transport history - and there are many more of them in the world than there are historic cable car systems. However, on Hong Kong Island, the trams offer a very cheap, convenient (with Octopus Card) and safe way of having a bit of a look around. Good for the kids... go upstairs.

Good way to see Hong Kong while resting your feet. We rode the tram after walking up and down the hills of Hong Kong. It was a nice way to relax and continue to sight see. It is slow so we only took it one way and then caught the MTR (much less scenic but faster) back.This was inexpensive but it wasn't included on the Airport Express octopus card so if you have one of these cards make sure you add some extra fare to cover this.

Best mode of transport in HK Island - slow and steady creature. I love the HK Tram! Is slow, steady, and very awesome mode of transport! When I was working in HK, this was my favorite mode of transport, great way to soak in the street atmosphere. For one flat rate, you can travel one end to the other end (Saukeiwan to Kennedy Town). This is a great transport if you have the time (is slow). Sometimes taking the tram could be faster than taking the bus (as the tram uses a dedicated lane) if there is a jam. It brings you to most tourist spots in HK Island (Central, Wan Chai, Causeway Bay, Sheung Wan etc). There is even a loop to Happy Valley (note the tram front sign board which will show you the tram direction).I love the slow and steady trams - bring back many happy memories! Ding - ding!
See the authentic HK. This is a fun and inexpensive way to see all of HK and not just the tourist attractions. These trams take you all around the city and you can get a real feel for authentic HK.

Awesome is the word I using to describe. Do tell anyone you've visiting Hong Kong if you haven't ride on the double decked cable car. It's the best way to "Walk" around Hong Kong Island, to feel and breathe the air of Hong Kong. The best route you can get is Sheung Wan to North Point. Make sure you ride it to the End station! Big Big tip.

Cheapest attraction in Hong Kong. took a tram ride from our hotel in North Point to the Hong Kong and Shanghai Bank Building to alight for the Peak. What a wonderful way to just cruise through the city with all of the hustle and bustle going on below and appreciate the old and new buildings.

Great way to see Hong Kong. Have been travelling to Hong Kong for the last 15 years - this january was the 1st time to take the Tram.Great value and an easy wasy to get around and see the sights of Hong kong.Fare is paid when you get off and is a fixed price per journey.
Classic city icon. Must do if in Hong Kong. Make sure you have enough coins. 2.30 HK$

best way to travel in hong kong. this is by far the best way to travel in Hong Kong.you have never visited HongKong if you do not ride this.cheap and chearful and goes a long way.If you ride from the main station you will get a good front seat

Best way to see more with less efforts. Finally exasperated with the footpaths? A little exhausted by the heat and the humidity. Out of breath because of the pollution? Take the tram, climb to the first floor, take a seat in front and finally, there you can take pictures without people pushing you around or blocking your lense. You'll see Hong Kong much more and in much better conditions by doing this. And it's cheap too!

One of the easiest, cheapest, most fun way to get around Hong Kong.. I have used this transport system each time I have visited Hong kong over the decades and am surprised by so many long time visitors who have never ever tried it. Not only is it a charming relic of the past but it's actually a very practical way to get from North to South in HK proper. You can really get lost as it's mostly on one track. It's easy to see and get on and off even if you don't know the stops the worse that will happen is you're two blocks too short or further down. It's costs almost nothing plus you get a very nice birds eye view of the streetlife from the 2nd floor. Most recommended!

Trams of the past. This old trams are from the days of the British Empire. However it´s great to take a ride in them. Try to get a seat in front of the top. Only the seats are very small. So don´t expect a great seat.
A must. Sort out some change (or get yourself a pass) and away you go. The best way to travel!!
Ding Ding, Ding Ding. Another piece of commuter transport that has to be enjoyed. Get on at the start or end of a line to get the coveted upper deck front seat and BRING your camera/video !!

tram. if youre referring to the tram well it is a nice(and very cheap) experience trying this, i hopped in just to kill time and look around since i decided not to go to the peak because of the long queue on a sunday morning...you can use your octopus card or just drop hk2+ sorry i dont remember cause i used my card as you exit the tram,i stayed at the top so good thing it didnt rain
just hop on. great (and cheap) way to see Hong Kong Island. Best at night. Head upstairs and take it all in.
Pedantic point. It's not a cable car, it's a tram!!It's still great fun though and so cheap. A real must-do!

Something different. A wonderfully nostalgic way to get some sights in, at a leisurely pace, and economical to boot. Get up from the back, and tap your octopus card when you you exit at the front. Also a good way to the traffic jams that can get quite bad.The stairs leading to the upper deck are rather steep, and be prepared to stand if all the seats are taken. Not a lot of seats, since the tram is not huge, so this is a common possibility.
Bargain sightseeing. Cheap and interesting way to see parts of Hong Kong
Great. aways like to spend time in HK, have a couple of good dinners, and enjoy the chops

the cheapest tourist fare. For $2.30 it would have to be the cheapest tour of HK island. Get on, find a seat upstairs and watch HK world pass by as the tram rambles from one end of the HK to the other.

avoid the traffic. trying to get from Wanchai over to Happy Valley for the races last year took 45 minutes in awful traffic. We went last night on the cable car, it was delightful, and didn'y have to worry about the traffic. Hopped on one after the races and was back in Wanchai in 15 minutes!! And it costs next to nothing.

HK's Cheapest Transport. HK Island has this wonderful narrow gauge cable car. A great way to met the locals and cheap to boot. My wife commented just like the cable car in Harry Potter movie - she was right.
Tram ride. Another must do. Remember to get on at the back and leave at the front, and it only costs about 20p! amazing value
Nice view from above. Nice view especially if you are the one riding in front at the second level of the bus.

Charming way to see Hong Kong.. It only costs a couple of Hong Kong Dollars to ride it. And you can go from one tip of the Island to the other. Make sure you get on the top deck, so you can have a very particular view of this amazing city. Don't forget your camera: you will see and experience a different Hong Kong. If you have good weather, this is a beautiful experience!

Fun. This is a great way to see old and new hong kong, you go through market areas, chinese herbalists, antiques through to the business centre and then onto where everyday people live and go about their lives - I thoroughly enjoyed the travel and at around $2 AUD for the whole journey.....

Nice Glimpse of the "Real" Hong Kong. As previously said, there is no such thing as a fake Hong Kong - everything is real. However, to fastest way to get under Hong Kong Island's skin is by riding these ding-dings. I boarded one in front of the HSBC building in Central and went all the way to the Sheung Wan Tram Terminus. The ride was pretty amazing but I must admit that I got bored at some point and never completed the whole route from West to East. Anyway, it was a pretty good insight into what people do daily -- buying, selling, walking, and basically being busy.

A Cheap Way Through Famous Hong Kong Areas. For some strange reason this iconic Hong Kong attraction is more fully described and commented upon under the heading 'double decked cable cars'. As such it has reached number 9 in HK attractions. I therefore suggest you check out the reviews there. Suffice to say here that if you have the time you can use these trams as a superb way of seeing many tourist spots on Hong Kong Island very cheaply. They are sometimes crowded, but just get on at the back and keep working your way to the front where you will get off. You will need the right coins or better still, use an Octopus card.

A great way to see Hong Kong Island. I love these trams. If you are not in a hurry, you will certainly get a very good view of the major areas on Hong Kong Island. Starting in Central (not far from the Star Ferry) choosing either East or Westbound trams will take you through interesting areas. Those heading towards Kennedy Town will take you through the really interesting (and a bit smelly) dried sea food streets, while those heading East towards Shau Kei Wan will take you through the famous districts of Wanchai and Causeway Bay. As the fare is so cheap (only HK2.30) you can use it as your own hop-on hop-off service. The routes and stops can be found at this website: http://hktramways.com/en/service/routemap2.htmlThe trams can get a bit busy though and you may find yourself standing. You have to enter from the back and leave from the front. I always make my way up stairs for a good view, and my favourite seats (if I have the chance to get one) are those at the very front.

Less than $0.31 USD For An Excellent Ride. Road in the top deck of the ding ding my first day in Hong Kong for an hour and half to get a view of the western, central and eastern areas of Hong Kong Island. I boarded early on a Saturday morning, had no problem getting a good seat and it wasn't crowded the whole trip. The front seating gives excellent views but the views from the back seats were better since the back window was down. Less than thirty-one cents (US) for an unlimited one-time ride is fantastic. Going the ding ding way is a top-notch experience.

Great (and easiest) way to travel. (Why is it called a "cable car". Surely it is a motorised tram?)We loved it. It was the simplest way to travel. Although HKG has a great metro system, it involves long walks down tunnels, along escalators etc. With buses, you need to be aware of numbers, routes etc. No such problem with the trams - there was simply one line, travelling West - East. You literally hop on and off.The equipment was antique so at least you had something to look at while travelling.But we rarely got a seat. Forget about the reccommendations to get a seat upstairs in front - it was always crowded. It was popular amongs the elderly and Philipino maids, possibly because it was the cheapest way to travel. But you need to be reasonably fit to "strap-hang"

Always worth a go. It's one of the slowest ways to get around the island but fun to ride on off peak hours if you can get a seat on the top. For the price of the fare, it's worth the ride where you can see the sights of Hong Kong at a leisurely pace.

Iconic HK. Another piece of HK! You have to ride a tram!!....and yes, go upstairs to the top deck, feel the breeze against your skin, breathe in Hong Kong! And all this for 2HK$......you could ride the whole line and back - what a great way to really see Hong Kong life. Don't forget your camera!

Best way to see the city. I did a massive amount of walking in HK but I'm glad I spent a couple of hours hopping on and off the cable cars, as I would never have been able to see as much of the city as I did without them. They're cheap, fun, and the tracks go for miles.

Amazing.. On this attraction you can get a glass bottom or covered bottom to go from Tung Chung to the massive Buddha. The view over the valley and waterway below is spectacular. The cable car attracts a lot of visitors, and is really worth taking the 5.7km ride to the Ngong Pin township. From here there is a nice stroll to the base of the 254 steps up to the Tian Tan Buddha which is extremely large. The are eateries and gift shops in Ngong Pin and also the Po Lin Monastery. Such a wonderful experience.
Rest your feet. Great way to see HK, esp if you aren't into walking at the moment. Get a capsular view of the city and areas.

The largest double decked tram system in the world.. The Hong Kong double-decker trams have been running since 1904. They are the cheapest form of transportation in Hong Kong. The cheap fares in part explain the crowded trams. The trams are slow but they provide a visitor with an interesting insight into Hong Kong. The routes extend from Kennedy Town in the West to Shau Kei Wan in the East on Hong Kong Island. There are 118 stops and there is a tram stop roughly every 250 meters. There are 161 passenger trams and they constitute the world’s largest double-decker tram system. History buffs should remember that the trams run along the harbor shoreline, as it existed in 1904. This is one way to see how much land has been reclaimed in the last century. The trams are all painted with advertisements that are very colorful. Companies can hire a tramcar for a year and use the tram body as a mobile advertisement. Considerable ingenuity goes into the decoration of the trams. For a wonderful view of the city from a different perspective, climb to the upper level and sit in the front seats of the tram to see Hong Kong from an entirely different perspective. Be sure to bring your camera!

a great way to go to the non touristic part of the city. if you are in a hurry going from one place to another, don't take the tram...but if you have time during non rush hour, just pop into one and try to get a seat in the upper deck, you can get to know Hong Kong more by just sitting and looking around...

Very Harry Potterish. We have decided that the trams must have been the inspiration behind the crazy bus in the HP movies. They are so narrow and tall that you feel they are almost miniature and you almost expect them to topple over as they are so thin. The stairs are really narrow and winding and we just had to ride right in the front up the top. We used the tram to travel a few stops on HK island, and while I agree that the routes don't get you to many places they are such a novel way to get around we found them a "must do"

Iconic Transport, memorable experience. They are not really cable cars, rather trams with electric motors with the power coming from overhead cables (cable car?). We rode them in the Causeway bay area, you get on the back and pay at the front when you get off. Octopus card is the best way. They can get crowded so getting off, if you are at the back is difficult,.Best to go up the top as there are also stairs down at the front, so easier to get out.
Funny. Just a fun thing to do, I suppose. Don't think it's very efficient for getting around. Maybe for some areas
An awesome cheap way to see Hong Kong. Get a seat up on the front upper level and enjoy a side of Hong Kong you can't get from the subways

From end-to-end, a cheap transport with great sights. Enough said about it. Take it and you will know. One thing I like about Hong Kong, they don't get rid of things just because the new stuff are more efficient.

ding ding tram. we tried the tram, ding ding double decker..the time we rode it, it was always full and the hallway is very narrow..its our first time..but maybe if we live in Hong Kong, we will get used to it..and we us a tourist there we really have to study well the port of getting on and off , the names of the streets ..and of course, as all Hong Kongners say..get an Octups card which is really really convenient..coz drivers never give u money change..
Still the best tour for the money in the world. Watch life in Hong Kong bustle about you from a traditional viewing platform: 2 hours of viewing entertainment of great variety for US$0.16.

A cheap way to get around Hong Kong. Odd that a transportation system would have status as a tourist attraction. I don't see any reviews of the 63X bus here... Hong Kong's trams (and they are trams, not cable cars - cable cars are things that go up and down mountains, these move through the resolutely horizontal streets of Hong Kong) are a cheap, often crowded, noisy, and rather slow way to navigate Hong Kong. But they're cheap. Even with the recent fare increase (2.30 per trip) there's no cheaper way to get around apart from walking.They're packed at certain times - weekends and evenings. If you're only going on the tram for recreational purposes, please be aware that some people use them to commute and it would be politer not to gawp, and not to take up space when you could just as easily sit on the tram in the middle of the day and not contribute to it being overcrowded. Although if you want the full Hong Kong public transport experience, wait and see if you can spot the gloomy sight of a pregnant woman having to stand while everyone who's occupying the seating studiously ignores her. Unmissable!

Pointless. Was told that this is one of the "must see" things in HK, but it was not all it's hyped up to be.Crowded and slow.Sure, it took you from one side of the island to the other, but if you can't see out the window, then there's no point. Also, did I mention that it's ridiculously crowded and slow?
Very Hong Kong. I like HK cable cars, I can visit the town, feeling the energy and still being quietly sitting where a moving view is. I recommend it to real HK lovers

Great way to see the sights. The double decked cable cars are a wonderful way to see the city. They're all very nice, clean and comfortable. We loved to sit up on the top deck in the front. Its so hot in Hong Kong; we loved just sitting and relaxing seeing the sights this way...

Excellent Way to See Hong Kong. Make sure you have pleanty of coins as no change is given. Our hotel was only 2 minutes walk from the terminus and we were able to ride all the was across the island for the equivalent of a few pence. The are great, winding their way through the busy streets. Sit up top and see Hong Kong life as you pass by. Very gentle pace, no good if your are in a hurry.

The Ding Ding Is a Must-Do in Hong Kong. Considering my first ride on a Ding Ding was back on hot summer day in 1990 and some pervert molested me (taking advantage of very crowded situations) and a couple other foreign women, I still love the Ding Ding.I recommend going when it's not busy, though.The front seats in the upper deck are my favorite.Pick a quieter time and just go along for the ride.Check the website to get a better idea of what the routes are: ---------

Another "must do" in Hong Kong.. Get the feel for Hong Kong for about AU$0.25 and go for a ride on a double-decker cable car (tram). They are clean, noisy and full of locals plus a few tourists. Make sure you have the correct fare as no change is given.
Bizzare, but free and ruthlessly efficient. Excellent, much like all of Hong Kong - it just works as it should

Fun to ride, but a bit crowded.. This cable car ride is a must if you wanna complete the checklist of tourist activity in Hong Kong. It is cheap ($2HKD if I am not wrong.), convenient, and give you good view of Hong Kong island. You can always take subway if you want, but it would not give you the view that the cable car has.

Don't miss this!. We almost decided to skip the ding-ding tram ride as we haven't got any slightest idea how or where to board the tram. But we decided to give it a try on our last day in HK and I'm so glad we didn't miss this. We basically follow how others get on the tram (via the rear entrance, further away from the driver's seat) and enjoy the sights and sounds while the tram crawls along the road. It's enjoyable and cheap!
My parents love it. It is nice way to go around HK island. We go to the western market using this and the tram stop very near (nearly in front) of the market.

Its the BEST transport in Hongkong. I love them. The terminus was right outside my hotel, and while they might be unsuitabe for those with little time, the tram is an excellent means of transport around the Central District and Causeway Bay. They are so slow, you can watch streetlife below you (naturally, sit on the top deck). You need to have exact change or an Octopus card (so much more convenient) and you pay on exit. On my last day in HongKong, having ticket off most sights I wanted to see, I did nothing but ride the tram, shop and eat - and it was my favourite day.

Cheap & fun. The best way to see the sights and experience the Hong Kong culture on Hong Kong Island, compared to taking the MTR. Taking the ride during off-peak hours will guarantee a seat at the front of the upper deck to get a good view of the city. You pay a flat fare of $2.3 as you get off and get on at the back of the tram. If time allows, take the longest route from Western Market to Shau Kei Wan, it takes about an hour and a half. Don't worry if you want to get off at a particular place of interest as there are many stops along the route (approximately every 250 metres) and the service is very frequent.

This tram runs on the old shoreline of Hong Kong!. This is the cheapest and most fun way to see a lot of Hong Kong. The tram was built years ago and runs along an old shoreline, before landfill extended the city out and out into Victoria Harbour. You can get off and on with little expense, but my friend and I stayed on as I was exhausted from a month of travel and a busy time in Kowloon the previous day. I loved seeing the different neighborhoods, including where my friend went to school and lived, and the famous race track and sporting clubs of the city. I loved passing great statues, lively streets that begged to be photographed with their colorful signs, and old cemeteries with their great stones suggesting the history of the city.When we had finally run through all the routes on the tram, we got off the bus, had a quick bite to eat at a local fast food restaurant, although McDonalds was across the street.When we finished, it was dusk and darkening quickly So we caught a bus, as they are faster, back to the neighborhood above my hotel and I walked the labyrinth of walkways to my high rise on the Harbour.The tram is the perfect way to see non-tourist Hong Kong and take a day off from the scurrying about that seeing a busy metropolitan area demands.

They are fun, cheap and quick.. They are an institution in Hong Kong and run parallel to the water front so they are quick a quick way of moving about Hong Kong and they go to all the main places. Also they are very cheap 2.4hong kong dollars.

Cheap way to see the city. They offer lower fare than the other modes of transportation. They are slower than buses, but they are ideal for visitors unfamiliar with the city. You are less likely to miss your trolley stop, plus you get to see the city as an added bonus.
excellent way to see HK. cheap to ride, fun t be on, especially if u can get to sit in front on top.
Get a front row seat!. Almost like a Disney Land ride. No bumps, safety is good, seats are little cramped if you're over 6' tall.

So much fun!. Make sure you have your MTR card at the ready when you enter and exit the cars! We couldnt get off as it was so busy and had to run to the front to 'tap' our cards! Hectic in the rush hour but worth a mingle with the locals. If you are not sure where the one you are on is going just go a couple of stops, or like us just sit on board untill you need to get off. You will never go too far from a taxi stand or the MTR stop!
EXPERIENCE IT. Great way to get around Honk Kong, cheap, hair raising...who needs a roller coaster when you have these :)

Great way to see the city. The Cable Car / Tram runs along the main street of the Island, it is a handy way of getting around. Quite cheap also it is a great way to avoid the crowds; but...If you MUST get off at a particular stop be aware that during peak periods it can get extremely busy, packed to the point where we took about 3 stops to make it downstairs. We didn't mind because we were just sightseeing, but the driver will only stop for a very short while at each stop - so if you are not at the door ready to jump out you will likely miss it and have to get the next one.Also FYI get on at the back and exit from the front - you pay on the way out - just drop some cash into the slot or tap your Octopus Card.They are such a distinctive sight on the street, such a great way to travel - although sometimes in heavy traffic I am pretty sure walking is just as quick - but nowhere near as much fun.

Why spend US$5 in San Francisco when you can ride a better cable car tram in Hong Kong for US$0.36. The historic 'ding ding' cable car tram that slowly makes its way down the streets of Hong Kong Island. This is something visitors can do very quickly and easily and is an activity that children can enjoy as well. Just board the ding-ding at one of the many hop-on, hop-off stops with HK$2.30 in hand or tap your Octupus Card and off you go!We much prefer to ride on the top level, in the front is the very best but those seats are very frequently taken. Best to have your camera ready as there always seems to be something to take a picture of when looking out the Ding Ding windows. The ding ding has recently increased its prices from HK$2 to HK$2.30 but this is just a fraction of the cost of riding the similar, but much more touristy San Francisco trams (just to offer an example). There is an excellent 'Ding Ding' HK Tram Guide available on the Discover Hong Kong Website, includes maps and and area highlights. Its well worth a quick look prior to taking a ride on the 'ding ding'.

better than sliced bread. always love the double decker buses . took one to Stanl;ey market and from Aberdeen to Central skip the Big Bus tour check out the local bus service -clean , inexpensive and just as much fun
1 of the oldest public transport in HK island. they call it "ting-ting" its runs along main street in HK island & its cheaper than MTR

Great way to see Hong Kong. We used these trams to get a feel for the area. They are such fun to ride and really cheap. They only run on Hong Kong Island and have a fixed fare of $2.30 which you pay in a box at the end. There is no change given so small change is a must. They run every 2 minutes and we just waited for one that was not to crowded so we could sit upstairs at the front and do the tourist thing. Loved it!
Fun!. Making our way up and down the winding staircase and through the packed cable car was a bit challenging but sitting on the top level was a neat ride.

Brilliant way to see Hong Kong. The underground train service is the fastest way to get around Hong Kong, but, of course, you see nothing. The trams, on the other hand rattle along, and get stuck in traffic but you get to see the city. And they're really cheap -- two Hong Kong dollars and thirty cents which, in English money, is less than twenty pence. All journeys are the same price, stops are frequent, so you can just hop on and off. Locals use them all the time and they can be crowded, but it all adds to the experience! There's really just one line running the length of Hong Kong island so almost any destination will do -- the only one to avoid is Happy Valley which will take you on a detour. You get on at the back and off at the front -- if paying cash rather than Octopus Card, you put the money in a box by the driver. There's no change given, so ask at your hotel for some small coins.
An experience to behold. Used the tram from Wanchai to Westen Market and then to Kennedy only cheap with your card
Called the "Tang Tang" because of the bell. great price , get you everywhere on Hong Kong Island for 2.30
Nothing special. Worth taking a (cheap) ride but nothing special really

Authentic feeling. Took ding ding car from Sheung Wan (where the ferry to Macau departs) to Causeway Bay on a night after the Macau trip. Took the top level front seat on a Friday night. It was a 45mins journey to Causeway Bay as I watch the people, cars and bus moving on the roads. It feels great, nice view and wind from my seat enjoying the hustle and bustle of the CBD area.A ding ding car ride comes cheaper and more interesting that the MTR, only at HKD2.30! :) Loved the experience. Highly recommended if you are not rushing for time. Even if time is tight, would recommend shopping less to experience the ding ding car ride!

Nice way to spend some time. We took the subway out to the end of the cable car line and hopped onI think it was $2.30HKG each - pay when you get off - so it's practically free. Sure you don't see anything you wouldn't see from walking around, it moves rather slowly but its an experience worth having and that fact that its double decked is neat (especially for north americans because we don't really get that sort of stuff here). We road it from the far end to causeway bay - check the cable car there are a few different ones, most go in the same general direction but some turn, stop or go on a diversion.Also, on saturday morning(the day we took the car) there was a market close to the start of the cable car (the end farthest from central). Fruit, meat, clothes - there was a bakery there and a few other things. Being further from the tourist area it seemed rather cheap. We tried to go for dimsum but the menus were completely in chinese - but if you want to get away from the tourist area, but close to the subway or tram - this seems like a good place to go
Nice experience. A nice sightseeing to see HK island on the upper deck

An Experience but Not Transportation. We were recently in Hong Kong and on my list of things to do was to ride the open air double decker bus in Central on Hong Kong Island. My plan was to ride it from Western Market to North Point possibly in both directions to get a feel for the area.Well the first issue was where to get on. It seems that it runs down the middle of the street so while the normal buses run right at the curb, the open air double decker runs down the middle and I didn't see where I could board it. After exploring I discovered that there are only a couple of designated stops where there is a platform in the middle of the street, so off we went.Buses seemed to run pretty frequently and after just missing the first one we didn't have to wait long for the next one. But for some reason it looked like 100 people had the same idea. We boarded in the rear and headed upstairs to get a seat. Luckily we got the last one, the only problem was that it was in the back and faced to the center as opposed to the front. My suggestion is that if you want to experience the ride, wait until you see a bus pull up that is fairly empty and then jump on the get your seat. Our bus had standing room only both upstairs and down.Then let me tell you about the traffic. It was horrendous but since we weren't driving who cares. We were riding between 1-2pm so maybe this was luch hour related. I would suggest that you try to ride earlier in the moring to beat the lunch madhouse.You pay when you depart and you can use either cash or for us an Octopus Card. Made all of our traveling a little less hectic. We got off at Causeway Bay instead of riding to North Point and waited for a return bus that had less people and more enjoyable.
Way to site see. Get out your camera and enjoy the sites. Good way to take in the warm, sunny climate. Remember sunscreen!
Just like the old days. The Ding Ding as it is called by the locals, this tram takes you from Sai Wan to Shau Kei Wan passing through Central, Wan Chai, Causeway Bay and North Point.
Made in HK. Great and cheap... and slow. But who cares?! Don't miss it.

Great experience. Another bargain basement experience in Hong Kong! Although the routes are fairly limited, we just travelled around for a while to see all the sights. They can get pretty cramped at times.
Cheapest attraction and transport in hong kong. A bit of history and actually useful if you aren't in a rush. Can get crowded, but that's part of the experience.

A fun way to get a handle on Hong Kong. Really these are trams...not cable cars...and they go back to the older Hong Kong before buses, metro and other modern transport but they are a great fun way to see the main drag through Central and other areas such as Wan Chai. It costs almost nothing to use the trams and you pay the same whether you go one stop or 20 - about 3HK Dollars. Very authentic and still part of everyday transport for locals. A must-do!
Very nice !. A new expeariance , you must try this! If you have been here once you just have to come back !
Ride a piece of history in Hong Kong. While the double-decker trams are a bit slow, they are a great way to get around Hong Kong - if you have the time.

A Must to appreciate old Hong Kong. This was a really fun, but brief, ride along the old main streets of Hong Kong Island. Go upstairs so that you can see the other trolleys coming toward you. The neighborhoods like Wanchai are easy to see from the 2nd floor.

This is a double ding-ding. From East to West, you can see all of Hong Kong for 2.30 HK$. Really a great way to see the neighborhoods and the city scenes. Use the Octopus Pass! A little hot a humid depending on the weather.
Great fun and good views. a ride in the upstairs at sunset or later at night is fun, and bring your camera -- a very cheap way to see a bit more of HK from a HK perspective.

Great fun. We really enjoyed this tour, and we are not the sort of people who do tours ! But this was informative , fun and you can jump on and of as many times as you like . Buy the extended 48 hour package as it takes on 3 parts of Hong Kong, Kowloon and Stanley.
A great way to view the street life in Hong Kong. The double decked cable car is a great way to get a feel for the city and become acquainted with what's available to explore further.

A cheap, authentic way to navigate Hong Kong island. I traveled by plane, train, bus, ferry, cab, tram, foot, and the "ding ding," and the "ding ding" was my favorite. It was a great way to experience the true Hong Kong locals and see the various neighborhoods across the Hong Kong island.

Worth doing for the experience. Worth doing as a tourist thing to do for the experience. Extremely cheap to do also!
However, it is very small and squashed and you can't even get on during rush (peak) hour. I prefer taxi's as they're cheap anyways.

SO cheap - good way to see the island. It cost 2.3 HKD (~£0.22 GBP) per trip, pay when you get off.
Great way to move along the island, and cost's practically nothing. Good experience.
Recommend you use the "Ding Dong" (local term for the tram) atleast once on your visit!

An Excellent Way To Experience The Neighborhood. This is a unique feature in HKG island. The attractive looking trams are decorated with colorful ads. You get in from the back and pay when you alight, for a fare of only HKD2. It takes you into the neighborhood, a great way to see more of Hong Kong.We took the tram on a Wednesday noon, without any specific stop in mind. We simply jumped down at one stop, and then went to a neighborhood restaurant for a delicious roasted pork lunch. Took a stroll along the main street then took a tram back to Central. You can really see the transformation from Central to the neighborhood, which has many high rise residence.Check out the attractions at each stop here: http://www.discoverhongkong.com/tramguide/eng/index.jsp
DIng Ding. Catching the ding ding is part of the trip here, they are small and I had to keep ducking my head on the top level.Go to the top of the tram to enjoy some of the view.

Easy to use once you know how!. The trams are a very useful way of getting about on hong kong island-would be helpful to have a map of their route and stops(we didn't have one) as we had a bit of trial and error before we got to where we wanted to be. Buy an Octupus card from the MTR and you can simply pay on exit with this.

Cram on the Tram... You cannot miss this for HKD2.30. As a resident in HK, I wanted to provide an update on the Tram experience. When I first moved here, I wanted to try everything, test it all out, explore, experience - after all that’s why you travel isn’t it!! So cramming on the tram was an experience, but now two years later I am in agreement that this is truly one of the most cost effective ways of seeing HK. Just do it any other day than a Sunday or you will not enjoy the ride as you will be packed in like a sardine can!For a total of USD 0.30cents, / HKD$2.30 its definitely worth it. If you have a local octopus card you can just tap this as you exit, otherwise make sure you have the coins as like all transport in HK, you have the exact fare or you simply don’t get your change.The tram literally runs along the northern part of HK Island and shows a variety of different sites as you make your way from Witty Street Deport down through central, causeway bay and off through to North Point. The most enjoyable experience I have had on the trams is simply hopping on one end, and soaking up the sites as it makes it way to the other side of HK Island. A must for anyone who is visiting HK!
View from above. Great to see the city and people. Very cheap fare and best of all ... Air conditioned during the hot summer heat.

Great for people watching. HK is is quite spread out, so you may not always want to walk through the urban jungles! Why not take a tram, climb to the top floor and enjoy the views around the city from a bit of a hight! Great value too as costs only 2HKD!

Cheap ride and You can see the real Hong Kong neighborhood. You get on at the rear and get off at the front, pay $2.30 Hong Kong dollar as you exit, be warn you must have exact change or an Octopus card, one price for the whole journey, the most interesting portion of the ride is from Causeway Bay to Central, unless you want to peek into the other face of Hong Kong, you can never got lost, when you feel you had enough, just get off and look for a stop on the opposit side, it should bring you back where you start, it's safe on the car, no crime activity was ever reported, just act like you are in any other country, watch your belongs at all the time, it's hot in the afternoon, as there are no air condition, best time in late evening, never on weekends, get on when you see the car is not full, so you can have a seat up stair, otherwise don't get on at all, standing room only is not adviceable, enjoy the ride.

Great way to see Hong Kong neighbourhoods. The Hong Kong Tramways company has been in operations since 1904 (according to their website). In the past there were 2 fares, a cheaper one in the lower deck. But now there is one general, unbelievably low fare ot $2.30HKD (increased in July 2011 from $2) for any distance. Our favourite way of riding the tram is to get on at one of the end terminals (Shau Ki Wan in the east or Kennedy Town in the west) and go all the way to the other end of the island for a richly colourful and leisurely visual tour of the city. Along the way you would see the old dry goods stores in the Western District, financial district in Central, local neighbourhood life in Wanchai, a busy traffic light just outside Sogo Department Store in Causeway Bay, Victoria Park and the Central Library approaching North Point, and the market in Shau Ki Wan..... because the tram travels at a relative slow speed, you can take great photos of all the sights especially if you sit at the front on the upper deck.

We would just ride it all day. The tram experience was so culturally rich, my husband and I probably could have just stayed on there the whole time and just ride from the one side to the other and enjoy the view of the main streets of HK Island. It's impossible to get lost on those things, so if you forget to get off, just enjoy the ride...

An excellent way to spend HK$2. These old-fashioned tram cars are a blast to ride and a fun way to experience travel along the HK island major streets. The cost is just HK$2 per ride, making this ridiculously cheap and good value for money. In addition to the star ferry (our historical ferry boat) and the peak tram, this is our third historic means for transportation that has been well preserved. Like the others, HK manages to make continued use of the Cable Cars. The The advertisements lining the sides of the street trams are also interesting, helping add context and color to your photos of the districts between Causeway Bay all the way past the main central district. We recommend taking a ride on the cable car while you are touring HK island side attractions, you can hop and off for a quick ride, takes just 5-20 minutes depending on how long you want to stay on.
